div.head: TO THE SACRED MAJESTIE OF THE LADY ELIZABETH, QUEENE OF BOHEMIA.
div.p:
MOst Sacred Majestie, having before made some exposition upon the Proverbs of King Solomon, I have now done the same upon his Preaching. For seeing so great a King was pleased to be a Preacher, I have brought the homage of a Preacher to him. My former labours received the honour of Patronage from your Royall Brother, my dread Soveraigne, to whom the God of mercy and glory be a gratious Patron, and a safe defender: these labours most humbly beseech the same from your Sacred Majestie. For seeing, when I was your ordinary Chaplaine, I had long and often in expounding other parts of Scripture, the gracious attention of your hearing, I desire that the world may read these with the favourable light of your Patronage. It is but a beame of that illustrious and
splendent light shining in you which I crave, and which though clouded with many trials, yet breaks out gloriously in heavenly patience, spirituall cheerfulnesse, divine courage, noble courtesie. To put these, and many other graces in one, God hath made you, the onely Daughter of a famous King deceased, the only Sister of a glorious King alive, that all might looke upon you to his greater glory. And he that hath made you the mirror of his praise for others to looke upon, vouchsafe himselfe to looke upon you as the object of his graciousnesse. He that is the only wise God be your pretious comforter: he that is the only Sonne of God be your mercifull Saviour, and make you glorious in the happinesse of heaven, who hath made you so glorious in the troubles of the earth.

closer.signed: Your Majesties in all devoted and obliged serviceablenesse of heart, MICHAEL JERMIN.

div.head: To the Christian Reader.
div.p:
CHristian Reader, to make ashort commentary upon mine owne mind in publishing this commentary upon the Booke of Ecclesiastes: I desire that God may be glorified by the knowledge of his Word, and that the Church of God may be illightned in the knowledge of it, and that the discharge of my duety to the Church might be in some sort expressed. For though the Scriptures be the firmament of the Church, in which the Sun of truth shineth, the Moone of knowledge is in her full brightnesse, and where there are a multitude of starres of most excellent and divine light; yet such are the clouds of humane ignorance, such the mists of our corrupted nature, that we perceive but darkly the beauty and glory of them. If therefore such means be used, as that these clouds may be in some measure cleared, and the thicknesse of these mists in some part lesned, it is not a labour that needeth to be judged of, as needlesly bestowed. As for this booke of the Preacher, such is the blindnesse of the eyes of many in the reading of it, that mistaking utterly his heavenly meaning, from hence they frame pretences for their owne earthly and voluptuous living. But such also are many passages of this booke,
that even they who have the sharpest sight, must acknowledge a dimnesse of their eyes when they looke upon them. Where if my small candle hath given any light, the whole praise be given unto the Father of lights: if it hath cast a false light, I presume that they who discerne it, will not be misled by it, I hope that they who discerne it, shall receive no hurt by it. For though we may not walke in the way of a right understanding, in all things, yet if we doe walke in the way of a right faith, and of a godly life, we shall be sure not to misse the way unto eternall life, which God of his mercy grant to us all for his Sonne Jesus Christs sake. The faults of the printing had not been so many and great, had mine health beene greater, that I could have lookd after it. But let thy courtesie be the physicke to cure them, and for many of them there is a remedy set downe in the end of the booke, where seeing thou mayest easily correct them, be not hasty to condemne them. Farewell

closer.signed: Thine in CHRIST JESUS, Michael Jermin.

div.head: A COMMENTARY VPON THE WHOLE BOOKE OF ECCLESIASTES.
The Preface.
div.p:
GRegory Nyssene writing upon this booke, beginneth thus:Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 1.
Nobis Ecclesiasten proponimus exponendum, qui magnitudini utilitatis habet parem laborem contemplationis: Ecclesiastes is proposed to be expounded by us, which is a Booke, that to answer the great profit of it, requireth great paines in him that shall goe about it, and not onely great paines, but also great abilities, to be able to reach the height, to fathome the depth of it: And what then can be expected, Hac qualicunque
lucubratiuncula mea, Hugo de Sanct. Vict. Praesat. in Ecclesiast. iter ad intelligentiam praeeunte? From this my dimme light, shewing the way for understanding of it? But seeing Christ hath commanded us to search the Scriptures, let me have leave to search this booke of Scripture as I can; trusting that He, Qui scrutandi dedit praeceptum, ad hoc etiam omnino dabit vires, who hath given the commandement for searching, will also give strength in some measure, for the doing of it.

div.head: The generall scope of the Booke.
div.p:
THe greatest labour of Philosophers hath been to finde out the greatest good of man; wherein what hath their labour been, but a labyrinth, in which themselves being lost, they were farre from finding that which they sought? But this being the scope of the Royall Philosopher, the Ecclesiasticall King of Israel in this Booke, he shews where it is, by shewing it not to be in the things of this world: he declareth what it is, by declaring what wee must be in the feare of the Lord, and in keeping his Commandements. It is a mistake, as some thinke,Picolomineus. of the meaning of Epicurus, to imagine that he placed the chiefe good of man in a sensuall pleasure; but that he intended the sweet delight of vertue, and therein the happy contentment of mans minde, to be the bed of rest unto it. Now much more are they mistaken, who thinke that in this book a luxurious pleasure is commended to us: seeing it is from a discommendation of worldly things, in respect of the vanitie of them,Hieronym. in Ecclesiast. Et quae dum tenentur, intereunt, and which are still in loosing even while they are kept, as St. Hierome speaketh, that the Preacher laboureth to make us to deny the world: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and to seate the minde above a sensuall contentment, as a Greek Father expresseth the purpose of this booke. The things whereof the vanitie is here weighed unto us, are by Hugo de Sancto Victore reduced unto three heads, as being, Aut quae propter homines facta sunt, aut quae ab hominibus facta sunt, aut quae in hominibus facta sunt, Either those
things which were made for men, or those things which are made by men, or those which are made in men.Hugo de Sancto Victore in Ecclesiast. Homil. 1.
In his quae ab hominibus facta sunt, vanitas est curiositatis, in his quae propter homines facta sunt, vanitas est mutabilitatis, in his quae in hominibus facta sunt, vanitas est mortalitatis, In those things that are made by men there is the vanitie of curiositie, in those things that are made for men, there is the vanitie of mutabilitie, in those things that are made in men, there is the vanitie of mortalitie. The way which I shall follow in tracing out the sense of what is here delivered, shall be by walking in the steps of a literall exposition, because that it is to which the Preachers hand leadeth me. And yet because there may be some things, as an ancient Writer noteth, Spiritualiter intelligenda, non negligenter praetereunda, spiritually to be understood, and not to be omitted negligently, I shall sometimes turne aside to meet with a mystery, that may bring profit with it: they being alike to be condemned, Qui mysticam intelligentiam vel inquirendam pertinaciter negant, ubi est, vel apponendam superstitiose contendunt, ubi non est, who wilfully refuse to seeke for a mysticall sense, where it is to be had, and who superstitiously strive in seeking for it, where it is not to be had, as the same Authour addeth.

epigraph.q: VER. 1. The words of the Preacher the Sonne of David King of Jerusalem.

div.p:
Verse 1. WE have here not onely the title of the Authour expressed by three names, but also the office of a Governour set forth by three duties. First, that he must be a Preacher, in teaching those that are under him: secondly, that he must be a Sonne, in being himselfe obedient to that which hee teacheth: thirdly, that he must be a King, in commanding and exacting that those things be performed which are taught by him. But to consider them as the titles of the Authour, set downe to procure the better regard of what he writeth. First, he is called the Preacher: and if wee take the reason to be, because these words were written by Solomon, to be read in the Church and Congregation;Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 1. then Gregory Nyssene asking the question, why this booke rather then others should be called the words of the Preacher, seeing that Moyses and the Prophets were read in the Church and Congregation also; he giveth a good answer to it: because in other bookes, there are many things of Warres, and Cities, and Countries, and Mariages, which are not so profitable
for the Church of God,Gregor. Nyssene in Ecclesiast. Homil. 1.
Hujus autem libri doctrina ad solam Ecclesiasticam conversationem pertinet, ut quae ea explicet, per quae quis rectè & ex virtute vitam instituat, but the Doctrine of this booke belongeth onely to an Ecclesiasticall conversation, as speaking of those things by which any one may leade a vertuous and a godly life. Or else if we take this booke to be written by Solomon after his repentance, as the Iewes affirme, then we may conceive him to be called the Preacher or Ecclesiastes, as making his repentance in the Church, to which by his repentance he was againe joyned, and as thereby teaching repentance unto others. And then the Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 rendred the Preacher, being of the feminine gender, in which regard some say, that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
anima the soule is to be added to it, filling up the place thus, The words of the preaching soule, it very well agreeth to Solomons penitent soule, grieved for the sinfull pleasures of his body. It may be noted also that it is sayd, The words of the Preacher, because in this booke he speaketh with the words of diverse, sometimes of himselfe, sometimes of some other person. And therefore in the end of the booke, as it were speaking unto all, in whose words he had spoken, and shutting up their many words in a few, but containing the whole truth, Eccles. 12.13. he sayth; Let us heare the conclusion of the whole matter, feare God and keepe his Commandements, for this is the whole dutie of man. Secondly, he is called the Sonne of David, as walking in the steps of his Father David, both in the course of his repentance, and in the wayes of godlinesse, which here he teacheth. Thirdly, he is called the King of Ierusalem, because in Ierusalem the glory of the world being chiefly shewed, the vanities of the world being most of all embraced, it is to them more especially that he writeth, to make them contemne the glory of worldly things, to make them to see the vanitie of them. But seeing to the Sonne of David, to the King of Ierusalem (or else the King in Ierusalem, as the Originall more directly is) is added the Preacher; Forte ad ducem ecclesiae intuetur inscriptio, perhaps the inscription casteth an eye to him who is the Captaine and Leader of his Church, (as a Greeke Father speaketh) to Christ, who is indeede the Preacher of righteousnesse, who is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Ecclesiastes, congregans coetum, gathering into one Church both Iewes and Gentiles, and calling together into one Congregation, those who were scattered in the errours of iniquitie. He is the Sonne of David, to whom the whole multitude sang their Hosanna. He is the King of Ierusalem, of that Ierusalem, which is the Citie of the great King. He was King in Ierusalem, being there crowned with thornes, being there lifted up on the throne of his crosse. Non ad eum fit verbum Dei, Hieronym. in Ecclesiast. sicut ad caeteros prophetas, sed ipse est verbum, verba{que} loquitur ad ecclesiae viros; The word of the Lord doth not come to him, as to the other Prophets, but he is the word, and he speaketh words to the men of the Church, as S. Hierome hath it.

q.p: VER. 2. Vanitie of vanities, sayth the Preacher, vanitie of vanities, all is vanitie.
VER. 3. What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the Sunne?

div.p:
Verse 2. After the three titles of the Authour, Hugo de Sancto Victore conceiveth Solomon, to set downe the summe of the three parts of his book in the three following verses. In this verse the vanitie of mutabilitie, which is handled from the first verse unto the twelfth verse of this Chapter: in the next verse, the vanitie of curiositie or desire, which is handled from the twelfth verse of this Chap. unto the twelfth Chapter: in the following verses, the vanitie of mortalitie, which is handled from the beginning of the twelfth Chapter to the end of it, and of the booke. The same Authour speaking of these vanities sayth;Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Prima vanitas naturalis est, & apta sive congrua: secunda vanitas culpabilis est quia perversa: tertia vanitas poenalis & misera. Prima causa est peccati; secunda peccatum; tertia poena peccati; The first vanitie is naturall, and fit for the nature of worldly things; the second is sinfull, because perverse and froward; the third penall and miserable. The first is the occasion of sinne, the second is sinne, the third is the punishment of sinne. But to consider the verse in it selfe. The Preacher which is the first of the titles in the former verse, is here the onely title of the Authour, as shewing that to be his proper title as Authour of this booke. Or else it sheweth that in his repentance, he esteemed this title above all: and that he thought this to be more glorious unto him, then that he was either the sonne of so great a King, or else so great a King himselfe. An ancient Writer sayth of this part of the verse, Sayth the Preacher, Cum pondere pronuntiandum est, that it is to be pronounced with a weighty emphasis. He sayth it, who in his sinfull folly did not consider it: he sayth it, who hath sayd so much of so many things: he sayth it, who being the Sonne of a wise King, was himselfe the wisest King that ever was or shall be. Quod ergo tantus, & talis dixit, vanum esse non potuit, etiamsi de vanitate dixit, Wherefore that which one so great, and such a one hath sayd, cannot be vaine, although he hath sayd it of vanitie. But if all things be vanitie, then himselfe also, who spake this, is vanitie. And if vanitie speake, what can it be but vaine that is spoken? To answer this: it was not himselfe in speaking this that spake, it was the spirit of God that gave him utterance. And therefore Hugo de Sancto Victore sayth, Vbi putatis mens erat hujus hominis, quum haec diceret? Homo erat, sed supra hominem erat. Quia nisi hominem excederet, omnem hominem mendacem esse non videret? Where doe yee thinke was the minde of this man, when he sayd these things? He was a man, but yet above a man: because unlesse he did exceed a man, he could not have seene that all men are vanitie. But to consider what he
sayth, what the Spirit of God meaneth by vanitie, the Spirit of God can best tell us: Jere. 16.19. who doth himselfe explane it, when the Prophet Ieremiah acknowledgeth, Surely our Fathers have inherited lyes, vanitie, and things wherein there is no profit. The vanitie then whereof the Preacher speaketh, is the lying promises of contentment which worldly things make, and the no-profit which is made of them. Vanitie of vanities, sayth the Preacher, that is, the vanitie of them, is even more then vanitie: and as if he would say more, but could not, he sayth the same againe: and least he should not have sayd all, yet he addeth, All is vanitie. Saint Hierome tels us, that in all translations besides the Septuagint, the words are rendred 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
vapor vaporum, Hieronym. in hunc vers. a vapour of vapours, as shewing, that as a vapour being the extraction of the thinnest part of any thing, if the thinnest part of a vapour should be extracted also, the thinnesse of that would be exceeding great: so the vanitie of worldly things, which is a vanitie of vanities, to be exceeding great also. But doth not this redound to the dishonour of the Creatour, if all things created by him in this world be so strangely vaine? Clemens Alexandrinus apprehendeth,Clemens Alexan. strom. l. 5. that it was from a mistake of the meaning of this verse, that Epicurus affirmed, Omnia temere ferri, All things to be caried lightly and vainely. Wherefore that wee may not mistake also, Saint Gregory tels us the meaning to be,Gregorius. M. in c. 12. Pri. Samuel. In comparatione aeternorum bonorum vana esse omnia, etiam bona temporalia, In comparison of eternall good things, even all things to be vaine, yea, although they be good things temporally. Which is indeed most true, but I conceive the Preachers speech to intend rather the vanities of mans life, then to be uttered of the creatures generally. But having considered, who it is that sayth it, what it is that is sayd, I will say no more, but that which S. Chrysostome speaketh of this verse,Chrysost. Epistola ad Eutropium. Hunc versiculum si saperent, qui in potestate sunt, in parietibus omnibus & in vestibus scriberent, in foro, in domo, in januis, in ingressibus, & ante omnia in conscientiis suis, ut semper eum oculis cernerent, & corde sentirent. This verse, if they who are great in this world were wise, they would write on all their wals and garments, in their common meeting places, in their private houses, on their dores, in their entries, and above all in their consciences, that so they might alwayes see it before their eyes, alwayes consider it in their minds.

q.p: VER. 4. One generation passeth away, and another commeth, but the earth abideth for ever.
VER. 5. The Sunne also ariseth, and the Sunne goeth downe, and hasteth to the place, where it arose.
VER. 6. The wind goeth toward the South, and turneth about unto the North: it whirleth about continually, and the wind returneth againe according to his courses.
VER. 7. All the rivers come into the Sea, yet the Sea is not full; unto the place from whence all the rivers come, thither they returne againe.

div.p:
Clem: Alex. Stromat: 5.
Ver. 4. Clemens Alexandrinus who sheweth the theft of Philosophers from the sacred Scriptures, might easily have shewed, that Aristotle tooke from hence his principles, that Materia prima, The first matter, which is as it were the earthly foundation of things abideth for ever, and that Corruptio unius est generatio alterius, the corruption of one thing is the generation of another, the passing away of one generation is the comming of another. But to view the words. A generation, is, the number of men, which at any time are living together upon the earth, according as the derivation of the Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth give us to understand, and so long as any of them are alive, so long doth that generation continue.
Now ever since that the first man passed away from his obedience unto GODS Law, and that sinne came into the world, thus it hath beene still, that one passeth away, and another commeth: one passeth away that the other may come, the other commeth to passe away also, Et hanc viam omnes post ipsum per transeunt, qui ab ipso per carnis nativitatem descendunt. And this way doe all passe after him, who by the birth of the flesh are come from him, as one saith. The force of the verse, as it followeth the former, is this, If you cannot beleeve but that mans labour doth get him some profit, yet what profit is it, when it cannot bee enjoyed? And how can it bee enjoyed, when man himselfe passeth away? Or else the force is this, if you thinke it a thing not to bee regarded, that what you doe is vanity: is that also not to bee regarded, that yee your selves are vanity? For yee passe away. And were it but a few, or if many, were it not all, the miserable vanity were the lesse, but it is the whole generation that passeth away, and though another commeth, the other by passing away, hath shewed it the way which it must passe likewise. But seeing it passeth away, whither doth it passe? When it commeth, from whence doth it come? Surely, this also sheweth the great vanity of men. For all can say, Hinc abeundum, Hence we must: but quò transeundum, whither then, none can tell. All have a comming; but whence they come, none brings the newes with them. The Preacher therefore only saith, One generation passeth away, and another commeth. The originall doth expresse it selfe by a participle, and thereby sheweth, that it doth not only passe away, as it were when the time commeth, but is continually passing away, and never abideth, which as it maketh the vanity the more, so it is still made more, in that the earth abideth for ever. The element which is so much beneath man, that element which a man treadeth under his feete. (For as the latine word terra, is taken a terendo from breaking and wearing, so the Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is taken from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth to breake and to weare also,) even the earth which is trampled on abideth, when man passeth away. Man was made of the earth, yet man vanisheth, and the earth continueth: the earth was made for man, yet man passeth away and the earth standeth still. The earth standeth, and standeth in testimonium & poenam culpae hominis, for a monument of mans sinne, and punishment, bringing forth bryars and thornes unto him. The earth standeth, and standeth up an accuser against man. For so Olympiodorus speaketh,Olympiodor. in Ecclesiast. Terra quidem in perpetuum stat, accusatrix vestra effecta, in qua nefaria opera purpetrastis, The earth indeed standeth for ever, being made an accuser against y, for the evill deeds which yee have committed in it. The earth standeth, Vt venientes mittat, pertranseuntes portet, discedentes recipiat, to send those people that come, to beare those that are passing away, to receive those that are gone, as Hugo de Sancto Victore speaketh.Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 1. But doth the earth stand for ever? If we take it, in a mystery for the Church, as Saint Gregory doth, then most true it is, that it abideth for ever, Quia sancta
ecclesia in hoc saeculo a catholica fide nequaquam deficiet, & in futuro cum Deo aeterna stabilitate permanebit, Gregor. in 7. Psalmos Poenitentiales. Because the holy Church in this world shall never faile from the Catholike faith, in the next, shall abide with God for ever setled. And then wee may understand the generation which passeth away to be the Iewes, the generation that commeth to be the Gentiles, Hieron. in Ecclesiast. the Christians, as Saint Hierome doth. Or else if we may here understand a mystery, wee may take the generation that passeth away, for that which was made out of the earth, the generation that commeth for that which shall be raised out of the earth, and that the earth is said to abide for ever, because it shall continue untill this be done. But to keepe to the letter.Tremellius in hunc vers. The earth is said to abide for ever, in respect of the vanity and shortnesse of mans life, which is so quickly gone. Or else it is said to abide for ever, because it is a thing unknowne to men, or Angels how long it shall continue. For the originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is taken from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth to lye hid, and speaketh of that continuance, the continuance, and the ceasing whereof is a thing unkowne and concealed. But what is it that maketh the earth to abide so firmely? Surely let Philosophers search for a reason of it, let us abide satisfied with that of Saint Ambrose, Ambros. l. 1. Exam. c. 16.
Non fulcris suis stabilis perseverat, sed Dominus fundavit eam, They are not her owne pillars that doe beare it up, but the Lord hath founded it.

Ver. 5. The generall exposition among the Ancients given of this Verse, and of the two following, is, that by the vanity of these creatures is set forth the vanity of man.Greg. Nys. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 1. And therefore Gregory Nyssene saith, O homines qui universitatem aspicitis, vestram ipsorum naturam intelligite, O men who doe behold the universe, understand your owne nature in it, Est ad solis similitudinem nostrae quo{que} naturae ortus & occasus: una est omnibus via, unus ingressus vitae circulus, There is of our nature a rising, and a going downe, as of the Sunne: there is one way to all, wee all walke one circle of life. But as I conceive, this ariseth not to the meaning of the place. For as in the Verse before the Preacher comparing man with the earth, shewed the vanity of man to be greater than the earth is subject to: So in these following verses he compareth the vanity of man with the Sunne, and wind, and waters, shewing it to bee greater, than that which they have in them. This verse speaketh of the Sunne,Zanchius de operibus Dei. which though a glorious creature, and as Zanchius speaketh, Gloriosior quod alios illuminet, quam quod ipse luceat, more glorious that it illightneth others, then that it is so bright in it selfe, yet much inferiour is it unto mans beauty and glory. Notwithstanding the Preacher shewing the transitory vanity of man, preferreth the Sunne before it: which though in motion it passeth on from rising to going downe, yet passeth not away, but returneth to his place, as Symmachus and Theodotio did translate the word: or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as Aquila translated it, that is, saith Saint Hierome aspirat, and so doth Tremellius translate it, attaineth to his place. Our English saith, hasteth, the French very well, ahane, laboureth hard towards his place, as one that bloweth labouring:
and which though labouring, yet laboureth not in vaine, but commeth to his place. Man passeth away, and his place beholdeth him no more,
Iob 20.9. as Zophar speaketh in Iob: but the Sunne commeth to his place, that is, to the poynt where his circular motion is terminated and accomplished: for as the place of any thing is, that wherein it stayeth; so that is sayd to be the place of the Sunne, because there it stayeth from going to any other poynt, wherein it hath not been before. The Sunne commeth to his place 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
& oritur ipse ibi, and it selfe ariseth there, as Saint Hierome rightly translateth the Hebrew; whereas man passeth away, and another ariseth in his place. Now this being the proper translation of the Originall words, doth much confirme that to be the meaning of the verse which I have delivered. Saint Ambrose, as also St. Hierome applying this verse in a mystery to Christ, shew how that he is the Sunne, Qui oritur justis, & occidit injustis, which riseth to the righteous, and shineth upon them, but goeth downe to the unrighteous, and leaveth them in darknesse: but then they doe also both of them reade the next words thus, Trahit ad locum suum, draweth to his place,Ambros. in Psal. 119. Octon. 12. and applying it to Christ, say, that he being gone to heaven, doth draw the desires of all men unto him.

Verse 6. The Septuagint doe make the first part of this verse to belong to the former verse, as if the Preacher spake it of the Sunne, That he goeth to the South, and returneth about to the North: and thereupon Saint Ambrose applying it mystically to Christ, sayth that he went first to the South, first to the Iewes, Ad nobiliorem plebem, quae erat genus electum, vendicans sibi Patriarcharum prosapiam, The more noble people, which was a chosen Nation, challenging to themselves their descent from the Patriarchs: but because these persisted in their wickednesse, he returned about to the North, Gyravit ad Gentes, Ambros. in Psal. 119. Octon. 12. He came about to the Gentiles. But to take the words as a part of this verse, and as applyed to the winde, for so the Originall doth apply them. Wee have here the vanitie of man compared to the winde: and though that may be conceived to be of all things most vaine, most light; yet here mans vanitie is shewed to be greater. And whereas Iob sayth, Iob 7.7. O remember that my life is winde; the Preacher sayth, that it is more vaine then winde. For though the winde passe on speedily, and passe away quickly, though most inconstantly it passe from place to place, and every way turneth it selfe, which our Translation hath, whirleth about continually, yet it returneth still, and going from the North, it commeth backe to the North againe: but it is not so with man: and that which Iob speaketh of himselfe, is true of every man, When a few yeares are come,
Iob 16.22. I shall goe the way whence I shall not returne. That this is the meaning of the verse, the Originall sheweth by the conclusion of it, where it is sayd, Vadi • ventus & revertitur super circulos suos, the winde goeth and returneth againe upon his circles, Atque in se sua per vestigia volvitur, and is turned into it selfe, by its owne steps, as the Poet speaketh: as if the Preacher did bid us to note, that although the winde goeth toward the South,
and returneth unto the North, that though it turne never so many wayes whirling continually, yet that the going of it hath his returnes in the circles of it: whereas the passing breath of mans life hath no returne. But though man being gone from his naturall life cannot returne, yet being gone from his spirituall life, he may and should returne. In this it were good, if man were like the winde, and being gone to the South of sinfull lusts and pleasures, to the South of vaine and worldly contentments, it were good that he would returne to the North of sorrow and repentance for his sinnes, for his vanities; and having wandred here and there, and whirled about continually in the giddy mazes of iniquitie, it were good that he would returne according to his circuits, and goe backe to God by the contrary courses of amendment. This is that which God calleth for so earnestly, Cantic. 6.13. saying, Returne, returne O Shulamite, returne, returne. Where the word returne being foure times repeated, Saint Bernard sayth, that wee are called to returne from foure things,Bern. Par. Serm. 58.
Primò ab inepta laetitia, secundò ab inutili tristitia, tertiò ab inani gloria, quartò a latenti superbia, First, from a foolish mirth, secondly, from an unprofitable sadnesse, thirdly, from a vaine ostentation, fourthly, from a hidden pride. For these being the vanities of the world, from these wee must returne, to goe to God, to come to happinesse.

Verse 7. Here the vanitie of man is compared to the Rivers, which though they goe away likewise, yet it is but into the Sea: from whence as they come forth, so thither their returne is, that from thence they may come forth againe. And therefore as one speaketh, Dum mare sine intermissione recipit quod effudit, sine defectu effundit quod recipit, & fit defectus sine defectu, while the Sea without ceasing receiveth that which it sendeth forth, it sendeth forth without ceasing that which it receiveth, and so the passing away of the Rivers is not a passing away. But the passing away of men is into the bottomlesse gulph of death, from whence is no issuing forth: that devoureth all, sendeth backe none, which sheweth the vanitie of men to be worse then of the Rivers. And that this is the meaning, appeareth from the words. For when it is sayd, All the rivers run into the Sea, yet the Sea is not full, why is this added, but to shew that the end why the Rivers goe into the Sea, is not to fill it, seeing that is not filled, that is, is not filled the more by them. But what then is the end why the Rivers goe into the Sea? The Originall plainly sheweth, and as it is rightly translated by the Septuagint, and by the Vulgar Latine it cleerely appeareth. For say they, Ad locum unde exeunt flumina, revertuntur, ut iterum fluant, the Rivers returne to the place from whence they came, that they may flow againe. Wherefore in their flowing againe, they are not so vaine as man, who in his flowing away hath no reflux allowed him. Saint Gregory in a morall sense applyeth this verse unto Preachers, who having studied and meditated of heavenly things, doe then send them forth, for the watering of the Lords fields;Greg. Mor. l. 30. c. 3. and when they have done so, doe then returne to studying and meditating againe. Because unlesse they doe this, Interna caecitas etiam
externa praedicationis verba siccabit, An inward ignorance, will dry up the outward words of their preaching. But by this meanes, Quasi decursura foras flumina intus semper oriuntur, quatenus illic amando sumunt, unde ad nos praedicando defluunt, the rivers which flow forth abroad, doe arise within continually, for as much as from them they take by a studious love, those things which by preaching flow forth to us. Or else in a morall sense, we may apply the verse another way.Caesarius, Dialog. 1. And as Caesarius the brother of Nazianzene saith, Pulchrum quo{que} quod quum mare fluminum sit mater, ipsum eadem rursus suscipit; hinc quidem quasi inlucem proferens, illinc vero recipiens quasi hospites, This also is delightfull, that whereas the Sea is the mother of the rivers, it selfe doth receive the same againe: now bringing them forth as it were into the light, then receaving them, as it were guests unto her. So may we admire the Sea of Gods goodnesse, who by his Holy Spirit having brought forth the children of grace, when by their holy obedience they doe returne unto him, doth entertaine them as welcome guests with all respects of love. Now as all this ought to humble us; so it must stirre us up to the seeking of a better life, seeing in this life so many of the creatures doe excell us.

epigraph.q: VER. 8. All things are full of labour, man cannot utter it: the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the eare with hearing.

div.p:
Verse 8. The verse saith, All things are full of labour, and it is not an easie thing, it is not a little labour to find the meaning of the verse. Howsoever the ancient expositours may have satisfied themselves in the understanding of it, that which they say doth not satisfie me. The Originall may be translated, either Omnes res all things, and so doe the septuagint and the vulgar latine read it, or else omnes sermones, all words, and so doe Gregory Nyssene and Saint Hierome reade it. In that which followeth, the Originall saith no more then this, Non potest homo eloqui, man cannot expresse. Our English applyeth it unto labour, saying, Man cannot utter it. The Ancients apply it either to the things, or to the words, saying, Man cannot expresse them. As for the meaning of the Verse, the Ancients understood it of the knowledge of things, which it is laborious and difficult for man to get: and seeing man doth not know what things are, much lesse can hee expresse what they are. The eye is not satisfied with seeing, man cannot by his owne study, find the knowledge of things: the eare is not filled with hearing, man cannot learne the knowledge of things by the hearing of others.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Wherefore Saint Hierome saith that it is written Contra eos qui putant otiosis sibi & vota facientibus, venire notitiam scripturarum, Who thinke that the knowledge of the Scriptures
will come unto them,Hugo de Sancto Vict. Homil. 1. in Ecclesiast. being idle and wishing for it only: Hugo de Sancto Victore understandeth the latter part of the verse thus, That although man doth not attaine to the knowledge of things, yet that which hee attaineth unto, doth give him that sweet delight, that hee still seeketh more, and that the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the eare filled with hearing. Wherefore hee saith, Cor humanum toti mundo non sufficit: & totus mundus cordi humano non sufficit, The heart of man is not sufficient for the whole world, and the whole world is not sufficient for the heart of man. The first he sheweth, because all things are hard to be understood, and man cannot expresse what they are: The second, because the eye is not satisfied, nor the eare filled with seeing and hearing. Gregory Nyssene expounding the verse as being translated, Omnes sermones sunt laboriosi, All words are full of labour, man cannot utter them, tells us, that nothing is more easie then to speake, and therefore that we must understand the Preacher of those words, whereof the Apostle speaking saith,1 Tim. 5.17. That they are worthy of double honour who labour in the word. Sermones ergo sunt qui verè sunt sermones, qui fiunt ad animarum utilitatem. The words therefore (saith he) are those, which are truly words, and which are spoken to the profit of soules. And such words (saith he) are full of labour, because they who teach them must be carefull to follow them in their owne lives. But if a man cannot expresse those words, how can he utter that Aeternall word of God? The Father addeth truely,Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 1.
Quaevis certè quantumvis sublimis oratio, & vox quantumvis magna est obscuritas quaedam & silentium, si ad veram ejus quod quaeritur judicetur significationem, Whatsoever speech it be, though never so high, whatsoever voice, though never so great, it is but darkenesse and silence, if compared with the true signification of that which is sought. But to deliver mine apprehension of the meaning of the verse: I conceive the Preacher to say, That all things desired by man are full of labour, full of wearinesse in the seeking of them, which is a misery unto him: and that the misery is made the greater, for as much as the desire of man is not full, not wearied in the seeking of them. For as one well speaketh, Magna est miseria semper ad indigentiam accipere, & nunquam indigentiâ accipiendi posse carere, It is a great misery, alwayes to receive for the supplying of our want, and never to want the need of receiving. And yet this is the vaine condition of man in this world. So that as Saint Ambrose speaketh,Ambros. de Bono mortis c. 7.
Nullus finis laboris, nullus est fructus abundantiae, there is no end of his labour, no fruit of his abundance to satisfie his desire. Or else, I take the meaning of the Preacher thus: That all things being full of wearinesse even when they are enjoyed, yet that man is not weary in the desiring of them. And the things desired or enjoyed by man belonging either to the body or to the soule, the unsatisfied desire of things belonging to the body, is expressed by the eye, of things belonging to the soule is expressed by the eare.

q.p: VER. 9. The thing which hath beene, is that which shall be, and that which is done, is that which shall bee done, and there is no new thing under the Sunne.
VER. 10. Is there any thing whereof it may bee said, See this is new? It hath beene already of old time, which was before us.
VER. 11. There is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be any remembrance of things that are to come, with those that shall come after.

div.p:
Verse 9. Man, whose fickle changeablenesse cannot fasten upon the permanency of any thing, doth seeke to settle his contentment in the newnesse of things. But this also the Preacher declareth to be vaine, shewing here that there is nothing new, neither that which shall bee, nor that which is, because that which shall be, hath beene, that which is, shall be. The kind of things is still the same, the contentment which they yeeld is still the same in the nature of it, the vanity of the things, and of the delight taken in them is still the same, for there is nothing new under the Sunne. If we will have new things, we must goe above the Sunne. There indeed are new things of another nature, things of eternity, things of true contentment, things in which there is no vanity. But that we may attaine to these, we must be new creatures by amendment of our life: the old man must be crucified in us, that we may be glorified in these new things. The Septuagint, Saint Hierome and the Vulgar Latin, doe read this verse by way of question and answer, saying, Quid est quod fuit? Ipsum quod futurum est. Quid est quod factum est? Ipsum quod faciendum est, What is that which hath beene? The very same which shall be. What is that which hath beene done? The very same which shall bee done. And surely in naturall things it is a thing most evident, a certaine course and constant order being still observed in them. As for civill affaires, which are swayed and caryed by the will of man, he that shall duely marke them, even in the greatest variety and inconstancy thereof, shall find a revolution, whereby they are turned about in one and the same circle. Wherefore hence it is that the knowledge of Histories is accounted so excellent, because setting things past before our eyes, it shewes us how to order the things
that are present. So that they who are taken up with novelty and stand so much amazed at it, doe thereby but give the greater testimony of their great ignorance in things that are past, being indeed like children or rude Country people, by whom many things are received and admired as new and strange, which in the City and Court, are common, stale, and of no regard. But seeing there is nothing new, let this bridle our restlesse desire in seeking after new things, let us fasten our minds with this nayle, and make them contented with things that are present, least skipping hither and thither, now after one thing, then another, we take away quietnesse which is the only solace of our life. Gregory Nyssene having here a peculiar exposition of this passage, let me have leave to set it downe. He reading the verse by way of a question, supposeth that the Preacher having shewed all things, that are, to be vaine, doth here aske the question, What is to be conceived of those things which have been? And that answering he telleth us, that as things shall be, so they were, that is, as they shall be renued to a perfection in the resurrection, so they were made in perfection in the creation. And then we may take the following words to signifie: but that as yet there is nothing under the Sunne renued from the vanitie thereof. There must be a new heaven,Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 1. and a new earth, when that shall be. The same Father observing the difference of phrase that is used, in, Hath been, and Hath been done, applyeth the one to the soule, the other to the body. For (sayth he) Fuit seu orta est anima, & corpus factum est, The soule was or began to be; but the body was made. The soule therefore which was without sinne, shall be purged, and shall be so againe: the body as it was first made, so shall it be made againe. Neque enim est aliquid aliud resurrectio nisi quae sit omnino in pristinum statum restitutio, for (sayth he) the resurrection is nothing else but a restitution into the former state and condition.

Verse 10. This verse is added, to expresse more fully, more forceably the sense of the former: and because worldly mindes imagine to themselves, a newnesse, a varietie of some things, wherewith their delight is much taken; the Preacher therefore sayth, whatsoever any one may imagine to himselfe, or others may admire; Is there any thing whereof it may be truely sayd, See this is new? Or seeing the Originall goes thus, Estne verbum, quod dicat? Is there a word which may say? Wee may take it thus. Is there any new word to be invented, that may set forth any new thing? The answer of the common saying is, Nihil jam dictum, quod non sit dictum prius, there is nothing now sayd, which was not sayd before. And the answer of the Preacher is, that all things are so farre from being new, that they are old, and have been already of old time. But because the former verse may also have another meaning, that will give another sense unto this. When it is sayd therefore, The thing which hath been, it is that which shall be, wee may conceive the meaning to be, That as that which hath been, is not now, so that which shall be, is not yet, and so both doe shew their vanitie in their not being. When it is
sayd, That which is done, is that which shall be done, we may take the sense to be, that also the thing which is, is much what the same with that which shall be, because it is so little time untill that it shall not be, and so even no lesse vaine. Wherefore an ancient writer sayth, Quod est, dum est, pene nihil est, that which is, while it is, is almost nothing, seeing the moments of the present time doe flie away so fast. And when the Preacher addeth, Nihil est novum sub sole, Nothing is new under the Sunne, Gregory Nyssene expoundeth it,Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 1. That which is new under the Sunne, is nothing indeed. Now if thus we take the meaning of the former verse: then the force, which this verse addeth to it, is this, That so vaine is the continuance of the thing, that is, that it doth not stay, untill it can be sayd, It is. And if it be asked, what it is? He that answereth must tell, what it was, not what it is. And when it is added, It hath been already of old time, which was before: in a consequent exposition, the meaning of that must be, that nothing is truely sayd to be but God onely, who hath been of old even from everlasting, and before that wee ever were. For seeing Gregory Nyssene expoundeth novum esse to be new, by revera subsistere, to be and to subsist indeed, and thereupon understandeth nothing to be new, because nothing in this world truely is; therefore in like manner that which is sayd to be of old, must be understood of that which truely is, and that is God alone. But to apply this in a morall sense: it serveth well to teach patience unto Gods servants, and if they be hated of the world, it is that which hath been alwayes in the world; if they suffer reproach, slanders, persecution, it is that which shall be done to Gods servants after themselves be gone. The thing which hath been, it is that which shall be; and that which is done, it is that which shall be done. Neither let any say it is strange, it is new that which I endure. For is there any thing of which it may be sayd, see this is new? No, Ezek. 1.16. the servants of God have of old endured the same, whatsoever it be that is endured by any: and therefore let every one expect that to be done to himselfe, which hath been done to them. In the vision of the Prophet Ezechiel, wee reade of a wheele in the wheele,Ambros. de Virg. l. 3. circa finem. and this Saint Ambrose expoundeth to be, Vitam intra vitam, quod Sanctorum vita sibi non dissonet, sed qualis fuerit superioris aetatis, talis sit & sequentis, Life within life, because the life of Gods Saints is not different the one from the other, but such as it was in the former ages, such it is in the ages that follow.

Verse 11. It is some kinde of preservation of things that are not, that they are not forgotten: and because this might seeme to mitigate the vanitie of worldly things, the Preacher sheweth that there is also no remembrance of things, neither of former things which goe before, that is, neither of things past which are already gone, neither of things present when they shall be gone also, neither shall there be any remembrance of things which shall be, whether they shall be soone after,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. Homil. 2. in Ecclesiast. or whether a long time after. So that as Hugo de Sancto Victore speaketh; Non solum praesentia eorum interitu sublata est, sed memoria quo{que} oblivione
deleta est, not onely their presence by perishing is taken away, but their memory also by oblivion is blotted out. Wherefore let this check the great minds of some, who thinke to doe some great thing by which they will be remembred, and let it make them to seeke after righteousnesse; Prov. 10.7. for it is the righteous, it is the memory of the righteous that is blessed. Or else let me offer to consideration, this meaning of the Preacher: who to shew the vanitie of worldly things, sayth, that there is no remembrance 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
capitum & primariorum, of those who have been chiefe and highest in worldly esteeme, of those who by their famous deeds, their glorious works, have striven to leave their memory behind them: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and much more that there is no remembrance of them, who have been inferiour in the worlds repute: and that they who shall be, whether great ones or of meaner accompt, shall not be remembred by them who follow after them. Gregory Nyssene taking here also the same way in expounding this verse, that he did in expounding the former, goes from the beginning to the end of the world, and conceiveth the Preachers meaning to be, That as now there is no memory of that happinesse wherein man was created; so in the Resurrection, there shall be no remembrance of the misery which man now suffereth.Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 1.
Quando enim ad vitium conversa est natura, bonorum nobis subrepsit oblivio; quando autem ad bonum redierimus, rursus malum oblivione tegetur; For when our nature turned unto sinne, then a forgetfulnesse of good things came upon us; and when we shall returne unto goodnesse, then evils shall be covered by forgetfulnesse from us. The Chaldee doth here understand a mystery, and shewing the great happinesse of the time of the Messiah, he sayth;Chaldaeus Costi. Profecto praeteritarum nationum memoria non extat, ne{que} earum quae post futurae sunt recordatio erit iis qui temporibus Regis Messiae victuri sunt; Surely in respect of them who shall live in the times of Messiah the King, the memory of past Nations is not, the memory of them which shall come after shall not be: as if they onely were worthy not to be forgotten, and that time onely were worthy to be remembred. And indeed a most happy time it was: but, if wee so remember it, as to forget our sinnes.

q.p: VER. 12. J the Preacher was King over Israel in Jerusalem.
VER. 13. And J gave my heart to seeke and search out by wisedome concerning all things that are done under heaven: this sore travell hath God given to the sonnes of men to be exercised therewith.
VER. 14. J have seene all the workes that are done under the Sunne, and behold, all is vanitie and vexation of spirit.

div.p:
Verse 12. I the Preacher, that is, as an ancient writer speaketh, Ego qui vos doceo, expertus sum universa, quae dico, I who teach you, have learnt in my selfe all these things which I say unto you: and therefore as I speake no more then I know, so doe yee regard it the more because I speake it unto you. I was King. He had not yet put off his royall robes, he had not yet layd aside his crowne, and yet considering the vaine uncertaintie, and speedy passing away of worldly greatnesse, he rather affirmeth himselfe to have been then to be.Hildebertus Episc. de contemptu rerum humanarum. Epist. 56.
Hildebertus considering the same of all worldly things, sayth of them; Haec aliena esse fuga ipsorum denuntiat. Bona vaga, bona pennata sunt haec omnia. Eorum est, nusquam esse diutius, eorum status nemini statum praefigere certiorem, That these things doe not properly belong unto us, their flying away from us doth plainly declare. Gadding good things, winged good things are all these things. It is their propertie to be no where long, it is their condition to afford unto none a certaine condition. Hugo de Sancto Victore noting also that he sayth, I was King, giveth it this touch; Fui inquit, quasi dicat, jam non sum, quia etsi sum, id ipsum jam nihil esse agnosco quod sum; He sayth, I was, as if he had sayd, I am not now; because although I am, yet I know that to be nothing which now I am. Or else if we conceive this booke to have been written by Solomon after his repentance, wee may conceive him to say, I was King, as one that was come downe from his throne of glory, and lying on the ground, lamenting and bewailing his former iniquities and vanities. But one sayth very well; Vtinam tam certum de poenitentia illius, quam non dubium de culpa testimonium haberemus, I would to God that the proofe of his repentance were as certaine, as that of his fault is undoubted. Or lastly, in that he sayth, I was, wee may note him to have been King a long time when that he wrote this Booke, and so to have written it in his old age. King over Israel in Ierusalem: and being so, he wanted neither wealth nor power
to get knowledge, both the more fully and the more easily. Which therefore shameth those which being great and rich, yet are illiterate and idiots in knowledge. And surely it is a great damage both to Church and State, that they are the poorer sort onely who seeke after knowledge, and who being destitute of meanes, cannot make so happy progresse in it. But these also are too often worthy of blame. For when by some degree of knowledge they have attained greatnesse and wealth, and so are made fit to seeke more, then doe they lay aside their seeking, as refusing to fight when they are well armed, and then onely being forward to the battell, when they are naked and without weapons. A Greeke Father applyeth the verse to Christ, telling us, that as he is called the Physitian, the life, the resurrection, the light, the way, the dore, the truth, so here the Preacher, Omnia nomina humanitatis & benevolentiae in homines, all being names of his love and good will towards men. Wherefore he addeth, Nos alloquitur Ecclesiastes: audiam us ejus verba, qui sumus ecclesia, The head of the Church speaketh unto us: let us heare him, who are the Church.

Verse 13. Behold here the royall Student, not given to his pleasures, but given to his Booke: and see the matter, the method, the manner, the diligence of his studying. The matter is all things that are done under heaven, as the Ethicks of the manners of men, the civill histories of the deeds of men, the naturall history of the works of God. Or else to take the matter more largely, by all things under heaven, wee may understand all things under God, Daniel 4.26. it being the phrase of Scripture, sometimes by the heavens the throne of God, to understand God himselfe who sitteth on the throne: so high his study caryed him, but there it stood amazed. The method of his study we have, in that it is sayd, by wisedome, for that is the onely right method of well seeking any thing. And therefore an ancient Writer maketh him to say, Si sine sapientia quaererem, etiamsi sapientiam quaererem, insipienter quaererem, If I sought without wisedome, although I sought wisedome, I should unwisely seeke. Method is the wise part of study, but an unwise method, is a methodicall folly. The manner of his studying wee have in that he sought and searched. Quaerebat ignota, investigabat profunda, he sought things unknowne, he searched deepe things, sayth Hugo de Sancto Victore. Or else we may understand his seeking, of seeking the helpe, counsell, direction of others, for that the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifieth, from whence is derived 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
commentarius a commentary. His searching wee may understand to be his owne meditation. For both must goe together to make a good Student: seeking to see what others have found, searching to try what himselfe can finde. The diligence of his studying we have in that he gave his heart unto it; he went about it, not onely with a willingnesse, but with a love, which lockt him up, and held him hard unto it. Againe, his diligence is shewed, in that he did not seeke and search all things, but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
super omne concerning all things, as what the causes, the reasons, the uses, the effects of them were
as well as their natures. In the latter part of the verse, where we reade sore travell, the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which the Septuagint and as S. Hierome tels us, Aquila and Theodotio translated 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, distentio sive occupatio, a busie occupying or distending of the minde with care. Symmachus as St. Hierome also sheweth, did translate the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a restlesse troubling of the minde. The Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 properly signifieth evill, but as the Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 evill is taken 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 from labour, so in Hebrew the word signifying evill, signifieth also the hardnesse and sorenesse of labour. The rest of the verse I finde Interpreters generally to render as our English hath it,Hieronym. in hunc vers. This sore travaile hath God given to the sonnes of men, to be exercised or afflicted therewith. And therefore St. Hierome taking this study of Solomon in an ill sense, as winding up the spring of his minde too high; in which respect,Hugo de Sancto Victore in Ecclesiast. Homil. 5.
H. de S. Vict. sayth, Magna superbia mortalem hominē de tam multis praesumere, & rursum magna curiositas tam multa appetere, it was a great pride for a mortall man to presume of so many things, and a great curiositie to seeke so many things. Saint Hierome, I say, accordingly understandeth these words, that God is sayd to give this sore travaile unto men, as a punishment of their curious and ambitious minde. But to adde to Solomons hard study, this hard censure, I doe not see any reason, seeing it is sayd, that he sought by wisedome. And if I may deliver mine apprehension, I should translate the latter part of the verse thus. This sore travaile hath God appointed unto man 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ad respondendum in eo, or ad exorandum in eo, to answer thereto with his blessing upon it, or to be intreated therein for giving successe unto it, for so the Originall may well enough be rendred. For it is a diligent and painfull labour and study, on which God bestoweth knowledge and the finding out of things. And yet he stileth them the sonnes of men, that whatsoever their knowledge may be, they might not be proud of it, but considering themselves to be subject to infirmities, misery, and death, might use their knowledge to gaine happinesse and glory. And surely this glory will be the greater unto them, who studying the knowledge of the creatures, and those many miracles which are shewed in them, doe thereby set forth the glory of the Creatour. For there is nothing which though it have not words, yet hath not as it were a mouth to speake his praise that made it.Greg. Nyss. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 2.
Gregory Nyssene going on in his mysticall sense telleth us, that here is set downe the cause why Christ came in the flesh, and conversed with men, Nempe ut dare • cor suum ad considerandum in sapientia, de omnibus quae facta sunt sub sole, Namely, that he might give his heart to consider in his wisedome of all things that are done under the Sunne; for the things above the Sun had no need of a Physitian: but under the Sunne he considered, how vanitie entred into the world, how it encreased, how it prevailed, what the confusion of all things was.

Ver. 14. There is one word of the Originall in this verse not easily translated, and that is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which the Septuagint translated 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , & which anciently was rendred in Latin praesumptio presumption of spirit; and
St. Austin reading it so, thereupon tels us that the things of this world, Elationis & superbiae plena sunt, August. de Serm. Dom. in Monte. Homil. 1. Gregor. Neocaesar. are full of pride and loftinesse of spirit. And to the same purpose Gregory Neocaesariensis sayth, Spiritu prodigioso & execrando omnia haec inferiora plena sunt, All these inferiour things are full of a prodigious and execrable spirit. A Greeke Father understanding the Greeke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 according to the proper signification of it, for the free election of mans will, conceiveth the Preacher to shew here what is the cause of the vanitie of things, namely, the free will of mans spirit. St. Hierome tels us, that his Hebrew Master taught him to take it pro afflictione spiritus, for the affliction of the spirit. And to this effect most Interpreters doe render it. For the radicall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying pascere & depascere, to feed, and to consume, they take the meaning of the derivative word here used according to the latter signification. And therefore the French to expresse the force of the word renders it rougement, a gnawing and knipping of the spirit. But as Saint Hierome sayth, Aquila did render it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Symmachus
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, pastio nourishment or feeding. And this being the most proper signification of the radicall word, doth also exceeding well agree unto the place. For if we take the spirit for the winde, and so render it, how excellently is the vanitie of worldly things expressed, by faying that it is a feeding on the winde, and nourisheth alike? In which respect, Bernard sayth of them,Bernardus. Non esurientes animas, sed esuriem ipsam pascunt animarum, They doe not feed our hungry soules, but rather the hunger of our soules. And here we may note the difference of the phrase used in this verse, from that in the former. For there speaking of his study, he speaketh of all things under the heavens, under God: but here speaking of the vanitie of things, he speaketh of all things under the Sunne. Now if we doe referre the vexation of spirit to his study mentioned in the former verse, and understand the study to be a curious and presumptuous study, then it is a great mercy that God is sayd to give this sore travaile, this vexation of spirit unto the sonnes of men. For if this study were not painfull and evill, who would see the evill of it? But now the affliction of it doth make it to be hatefull,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 6.
Et facilius quod praemittit, vanum esse agnoscitur, dum id quod infert durum esse sentitur, And that which it promiseth is the more easily acknowledged to be vaine, by how much that which it bringeth is found to be grievous, as Hugo speaketh. Or else if we understand the study to be a diligent and commendable searching for knowledge: then wee have here the blessing of God upon it, bringing the Preacher so to see all the workes done under the Sunne, as to see them all to be vanitie and vexation of spirit; and so to shew them unto the sight of others. Now they are sayd to be vaine, Quia possidentes non adjuvant, because they doe not helpe the possessours of them; and are sayd to be vexation of spirit, Quia quaerentes affligunt, because they afflict them that doe seeke after thm,Ibid. as Hugo also speaketh. Or else the vanitie and vexation of spirit, may be referred unto his seeing and knowing; the knowledge of man being such as is full of vanitie and unquietnesse,
unquiet in the getting, unquiet being gotten, least forgetfulnesse should loose it againe, and vaine where it is greatest, because it is farre from the perfect discovery of any thing. For this world and the things in it, are a booke of that largenesse and greatnesse, that none is able to reade it over.

epigraph.q: VER. 15. That which is crooked, cannot be made straight: and that which is wanting, cannot be numbred.

div.p:
Verse 15. The Septuagint, and according to them the Vulgar Latin, reading this verse in a more morall sense, doe set it downe thus; Perversi difficilè corriguntur, & stultorum infinitus est numerus, The perverse are hardly corrected, and of fooles the number is infinite. Now they are properly sayd to be perverse, who have been right, and how hardly they are amended, St. Austin sheweth, saying,August. Epist. 137. ad plebem Hipponens. Quomodo difficilè expertus sum meliores, quam qui monasteriis profecerunt, ita non sum expertus pejores quam qui in monasteriis ceciderunt, As I have hardly found any better then they who have profited in monasteries; so I have found none to be worse, then they who have fallen in monasteries. For such are hardly amended. But as for fooles, as for those who were never good, the number of them is infinite. It is a small matter,Cajetanus. which Cajetane lamenteth, as standing amazed at the miserable condition of mankinde, because of ten Virgins, the one halfe even five were foolish: it is rather to be wondred at, that all are not foolish, seeing so many are. For as Seneca sayth, Non tam bene cum rebus humanis agitur, Seneca de vita beata. c. 2.
ut meliora pluribus placeant: argumentum pessimi, turba est, It is not well with humane things, that the best things doe please the most, a multitude is an argument of that which is worst. But to consider the words, as in themselves they offer themselves. Saint Hierome and Gregory Nyssene doe reade the first part of the verse thus, Perversum non potest adornari, that which is perverse cannot be adorned; and thereupon St. Hierome sayth, Qui perversus nisi ante corrigatur, non potest adornari. Recta ornatum reciptunt, & curva correctionem, He that is perverse, unlesse he be first corrected, cannot be adorned. Right things doe receive adorning, and crooked things correction. Our English sayth, that which is crooked cannot be made straight: or else it may be read thus; that which is out of order cannot be ordered, and that which is wanting cannot be numbred. And for the meaning of it, the Preacher having sayd, that all things that are done are vanitie and vexation of spirit, here he sheweth the vanitie of them, in that they are crooked, perverse, and out of order: the vexation of spirit that they bring, in that their crookednesse cannot be corrected. The vanitie he sheweth in the defects of them; the vexation of spirit that they bring, in that their defects cannot be supplyed. For not to be numbred, is, not to be, because of nothing there is no number, and therefore
that which cannot be numbred, cannot be made to be. Tremellius Tremellius. therefore reads it well, Non posse in numerum venire, that it cannot come into number, it cannot come into being, it cannot be supplyed. Or else we may take the meaning to be, that the vanitie of things that are done under the Sunne is thus aggravated. First, that they are crooked and out of order, and so crooked, so out of order that they cannot be rectified and made straight. Secondly, that they are full of defects, and that the defects are so great, as not having so much entitie or being in them, as that they can be numbred: for the least thing that is admitteth numeration. Or else, that they are full of defects, and so full, that they are infinite and cannot be numbred.

q.p: VER. 16. J communed with mine owne heart, saying, Loe J am come to great estate, and have gotten more wisedome then all they that have been before me in Jerusalem: yea, my heart had great experience of wisedome and knowledge.
VER. 17. And I gave my heart to know wisedome, and to know madnesse and folly: I perceived that this also is vexation of spirit.
VER. 18. For in much wisedome is much griefe, and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.

div.p:
Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 7.
Verse 16. Hugo de Sancto Victore, who still taketh Solomon in the worst sense, supposeth him to speake this of his former pride of life. And thereupon when the Preacher sayth, In corde dixi, I sayd in mine heart, he addeth, In corde dixi, de corde enim tumui, I sayd in mine heart, for I swelled in mine heart. And then shewing how a proud heart doth still swell bigger, he noteth, that he, Qui primum de se plus quam debuit, sensit; deinde usque ad aliorum contemptum venit, who first thought of himselfe more than he ought, next proceeded even to a contempt of others, saying, that he had gotten more wisedome, then all that were before him in Ierusalem: So that he made himselfe praecedentibus summum, subsequentibus primum, the highest to them that went before him, the first to them that followed after him. But not to thinke so ill of what Solomon spake: if we looke with a milder eye upon him, wee may behold his humilitie here. For first he did speake in his owne heart of his great estate, he did not with great words set it out to others.
His heart sayd it, that his heart might give thankes to God, who had made him so great. Secondly, whereas God had sayd of him that he should be wiser then any that were before him,1 King. 3.12. or any that should be after him, he speaketh onely of those that were in Ierusalem before him; so that he doth not preferre himselfe before Abraham, and Moyses, and others that were not in Ierusalem. Yea, whereas the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ad facies meas, before me in Ierusalem, as present there with me, I suppose that he may be understood, onely to preferre himselfe before them, which either himselfe had sent for to commune with; or which had come of themselves to try him and his wisedome; as the Queene of Sheba did. But to consider the meaning of the verse, as it standeth in the Chapter. Either we may take it thus, that Solomon from the vanitie of other things reflecting upon himselfe, and saying in his own heart, What shall I say of my selfe? I am become great, though other things be small and vaine; and though the wisedome of others before me were vaine, I have gotten more wisedome then all that were before me: yea, not onely is it more then others have gotten, but much also in it selfe, much wisedome, much knowledge. My heart hath seene much, sayth the Originall, and St. Hierome sayth upon it,Hieronym. in hunc vers. that the eye of his heart had seene more, then his tongue was able to utter. Or else wee may take the meaning thus: that Solomon being ashamed in himselfe of the vanitie which he saw in worldly things, He communed with his owne heart, saying, I am come to great estate, I am a great King, I have meanes to doe things in a better manner, shall those things which are done by me be vaine also? And that thereupon he sayth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
adjeci I added, as St. Ierome and Gregory Nyssene doe reade it, I added to my great estate, great wisedome by study and paines, even greater then all they that have been before me in Ierusalem: yea my heart looked into the depth of wisedome, and knowledge. Where Clemens Alexandrinus noteth,Clemens Alexand. Stromatum 1. that first it is sayd wisedome, then knowledge, Quoniam in multitudine sapientiae est multitudo cognitionis, because in the greatnesse of wisedome, is the greatnesse of knowledge. Or else as Gregory Nyssene speaketh,Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 2.
Quia ex sapientia constat cognitio, because knowledge consisteth of wisedome, the knowledge of humane things consisteth of the understanding of things divine.

Ver. 17. In this verse Hugo supposeth Solomon to set forth also his own former vanity. And therfore when he saith, I gave mine heart to know, he noteth him, to shew the pride of his heart, as if for him to know wisedom, it were enough but to give his mind to know it. And when he saith, that he sought to know madnesse and folly, he expoundeth it. Nequaqua ad hoc mala cognoscere voluit, ut cognita vitaret, Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 7.
sed ut se de malorum cognitione extolleret, & alios de opere damnaret, that his will to know those evils was not at all, that he might shunne them being knowne, but that he might boast himselfe of the knowledge of the evils, and might condemne others for the doing of them. And lastly, when he saith, I perceived that this also is vexation of spirit: he apprehendeth the affliction
of labour to have quelled the pride of his spirit, as before it did the curiosity of his spirit: and that his vexation was, because his knowledge, Iniquum per conscientiam arguebat, quam elatus ad ostentationem quaerebat, did prove him in his conscience to bee wicked, seeing in his pride hee sought it for ostentation. But to consider Solomon in a better minde. This verse sheweth, that having gotten more wisedome then others before him, yet he did not cease to get still more, but giving his heart to it, he still laboured to know wisdome. And that he might the better know it, he laboured not only to know it in it selfe, but to know it also by comparing it with madnesse and folly, that the foulnesse of the one might set out the beauty and clearenesse of the other. And first hee sought to know wisdome, that knowing madnesse and folly, he might as well hate them, as know them. The Originall word is plurall, and speaketh of madnesses, as shewing the many kinds which are of madnesse. And because madnesse commonly is joyned with a conceit of wisdome, he addeth folly to expresse it truly. But whatsoever he was in greatnesse, or how great soever the wisedome was which he had gotten, or how great paines soever he tooke to get wisdome, in conclusion, it was vexation of spirit to him, to know, that himselfe also was vanity, that his wisdome was no better, and that he could not by all his wisedome redresse the vanity of those things which he did. In conclusion, by his wisedome and knowledge he perceaved and came to know, that even this was vexation of spirit. The Originall word is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and by Pagnine according to the Chaldee signification of the word is translated cogitatio spiritus, a thought of the spirit: which well agreeth to the place. For Solomon having communed in his heart, and thought with himselfe of this and that, he knew it at last to be but a vaine thought of his heart: having brought himselfe to this perfection of knowledge, as to know himselfe and his wisdome to be as the vanity of a thought.Bernard in Serm. de 7. donis Spir. Sanct. For as St. Bernard speaketh, Vere scientia est, scire nos mortales & fragiles, & in hac peregrinatione dolendum & lugendum esse, It is truly knowledge to know that we are mortall and fraile, and that in this pilgrimage it is sorrow and griefe and vexation of spirit that is our portion.

Ver. 18. The Preacher from his own particular experience delivereth a generall rule, that wisdome and griefe are made up in the same heape, that knowledge and sorrow doe grow upon the same stalke.Aristotle Ethic. 10. cap. 7. Aug. solil. l. 1. c. 12. But how then doth the Philosopher say, Quod maxima delectatio est, quae est secundum operationem intelligentiae, That the greatest delight is that which is according to the operation of wisdome? How then doth St. Austin say, Videbatur mihi si se ille mentibus nostris veritatis fulgor aperiret, aut non me sensurum fuisse illum dolorem, aut certe pro nihilo toleraturum, It seemed to me, that if that light of truth would open it selfe to our mindes, either I should not feele this paine, or else endure it as a thing of nothing? Aquin. 1. 2ae. Quaest. 38. Ans. 4. The answer which Aquinas giveth is this, Quod ex parte rerum cognitarum scientia dolorem causat, ex parte autem contemplationis veritatis delectationem, that in respect of the contemplation of truth
knowledge causeth delight, but in respect of the things knowne, that it causeth sorrow. Now if they bee good things which are knowne, then the sorrow is from the great labour, which a man must take to attaine the knowledge of them; and from the little perfection of knowledge to which his great paines hath brought him. If they bee evill things which are knowne, then his sorrow is, that he is subject to them. Thus Saint Ambrose understandeth the latter part of the verse, saying,Ambros. de spiritu & Anima. Qui apponit scientiam; apponit dolorem; quia quanto magis homo sua mala intelligit, tanto amplius suspirat & gemit, He that addeth knowledge, addeth griefe; because by how much the more a man knoweth his evils, by so much the more hee lamenteth and sorroweth. And to the same purpose Saint Gregory expoundeth it, saying, Qui apponit scientiam, apponit dolorem; Gregor. Moral. l. 18. cap. 24.
quia quanto plus homo coepit scire quod perdidit, tanto plus lugere incipit corruptionis suae sententiam, quam invenit, He that increaseth knowledge, increaseth sorrow, because by how much the more a man beginneth to know that which he hath lost, by so much the more he beginneth to lament the sentence of his corruption which he hath found. But as for the former part of the verse, that which our translation readeth griefe, in the originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth indignation, according as by the Septuagint it is translated, and as the vulgar Latine readeth it. Now as it is so read, the sense of it is well given by Saint Hierome, Quanto magis quis sapientiam fuerit consecutus, tanto plus indignatur subjacere vitiis, Hieronym. in hunc versum. & procul esse a virtutibus quas requirit; By how much the more any one hath obtained wisedome, by so much the greater is his indignation, that he is subject to vices, and is so farre from vertues which he seeketh after. And this is that indignation which,2 Cor. 7.11. that the sorrow of repentance had caused in the Corinthians, was Saint Pauls joy. And therefore Salonius also saith, Quanto quisque plus proficit in sapientia, tanto magis sibi irascitur de malis operibus quae gessit, By how much the more any one profiteth in wisdome,Salonius. by so much the more is he angry with himselfe for the evill workes which he hath done. But the indignation which is here spoken of, the Chaldee Paraphrast understandeth not to be the indignation of man,Chald. Paraph. but the indignation of God, and therefore expoundeth it, Vir qui multiplicat scientiam, quando peccat & non convertitur ad sapientiam, multiplicat indignationem à Domino, The man who multiplieth wisdome, when he sinneth, and is not turned unto wisdome, multiplieth indignation from the Lord Himselfe.

Now against this which Solomon here teacheth, perhaps it will be objected, that some there are, who spend their whole time, and even grow old in the study of Philosophy, History and other lesse usefull matters, and therefore that they seeme to find great delight in it, seeing they cannot be drawne from it. But the reason of this is, not that they have attained to more than Solomon did, but that with Solomon they doe not take an account of their study, to see what the true benefit of their paines and study is, whereby they would soone perceive the small comfort
and great trouble of it. Wherefore though there be not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , such as oversee our studies, and call us to a reckoning for them; yet it were very good that we would reckon with our selves, to see how we imploy our time and abilities, that our care therein may make the trouble and sorrow of our paines the lesse, by the greater good wee reape.

q.p: VER. 1. J sayd in my heart, Goe to now, I will proove thee with mirth, therefore enjoy pleasure: and behold this also is vanitie.
VER. 2. I sayd of laughter, it is mad: and of mirth, What doth it?

div.p:
Verse 1. THe speech of the Preacher is not like the speech of many, who have not that in their power, which is pleasing to their heart;Gregor. Nys. Hom. 2. in Ecclesiast. Adeo ut propterea fide sit indignus, ut qui illa accuset, quae non est expertus, so that he might be unworthy of credit, as one condemning those things whereof himselfe had no experience. For he being the glorious King of Israel, Non operam ponebat in iis quae non habebat acquirendis, sed ut frueretur in quibus abundabat, he did not place his labour in getting those things which he had not, but how he might enjoy those things wherein he abounded. Nam cum cupiditate simul extendebatur copia, & ad fruendum laxum et liberū erat etium, For his plentie was extended as wide as his desire, and his leasure of enjoying both was loose and at libertie, as Gregory Nyssene speaketh. He therefore could say in his heart, to his heart, Goe to now, I will proove thee with mirth. Our English phrase, Goe to now, though in the words it answereth very well to the Originall, yet as our manner is of using it, it doth not expresse the force of the Originall.
