That is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
vade nuns, Goe now. First, he sayth it, as speaking to a heart that was under authoritie, under the command of wisedome, and that stirred not, untill leave and order was given. Secondly, he sayth, Goe now, now (if we may take the Hebrew 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as Aben Ezra sayth that in the Scriptures it is alwayes taken) that I have first setled thee by wisedome,
that pleasure doe not transport thee: now that I have first tryed the study of wisedome and knowledge, and found that to be vanitie and vexation, now goe, I will try thee with mirth. In our translation it followeth, therefore enjoy pleasure; but the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Et vide in bonum, And see into the good of it, see what thou canst finde in it, which may be the good that is desired by thee, and which may give thee satisfaction in the pleasing of thee. Vatablus Vatablus. therefore doth well expresse the sense of the place, Experiar quantum in eo bonum sit, I will try how much good there may be in that. And to the same effect the Chaldee Paraphrase sayth, Videbo bona saeculi hujus, Chald. Para. I will see the good things of this world. But behold, all is vanitie. He quickly giveth his judgement of this: the folly of this was so manifest, that forthwith his heart descryeth it, and pronounceth the vanitie of it. For seeing the objects of worldly mirth, as Plato speaketh, Inania sunt omnia, Plato de Repub. 9.
& longius absint ab ente quam a nihilo, quî fieri potest, ut vacuitates animi nostri expleant, are all of them emptie things, and farther distant from a true being then they are from nothing, how can it be that they should fill the emptie capacities of our mindes? How truely therefore doth the Preacher pronounce them to be vanitie.

Verse 2. The Originall most directly maketh the Preacher to speake to laughter, to mirth, not of laughter, of mirth, as shewing that even in laughter, in mirth, he had that care of himselfe, as that even then he was able to condemne it, able to reproove it. Now by laughter, wee may understand an excessive mirth, because it is commonly an excessive mirth that breaketh forth into laughter: by mirth, we may understand a lesser violent degree of worldly delight. Or else by laughter, we may understand an outward delight, because that joy which lyeth hid within, by laughter, Ruptis quasi modestiae claustris, Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 8.
quadam levitate & incontinentia lubricae mentis propalatur, the barres, as it were, of modestie being broken open by a kinde of lightnesse and incontinency of an inconstant minde, is made to be manifest, as Hugo speaketh. By mirth, wee may understand, an inward and secret delight, which sometimes is the greater from the secrecy of it. Or else we may understand the Preacher to mention laughter, thereby to shew that he speaketh of a carnall mirth. For a spirituall mirth, doth seldome or never dissolve the minde into laughter. Sed ea tantum laetitia quae a carnis blandimento concipitur, etiam per carnis motum facile aperitur, but onely that mirth which is conceived by a flattering of the flesh, is also manifested easily by the motion of the flesh, as Hugo also hath it. That which the Preacher sayth of laughter, is, that it is madnesse. The Hebrew word which we have is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and signifieth madnesse: but Saint Hierome tels us, that Aquila did reade it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
errorem errour, as the Vulgar Latin also hath it; and surely it is a great errour to take that for the true good of man: that Symmachus did reade it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
tumultum, a tumult, and surely it is a riotous disorderly tumult, that usually it maketh in the minde and understanding of man: that Theodotio did reade it as the Septuagint doe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
circumlationem,
a giddinesse, and surely it is a giddinesse of the head, a whirling lightnesse of the minde that laughter causeth. Gregory Nyssene speaking of this reading, sayth, Quod quidem sensu idem est quod delirium & amentia, which in the sense of it is the same with raving and madnesse. Of mirth, that which the Preacher sayth, is onely a question, What doth it? As shewing that himselfe could not tell of any good that it doth. Or else it may be taken as implying, What doth it but cause that madnesse of laughter whereof I have spoken? Or else it may be taken as a challenge to all the most cunning inventers of pleasure, to tell if they can,Chald. Para. what true good it doth? The exposition which the Chaldee giveth of it, is this, Quid emolumenti est viro qui fecerit illud, What benefit is it to a man who hath been taken with it? And if you will know the answer which a Greeke Father giveth, he will tell you, what it doth, saying, Naturae virtutem effoeminat, animi robur emollit, animae vires enervat, affert interitum rationi, cogitationum serenarum puritati caliginis tenebras immittit; It effeminateth the vertue of nature, it enfeebleth the strength of the minde, it weakneth the forces of the soule, it bringeth destruction to reason, it casteth the mist of darknesse upon the puritie of serene thoughts. The same Father apprehendeth the Preacher to speake here of or to mirth as to a thiefe unawares crept into the house of his soule, and thereupon to say unto it, What dost thou? What dost thou here thou pernicious enemy, and doing me little or no good, whatsoever contentment for the present thou pretendest to bring unto me? Lastly, an ancient Writer noteth here, Quod gaudium tantum arguitur, risus vero omnino reprobatur: quia risus omnimodo malus est, gaudium verò non semper malum est, nisi quando de malo est, That mirth is here onely reprooved, but that laughter is altogether rejected: because that laughter is wholly evill, mirth is not alwayes evill, unlesse it be in an evill thing. But then laughter must be understood to be with indecency.Clemens Alexand. Paedagogus. l. 2. c. 5. For as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh; Si quomodo oportet, proferatur, prae se fert decorem & honestatem; sin aliter prodeat, indicat intemperantiam, If laughter be used as it ought, it setteth out the comelinesse and dignitie of man; but if it be used otherwise, it sheweth an intemperancy in man.

epigraph.q: VER. 3. J sought in mine heart to give my selfe unto Wine (yet acquainting mine heart with Wisedome) and to lay hold on folly, till J might see, what was that good for the Sons of men, which they should doe under the heaven, all the dayes of their life.

div.p:
Verse 3. The first part of this verse is rendred with great diversitie.
The Septuagint, and according to them the Vulgar Latin doe render it, Cogitavi in corde meo abstrahere a vino carnem meam, ut animum meum transferrem ad sapientiam devitarem{que} stultitiam, I thought in mine heart to withdraw my flesh from wine, that I might apply my minde to wisedome, and might shun folly. And this sayth Aquinas, Aquin. 2. 2 ae. Q. 188. A. 5. Gregor. Moral. l. 6. c. 26. is spoken to teach us to avoyd needlesse curiositie in the study and contemplation of divine things, seeing as St. Gregory speaketh, Nonnulli dum veritatis discipali esse humiliter negligunt, magistri errorum fiunt, Many while they neglect to be humbly the Schollers of truth, are made the Masters of errours. Saint Hierome renders it thus; Consideravi in corde meo, Hieronym. in hunc versum. ut traherem in vino carnem meam: & cor meum deduxit me insapientiam, I considered in mine heart, that I would spend the time of my flesh in wine: and mine heart lead me into wisedome. Which he expoundeth thus; Volui vitam meam tradere delitiis, Hieronym. in hunc versum. & carnem meam ab omnibus curis liberare, & quasi vino sic voluptate sopire; sed cogitatio mea & ratio naturalis retraxerunt me, & deduxerunt ad sapientiam requirendam, I would have given my life to delights, and to have freed my flesh from all cares, and as it were with wine, so with pleasure, to have brought it asleepe; but mine owne thoughts and naturall reason drew me backe, and lead me to the seeking of wisedome. According whereunto the French translation doth also render it. I' ai recherche en mon caeur le moyen de me traitter delicatement, I sought in mine heart the meanes to use my selfe delicately. Gregory Nyssene doth reade it,Greg. Nyss. in hunc vers. Consideravi an cor meum carnem meam tanquam vinum traheret, & cor meum deduxit me in sapientia, I considered whether my heart could draw my flesh as it were wine, and my heart lead me in wisedome: which he expoundeth thus; As the thirst of a man draweth the wine easily and earnestly unto it, so I considered how my heart, how mine understanding might easily draw the sensitive parts of my soule after it, and make them readily to be ruled by it: which being done, I went on without any hindrance in the way of wisedome. As our translation doth render it, so we may note, that the folly of following wine, and the voluptuousnesse of feeding and feasting thereby noted, was so apparant without tryall, that it was not enough for him to say, I thought to give my selfe to wine, but I sought in my heart to doe it, it was a labour to him to bring his heart unto so foolish a thing. Or else we may conceive the labour to be, because he would both give himselfe to wine and belly delight, and also acquaint his heart with wisedome, which must needs be very hard, seeing that so quickly destroyeth the wisedome of any one. But therefore it followeth, that he would lay hold on folly, he would not suffer that to lay hold on him; because then he should not be able to cast it off so readily, as having it in his owne power he might doe. And if I might presume to deliver mine apprehension, I would render it thus: I sought in my heart to bend eagerly my sensuall appetite unto the drinking of wine, and I sought also to draw my heart unto it, which leading me in wisedome was averse from it, and that I might make it to take hold on folly. For though the Originall word signifie
to draw, yet I render it to bend, the drawing of the appetite being like the drawing of a bow, which the more strongly it is drawne, the more it is bent. In the rendring of the latter part of the verse, which sheweth the end for which he did the other, all doe agree. And because it speaketh of the good whieh men should doe all the dayes of their life: a Greeke Father noteth, that some things seeme good to men, but it is only for a short time, there being speedily a wearinesse of them: and that there are some things which are good to men in their youth, other things that are good to them in their old age; but that the Preacher would see that good thing, Cujus cum participatione extenditur appetitus, & ejus aetate qui desiderat non circumscribitur, the desire whereof is extended with the enjoying of it, and which is not limited by his age, by whom it is desired. But the Originall goes thus, Numero dierum vitae eorum, in the number of the dayes of their life, as shewing the fewnesse of mans dayes, so that they may be numbred. For as the Poet speaketh, Pauperis est numerare pecus, It is a signe of a poore man to number his Cattle, so it is a proofe of the scantnesse of mans dayes, that number doth easily measure them.

q.p: VER. 4. I made me great workes, I builded mee houses, J planted me Vineyards.
VER. 5. J made me Gardens and Orchards, and I planted trees in them of all kind of fruits.
VER. 6. I made me pooles of water, to water therewith the wood that bringeth forth trees.
VER. 7. J got me servants and maidens, and had servants borne in my house, also I had great possessions of great and small Cattell, above all that were in Ierusalem before me.

VER. 8. J gathered mee also Silver and Gold, and the peculiar treasure of Kings, and of the provinces: J gate me men singers, and women singers, and the delights of the sons of men, as musicall instruments; and that of all sorts.
VER. 9. So J was great and increased more than all that were before me in Ierusalem; also my wisedome remained with mee.
VER. 10. And whatsoever mine eye desired I kept not from them, I withheld not mine heart from any ioy: for my heart reioyced in all my labour, and this was my portion of all my labour.

VER. 11. Then J looked on all my workes, that my hands had wrought, and on the labour that J had laboured to doe: and behold all was vanity and vexation of Spirit, and there was no profit under the Sunne.

div.p:
Verse 4. The true greatnesse of man is to esteeme little the vanities of this world, and as Maximus Maximus. speaketh, Magnus est cui nihil magnum, he is truly great, to whom nothing in this world is great.Gregorius. Saint Gregory therefore saith very well, Let any one be never so great, Parvulus est qui terrena diligit, He is very little that loveth earthly things. And let any one be never so little, Magnus est qui aeterna concupiscit, He is indeed great, that seeketh heavenly things. And to the same purpose Seneca Seneca. speakes worthily, Nihil magnum in rebus humanis, nisi cor magna despiciens, There is nothing great in humane things, but a heart despising the things esteemed great by men. But man having by sinne deprived himselfe of that inward greatnesse, wherein by God he was made, Extra quaerit quod intus perdidit, & in semetipso minoratus, magnificat opera sua, He seeketh without that which was lost within, and being made little in himselfe, who was Gods worke, he striveth to make his owne workes to be great, as Hugo speaketh.Hugo de Sancto Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 9. His owne workes he raiseth to a mighty height, Et dolore propemodum afficitur, quod coelum in suo tecto non fecerit, and is as it were grieved, that he hath not made the heaven to be the roofe of them. His owne workes he setteth out with a glorious pompe, and as it were troubled, Quod ipsos solis radios in eis fabricari non possit, That he cannot worke the very beames of the Sunne in them. His own workes he enlargeth to a vast greatnesse, Tanquam alium orbem terrae sibi construens, as it were making to himselfe upon the earth another earthly world, as Gregory Nyssene speaketh. And then being as great in pride,Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 3. as his workes are great, this is the delight that hee taketh in them. But
Seneca Seneca. saith well, he is truly great, Qui magna facit, & parva sentit, licet magna sciat, Who doth great things and thinketh them to be little, although he know them to be great. I builded me houses; The weaknesse of mans constitution being not able to endure the inequalities of heate and cold, therefore an house is both usefull and needfull for man. But the pleasure of man transcendeth the bounds of use and need, and hee must build houses, many houses, many houses in one, for the greatnesse of it, and many houses in diverse places, to multiply his vanity. To adde yet unto it, these also must be trimmed with much cost, and more curiosity. Aurum in aereas membranas dissectum ubi{que} illinitur, ut avidos in se oculos convertat: arbores ita formantur ex ligno, ut putentur ex caelaturis ramos, fructus & folia producere; Gold being cut into ayrie skinnes and beaten into very thinne leaves, is every where besmeered on them, to turne the greedy eyes to looke upon them: trees are so made out of the wood, that from the carving they may be thought to bring forth branches and leaves and fruit.Greg. Nyss. in Eccles. Homil. 3. But as Gregory Nyssene very well addeth, In haec studium quod confertur, est reprehensio & insimulatio negligentiae in iis quae sunt priora. Quo enim major fuerit & multitudine & materiae sumptu magnificentia in aedium structuris, eo magis arguitur inornatam esse animam, The care which is bestowed upon these things doth accuse and reprove the negligence which is in things that are better. For how much the magnificence is greater in the structure of houses, either in respect of the multitude of them, or the cost of the matter, by so much the shame is greater, that the soule is not adorned. Let that be built up carefully; let humility be the pavement of it, let hope be the roofe of it, let faith be the pillars of it; on this side let Iustice be towards men, on that side devotion towards God, Et haec omnia praeclarus artifex, nempe charitas, apte inter se conjungat, And let love an excellent Artificer neately joyne all these together, and then there will be a house for wisedome to dwell in. I planted me Vineyards. The Preacher having told us, that he made workes, built houses, even as great as mountaines, he sheweth also how hee planted the mountaines with Vineyards. Now a Greeke Father telleth us, Magnum affectionum catalogum comprehendit vinearum plantationis confessio, This his confession of the planting of Vineyards containeth a great catalogue of his vaine affections. For as the same addeth, Wine immoderately taken, Est fomes intemperantiae, pernicies juventutis, probrum senectutis, dedecus mulierum, insaniae pharmacum, Is the nourishment of intemperancy, the bane of youth, the reproach of old age, the shame of Women, the poison of madnesse. But the Preacher sheweth, that he did not only use that Wine which was to be gotten, but provided also by planting many Vineyards, both for the abundance and delicacy of it. Surely where this mind is, there is commonly no mind to plant the Vineyard of the soule, but there the plants of vertue are suffered to dry up, and wither quite away. Whereas if it were well dressed, well ordered, it would be a most fruitfull Vineyard, so that a man should bruise his Grapes into the cup of wisdome, and drinke that
Wine which would indeed make his heart merry. Lastly, wee may note in these words, that the Preacher doth kindly expresse the nature of worldly pleasure, which is to bee all for it selfe. And therefore hee saith, I made me great workes, I builded me houses, I planted me Vineyards. If these great workes had beene made for some great good ends; if these houses had beene built to lodge strangers, the fatherlesse and widdowes, if these Vineyards had beene planted to relieve and comfort those; whose Vineyards were spoyled and destroyed, they had beene made, builded, planted for God, and he would have given a reward of blessednesse unto it. But that all was for himselfe made all to be nothing though never so great.

Verse 5. From the pleasures of the eye, the Preacher sheweth how hee lead himselfe to the pleasures of the tast and smell. Or else as Gregory Nyssene noteth, from the pleasures of the house, he sheweth how he walked 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ad subdiales voluptates, to the open pleasures of the ayre. He saith, I made me Gardens and Orchards, as shewing that there were none already made pleasant enough for him, and that there were none made before him like unto his. Yea, it was his owne particular direction that gave order for the making of them. And he made not only Gardens, but Orchards 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 saith the Originall, Paradises Paradises, most pleasant and delicious Gardens and Orchards. It was not one, but many Paradises that he made, as if he would strive to exceed that delight wherein at first man was placed by God, who made but one Paradise for him. But let sensuall hearts take heed how they suffer themselves to feed too much upon these pleasures, least at length, to use the words of the Prophet Isaiah,
Isai. 1.29. & 30. they be confounded for the Gardens that they have chosen, and that themselves be as a Garden that hath no water. And let those to whom God hath afforded these delights, have in their Gardens as Ioseph had, a Sepulcher, that is, let them in their pleasures, remember their death, that will bee a good meanes to keepe away the sinne of pleasure from them.Petrus Damianus Epist. 114. For as Petrus Damianus speaketh, Nullum libidini diversorium, in qua versatur mente Sepulchrum, there is in that mind no lodging for the lust of sin, where the bed of the grave is already made. And as Iosephs Sepulcher in his Garden was made the Sepulcher of Christ, so it were good also, that such in their Gardens would thinke of Christs Sepulcher, that is, in their delights would thinke of the misery which he suffered for them. For as Saint Basil speaketh, Benedicitur hortus, Basilius. in quo monumentum est quod temporariam excepit dispensationem mortis in corpore Domini, Blessed is that Garden, in which is the monument that hath received the temporary dispensation of death in the body of the Lord. But to goe on with the Preacher. And I planted trees in them of all kinds of fruits. Adeo ut omni ex parte jucunda omnia in oculum incurrant, So that from all parts all pleasant things might present themselves to the eye:Greg. Nyssen. in Eccles. Hom. 2.
Et quolibet anni tempore videat quod est praeter anni tempus, and in every season of the yeare might see that which was above the season, as Gregory
Nyssene speaketh.Chaldaeus Costi. The Chaldee Paraphrast doth thus enlarge the sense of the words, Plantavi viridaria amoenitatis plerissima, ubi omnis generis olera seminavi, quae ad victum et convivia, et ad sanitatem usui forent: herbas quoque olfactu nobiles adjeci; item et arbores steriles, et aromata ferentes, quas ad me daemones et nocentes angeli ex India detulerunt, I planted me orchards full of delight, where I sowed herbs of all kinds, whether usefull for food and feasts, or health. I added also flowers excellent for smell, and moreover trees that did beare no fruit, but were for shadow onely, tecti vicem aeri praebentes, being as it were a roofe hanging in the ayre, Vt etiam quum sub dio essem tanquam, in domo delicatè vitam agerem, that when I was in the open ayre, yet I might be for delicacy as it were in an house, as a Greeke Father expresseth it. I had also trees bearing spices, which the devils and hurtfull Angels brought from India unto mee.Cyprianus de discipl. & habitu virgin. St. Cyprian also speaking of other the like vanities, sayth, Quae omnia peccatores & apostatae angeli suis artibus prodiderunt, All which things sinners and the apostate Angels have brought forth by their arts. But as Gregory Nyssene speaketh sweetly, Quid multis opus est hortis ei qui ad unum intuetur? Si essem in Paradiso non ad multorum hortorum desiderium diffunderer, What need of many gardens unto him, who looketh unto one? If I were in Paradise, my heart would not be spread after many gardens. And that wee may come to this Paradise, we must keepe well the garden of our soules; that must be hortus inclusus a garden shut up carefully, so that the destroying beasts come not into it, and that the malicious enemy sow not weeds in it: that garden we must plant with trees of all kindes of fruits, with all vertues, all graces: and as Saint Hierome speaketh,Hieronym. in hunc vers. the chiefe plant must be lignum sapientiae, the tree of wisedome: Nisi enim in medio illud plantetur, ligna caetera siccabuntur, for unlesse that be planted in the middle, the rest of the trees will be dryed up. Nazianzene writeth of a Country called Ozyza, which was full of all sorts of most pleasant and curious flowers, but there was no corne in it: now surely this part of the world sheweth what this world is, namely, a world full of flowers, full of vanities, and wherein worldly hearts doe make most pleasant gardens:Gregor. Nazianzen. but in these gardens, in this world, there is no corne, no true comfort to be found: that is in heaven, where it is alwayes ripe, alwayes gathered, and yet alwayes growing, alwayes standing. Thither therefore let us labour to come, that we may reape the harvest of blessednesse.

Verse 6. Among Per tenta vanitatis, the strange phantasmes of vanitie,Hugo de Sancto Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 9. as Hugo speaketh, wherein the world still exceedeth, one is the invention of a wildernesse which often is adjoyned to great gardens belonging to great houses, and by a multitude of thick bushes and trees affecting an ostentation of solitarinesse in the midst of worldly pleasures. And this it was as I conceive whereof Solomon in this verse speaketh, having made such a one for himselfe, and for which he made pooles of water,Hieronym. in hunc vers. that as St. Hierome speaketh, Longius viror humore praepeti nutriretur, the greennesse might be the longer continued and nourished by
moysture alwayes ready at hand. The Vulgar Latin doth reade it, Extruxi, I built me pooles of water, as implying the greatnesse and neatnesse of them. And surely in that he sayth, I made, wee may apprehend an intimation, as if they were to be preserved before those which God had made.Greg. Nyssen. in Eccles. Hom. 3. In regard whereof Gregory Nyssene stileth them Maria m • nu facta, Seas made by the hand of man. But here also wee may note the method of the Kings pleasures; and how from his eye, taste, and smelling, he swimmeth along to delight himselfe and his touch, by bathing his body in the cold and soft and playing waters. For though this end of making the pooles be not expressed, yet that to this end they were also made, we may not amisse conceive, this being no little pleasure, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , iis qui exhilarani corpora, to them who refresh and cheere up their bodies, as a Greeke Father speaketh. Or else wee may observe the method of his pleasures to be; that passing from the earth, whereon he built houses and his great workes, and comming to the ayre, the sweetnesse whereof he enjoyed in his gardens and orchards, from thence he is caryed to the waters,Ibid. Vtpote quod oporteat in omnibus elementis se explere delitiis, as seeking to fill himselfe with delights even in all the elements, as the same Father also hath it. But that from these pooles of water, wee may draw something that shall be wholesome for us: let us also make pooles of waters; let us make our eyes pooles of waters, that so a sorrow for our sinnes, Irriguo suo diluat, & fluento fontis sui abstergat, Ambros. lib. de Isaac & anima. may wash them away with the watering of it, and cleanse us from them by the current of amendment in the course of our life, as the words of St. Ambrose are. Or else let us make us pooles of charitie, therewith to water the decayed trees of misery, therewith to moysten the dry ground of want and necessitie. For as St. Ambrose againe speaketh, Exuberat charitas, ut haurire eam cominus possis, Ibid. charitie overfloweth, so that it is alwayes neare at hand for thee to draw out of it. Charitie is puteus Reboboth, puteus latitudinis, the well of bredth, Gen. 26.22. which name we reade to be given by Isaac to a Well which his servants digged: for charitie doth spread abroad her waters wheresoever is need of them. Or lastly, let us make us pooles by digging into the depth of heavenly knowledge. For as Gregory Nyssene speaketh,Gregor. Nyssen. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 3.
Nihil melius fonte divino per quem animae siccitas irroratur, virtutes oriuntur, & nemus bonorum studiorum & operum in nostris germinet animis, There is nothing better then this divine fountaine, by which the drynesse and barrennesse of our soules is made wet and moystned, by which vertues doe spring up in us, so that even a wood of good desires and works doth sprout forth in our lives.

Verse 7. It is the folly of man, that he is not onely delighted in the vanitie of his owne eyes and of his owne imagination, but also in the vanitie of the eyes of others, and of the imagination that others have of him. The Preacher therefore having shewed, how he tryed his heart with the delight of the one, here he sheweth how he tryed himselfe also with the delight of the other. For what is the pleasure of a
multitude of servants, of a greater multitude of cattell, but that others looke with admiration upon them, and by the great number of them, imagine a great deale of happinesse in him that hath them? And this imagination in others, is that which much increaseth his owne imagination of his owne greatnesse, which the Preacher here expresseth, saying, that he had servants and cattell above all that were in Ierusalem before him: Wherein the pride of man doth even exceed nature, making him to behold himselfe, as if he were not of the same nature, but even of another from all that had foregone him. And in a particular reference to Solomon, we may conceive it as an imagination, that he was King not onely over those that lived with him, but as it were a King over all that had been before him, being above them all in his great retinue of servants,Hieronym. in hunc vers. and possessions of cattle. St. Hierome readeth it, Mercatus sum servos & ancillas, I bought me servants and maydens. But as a Greeke Father speaketh, Quot nummis aestimasti rationem? Quot obolos expendisti pro Dei imagine? At how many pence diddest thou value reason? At how many halfe-pence diddest thou rate the image of God? Plainly, as if these were vanities, glory in the buying of them. To the servants and maydens that were bought, the Preacher addeth those which were borne in his house; and as if they had been borne of his small and great cattell, so doth he joyne them to his great and small cattell. It being the vaine pride of too many men, to reckon those that are under them no better then beasts. But the Originall calleth them 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
filios domus, Sonnes of the house, as shewing, that though they be not sonnes of the body, yet that they are sonnes of the house, and therefore in some sort to be respected as sonnes. After his servants come his cattle, as shewing also that he had his servants to this end, for to looke unto his cattle, and therein to be imployed. And here it may be noted, that it is not onely sayd, that he had servants, but that he had much cattell, so that his cattle were more than his servants, his imployment no lesse than his servants were. Whereas it is the vanitie of many, to have many servants, and few or no cattell, little or no businesse for them, or else that businesse which is worse then none.Seneca Epist. l. 6. Epist. 46. This it is which Seneca condemneth, who sayth, Caenantem dominum stantium servorum turba circumdedit, alius sputa detergit, alius reliquias temulentorum colligit, alius pretiosas aves scindit, & erudito manu frusta colligit, alius vini minister, alius cui convivarum censura commissa est, expectat quos revocet in crastinum, A troope of servants compasse their feasting Master, one wipeth away that which is spitten, another taketh away the fowle trenchers, another carveth the costly birds, and with his artificiall hand divideth them into pieces, another filleth the wine, to another is committed the disposing of the guests, Gen. 18.6. & 7. and he expecteth whom he must invite the next day. It is true, that Abraham had many servants, but that they were all imployed, it appeareth, because when the three men came to his Tent, there was none at home, but himselfe ran for a Kid, and his wife made ready the meale. And in Athenaeus it is related, that among the Trojans one man had a
thousand servants, and some, more; Ac eorum unumquem{que} pacis tempore agros colere; belli vero, militiae nomen dare, suosque illis duces esse dominos, Athenaeus. l. 6. And that in time of peace they did dresse the ground, in time of warre they served in the warre, and had their Masters for their Captaines. And surely where there is not imployment for more, the judgement of St. Chrysostome is, Herum unum uno servo contentum esse decebit, Chrys. in 1. ad Corinth. Homil. 40.
imo uno servo tres heros, It is meet that one Master be contented with one servant, yea three Masters with one servant. It may seeme in some sort that God thought so (though I take it for no argument) and therefore he sayth, Levit. 25.6. That the Sabbath of the Land shall be meate for thee and for thy servant, and for thy mayd, As if God supposed that one Master should not have above one servant, one mayden.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome applying this verse in a mystery to Christ the King of his Church: by the servants understandeth those, Qui habent spiritum timoris in servitute, & spiritualia magis desiderant quam habent, who have in servitude the spirit of feare, and doe rather desire spirituall things then enjoy them: by the maydens, he understandeth those soules, which are yet addicted to the world and flesh: by those borne in the house, he understandeth those who are members of the Church, and are before the servants and maydens before mentioned, Necdum tamen libertate donati sunt nec nobilitate a Domino, but yet are not set free or ennobled by their Master. Others he sayth there are in this family of the Preacher, who for their ignorance and simplicitie in divine things, are no better then Oxen or Sheepe, having not attayned, Vt homines esse mereantur, & redeant ad imaginem conditoris, that they should be accounted men, as being returned to the image of their Maker.

Verse 8. To make up the greatnesse of his wealth, whereof he spake in the end of the former verse, here he addeth, that he gathered silver and gold, whereby indeed he made up the greatnesse of his vanitie. For they are gold and silver, which are the worst riches, though most esteemed of, and which doe bring the greatest evils unto men. Wherefore the Scripture declaring how hard it is for the rich to enter into heaven, and yet shewing Abraham and Iob to be rich, who no doubt are possessed of heaven. Saint Chrysostome sayth,Chrysost. in Epist. ad Timoth. Homil. 12.
Opes illis non in auri argentique talentis erant, sed in pecoribus: quae profecto divitiae & innocuae & divinitus permissae sunt, Their riches were not in talents of gold and silver, but in store of cattle: which are hurtlesse riches, and allowed by God. Wherefore God hath placed these kindes of riches upon the face of the earth, as shewing them to man, and offering them unto his paines and diligence: but gold and silver he hath hid in the bowels of the earth, to keepe men from seeking of those things which are so pernicious unto them. And indeed in seeking of those riches the greedinesse of mans desire is sooner satisfied, then in seeking of gold and silver: in possessing of those riches the uncharitablenesse of mans heart is not so hard, as in gold and silver: in keeping of those riches the feare of mans minde is not so troublesome as in keeping of gold and silver.
For how is the money-rich man,Sidonius Apollinaris. Epist. l. 2. Epist. 13.
Septus armis ac satellitibus, ac ferro pressus ut premat aurum? Hedged about with weapons and Guards, and pressed downe with iron, that he may presse under him and keepe close his gold, as Sidonius Apollinaris speaketh? But gold and silver being the common treasure of many, the Preacher sheweth that he had the peculiar treasure of Kings, and of the Provinces, that is, sayth the French translation, The most precious jewels which are found with Kings, and throughout the Provinces. And because the gathering of gold and silver depriveth men many times of other delights; the Preacher sheweth how in his wealth, and with his wealth, he sought the delights of musicke, that so he might finde if he could that good thing of mans life, wherein he might rejoyce. He got him men-singers, and women-singers; but the Originall is diversified onely by the masculine and feminine gender; and it being the manner of Scripture by that variation to expresse a generalitie or universalitie of things, wee may here understand all kindes of singers, as in the end of the verse by the variation of the singular and plurall number, are expressed all sorts of musicall instruments. Now these are called the delights of the Sonnes of men, because the musicke of instruments is proper unto men, whereas the musicke of the voyce is in birds also. Or else we may understand the delights of the Sonnes of men, of musick generally, great being the power which the delight of musick hath upon men. Of which King Theodoric writing to Boetius in Cassiodore sayth;Cassiodorus. l. 2. var. 41.
Haec quum de secreto naturae tanquam sensuum regina, tropis suis ornata processerit, reliquae cogitationes exiliunt, omniaque facit ejici, ut ipsam solummodo delectet audiri. Tristitiam jucundat, furores attenuat, saevitiam blandam efficit, ignaviam excitat, vigilantibus reddit requiem, vitiatam turpi amore revocat ad castitatem, & quod beatum curationis genus est per dulcissimas voluptates expellit animi passiones, & per insensibilium obsequium praevalet sensuum exercere dominatum, When shee commeth from the secret of nature, as it were the Queene of the senses, adorned with her musicall figures, other thoughts skip away, and shee causeth all things to be cast out, that there may be a delight onely of hearing her. Shee sweetneth griefe, mollifieth rage, mitigateth crueltie, quickneth lazinesse, giveth rest to the watchfull, maketh her chast who hath been defiled with uncleane love, and that which is a most blessed kinde of curing, by most sweet pleasures driveth away the passions of the minde, and by the subjection of things that are insensible, obtaineth command over the senses. But though this be the delight of the sonnes of men, let the delight of the sonnes of God be the musicke and harmony of their lives unto Gods cōmandements: for as Cassiodore speaketh,Cassiodorus, l. de Musica. Quando iniquitates gerimus, muficā non habemus, when we commit wickednesse, we have not then musick. Thus have we the end of the verse rendred in our translation, because as I conceive, the former words speake of singing. The Septuagint do render the latter part of the verse, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pocillatores & pocillatrices, men cup-bearers and women cup-bearers; or as St. Hierome hath it, Ministros vini & ministras,
men-servers and women-servers of wine, and I suppose it to be rendred so, because Solomon (as it appeareth) had such cup-bearers,2 Chron. 9.4. as that the Queene of Sheba wondred at them. Arias Montanus doth render it captivam & captivas, that is, many captive women; and to the same effect Pagnine, supposing the Preacher to meane such delicate captive women as were taken in warre. Wherein as they have some furtherance from the roote of the Originall word, so it may be they were pleased the rather with that translation, because of the words going immediately before. The delight of the sonnes of men. But how the Originall is here to be taken, he that is the originall of all languages and words knoweth best.

Verse 9. The Preacher had before shewed at the fourth verse, how he had made great works, and here he sheweth how he was made great by his works, and by his houses, by his vineyards, by his gardens, orchards and trees of all kinds, and of all kindes of fruits, by his pooles of water, and by his watered woods, by his servants and maydens, and by his much cattle great and small, by his silver and gold and peculiar treasure of Kings and Provinces, by his singers of all kindes, and musicall instruments of all sorts: and from hence is shewed that it was to make himselfe great, that he made himselfe great workes. For this it is which the heart of man seeketh after in this world before all things. Luk. 12.18. The rich foole in the Gospel sayth, that he will build his barnes greater; he speaketh not of the strength of his barnes, nor of the commodiousnesse of them, but only of the greatnesse of them, that by the greatnesse of them his owne greatnesse might be set out. It is not without some mystery that the blind man beginning to recover his sight, sayth, that he saw men walking as trees. Mark. 8.24. For mans blindnesse doth not otherwise looke upon men, then it looketh upon trees, esteeming of them according to their talnesse and greatnesse. For so it esteemeth of men according to their greatnesse and talnesse in worldly estate and earthly vanities. But St. Chrysostome admonisheth us, Si videris virum speciosum, Chrys. Homil. in Psal. 150.
ne admireris, nam & arbores altitudine excelsae, If thou seest a goodly tall man, doe not admire him, for trees are of a great talnesse also: and if thou seest a man great in worldly estate, doe not gaze upon him, it is but a worldly greatnesse that is in him. For though Solomon were great and encreased, yet it was onely more then they that were in Ierusalem before him: not more then they that were in the feare of God before him, not more then they that were in vertue and holinesse before him. There is no comparison betweene the greatnesse of the world, and the greatnesse of them. But Solomon also telleth us, that his wisedome remained with him. And surely he had need to tell us so, for else it might have been feared much, least these worldly delights had spoyled him of that: else it might have been thought, that while he followed after them, he had forsaken that, and while he filled himselfe with the one, he emptied himselfe of the other. Well also it is, that he calleth it my wisedome, that is, the wisdome which God gave him, divine and heavenly, for else it might have been doubted,
least he had beene deceived, and had thought that to be wisedome, which hath a shadow of wisedome, but is none in truth. For there is a wisedome in the sonnes of this world, a wisedome which looketh to the pleasing of the flesh, regardeth not the hurting of the soule; a wisedome whereby they being fearefull where no feare is, they have no care where the greatest danger is. But this was not the wisedome which Solomon received from heaven, and of which he sayth, my wisedome continued with me. Saint Hierome reads it, Ad stitit mihi, my wisedome stood by me. Gregory Nyssene reads it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
stetit mihi, stood with me: and so doe Pagnine and Arias Montanus render it. So that although he increased in worldly greatnesse, yet he did not in wisedome: that stood still. The time and desire which he spent upon worldly delights, left him no time, no desire to looke after the benefiting of himselfe therein. All that he can say, is, and that is much considering his present disposition, that his wisedome stayd with him. That was at a stay, while he went on from delight to delight. Or else wee may take his meaning, that besides all his other delights, also his wisdome remained with him, as shewing that to be his chiefest delight, and which made up the fulnesse of all the rest.

Verse 10. After the matter and objects of the Preachers delight, wee have here the manner of his seeking it, and the manner of his enjoying it. First, the manner of his seeking it, and if we take the end of the former verse,Greg. Nyss. in Eccles. Homil. 4. with reference to this, as Gregory Nyssene doth, then by the remaining of his wisedome with him, he meaneth that his wisedome served him, to search out delights for him, and to direct him to the greatest of them, and in the greatest to the greatnesse of their delight. To the wisedome of his understanding, he added the helpe of his eye, which is a sense both eager and quicke in hunting after pleasant delights. And he sayth, that he gave it free and full scope, it had all the play of the game: for whatsoever his eyes desired, he kept not from them. Now certainly the eye is most forward in desiring, and if it may have for asking, it will aske often enough. Yea indeed too bold it is, and too often taketh leave where it is not granted, and yeeldeth to desire, when care laboureth to keepe it away. Wherefore take wee heed of giving this libertie, and let it be our care to keepe our eyes shut from the delights of them.Paulinus Epist. 4.
Paulinus doth well admonish us, Reminiscamur qua pernicie illis in Paradiso oculi sunt aperti: quos tamdiu habuerunt illuminatos, quamdiu clausos habuere peccato, Let us remember how unhappily their eyes were opened unto them, that were in Paradise: which they had illightned, so long as they had them shut unto sinne. Where we reade, Mat. 6.22. the eye is the light of the body, the Greeke is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , lucerna corporis, the lampe, the candle of the body: for as a lampe burneth very well, and giveth good light so long as it is shut up and kept close within some roome: but if it be set open in the ayre, is soone blowne out with the winde; so the eye if it be kept shut from vanities by a watchfull carefulnesse, then it giveth the best light to the
body; but if it bee wantonly and negligently opened, then the good light of it is soone put out. Of this the Poet singeth sweetly,Arator. Quum lumina claudit, Pectora tunc aperit, coeli{que} cognoscitur autor: Discedente die, quantum meruere tenebrae, when the eyes are shut, then the heart is opened, and then is God discerned: when the day goeth away, how great is the benefit which the night bringeth. But to returne to the Preacher, who when his wisdome had searched, and his eyes sought for delight, then permitted his heart to make choice of what joy it would: hee used no restraint, but to the pleasure of the joy added also the pleasure of a free choice. For joy it is that the heart of man would have, and yet almost it would not have it, unlesse it might have it in this manner, that it selfe may have a freedome in the choosing of it. But what doth the Preacher speake of not withholding his heart from any joy? Can there be any joy, where God is not? Philo tels us,Philo. l. Quod deterior potiori insidietur. Opifex est Deus boni risus, & gaudii, ideo{que} Isaac non vulgariter genitus, sed operante Deo credendus est. Nam si risus Isaac intelligitur, risus autem factor est Deus, The worker of good laughter is God, and therefore Isaac is not in a common manner borne, but by faith he is conceived. For if Isaac be understood laughter, it is God who is the cause of laughter and joy to the heart. But it was no true joy, it was a worldly joy wherof the Preacher speaketh, and that he sheweth by speaking of the labour also which was joyned with it, saying, My heart rejoyced in all my labour. Labour there was in the seeking of it, labour in the possession of it, and yet this is the All, which man seeketh of all his labour: this is the portion which the Preacher saith he desired to obtaine, and this he saith he had, there being no sicknesse, no enemy, no other crosse either in mind or body, at home or abroad, to disturbe him in it, or deprive him of it. So that wee have here under the law, the Prodigall of the Gospell, Luk. 15. asking his portion of his Father: which is devided to him, and spent by him in the farre Country of this world upon worldly delights.

Verse 11. Wee have here the Prodigall returned to himselfe, and Solomon saying as the Septuagint have it, Quum convertissem me, when I had turned my selfe to all my workes, I saw the feeding of my pleasures to be, but the feeding of swine, and the joy wherewith I would faine have fed my selfe, to have beene but as huskes. And therefore now deviding all his pleasures before particularly mentioned into two kinds, the outward workes of his hands, and the inward contentment of his phantasy and senses, now looking upon them with the eye of his mind, he doth not call them joyes and pleasures, but working only and labour. And whereas in the beginning of the former Chapter, hee had said, that all is vanity, he repeateth the same againe, as shewing that he meant it of all the contentments of this life.Chrysost. in Psal. 4. Now Saint Chrysostome tell us, Vanum est quod est inane, quando nomen quidem fuerit, res nequaquam. Nomen divitiarum, res autem minime, & nomen gloriae, res vero minime, nomen potentiae & remanet nomen solum. Quis est ergo adeo excors ut quaerat nomina, quae rebus defecta sunt, & persequatur inania, quae oportet
fugere, That is vaine which is empty, when there is a name, but not any thing at all, a name of riches, but not the thing, a name of glory, but without the thing, a name of power, but the name is only to be found. Who is therefore so voyd and empty of understanding, as to seeke after names which have not the things, and to follow after those vaine things which should be shunned. It seemeth, that before Solomon did not looke upon the things, but only after the satisfying of his desire: but now looking upon the things, and seeing them the better, because he had tryed them,Petrus Damian. Epist. l. 2. Ep. 17. he pronounced them to be vanity, that is, saith Petrus Damianus, Qui tot momentanearum rerum congessit exempla, non tam vile quid esse omnem mundanam gloriam, quam nihil esse signavit, He that had gathered together the exemplary proofes of so many momentany things, sheweth all worldly glory, not so much to be a vile thing, as rather to bee nothing. Wherefore a Greeke Father also saith, Qui ad haec adspicit, nihil aspicit, Hee that looketh on these things, beholdeth nothing. Yea not only doth the Preacher judge them to be nothing, but a vexation of spirit: nothing in themselves, and yet a vexation of Spirit to him that embraceth them: nothing, besides this one thing a vexation of mind. Wherefore he addeth, And there was
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Nihil amplius, nothing more under the Sun. The Septuagint, and according to them the vulgar Latine doe render it, Et nihil permanere sub sole, and nothing to remaine under the Sunne, nothing which he could lay hold of, nothing to which he could firmely adhere, and on which settle himselfe, as shewing this to bee the vanity of worldly things, and the vexation of them.Greg. Nyssen. in Eccles. Hom. 4.
Gregory Nyssene understandeth it of the short continuance of sensuall delights, so that, Quum cessaverit operatio, deletur etiam sensus voluptatis, ne{que} ejus quicquam amplius reconditur, When the operation ceaseth, the feeling of the pleasure is also abolished, and there is not any thing that is reserved of it. Our translation reads it, There was no profit. For what profit can there bee, when of all things there is one end, vanity? Vnlesse that any one can find profit in vexation of spirit. Lastly, seeing the Preacher useth so often this phrase under the Sun, perhaps hee considered, Psal. 18.5. what his father said of God, Posuit in sole Tabernaculum suum, he hath set his Tabernacle in the Sunne, as the Septuagint and the vulgar Latine have it: as shewing that he speaketh of all things in this world under God. Or else the meaning of the phrase is, that as farre and wide as the Sunne shineth there is no true profit to be found upon earth in earthly things. The insulae fortunatae, fortunate Ilands, which any one may talke of, are but meere dreames, not lying any where under the Sunnes light.

q.p: VER. 12. And I turned my selfe to behold wisedome, and madnesse, and folly; for what can the man doe that commeth after the King? Even that which hath beene already done.
VER. 13. Then I saw that wisdome excelleth folly, as farre as light excelleth darkenesse.
VER. 14. The wise mans eyes are in his head, but the foole walketh in darknesse: and I my selfe perceived also that one event hapneth to them all.
VER. 15. Then said J in my heart; as it hapneth to the foole, so it hapneth even to me, and why was J then more wise? Then J said in my heart, That this also is vanity.
VER. 16. For there is no remembrance of the wise more than of the foole for ever, seeing that which now is, in the dayes to come shall bee forgotten: and how dyeth the wise man? as the foole.
VER. 17. Therefore I hated life, because the worke that is wrought under the Sunne is grievous unto me: for all is vanity and vexation of spirit.

div.p:
Verse 12. The Preacher having returned to himselfe, and rightly judged of the vanity of all inferiour and sensuall delights; he turneth himselfe now to view and consider the things belonging to the mind. Saint Hierome and Gregory Nyssene begin the verse thus, Respexi ut viderem,
I looked that I might behold, that is, he carefully looked, that he might understand. For many there are that doe looke upon things, but it is not to behold, it is not to understand them, it is onely because they stand in their way, because they offer themselves to their sight. But he that will judge of things, must looke upon them, as here the wise man doth, he must looke upon them, that hee may behold them, he must looke upon them, that he may looke into them. To expresse the passing of the Preacher from one matter to another, the Septuagint, and the Vulgar Latine after them, begin the verse thus, Transivi ad contemplandum, Hugo de Sancto Vict. in hunc vers. I passed to consider; and Hugo de Sancto Victore noteth upon it, that Hebraeus, and Hebrew in the Originall signifieth Transeuntem one that passeth along, as if the King were made a right Hebrew herein. For let the heathen boast of what they can, the Hebrewes were the first that attained to humane wisdome, and knowledge. But to passe on with the Preacher. To behold wisedome and madnesse and folly: by wisdome I understand a Philosophicall prudence, by madnesse the curiosity of men, either in pursuing after things above their strength, or in pleasing themselves with their owne toyes, by folly the simplicity of men in not perceaving or misapprehending the right course of things. Saint Hierome supposeth these two to be added to wisdome, as noting the wisdome to which man attaineth,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Plus erroris stultitiae{que} habere quam verae certae{que} prudentiae. Ita{que} illa quae novimus, opinari nos potius quam tenere, & aestimare magis quam scire quod verum est, To have in it more errour and folly, then true and certaine wisdome. And therefore that even those things which we doe know, wee doe rather imagine then apprehend, and doe suppose rather then conceive that which is right. Now this doth well agree with that reading which a Greeke Father hath of the latter part of the verse, who saith, Quis est homo, qui ingredietur post consilium ea, quaecun{que} ipsum fecit? Who is the man that will enter after counsell into all those things, which counsell it selfe hath made? To which the answer is implyed, it is madnesse and folly to attempt it, it is madnesse and folly that is attained by it. Where the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is translated counsell, according to the Chaldee signification of it: and Gregory Nyssene telleth us, that by counsell in the latter part, is understood that wisdome whereof the first part of the verse speaketh. But to take madnesse and folly, as they are plainely opposed to wisdome, it is well noted by Hugo, that first he looked upon wisdome,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 7. as thereby comming to behold madnesse and folly. For as he speaketh, Nemo ad tenebras vadit ut videat tenebras, sed ad lucem venit ut videat per lucem, non solum lucem, sed & tenebras & lucem, No one goeth to darknesse, that he may see darknesse; but he commeth to the light, that by the light he may see, not only light, but light and darknesse also. First therefore the Preacher saith, that hee beheld wisedome, that so he might behold In ipsâ quod ipsa est sapientia, & per ipsam, errores & stultitiam, quod ipsa non est sapientia, In wisedome it selfe, what it selfe is, and by it selfe madnesse and folly, which wisedome it selfe is
not, as Hugo addeth. The last part of the verse the Septuagint doe read in a much different manner: and Saint Hierome tels us, that from their reading, Multum in hoc loco sensus diversus est, much in this place is the sense different. But I doe not see, but that the sense also is as much different from the reading which himselfe bringeth. Our translation agreeth with Tremellius, but that it agreeth fully with the Originall is more than I perceive. I desiring to come as neere to the Originall, as I could, should render it thus, for what is that man, who shall attaine after the King, to that which they have already made him? That is, to that which wisdome, and the knowledge of madnesse and folly have made him: thereby implying the perfection to which he had attained, so that he was the better able to judge of these things. There is in this verse, and the former, and in some other verses, a kind of emphaticall use of the pronoune 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ego, I turned my selfe. And I conceive that it is so used by the Preacher; thereby to shew unto us, that it was a thing, which he did of himselfe, and of his owne setled purpose; and that it was not done by the meanes of any other occasion.

Verse 13. Then I saw, That is, hee had no sooner turned himselfe to behold, but he saw presently the excellency of wisdome above folly: it being so great, so manifest, that it appeared forthwith, and was as clearely discerned as the excellency of light is above the darknesse. But yet he saw, before he judged; he did not rashly deliver his sentence, as the manner of too many is, commending things and preferring them before others, before they see any good cause why to doe it. Of Almighty God Saint Ambrose saith, Quae probat videt, Ambros. Hexam. l. 1. cap. 9.
& quae videt probat, Those things which he approveth he seeth, and those things which he seeth he approveth; and so it is with those that feare God, they doe not approve any thing but that which they see to be good, neither doe they delight to see any thing, but that which for the goodnesse of it, they approve. And fitly is it said, that he saw the excellency of wisedome. For as Saint Ambrose also saith, Bonorum proprium est, Ambrosus Ibid. ut externo commendatore non egeant, sed gratiam suam quum videntur ipsa testantur. Plus est quod probatur aspectu, quam quod sermone laudatur, It is the property of good things, that they doe not need an externall prayser, but themselves when they are seene, doe testifie their grace. It is a greater excellency which is approved by sight, then that is which is commended by speech. Againe by this phrase hee doth properly set out the nature of wisdome, Quae videndo complacet, quoniam ipsa videndi officium subministrat, which pleaseth in being seene, because it is it selfe which giveth ability of rightly seeing things. Then I saw that wisdome excelleth folly: It is a humane wisdome whereof I conceive him to speake, which therefore though he could not free from vanity, yet doth he preferre before folly, as much as light is to be preferred before darknesse. Now light hath God himselfe for the praiser of it, and it is the first thing that God praised. Let there bee light, is the first word that God ever spake, and that God saw the light to be good, is the first praise that God ever
gave.Ambr. Jbid. Wherefore Saint Ambrose saith, Vnde vox Dei in divina Scriptura debuit inchoare, nisi a lumine? Vnde mundi ornatus nisi a luce exordium sumere? From whence ought the voice of God, in Scripture to begin, but from the light? From whence should the beauty of the world take his beginning, but from the lights excellency? Assoone as God had made the light, hee divided the darkenesse from it, as if he would not have the excellency thereof to be dishonoured by the company of it: or as shewing the unworthinesse of darknesse, as not being fit to be joyned with light. Let it therefore be our care also, to divide wisdome from folly: the society of the one doth much shame the other, and indeed most unworthy is folly, so much as to be joyned in comparison with wisdome.

Greg. Nyss. in Eccles. Verse 14. Gregory Nyssene speaking of this verse saith, Estne ullum animal eorum qui caput habent, quod habaet oculos extra caput? Is there any living creature which hath a head, and hath not his eyes in his head? What is this therefore, that the Preacher saith of a wiseman, that he hath his eyes in his head? The answer which hee giveth is this. That Christ is the head of a wiseman, and that his eyes are fixed upon Christ.Greg. Mag. Moral. l. 17. cap. 5. And so doth Saint Gregory the great expound or rather apply the words saying, Sapiens quisque illum tota intentione considerat, cujus se membrum per fidem pensat, Every wise man thinketh upon him with the whole intention of his mind, a member of whom by faith he considereth himselfe to be.Olympiod. in hunc vers. Olympiodorus expounding the words, more largely saith, That a Wise man hath his eyes in his head, Quia ad suprema visum & animum erectum habet, coelestia meditatur, cogitat{que} illa quae Dei sunt, non contemplante illo quae videntur, sed quae non videntur, Because he hath his sight and his mind lifted up unto the highest things, he meditateth heavenly things, he thinketh on the things of God, he mindeth not those things which are seene, but those things which are not seene. Gregor. Neocaesariensis expounding those words saith, Sicut sapienter Deus custodes oculos in capite collocavit ut longius pertingere visu possint; Sic sapiens in capite ponit visum, h. e. intellectum suum (hic est oculus animae) h.e. ita ut quae à longe sunt prospicere valeat, As God hath wisely placed those keepers, the eyes in the head, from whence their sight is able to reach farre; so a wise man placeth his sight, that is, his understanding (for that is the eye of the soule) in his head, that is, so, that hee may bee able to discerne those things which are a farre of, as namely what shall bee at death, what after death, what account hee shall give to God, what in hell the damned suffer, what in heaven the blessed enjoy. And then going on and expounding the next words he saith, But the foole walketh in darknesse, Greg. Neocaesariensis in hunc vers. that is, Ignorat haec omnia, & qui haec ignorat, caecus & stultus est, quamvis omnes mundi scientias norit, Is ignorant of all these things, and hee that is ignorant of these things is blind and a foole, although he have all the knowledge of the world. Wherefore a Greeke Father also saith, Verae sunt tenebroe acer visus in sensibilibus, A sharp sight in worldly things is indeed true darkenesse. A foole then hath
not his eyes in his head but in his heeles, Nam quando vis animae contemplativa occupatur in rebus sensibilibus, in ejus calcaneos oculorum transit natura, For when the contemplative power of the soule is busied in worldly things, the nature of the eyes passeth to the heeles, which the Serpent pursueth, and biteth with his teeth, as Gregory Nyssene also hath it. But if we take the wise man here to be a humane wise man, we may understand his eyes to be in his head, because he looketh in capita et principia rerum, into the causes and beginnings of things, and marketh what is chiefely to be regarded in them; whereas a foole walketh in darknesse, neither considering from whence things come and arise, neither whither they goe, nor to what they tend. A wise man seeth what is past, foreseeth what is to come, and accordingly ordereth his wayes; whereas a foole, looketh no farther then the present, and when evill is present to seise upon him, then onely seeth it. A wise man is sharp-sighted and circumspect, marking all circumstances for the right doing of any thing; wheras a foole goeth on in a confused blind manner in all that he doth. But against this preferring of wisedome before folly, as much as light is before darknesse: against this placing of a wise man above a foole, as much as the head is above the feete, the Preacher objecteth, That one event happeneth to them all: he sayth not to them both, but to all of both; to all wise men, to all fooles. And this objection he sayth that others need not to make, but that himselfe also perceived it, himselfe made it in his minde, and that thereupon he sayd in his heart, as the next verse sheweth.

Verse 15. I have not omitted to give such usefull expositions of the former verses, as the words would beare. But the wisedome wherof the twelfth verse speaketh, being as I conceive to be understood of humane prudence and understanding: in the thirteenth verse, that is sayd to give light to him that hath it, and therefore to preferre him before the ignorant who is in darknesse: in the fourteenth verse it is sayd to be the eyes of the wise man, because he seeth farre into the natures, conditions, causes, reasons, circumstances, vertues, operations, events of things; whereas the foole walking in darknesse, seeth not the things that are obvious unto him, and lie before his feete when he walketh. But against this the Preacher objecteth, that although the wise man seeth so farre into the nature and condition of things, and into the event of them, yet that one event happeneth to them all. And to this objection answering in this fifteenth verse; first of all he granteth it; secondly, he applyeth it; thirdly, he repineth at it; fourthly, he delivereth his sentence upon it. He granteth it in these words, Then sayd I in my heart, I sayd that it was so, and in my heart confessed it to be true. He applyeth it in these words, As it happeneth to the foole, so it happeneth even to me, I cannot deny it in my selfe, of whom it cannot be denyed, that my wisedome is the greatest of any. He repineth in these words, And why was I then more wise? Why did I take so much paines to be wise? Why did I so carefully search into the nature and condition of things, forecast the events
of things? He delivereth his sentence in these words, Then I sayd in my heart, that this is also vanitie. Then I concluded of it, and sayd in my heart, when I had considered of it, that this is also vanitie. And that we may not thinke it to be a small matter which he sayth,Ambros. de Abrah. l. 2. c. 10. St. Ambrose sayth, Quid deterius vanitate? What is worse then vanitie? The vanitie whereof this verse speaketh, is this, That all the learning and wisedome of man, is not able to dispose of the event of things, but that as they fall out to fooles, so oftentimes to wise men. And therefore I may use the words of S. Austin, though not in his sense, Ambulat homo in imagine veritatis, Augustin. de Temp. Serm. 50.
& conturbatur in consilio vanitatis, Man walketh in a shadow of truth, and is disquieted in the counsell of vanitie. This is that which the Psalmist teacheth, Psal. 38.6. Surely every man walketh in a vaine shew: surely they are disquieted in vaine: he heapeth up riches and knoweth not who shall gather them. His wisedome provideth that his sonne may gather them, that his sonne, a good husband, a wise man may enjoy them. But yet he knoweth not, what shall be; perhaps it shall be so, perhaps not;Augustin. Ibid. and as St. Austin speaketh, Inter forte fiet, forte non fiet; nescit quid fiet, & vane conturbatur, betweene perhaps it shall be done, perhaps it shall not be done, he knoweth not what shall be done, and disquieteth himselfe in vaine.Greg. Moral. l. 2. c. 25. St. Gregory sheweth this vanitie very well, saying, Saepè dum cautus futurae praevidet, incautus damna praesentia non videt: saepe dum plus justo vigilantem se in actione exhibet, ipsa actionis suae inquietudine rebus subditis pejus nocet: plerumque tantis cogitationum voluminibus implicatur, ut ipse ferre vix valeat, quae inter se providus versat, et quum nihil opere faciat, sub magno cordis sui pondere vehementer insudet: plerumque quasi ventura animus conspicit et fit plerumque ut nulla eveniant, quae praevidentur, totaque cogitatio illa quae diu plenâ se intentione paraverat, repente vacua requiescit, Oftentimes while he is wary in foreseeing things to come, unawares he doth not see present evils: oftentimes while he is too vigilant in his businesse, his owne troublesomnesse doth most hurt the businesse: not seldome he is so overwhelmed with the waves of his own thoughts, that he is unable to cary himselfe up in those things which his provident care tosseth up and downe in his mind; and when he effecteth nothing, he strugleth mightily under the burden of his owne heart: not seldome his minde even beholdeth the things that are to come, and often it commeth to passe that none of them fall out; and all that imagination which with a great deale of earnestnesse made it selfe ready to entertaine what it looked for, resteth at length emptie of what it expected. What therefore should this teach man, but not to trust to his owne wisedome? What therefore should man doe, but with the care and diligence of his owne wisedome, seeke to God for his blessing upon on his wisedome, to whom the events of all things are knowne, and by whom they are disposed? To God let every one commit the event of things, and let no one judge of a wise mans care by the event that followeth it.Greg. Nyss. in hunc vers.

Verse 16. Gregory Nyssene taketh the objection of the fourteenth
verse to be proposed by the Preacher in the person of some other, and that rejecting it himselfe, he sayth, This is also vanitie. Accordingly therefore in this verse, he conceiveth the Preacher to confirme his rejecting of it. And when the Preacher sayth, Non est memoria sapientis cum stulto in aeternum, The remembrance of the wise man is not with the foole for ever (for so the Originall goes) he conceiveth it, That the memory of the wise man is for ever, but the memory of the foole is not so. And therefore that although both dye, yet the dying of both is not alike. For as Hugo sayth,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 12.
Sapientia quae vitae praesenti mortalitatem non tollit, futurae vitae tribuit aeternitatem, Wisedome which doth not take away the mortalitie of this present life, giveth eternitie to the life to come. And whereas the Preacher sayth, The things which now are, in the dayes to come shall be forgotten, Gregory Nyssene understandeth them of the things of a foole. Lastly, whereas the Preacher sayth, How dyeth the wise man? as the foole. (For so the Originall may be well rendred) he conceiveth it in this manner. How therefore doth any one say, that the one dyeth as the other? For as Hugo de Sancto Victore also sayth, Quare unâ viâ ab hac vita exeunt, Hugo de Sanct. Vict. Ibid. qui post hanc vitam ad unum praemium non pertingunt? Why doe they goe the same way out of this life, who after this life doe not come unto the same reward? But to understand this passage of the prudent and foolish, learned and unlearned; for so in this place the Septuagint, and after them the Vulgar Latin doe reade it, saying, Mo itur doctus similiter et indoctus, The learned dyeth as well as the unlearned. And to take Solomon as granting the objection made in the fourteenth verse, here he confirmeth the truth of it by another argument; because the memory of the wiseman, as well as of the foole doth not abide for ever. They are the words of King Theodoric in Cassiodore, though there uttered in another sense,Cassiodoru • . var. Magnum beneficium, oblivionis nescire defectum, & quaedam similitudo verè coelestium est, It is a great benefit, not to know the decay of forgetfulnesse, and it is a kinde of similitude of true heavenly things. But it is the condition of a wise man as well as of a foole to be forgotten: and though a wise man may be remembred somewhat longer then a foole; yet in respect of for ever, they are both forgotten alike. For in that, in eternitie, the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the Iam, the now dierum transeuntium of dayes that passe away is wholy swallowed up, wholy forgotten; in which manner I conceive the Originall words to be most fitly translated. And though while the wise man and the foole live, there be some difference betweene them, yet when they are dead, in respect of the memory of them for ever there is no difference. For so I understand the last part of the verse in reference to the former, and doe not take it to be another argument, prooving the equalitie of them, in that they both dye. But yet seeing the words may be so taken, it may be considered, that though the learned man know many things, yet he knoweth not how to escape death, that is beyond his skill. And as Seneca sayth,Seneca. Errores fortunae mors inevitabilis reformat, inevitable death reformeth the errours of fortune, making the
rich and poore, noble and ignoble alike; So it may be sayd, Differentias scientiae mors confundit, The differences of learning death confoundeth, and shuts up both learned and unlearned in the grave. Laertius Laertius. reporteth, that Alexander seeing Diogenes tumbling among dead bones, he asked him what he sought, to whom the other replyed, that which I cannot finde, the difference betweene the rich and the poore. And he that shall seeke there the difference betweene the learned and unlearned, shall never finde it also. Wherefore this may well quell the pride of any ones wisedome, any ones learning: and let this make every wise man, to seeke that happinesse, wherein not onely his memory but himselfe shall be immortall.

Verse 17. I hated life: I who abounded so much with all things, which might make me to love it. I whom the delights of this life did even wooe, to winne mine affection. I hated. Indeed I had given mine heart to the pleasures of this life, I had pursued them with the heate of mine affection: but finding my heart to be deceived, my desire frustrated, my love deluded, this hath turned it into hatred. I hated life, not onely the things of this life, but even life it selfe which is spent in such things, as being foolishly led on, shamefully wasted, wretchedly imployed.Ambros. de bono mortis. c. 2. For as St. Ambrose speaketh, Quid est, quo haec vita delectet, in qua et multae molestiae, et multae lachrymae eorum, qui afflictantur molestiis, & non est qui eos consoletur? What is there in this life that may truely please, in which there are many troubles, and many teares of those that are troubled, and there is not at all wherewith to comfort them? Therefore I hated life, therefore, because of the confusion of things before spoken of, Quum tota confusioni sit obnoxia, neque in bonis suis dum stare videtur, neque in malis suis dum finitur, bonos a malis, vel dignos ab indignis secernit, Seeing it is all of it subject to confusion, and neither in the good things of it, while it seemeth to continue, nor in the bad things of it, when it is ended, doth distinguish the bad from the good, or the worthy from the unworthy, as an ancient Writer speaketh. Therefore I hated life, which me seemes Solomon speaketh with such an indignation, as when Seneca sayth,Sene. Quaest. Natur. l. 1.
O quam contempta res est homo, nisi supra humana se erexerit, O how contemptible a thing is man, unlesse he be lifted up above the things of men! But the Originall expresseth it selfe more fully, then by life, that sayth, I hated lives, not onely this kinde of life, or that kinde of life, not onely this time of life, or that time of life, not onely the life of this man, or of that man, but the lives of all men, of all kindes, of all times. I hated mine owne life as well as the life of others. Mine owne life, because the worke that is wrought under the Sunne is grievous unto me: the life of others, because all is vanitie and vexation of spirit. That which our translation hath is grievous unto me, the Originall delivereth thus 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which St. Hierome translateth, Malum supra me, evill above me, above my skill, my strength, my command to make it good unto me by any meanes. Gregory Nyssene translateth it, Malum adversum me, evill against me: for though it pretend the delight and pleasing of me, yet in
truth it is hurtfull and pernicious unto me.Augustin. Epist. 36. ad Licentium. For as St. Austin speaking of the things of this life sayth, Habent asperitatem veram, jucunditatem falsam, certum dolorem, incertam voluptatem, durum laborem, timidam quietem, rem plenam miseriae, spem beatitudinis inanem, They have true bitternesse, false contentment, certaine griefe, uncertaine pleasure, hard labour, fearefull rest, matter full of misery, hope emptie of happinesse. All is vanitie and vexation of spirit. And therefore as St. Ambrose sayth,Ambros. de bono mortis. c. 2.
Quid miserius, quam ut custodia torqueat, quorum abundantia non profit? What more miserable, then that the keeping of those things should torment by vexation of spirit, the abundance whereof by the vanitie of them doth no way profit? The hatred therefore which the Preacher here speaketh of, I conceive to be rather an elegant and forcible expression of the miserable vanitie of mans life, little deserving any love, then that the Preacher had any such affection in himselfe of it.

q.p: VER. 18. Yea I hated all my labour, which I had taken under the Sunne: because J should leave it unto the man that should be after me.

VER. 19. And who knoweth whether he shall be a wise man, or a foole? Yet shall he have rule over all my labour, wherein J have laboured, and wherein I have shewed my selfe wise under the Sunne. This is also vanitie.

div.p:
Verse 18. It is the commandement of God in the law of Moses,
Lev. 11.41. Every creeping thing that creepeth on the earth, shall be an abomination unto thee. And what is all mans labour concerning the things of this life, but a creeping thing on the earth? Wherefore Solomon might well say, I hated all my labour. But there are in this verse couched together six reasons of the Preachers hatred. First, because it was labour and toylesome unto him: secondly, because it was labour taken under the Sunne, and for things of base unworthinesse: thirdly, because he must leave it and passe it over: for as a Father speaketh, Transmissores sumus, non possessores, wee are onely conveyers to others of the things of this life, not possessours of them: fourthly, because he must leave them to the man he knoweth not who: and as St. Austin speaketh, perhaps to some thiefe,Augustin. de Temp. Serm. 50.
Qui una nocte venit, et tot diebus et noctibus congregatum invenit paratum. Et multa quae congregavit inanis vanitas, parata invenit hostilis iniquitas, who commeth in one night, and findeth that ready for him,
which was gathered and laboured for, many dayes and nights. And those things which an idle vanitie scraped together, an hostile crueltie taketh as ready prey: fifthly, because himselfe must goe away, that the other may come after him, and enjoy his labours: lastly, because he doth leave his labours to those, who shall also goe away as himselfe doth.Augustin. Ibid. For they are as St. Austin speaketh, but successuri non permansuri, They are but such, as shall come after him and succeed him, they are not such as shall continue when he is gone. And therefore suppose that a man leaveth his labours to his children, yet St. Austin doth handsomely mocke at it; saying, Magna pietas, thesaurizat pater filiis, imo magna vanitas, thesaurizat moriturus morituris, O great naturall affection, the Father laboureth and gathereth riches for his children; yea rather, O great vanitie, he that shall dye himselfe, laboureth for them that shall dye also. In the beginning of the verse, the Pronoune I, in the Originall is used with an Emphasis, as noting that he was the same who now did hate, who before did love, and that as he had given himselfe to delight in the things of this life, so he could take away himselfe againe, and make himselfe to hate them.Gregor. Nis. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 5. And Gregory Nyssene noting here, that he calleth his pleasures labour, sayth, Per hoc quod laborem nominavit delitias, significat, quod per vim veluti quoddam difficile certamen admisit voluptatis participationem; by this that he termeth his delights labour, he signifieth, that he admitted the tryall of pleasure, as putting himselfe to some distresse, and as it were entring into a hard combat, that his wisedome might both comply with him, and yet keepe a ruling and commanding hand over his delights. Now let the consideration of this verse, make us in our hearts to leave our worldly goods, before that we leave them in the world. And if any hatred arise in us by reason of this misery, let it be against our sinnes the cause of it, not against our labour, wherein we are by God appointed to imploy our time.

Verse 19. From the more generall complaint, of not knowing who shall come after, the Preacher descendeth to a more particular complaint, of not knowing, whether he that commeth after shall be a wise man, or a foole.
