If he be a wise man, then he complaineth, that he shall have rule over all his labour, wherein he hath laboured, and that when he hath taken the paines and care, another shall enjoy the comfort and pleasure of it: if he be a foole, then he complaineth, that he should have authoritie over his labour, wherein he hath shewed himselfe wise under the Sunne. Or else wee may suppose the Preacher, to speake onely of the foole, and to omit to speake of the wise man, that should come after him, as being contented with his owne losse, so that a wise man might gaine his labour and succeed him in it. But that a foole should be master of his labour, as if himselfe had been a servant to him in it; this he sayth is a great vanitie. For though our English Also doth not expresse this unto us, yet the Originall 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth import so much. And therefore the Septuagint, and after them the Vulgar Latin doe render it, Et est quicquam tam vanum? And is there any thing so vaine? For as
Hugo de S. Victore speaketh, Si vana sunt haec omnia, Hugo de Sancto Vict. in Eccles. Homil. 12.
etiam in nostros usus quaesita & retenta, quid erunt ad stultorum voluptatem transmissa? If all these things be vaine, being gotten and kept to our owne use, what will they be being left to the pleasure of a foole? If all these bee vaine being left to a wise sonne, who as Saint Austin speaketh,August. de Temp. Ser. 50.
Servabit quod dimisisti, augebit quod servasti, will keepe that which thou hast left him, will encrease that which thou hast kept: what shall they be being left to a foole, who will manifest his folly in that wherein thou hast shewed thy wisdome, Et fluendo perdet quod tu laborando congregasti; and by a profusenesse will wast that, which thou by labouring hast gathered? Saint Hierome, Hieronym. in hunc vers. because the Preacher speaketh of shewing his wisdome will not have the verse to bee understood of worldly things, for saith hee, what wisedome is there in them? He therefore expoundeth the place of the labours of spirituall wisedome in writing of bookes, wherein a man having laboured night and day, yet they may come into the hands of fooles, who thence may take the seeds of heresie, and bring a slander upon them. A Greeke Father marking those words, hee expoundeth them another way, and saith, It is not the manner of every one, cognitionis causa dimittere sensum, ad faciendum harum rerum periculum. Quod quidem ego inquit, per sapientiam feci, For experience sake to let loose his sensuall delight, thereby to get a tryall of these things, which I by wisedome was able for to doe. For suffering the desire of nature, as it were a young Colt, Libere in inferioribus parumper exultare animi motibus, A little while to sport it selfe freely in the inferiour motions of the soule, I did againe reine it backe by reason, and made it subject to my power. But who can tell, whether hee that shall have rule over my things, will not rather serve his pleasure, then keepe a ruling hand over it, and so like a foole, make my riches and abundance the matter of his wickednesse. But the plainest sense is to understand here a humane wisedome, which Solomon having shewed in his great workes, strong Castles, stately buildings which he had made, hee complaineth that they should come to a foole coming after him, who neither would discerne the wisdome of them, nor have wit how to use them. This therefore should make Parents carefull to bring up their children in knowledge, and the practise of godlinesse, that so the hope of their religious and discreete lives when themselves are dead, may diminish this misery while they are yet alive.

q.p: VER. 20. Therefore I went about to cause my heart to despaire of the labour which I tooke under the Sunne.

VER. 21. For there is a man, whose labour is in wisedome, and in knowledge, and in equity: yet to a man that hath not laboured therein, shall hee leave it for his portion. This also is vanity, and a great evill.

div.p:
Verse 20. We have here Solomon turning another way, for so the Originall most directly soundeth, saying, Then I turned my selfe to make my heart despaire. For faine would his heart find contentment, and seeing it could not be found in the vanity of his labour, he turned his heart to a carelesnesse of his labours, not regarding what did become of them: seeing he could not find it in the vexation of his spirit, he turned his heart to a secure despaire of spirit: there being some imaginary contentment in this,Augustin. in Psal. 129. where none else is to bee had. But as Saint Austin speaketh, Fallax foelicitas, ipsa est major infoelicitas, a deceitfull happines is in it selfe a greater unhappinesse; and whatsoever the ease of this course may be to a distressed mind, it is in it self the greater misery. But Solomon would try all, and therfore here he saith, that he made his heart despaire, and that of all his labour which he took under the Sunne, as well of his better labour, as of his worser, as well of his labour of wisdome, as of his labour to delight his senses, of all, because where there is any hope, there is no despaire. Now here wee have set downe the two causes of despaire, first vanity, secondly vexation. Vanity is a great cause of despaire, for when men have laboured hard, and find no successe, that makes them to despaire of any successe. Thus he that hath taken paines, and tryed many wayes to recall some one from his sinfull courses, but cannot doe it, he despaires of amendment. But as vanity is the cause of this despaire, so the despaire is vanity.Augustin. in Psal. 55. Wherefore Saint Austin saith, Noli dicere, nunquid ecce talem hominem Deus correcturus est tam, malum tam perversum? Doe not say, what will God ever amend such a man, so wicked, so perverse? Noli desperare; quem rogas attende, non pro quo rogas: magnitudinem morbi vides, potentiam medici non vides, Doe not despaire, look to him, to whom thou prayest, doe not looke on him for whom thou prayest: thou seest the greatnesse of the disease, thou dost not see the power of the Physitian. Secondly, vexation of mind is a great cause of despaire; for when the mind is vexed and cannot find comfort, then
it seeketh comfort in not seeking of it. Thus when a haynous sinner is tortured in his Conscience, and cannot get ease, then his ease is to despaire of pardon, then he saith, Fruar hoc saeculo in voluptate, in lascivia, in cupiditate nefaria: jam perdita spe reparationis, vel habeam quod video, si non possum habere quod credo, I will enjoy this life, in pleasure, in wantonnesse, and in the desires of sinne: now the hope of recovery being lost, yet let mee have that which I see, if I cannot have that which I beleeve. But as Saint Austin speaketh, valde in profundo sunt, August. in Psal. 129.
qui nec clamant de profundo, they are sunke very deepe, who doe not cry out of the deepe. And to them David is sent from God, as Nathan was to David, that from him they may learne to seeke, and from his comfort, hope to find the mercy of God, though their sinnes be very great. For as Saint Cyprian speaketh, Nec quantitas criminis, nec brevitas temporis, Cypr. Serm. de Coena Domini. nec horae extremitas, nec vitae enormitas excludit à venia, Neither doth the greatnesse of the fault, not the shortnesse of the time, neither the extremity of the last houre, nor the enormity of the whole life exclude from pardon.2 Sam. 1. When the Amalekite brought newes to David of King Sauls death, and that being desired by himselfe, he slew him, because he saw hee could not live: We read that David presently commanded him to bee put to death, as one condemned by his owne mouth. But what was his offence here? One tels us, Illum David statim morte damnavit, quum percussum ab hoste desperasset esse victurum, & eum sublata spei fiducia jugulasset, Therefore did David slay him, because when the King was wounded by the enemy, he despaired of his life, and that having no confidence of hope he had killed the Lords annoynted. For he should have used his best diligence to have preserved Saul, and not by despaire of helpe, to say he could not live. And surely whether the danger bee our owne, or the danger of any other, we must never despaire, that will make our owne case the more dangerous, the case of others the more remedilesse: and what ease so ever wee may finde in it, it may easily bring evill upon us. But to returne to Solomon, and to his turning himselfe to a carelesse negligence in despaire of things, it serveth to condemne the never wearied covetousnesse of some, the never tyred ambition of others, who notwithstanding the vanity, and vexation that the Preacher sheweth, yet have no stop nor stay of themselves.

Verse 21. The Preacher giveth here the reason of his despaire, because neither wisedome nor knowledge, nor equity were able to give hope to his labour, and what then could? That which our translation and Tremellius reade equity, in the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and by the Septuagint is rendred solicitudo carefulnesse; by Saint Hierome virtus, vertue or power, by Gregory Nyssene it is read 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
animi magnitudo, a courage or greatnesse of mind, by Pagnine and Arias Montanus, rectitudo a rightnesse, but as I conceive, the French doth translate it very well, adressè, a right directing and ordering of things. There is (saith the Preacher) a man, that is, though there be not many such, yet there is a man; and it may be speaking of himselfe and in commendation
of himselfe, therefore hee saith indefinitely there is a man, whose labour is (and I take the Originall to note the labour with some emphasis) in wisdome knowledge and equity. Which may be understood two wayes, either that wisedome knowledge and equity, were the things wherein hee laboured, or else that his labour was about other things, and that they were done in wisedome, knowledge, and equity. Saint Hierome will not have the verse by any meanes to be understood this latter way, for saith he, Quid ad opes terrae pertinent sapientia, scientia, virtus, in quibus se laborasse testatus est, quum sapientiae, scientiae, atque virtutis sit calcare terrena, What doe wisdome, and knowledge and vertue belong to the glorious things of the earth, wherein hee testifieth that hee laboured? When as it belongeth to wisdome, knowledge, and vertue to despise earthly things. And because the Preacher hath before spoken of his labour in wisdome according to this sense, in the nineteenth verse, therefore I doe here rather conceive him to speake in the former sense. And yet if any like better the other meaning, then he may distinguish, wisedome, knowledge, rightnesse in this sort. First, that his labour was in wisdome, because he had layd a wise foundation for it, and for the beginning of it: Secondly, that it was in knowledge, because he proceeded on according to knowledge: and, Thirdly, in rightnesse, because he directed and ordered it to a right end; or else in equitie, because it was without iniquity. According to the other meaning we may distinguish them thus. First, that his labour was in wisedome in respect of higher things: Secondly, in knowledge, in respect of inferiour things: Thirdly, in rightnesse, in respect of a right ordering and directing the affaires of this life, or else in equity, in respect of a just ordering of them. Otherwise they may be distinguished thus. First, that his labour was in wisdome for the matter of it: in knowledge for the manner of it; in rightnesse for the end of it, or else in equity, in regard of an equall and indifferent judgement in the pursuite of it. Hee addeth, Yet to a man that hath not laboured therein shall he leave it for his portion. Now if we follow the latter meaning of the former words, then the Preachers complaint is, that he shall leave his labour to one who hath not laboured with him,Hieronym. in hunc vers. and as Saint Hierome speaketh, Sudor mortui erunt delitiae viventis, the sweate of the dead shall bee the baths of delight to the living. If wee embrace the former meaning of the former words, then the Preachers complaint is, that hee shall leave his labour to him, who hath not laboured in wisedome, knowledge, rightnesse: but being Otiosus an idle person, as the Septuagint have it, hath not taken the paines to bee acquainted with them. And therefore Hugo de Sancto Victore expounding it saith,Hugo de Sancto Vict. in Eccles. Homil. 12.
Nonnunquam subsequentium negligentia hoc paratum in usum assumere respuit, quod priorum sagax diligentia non sine grandi labore ac cura acquisivit, Oftentimes the negligence of them that come after, refuseth to make use of that which is made ready for them, and which the wise diligence of those that went before, obtained with great labour and care. Our translation
saith, leave it, but the Originall saith give it. And perhaps that word is rather to bee used, as shewing that the Preacher speaketh of leaving it to some, either child, or kinsman, or friend: and perhaps thereby the Preacher also aggravateth his complaint, as shewing that it should be his owne deed, and that himselfe should bestow his labours of worth upon an unworthy person: which though he doth in love, yet hee is as it were sorry that hee should doe it. Wherefore hee concludeth. This also is vanity and a great evill. First it is vanity, because it is as Hugo speaketh, In cognitione veritatis laborare, ut in notitiam illorum veniamus, qui veritatem nec propter se suscipere volunt, nec in aliis sciunt approbare, To labour in the knowledge of truth, that wee may come into their knowledge, who neither will embrace the truth for themselves, nor know how to approve of it in others. Secondly, it is evill, Quae si quaerenti labor est, & accipienti utilitas non est, because if it bee labour to the seeker, and no profit to the receiver, how can it choose, as one speaketh, but be evill? Thirdly, it is a great evill, Quia & ille malo suo colligit, & iste accipit in malum, Because the one doth gather it with his evill of labour, the other doth receive it to his evill of shame, as the same Author also goeth on. Or else wee may apply the vanity to the great labour lost, the evill to the idle not-labouring person, the greatnesse of the evill to this, that hee must leave it, who could and would make use of it; that he shall have it, who neither will be nor can bee the better for it. That which our translation hath, for his portion, according to the Originall may bee understood of the labourer, as shewing that to be his portion, the portion of his labour, which hee leaveth to another, that laboured not for it. And if wee understand it of the portion of his estate in this world, a good way to ease the great evill and vanity of it, is to give a good part of it, to GOD and to pious uses, which shall not want a reward. But so cold is the devotion of many herein, that rather than they will give any thing to GOD of whom they have received all, even when they have no children, no kindred, they will give it to a stranger for names sake, or for some other as poore a reason.

q.p: VER. 22. For what hath a man of all his labour, and of the vexation of his heart wherein hee hath laboured under the Sunne.
VER. 23. For all his dayes are sorrowes, and his travell griefe: yet his heart taketh no rest in the night. This is also vanity.

div.p:
Ver. 22. The Preacher here laboureth to expresse the labour of man. For there is labour, but it is without vexation of heart, and though the body toyle, the head worke hard, yet the heart is at rest. There is also vexation of spirit, but it is without labour: and though the heart be disquieted with care, or feare, or desire unsatisfied, or such like passion; yet the body is at ease, the head is not troubled with study to finde out knowledge. But both these are the condition of man, even labour to tire him, and vexation of heart to spend him. But it is more also then these, which is mans burden. For he laboureth in the vexation of his heart, and it is his labour how to put his heart to the greatest vexation, and his heart is even vexed that it is not more vexed. And all this is under the Sunne, all is for the vaine things of this world. For Quid proderit homini? What will it profit a man? saith the Septuagint. What benefit hath hee to recompence this labour? Quid superest? What is remaining to a man? saith Tremellius, What is remaining to a man when all this labour is ended? Quid fit homini? What is done for a man? saith Saint Hierome, What is done for a man, when he hath done, and suffered so much? What hath a man? saith our English, when he hath had such labour, such vexation of heart? Hee proposeth it as a question, and as a wise man, thinking that though himselfe might not bee able to tell, although hee had sought much to know it, yet that some other might know. Hee therefore proposeth it to any one to tell himselfe. Sometimes a question is made, as importing that no answer can be made unto it: but here though the question may expect an answer, yet it supposeth the answer to be nothing. For when it is asked, What hath a man of all his labour? Perhaps some one may answer, as Saint Austin hath it,Augustin. in Psal. 50.
Ecce saccos impleo, parietes mei vix capiunt quod acquiro: undique lucra confluunt, & more fontium nummi fluunt, Behold I fill up sackes, my wals doe hardly hold that which I get, my gaines doe flow out every way, and monies runne like a streame into my purse. But Saint Austin also sheweth this to be no answer, for saith hee, Vt sacculus
tuus impleatur nummis, anima tua febricitat curis, ut accedat aurum, perit fides, ut foris vestiaris, intus expoliaris, That thy sack may be filled, thy soule feavereth with cares, that thy gold may increase, thine honestie is diminished, that thou mayest be richly clothed without, thou art spoyled and left naked within. Or else let the best answer be made that can be made, it is nothing to the question.Augustinus. Ibid. For that is Quid
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Quid existens? What is there that abideth and continueth to a man, in all his vexation of heart under the Sunne? For what things soever they may be that are gotten, yet as St. Austins words againe are, Sine dubio transitoria sunt: aut per nos transeunt, aut nos per illa transimus, Without doubt they are transitory things: either they passe away by us, or wee passe away by them: either they passe away while that we live, or else they are let goe when that we dye, either they passe away by our spending of them, or in the using of them we passe away our selves.

Verse 23. It is the complaint of St. Ambrose, Ambros. de fide Resurrectionis. Quid in hac vita non experimur adversi? Quas non procellas tempestatés{que} perpetimur? Quibus non exagitamur incommodis? Cujus parcitur meritis? What misery doe wee not undergoe in this life? What stormes and tempests doe we not endure? With what troubles are wee not tossed? Whose worth is spared? Wherefore St. Austin also lamenteth, Dura causa est vita mortalis. Augustin. in Psal. 50.
Quid est aliud hic nasci, nisi ingredi laboriosam vitam? Mortall life is a hard condition. What is it else to be borne here, then to enter into a troublesome life? The Preacher therefore sayth, That all mans dayes are sorrowes, his sorrowes begin when his dayes beginne, his sorrowes goe on, as his dayes goe on, as the travell of his journey proceedeth, so his griefe proceedeth, as he passeth from one businesse to another, so he passeth from one griefe to another. Yea, many are the sorrowes of every day unto him, his travell is but one continued griefe; his businesse is onely the worke of griefe. Sorrow is the Sunne that makes his dayes unto him: it is that which makes him to see himselfe, to see his condition. And when his Sunne is so blacke, what are his dayes? In the night he doth not labour, but yet he doth not rest: his body doth not labour, but his heart is not quiet. And therefore as Hugo speaketh,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 12.
Multum miser est qui nec illud tempus quod naturaliter quieti datum est, quietum habere potest, He is very miserable, who cannot have that time quiet, which even naturally is given for quietnesse. Per diem labore atteritur, per noctem cura laboris cruciatur, In the day he is worne with labour, in the night he is torne with the care of his labour. Or as St. Austin speaketh,Augustin. in Psal. 50.
Per diem vexatur laboribus, per noctem agitatur timoribus, In the day he is vexed with labours, in the night he is tossed with feares. Or as St. Ambrose expresseth it, In nocte dies desideratur, in die nox quaeritur: Ambros. de bono mortis. c. 3.
ante eseam gemitus, inter cibos fletus, nulla requies à perturbationibus, nulla à laboribus reclinatio, In the day the night is desired, in the night the day is fought for; before food sighing, in feeding weeping, no rest from troubles, no ceasing from labours. The Originall is, that the heart of man 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
non jacet, doth not lye downe to rest, sayth St. Hierome, doth not apply
it selfe to rest;Gregor. Nyssen. in Eccles. Hom. 5. but as Gregory Nyssene speaketh, Non tantum gaudet in iis quae habet, quantum tristatur ob ea quae desunt, Is not so much quieted in those things which it hath, as it is tormented for those things which it hath not. For covetousnesse doth not onely bring forth thornes, wherewith godlinesse is choaked, but wherewith also it selfe is pricked and gauled. And doth not the Preacher then well conclude, this is also vanitie? The heart of man is hardly perswaded that the things of this life are vanitie, and therefore it is, that the Preacher doth so often repeate it, to beate it into man. Yea, the heart of man doth hardly beleeve, that sorrow it selfe, yea, and continuall sorrow, continuall griefe suffered for the getting of worldly things are vanitie, and therefore the Preacher doth assure them that it is.

q.p: VER. 24. There is nothing better for a man, then that he should eate and drinke, and that he should make his soule enjoy good in his labour. This also I saw that it was from the hand of God.
VER. 25. For who can eate? or who else can hasten hereunto more then J?

VER. 26. For God giveth to a man that is good in his sight, wisedome, and knowledge, and joy: but to the sinner he giveth travell, to gather and to heap up, that he may give to him that is good before God. This also is vanitie and vexation of spirit.

div.p:
Verse 24. As our translation readeth this verse, it may well be understood as the speech of a voluptuous person: and whereas the Preacher had shewed, the sorrow and labour of mans life, and the vanitie of both, in that another enjoyeth the content of it; thereupon it may be supposed that such a one should say, There is nothing better, then that a man should freely eate and drinke, and give himselfe to pleasure. And whereas it followes, as the Septuagint have it, Et hoc de manu Dei est, and this is from the hand of God: An ancient writer noteth, that there be some men who say, Devoremus & inebriemur, & benefaciamus nobis ex iis quae Deus dedit nobis, quia et hoc de manu Dei est, quia et haec ideo data sunt nobis, ut bene nobis faciamus, Let us devoure and be drunken, and doe unto our selves good by those things which God hath given us, for even this is from the hand of God, and therefore are these things given us,
that we should doe good to our selves with them. But as he addeth, Et si Deus bona omnia ad usum fecit, ad pravos tamen et inordinatos usus nihil fecit, Although God hath made all things good for use, yet he hath made nothing for bad and inordinate uses. But the Originall being, Non est bonum homini quod comedat & bibat, It is not the good that belongeth to man, to eate and to drinke, I conceive the Preachers meaning to be this, that having before shewed the vanitie of mans life in the griefe and paines of it, and in providing for the contentment of others, here he sheweth the enjoying of a mans owne contentment, which he expresseth by eating and drinking, because therein it appeareth most plainly, not to be the good of man, and in the last verse of this Chapter he pronounceth it to be vanitie. The not goodnesse, in truth, of it, the Originall declareth, in that it sayth, Vt ostendat animae suae bonum in labore suo, and that he shew himselfe good in his labour. For it is but a shewing of good to the soule, it is not a right enjoying of it. And yet the Preacher granteth, that this is from God. He sayth that himselfe saw it to be so, as noting, that he did not forget this, when yet he pronounced it not to be the good belonging unto man. For howbeit, as S. Hierome sayth, Siquidem Dei munus est, talem viro justo dari mentem, Hieronym. in hunc vers. ut ea quae curis et vigiliis comparavit, ipse consumat, it be indeed the gift of God, that such a minde be given unto a good man, as that himselfe consumeth those things which by his cares and watchings he hath gotten. And howbeit, as Cyrillus speaketh, Qui bene agere, et Dei mandata servare decreverint, Cyrillus in Catena Graeca. eos sequetur dives coelestium bonorum distributio, et terrestrium bonorum participatio, there shall follow them who are carefull to doe well, and to keepe Gods commandements, a rich distribution of celestiall good things, and a participation of terrestriall good things: notwithstanding the enjoying of earthly good things, eating and drinking, are not the good of mans life upon the earth. Bonum est, veros cibos & veram sumere potionem, quos de agni carne & sanguine in divinis voluminibus invenimus, That good is, as St. Hierome speaketh, to take true meate, and true drinke, which from the flesh and bloud of Christ wee finde in the sacred volumes. It is not by bread onely that man liveth: hoc veri Verbi est verbum, This is the word of the true Word, sayth a Greeke Father, Pane non alitur virtus, non carnibus vis animae fit bonae habitudinis, & pinguescit, It is not by bread that vertue is nourished, it is not by flesh that the powers of the soule are made to be of a good liking, and to grow fat, as Gregory Nyssene addeth. By other eating and drinking it is that the good of man is enjoyed, and that is in the actions of justice, temperance, patience, and other vertues. And yet though to enjoy the good of a mans labour, be not the good of man, yet it is good for man to enjoy it. Psal. 127.2. For this is that beloved sleepe which God giveth to his servants. And when St Paul exhorteth to use this world as not abusing it,1 Cor. 7.31. his meaning is, that he would not have those who are heyres of the world, so to serve the world, as if they were slaves unto it, but to use and enjoy the benefits of God with a quiet minde.

Verse 25. In the two last verses of this Chapter, the Preacher prooveth the two parts of the former verse. First, he proveth in this verse that a mans owne enjoying of the good of this life, is not the good of man: secondly, he prooveth in the last verse that the enjoying of it, is from the Lord. The force of the proofe in this verse is thus set downe by Lyra, Lyra in hunc vers. Experto credendum est: Ego autem supra omnes expertus sum, & tamen dixi quod in hoc non consistit bonum hominis, propter quod est mihi credendum, To him that hath tryed, beliefe is to be given: but I have tryed above all others, and yet I say that the good of man doth not consist in this, wherefore I must be beleeved. And Gregory Nyssene delivering the force of the proofe to the same effect, he sets it downe thus,Greg. Nyssen. in Eccles. Homil. 5. Hieronym. in hunc vers. Haec ego dixi voce mea, This have I sayd with my voyce. Saint Hierome makes this verse, to beginne the proofe of the latter part of the former verse, who reads it thus; Quis enim comedit, & quis parcit sine illo, qui homini bono coram se dedit? For who eateth, and who forbeareth without him, who giveth to a man, that is good in his sight? Gregory Nyssene doth reade it also, with some reference unto the same manner: So that the copies of the Originall may seeme not to have been the same in this verse. The Septuagint may be thought rather to have delivered the sense of the place, then to have followed the signification of the words. For they say, Quis ita devorabit, & delitiis affluet ut ego, Who shall so devoure, and abound with delights as I? Whereupon Hugo sayth,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Hom. 13.
Mala gloriatio ista, & sunt tamen, qui in ejusmodi gloriantur, This is a bad glorying, and yet there are that doe glory in these things. But as he addeth, Si nemo potest, quod tu potes; magnum est, si bonum potes. Si vero amplius in malo potes, quid gloriaris? Malum enim posse, potestas non est, sed infirmitas, If none can doe that which thou canst, it is a great matter, if it be good which thou canst. But if thou canst doe more in evill, why dost thou then glory? To be able to doe evill, is not a power, but a weaknesse. As the Originall words are now found, it is no easie matter, according to the signification of them, to render the force of them. Our translation is verball enough, but yet thereby not so plaine. Let me with submission offer mine apprehension. I conceive the Preacher in this verse to set forth his abundant enjoying of the good of this life, two wayes. First, by the lowd and free cry of his command and authoritie for it, secondly, by the readinesse and speed that was used in obedience unto it, for the satisfying of his desire. And therefore I take the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used as it signifieth to cry, or to call aloud; and so should render the verse according to this sense, Who can call for, more freely? Who can enjoy more speedily, the good of this life then I can? And therefore who should also be beleeved rather then I; who deny the enjoying of the good of this life to be the good of man? From hence we may take this lesson, that no one doe promise to himselfe, or take upon himselfe those things, which those who have been farre more able then himselfe, have not been able to performe. And for an instance, let not those promise to themselves
heaven, who live carelesly in religion, when it is hard for them who are very carefull to attaine thither.

Verse 26. Where God seeth goodnesse, there he looketh graciously; he hath a blessing in his hand for him that is good in his sight. It is not to him that is good in the sight of men, but to him that is good in the sight of God, that the Lord is good. He giveth to a man that is good, Gregor. Nis. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 5.
Bono, qui vivit ad boni solius imaginem, To the good man who liveth according to the likenesse of him who is good alone, as a Greeke Father speaketh. And St. Hierome sayth, Pulchre homini bono Deus dat, Hieronym. in Eccles. Elegantly it is sayd that God giveth to a good man, because unlesse he be good, God is not so properly sayd to give unto him. And therefore when afterwards it is sayd, to the sinner he giveth, Lyra expoundeth it,Lyra in Eccles. i. e. dari permisit, he permitted it to be given to him. Wisedome and knowledge and joy. The Chaldee Paraphrast doth distinguish these three words thus,Chald. Para. Viro cujus opera sunt recta, coram Domino, dedit sapientiam & scientiam in hoc saeculo, & laetitiam cum justis in saeculo venturo, To the man whose workes are right before the Lord, he giveth wisedome and knowledge in this world, and joy with the righteous in the world to come. But to distinguish the words with a more particular reference to the place. By wisedome we may understand a wise desire to enjoy the things which he hath; by knowledge, a discerning of the manner how to enjoy them aright; and by joy the comfort of enjoying of them. All which none can have, but from God alone. But to the sinner he giveth: it is not added, to him that is a sinner in his sight. For a sinner doth not tary in his sight: and God also turneth away his eye from him, as he hath turned himselfe away from Gods law. Wherefore that which God giveth him, is but from the not giving of his mercy to him. And it is therefore travell, not joy, it is a carking solicitousnesse, not wisedome, to gather; not a contented wisedome to use that which is gathered: it is a greedy knowledge how to heape up, not a delightfull knowledge how to imploy with comfort that which is heaped up: and the gathering the heaping is but to fill Gods hand, that he may give to him, who shall use it, imploy it in a thankfull joy. And yet this, this which God giveth, this which a good man receiveth, this is also vanitie and vexation of spirit. Wherefore Gregory Nyssene sayth, Qui hoc esse bonum judicat, Gregor. Nyssen. in Eccles. Hom. 5.
ignorat se bonum definire in eo quod vacuum est, He that judgeth this to be good, knoweth not that he defineth good in that which is vaine. Vanitie it is because although God giveth it, yet he taketh it away againe: Vanitie it is, because although a good man hath it, yet by that he is not made the better. Vexation of spirit it is, because although wisedome desire it, yet wisedome seeth no hope of keeping it: vexation it is, because although knowledge discerne how to use it, yet it knoweth not how to continue the use of it: vexation it is, although it be joy, because joy that is to be parted with, cannot but vex.

q.p: VER. 1. To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under heaven.
VER. 2. A time to be borne, and a time to dye: a time to plant, and a time to plucke up that which is planted.
VER. 3. A time to kill, and a time to heale: a time to breake downe, and a time to build up.
VER. 4. A time to weepe, and a time to laugh: a time to mourne, and a time to dance.
VER. 5. A time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together: a time to embrace, and a time to refraine from embracing.
VER. 6. A time to get, and a time to loose: a time to keepe, and a time to cast away.
VER. 7. A time to rent, and a time to sow: a time to keepe silence, and a time to speake.
VER. 8. A time to love, and a time to hate: a time of warre, and a time of peace.

div.p:
Verse 1. THE Preacher having ended the former Chapter with the good enjoying of the good things of this life, and with the vanitie which yet is therein: he beginneth this Chapter by shewing how they may be well enjoyed, namely, by taking them in their time and season, and withall by shewing their vanitie, in that they have but a time and season. More generally wee may note, that the Preacher having before shewed the vanitie of humane things from his owne experience in himselfe; here he goeth on to shew it, from those things which his experience had observed
in others: wherein wee are taught, first to looke upon our selves, and to marke our owne wayes, and then to cast our eye on those things which are done by others. But to consider the verse. The Originall words here used for time are in the first place 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying properly determinatum tempus, a set appointed time, in the latter place 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying properly opportunum tempus, an opportune time. And therefore it seemeth to mee that the words may bee rather transposed thus, To every thing there is a time, and a season to every purpose under heaven. For so also a Greeke Father doth read it, putting in the first place 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth time, putting in the second place 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth the opportunity of time. But in expounding the meaning of the verse he putteth another difference betweene them. And because time is the common measure of all things, by time he understandeth measure, and so conceiveth the Preacher to require two things in the well doing of every thing: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , summetriam & opportunitatem, a fit measure and a convenient opportunity. But he taketh his measure of the verse somewhat awry. To consider then the verse as we read it. The first thing is the season of things, and that is of such use in the use of things, that as an Ancient Writer hath it, Quando tempus habet, bonum est ut sit, etiamsi bonum non est illud, quod bonum est ut sit, when it is in season, it is good that it should be, although that, which it is good that it should be, even be not good in it selfe. The other thing is the time of all things: for every thing under heaven hath but a time, and such a time as is also allotted to it. So that as the same Author speaketh, Omne quod est, aut aliud subsequitur, ut non ab initio veniat, aut praecurrit aliud ut usque ad finem se non extendat, Every thing that is, either goeth after another, so that it was not from the beginning, or else goeth before another, so that it doth not continue to the end. Now as the first teacheth, that nothing in his time is to be rejected, and nothing not in his time is to bee embraced, so the other teacheth in such sort to use things in their time, as to see the vanity of them in that they have but a time. But as every thing hath its season, so one thing there is which hath every season, and that is the businesse of our salvation. Wherefore Nazianzene saith; Sow when the time is of sowing,Nazianzene Orati. in S. Baptismo. gather the fruits when the time is of gathering, &c. At vero salutis tuae negotium semper age, But be alwayes doing the worke of thy salvation. And least this place might seeme to oppose it, which appointeth a particular season to every thing, Saint Ambrose noteth,Ambros. in Psal. 118. that it is spoken of every thing under heaven, Sed Dominus Iesus supra coelum est, nullo circumscriptus tempore, but that the Lord Iesus is above the heavens not being circumscribed with any time. And surely it must be the care of every one so to use the things of this world in their time, which have but a time, Vt transeunte tempore sub coelo, succedat aeternitas quae est in coelo, That time passing away which is under heaven, eternity may succeed which is in heaven, as Hugo speaketh.

Verse 2. The Preacher here beginneth by diverse particulars to
shew, how as there is a fit time for the enjoying of worldly things, so the season is no lesse fit, which taketh them away: and putting these two seasons into the scales, he teacheth how the vanity and vexation of spirit in the parting with them, overweigheth the good that is found in the having of them.Hugo de Sancto Vict. in Eccles. Homil. 13.
Hugo de Sancto Victore in the enumeration of these particulars, noteth severall things. As first hee noteth, that good and bad things are still joyned together: because such is the condition of this life, Et mixta sunt omnia, quamdiu tempus est, ut omnia habeant tempus, and all things are mixed so long as there is time, that all things may have time. Secondly, he noteth that the Preacher beginneth with placing good things before evill, and afterwards commeth to place evill things before good; because there are two lives to man, a carnall life, and a spirituall life,1 Cor. 15.46. and as the Apostle speaketh, first that which is carnall, and them that which is spirituall. Now in the carnall life the good things goe before, the evill follow after: in the spirituall life the evill goe before, the good follow after. And therefore Hugo farther noteth, that as the Preacher beginneth from good to evill, saying, There is a time to be borne, and a time to dye; so he endeth from evill to good, saying, A time of Warre, and a time of peace, Quia prima vita, primum bonum, & ultimùm malum: secunda vita primùm malum, & ultimum bonum habet, Because the first life hath first good, and afterwards that which is evill, the second life, hath first evill and afterwards good. Thirdly, hee noteth how the Preacher confoundeth this order, and sometimes putteth good things first, sometimes evill, as shewing the confusion that is in the world, Quia nec malis us{que} ad finem bona, nec bonis us{que} ad finem mala, Because neither the wicked have alwayes good things, nor the good have alwayes evill things. Saint Hierome tels us how the Iewes doe apply all these to the people of Israel. Hieronym. in Ecclesiast. The time of being borne, and of planting to Gods choosing and making them his people: the time of dying and plucking up to their leading into captivity: the time of killing to their bondage in Aegypt; of healing to their deliverance from thence, the time of breaking downe to the destruction of the Temple, of building up to the building of it againe: the time of weeping to the taking of the City, of laughing when it was againe restored: the time of casting away stones, to the scattering and casting away of them, the time of gathering stones, to the gathering together of them againe: the time of embracing to the love of God, Ierem. 13.7. & 9. which as a girdle compassed his people: the time of refraining to the removing of Gods love, and their misery in captivity, which God shewed to Ieremiah by a girdle hid in a rocke and marred: the time of getting and keeping, to the time of blessing and preserving them, the time of loosing and casting away, to the time of rejecting them: the time of renting, to the time of renting them, the time of sowing, to the time of sowing them againe: the time of keeping silence, to the silence of their Prophets now, the time of speaking, to the time when they shall not want the comfort and speech of GOD in their enemies land: the time of hatred, when they crucified Christ, the
time of love, when God loved them in the time of the Patriarchs: the time of Warre, when yet they are impenitent, the time of peace, when the fulnesse of the Gentiles being come in, Israel shall be saved.Hierome in hunc vers. St. Hierome himselfe giving a spirituall sense to these words faith, that the time of being borne is, Partus iste qui de timore nascitur, That birth which commeth from feare: the time of dying is, when a man being perfect in godlinesse, feare is cast out. Gregory Nyssene also applyeth the time of being borne, Greg. Nys. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 6. to that religious care, whereby Nobis ipsis quodammodo patres sumus, wee are as it were fathers to our selves, and doe bring our selves forth to bee children unto God: the time of dying, to a religious mortification of our selves, whereby a man, Nunquam sibi vivit, sed viventem in seipso habet Christum, doth never live to himselfe, but hath Christ living in him. But in a literall sense the words import two things, first that as there is a time of being borne, so there is a time of dying. Clemens Alexand. Stromatum l. 3. For as Clemens Alexandrinus reporteth, Solome asking our Saviour Christ how long death should have power, the answer which our Saviour gave, was, so long as you women bring forth. For as he addeth, Ortum omnino sequitur interitus, Dying is sure to follow after being borne. The other thing which the words import is, that there is a fit time for being borne, namely when the season appointed by nature is accomplished, those that come before being abortives: and that there is a fit time of dying, namely when the period set by nature is come, those that dye before suffering a violent death. Wherefore a Greeke Father saith, Venit tempus & natus sum; veniet tempus & moriar, The time came, and I was borne, the time shall come, and I shall dye. The last part of the verse, sheweth the same in things of a vegetable life, which was shewed in things of a sensitive life: or else sheweth the same in things that are brought forth by art and industry, which was shewed in things brought forth by nature. In a spirituall sense we know who is our husbandman: wee know whose husbandry we are; the one we have from our Saviour Christ, the other from St. Paul the servant of Christ. Ioh. 15.6. 1 Cor. 3.9. The time of Gods planting is this life, for now he is ready to plant grace in the hearts of all: the time of his rooting up is the day of judgment, for then he will roote up the tares from his Corne. Or if we will apply the words to our selves, there is a time to plant those vertues in our soules which are not growing in them, and there is a time to plucke up the weeds of vice which grow too fast in them. A time must be allotted unto both; and a fit time taken will make the worke both the more easie, and the more successefull.

Verse 3. The Preacher in the former Verse having placed good before evill; in this verse he placeth the evill before the good: for so it is in the things of this world, Subsequuntur quae praecesserant, & rursus quae sequuta fuerunt praecedunt, Those things follow which went before, and those things goe before which followed. The verse we may consider in a threefold sense, either literall, morall, or spirituall. As for the first, the Preacher having spoken of the vanity of man, in his being and not being, from thence hee goeth on to shew the vanity of those things
which serve for the preservation of his being; and having shewed it in plants, here hee sheweth it first in beasts, which in their fit time and when they are fit food for man, are killed for his use, and which at another time are kept alive and cherished, and so are as it were healed, that they may bee made fit for mans nourishment. Now as Cicero Cicero. speaketh, Quotidie mori docemur, qui mortuis nutrimur, We are continually taught to dye, who doe live by those things which are made to dye for us; so the Preacher doth farther shew man his vanity, by the perishing of those things which for his sake are subject to vanity. Secondly, the Preacher having spoken of the inward meanes which serve for the preservation of mans being, he speaketh also of the outward meanes, as of houses and buildings, and which as in time growing old, have a fit time to be broken downe; so when they are built in their time, have but a time of standing though built never so strongly. Much hath beene the labour, and great the cost of men, Vt starent post ipsos monumenta jactantiae illorum, & invaluerunt us{que} ad aliquid, That the monuments of their vaine glory might stand after them, and something they have done, as one speaketh: but what a vaine pleasure is this, that their buildings stand upon the earth, when themselves are fallen into the earth? And what though their buildings outstand them? They cannot stand out against time, which will have a fit time to throw them down. And in this literall sense wee may marke, that the Preacher saying, in the former verse, A time to plucke up, that which is planted, hee doth not here speake in the same manner; because that which is killed, is not healed, but another; that which is pulled downe is not built up, but another. In a morall sense we may understand the verse thus: that justice hath a fit time of killing, where expectation of amendment is already killed; and mercy hath a fit time of healing by forgiving, where hope of doing good by it giveth vertue and force to the medicine: justice hath a time of breaking downe by due punishment where it is needfull, and of building up by rewarding the well doers for their encouragement: justice hath a time of killing and destroying where wrong is done, and of healing and building up, where wrong is suffered. Lastly, in a spirituall sense,Greg. Nyss. in Eccles. Homil. 6.
Gregory Nyssene telleth us, that there is a time of killing, Malam animi motuum aciem, & hoc civile quod in nos per voluptates geritur bellum, & nos captivos reddit legi peccati, That hurtfull army of the affections of the minde, and that civill warre which pleasures make against us, and which doth make us captive unto the law of sinne: and there is a time of healing the wounds which they have given us. There is a time of breaking downe the strong holds of sinne, and there is a time of building up the Temple of God in our selves. And here we may note the order that is used: first there must be a killing before there can be a healing: first there must bee a breaking downe, before there can bee a building up.
Jerem. 1.10. In the commission of the Prophet Ieremy the same order is observed: where God saith, I have set thee this day, to roote out and to pull downe, to build and to plant. The straw and the stubble that is
in us must first be taken away, before that we can build silver and gold, and pretious stones. For as a Greeke Father speaketh, Fieri non potest ut cum stipula coalescat argentum, vel foeno agglutinetur aurum, vel ligno margaritum, It cannot be that silver should agree with stubble, or gold be joyned with straw, or a Pearle with wood.

Verse 4. The Preacher passeth from man considered in his owne being, and from those things that doe preserve him in his being, to other things that doe belong to them. And therefore Lyra briefly expounding this verse saith, that there is a time to weepe, in infortuniis in the misfortunes of this life, and a time to laugh, in eufortuniis in the good fortunes of it: that there is a time to mourne in funeribus defunctorum in the funerals of the dead, and a time to dance, in nuptiis conjugatorum at the bridals of the maryed. But to marke the words a little more narrowly, The latter part of the verse, is but velut repetitio ejus quod prius dictum est, As it were a repetition of that which is before spoken,Gregor. Nis. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 6. saith Gregory Nyssene. Only saith he, it addeth some amplification unto it. For as by dancing is signified a greater measure of rejoycing, so planctu, by mourning, the Scripture useth to expresse a greater measure of sorrowing. But Hugo farther noteth, that Fletus & risus ad animum pertinent, planctus & saltatio ad corpus, weeping and laughing doe belong to the minde,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Eccles. Hom. 15. mourning and dancing to the body. And indeed the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which is here used for mourning signifieth the outward cariage of the body in sorrow. Wherefore saith he, in the first place are set downe the joy and sorrow of the mind: by mourning and dancing in the second place the same things are signified, but as they are shewed in the motions of the body. For as a Greeke Father saith, vulnerum animi tanquam sanguis lachrymae sunt, Teares are as it were the bloud of the wounds of the soule, which manifest the greatnesse of them, and so the light skipping of the body in dancing, is but a shadow of the light and lofty flying of the mind in joy. Now God hath blended these two in mans life for many reasons: but I will mention two only. The first is to distinguish this life from the next. For in the next life, either in heaven there will bee nothing but joy; or else in hell nothing but howling. If in this life there should bee nothing but joy, many would looke for no other heaven: if now there should be nothing but sorrow, many might seeme to bee in hell before they come unto it. This life therefore which is the way to either, partaketh of both. Secondly, God hath mixed joy with sorrow in this life, thereby to keepe us in the right way. For if we should have nothing but joy, we should be quickly too much puffed up: if nothing but sorrow, wee should bee easily too much cast downe. But these being mixed, the sorrowes of this world doe weane our affections from the vanities of it: the joyes of this life do make us long for the greater joyes of the next. Now seeing there is in this life a fit time for both, Per haec discimus, quod ad rem praesentem oporteat etiam animum accommodare. Prospere res succedunt? Tempestivum est laetari: reducta est animi alacritas ad demissionem? converti etiam convenit
in lachrymas, By this wee learne, that we must apply our minds to the present occasion. Doe things succeed happily? It is a fit time to rejoyce. Is the cheerefulnesse of our mind humbled? It is meete then that our singing bee turned into weeping, as the same Father speaketh. But more generally Saint Hierome tels us, and out of him the ordinary Glosse.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Nunc tempus flendi est, & in futuro ridendi: Beatienim flentes, quoniam ipsi ridebunt, Now is the time of weeping, hereafter of laughing. For as our Saviour saith, Luk. 6.21. Blessed are yee that weepe now, for ye shall laugh. And Gregory Nyssene also shewing this life to be the time of mourning, in which there is so much cause of mourning,Greg. Nyssen. in Eccles. Homil. 6. thereupon saith, Omnia primas tenent in malorum excellentia, omnia parem praebent luctus occasionem, All things have the precedency in the excellency of evils, all things afford like matter of griefe: So that for which to lament most it is hard to find.

Verse 5. It is not easie to enter into these stones, and to discerne what is meant by them. An Ancient Writer taking them for men, expoundeth the casting away of stones to be casting of men into banishment, the gathering of stones to bee the recalling of them into their owne Countries and places.Gregor. Dialog. l. 3. c. 37 prope finem. Saint Gregory the great taking them for good men, and reading the words tempus mittendi lapides, a time of sending stones, applyeth them to God, who in his good time sendeth good men into the world for a blessing to it, and in his time gathereth them out of the world to deliver them from the evils of it. But that which I conceive to be the right veine, for finding the meaning of the stones,Lyra in hunc vers. is that which Lyra hath, who by stones here understandeth fortilicia, fortresses, as being anciently for their strength made of stone; and which have a time, when though never so strong they are demolished, and their stones cast away: as on the other side, there was a time which served fitly for gathering the stones together, and for the building of them. A Greek Father taketh these stones for stones of Warre, but applying them in a spirituall manner hee saith, Est omnino intelligendum, quod quae vitium perimunt cogitationes, eae sunt lapides, qui ab Ecclesiaste fundâ recte jaciuntur, quos semper mitti oportet & colligi. Mitti quidem ad eum evertendum, qui contra vitam nostram erigitur: colligi autem ad hoc ut animae nostrae sinus plenus sit iis praeparatis, ut ad manum sit quod jaci possit in adversarios, It is absolutely to be understood, that the meditations which destroy vice are the stones which by the Preacher are rightly cast from the sling, which it is needfull alwayes to bee cast out, and alwayes to be gathered: to be cast out for the overthrowing of him, who riseth up against us; to be gathered for this end, that the bosome of our soule, may bee filled with them in readinesse, and may have at hand that which may bee throwne against the adversaries. Of these stones hee saith, Est adeo pulcher jactus, ut & hostem interimant, et ab ejus qui jacit manu non separantur, The casting is so excellent, that they both kill the enemy, and are not put away from his hand that throweth them. The latter part of the verse I would also understand as pertaining
to the same sense with the former, because in this passage of the Preacher, it is generally so set downe by him. And then by embracing, I should conceive the embracing of safetie and defence in strong Fortresses: according as I finde the word used in Iob, where it is sayd, They embrace the rocke for want of a shelter. Job 24.8. Now there is a fit time when fortresses doe serve for defence; and there is a fit time which sheweth the vanitie of them, and when he that flyeth unto them, is farre from embracing safetie and defence by them. The literall meaning which the words present to the first view, is to understand them of those embracings which God hath ordained for the continuance of mankinde upon the earth. For as there is a time in which this embracing is to be used, Vt reparetur mortalitas, Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 15.
et excipiatur mortalium infirmitas, that mortalitie may be repayred, and the infirmitie of mortall men may be sustained, as Hugo speaketh: so there is a time in which it is good to refraine from this embracing: and that is especially in the time of Gods wrath and visitation. The ancient Fathers doe very much note the manner of Noahs going into the Arke, and how the Father and the sonnes went together, the Mother and her daughters in law went together: God himselfe dividing at that time those whom himselfe had joyned together. Whereupon St. Ambrose sayth,Ambros. l. de Noe & Arca. c. 21.
Aperte et velut ordine ipso ingressionis, vocem quandam justus emittit, tempus illud non esse delitiarum, quo omnibus imminet interitus: quam enim indecorum, ut quo tempore viventes morerentur, eo morituri generarentur? Plainely, and as it were by the order it selfe of their going in, the righteous man pronounceth, that, not to be a time of delights in which destruction hangeth over all: for how unseemely is it, that at what time the living dye, at the same time they should be begotten who are to dye. Notwithstanding Saint Chrysostome conceiveth, that Cham even in the Arke did neglect this care: and this he gathereth from Scripture,Chrysost. in Genes. Homil. 28. because when they came out of the Arke, it is sayd, and the sonnes of Noah went forth of the Arke, Sem and Ham and Iaphet, and Ham is the Father of Canaan, as being conceived in the Arke, and borne not long after their comming out. But unworthy is the example of cursed Cham to be followed. Gen. 9.18. Lastly, Si voluerimus ad altiora ascendere, if wee will ascend unto higher matter, as St. Hierome speaketh, there is (as he applyeth the words) a time of embracing by contemplation and study the high things of wisedome,Hieronym. in hunc vers. and because the minde of man cannot alwayes be lifted up so high, there is a time of refraining from this embracing, that so the body in his place may also be cared for.

Verse 6. Man having deprived himselfe of those true good things wherein he was created, seeketh now after those things, In quibus est vere aliquid ad bonum, sed non vera bona, in which there is truely something that may serve for good, but they are not truely good things, as one speaketh. And these God, In tempore suo nunc tribuit acquirenda, nunc acquisita subtrahit, now giveth to be gotten, now taketh away being gotten, that man may both see the vaine contentment of them when he
hath gotten them, and the great vanitie of them when they are lost. The Preacher therefore passing from the things belonging to man, to the using of them by man, here he speaketh of getting, loosing, keeping, and casting them away. The Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for the most part is translated by Interpreters to get, and the reason I suppose to be, because the next words speake of loosing: but the signification of the word is to seeke, and it may be that the Preacher doth use this word here, to shew that all which man can attaine unto, is but a seeking of the things of this world, for there is no true getting of those things which are to be lost againe. And therefore as an ancient writer hath it, Agnoscat homo, quod omnia quae invito tolli poterant fuerant, etiam quum possidebantur, extranea, Let man acknowledge, that all things which can be taken from a man against his will, even then when they were possessed, were not his owne. Yea they are not onely such things which may be and are taken away, but such as himselfe also must cast away. For as there is a fit time of keeping them, so there is of casting them away: because as the same Authour speaketh,Ibid. Homil. 16.
Quae suo tempore custodita possint servanti ferre subsidium; rursum nisi tempore suo abjiciantur possint facere detrimentum, Those things which in their time being kept, may be helpfull to the keeper of them; againe, unlesse in their time they be cast away, they will be hurtfull to him. Which therefore that we may doe, wee were best at all times to cast them away from the love of our hearts. Gregory Nyssene, Gregor. Nyssen. in Eccles. Hom. 7. who readeth the first part of this verse, Tempus est quaerendi, there is a time to seeke, applyeth it to the seeking of God, Cujus inventio est ipsum semper quaerere, The finding of whom is alwayes to seeke him. For as he addeth, Non est aliud quaerere, & aliud invenire, sed acquirendi lucrum est ipsum quaerere, It is not one thing to seeke and another thing to finde, but the gaine of finding is the seeking it selfe. Now the time of seeking God, he tels us briefly, is, the whole life of man. For as he addeth farther, In hoc solo, studii tempus est totum studium, In this thing alone, the time of seeking is the whole seeking of man. The loosing here mentioned he applyeth to the loosing of sinne, Cujus amissio est lucrum, whose loosing is indeed a gaining. Wherefore he sayth, Mala possessio est avaritia, perdamus eam: malum depositum est acceptae injuriae recordatio, id aemittamus, Covetousnesse is an ill possession, let us loose it: the remembrance of a wrong received is a thing ill layd up, let us let it goe; for the loosing of that must needs be a gaine, which being kept breedeth losse. He expounding also the latter part of the verse, sayth, Quid servandi? Id scilicet quod a nobis inventum est ex inquisitione. Quid ejiciendi? Id scilicet cujus amissionem existimatum est conferre, There is a time to keepe, what? Namely, that which by seeking wee have gotten: and that being God, let us keepe him, for he it is that must keepe us. There is a time to cast away, what? namely that, the loosing whereof is a benefit unto us; and that being sinne, let us by repentance so cast it away, that wee never take it againe: for it is the casting away of that, that keepeth God with us.

Verse 7. The condition of mans life taketh often much contentment in the sowing together of a friendly societie, and where it is done in a fit time, how sweet is it? But the vanitie of this appeareth in that the renting also of societie is that which is needfull also to have contentment, and which hath a fit time in which it must be done. Wherefore Hugo sayth, Habet consutionem suam tempore suo consensus socialis; Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 16.
habet & scissionem suam in tempore suo zelus justae contradictionis, A sociable agreement hath in its time his sowing together, and the zeale of a just contradiction hath in his time his renting also. Answerably to this I take the latter part of the verse to speake of a sociable conferring and talking together, wherein the minde of man is much delighted, and when it is done in a fit time, how pleasant is it? But yet the vanitie of it is manifest, in that the minde of man being wearyed with its owne content, silence is desired in the place of it, and hath a fit time that makes it most agreeable. This I conceive to be the most naturall meaning of the place. But if we shall take the time of silence and speaking in a generall extent, then wee may first note, that silence goeth before speaking, and therefore as S. Hierome sayth, Discamus prius non loqui, Hieronym. in hunc vers. ut postmodùm ad loquendum or a reseramus: nihil nobis rectum esse videatur nisi quod discimus, ut post multum silentium ex discipulis efficiamur magistri, Let us first learne not to speake, that afterwards wee may open our mouths to speake: let nothing seeme to be right unto us, but that which we learne, that after long silence, of Schollers wee may be made Masters. And indeed it is silence which is the chiefe thing. Wherefore Seneca sayth,Seneca, Epist. 40.
Summa summarum haec est, tardiloquum te esse jubeo, In summe, the summe of all is this, I require thee to be slow in speaking. And St. Ambrose sayth,Ambros. in Psal. 38.
O validum scutum circumspectae munitionis silentium! O fidissimum stabilitatis fundamentum! Multi enim etiam stabili corde firmati, incauti tamen sermonis fluctuantis errore ceciderunt, O the strong buckler of a circumspect defence, silence! O the most faithfull foundation of stabilitie! For many being well setled with a stable heart, yet unawares have fallen by the errour of a wandering tongue. But yet there is a time to speake also, and as sometimes, Dixisse culpa sit quae fuerant reti • enda, It may be a fault to have spoken those things, which should not have been spoken; so at another time, Tacuisse noceat quae dicenda fuerant, It may be hurtfull not to have spoken those things which should have been uttered. So that not onely the works, but the words of men are tossed with uncertaintie, and vanitie possesseth all. Saepè non possumus loqui quum volumus; & saepè non volumus, quum possumus; saepius autem utrum{que} non debemus, quum facimus, Often wee cannot speake when we would; and often wee will not speake, when we can, and more often we doe both, when we ought not. Sic jactatur homo de tempore ad tempus, & non intelligit tempus suum in omni opere suo, So is man tossed from one time to another, and doth not know his owne time in any of his doings, as one speaketh. Now to understand the former part of the verse in the same kinde; there is a time of renting, a time of renting open the lips, when undue
feare of displeasing, or unjust bribing, or sloathfull negligence, may hold them hard together: and there is a time of sowing up the lips, when choler, or rashnesse, or provoking speeches doe strive to open them too speedily. Or else there is a time of renting the lips to reproove impudency: and there is a time of sowing up the lips, by passing by in silence the slips of infirmitie. The impudent are such, that as St. Gregory speaketh,Gregor. Past. Cu. Par. 3. Adm. 8.
Non nisi increpatio dura illos compescit, & se delinquere nesciunt, nisi a pluribus increpentur, That it must be a sharpe reproofe, or else it doth not worke upon them; and they know not themselves to have offended, unlesse by many they be reprooved. But the weake are often such,Ibid. Adm. 17. that as the same Father speaketh, Ad se reducti tanto libentius exhortationis verba recipiunt, quanto se tranquillius toleratos erubescunt, That being brought unto themselves, they doe the more willingly receive the words of exhortation, by how much the more quietly they have been borne with, being ashamed of it. But to consider the words also in a more spirituall sense; There is a time of renting our selves from the devill, and of breaking from his snares and bonds: and there is a time of uniting also, and as it were sowing our selves to God, and of fastning our hearts to his commandements,Greg. Nyssen. in Eccles. Homil. 7.
Vt ab illo abrupti cui male adhaesimus, illi adhaereamus, cui bonum est adhaerere, That being rent from him to whom we have stuck perniciously, we may stick to him, to whom it is good to sticke, as Gregory Nyssene speaketh. For as the Psalmist speaketh, It is good for me to hold me fast by the Lord; Psal. 73.27. So surely it is good for all to cleave fast to him. According to this application of the first part of the verse, Gregory Nyssene applyeth also the latter part, saying, That there is a time of keeping silence, when we thinke of God, whose glory cannot be expressed: and there is a time to speake, namely, of such things, which concerne our dutie towards God and man, and may increase vertue in our selves and others. An ancient writer doth handsomely apply the first part of the verse in a spirituall sense, and manner, to the flesh and the spirit: to the flesh, the renting, for being made one with it by living according to the flesh, we must rent our selves from it: to the Spirit, the sowing, because by living godly it must be our care to be joyned to him. Neither (sayth he) is this to be omitted, that the things which are rent asunder are substantially one; but the things which are sowne together are substantially diverse, being as it were accidentally made one, by something that tyes them. For so indeed man by his corrupted nature is made one with the corruption of the flesh; but he is united to spirituall things by the bond of grace. In this sowing therefore to the Spirit, the needle is compunction, the threed is love. The needle maketh way and goeth through both, that so the thread may hold both together. First then, the needle of compunction goeth through the things of the flesh, when it considereth our sinnes, it goeth through the things of the Spirit, when it considereth the mercies of God: it goeth through humane things, when it considereth our duties towards God; it goeth through spirituall things, when it considereth
his gracious promises towards us. Then followeth the thread of love, for the sight of Gods gracious promises in his mercy, maketh us to love him, and God seeing our sorrow and repentance, he is in love reconciled to us, and so wee are happily fast tyed the one to the other.

Verse 8. Time is a circle, and the Preacher shutteth up this passage of time in a circle: For having begunne with a time to be borne, and a time to dye: he endeth with a time of warre, which is a time of dying, and with a time of peace, which is a time wherein people by bringing forth are multiplyed. But first to consider the first part of the verse, A Greeke Father defineth love and hatred thus: Amor est intrinsecus insita in id quod animo est jucundum, habitudo operans per voluptatem. Odium est alienatio ab eo quod est injucundum, et aversio ab • o quod molestiâ afficit, Love is an inward seated inclination to that which is sweet to the mind working by pleasure and delight. Hatred is an alienation from that which is unpleasing, and a turning away from that which breedeth trouble. But how great soever the pleasure may be of enjoying that which is loved, how great soever the contentment may be in shunning that which is hated, yet let no man set his heart upon them. For great is the vanitie of them: seeing the same things, Quae sunt odio habita possint iterum juste diligi, et dilecta rursum juste odio haberi, which are accompted worthy of hatred, may againe justly be loved, and those things which are loved, may againe justly be hated, as one speaketh. There is sayth the Preacher, a time to love, and a time to hate: yea fit time for both. And therefore St. Ambrose speaking of these words sayth,Ambros. in Psal. 118. Octon. 14.
De quo hoc dicit Ecclesiastes? Nonne de eo, quod ratione temporis fiat, ut pie & amare & odisse possimus: ut quos dilexeris odisse, & quos oderis amare conveniat. To what purpose speaketh the Preacher this? Is it not to shew us, that according to the difference of time, wee may both hate and love: and that it may be fitting to hate those whom thou lovest, and to love those whom hatest? While the time is, what love is sweeter then the love of a wife, who is as St. Ambrose speaketh, Quaedam vitae cohaeres, Ibid. a kinde of coheire of the life of man? While the time is, what love is more pleasing then the love of a brother, who as St. Ambrose also speaketh,Ibid. Eodem formatur naturae hospitio, Is formed in the same lodging of nature? Notwithstanding it is not seldome, that by the occasions of this world there is a time of just dislike against them. And in religion our Saviour Christ sayth, Whosoever for my sake doth not hate wife and brethren, Luke 14.26. cannot be my Disciple. Vnto the times of love and hatred, agree the times of warre and peace: the times of hatred being times of warre, the times of love, being times of peace. And of these the changing of them in time, is enough to shew the vanitie of them at any time.Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Eccles. Hom. 16.
Non ergo existimet homo valde metuendum bellum, cui potest pax succedere: neque pacem illam veram, quam subsequens hellum potest perturbare, Let no man therefore thinke that warre much to be feared, to which peace may succeede: neither that peace to be true, which by a following warre may be disquieted,
as Hugo speaketh. Gregory Nyssene applying this verse in a spirituall sense, tels us, Est unum solum
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , diligendum natura, id quod vere est, There is but one thing to be loved in the nature of it, that which truely is; and of which the Law sayth, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God, with all thy heart, thy strength, thy might. And there is but one thing againe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Vere odio habendum, Greg. Nyss. in Eccles. Homil. 8. Mat. 5.43. truely to bee hated, namely, the Authour of vice, the enemy of our life; of whom the Law sayth, Odio habebis inimicum tuum, thou shalt hate thine enemy. And accordingly applying the rest of the verse, he sayth; Si ergo amoris & odii intelleximus opportunitatem, alterum quidem diligamus, cum altero vero bellum geramus, If therefore we have understood the fit time of love and hatred, let us be carefull to be at peace with the one, let us be continually in warre with the other. An ancient writer applyeth this verse in a spirituall sense unto the flesh, of which the Apostle saying in one place, Ephes. 5.29. No man hateth his owne flesh: in another place he sayth, Let no one take care of the flesh. Rom. 13.14. So that here is love and hatred, and that wee may know the times of it, the same Authour tels us, Diligenda est caro quantum pertinet ad compassionem naturae; et rursum quantum ad castigationem culpae spectat odienda, For as much as pertaineth to a compassion of nature, the flesh is to be loved; but againe in respect of the chastising of sinne, it is to be hated. Wherefore discretion is needfull, and the time of hatred and love is set downe, that we may goe in a right course, Neque suffocemus naturam, dum culpam persequimur, neque culpam nutriamus, quando naturam fovemus, and may neither overthrow nature while we suppresse sinne; neither yet nourish vice, while we cherish nature, as one speaketh: But because this cannot be done without great striving, much fighting, therefore it is added, a time of warre, and a time of peace, Vt simul agnoscat homo, et quod nemo sine pugna ad victoriam pervenit, et quod qui legitime certaverit, post adeptam victoriam in pace requiescet, That so a man may acknowledge, as well that no one obtaineth victory without fighting, as also that he who fighteth lawfully, after the victory obtained, resteth in peace, as the same Father addeth.

q.p: VER. 9. What profit hath he that worketh, in that wherein he laboureth?
VER. 10. I have seene the travell which God hath given to the sonnes of men, to be exercised in it.
VER. 11. Hee hath made every thing beautifull in his time: also hee hath set the world in their heart, so that no man can finde out the worke that God maketh from the beginning to the end.

div.p:
Verse 9.Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 17. It is the wish of Hugo by occasion of this passage of the Preacher, Modo de temporibus exivimus, sed utinam pervenissemus ad aeternitatem, wee have passed over the times, but I would to God, wee were come to eternity. And God grant that we may so passe the times of this life, that in his good time wee may come to eternall life. A Greeke Father maketh this verse, to be the speech of conscience, speaking to the soule of man, when this life is ended. Then conscience saith, Where are thy stately houses? Where are thy stuffed bagges? Thy brazen statues, the applause of thy flatterers? What profit hath he that worketh, in that wherein he laboureth? But though the words doe fit the mouth of conscience, the application doth not fit the meaning of the place. The Preacher having shewed in the vanities of time, the succession of evill after good, the precedency of evill before good, the mixture of evill with good, the fitnesse of time for both, and therein the vanity of the things of this world, though being enjoyed in their time, there may be some good in the enjoying of them: here he sheweth that it is not all mans working, all his labour that can help this. He cannot effect that the time of dying, should not follow the time of being borne: hee cannot bring it to passe, that a time of weeping should not goe before a time of laughing. He cannot prevaile, that a time of getting, and loosing should not be mixed together. The profit of all his labour is not the redressing of this vanity in things. All his working can never find a fit time to remedy these fit times of changing, and wherein the vexation of mans spirit is established. The Hebrew therefore that was Saint Hieroms Master in expounding the Scriptures unto him,Hieronym. in hunc vers. did rightly expound to him the meaning of this verse, Quum omnia suo labantur tempore, & sit tempus destruendi & aedificandi, flendi & ridendi, &c. Quid frustra conamur & tendimus, & brevis vitae labores putamus esse perpetuos? Seeing that all things doe passe away in their time, and that there is a time of breaking downe, and of building up, a time of weeping and a time of laughing, &c. Why doe we in vaine worke, and labour, and thinke to make the workes of our short life to be of long continuance? For as Saint Basil bringing in Iob comforting his Wife in their calamities maketh him to say, Semper prospere agere solius est Dei: Basilius Homiliar. 23. Cujus titulus est, Non esse adhaerendum rebus temporal. Bibisti liquidum vitae laticem, & turbidum iam toleranter bibe, It belongeth to God onely alwaies to enjoy contentment. Thou hast dranke of the cleare waters of this life, now drinke of them patiently when they are troubled: so must every one be contented when the time commeth to mourne,
who when time was, danced: when the time commeth, to have that pluckt up, which in his time he planted. There will be no profit in all his labour by seeking to avoyd it.

Verse 10. The Preachers Vidi here, I have seene, is nothing else but an affirmation of that which he saith. For when we see a thing, the eye doth as it were say, that this is such a thing, so the Preacher saying, I have seene the travell, it is as if he said, This is the travell, this, that all things in this world have a contrariety of times; this, that man must be subject to these times, and cannot by all his labour and working free himselfe from it. This is that which God hath given, that is, this is that which God hath appointed and ordained, and which man cannot alter. For as an Ancient Writer speaketh, Omnia nutum sequuntur dispositionis aeternae, ne{que} arbitrio humano subduntur, All things doe follow the becke of the supernaturall disposing, neither are the changes of times subject to mans arbitrement. This therefore God hath given, God hath appointed to the sonnes of men, that is, to all generations, to all successions of men. None shall be able to say, things were better in the times of our fathers; none shall bee able to thinke with themselves, things may be better in the dayes of our children.August. in Psalm. 30. conc. 2. For as Saint Austin speaketh, Si interrogares parentes tuos, similiter tibi de diebus suis murmurarent, If thou couldest aske thy fathers, their complaint of their dayes would be like to thine, and if thou couldst heare thy children, they would say as the Preacher doth, We have seene this travell which God hath given to the sonnes of men. Now God hath given it to them 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to bee humbled in it: for so the signification of the word most directly soundeth, and so it agreeth not amisse to the scope of the place. For by this travell God humbleth the sonnes of men, that so they may not trust in their owne labour, that so they may not hope in their owne workes, either to hinder that which God hath appointed, or to procure that which God hath not ordained. By this travell God humbleth the sonnes of men, that so they may not be proud, but being dejected with the vanity of them, may become weary of this life, per quam mortales transeunt nascendo & moriendo, through which mortalls passe away by being borne and dying:August. de civita. Dei l. 19. c. 20. Aug. l. cui titul. speculum peccatoris. and may desire that life, In qua immortales manent, nihil adversi omnino patiendo, In which they remaine immortall by suffering nothing at all, that is offensive to them, as Saint Austin speaketh.
