And therefore doth God make the things of the earth so troublesome unto men, Vt quanto infoelicior mundus iste conspicitur, tanto foelicius pro amore coelestis patriae contemnatur, That by how much the more unhappy this world is found, by so much the more happily it may be contemned, in respect of our love to our heavenly Country, as the same Father speaketh. Or else, God hath given this travell to the sonnes of men to be exercised in it. Origen. in Ioan. Homil. 27. For as Origen speaketh, Duas Deus nobis vitas constituit, praesentem & futuram: praesentem in certamen posuit, futuram in certaminis praemium, God hath appointed two lives for us, the present, and the future: the present he hath ordained for our exercise of striving,
the future for the reward of our exercise. God hath appointed the changes of time, that man may be exercised in them, sive volens ad meritum, sive nolens ad tormentum, either wisely and willingly to his praise, or else unwillingly and foolishly to his torment and vexation, as one speaketh.

Verse 11. That any thing is made in his time, is enough to make it beautifull. For as Hugo Victorinus speaketh, Omnia tempus habent, Hugo Ʋictorinus in Ecclesiast. Homil. 1.
qùia in tempore suo omnia bene fieri habent, & bona sunt, quum bene fiunt omnia, There is a time to all things, because in their time all things are well done, and all things that are well done, are good being done. But when God who is the disposer of time, and the beauty of holinesse, maketh any thing in his time, it must needs be beautifull. Notwithstanding the vaine heart of man, is too apt to blame the things which God hath made. A time of laughing hee liketh, but not a time of weeping, a time of dancing, but not a time of mourning. Et quum bene fit, & ipse male non vult, dicit male fieri, quum bene fiat, & ipse male velit, And when a thing is well done, but his evill will would not have it to be done, he saith, that it is ill done, but the thing is well done, and it is his will that is evill, as one speaketh. Now the reason why man is so ready to blame the workes of God, is, because the world is in his heart, and God is said to have set it there, because he hath permitted the world to be there. The love then of the world that is in mans heart, makes him to desire that all things in the world should prosper alway. He is pleased with a building up, but displeased to heare of a breaking downe: he is well contented with planting, but discontented to heare of plucking up. So that being blinded with this love, he cannot find out, the wise causes from which they doe proceed, which is the beginning of them: he cannot find out the good uses to which they are ordained, which is the end of them. That which our translation readeth, He hath set the world in their heart, the Septuagint and according to them the Vulgar Latin render, Et mundum tradidit disputationibus eorum, and hee hath delivered the world to their disputation. For as an Ancient Writer saith, Proposuit Deus opus suum in oculis hominum, ut interrogaret corda ipsorum de eo, God hath set his worke in the eyes of men, that hee might aske their hearts of it. And many are the answers which mens hearts have given, or rather multa fabrefacta mendacia opinionum de judicio rerum, many lyes of opinions artificially made of the judgement of things. Aliqui asserunt nihil esse, nisi ipsum quod videtur, alii quod nihil est vere, nisi ipsum quod non videtur, Some affirme, that nothing is, but that only which is seene: others, that nothing truly is, but that onely which is not seene. Et texunt rationes, & quasi rationes, & est cui{que} ratio existimatio sua, And they frame reasons, and as it were reasons, and every ones opinion is to him a reason. But the booke which God hath given man to study, consisteth of two volumes, the one containeth the workes that he hath made, the other his providence over his workes: the one is larger, the other hath more hidden and abstruse matter: the one is read by more, the other by them who
are more excellent, the one is understood by sharpnesse of reason, the other by the illumination of Gods Holy Spirit. For God hath made it darke, and God hath done this to this end, that man not being able to find out the worke of God, he might seeke to God, because unlesse God reveale it, man cannot know it. Or if man by the light of nature bee able to find out some of Gods workes, yet he cannot find out his work from the beginning to the end. Hee cannot find out the beginning of it, how God made all things by his word of nothing: he cannot find out the end of it, Si enim ad finem pervenire potuisset, invenisset uti{que} Deum: quoniam a quo sunt, ibi finem habent omnia. For if he could have come to the end, he would have come to God, because from whom all things are, there they have their end. But to know these things 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Convenientem sibi asscribit magistrum, nempe Deum, requireth a fit matter for it,Clemens Alexand. Admonit. ad Gentes. namely God, as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh. But these translations doe not appeare to mee to kisse the Originall. The Hebrew word is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which doth not properly signifie the world, but Tempus absconditum a hidden time: and I thinke that the plaine signification of the word, will make the sense plainest, and best agreeable to the scope of the place. It may bee therefore rendred thus, Hee hath made every thing beautifull in his time, also he hath set a hidden time in the heart of them: that is, hee hath hidden from the heart of men the time for every thing which hee hath appointed; so that man cannot find out the worke which God maketh; the worke which God maketh in his time from the beginning to the end, from the beginning of the world to the end of it, or from the beginning of his life to the end of it. Hee cannot finde out what GOD will doe in the time of it: when it is done, hee cannot finde out, why God hath done it. Non invenit homo quo fine fiant haec omnia, donec ipse finem accipiat, Man findeth not out, to what end all those things are done, untill himselfe come to his end, as one speaketh. Then hee shall understand it: then, either the mercy of God or his justice will shew it unto him. Wherefore the counsell is good which Hugo giveth,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 13.
Sit paratus homo ad omne tempus, sive bonum sive malum sit, ut per bona & mala probatus transeat ad bona glorificandus, Let a man bee ready for all times, whether good or bad, that being proved by good things and bad things, he may passe to good things, to be glorified in them.

q.p: VER. 12. I know that there is no good in them: but for a man to rejoyce, and to doe good in his life.
VER. 13. And also that every man should eate and drinke, and enjoy the good of all his labour, it is the gift of God.

div.p:
Verse 12. The Preacher having shewed, that no one can know the times of Gods workes, Yet saith he, this I know, this I will take upon me to tell, that there is no good in them, that is, howsoever good, howsoever beautifull they may be in themselves and in the seasonablenesse of them, which are things that God maketh; yet there is in them no good for man, there is no other good which man is to doe in them, then to rejoyce, and to doe good in his life: that is,Glossa minor. as the lesser Glosse doth well expound it, Frui praesentibus, & facere quod in futuro prosit to enioy the present things, and to doe that which may bee profitable in the time to come. The Originall here is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
in vitis suis, in his lives, and though it be an Hebraisme, yet by occasion of it, wee may note the two lives of man, either his life in prosperity, or else his life in adversity. And surely that which is good for man, is to rejoyce in both, is to doe good in both. And therefore when our Saviour Christ speaking of sad times saith, when these things begin to come to passe,Luk. 21.28. Galfridus, apud Tilmannum. then looke up, and lift up your heads; thereupon Galfridus saith, Dimittamus in prosperis capita, ne vanitatis aura nos rapiat, Levemus in adversis capita, ne nos torrentis mergat unda, Let us hold downe our heads in prosperity least the ayre of vanity cary us away; in adversity let us lift up our heads, that the water of the torrent doe not drowne us. And in the times of adversity, let us doe good by setting forth the good example of our patience, and by doing good to them who have beene the causes of our evils. But if it be the good of man to rejoyce in times of adversity, and to do good in them, then much more in the times of prosperity. When God sendeth man good things, let him with moderation, humility, thankfulnesse take the comfort of them. For what is more wretched, then as Plutarch speaketh, Parare opes tanquam splendidos, Plutarch. l. de Cupid. Divitiarum. uti tanquam sordidos, To get the good things of this life as men that are in prosperity, to use them as men that are in misery? What is more unreasonable, then as Saint Chrysostome speaketh, Suis abstinere tanquam alienis, To abstaine from a mans owne things, as if they were the things of another man? And indeed as the same Father goeth on,Chrysost. Homil. 2. ad Popul. What are the things that such a one hath, but the things of another rather than his owne? Quae enim ne{que} aliis erogare, ne{que} in necessariis impendere audet, licet multas sustineret poenas, quomodo propria sunt? For how are those things
his owne, which he dareth not although he suffer much by it, either to extend unto others in charity, or else to expend upon his owne necessary occasions. But as a man must rejoyce and doe good to himselfe in times of prosperity, so must he doe it to others, by making them also to rejoyce through a partaking with him in the good, which God hath sent him. In generall, it must bee the care of every man in all times, to feare God, for that is the good of man, that it is which maketh all times to be good to man. And therefore hath God hidden, the times of his workes from man, Vt dum nec pro nostro intellectu penetrare, nec pro nostro arbitrio immutare possimus, amplius timeamus, That seeing wee are not able either by our understanding to pierce into them, or according to our minds to alter them, therefore we should feare him the more, as an Ancient Writer speaketh. Had it beene said onely, it is good for a man to rejoyce, it would have beene entertained readily. But it is added also, that we must doe good: and surely that alone is true rejoycing, that alone it is which maketh all joy to be comfortable.

Verse 13. It is not the gift of God to man, to know the times of things: that God hath reserved to himselfe: but that every man should eate and drinke, that is, that every man should enjoy health, and thereby enjoy the good of his labour, that is his gift unto them. For as the Poet speaketh,Horatius. Valeat possessor oportet, Si comportatis rebus bene cogitat uti, Hee that hath gathered much together, if he thinke to enjoy it, it is needfull that he should enjoy health. And that he may enjoy health, it must be the gift of God unto him. Wherefore when Iacob saith, The God which fed me all my life unto this day,Gen. 48.15. & 16. Philo Allegoriar. l. 2. the Angell which redeemed me from all evill, blesse the laddes: it is the note of Philo upon it, Sanitatem meram, quam nullus morbus praecessit, Deum per semet solum largiri opinor, liberationem autem à morbo etiam per artem & medicinam, I thinke that God doth give by himselfe alone, that which is meerely health, and hath not had any sicknesse going before it: but as for recovery from sicknesse, that he giveth also by art and the skill of the Physitian. And hee thinketh that Iacob did here speake in this manner, as reproving Ioseph because hee had before sent a message unto him by his brethren, Gen. 45.9. & 11. saying, Come downe unto me into Aegypt, and there I will nourish thee. The Father therefore seeing his sonne to be his mothers child in her infirmity, and that as she ascribed too much to the Creature, saying, Give mee children,
Gen. 30.1. or else I dye, so did he likewise, saying, I will nourish thee, this made him to tell his son, that it is God who doth feed us, it is Gods gift unto us, that we eate and drinke, and so enjoy health. And it is Gods gift that every man enjoyeth the good of all his labour. Where wee may first note, that it is upon labour that Gods gift is bestowed. For Saint Ambrose writing on those words of our Saviour Christ, many Leapers were in Israel in the time of Elisaeus the Prophet, and none of them was cleansed saving Naaman the Syrian, there telleth us, evidenter hic sermo Domini informat nos, Ambrose in c. 4. Lucae. non dormientibus divina beneficia, sed observantibus deferri, This speech of Christ doth manifestly teach us, the benefits
of God to be bestowed not on them that sleepe, but on them who observe to doe what God requireth of them. Secondly, wee may note here, that Gods gift maketh man to enjoy the good of all his labour, not onely the good of his comfortable labour, but of his miserable labour also. And as an ancient Writer speaketh, Non solum quando bonis hujus mundi industriâ suâ acquisitis cum gratiarum actione perfruitur; sed tunc etiam, quando in adversis constitutus pro patientiae suae labore spe futurae consolationis laetatur, Not onely when he enjoyeth with thankfulnesse the good things of this world, which by his labour he hath gotten, but even then also when placed in adversitie, he rejoyceth in the hope of future consolation, as a reward for the labour of his patience. The evill that is in any of mans labour, that is, his own gift to himselfe: but the good of it, that is Gods gift. For indeed evill cannot come from God. And therefore when Saul came into the cave where David was,1 Sam. 24.4. and Davids men sayd unto him, Behold the day, of which the Lord sayd unto thee, behold, I will deliver thine enemy into thine hand: This mentioning of the Lord could not make David to hurt Saul: because as St. Basil noteth upon it; Hominis interemptio, Basilius Seleuc. Oration. 16.
Dei donum non est, neque oculus divinus arridet, The killing of a man is not Gods gift, neither is the sight of God pleased with it. So also when it is sayd in Iob, Sathan went forth from the presence of the Lord,Didymus, in Catena Graeca. Didymus thereupon writeth thus, Nisi extra Deum diabolus fuisset, contra Iobum nihil fuisset moliturus, Vnlesse the Devill had gone forth from God, he had never done any thing against Iob. God himselfe minding no ill at all to man.

q.p: VER. 14. I know that whatsoever God doth, it shall be for ever: nothing can be put to it, nor any thing taken from it: and God doth it that men should feare before him.
VER. 15. That which hath been is now, and that which is to be, hath already been, and God requireth that which is past.

div.p:
Verse 14. The Preacher here saying, I know, sheweth that he refuteth an objection of some, who doe not know the truth. For because of the changeablenesse of worldly things, from hence some would impute a changeablenesse to God by whom they are made. And from the uncertaintie of events, some would inferre a neglect in Gods government. But the Preacher sayth, I know, and let all know from him,Phil. l. Quod Deus sit immutabilis. that whatsoever God doth, it shall be for ever. Philo therefore sayth well, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , what greater wickednesse can there be against
God, then to thinke him to be changed, who is unchangeable. And doubtlesse,Salvian. De Guber. Dei. l. 1. nothing is more true, then that God, as Salvianus speaketh, Qua potestate et majestate cuncta condidit, etiam eadem providentia & ratione moderatur, By what power and majestie he hath made all things, by the same providence and wisedome doth he also governe all things. That change which is in worldly things, is from themselves, not from any change in God. Their being they have from God, Quod autem esse desinunt, ex semetipsis habent; sicut et hoc quod antequam essent, nihil fuerunt, ex semetipsis habuerunt, But that in any kinde they cease to be, they have it from themselves, even as that they were nothing before they were,Hugo Victorinus in Ecclesiast. Homil. 18. they had from themselves also, as Hugo Victorinus speaketh. And if in the government of worldly things, God may seeme sometimes to alter his pleasure, the same Authour speaketh well, Dispensatio occulta est, qua non mutatur consilium, sed opus variatur, & judicium exercetur. Nam hoc ipsum judicium est, quod judicium differtur aliquando, ut tempore suo restauretur, It is a secret dispensation, by which his counsell is not changed, but the worke is varied, and judgement is exercised. For even this is judgement, that sometimes judgement is differred, that in his time it may be recalled. And this is most certaine, as Salvianus hath it,Salvian. de Guber. Dei. l. 2.
Sicut omnipotentia Domini indeficiens, sic censura inde mutabilis, That as the omnipotency of God is without defect, so the counsell of God is without change. For how can there be any change in him, to whom nothing is past or to come, but all things are present? As God filleth heaven and earth, and every where is present, so doth he fill all time, and all things at once are present unto him. He is as Hilarius Hilarius. speaketh, Immensae virtutis vivens potestas, quae nusquam non adest, non deest usquam, A living power of infinite vertue, which no where is not present, and is not absent any where. But not to speake more of this:Salvian. de Guber. Dei. l. 1. So foolish are these and such like objections, that as Salvianus speaketh, Cavendum est, quod ne id ipsum quod pro honore Dei dicitur, injuria Dei esse videatur. Tanta quippe est Majestatis sacrae & tam tremenda reverentia, ut non solum ea quae ab illis contra religionem dicuntur horrere, sed aliam quae pro religione nos ipsi dicimus, cum grandi metu & disciplina dicere debeamus, Care must be had, least that every thing which is spoken for the honour of God, may seeme to be an injury unto him. For so great and so fearefull is the reverence due to the Divine Majestie, that wee ought not onely to abhorre those things which are spoken against Religion, but also with feare and awfulnesse to speake those things, which wee our selves speake for Religion. Let it suffice therefore, as the Preacher sayth, That whatsoever God doth, it shall abide for ever. And that nothing can be put to it in the blessings of his providence: nothing can be taken from it in the judgements of his providence; nothing can be either put to it, or taken from it, in respect of the perfection of it. And that God doth it, that men should feare
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
à faciebus ejus, from his faces, to make some use of the verball translation: that is, that men should feare from the face of his judgements, and tremble at his angry
looke. For as the Psalmist speaketh, Psal. 34.16. The face of the Lord is against them that doe evill. And that men should reverence the face of his mercies, have their eyes towards it, and put their trust in it. For as the Psalmist also speaketh, The eyes of the Lord are upon the righteous.
Psal. 34.15. And that all men should hang downe their faces, and be ashamed, who thinke to mend what God doth.

q.p: VER. 16. And moreover, I saw under the Sunne, the place of Judgement, that wickednes was there: and the place of righteousnesse, that iniquitie was there.
VER. 17. J sayd in my heart, God shall judge the righteous and the wicked: for there is a time there for every purpose, and for every worke.

div.p:
Verse 16. The Preacher againe here sayth, I saw, as preventing the objection which he saw some ready to make. For having shewed the constant providence of God in ordering and governing the things of the world, he bringeth the objection that is made from the confusion of things in the world. And he giveth an instance in the confusion of judgement and justice: because if God did rule and governe the world, it might seeme that above all things he should not suffer that to be. This is the objection, which to confute Salvianus that devout and learned Biship of Marseiles, hath written eight most excellent bookes: and who in the entrance of his booke, setting downe the objection, sayth,Salvian. de Guber. Dei. l. 1.
Incuriosus à quibusdam, & quasi negligens, humanorum actuum, Deus dicitur, utpote nec bonos custodiens, nec coercens malos; quia boni mala omnia patiuntur, mali faciunt, God is by some sayd to be carelesse and negligent in the affayres of men, as neither preserving the good, nor restraining
the bad: seeing the righteous suffer all evils, the wicked commit them. Thus is the heart of man moved against God, for that, for which he ought to be loved by man, and to be praysed.Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Eccles. Hom. 18. For as Hugo de Sancto Victore speaketh, Conqueritur homo, quod malus homo à Deo toleratur, quum manifestum sit quod nullus homo fuisset bonus, si nullus aliquando fuisset toleratus malus, Man complaineth that evill men are suffered by God, when as it is manifest that no man had been good, if no man that is evill had been sometimes suffered. But to consider the Preachers words. I saw: he that had a discerning watchfull eye was able to see it; for commonly such wickednesse is hid, and the place of judgement is made to be a cover for it. I saw under the Sunne. The wickednesse that is, is under the Sunne, and as the Preacher sayth, I saw, so the Sunne saw it also. It is by the light of the Sunne that sensible things are discerned, and it is by the light of the Sunne of righteousnesse, that wickednesse is discerned. Vnder that Sunne therefore it was also that the Preacher saw it. I saw under the Sunne the place of Iudgement. The place of Iudgement is that which this world hath: the place where it should be, where it is ordained to be, where it is lookt for, where it is pretended to be, but where it is not. The Preacher saw that wickednesse was there: there, where the place of it was never appointed, there, where the place doth no way agree unto it. And therefore the Preacher as not beleeving his eyes, he lookes againe to be sure of it, as being a thing so bad, so strange to be so. But he finds that so it is: and he saw the place of righteousnesse that iniquitie was there. The throne which Solomon made,1 King 10.18. was overlayd with the best gold, auro purissimo, with the most pure gold; and what did this signifie, but the esteeme and price, in which God would have justice to be held; as also how pure the judgements should be that from thence are given. But too often, where the seate is gold, he that sits on it is brasse; where the place is the place of judgement and righteousnesse, wickednesse and iniquitie are found. Or if it shall be thought better to distinguish these two sentences. In the first place, wee may understand the place of them, who are placed in authoritie: in the second place, wee may understand the place of them, who are placed under them. For as an ancient Writer speaketh, Nisi illi per impietatem, innocentiam opprimerent, isti per iniquitatem, justitiam non impugnarent. Propterea nam{que} inferiores ad iniquitatem perpetrandam audaces sunt, quia superiores ad tuendam innocentiam non pii sunt, Vnlesse they by wickednesse did oppresse innocency, the other by iniquitie would not oppose justice. For therefore are inferiours bold to commit iniquitie, because superiours are not religious in defending of innocency. Or else wee may distinguish the sentences thus: the place of Iudgement, wee may understand to be the place of punishing the wicked, but that wickednesse was there. The place of righteousnesse, we may understand to be the place of rewarding and cherishing the righteous, but that iniquitie was there, and the righteous were disgraced and afflicted. Or lastly, wee may understand, and distinguish the sentences thus: in the place of Iudgement,
wee may apprehend the Iudge as a Iudge, and as giving the judgement of wickednesse, when his place calleth for justice: in the place of righteousnesse, wee may understand the Iudge as a man, who in his owne life and conversation, more especially then others, should shew forth righteousnesse.Cassiod. var. l. 6. var. 21. For as Cassiodore speaketh, Prima aequitas est, in se praesules inchoare: ut debeant criminosi metuere, quem non queunt similem reperire. Nullus enim in se culpas timet reus quas habere conspexerit cognitorem, The first righteousnesse is, that Governours beginne with themselves, that so they who are faultie may feare him, whom they cannot finde like unto themselves. For a guiltie person never feareth those faults in himselfe, which he seeth to be in his Iudge. But where this righteousnesse should be, there is too often iniquitie. And the bad Iudge freeth another, because he would not condemne himselfe. For as Cassiodore also speaketh, Sicos actus nullus damnat in altero: quia natura est humani animi, ut nitatur potius vindicare, quod se cogno verit admisisse, No one condemneth his owne acts in another, because the nature of mans minde is, that it endeavoureth rather to justifie that which himselfe practiseth.

Verse 17. The Preacher here answereth the objection, and to shew that himselfe quickly saw the answer, as well as the objection, he sayth with an emphasis, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Dixi ego, I sayd. I sayd in my heart: to shew that he was resolved and firmely perswaded of it. And what he sayd in his heart, he hath here sayd openly, that all may heare, and all may be perswaded of it also. God shall judge. Man now too often doth not judge, although he may sit upon the seate of judgement: but God shall judge, although his judgement seate be not now seene, be not now considered. God shall judge: not but that he doth now judge also.Salvian. de Gubern. Dei. l. 1. For as Salvianus speaketh very well, Ita in futuro judicaturum affirmemus, ut tamen semper, etiam in hoc saeculo judicasse doceamus. Dum enim semper gubernat Deus, & semper judicat: quia gubernatio ipsa est ipsum judicium, Let us so affirme, that God will judge in the time to come, as that withall we teach, that God in this world doth also judge alwayes. For while God alwayes governeth, he alwayes judgeth; because the governing is it selfe a judgement. God shall judge the righteous, the righteous shall first be judged, that they being in the comfort of safetie, may not be terrified with the judgement of the wicked: and that the wicked being left out may see their judgement begun before it is begun. He shall judge the righteous and the wicked. To the righteous, who is here wronged, he shall give righteous judgement: the wicked, whose iniquitie is here spared, his judgement shall not spare. He shall judge the wicked Iudge for his wickednesse: to the righteous Iudge his righteousnesse shall adjudge a glorious reward. For there is a time there, for every purpose and for every worke: there is a time there for every thing:Lyra in hunc vers. Quia multa quae nunc videntur inordinata ad ordinem divinae justitiae reducentur, Because many things which now seeme to be out of order, shall there be brought into order by Gods divine justice, as Lyra speaketh. Then will be a fit time for all things, then they will be growne
to a ripenesse. For as Tertullian speaketh, Nihil sine aetate est: Tertul. de veland. virg. l. 1.
omnia tempus expectant, There is nothing without a time of maturity: and as all things expect that time, so this time of Gods Iudgement all things expect, as the time of maturity for all things. There is a time there for every thing, that is saith Saint Hierome, Deus non judicat per partes, Hieronym. in hunc vers. & per singulos, sed in futurum reservat judicium, ut omnes pariter judicentur, God doth not judge by parts, and by singulars, but reserveth things unto the future judgement that all may be judged together. But that Salvianus and Saint Hierome may not seeme to oppose one the other: There is a secret judgement, and there is a manifest judgement: by his judgement that is secret, God judgeth every particular in this world, and every singular person when he goes out of the world: by his manifest judgement hee will at last judge all together. For every purpose and for every worke: not only the works of men at that time shall be judged, and of which alone man passeth his judgement, but every purpose also shall be judged, although it have not proceeded to the working of it. For every purpose: the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which most directly is thus rendred, Tempus omni voluntati, A time for every will: a time for Gods will, as well as a time for mans will. And as man now doth whatsoever he will, and too often followes the bent of his will, though it cary him to wickednesse; so then God will have his will, then will be the fit time for it. And therefore whereas we read it in the Epistle to the Galatians, In due season we shall reape if wee faint not, the Greeke is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in his time wee shall reape,Tertul. advers. Mar. l. 5. c. 4. and so I find Tertullian to render the words. The time of judgement is Gods time, his proper and peculiar time, the fit time for his will to be done upon those who have not done his will: the fit time for his good will to be shewed to those, who have followed his will. The last part of the verse in the Originall is thus set downe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Et super omne opus ibi, and upon every work there, that is and there God will shew himselfe to have had an eye and a regard upon every worke. Or else, and there God will give his judgement upon every worke. Or else, and hee that is above every worke will shew himselfe there. Or else, and he that is over the whole, there is, as Tremellius reads it: there is, that is, there is glorious in that glorious worke. So that these last words may bee referred, either to the time of the judgement, or to God who will be the Iudge. But let not therefore those who are here wronged, be too much afflicted, God shall there doe them right. Let not them who here unjustly prevaile too much triumph, God shall there confound them, and their prevailing here shall be there their overthrow.

q.p: VER. 18. I said in mine heart concerning the estate of the sonnes of men that God might manifest them, and that they might see that they themselves are beasts.

VER. 19. For that which befalleth the sons of men, befalleth beasts, even one thing befalleth them: as the one dieth, so dyeth the other; yea, they have all one breath, so that a man hath no preeminence above a beast, for all is vanity.
VER. 20. All goe unto one place, all are of the dust, and all turne to dust againe.
VER. 21. Who knoweth the spirit of man that goeth upward, and the spirit of the beast that goeth downeward to the earth?
VER. 22. Wherefore I perceive that there is nothing better, then that a man should rejoyce in his owne workes: for that is his portion: for who shall bring him to see what shall be after him?

div.p:
Verse 18. The answer of the Preacher having two parts, he repeateth againe his words, I said in mine heart: and having answered concerning God, and shewed his just providence, though things may seeme to be neglected by him: here he answereth concerning man to whom the things of this world are so full of disorder and confusion. And because this answer concerneth either the righteous, or the wicked, I will consider it both wayes. First then, the confusion of things in this world in respect of the righteous is, that God might manifest them, and see whether in the darknesse of this world they would looke after him. For when God shewed himselfe plainely unto man in his creation, then man departed from God, and turned away from him. God therfore trieth,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 18.
Si requisierit absentem, & absconditum desideraverit, & sciat esse quod non videtur, If he will seeke him being absent, and looke after him being hid, and may know him to be in governing and disposing of the world,
although he doe not see him. Or else it is to manifest them to themselves, that they may see how weake their judgement is, how darke their understanding, how shallow their insight into the wayes of God, and that they are but beasts in respect of God. Psal. 73.22. For so the Psalmist speaking of those things whereof the Preacher here doth, sayth, So foolish was I and ignorant, I was as a beast before thee. Ambros. in Psal. 72. And Saint Ambrose writing upon those words of the Psalmist saith, Pulchre addidit, Apud te, quia, comparatione coelestium homo quid est, nisi jumentum irrationale? Elegantly did he adde before thee, because in respect of heavenly things, what is man but an unreasonable beast? This therefore would God have man to acknowledge, and therefore the Originall addeth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ipsi sibi themselves to themselves, that is, that in respect of their own esteeme of themselves, and in their humble account of themselves, they should see themselves as beasts, and also as beasts should submit themselves to the yoake of Gods pleasure, to the burden which Gods disposing providence layeth upon them. Or else that they may see that themselves are beasts, in the miseries and calamities and changes of this world, which to them are common with beasts. And therefore as Saint Hierome speaketh,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Non mirandum esse inpraesenti vita inter justum & impium nullam esse discrepantiam, quum etiam inter pecudes & homines secundum corporis qualitatem nihil differre videatur, It is not to be marveiled, that there is no difference in this life betweene the righteous and the wicked, when as even betweene men and beasts in respect of the quality of the body there may seeme to be no difference. And God would have the righteous to see that they are so beasts, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ipsi sibi, themselves to themselves, that is, by their owne fall, by the just punishment which they have brought upon themselves. Secondly, the confusion of worldly things in respect of the wicked is, that God might manifest them, and shew what the corruption of their heart is: and that they might see, or as Pagnine reads it, Vt ostenderet, that God might shew that themselves are beasts, themselves though men are beasts, beasts in minding nothing but earthly things, beasts in considering onely the things that are present, beasts in destroying and oppressing one the other. And that they are beasts 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ipsi sibi, indeed beasts to themselves, in their owne apprehension and imagination and perswasion, as thinking that after this life all is done with them, and that there is no more reckoning to be made, for that which is done here.

Verse 19. If we take this verse as the speech of the righteous, it is their humble confession, and is to be understood of the body only. If we take the words as the speech of the wicked, it is their sinfull consolation, whereby they hearten themselves in their wicked courses. But to consider the words, that is said properly to befall a man, of the comming whereof he doth not know, and of this it is that the verse speaketh: the scope of the place ayming at those events, whereof man is ignorant, as a beast is of those events that doe befall a beast. That which befalleth the sonnes of men, befalleth beasts, and seeing the event of dying
followeth, in that the Preacher saith, the sonnes of men, wee may understand the event of being borne; for that befalleth beasts, as it befalleth men, as the one is conceived, so is the other, as the one commeth into the world so doth the other, even one thing befalleth them both. Vnlesse the difference bee, that mans comming into the world is more wretched, presaging by his cryes, the miseries that doe expect him. For as Chrysologus speaketh,Chrysologus Serm. 44.
In vitâ quem laetitia tenebit, qui vitae sumit exordium de moerore? Whom shall comfort entertaine in his life, who from sorrow beginneth his life? As the one dyeth, so dyeth the other: As death is common to all beasts, so is it to all men; as the one cannot shunne it,Chrysostom. Homil. de fida & Spiritu Sancto. so neither can the other. Saint Chrysostome taking notice, how in matrimoniall contracts, care is taken for children, and how if one dye the other shall succeed him, thereupon saith, Non solum qui vivunt mortis sententia feriuntur, sed & illi qui nondum nati sunt, Not only they that live are strucken with the sentence of death, but they also which are not yet borne, they are sure to dye also, if ever they be borne. And as the time of their death is unknowne to beasts, so is it to man also. Psal. 78.48. We read in the Psalmes, Hee destroyed their mulbery Trees with the frost: now the Mulberry Tree doth not put forth his blossomes, as other trees in the spring, when often the cold doth nip them; but when the heate being growne strong, lesse danger appeareth; and so many men are carefull in shunning the occasions of sicknesse and the ayres contagion, and yet as the frost destroyeth the Mulbery Trees, so the frost of death destroyeth them when it is not looked for. The counsell therefore of Seneca is good,Seneca. Nescis quo loco te mors expectat, tu ita{que} in omni loco mortem expecta, Thou knowest not in what place death expecteth thee, doe thou therefore expect death in every place. But though as one dyeth, Hugo Victorinus in Eccles. Hom. 18.
so dyeth the other, yet as Hugo Victorinus speaketh, Quod similiter habent ex simili causa non habent: quia homo ut moriatur ex culpa habuit, jumentum vero ex natura quod moriatur accepit, That which they have alike, they have not from the like cause, because that man dyeth, he hath from his offence, that the beast dyeth he hath from his nature. And let the wicked know, that death which is from their offence is the passage to their punishment for all their offences: and let the godly know that death, which for their offence endeth their life, endeth also their offences, that they shall sin no more. Yea they have all one breath: the Originall word is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and if wee take the words as spoken by the righteous; it must be rendred breath, it being but the breath of this temporall life, which they know to be the same in all. But if we take the words as spoken by the wicked, the word may perhaps rather bee rendred, spirit: for they imagine, or at least would imagine, the spirit of man to bee mortall,Greg. Dial. l. 4. c. 3. as is the spirit of a beast. But Saint Gregory tels them, that God hath created three living spirits, Vnum qui carne non tegitur: alium qui carne tegitur, sed cum carne non moritur, tertium qui carne tegitur, & cum carne moritur, One which is not covered with flesh: another which is covered with the flesh, but doth not dye with the flesh,
a third which is covered with the flesh, and dyeth with the flesh. Wherefore although the Spirit in man and beast bee one, in that it is covered in both with flesh; yet it is not one in this, because in the beast the Spirit dyeth, with the flesh, in man it dyeth not. So that a man hath no praeeminence above a beast: No, in respect of giving up his breath, hee that hath both the greatest praeeminence among men, hath no praeeminence above a beast: but in respect of giving up the Spirit, as the wicked are beneath the very beasts; so the righteous are aequall to the Angels. For all is vanity: all is vanity and vanisheth in this mortall life: but after this life, the vanity to the wicked is turned into unsufferable misery; the vanity to the righteous is turned into unexpressable glory.

Verse 20. All goe unto one place: All, for all in this journey are fellow travellers; all both men and beasts. The beast which caryeth man in his journey on the earth, is caryed in an equall condition with man in this journey to the earth. All goe: yea, all are alwayes going: for there is no journey else, in which there is not some staying, some resting for one occasion or other, but in this journey, there is no time of stay. When once this journey is begun, and begun it is, as soone as life beginneth, there is nothing but a continuall going on. Alexis the Poet, being asked what he did, made answer, Paulatim morior, I dye by little and little. He was indeed an old man when he spake it, but the youngest may say the same. For as Seneca speaketh,Seneca. Paulatim morimur, quia paulatim vita decrescit, hoc autem decrementum, quid aliud est quam mors paulatim procedens? we dye by little and little, because by little and little our life goeth away, and what else is this going away of life, but a going on by little and little unto death? All goe unto one place. It is but one place, there be no upper and lower places in death, but how different soever, the places of men may be while they lived, when they dye, they are all in the same place: yea beasts are in the same place, with the wisest, the richest, the greatest men. They goe to one place, even to the earth. And there indeed is the place, where the beasts doe rest, there is their journeys end. But the righteous and the wicked which hitherto keepe company, there are divided, and take their severall wayes, the one to the place of endlesse comfort, the other to the place of endlesse torment. Wherefore an Ancient Writer saith, Vna sorte involvuntur justi cum impiis, donec pariter currunt in via, ut quum simul exierint, discernantur, & ordinentur dispariter, The righteous and the wicked are wrapt up in one condition, while they goe on alike in the way, that when they are gone our together, they may be distinguished, and not alike rewarded. All are of the dust. Saint Basil saith,Basilius. that when God made man of the dust of the earth, hee tooke the dust from the fower parts of the earth, that so whither soever men should goe, or wheresoever men might bee, whether East, West, North or South, they might still remember that they were made of that earth:Chrysolog. Serm. 45. And Chrysologus puts us in mind of another thing, he tels us, Pulvere concreti,
plasmati luto calcamur vitiis, Being made of the dust, formed of the clay, wee are trode upon by vices. This it is which maketh the earth it selfe at last, to trample upon us all, when all turne to dust againe. Now thus God hath appointed it, Vt per id quo vadit homo, agnoscat unde venerat, that by the place to which man goeth, he may acknowledge the place from whence he came, as an ancient Writer speaketh: that by the grave wherein his body is laid, he may consider Paradise in which being made hee was set by God; that by the basenesse to which he is brought, hee may consider the glory to which hee was created, and so may seeke carefully to returne thither, before that hee returne to the dust.

Verse 21. If we apprehend these words as spoken by the wicked, then it is a question which implyeth an answer of denyall: as if though some doe talke of such a thing, yet that it was not so, and therefore none could know it to be so. If we apprehend the words as spoken by the righteous, then it is a question that implyeth a difficulty in the affirming of it, though not an untruth: as if they were but few that knew it, and as if the frailty of mans condition, and the confusion of humane things did deceive many in it. Who knoweth? Indeed none but they to whom God hath made it knowne.Tertull. de Anima. c. 1. For as Tertullian speaketh, Cui veritas comperta sine Deo, cui Deus cognitus sine Christo, cui Christus exploratus sine spiritu Sancto, cui spiritus Sanctus accommodatus sine fidei Sacramento? To whom is the truth discovered without God, to whom is God knowne without Christ, to whom is Christ revealed without the Holy Ghost, to whom is the Holy Ghost given without the Sacrament of faith? The Philosophers were very busie, and much turmoyled in seeking after the nature of the soule, and to speake of them in Tertullians words,
•• tul. Ibid. Non ignoro quanta sit sylva materiae istius apud istos, I am not ignorant, what a wood and plenty there is of this matter among them. A wood it is, wherein if they saw any light of the truth, it is only a glimpse of it, through the thicke trees of ignorance and errours; and wherein if any shall seeke for the truth, he shall seeke it in a wood. Certe non alius potius animae demonstrator quam auctor, Surely there is no better manifester of the soule, then he who is the maker of it, and that is God himselfe. Eccles. 12.7. Wherefore the Preacher who setteth downe this question here, who knoweth? did himselfe know it from God, and telleth us that the spirit returneth unto God who gave it. Nostraita{que} institutio sit de porticu Solomonis, Let our instruction therefore be from the Schoole of Solomon, and let us know that the spirit of man goeth upward. The Originall is the spirit of the sonnes of men, not that they have it by generation as being sonnes, but because they have it together with their generation from God bestowed on them. The Philosophers also talke much,Tertul. advers. Haereti. de praescrip. cap. 7. of the ascending and going upward of the soule: and as for the soules of the wise, Plato affirmed them to ascend unto the skie, the Stoicks affirmed them to be under the Moone, another affirmed them to ascend only into the ayre. But the Preacher here comparing the spirits of men
with the spirits of beasts, not the spirits of wise men, with the spirits of fooles: by going upward, understandeth the immortalitie of the spirits of men; by going downward to the earth, the perishing of the spirits of beasts. And by the manner of the Preachers phrase, I apprehend him to compare the spirit of man unto a purer exhalation, which ascending upward, continueth in the ayre: the spirit of a beast, unto a thicke and blacke vapour, which being dissolved into raine, descendeth and falleth to the earth. The spirit of man therefore dyeth not,Tertull. de Anima. c. 53 and as Tertullian speaketh; Abducitur dum absumi videtur, opere decedens non vigore, actu languens non statu, comparere cessat, non esse, It is but caryed away when it seemeth to vanish away, and failing in his worke, not in his strength, departing in respect of actuating the body, not in respect of its owne actuall existence, ceaseth onely to appeare to be, not ceaseth to be. In a spirituall sense St. Hierome applyeth these words thus: and asketh, who knoweth, whether one of understanding and learned in the Scriptures, id est homo, that is a man, but not living religiously and carefully, as his knowledge directeth him, doth not goe downward to the place of misery? And whether one of more simplicitie in understanding and plainnesse in knowledge;Hieronym. in hunc vers. Qui jumentum hominis comparatione dicatur, who in comparison of a man may be sayd to be a beast, but yet living more vertuously and godly, doth not goe upward, and to the place of joy.

Verse 22. The Preacher having seene the objections that were made by worldly minds, against the government of the world by Gods divine providence, and having made others to see the truth, by answering of them: he resumeth his assertion which he delivered before at the thirteenth verse, and concludeth, Wherefore I see and perceive that there is nothing better for man, who cannot see into Gods workes, and the reasons of them, then that he rejoyce in his owne workes: there is nothing better for man, who is often forced by the wrongfull doings of others to suffer that wherein he hath no cause of rejoycing, then that he doe therefore rejoyce in those things which he doth himselfe. And seeing that his portion is the same with beasts in that he dyeth, let him take his portion of living comfortably while that he liveth. Seeing he shall not returne when he is gone, let him goe on with cheerefulnesse and contentment while he continueth here. For that is the portion which God hath divided to him, that is the talent which God hath committed to him. His owne works are they for which he shall answer: and that he may rejoyce in them, let him be carefull that his workes be vertuous and good, for then he may safely rejoyce in them, then he shall be sure to have comfort and joy from them. Lyra therefore in this place, expoundeth his owne works, to be the works of vertue,Lyra in hunc vers. Quae proprie dicuntur humana, alia enim magis dicuntur bestialia, which properly are sayd to be the works of men, for other works are rather sayd to be the works of beasts. For who shall bring him to see, what shall be after him? Hieronym. in hunc vers. St. Hierome tels us, Apertius interpretatus est Symmachus, dicens, ut videat
quae futura sunt post haec, More plainely doth Symmachus translate the words, saying, For who shall bring him to see those things which shall be after these? And indeed the meaning so is plainly this; There is nothing better then that a man should rejoyce in his owne works, in those which he is able to doe, and which he doth well, and that he should doe them with rejoycing and alacritie: for who shall bring him to see the things that shall be afterwards? How can he know whether he shall be able to doe those things, which now he is able to doe; whether he shall doe those things, which now he doth, whether the things that shall be afterwards will be matter of rejoycing to him or no? But to take the generall reading of the words, Who shall bring him to see what shall be after him? that is, sayth the French translation, Qui le remanera? Who shall bring him backe when he is gone out of this life, to enjoy the things of this life againe? Let him therefore rejoyce in the good use of them, while that he hath them. The Pythagoreans taught a returning of men to this life,Tertull. de Anima. c. 28 after they were departed. And Tertullian tels us, that Pythagoras to establish this tenet among his Schollers, did hide himselfe in a cave, and to dissemble his feigned death, Septenni se ille patientia damnabat, he condemned himselfe to prison there by the space of seven yeares. Now none knew of this but his mother onely, who ministred unto him, and brought him notice still of those who dyed in the meane while, that so by telling of their being dead, as if he had talked with them, he might assure the imagination of his owne being dead. At length appearing againe not unlike one that came out of a Sepulchre, for his cave had changed him, Ad mortui veteris horrorem, to the horridnesse of a long dead man; he was received as one that was alive againe. For as Tertullian speaketh, Quis non crederet revixisse, qui crediderat obiisse? Who would not beleeve him to be alive againe, who had beleeved him to be dead? But howsoever, he lyed concerning his owne death, to make his tenet seeme true, that the dead doe live againe: Tertullian well concludeth, Mortuos quidem ex vivis effici constat, non ideo tamen ex mortuis vivos, It is most true, that of living men all become dead, but that from the dead, men are made living, is not therefore true. For as the Preacher sayth, Who shall bring them back?

q.p: VER. 1. So J returned, and considered all the oppressions that are done under the Sunne, and behold the teares of such as were oppressed, and they had no comforter: and on the side of their oppressours there was power, but they had no comforter.
VER. 2. Wherefore I praised the dead, which are already dead, more then the living which are yet alive.
VER. 3. Yea, better is he then, both they, which hath not yet been, who hath not seene the evill worke that is done under the Sunne.

div.p:
Verse 1. THE Preacher having wearied himselfe with the sad consideration of the miseries and vanities of this world, gave some rest unto his thoughts: but returning to his meditations, he passed from the consideration of vaine and temporall things, to the consideration of vaine and sinfull things. And first he beheld all the oppressions that are done under the Sunne. Wee reade it oppressions, and as I suppose by reason of the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which followes, signifying fiunt are done, that agreeing best unto oppressions. But the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifieth Oppressos, them that are oppressed: and the other Originall word signifieth as well subiguntur are brought under, as fiunt are done. So that the more direct reading may seeme to be this, that he beheld all the oppressed, which are brought under, under the Sunne. He speakes of all the oppressed, as being many. For as one sayth well, Mundus nescit irasci nisi in innocentes, the world knoweth not how to be angry but against the innocent. Hence it is, that our Saviour Christ sayth to his
Disciples, Luk. 21.9. When yee heare of warres and commotions, be not terrified: he sayth not, when yee heare of warres and commotions against your selves: supposing that these things must be understood to be against the innocent. And therefore the Preacher also here sayth, And behold the teares of the oppressed, as if nothing were more common to be seene.Chrysost. Homil. de Absalom. So that St. Chrysostome cryeth out, O Innocentia, quantum apud reos periculi suscipis! O Innocency, how much dost thou suffer with them that are guiltie! Vnder the Sunne. It is the observation of Theodoret, that God appointed the vehement heate of the Sunne sometimes to scorch the earth,Theodoret. l. 3. de Diis & Angelis. and to destroy the fruits of it: Ne solem vitae causam autorem{que} opinemur, Least wee should thinke the Sunne to be the cause and authour of life. And I suppose the Preacher shewing the vanities of the world, so often to speake of them as being under the Sunne, least any should thinke the Sunne to be the God of the world. Or else wee may conceive him to make mention here of being under the Sunne, because although the wrongs of the oppressed were most apparent and plaine, yet there was none to comfort them. And behold the teares: the Originall word is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying lachrymam, non lachrymas, a teare (according to the Hebrew tongue) not teares: as if the oppressed had wept so long for sorrow, or else had wept so much to beg helpe, that they could weepe no longer, could weepe no more, but had onely a teare left them, (if I may in this manner borrow an expression of the greatnesse of oppression, which the place intendeth) And on the side of the oppressours there was power. The Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used, signifieth to oppresse either by fraud or else by violence. Wherefore seeing the oppression is here repeated: in the first place wee may understand oppression by fraud: in this latter place, oppression by violence; and the rather because it is sayd, that on the side of the oppressour there was power. Or else wee may understand it thus, that whereas the oppressed had no comforter to relieve them; the oppressours had friends and great ones to support them. But they had no comforter: none on earth, none from heaven, no man was their comforter, neither was God. For he doth reserve comforts for them another where, and here doth sometimes leave them without the comfort of any;Hugo Victorinus in Eccles. Hom. 19.
Ne in alieno consolentur quod suum non habent, & minus desiderent ejus consolationem quam nondum habent, least they should be comforted in the helpe of others, because they have not his, and should the lesse desire his comfort, which as yet they have not, as Hugo Victorinus speaketh. Let therefore in this case God be sought unto, whose power is above all power, in expectation of him, let patience rest, for he is and will shew himselfe the comforter of the comfortlesse.

Verse 2. Indeed so many, so great are the miseries of this life, that in comparison of them, even death it selfe is to be preferred before life. For as St. Ambrose speaketh,Ambros. de fide Resurrectionis. Quid nobis miserius, qui tanquam spoliati & nudi projicimur in hanc vitam, corpore fragili, corde lubrico, imbecillo animo, anxii ad solicitudinem, desidiosi ad labores, proni ad voluptates? What is
more miserable then wee are, who like men naked and spoyled are cast into this life, fraile of body, inconstant of heart, weake of minde, full of cares, sloathfull to labours, prone to pleasures. And therefore one sayth well; Quomodo potest amari haec vita, tantas habens amaritudines? Kempis. l. 3. de Imitat. Christi. c. 20.
Quomodo etiam dicitur vita tot generans mortes? How can this life be loved, which is so full of loathsome bitternesse? yea, how can it be called a life, which bringeth forth so many deaths? The resolution therefore of St. Ambrose is, Tantis malis haec vita repleta est, Ambros. Serm. 37. de Sanctis. ut comparatione ejus mors remedium putetur non poena, With so great evils is this life stuffed, that in comparison thereof death may be thought a remedy, and not a punishment. For as the same Father elsewhere speaketh,Ambros. de Bono mortis. c. 2.
Si plena oneris vita, utique finis ejus allevamentum, If this life be loaded with burdens, then the end of it must needs be an ease. But I understand rather the Preacher in this place to preferre the dead before the living in respect of the evill of sinne. He sayth therefore, I praysed the dead; Ambrosius de fide Resurrectionis. he it is Qui sapientiam poposcit & impetravit, who asked wisedome and obtained it, as St. Ambrose speaketh. I praised the dead more then the living: and most justly; for as St. Ambrose speaketh, Quid est mors nisi sepultura vitiorum? Ambros. de Bono mortis. c. 4. Luk. 2.29. What is death but the buriall of vices? And seeing the death of sinne is better then the life of sinne, this must needs make the dead more worthy to be praised than the living. Wherefore doth not old Simeon say, Now lettest thou thy servant depart in peace, Quasi à vinculis quibusdam ad libertatem festinaret, as if he hasted from some bonds unto libertie? And indeed they were bonds that did hold him, even bonds that made him captive unto the law of sinne. Doth not Iacob say,Gen. 47.9. Ambros. Ibid. Few and evill have been my dayes? Mali, non quia dies mali, sed quia nobis accessu dierum incrementa malitiae cumulantur, Evill, not because the dayes were evill, but because in us the encrease of wickednesse is heaped up by the encrease of dayes. Doth not St. Paul say, It is gaine to dye? Phil. 1.21. Nam lucrum est evasisse incrementa peccati, For it is gaine to have escaped the gaine and encrease of sinne, as St. Ambrose also speaketh. The dead which are already dead, more then the living which are yet alive: that is, sayth Lyra, Qui sublati sunt ex hac vita, Lyra in hunc vers. antequam experientiam haberent tanti mali, Who are taken out of this life before they have experience of so great an evill. He that is the Authour of the Commentaries upon the Epistle of St. Paul to the Ephesians, Hierome in Epist. ad Ephes. which are among St. Hieromes workes, reads the words thus, Laudavi omnes mortuos, qui olim mortui sunt, I praised all the dead, which are dead long since: as if to be dead any way were better then to be alive: or, as if they who were not onely dead but forgotten, not onely dead but turned into ashes, and their ashes lost, were better then the living. But seeing the Originall word speaketh of a time past, wee may well understand the Preacher to speake of those who are dead being young, and to preferre them before those who live to elder yeares. For as St. Bernard speaketh,Bernard. Meditat. c. 2.
Cur tantopere vitam istam desideramus, in qua quanto amplius vivimus, tanto plus peccamus: quanto est vita longior, tanto culpa numerosior? Why doe wee so much desire
this life, in which by how much the longer wee live, by so much the more wee sinne: by how much our yeares are more, by so much our sinnes are more.Ambros. Epist. ad Heliodorum. And St. Ambrose sayth, Quod esse discriminis putas inter eum qui moritur puer, & eum qui demoritur senex, nisi quod hic peccatis abeat oneratior, & plurium culparum coram Deo reus quam ille? What difference dost thou thinke there is betweene him that dyeth a childe, and him that dyeth an old man, but that this goeth away more burdened with sinnes, and guiltie of more faults before God then the other?

Verse 3. That the Preacher speaketh of the evill of committing of sinne, this confirmeth me, because here he speaketh of the evill worke, and of the evill that is done. Better is he, that is not so ill. For we are not so to understand the Preacher, as if he that is not borne, hath any being before he is borne, and that he is the more happy, because he is not yet encumbred with a body, which thing some have imagined: but because it is better, or rather not so ill, at all not to be, then either to be, or else to live unhappily, and wickedly. Better is he then both they, that is, sayth Lyra well,Lyra in hunc vers. Malo homine mortuo, & malo homine vivente, An evill man dead, and an evill man living. Better is he then both they, who hath not yet been: Ambros. Serm. 18. in Psal. 118. Wherefore St. Ambrose sayth, Mortuus praefertur viventi, quia peccare desinit: mortuo praefertur qui nondum natus est, quia peccare nescivit; He that is dead is preferred before the living, because he ceaseth to sinne; and he that is not borne is preferred before the dead, because he hath not knowne how to sinne. Who hath not seene the evill worke that is done under the Sunne: if wee understand the words of the evill of misery, it may serve to expresse the greatnesse of humane misery, though in it selfe it be not so to be taken; and better is he that is not yet borne, then both they, either he that is already dead, or he that is yet living. For as St. Hierome speaketh,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Cicero in Tuscul. 1a.
Alius mala adhuc patitur, alius quaesi nudus de naufragio evasit, The one doth yet suffer evils still, the other is but escaped as one naked from shipwracke. And therefore Cicero could say, Non nasci longe optimum, not to be borne is the best of all. And howbeit, Solomon alone hath expresly delivered this sentence, it is not the sentence of Solomon alone.Iob 3.3. Ambros. de fide Resurrect. For Iob sayth, Let the day perish wherein I was borne, and that he sayth as St. Ambrose expoundeth him, Quia cognoverat nasci malorum omnium principium esse, & ideo diem quo natus est perire optavit, ut tolleretur origo incommodorum, Because he knew, that to be borne was the beginning of all evils; and therefore he wished that the day of his birth might perish, that so the beginning of evils and troubles might be taken away. But as I have sayd, I understand the Preacher here rather to speake of the evill of sinne: Mat. 26.24. and in that respect it is that our Saviour Christ speaking of Iudas, sayth, It had been good for that man if he had not been borne. Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Eccles. Hom, 19. For as one sayth very well, Majus malum peccatum est, quam non esse, & melius esset non esse quam peccasse, To sinne is a greater evill then not to be, and it is better not to be then to sinne. In generall, the reason is given by Hugo de Sancto Victore thus, Quod longius à malo est in bono, ipsum majus est bonum. Si ergo malum est esse, bonum utique est non
esse, & multo melius utro{que} non fuisse; That which in good things is farthest from evill, is the greater good. And therefore if it bee evill to bee, it is good not to be, and much better then both, not to have beene at all.

q.p: VER. 4. Againe I considered all travaile, and every right worke, that for this a man is envyed of his neighbour? this is also vanity and vexation of Spirit.
VER. 5. The foole foldeth his hands together, and eateth his owne flesh.
VER. 6. Better is a handfull with quietnesse, then both the hands full with travell and vexation of Spirit.

div.p:
Verse 4. The Preacher having considered the sinfull vanity of malice which oppresseth right, hee considereth next the sinfull vanity of envy, which opposeth right doing, saying, I considered all travaile and every right worke: Olympiodorus reads it,Olympiad. Omnem laborem & omnem fortitudinem operis, all labour and all strength of worke; as if the Preacher intended only the paines of labour, and a patient courage in the enduring of it. But the Originall is more large, and speaketh of the generall rightnesse of worke. And this rightnesse may be taken either for the hansome rightnesse of a worke, as it is a worke, and so the Vulgar Latin according to the Septuagint doe take it, rendring it Industrias, that is an aptnesse in the doing of things: or else the rightnesse may bee taken more largely, either for the rightnesse of a worke as it is a worke, or else for the rightnesse of a worke according to the rules of vertue, and so Saint Hierome may seeme to take it,Hieronym. who renders it omnem virtutem operis, all vertue of worke. That for this a man is envied: When Abraham had rescued Lot, and conquered those Kings by whom he was taken prisoner, afterwards the word of the Lord came unto him saying, Feare not Abraham, I am thy shield.
Gen. 15.1. If this had beene spoken to him before the battle, it might have beene done to encourage him: but being spoken to him after the battle and victory, they seeme to arme him against a new combat of envy which his valiant and well doing was ready to bring upon him. For this is the difference betweene envy and other vices: that they are cured by the good examples of others, but the goodnes of others is that from which this sin ariseth. Old Iacob speaking of his sonne Ioseph saith, Gen. 49.23. that the Archers have sorely grieved him, and shot at him, and hated him: and Saint Hierome expounding
the words noteth,Hieronym. in Quastionib. Hebrae. Hic invidiam cum arcu & sagittis introduci ad sagittandum quod immaculatum est, That here envy is brought in with bow and arrowes shooting at that which is immaculate, and where there is no spot to bee a marke for it. Or else, as an Archer doth set up some white thing to be the marke at which he shoots, so it is the whitenesse of some good thing, against which the height of envy is caryed. And therefore, Gen. 37.33. when Iacob saith, an evill beast hath devoured my sonne, hee may seeme to prophesie, it being envy which had made him away, and which is so evill a beast, that it is goodnesse alwayes that is opposed by it. The Preacher here speaketh of all labour, and of every right worke: for if it be right, whatsoever it be, though never so small, it is by envy opposed; that will seeke to hinder the labour in the doing of it, that will seeke to overthrow the rightnesse of it when it is done. Yea it is the nature of envy to make little things appeare to be great. Wherefore it is reported by Panormitanus, Panormit. that a question being moved before Fredericke the King, what was good for the eye sight, and the Physitians answering some one thing, some another; Sannizarius answered that envy was very good: at which there being a smiling, he gave his reason for it; because that doth make all things appeare bigger then they are. For this a man is envyed of his neighbour: nay of his Father in Law. For did not this make Saul to envy David, so that David flying to Achish, Maluit hosti quam invidiae subjacere, he had rather be under an enemy,Hieronym. Epist. ad Eustochium. then under envy, as St. Hierome speaketh: Nay, of his brother, when there was but one brother in the world. For did not this make Cain to envy Abel, Vt esse solum zeli livor faceret, quem primum fecerat lex naturae, So that the rage of envy made him to be alone, whom the law of nature had made to bee the first:Chrysolog. Serm. 4. de duóbus filiis. as Chrysologus speaketh. For indeed there is nothing so contrary to charity and affection, whether of nature or grace, or the neighborhood of place as envy is. This is also vanity and vexation of spirit. First vanity, for what is more vaine, then that as Saint Chrysostome speaketh, Aliena gloria plus offendant quam proprium damnum, Anothers honour should more offend a man, than his owne hurt? And yet was it not so with envious Saul, who when David played on his harp to cure him of the evill spirit, did throw his Speare at him, Malens a malo spiritu torqueri, quam Davidem vivere, choosing rather to bee tormented by an evill spirit, then that David should live,Bern. de Inter. domo. c. 2. Cypr. de zelo & livore. as Saint Bernard speaketh. For what is more vaine, then as St. Cyprian speaketh, In malum proprium convertere bona aliena, aliorum gloriam facere poenam suam, & nullius magìs quam suae salutis hostem esse, To turne the good things of another to bee evill to himselfe, to make the glory of another to be his punishment, and to bee an enemy to nothing so much, as to his owne welfare? Secondly, vexation of spirit: in which respect Saint Chrysostome sayth,Chrys. in 2. ad Corinth. Homil. 19.
Praestat serpentem provolutum in visceribus habere quam invidiam, A man were better have a Serpent tumbling in his bowels then envy. For if a Serpent have food given it, it will not feed upon a man; but the more food is given to envy, the
more it gnaweth him in whose bowels it is.Chrysolog. Serm. 172.
Chrysologus therefore speaking of envy saith, that being Suorum carnifex, torquet animos, discruciat mentes, corrumpit corda, & quid plura? hanc qui suscipit, sua sustinet sine fine supplicia; nam quot sunt prosperitates hominum, tot sunt tormenta invidorum, the executioner of them that entertaine it: it tortureth the affections, it vexeth the minde, it corrupteth the heart, and what need of more? whosoever receiveth it, endureth without end his owne punishment: for as many as are the prosperities of men, so many are the torments of the envious. Such is the vexation of spirit which envie causeth, that it is one of the torments of hell. For our Saviour Christ speaking of them saith, There shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when yee shall see Abraham and Isaac and Iacob and all the Prophets in the kingdome of God. For as Cajetan upon the words addeth,Luk. 13.28. Cajet. Ibid. Nimis invidum torquet foelicitas aliorum, The happinesse of others, doth extreamely torment the envious.

Verse 5. This verse may be either referred to the verse before, or else considered as speaking of another sinfull vanity to which the Preacher passeth. If it be referred to the former verse, then the foole here is the envious man; for what greater foole then he, who not looking into his owne evills to bee grieved for them, is vexed with the good of another. He it is who foldeth his hands together, as a man discontented and heavy for the contentment which another hath and enjoyeth, and as studying and plotting with himselfe how he may bereave him of it; and as desiring to enwrap him within the traps of his envie as he enwrappeth his owne hands. He it is that eateth his owne flesh. Greg. Nazianz. in Oratione de Seip. For as Gregory Nazianzene speaketh, Invidia tabes est possessoris, virus & rubigo eorum qui ea exagitantur, Envie is the consumption of the possessour of it, the poyson and rust of them that are troubled with it. He eateth his own flesh, not sparing to hurt himselfe, that he may hurt him whom he envieth. To which purpose Lyra tels us a story, which is taken out of Aesop, That in a certaine City there were two men, the one very covetous, the other, very envious: the Ruler therefore of the City sent for them both, wishing them to desire what they would, and it should be granted them: adding withall, that he who did aske first, should have his asking granted, but the other should have the same doubled. Now hereupon the covetous man would not aske first, because he would have the request doubled: the envious man would not aske first, that his companion might not have more than himselfe. But the Ruler pressing them to aske,Lyra in c. 3. Geneseos. the envious man asked that one of his owne eyes might be pulled out, that so his companion might loose both of his eyes. But if this verse be considered as containing another sinfull vanity, to which the Preacher passeth, then the foole is the sloathfull person, the contrary to the laborious man of whom the former verse speaketh,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 19. and who Reprehendit operantem, & quasi solicitum arguit, ut ipse sit dissolutus, Blameth the painefull man, and reproveth him as too carefull, that himselfe may be carelesse, as Hugo de Sancto Victore speaketh. Now hee is called a
foole, because there is nothing that doth more dull and besot the understanding then idle and sluggish lazinesse. And indeed what a foole is he, who thinketh not of providing for the time to come, who hopeth to fill his hands with things needfull when they are folded together. He foldeth his hands, that they may not be reached out to worke, and as it were making a covenant with idlenesse and sloath. Hee eateth his owne flesh: for having made himselfe fat by ease, he consumeth himselfe afterwards by want and misery. He eateth his owne flesh, that is, he wasteth his estate to nothing, and brings himselfe to wofull distresse. Wherefore, when Ioseph having bought the land of the Egyptians, gave it unto them againe to dresse it, and to till it, paying unto Pharaoh a great tribute out of it:Ambros. de Offic. l. 1. c. 16. Saint Ambrose conceiveth, that Ioseph did it in compassion towards them: because the land of Egypt being of it selfe very fruitfull, that made them to be idle, the cause of much misery: whereas the tribut which they payd unto Pharaoh made them to be industrious, which kept them the freer from distresse.Ambrosi. Epistolarum. l. 4. Epist. 30. But Saint Ambrose giveth of this place another exposition, he saith, Stultus complexus est manus suas, & devoravit viscera sua, id est, corporalibus se implicavit negotiis, ut non invenerit vitam aeternam. The foole hath folded his hands, and devoured his own bowels, that is, he hath entangled himselfe in bodily affaires, so that he shall not find eternall life.Ambros. in Psal. 104. So in another place he saith, He hath embraced his hands, and devoured his owne bowels, Carnalia magis cogitans, quam spiritualia, thinking more of carnall things then of spirituall. To the same purpose another Ancient Writer expounding these words saith,Graecus in Catena Graeca. Glossa Ordinar. Otiosus actiones suas infames amplexatur & deglutit, The idle person embraceth his own infamous actions and swalloweth them downe. And so the ordinary Glosse expounding also this verse saith, He eateth his owne flesh, Carnalibus scilicet desideriis tabescens donec consumatur, namely, wasting away in carnall delights and lusts, untill hee bee consumed.

Verse 6. If we understand the former verse, as speaking of the envious person, this verse giveth me occasion to apprehend another sense in it. And by the folding of his hands together, we may understand, his scraping after worldly things, and his greedy clasping of them; by the eating of his owne flesh, we may understand his wasting of himselfe with care and vexation in the seeking and getting of them. For that is the nature of envie, it maketh men greedy after those things which they envie at in another, and giveth them no quietnesse by striving to exceed another in them. But the Preacher framing his owne conclusion according to this whereof he had last spoken, saith, that better is a handfull with quietnesse, &c. Where the comparison is not only in respect of one handfull and two, as shewing that one with quietnesse is better than two with trouble. But in the first place the Originall word signifieth the palme of the hand; in the second place it signifieth the whole hand closed together to hold any thing. So that the meaning also is, that a little, even no more than a man can hold in the hollow of his hand being
spread abroad, is better than much which a man holdeth in both his hands, bended and folded to hold as much as they can: if the little be with quietnesse, the much with trouble and vexation of spirit. But then the little must be a fulnesse also, it must bee a handfull, it must be plenitudo volae, a fulnesse of the hollow of the hand, as the Hebrew is, it must be fully so much as shall be sufficient for his needefull and convenient occasions that want and distresse do not disquiet a man. For it is sufficiency with quietnesse that is better then abundance with trouble. One hand serves to feed a man and it doth it better to his health, feeding on wholesome meate, then two hands glutting him with superfluous dainties, and breeding diseases in him. In Cassian it is set downe to be the tale of Abbot Macarius. That in a certaine City there was a Barber, who trimming men for 3. pence a peece had many customers, and found his estate to encrease well by it: but hearing that in a City a farre off, there was twelve pence given for trimming a man, he would needs goe thither: but when hee came and found it to bee so, going to buy provision of food, he found that to bee so deare, that his great hire for trimming was all spent in that, so that he had nothing to lay up for his old age, which made him to thinke himselfe better in the former City, though his hire was lesse.Cassian. Col. 24. c. 13.
Cassian applyeth it to quietnesse and trouble, though in another manner, then I have here occasion. But surely a little gotten and possessed where quietnesse layeth up the comfort of it, is better than much, Quod curae arrodunt, solicitudines imminuunt; the comfort whereof cares gnaw away, and troubles diminish. When God had made man, wee read that the next day he rested, and why is this set downe saith Anselme, Nisi per hoc vellet innuere, Anselm. in c. 4. Epist. ad Roman. quod illum post cujus orationem requievit, adrequiem fecit? But that the Spirit of God would shew unto us, that God made him for rest, after the making of whom God is said to have rested. It is rest and quietnesse, that is the proper gift of man by God bestowed upon him, and this it is which is the good of man. When Martha was busied to entertaine our Saviour, he blamed her for it: but as Theophylact Theophylact. noteth, Non hospitalitatem Dominus prohibet, sed turbationem & tumultum, It was not her hospitality that our Saviour disliked, but the trouble and tumult of her mind. This taketh away the comfort, the good of what any one hath, though there be much that might afford it. The Originall here is, Plenitudo volae quietis, The fulnesse of the hand of quietnesse: and let it be the hand of quietnesse that doth reach it unto us, though it be but a little, that will make it to be a fulnesse, and that little fulnesse it will make to be better then much fulnesse of the hands of trouble and vexation of spirit, (for so also the Originall is) that is, then much fulnesse which travell reacheth with one hand, and vexation of spirit with another hand. But the Septuagint doe adde unto the end of the former verse, Dicens, saying: and Tremellius puts into this verse, Inquit, saith he, as if these were the words of the foole in the former verse. And if wee take the foole to bee the sluggard, hee may be conceited to say so, as applauding
himselfe in his owne lazinesse, wherein he is at quiet, though he have but little, and therefore preferring himselfe before those, who though they get more, yet it is with more travell and vexation of spirit. Wherein wee may note how idlenesse would cloake it selfe with the commendation of quietnesse, and the idle person please himselfe with the comfort of wanting trouble, the like being the manner of other sinnes also,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 19, and of other sinners. But as Hugo de Sancto Victore noteth, the foole considereth himselfe, Quando pugillum habet & requiem habet, when he hath his handfull and hath rest also, hee considereth not that when his handfull is emptyed, his rest will be gone likewise. He now eateth of his handfull in quietnesse, and commendeth his lazinesse, not caring to fill his other hand by labour, that thereon he may feed, when the other is spent.
