Wherefore when his handfull is consumed, then he eateth his owne flesh, and with hunger is whipt for his lazinesse, the rest whereof hee preferred before dew carefulnesse. But I would not have so worthy a sentence to bee lost in the mouth of a foole; for surely better is a handfull, where quietnesse filleth the heart, then both the hands full, where travell and vexation overwhelme the spirit. And therefore to take it as the speech of Solomon himselfe, and yet to apply it unto the slothfull foole, we may conceive that as in the verse before, he sheweth his misery in his wasted estate; so here he sheweth his misery in a plentifull estate. For as much as then also idlenesse maketh his life to be tedious and irksome unto him. So that he who laboureth and getteth but a little, yet by labour hath a quiet mind free from a burdensome tediousnesse is to be preferred before him.

q.p: VER. 7. Then I returned, and I saw vanity under the Sunne.

VER. 8. There is one alone, and there is not a second, yea, hee hath neither child nor brother: yet is there no end of all his labour: neither is his eye satisfied with riches, neither saith hee, For whom doe I labour, and bereave my soule of good? this is also vanity, yea, it is a sore travell.

div.p:
Verse 7. Then I returned: this sheweth that the Preacher had made some interruption in his thoughts from the considering of vanities, by interposing that conclusion of solid verity, which the former verse containeth. Or if wee take the former verse to appertaine to the setting
forth of vanitie: then wee may imagine the Preachers thoughts to have been so fast in the depth of those vanities, as one amazed with the folly of them, that he was faine to recall himselfe, and to recover himselfe as it were, that he might passe unto another matter. And I saw vanitie: it is from vanitie that wee fall into iniquitie, and as St. Gregory speaketh; Dum per quaedam transitoria ducimur, Gregor. Moral. l. 10. c. 9.
in quibusdam noxiè ligamur, quum{que} mens incommutabilitatis statum non tenet, à seipsa defluens ad vitia prorumpit, While wee are caryed through transitory things, wee are held fast in sinfull things, and while the minde doth not stay setled in an unchangeablenesse, flying from it selfe it rusheth into wickednesse. The Preacher therefore in his method, having considered first the transitory vanitie of worldly things, from thence he passeth in this Chapter, to the iniquitie of the world, which is a vanitie also, for so he calleth it. And indeed this vanitie it was which made Belshazzar to weigh so light in the ballance: Dan. 5.27. it was his iniquitie which made him to be found wanting, wanting of any true worth, so that his kingdome and his life vanished so quickly from him. Wherefore one sayth well, Quisquiliae palearum, & atomi fere invisibiles majoris ponder is sunt quam peccata, The sweepings of chaffe, and the motes of the Sunne, almost invisible, are of more weight and substance then sinnes are. Yea, such a vanitie is iniquitie, that as the same Writer speaketh, Inter aliquid quantumvis parum, & nihil, nihil mediat nisi peccat • r, Between something though never so little, and that which is nothing, nothing doth mediate and middle, but a sinner onely, who is so neere to nothing, that he may well be accounted to be nothing. The Prophet David speaking of this vanitie, fayth, Psal. 69.2. I sink in deepe mire where there is no standing. Sinne is but a mire, and such is the vanitie of this mire, that there is no standing in it, nothing that is able to support it selfe, or any one that is in it. Gregory Nyssene writing upon these words in the Canticles, My head is filled with dew, Gregor. Nyssen. in Cantica. and my lockes with the drops of the night; supposeth Christ there to represent himselfe and his Church: and therefore by the head he understandeth Christ, by the lockes the servants of Christ, the Prophets and Apostles. Now the hayre being on, it is an ornament, but being cut off, what is esteemed more vaine? In like manner, the servants of God being joyned by obedience unto Christ their head, they are worthy of all honour, but being cut off by falling into sinne, what are they but vanitie, and of no value? Vnder the Sunne, that is, that it was a vanitie visible and plainly to be seene: for as St. Austin speaketh, Sub sole visibilia omnia, quicquid visibile non est, Augustin. in Psal. 38.
sub sole non est, Vnder the Sunne all things are visible: whatsoever is not visible, is not under the Sunne. Or else under the Sunne, as shewing this vanitie to be spread as farre as the Sunne shineth. Or else the Preacher here expresseth the vanitie of sinne to be under the Sunne, as shewing the unthankfulnesse of sinne, in that it is under the Sunne, by which God affordeth so many blessings unto men. For in the Hewrew 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth the Sunne, is taken from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth Ministrare
to minister, because it ministreth to the world so many benefits. That to let the Sunne therefore man sinneth against God, maketh him unworthy to live under the Sunne.

Verse 8. It is the sinfull vanitie of covetousnesse which here the Preacher setteth forth, and which as it is commonly joyned in men with oppression and envie, so here the Preacher joyneth them together. There is one alone: and it were well if there were one alone, but indeed there are many such in the world. And yet there is one alone, for every such a one would himselfe have all alone: he would be one alone, so that none else should have share or part in any thing with him. And there is not a second: this is the first thing which a covetous man desireth, to have no body neere him, no body that may either borrow or beg or get any thing from him. Wherefore St. Chrysostome calleth a covetous man,Chrysostom. in Matth. Homil. 81. Isa. 5.8. Ambros. lib. de Naboth. c. 3.
Communem omnium hominum hostem, The common enemy of all men. And when the Prophet Isaiah sayth, Woe to them that joyne house to house, field to field, untill there be no place; St. Ambrose sayth, Arguit eos inefficacis avaritiae: fugiunt enim cohabitare hominibus, & ideo excludunt vicinos, He reprooveth them of covetousnesse which hath no vertue of doing any thing, for they shun to dwell with men, and therefore they shut out their neighbours. But as Eucherius speaking of the Sodomites sayth,Eucherius ad c. 19. Geneseos. Clausas domos hospitibus ingressus est ignis ad perdendos peccatores, The houses that were shut against strangers fire entred, to destroy the wicked; so let such take heed, who shun to have any neere them, least that the fire of Gods wrath be a neighbour to them. St. Chrysostome therefore speaking of covetous persons, and comparing them to fruitlesse trees,Chrysost. in Acta. Homil. 21. sayth, Tales sunt qui solum considerant ea quae sua sunt; imo nec tales sunt, nam hi ad incendium parati sunt, illae etiam ad aedificium, Such are they who looke after those things onely which are their owne; yea rather they are not such: for they are prepared for burning, the other for building also. Yea, he hath neither childe nor brother: nec filium quem genuit, nec fratrem cum quo genitus est, Neither sonne whom he hath begotten, neither brother with whom he was begotten,Hugo de Sanct. Vict. in Ecclesiast. Homil. 19. as Hugo speaketh: yea, not any kinsman, for so the word brother in the Hebrew is taken. Himselfe is the successour of his ancestours, but himselfe hath none to succeed him. Yet is there no end of all his labours: no end wherein his labour ceaseth, no All of all his labour. Neither is his eye satisfied with riches: much lesse is his heart satisfied. His purse is filled, his chest is filled, his house is filled, yet his eye is not filled. Neither sayth he, for whom doe I labour? The Originall doth not expresse sayth he, but onely implyes it, because it is supposed to be, not an expresse speaking, but onely in the heart, according as the Chaldee Paraphrast hath it; Non dicit in corde suo, he sayth not in his heart, For whom doe I labour? And surely, Qui nec sibi laborat, nec alii cui laborat, nisi soli vitio cui servit? Hic enim soli vitio servitur, & non est alius affectus, qui excuset solicitudinem vanam, cui ignosci possit, nisi solus ille qui vitium genuit, He that laboureth neither for himselfe, nor any other, for
whom doth he labour, but for his vice whom he serveth? For here he is a servant to his vice onely, and there is no other affection, which may excuse his vaine carefulnesse, and which might get some pardon for him, but onely that greedy affection which brought forth his vice, as an ancient Writer speaketh. And bereave my soule of good: the Chaldee Paraphrase here addeth as an exposition of it,Chald. Para. Surgam & faciam ex eo cleemosynam, & laetabor in hoc saeculo cum filiis hominum, & in saeculo venturo cum justis, I will arise, and will doe works of charitie, and I will rejoyce in this world with the sonnes of men, and in the world to come with the righteous. This is the good whereof a covetous wretch bereaveth his soule. And plainely, were it not the minde of such a covetous wretch to desire no children, no brethren, no kinsfolke, he might finde enough. For as Olympiodorus Olympiodorus. speaketh, Qui desiderio illorum tenetur, quamvis naturâ nullos affines & consanguineos habeat, charitatem tamen habens, omnes homines quamvis externos, esse sibi filiorum loco putat & fratrum, He that hath a desire of them, although by nature he hath no kinsfolke, no kindred, yet having charitie he accompteth all men, although strangers, to be in the place of children and brethren unto him. Wherefore the Catena Graeca sayth, Si quis fratrem non habet, Catena Graeca. ille proculdubio spiritum adoptionis filiorum non accepit: et si quis pater non est, is porro improbus est, If there be any one who hath not a brother, no doubt he hath not received the Spirit of adoption of the Sonnes of God: and if any one be not a Father, what is he but a wicked man? This is also vanitie, yea it is a sore travaile: for he that laboureth and enjoyeth his labour, receiveth some fruit from it; and he that laboureth but doth not use those things, which by his labour he hath gotten, yet if he leave them to those whom he loveth, Aliquod emolumentum capit laboris sui, desiderium et votum dilectionis suae, He reapeth some profit of his labour, in the desire and contentment of his love, as one sayth. But to labour, and thereby neither to enjoy comfort to a mans selfe, nor to expresse love to others, what can be more vaine? What more sore travaile can there be? The ancient Fathers tooke such joy in meditating upon Christ, that wheresoever they could finde any occasion, their learned skill made the words of Scripture to sound this musick. This verse therefore St. Hierome tels us, that some did apply to Christ. For he is one, and there is not a second, because he came to save the world without any company: and though there be many Sonnes of God, many who by adoption are called his brethren, yet there was none worthy in this worke to be joyned with him. Of his labour in bearing our sinnes and in suffering for us, there is no end, mans understanding cannot reach to the end of the greatnesse of them. His eye is not satisfied with riches,Hieronym. in hunc vers. alwayes desiring and seeking our salvation: neither doth he say, for whom doe I labour? for though we despise his love, refuse his mercies, yet doth he still labour to bring us to repentance, to winne us to himselfe. And indeed I finde, that St. Ambrose speaking of these words, sayth, Quis est iste, nisi ille, de quo dictum est, magister vester unus est Christus? Who is
this, Mat. 23.8. Job 9.8. but he, of whom it is sayd, Your Master is one even Christ: of whom wee reade, Who alone spreadeth out the heavens. Hic non est secundus, quia primus est: huic non est secundus, quia unus est, He is not the second, because he is first: he hath not a second, because he is one alone.Ambros. de Instit. Virginitatis. c. 10.
Vnus est qui secundum non habet, quia unicus, solus sine peccato, solus sine adjutorio, He is one and hath not a second, because he alone onely is without sinne, he alone is without a helper.

q.p: VER. 9. Two are better then one; because they have a good reward for their labour.
VER. 10. For if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow: but woe to him that is alone when he falleth; for he hath not another to helpe him up.
VER. 11. Againe, if two lie together, then they have heate: but how can one be warme alone?
VER. 12. And if one prevaile against him, two shall withstand him: and a threefold cord is not quickly broken.

div.p:
Verse 9. From the wretchednesse of a covetous solitarinesse, the Preacher passeth to the commendation of a friendly societie. Now Aquinas tels us, Aquin. 2.2ae. Q. 188. Ar. 8. Id quod est solitarium debet esse sibi per se sufficiens, That which is solitary must be in it selfe sufficient for it selfe. But what is so? When man was created in his perfection, then it was not good for man to be alone, much lesse now, when his miseries are so great, his infirmities so many, in regard whereof he hath need of societie, that his miseries may be succoured, his infirmities supported. There is none sufficient in himselfe but God alone, and he is one and alone in his nature and essence, though in his subsistence there be a Trinitie of persons, that from himselfe he might commend a societie to us. The Philosopher therefore sayth,Aristoteles Politico. l. 1.
Ille qui non communicat aliis est bestia, aut Deus, He that doth not communicate with others, is either a beast in the savage wildnesse of his minde, or else a God in the transcendency of his nature. But to consider the Preachers words: two, sayth he, are better then one, but then, though two, they must be one likewise. So it was when God made first two, he made them so two, as that he made them one, and it is still the being one of two, that maketh two to be better then one. One they must be in peace, one in affection, one in a mutuall correspondency of the offices of societie, or else much better one by
himselfe alone, then multiplyed into quarrels and discontentments by another joyned with him. But in peace better are two then one every way. Better in Religion, for where two or three are gathered together, there is God, and what is better then to have God with us? Better in the study of knowledge, and therefore St. Hierome writing to Rasticus sayth, Mihi placet, ut habeas Sanctorum contubernium, Hieronym. ad Rust. Monachum. nec ipse te doceas, I like rather that thou shouldest use the familiaritie of religious men, and not teach thy selfe. Better in the affayres of the world, for what is better then to take the advise of others, in that which a man goeth about, so that as Synesius speaketh, Et omnium oculis videat, Synesius. l. de regno. et omnium auribus audiat, omniumque animis in unum consentientibus consilium capiat, He may see with the eyes of all, he may heare with the eares of all, and with the minds of all agreeing in one, he may resolve what to doe. Which yet is not so generally true, but that it is better sometimes to be alone: alone in the fervency of devotion, alone in the height of contemplation. But that wee may be alone for the better performance of these, wee must be alone not onely from the company of men, but also from the company of distracting thoughts, of worldly considerations. Otherwise as St. Gregory speaketh,Gregor. Moral. c. 30.
Quid prodest solitudo corporis, si non sit solitudo cordis? What availeth the solitarinesse of the body, if there be not a solitarinesse of the minde? But for the most part two are better then one, because they have a good reward for their labour. One would thinke the Preacher should have sayd, because they have a good reward for or in their societie. And indeed so doe the Septuagint reade it, Habent enim emolumentum societatis suae, for they have the benefit of their societie. The very societie it selfe being a good reward unto them. And therefore St. Austin sayth,Augustin. l. de Amicitia. Quid sit vera amicitia nondum novit, qui vult aliam esse mercedem quam ipsam, What true friendship is he doth not as yet know, who desireth any other reward then it selfe. But the originall word here used is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying trouble or labour: and therefore the Preacher seemeth to me here to shew, that in the getting and keeping of good societie, there is no little trouble and labour. For there is company enough to be had, but to get good company, good in it selfe, good for our occasions and dispositions is no easie matter. And when such company is gotten, he that will not endure trouble and labour through many occurrences that may and will fall out, shall soone loose it againe. But let this labour and trouble be endured, because it hath a good reward which from societie ariseth. And it may farther be noted, that it is sayd, Their labour, because both must labour for the establishing and continuing of a good societie, or else it will not be. Or else the meaning of the words may be, they have a good reward for their labour, that is, in societie they have a benefit, whereby to ease themselves in their labour. Or else thus, that by societie they have the benefit of enjoying the more sweetly and comfortably those things which they have gotten by their labour. Saint Hierome goeth on in applying these words
also unto Christ: Two sayth he, are better then one, Melius est enim habitantem in se habere Christum, quam solum patere insidiis adversantis, Hieronym. in hunc vers. For it is better to have Christ dwelling in us, then alone to lye open to the snares of the enemy. And no doubt, there is a reward in the labour of Christ and his servants. But as St. Ambrose sayth, Christus ergo laborat? Doth Christ therefore labour?Ambros. in haec verba, Cohortatione ad Cleric. Yes, sayth he, Laborat, sed in nobis, He laboureth, but in us. He laboureth by making us to labour, by supporting us in our labour: and he that laboureth in us, giveth a reward of our labour to us.

Verse 10. The Septuagint, St. Ambrose, St. Hierome, Pagnine, Arias Montanus, doe all reade it, Si ceciderit unus, If the one fall, as not supposing that both should fall together. But though if the one stand, the other fall, he that standeth will the better be able to helpe up him that is fallen; yet if they both fall, they may also helpe one the other in rising, and therein also the mutuall helpe of societie is the better set forth. Now the Hebrew is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Si ceciderint, If they fall, the one will lift up his fellow. It is not sayd he may doe it, but he will doe it: neither is it sayd the one will lift up the other, but the one will lift up his fellow. For if there be a fellowship of love, and true societie betweene them, he will doe what he can, he will not let his fellow lye being downe, but he will lift him up, and he will helpe up his fellow as well as himselfe, if they be both downe. And it is for this reason given by the Preacher,Hieronym. Epist. 12. ad Abigaum. that St. Hierome speaking of himselfe sayth, Vltra soleo bonorum appetere necessitudinem, & me eorum ingerere charitati, I use to seeke of my selfe the friendship of those that are good, and even to thrust my selfe into their affection. But woe to him that is alone when he falleth: woe because he falleth, but a double woe, because he falleth when he is alone. Perhaps he may not be alone, in respect of some other that thrusteth him downe, and that may be some ease unto his woe, in regard that not falling of himselfe, he may be able to helpe himselfe up againe. But howsoever, another joyned with him, would helpe him up much better, and therefore woe unto him because he hath not the helpe of such a one. The Originall is, woe unto him, because he hath not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
secundum, a second to helpe him up: and indeed this is the right use of a second. Not as the bloudy fashion of the world is, who seeking to kill their enemy, desire to kill their friend also. Saint Austin marking the woe here set downe, thereupon fayth,Augustin. de Amicit. At quae foelicitas, quae securitas, quae jucunditas est habere cum quo aeque audeas loqui ac tibi, cui confiteri non timeas, si quid deliqueris? But what happinesse, what securitie, what sweetnesse is it to have one with whom thou mayest talke as to thy selfe, to whom if thou hast offended thou mayest be bold to confesse thy fault? And as it is a great happinesse to have such a one to whom it may be done, so it is often a great neglect of happinesse not to doe it. For many times when the devill tempteth some one to wickednesse, the very discovering of it to another, is a present remedy for the preventing of it: So that, as Abbot Moyses speaketh
in Cassian, Teterrimus serpens, Cassian. Coll. 2. c. 10.
velut à tenebroso ac subterraneo specu virtute confessionis fubte actus in lucem, & traductus quodammodo & dehonestatus abscedit, The most fowle serpent, as it were drawne out into the light by the vertue of confession from his darke and subterranean hole, layd open as it were and shamed, departeth away. Saint Hierome still applyeth this unto our Saviour Christ, saying, Si unus ceciderit, Hieronym. in hunc vers. Christus eriget participem suum: sed vae ei qui quum ruerit Christum non habet erigentem, If one fall, Christ doth raise him up that is partaker of him; but woe to him, who when he falleth hath not Christ in him to raise him up againe. Saint Ambrose also applying this to Christ; first, he tels us that Christ, projecit se, non cecidit, Did not fall, but did cast himselfe downe;Ambros. in Cohortati. ad Clericos. he humbled himselfe, that he might make us to be his fellowes. And then he noteth that he is sayd to raise us up, not to be raised up, because when he was downe, he raised up himselfe. Saint Gregory more generally applying these words unto God, sayth, Solus est, Gregor. in cap. 10. 1. Regum. quia Deo relinquitur; hunc certe cadentem nullus erigit, He is alone who is forsaken of God: such a one when he falleth no one raiseth up. But safe is he that feareth God, because God is with him, and he is not alone. For as our Saviour Christ sayth, I am not alone, Iohn 8.16. but I and my Father that sent mee; so his servants are not alone, but he is with them to the end of the world: and then they shall be with him for evermore.

Verse 11. If two lye together in the cold night of sorrow and sadnesse, they have the heate of comfort, which mutually they yeeld one to the other, even by striking together the hard flints of their misery, by easing their hearts, while their tongues talke of their distresse, by supporting each other under their burdens, who cannot beare his owne, by doubling the light of counsell which may the better shew them the way of getting out. If two lye together in the prison of affliction, societie gives heate unto their cold irons, softens the hardnesse of them, and though it cannot breake them off, yet makes them to be borne with the more contentment. Not because it is an ease to misery to see another in misery, which is the miserable comfort of bad mindes; but because in each, the feeling of his owne misery makes them the more ready to afford comfort one to the other. It is not sayd, if two sleepe together, although the Septuagint, St. Ambrose, and St. Hierome doe reade it so, and although naturally sleeping together, as well as lying together bringeth heate: but it is sayd, If two lye together, and in a morall sense, which is here intended by the Preacher, it must be so taken: because if two lying together in misery, sleepe carelesly in it, the heate will be little, the comfort small which one shall have from the other. And farther, this lying together, must be also understood, in the bed of good will and affection, otherwise though lying together they may be farre enough from the heate of mutuall comfort. Wherefore Lyra tels us,Lyra in hunc vers. Per hoc intelligitur quietatio plurium in una dilectione, By this is understood the resting of many in one affection,
and love of charity. Now if two lye together in this bed of love, they will lye together in the same misery, although but one be in it, by a fellow feeling of it, and by his care to give the heate of comfort unto him that suffereth it. And thus to lye with another by a loving compassion in his misery and by a readinesse to afford the heate of comfort unto him,2 Cor. 11.29. who should not be forward? Saint Paul saith, who is weake, and I am not weake? Who is offended, and I burne not? Where Saint Chrysostome noteth,Chrys. Jbid. Non dicit, quis infirmatur, & ego non compatior, sed ego non infirmor, hoc est, tanquam ipsamet infirmitate circundatus ita excrucior & angor? He saith not who is weake, and I have not compassion on him, but who is weake, and I am not weake, that is, as if I were encompassed with the same infirmity, so am I pained, so troubled: And Anselme expounding the latter words,Ansel. Ibid. who is offended, and I burne not? that is saith he, Valde mens mea cruciatur igne amoris zeli; My mind is much tormented with the fire of the love of zeale. Here was heate indeed, ever burning heate which came from that lying together whereof the Preacher speaks. But where is another such to be found? The Preacher speaks but of two lying together, and they are very few, who do thus lye together in the bed of charity. Eusebius Eusebius. tels us that a Poppy is the embleme of a City. Now a Poppy is like unto a Pompegranate having many graines within it: but the difference is, that in a Pomegranate the graines are fastned together, whereas in the Poppy they are loose the one from the other. This therefore it is which maketh a Poppy to bee the embleme of a City, because the affections of men are severed and divided, and they lye not together to cause a heate of consolation the one to the other. But not to understand the Preacher of misery only, it is true of prosperity likewise, and a lying together in love doth make the heate of joy therein to bee the greater. It is true also of the heate of devotion, and the society of others doth make that heate to burne by much the stronger.Seneca in Epist. 96.
Seneca speaking of the conversation of good men saith, Frequenter audiri & aspici frequenter, imo occursus ipse bonorum juvat, & est aliquid quod ex magno viro vel tacente proficias. Often to bee heard, and often to be seene, yea the very meeting with good men furthereth, and there is some profit to be gotten from a worthy man even holding his peace. Wherefore if they lye together, if they continue much together, how great a heate of goodnesse will be stirred up in them? The lying together of the dead body of one, with the bones of the Prophet Elisha, wrought a miracle, and gave life unto it: and surely the benefits of lying together in friendly love are even miraculous, by giving the heate of life to sorrow, the heate of a religious life to them, who are dead in sinne. But how can one be warme alone? Surely nothing so well, nothing so easily. Yea, saith Lyra, Lyra in hunc versum. Greg. Mag. Hieronym. in hunc vers. how can one alone shew the heate of charity to be in him? For as Saint Gregory speaketh, Charitas semper in alterum tendit, ut Charitas esse posset, Charity alwayes tendeth towards another, that it may be charity. Saint Hierome applying still this verse to Christ, saith, Si morte
dissolutus quis fuerit, & secum Christum habuerit, calefactus & vivificatus citius reviviscet, If any one shall be dissolved by death, and lye in his grave, yet if hee have Christ with him, he shall be warmed, and being quickned shall quickly live againe. Saint Ambrose saith,Amb. Cohortatione ad Clericos. Commortui sumus Christo, & ideo onvivimus: Christus nobis commortuus est, ut nos calefaceret, we are dead with Christ, and therefore doe we live with him: Christ is dead with us that he might heate us: Et qui in Christo moritur per Christum calefactus vitae & resurrectionis vaporem accipit, And hee that dyeth in Christ, being warmed by Christ, receiveth the vapour of life and resurrection. But as Saint Hierome adddeth,Hieronym. Ibid. Nisi Christus nobiscum dormierit & in morte quieverit, calorem aeternae vitae acoipere non valemus, Vnlesse Christ doe sleepe, and rest in death with us, we shall never be able to receave the heate of eternall life.

Verse 12. There are three things which concerne the life of man in this world, a weakenesse in falling, a misery in lying, a strength in standing, and in all these the Preacher sheweth the benefit of society. Wherefore having already shewed it in the two former here he shewes it in the last. And here he shewes two things, first how by society an enemy is withstood and resisted, secondly how by society he is vanquished and lead captive as bound with a threefold cord. First, then hee saith, And if one prevaile against him; that is, if one prevaile against one as being too strong for him, two shall withstand him. For as the Proverb is, Ne Hercules contra duos, The strength of Hercules is not able to prevaile against two united in their strength. When the Red Sea was divided, the Aegyptians as not fearing either part by it selfe, pressed after the Israelites, as insulting over the weakenesse of the waters; but when the two sides meeting in society joyned their strength, how soone were the Aegyptians destroyed?Tertull. advers. Marcion. l. 4. So that as Tertullian speaketh Egyptium exercitum concordia undarum obruit, the concord of the waters overwhelmed the Egyptian army. And surely though the weakenesse of one may bee as water in resisting another, yet another though feeble as water also being joyned to him, they may bee able to withstand a great might. And because there is one common enemy of all, that is the devill, who seeketh especially to fight in diuels, and by single combat against us, as knowing our weakenesse, and his owne advantage therein, let it be the care of every one by the society of counsell, and of prayer to withstand him. Two doe often resist him, when one cannot, and a threefold cord is not easily broken. Much may be noted from the sacred Scriptures of the mystery of three. And upon these words Saint Ambrose saith, Vt cognoscas secundum mysterium dictum, Ambr. Cohorta. ad Clericos. non secundum numerum, Optimi duo super unum, subjecit mysticum, & spartum triplex non facile rumpitur, That thou mayest know that it is spoken in a mystery, not for the number, Two are better than one, hee addeth a a mysticall thing, A threefold cord is not soone broken, Tria enim non composita non rumpuntur, for three which are not compounded, are not broken, and the Trinity which is of an uncompounded nature, cannot
be divided, because God who is one and simple is whatsoever is. But not to dive beyond the bottome of the words, if in the number three wee will note a mystery, the strength of it, is that, to which the words point, Dan. 3.17. and wee may remember the three children united in Gods worship to have beene so strong, that they withstood the force of the fiery furnace though made exceeding hot.Zeno. Ser. 4. de tribus pueris. Whereupon Zeno saith, Sacramento Trinitatis tam potentis elementi subacta est natura: qui putabantur incendio extingui, emicant beatiores incensi; By the mystery of the Trinity was the might of that powerfull element subdued: they whom the Chaldeans thought by the fire to have extinguished appeare in the fire more glorious then before. But the plainer exposition is that which Lyra gives,Lyra in hunc vers. Quanto plures & boni in amicitia conjuncti sunt, tanto status eorum melioratur, By how many they are, the more and good, which are joyned in society, by so much is their condition the better. And indeed such is the force of many, that it is able to withstand the power of Gods provoked wrath. Wherefore when God saith, should not I spare Niniveh that great City, wherein are more than sixescore thousand persons?Chrys. Hom. 3. de Incompreh. Dei natura. Saint Chrysostome speaking of it, saith, Non sine re, amplum populi numerum ibi proposuit, sed ut intelligas plurimùm eam pollere orationem quae cum consensu agitur & jugi concordiâ, It is not to no end, that God setteth downe there the great number of the people, but that thou mayest understand, that prayer to bee very prevalent, which is sent forth with consent, and with the continuall concord of many people.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome applying these words likewise unto Christ, saith, Et si adversus hominem robustior inexpugnando diabolus extiterit: stabit homo, stabit & Christus pro homine suo, pro sodali suo, And if the Devill assaulting man as stronger shall prevaile against him; man shall stand, and Christ shall stand for his man, for his fellow. But if I might have leave in this manner to apply this passage of Scripture: in the first place, where man is fallen through the weakenesse of our first Parents, we may apprehend Christ raising him up: in the second place where man lyeth in the misery which sinne hath brought upon him, we may apprehend God the Holy Ghost warning and comforting him, with spirituall graces: in the third place, where we have the strength of man withstanding his enemies, we may apprehend the glorious Trinity, placing and establishing man in glory where no enemy shall be able to hurt him.

q.p: VER. 13. Better is a poore and a wise child, then an old and foolish King, who will no more be admonished.
VER. 14. For out of prison hee commeth to reigne, whereas also he that is borne in his kingdome becommeth poore.
VER. 15. I considered all the living which walke under the Sunne, with the second child that shall stand up in his stead.
VER. 16. There is no end of all the people, even of all that have beene before them: they also that come after shall not rejoyce in him: surely this also is vanity and vexation of spirit.

div.p:
Verse 13. The Preacher having shewed the good of society in respect of private persons, now shewes it in respect of a publike person; not in regard of his authority and government, but in respect of the carefull manner of his governing: For which it is needfull that hee should have the helpfull society of others in counsell and advise: and better is one though meane that followes counsell, then another though never so great that is alone in the wilfulnesse of his owne wayes. In this sense therefore to consider the Preachers words. Great is the precedency and excellency of age above childhood:Clemens Alexand. Paedag. l. 3. c. 3. Wherefore Clemens Alexandrinus saith, Quo magis homo festinat ad finem, tanto est vere venerabilior, ut qui Deum solum habeat se seniorem. Nam ille quo{que} est aeternus senex, qui est omnibus quae sunt antiquior, By how much man draweth neare to his end, by so much he is truly more venerable, as having God alone elder then himselfe. For hee is also the eternall old one, who is elder then all things that are. Great is the preeminency of a King above a poore man; and yet better is a poore and wise child, wise in being ready to heare and receive instruction and counsell, wise in being carefull to follow it, for that is the proper wisdome of a child. And well doth the Preacher joyne poverty with wisdome, for as the Philosopher speaketh, Paupertas sapientiae reparatrix, Poverty is the repairer of wisdome, in that it puts men to it, and makes them more warily and diligently to looke into things. And indeed they are commonly the poorer children that are wise in this kind; the richer, either in pride not
suffering themselves, or by the folly of their parents, not being suffered to be ordered by counsell and instruction: and therefore Lyra sayth, Delitiosè nutriri, Lyra in hunc versum. et in delitiis vivere, impedit acquisitionem sapientiae, To be bred delicately, and to live in pleasures, doth hinder the getting of wisedome. Then an old foolish King: to be old is to adde honour and authoritie to a King; to be a King, is to adde honour and authoritie to old age: to be a foolish King, is to deprive both of their honour and authoritie. To be old, is a blessing of nature; to be a King, is a prerogative of favour; to be a foolish King, is to be unworthy of both. To be old, is to be Gods image; to be a King, is to be Gods substitute; to be a foolish King, is to be the Devils vassall. Who will no more be admonished: to refuse admonition, is in none a greater folly, than in a King, because in none it is more pernicious, to none more dangerous: but to be growne old in wilfull stubbornnesse, and selfe-conceited perversenesse, as well as in yeares, so that he will no more be admonished, and not onely not follow it, but not heare it, as it is the extremitie of folly, so it is the shame of honour, and maketh a poore wise childe better, better worthy of it. The Originall is, Qui nescit admoneri adhuc, Who knoweth not to be admonished as yet; who hath not as yet learned, though growne old, to be admonished; who hath not as yet learned the good of it in the affayres of a King. Surely such a one must needs be worse then a childe, who is so many yeares before him in the learning of it; worse then a poore childe, who though never so poore, by this is richer then such a King. Act. 1.15. & 23. When St. Peter stood up in the middest of the Disciples, and moved them to appoint, that two might be named, out of whom one might be chosen in the roome of Iudas: Saint Chrysostome asketh,Chrysostom. Homil. 3. in Acta. Cur non solus à Christo postulavit, ut ipse daret aliquem substituendum? Why he did not alone pray unto Christ, that himselfe would assigne one to succeed? The answer which he giveth is, Iam Petrus erat seipso factus melior, Now Peter was made even better himselfe in taking the assistance of others. And surely as it makes a King even more then a King, to be willing to be admonished; so it makes him lesse then a poore wise childe to refuse it.Exod. 18.24. Orig. in 18. Exod. Origen therefore speaking of Moyses embracing the counsell of his Father in Law, sayth, Accepit consilium inferioris ut formam humilitatis principibus populorum daret, He received the counsell of an inferiour, that he might leave to Princes over people, a patterne of humilitie. Amalesnentha Queene of Italy being deprived of her sonne and of her husband, and joyning her brother in the Kingdome with her, thus writeth of it, to the Senate of Rome; Exultate, Cassiodorus. var. l. 10. var. 3.
et factum nostrum supernis commendate virtutibus. Nihil reprehensibile desideramus agere, quae cum consilio alterius cuncta delegimus ordinare, Rejoyce, and commend our action to the divine powers. Wee desire to doe nothing that shall deserve reproofe, who have chosen to order all things with the counsell of another. For there is nothing doth make the actions of any to deserve reproofe so much, as when themselves in their actions refuse to be reprooved; at leastwise by counsell, a reproofe not unfit for Kings.

Verse 14. The Septuagint and Saint Hierome doe reade the end of the former verse, Qui nescit providere in posterum, Who knoweth not to provide for the time to come. And St. Hierome tels us that Symmachus did reade it, Qui nescit praecavere vicissitudinem, Who knoweth not how to prevent the interchangeable course of things. Whereupon Gregorius Thaumaturgus expounding this verse, sayth, That a poore and wise childe, is better then an old King and foolish;Gregor. Ponti Episc. in hunc vers. Cui in mentem non venit, fieri posse, ut quispiam ex carcere & ergastulo ad regni gubernacula constituatur, ipse autem postea ab iniquo principatu exturbetur, Into whose mind it commeth not, that it may come to passe, that from prison and bonds, some one may be set upon the throne of a Kingdome, and that himselfe may be throwne downe from his wicked command. And surely for an old King, who having lived long in this world must needs have seene the many changes of it, for him not to thinke of it, cannot but proove him foolish, and may soone make him to finde that which he doth not thinke of. For as St. Ambrose speaketh, Somnus est hîc vivendi usus, Ambros. Epist. c. 3, Epist. 19.
in quo diversae commutationum vices tanquam ebriae, & nihil solidum, nihil firmum, sed vacuae rerum species dispersae & circumfusae teneri videntur, & non tenentur, The use of living here is but a sleepe, in which there are diverse, and as it were drunken changes of things, nothing is solid, nothing firme, but the emptie shadowes of things dispersed and scattered up and downe, doe seeme to be held fast, when they are not held. But to view the Preachers words as here we finde them. For out of prison: the Hebrew is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
E domo vinctorum, From the house of them that are bound, that is, as it may be taken from a small homely cottage, wherein the dwellers are bound and shut up together: or else as it may be also taken, from some strict Schoole wherein children are tyed hard to good orders, and held close to severe discipline: or else we may take it, from the prison of povertie, from the house of them who are tyed and bound with many strayts, many distresses. He commeth to reigne: either to reigne as a King, or to be great in a Kingdome. And here for example,Ambros. de Ioseph. Patriarcha. c. 21. wee may well take Ioseph to be this poore wise childe. For that he was a wise childe his Fathers love shewed, who therein as St. Ambrose speaketh, Non tam filium pater praetulisse videatur, quam Propheta mysterium, May seeme not so much as a Father to have preferred his sonne before his other brethren, as a Prophet rather to have preferred a mystery, in respect of that to which he foresaw the wisedome of his sonne would bring himselfe. But that he was a poore childe also, the malice of his brethren, who sold him for a captive made to be true. The rest God performed for him, and when he was in prison bringing him to the King of Aegypt, out of prison brought him to be the next in greatnesse in the Kingdome. Yea, while he was in prison, what was he but even then a King?Ambros. Ibid. Saint Ambrose comparing Ioseph in bondage, with Pharaoh on his throne, sayth, Nonne videtur tibi iste in servitute dominari, ille autem in libertate servire? Serviebat Ioseph, regnabat Pharaoh; beatior hujus servitus, quam regnum illius,
Doth not the one seeme unto thee in his servitude to reigne, the other in his freedome to serve? Ioseph is in bondage, Pharaoh reigneth: more blessed is his bondage, then the others Kingdome. Whereas he also that is borne in his Kingdome, borne in the largenesse, in the plentie, in the freedome, in the greatnesse of a Kings estate, and hath the right of inheritance unto it, becommeth poore: for every one is not borne to that, in which he is borne, and he that is poore in understanding, though never so rich,Lyra in hunc versum. may easily become poore in estate also. Here we may take Zedekiah, as Lyra doth, for an example of it, who being borne the Sonne of a King, and comming also to sit upon the throne of the Kingdome, for the folly of his wickednesse became poore, a poore blind man, a poore fettered captive. Before I leave this verse, let mee also shew the blindnesse of the Church of Rome; whose manner being to bring the Scripture to their Religion, not fo fetch their Religion from the Scripture, Cogunt hoc videri in Scriptura dictum, quod ante lectionem praesumpserunt credendum, Doe even force that to seeme to be spoken in the Scripture, which before they read they have presumed that it must be beleeved, as Hilarius Hilarius. speaketh. Thus doth one of them alledge this verse to proove Purgatory: shewing himselfe no lesse foolish therein, then the foolish King here spoken of: and better is a poore wise childe that receiveth instruction, then such an old Master that perverteth knowledge.

Verse 15. The Preacher drawing his thoughts unto a pause, reduceth them to that which is his generall ayme in this booke, the vanitie of humane worldly things: and having in the verse before spoken of a King made poore, he setteth downe in this verse the manner how sometimes it comes to passe: namely, by the defection of his people from him, by the rebellion of his Sonne against him. I have considered, sayth the Preacher: it was a thing which came into the thoughts of King Solomon, though it come not into the thoughts of a foolish King. All the living which walke under the Sunne; that is, the common people; for living and walking under the Sunne is a thing common unto all; and that he sayth, all the living is but to expresse the great number and multitude of them. With the second childe, that is, sayth Lyra, Cum filio regis, qui est secundus ab eo, eò quòd regnaturus est post eum, With the Sonne of the King, who is the second from him, because he is to reigne after him.Lyra in hunc vers. And with him the people are sayd to be, because sayth Lyra, Accidit quod senescente rege, populus & maxime juvenes adhaerent filio ejus, qui pro eo est regnaturus, & aliquando regnum usurpat sibi vivente patre, It commeth to passe, that the King growing old, the people and especially the younger men (whom wee may conceive to be more especially meant here by the Preacher, when he sayth, living and walking under the Sunne, because they are most lively, they are most stirring) doe adhere and cleave to his Sonne who is to reigne after him, and sometimes he usurpeth the Kingdome, his Father being alive. This it was which Herod feared, whom Egesippus maketh to
speake thus, Si supra modum quis liberos meos excolat, reus est mihi etiam pro liberis meis, quibus author est prolapsionis: nimius enim cultus audaciae sumptus est. Nunquid invideo liberis meís? Absit; sed malo eos minus cum gratia posse, quam plurimum cum seditione. Quod enim superbiae vel rapinae est cito labitur, quod gratiae diu tenetur, If any one respect my children more then is fitting, he wrongeth me in my childrens hurt, to whom he is the cause of falling: for too much respect is the encouragement of boldnesse. What then? Doe I envie my children? No way.Egesippus. l. 1 de Excid. Hierusal. c. 39. But I had rather that they should be able to doe lesse with favour, then much with sedition. For that which commeth from pride or violence soone passeth away; but that which commeth from favour continueth long. And that this is the meaning of the place, Tremellius is so confident, as that he makes it the text in his translation, saying, Adjungentes se puero illi secundo, Ioyning themselves to the childe which is second unto him: or as the French translation also hath it, Suivre le parte de l'enfant second apres lui, to follow the partie of the childe that is second after him. But yet I hope I shall not offend to set downe mine apprehension of the Preachers meaning: who recalling his thoughts to his principall scope, the vanitie of worldly things, and having spoken immediately before of a King, considereth here the vanitie of Kings. And first setting forth the glory of them, he expresseth a King under the Embleme of the Sunne, shewing that as the Sunne giveth life to all things, and motion to the course of things; so the King giveth life to the estates of his subjects, and motion to the proceeding of their affayres: so that living and walking under the Sunne shine of his government, they flourish in their wayes. And indeed a King should be as the Sunne, cherishing and comforting his people. Wherefore when the lengthning of the life of Hezekiah was confirmed unto him by the going backe of the Sunne in the diall of Ahaz; Augustin. de mirabil. l. 2. c. 28. Saint Austin sayth (if the booke be St. Austins) Convenienter tale signum regi in mortis expectatione posito aptissimum evenit, quod Dominus per solem fieri disposuit, Conveniently did such a most fit signe fall out to the King being neare unto death, that God did order it by the Sunne to be done: namely, as I conceive to teach the King, that he should be in his life as the Sunne to his people. With the second childe: that is, he considered together with the King shining as the Sunne in his Kingdome, his second child, that is, his grand-childe established also in the Kingdome, and the succession of it continued so long, so that his grand-child shall stand up in his stead. By which phrase we may note, that to be a King, is but to stand up above the rest, whereby he is higher then they are: as it is sayd of Saul, that when he stood among the people,1 Sam. 10.23. he was higher then any of the people from the shoulders and upward. He standeth up on high, but yet at length another doth stand up in his stead: for himselfe to stand will not alwayes last. Or else we may conceive the Preacher to use this phrase, because he that succeedeth, commeth to stand in his Kingdome, by the fall of him that went before. I finde the ancient
Fathers to apply much this passage unto Christ. Saint Ambrose seemeth to be resolved that Christ is meant in this verse: and therefore he sayth, Hic est juvenis secundus, ut dicit Ecclesiastes, vidi universos qui vivunt &c. De Christo dictum liquet, He is the second young man, as the Preacher speaketh, I saw all the living &c: it is manifest that it is spoken of Christ. Ambrosius de Instit. virginis. c. 12. And adding farther, he sayth, Primus est secundum dignitatem ante quem nullus; secundus autem secundum carnem quia post Adam. Ego plus dico, non solum secundum lego, sed etiam novissimum. Ipse est & primus & novissimus. Qui primus est, propter nos se novissimum fecit. Primus quia per ipsum omnia: novissimus quia per ipsum resurrectio, He is the first according to his dignitie, before whom none is; but the second according to the flesh, because the second Adam. I say more, I reade, that he is not onely the second, but the last. He that is first, for us made himselfe the last. The first he is, by whom are all things, the last, because by him shall be the resurrection of all men.

Tremellius in hunc vers. Verse 16. There is no end of all the people: that is, sayth Tremellius, Populares et subditos nunquam sua sorte contentos esse, ac ne sapienti quidem regi plurimum acquiescere: propterea non esse mirandum, si male insipientibus accidat, People and subjects never to be contented with their condition; and not to rest long pleased even with a wise King, and therefore to be no mervaile, if that it fall out amisse to them who are foolish. But howsoever, a foule shame it is unto them, a foule sinne in them. The French translation putteth this sense into the Text, saying, N'on point trouve en qui s'arrester, They have found none in whom to rest, taking the Originall word, which signifieth an end to import the end of rest. But to follow rather the more naturall signification of the word: I conceive the Preacher who hath before shewed the glory of a King in his owne happinesse, and in the succession of his posteritie, here to shew it in the multitude of his people, as if there were no end of the number of them, that being a thing whereby in Scripture the greatnesse of a King is often set forth. And this being set downe here as the greatnesse of the Father, childe, and grand-childe, it is sayd, There is no end of all the people, even of all that have been before them. The Hebrew is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ad facies eorum, before their faces, as not signifying so much their being before in time, as rather their being with them and under them in their severall times. But after this greatnesse, what followes? They also that come after shall not rejoyce in him: Lyra in hunc versum. that is, sayth Lyra, Isto filio senescente parum curabunt de eo, sed magis adhaerebunt filio ejus, ut dictum est, When that sonne is growne old, they that are young, and so are likely to continue after him, will care little for him, but rather will sticke unto his sonne,Theodoret. Quaest. 46. in Daniel. as before is sayd. For as Theodoret writeth, observing how Baasha slew the house of Ieroboam, and how Zimri slew the sonne of Baasha, Per haec docemur nos, quod eos qui vitam agunt in sceleribus & flagitiis, Deus per se invicem punit, & sceleratum tradit sceleratiori, ijs utens tanquam quibusdam lictoribus, By these things wee are taught that God doth punish them, who lead their lives in sinne and wickednesse
by one the other, delivering up him that is wicked to him that is more wicked, and making use of them as executioners of his justice. But if it shall not be thought amisse to take the exposition which I have given of the former verse, wee may here understand the cutting off of that race and them from the Kingdome, so that the people shall no longer rejoyce in their prosperitie, and under the prosperitie of that succession. And because the Preacher useth this phrase, Rejoyce in him, perhaps it may imply the departing of the people in discontent from him, in regard of his hard usage, whereby he deprived the people of their joy under him. For so it was with the Preachers sonne Rehoboam, who being as St. Basil speaketh, Aetate juvenis, mentis prudentiâ adhuc junior, Basilius Concio: de humilitate. populo mitius imperium urgenti graviter minatus est, & per minas regnum amisit: per quas regaliorem se fore sperabat, per eas depositus à dignitate quam habebat, Young in yeares, and more young in the wisedome of his mind, answered roughly to the people that sought a milder government from him, and by his rough answere lost his Kingdome: being by those meanes deposed from the honour he had, by which he thought to make himselfe more Kingly. Surely this is also vanitie and vexation of Spirit: this, even this greatnesse of glory as the Sunne, this firmenesse of succession, this numberlesse multitude of people, even this is vanitie, vanishing all away to him that did enjoy it; and sometimes vanishing away by the multitude of the people, which was a part of the glory of it. This is vexation of spirit, for what greater vexation then the losse of a Kingdome? There is vexation in the possessing and establishing of it, but to loose it being possessed and established, is a vexation surely. The Fathers doe here also looke upon Christ: Saint Ambrose sayth, Illud quoque verè Christo convenit soli, quod addidit: Ambros. de Instit. virginis. c. 12.
Non est finis omni populo ejus, quia Christi populus innumerabilis finem non habet, That also which he addeth agreeth truely unto Christ onely, There is no end of all his people: for the innumerable people of Christ hath no end. Johannis 14. Saint Hierome also sayth, Praesago spiritu vidit Ecclesiastes, vidit omnes viventes qui possunt adolescentis participes esse, dicentis ego sum vita, Hieronym. in hunc vers. vetere stulto rege dimisso sequi Christum, The Preacher by a Propheticall spirit, saw all the living who can be partakers of the young man that sayth, I am life, to follow Christ, the old foolish King (that is the devill) being forsaken.

q.p: VER. 1. Keepe thy foote when thou goest to the house of God, and be more ready to heare, then to give the sacrifice of fooles: for they consider not that they doe evill.
VER. 2. Be not rash with thy mouth, and let not thine heart be hasty to utter any thing before God: for God is in heaven, and thou upon earth, therefore let thy words be few.
VER. 3. For a dreame commeth through the multitude of businesse, and a fooles voyce is knowne by multitude of words.

div.p:
Verse 1. THE Preacher having spoken of the sinfull vanities of men in themselves, and of their sinfull vanities towards other men; now commeth to speake of the sinfull vanities of men towards God: the vanitie of mans heart making Religion it selfe to be vaine, which in it selfe is the perfection of a man. And this he handleth as a Preacher more especially, shewing what is to be done, what not to be done in it, rather then setting forth the vanitie of it. Keepe thy foote: for the foote of man is weake in this case, and if it be not well kept, will soone slip aside. Keepe thy foote from the durt of worldly matters, from the mire of sinne and vice. This Pythagoras taught, when he sayth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , have not thy shooes on when thou sacrificest and worshippest, and which he tooke from the Scriptures, Exod. 3.5. it being sayd to Moyses, Put off thy shooes from thy feete, for the place where thou standest is holy ground. Keepe thy
foote, and let not irreligious carelesnesse keepe it back from hastning unto Gods house: bee there with the first, be there at the beginning of divine service. Cassian tels us, that in the Ancient times of the Church,Cassian. Instit. l. 3. c. 7. he that did not come to prayers, Priusquam Psalmus coeptus finiretur, before the first Psalme was ended, he did not dare to enter into the house of prayer, but standing at the dore untill the rest came out, Submissa in terram poenitentia negligentiae suae vel tarditatis impetrabat veniam, By a submisse repentance even downe to the earth, obtained pardon for his tardy negligence. Keepe thy foote, and when thou art in Gods house, keepe it there untill all the service of God be ended. Diverse of the Ancient Councels have set downe censures for them,Concil. Agathens. Can. 47. who were too forward to depart from Gods house. In generall, keepe thy foote as cleane as thou canst. In the law, the Priests were commanded to wash the inwards and the feete in water; and this saith Philo, Philo de Victimis. was done 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 surely not without a mystery, as to teach us to keepe our feete cleane when wee goe to Gods service. Keepe thy foote: the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and Tremellius reads it not without cause utrum{que} pedem tuum, both of thy feete, the foote of thy body, and the foote of thy soule. The foote of thy body, and let thy foote be bowed, in an humble and decent and devout posture: the foote of thy soule, that is either thy senses, for by them the soule goeth as it were forth from it selfe, and let them not gad, but be setled and fixed in a solemne modesty: or else taking the feete of the soule for the affections, by which the saile is caryed many wayes, let them be composed and ordered to the advancement of Gods service. Keepe thy foote when thou goest: when thou goest is the time of keeping thy foote, for when thou sittest or standest, the danger of hurt being lesse, the care of keeping it need not to be so great. But when thou goest keepe it, for the way is very slippery, and thou wilt quickly get a fall, if thy care be not the more: the way is very rough, and thou wilt never be able to goe on well, unlesse thy diligence bee watchfull. Let thy feete therefore be shod with the preparation of the Gospell of peace: Ephes. 6.15. be thou well prepared for the worke which thou goest about, when thou goest to the house of God. God hath reserved of men some for himselfe, as his Ministers, of things some for himselfe, as his tithes; of times some for himselfe, as his holy dayes; of places some for himselfe, as his houses, his Churches, his Oratories,Augustin. Epist. 121. ad Probam. and in them as St. Austin speakketh, Praeter Dei cultum penitus nihil agatur, ut nomini huic et opera jugiter impensa concordent, Besides the worship of God, let nothing at all be done, that with the name, the works that are continually done in them may duely agree. That which the Preacher here cals Gods house, the ancient Christian Church did sometimes call Dominicum, the Lords house; as when St. Cyprian sayth, In dominicum sine sacrificio venis? Cyprian. lib. de Operib. et eleemos. Dost thou come into the Lords house without a sacrifice? In Greeke it was also called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , signifying the same that the former name doth, from whence our English name Church is derived;Concilium Laodicen. c. 28. as in the Councell of Laodicea,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , The feasts of love must
not be made in the houses of the Lord. Sometimes the ancient Church did call it Basilicam, Amalarius. l. 3. de Offic. c. 4. the Kings house, because there as Amalarius speaketh, Regi omnium Deo, cultus et sacrificia offeruntur, To God the King of all, worship and sacrifices are offered. And indeed, what is it but the palace of the Great King? Gen. 28.16. Iacob as one troubled sayth, Surely the Lord is in this place, and I knew it not, as implying what he would have done in a holy reverence, if he had knowne it. But how many are there, that goe to Gods house, and know it to be Gods house, and yet carying themselves there in an irreligious manner, are not onely displeasing to God, but troublesome to others that are present with them? It were better if such would keepe their feete from going thither. And be more readie to heare. The Originall word translated ready, is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
propinquum, signifying a neerenesse, either in respect of time or place, as shewing us that being in the place of hearing God, wee should there heare him diligently, and that the time of hearing God being then, we should then harken to him carefully. Wherefore the Septuagint and St. Hierome doe reade it, Appropinqua ut audias, Draw nigh that thou mayest heare. Indeed to make up the sense in the Originall, there is something to be added. Our Translation addeth, Be thou: but as I conceive, we may not amisse repeate the beginning of the verse, and say, Keepe thy foote neere that thou mayest heare, that is, listen well and be continually attentive to heare: yea keepe thy foote neere to heare, and let that heare as well as thine eare, that is, walke carefully according as thou art taught, heare diligently what thou art to doe, and doe readily what thou hearest: for this also the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used signifieth. The French translation maketh up the sense thus; Approche-toy, draw thou neere to heare. When thou goest to Gods house, let thy comming thither be, let thy drawing so neare to God be to this end, namely, to heare him, to heare him with obedience, rather then to offer the sacrifice of fooles. The sacrifice of fooles is the outward formalitie of Religion; for what is it but the part of a foole, to thinke that God is pleased with shews of godlinesse? The Iewes that offered sacrifices to God, and did not make themselves a sacrifice of God, were but fooles: and they that goe to Church, and there stay untill divine service be ended, but doe not serve God in their lives, are very fooles likewise. For as St. Hierome speaketh,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Non ingredi in domum Dei, sed sine offensione ingredi laudis est, Not to enter into Gods house, but to enter in without offence is praise-worthy. For they consider not that they doe evill: they please themselves as if they had done very well; but though it be a sacrifice offered to God, a service done to God, they doe not please him. And it is so farre from being well done, that it is evill in his sight, and will be evill to them in their condemnation.

Verse 2. From hearing in Religion the Preacher passeth unto speaking; and he may be understood here either of speaking of God, or else of speaking to God.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome thinketh it best to understand the Preacher of a speaking of God, and that we are here forbidden, either
to speake or thinke of God any thing rashly and hastily: but to consider our owne weaknesse, and to remember, that as much as heaven is distant from the earth, so much is our understanding from the nature, glory, perfection of God. Iob speaking of God, sayth, Job 26.14. How little a portion is heard of him? The thunder of his power who can understand? It is but a portion, a little portion that we can conceive of him. The Hebrew is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
particulam, a little bit, nay, it is sayd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
particulam verbi, a little piece of a word, or, particulam alicujus, a little piece of something that wee doe heare of him. David sayth, What is man that God should regard him? And we may well say, what is man that he should speake or thinke of God? Take wee heed therefore that wee neither speake nor thinke rashly or hastily of him. But to listen to the Preacher, as he teacheth us to speake to God. Be not rash with thy mouth. The Preacher puts the mouth before the heart, when he forbids the rashnesse of them, because he would not have thee to put it before the heart in the using of it. And though he call it thy mouth, yet it is not so thine, as if thou wert Lord of it, and when thou commest to speake to the Lord in prayer, mightest use it at thy pleasure: but as it is thy mouth, so let it be thy care not to be rash with it. The Originall word here is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying turbari, to be troubled, and therefore noteth here such a hast as is in a troubled and confused manner. Doe not therefore tumble out thy words when thou speakest to God, let thy words be distinctly digested into order, understand well what thou sayest, and let others be able to understand thee. Doe not runne when thou readest, when thou prayest. It is reported, that in the Muscovy Churches, if the Minister mistake in reading, or stammer in pronouncing his words, or speake any word that is not well heard, the hearers doe much blame him, and are ready to take the booke from him as unworthy to reade in it. And surely, God is no lesse offended with the giddy praying of many, who send their petitions in post hast unto him. The Prophet David sayth, At last I spake with my tongue, his tongue came after his heart, his words came after long looking what he would say, what he should say. And the Preacher here would not have our mouth to be first, to be first opened before our understanding be opened for the directing of it. And let not thine heart be hasty to utter any thing: the heart and the mouth must be joyned together, and as there is clamor in ore, ita debet esse amor in corde, an expression with the mouth, so there must be an impression of it in the heart: but yet they must not be joyned in rashnesse and hastinesse. Now the heart is hasty many wayes, either when it taketh not faith with it in praying, for unlesse faith be in the company of prayer, it will never be able to reach unto heaven: or else when it taketh not patience with it, as being contented to stay Gods leasure, untill he grant our prayers: or else when it taketh not repentance with it, for God heareth not sinners: John 19.3. Mat. 6.33. or else when it preferreth worldly things before heavenly things, for, seeke first the Kingdome of heaven: or else, if the heart utter any thing, before it hath
words ready wherby to utter it:Iohan. Clym. for as Clymachus speaks, Mens ad inquisitionem verborum distentatur, the mind is racked, distracted, confounded, when being to utter it selfe, it is then put to seeke words. For God is in heaven, Glossa ordinaria in hunc vers. and thou upon the earth: that is, saith the ordinary Glosse, Deus omnia audit & videt, & stultitiam tuam arguit, quamvis ipse in coelo, tu in terra, God heareth and seeth all things, and reproveth thy folly, although he be in heaven, and thou upon the earth. Or else the force of the reason may be thus understood; for God is in heaven, a glorious Majesty, whose throne is the glorious heaven, and as Anselme speaketh, quilibet reputat Deum, id quo majus esse vel excogitari non potest, every one doth reckon God to be that, then which there can be nothing greater, nothing devised to be greater: if therefore to a great man thou wouldest not speake hastily, doe not to this great God. Thou art upon the earth: earth, made of earth, abiding upon the earth, and though thou mayest have the spirit of God, yet thou hast this treasure in an earthen vessell, and hast, may soone wrong an earthen vessell. Besides the Spirit of God, is a spirit of counsell, and wisdome: shew therefore the Spirit of God to be in thee, by being not rash with thy mouth, nor hasty in thy heart. Therefore let thy words be few: one saith well, that the mouth is the Index of the heart, and as Indices and tables doe briefly shew what is more largely handled in the bookes; so the mouth in prayer should but briefly point out to God, what is more fully enlarged in the heart. And indeed where the heart is full, either it cannot, or it careth not to be full in speaking unto God. It is a duty required, not to speake more in praying, then a man mindeth, and it is a thing well practised in praying to mind more than a man speaketh. The judgment of those religious persons was good,Cassian. Instit. 2. c. 10. who as Cassian relateth, utilius censent, breves quidem orationes sed creberrimas fieri: illud quidem ut frequentius Dominum deprecantes, jugiter eidem adhaerere possimus: hoc verò ut insidiantis diaboli jacula, quae infligere nobis tum praecipue quum oramus insistit, succincta brevitate vitemus, they thinke it best, that our prayers be short but frequent: the one that praying to God we might continually be joyned unto him: the other that by shortnesse, we might avoyd the devils darts which he throweth especially at us when we are praying. Which yet is not so to be understood, as if length of praying were a thing wholly to be condemned. For as Saint Austin speaketh, Sicut intentio orandi non est obtundenda si perdurare non potest, ita si perduraverit non cito est rumpenda, as the intention of the mind in praying is not to bee dulled and blunted if that it cannot continue; so if it doe continue, it is not suddenly to bee broken off. Absit enim ab oratione multa locutio, sed non desit multa precatio, si fervens perseverat intentio. Nam multum loqui est in orando rem non necessariam superfluis agere verbis: Augustin. Epist. 121. ad probam. multum autem precari, est ad eum quem precamur diuturna & pia cordis excitatione pulsare, & plaerum{que} plus gemitibus quam sermonibus agitur, plus fletu quam afflatu, farre be much talking from praying, but let not much praying be wanting, if an earnest devotion in prayer continue; For to talke much is to plead an unnecessary
matter with superfluous words, but to pray much, is to knocke at his gates to whom we make our prayers, with a long and devout stirring of our heart: and which is performed rather with sighing then with speaking, rather with weeping then with talking.

Verse 3. The Preacher here compareth the folly of a busie tounge to the dreames of a busie mind, and that as the one ariseth from multitude of businesse; so the other appeareth in multitude of words.Tertull. de Anima. c. 45.
Tertullian sheweth, that dreames are vacuae jactationes negotiosae animae, the idle tossings of a mind full of businesse: and in the idle tossing of many words, what can there be but a fulnesse of folly? How many tautologies, battologies are there: How many needlesse words? How often are there irreverent, unmannerly, ridiculous, if not worse passages in them? In a multitude of words there is commonly no multitude of matter. And therefore the Preacher saith, that a fooles voyce is knowne by them: it is but a voyce that is heard, it is but a sound that is made, it is like the uncertaine sound of a Trumpet, so that none can tell what it meaneth, what to make of it.Tertul. Ibid. Tertullian expressing the nature of dreames saith, Conspice gladiatorem sine armis, vel aurigam sine curriculis, gesticulantes omnem habitum artis suae: pugnatur, certatur, sed vacua jactatio est, nihilominus fieri videntur, quae fieri tamen non videntur. Actu enim fiunt, effectu vero non fiunt. Behold a Fencer without weapons, a Coach-driver without his running Chariot, acting and practising all the postures and feats of his skill: there is a fighting, there is a stirring, but it is an empty moving and gesturing, notwithstanding those things doe seeme to be done, which are not seene to bee done: they are done in the acting of them, but not in effecting any thing by them, so it is in many words, there is often much fencing, but no weapons wherewith the enemy is wounded, there is much running, but no chariot that winneth the race, much seemeth to be said, but it is to as much purpose as if nothing were said, all is an empty moving of the tongue. If there bee any worth of matter in the multitude of words, it is but by chance,Aristot. de Divin. per insomnia. as Aristotle saith that dreames doe foretell those things which come to passe. For saith he, as when a blind man shooteth many arrowes, perhaps one may bee neere the marke; so saith hee in the multitude of dreames which passe through the head in sleepe, perhaps one may hit upon that which falleth out to be so: and so in the multitude of words, which passe from the mouth of some, perhaps some there may be which cary some matter with them. Homer, Homer. Duas portas divisit somnii, corneam veritatis, eburneam fallaciae. Respicere est enim inquiunt per cornu, ebur est caecum, appointed unto dreames two dores, the one a dore of horne, which was the dore of truth, the other a dore of Ivory, which was the dore of deceit, for horne, as they say, may be look'd thorow, but ivory is thicke and darke. These dores may well be applyed unto the mouths of men, which are the dores of their minds and hearts. For to some it is a dore of glasse, which is soone broken open and easily giveth passage to a multitude of words, wherein the folly of their hearts and minds is discerned:
to others it is a dore of brasse, firme and solid keeping in their words with more care and circumspection, and shewing the firme solidity of their heart and mind. Wherefore when the Preacher here compareth the folly of many words to dreames, it is rather to be understood of the dreames of women then of men: because as folly is made knowne by multitude of words, so they are the dreames of women which are told and made knowne.Chrys. Hom. 87. in Mat. And therefore Saint Chrysostome asking the question why the innocency of our Saviour Christ was rather revealed in a dreame to Pilats wife, then unto Pilate, giveth this reason of it, Quia non edixisset Pilatus, sed secum ipse tenuisset, idcirco ex dispensatione mulier vidit, ut omnibus notum fieret, because Pilate would not have made it knowne, but would have kept it with himselfe, therefore it was ordered that a woman should see it, that so it might be knowne abroad. And surely a foole is like a woman in this, and as shee will bee telling her dreames, so will hee bee telling his folly by his many words. But as Tertullian saith, that dreaming is amentiae instar, as it were a kind of madnesse;Tertul. de Anima. c. 45. so indeed is much talking a kind of foolish madnesse; and as hee saith, non compotes somniamus, we are not our selves when we dreame; so how often doe men out talke themselves by their many words? At best he that useth many words is but a waking dreamer, as he that dreameth is as it were a sleeping mad man.

q.p: VER. 4. When thou vowest a vow to God, deferre not to pay it; for hee hath no pleasure in fooles: pay that which thou hast vowed.
VER. 5. Better it is that thou shouldest not vow, then that thou shouldest vow and not pay.
VER. 6. Suffer not thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sinne, neither say thou before the Angell, that it was an errour: Wherefore should God be angry at thy voyce, and destroy the worke of thine hands?
VER. 7. For in the multitude of dreames, and many words, there are also divers vanities: but feare thou God.

div.p:
Verse 4. The Preacher from the generall of speaking and praying unto God, descendeth more particularly to vowes made unto him. When thou vowest, be not rash and hasty in vowing, as Iepthe was, who sayth, Whatsoever commeth forth of the doores of my house to meete mee, shall surely be the Lords. For it might have been an asse or a dog as well as his daughter. And therefore as Divines note, God was not pleased to forbid him, as he did Abraham: but suffered him to doe it, and to offer the sacrifice of fooles:Hugo de Sanct. Vict. de Jepthe & ejus filia. Hujusmodi patri poena ideo retributa ne impunitum talis voti relinqueretur exemplum, Such a punishment being therefore inflicted on the Father, that the example of such a vow might not be left unpunished, as Hugo speaketh. When thou vowest a vow to God: God it is to whom a vow belongeth, Aquinas 2. 2ae. Q. 88. Ar. 5. and therefore Aquinas sayth, Quòd votum soli Deo fit, sed promissio etiam potest fieri homini, A vow is onely made to God, but a promise may be also made to man; and therefore a vow is properly an act of religion and of divine worship. When thou vowest a vow to God, deferre not to pay: deferre thou mayest by due consideration before thou vowest, but having vowed deferre not to pay it. And first, that thou mayest not deferre, let it not be an unlawfull or unworthy thing that thou vowest, that shame doe not hold thee backe: let it not be above thy strength which thou vowest, that impossibilitie doe not stop thy way. Secondly, doe not deferre it, least by deferring thou become lesse able to pay it: for as Lyra speaketh,Lyra in hunc versum. Ex tali tardatione fit homo plaerum{que} impotens ad reddendum, By such delaying a man is often made unable to performe it. Thirdly, doe not deferre, because if thou be speedy in paying thy vow to God, God will be speedy in rewarding thee for it. Zachaeus came downe quickly and received Christ gladly, and therefore did Christ bestow upon him a speedy requitall, saying, This day is salvation come to thine house. Luk. 19.9. Ambros. de Abel et Cain l. 1. c. 8. For as St. Ambrose speaketh, Festinavit Dominus ad beneficium & non expectavit ut promitteret, & postea impleret, sed antè fecit, postea declaravit. Dixit enim facta est salus, quod utique praevenientis fuit, non promittentis. The Lord hastened his blessing, and stayd not to promise, that afterward he might performe; but first did it and afterwards told him of it. For he sayth, Salvation is come, which is surely the voice of a preventing mercy, not of a promising grace. It is sayd of Cain, And in processe of time,
Gen. 4.3. or at the end of dayes; but be not thou like him, and stay not the end of dayes, untill thou have ended the paying of thy vow, proceed quickly to the performance of it, before that time proceed on farther. For as St. Ambrose speaketh, Prima voti gratia est celeritas solutionis, Ambros. Ibid. The chiefe grace of a vow is the celeritie of paying it. And therefore as he also addeth, Iustus celeritate suum votum commendat, A just man commendeth and setteth out his vow by the speed of doing of it. Fourthly, deferre it not, for he hath no pleasure in fooles: the Hebrew is directly as St. Hierome doth reade it, Quia non est voluntas in insipientibus, Because there is not a will in fooles: that is, as I thinke the sense may be taken, it is in fooles that there is not a will to pay it, it is the propertie of them to repent
of what they have done in vowing, and to be unwilling to doe what they have vowed.Augustin. Epist. 45. ad Armentarium & Paulinam. But as St. Austin speaketh, Non te vovisse poeniteat, imo gaude jam tibi sic non licere quod cum tuo damno licuisset, Let it not repent thee to have vowed, yea, rejoyce, that now in this manner that is not lawfull for thee to doe, which would have been lawfull for thee to thy damage and detriment. Be not therefore such a foole, and deferre not to pay thy vow. But the common translation and exposition of the words is to referre them to God, saying, For he hath no pleasure in fooles: he hath no contentment in them, who have no more wit, then to thinke that he is honoured by making vowes unto him, when by deferring to pay them, they are as good as not payd. The Psalmist sayth, Psal. 50.14. Offer unto God the sacrifice of praise, and pay thy vowes unto the most High: it is the paying of vowes that is the sacrifice of praise unto him. He hath no pleasure in such fooles, as regard not their owne good and benefit:Augustin.
