Ibid. for as St. Austin speaketh, Benignus exactor est & non egens, & qui non crescit ex redditis, sed in se crescere faciat redditores: quia quod ei redditur, reddenti additur, He is a bountifull exactor, and not a needy one, himselfe doth not encrease by those things, which are payd him, but he maketh the payers of vowes to encrease in themselves: that which is payd God, is added to his estate by whom it is payd, and maketh that the greater. Pay therefore that which thou hast vowed: the Preacher doubleth his exhortation, even thereby pressing to a speedy performing of our vowes. For when a Master doubleth his call, it is to make his servant come quickly unto him.

Verse 5. Better it is to vow, then not to vow, and that for three reasons, as Aquinas Aquinas. hath set them downe. First, because it is an act of divine worship, quae est praecipua inter morales virtutes, which is the chiefest among the morall vertues.Augustin. de virgin. c. 8. And therefore St. Austin sayth, Non virginitas ipsa, quia virginitas, sed quia Deo dedita est honoratur, Virginitie it selfe is not so much honoured because it is virginitie, as because it is dedicated to God. Secondly, because he that vowes something and doth it, doth the more subject himselfe to God, then he that doth it onely. For he subjecteth himselfe, Non solum quantum ad actum, sed etiam quantum ad potestatem, Not onely in respect of the act of doing, but also in respect of the power of doing, so that after he hath vowed, he cannot doe otherwise.Anselm. l. de Similit. c. 4. And therefore as Anselme sayth, Plus dat homini qui dat arborem cum fructibus, quam qui dat fructus tantum, He giveth more to a man, that giveth him the tree with the fruits, then he that giveth the fruits onely; so he giveth more to God that voweth, which is the tree, and doth it, which is the fruit, then he that doth it onely, which is the fruit onely. Thirdly, because by vowing the will is more immovably established in goodnesse. For to doe a thing out of a setled resolution unto goodnesse, belongeth to the perfection of vertue,Aristot. Ethic. l. 2. c. 4. as the Philosopher sheweth. As on the contrary, it doth much aggravate a sinne, to commit it out of a setled stubbornnesse. But though it be better to vow, then not to vow, yet it is better not to vow, then
not to pay when thou hast vowed. And as St. Hierome speaketh,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Melius est non promittere, quam promissa non facere, It is better not to promise, then not to doe the things that thou hast promised. It had been better that Pharaoh had never promised to let the children of Israel goe, then not to let them goe when he had promised it. For because Pharaohs words were but an emptie sound, therefore by Gods judgement, as St. Ambrose noteth,Ambrosius. Ranis impletur Aegyptus sonum inanem rerum & strepitum vanum reddentibus, was Aegypt filled with frogs, which made a great croaking, and a vast idle sound that had nothing in it. It is better to be slow in vowing, then to be slow in paying;Hieronym. in hunc vers. and as St. Hierome speaketh, Melius est ancipitem diu deliberare sententiam, quàm in verbis facilem, in operibus esse difficilem, It is better to deliberate, and to hold long in suspense our doubtfull resolution, then to be free and easie in our words, but hard and difficult in our works. But yet it is better to pay slowly, then not to pay at all. Although it be true as S. Ambrose speaketh, Quum moramfacis, non reddis, When thou delayest to performe,Ambros. de Abel et Cain l. 1. c. 7. thou dost not performe, because so long as thou delayest to performe, so long thou dost not performe. But yet better late then never. And yet better never to vow, then never to pay it. S. Ambrose tels us, Votum est postulatio bonorum à Deo, cum solvendi muneris promissione. Et ideo quum impetraveris quod petisti, ingrati est tardare promissum, A vow is an asking of some good things, with a promise of performing some dutie. And therefore when thou hast obtained that which thou diddest sue for, it is an unthankfull part to delay thy promise. But how wicked then is it, not to performe thy promise at all? An nescis quam grave sit ibi contrahere peccatum, ubi speras remedium? Dost thou not know, how grievous a thing it is to make that thy sinne, which thou didst hope should have been thy comfort against sinne? Certainly, it was no small curse which the Prophet intendeth, when he sayth, Psal. 109.7. Let his prayer be turned into sinne: and it is no little curse that thou bringest upon thy selfe, when thou turnest the religious vow which thou hast made into a fowle offence of an irreligious not paying of it. Good therefore it were that they who in sicknesse or any danger are ready to make vowes would consider this, that in their health and safetie they might be ready to performe them. For better it is not to vow, then to vow and not to pay.

Verse 6. Suffer not thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sinne: Lyra expoundeth it thus, Suffer not thy mouth by full and dainty feeding, to kindle lust in thy flesh, and to make thy flesh to sinne.Tertull. contra Psychicos. Hieronym. ad Oceanum. For as Tertullian speaketh, Appendices gulae, lascivia, atque luxuria, wantonnesse and lust are the appendants of gluttony. And Saint Hierome sayth, Venter mero aestuans cito despumat in libidines, The belly boyling with wine, doth quickly foame out into lust. The words also in themselves may admit this interpretation, Suffer not thy mouth, to give ill counsell unto thine owne children, and so to cause thy flesh to sinne. For this is a great wickednesse, and Cyrillus Alexandrinus speaking of them that practise
it,Cyrillus Alexand. sayth, Extrema supplicia sustinebunt, ut qui suos ipsi fructus corrumpunt, They shall suffer extreame punishment, as being such bad trees, as that they corrupt their owne fruites, and therefore are good for nothing but to be cut downe, and to be cast into the fire. But as the words stand in this place, they are more plainely to be understood thus, that by occasion of the mouth we should not suffer sinne to be committed in our flesh, whereof the mouth is a part. Suffer not, sayth the Preacher,Basil. Homil. 9. in Psal. 33. for if thou shalt but suffer it, it will soone be done: because as Basil speaketh, Peccatum quod per linguam admittitur, omnium fere propensissimum, sed & idem multiforme, the sinne which is committed with the mouth, is of all most ready, and withall it is of many kindes. The Originall is, Ne des, Give not thy mouth leave, which of it selfe is so much given to it, give it not the reynes, which is apt to runne so headlong. To cause: the mouth is a great cause of sinne, and therefore St. Chrysostome sayth,Chrysostom. Homil. 4. inter 16. varias. Vndique nobis diabolus insidias parare consuevit, sed facilius ore peccante: nullum enim illi aeque congruum organum est in ministerium interitus atque peccati, The devils manner is to lay traps for us every way, but no way so much as by a sinning tongue; for there is no part of the body so sit for the ministery of destruction and sinne. Thy flesh to sinne: that is, either thy selfe, the part being taken for the whole, or else the bodily part of thy selfe. For though thy mouth be prone to sinne, yet it cannot make thee to sinne, nor make thy body sinfull, unlesse thou suffer it. And though by thy former bad sufferance, now in a manner thou canst not choose but sinne with thy mouth, yet suffer it not to be an ordinary cause of sinning unto thee. Neither say thou before the Angel: Saint Hieromes Master understood the Angel here, to be the particular Angel, which God hath appointed to waite upon every one, and the meaning to be, Doe not vow, and not performe, for thy words doe not passe away into winde, but the Angel which is thy companion doth cary them forthwith unto God,Hieronym. in hunc versum. and God whom thou thinkest to be ignorant of what thou hast sayd, is provoked to anger by thee, so that thy workes shall be destroyed. Tremellius understandeth here the Angel of the Covenant, Mala. 3.1. Christ our Lord, of whom God sayth, Behold, I send an Angel before thee to keepe thee in the way: beware of him, and obey his voice,
Exod. 23.20. & 21. and provoke him not to anger. Others understand these words, before the Angel, to be the same with those in the second verse of this Chapter, before God, and that the Angel is here put for God, as an Ambassadour standeth for his Prince; the Angels being Gods ususuall Embassadours. Wherefore the Septuagint doe also reade it so, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , before God. But if I may deliver mine apprehension, I understand the Angel here to be the soule of man, which is of an Angelicall nature, and the meaning to be, When thou hast sinned in thy flesh, say not in thy soule, it is an errour: When thou hast sinned with thy mouth, either by thy rash praying, or by thy carelesse vowing, either delaying to performe it, or not regarding to performe it at all, say not in thy minde, excuse it not in thy soule, answer not thy conscience
which is Gods messenger to reproove thee for it, that it was an errour. The Originall word signifieth ignorance or errour, and Saint Hierome tels us, that Symmachus did render the word Involuntarium, A thing unwillingly done: all which are excuses, which men pretend for not keeping of their mouths from rashnesse, and for not keeping of their vowes and promises. First, ignorance, and either they know not that they sayd it, or else they sayd they knew not what: secondly, errour, and either themselves were mistaken in that which they sayd, or else others are mistaken in understanding that which was spoken: thirdly, unwillingnesse, and either they were forced to say that which they uttered, or else they were transported by some passion, so that it was spoken against their will. The Septuagint doe reade it, Non est providentia, say not, There is no providence: and though Tremellius doe not reade it so, yet he giveth the sense of the place according to that reading; shewing it to be thus, Say not with thy mouth, and sinne not with thy mouth, say not in thy thought before the Angel, who is the discerner of thy thoughts, that there is no providence, as if things did fall out by errour and chance. For why should God be angry at thy voyce? This wicked voyce of thine, either outwardly pronounced with thy mouth, or inwardly conceived in thine heart. Or else wherefore should God be angry with thy voyce? either thy first voyce, whereby thou hast spoken rashly, or vowed untruly: or else thy second voyce, whereby thou addest sinne to sinne, and with more naughtie excusing seekest to helpe and palliate thy former naughtie dealing. And destroy the works of thy hands: destroy thy works, because thou hast destroyed thy words; and make thine hands to erre in doing thy works ill, because thou pretendest errour for thine ill speaking; and make thee ignorant in that which thou dost, because thou pleadest ignorance in that which thou saydst; and make thy works to perish against thy will, because thou alleagest thy words to have been against thy will.

Verse 7. The most direct and verball translation of the words as I conceive is this, Nam in multitudine somniorum, & vanitatum, & verborum, multum, ideo time Deum, For in the multitude of dreames, and vanities, and words, much, therefore feare God. To make up the sense, there must be added to the word Much, much is he angry, the anger of God being that whereof the end of the former verse speaketh. And this verse being a generall conclusion to the former passage of the Chapter, wee may understand the Preacher, that many words which being full of rashnesse and folly, are but as many dreames, many vanities, are most offensive to God, and therefore that the feare of Gods anger should make them to be shunned. Or else in a neerenesse to a verball translation, the words may be read thus, as St. Hierome hath them, In multitudine somniorum, et vanitates et verba plurima, sed time Deum, In the multitude of dreames, there are vanities and many words; but feare thou God: and then the sense,Hieronym. in hunc vers. which as St. Hierome tels us the Iewes gave of it, is taken from the last words; and there being,
say they, in dreames many vaine feares and many terrifying words, feare not them, but feare GOD who ruleth all things. Or else wee may understand the words with reference to the excuses, which in the former verse are forbidden, and which being but as dreames are only full of vanities and many words, and will not profit any thing: and therefore that God who knoweth all things rightly,Lyra in hunc versum. and as Lyra speaketh, Omnia errata ad lineam justitia reducet, will reduce all errours to the line of justice, ought to be feared. But to give a translation according to the sense which the words may receive, they may be rendred thus, In the multitude of dreames, there is also a multitude of vanities, and in many words there is also much vanity, which in effect is the same with the translation which we read. To consider therefore this: Tertullian tels us, that Epicurus judged all dreames to be vaine, wherein diverse particular instances both of sacred and profane histories,Tertull. de Anima. c. 46 to use Tertullians phrase, Epicuro pudorem imperant, doe even force Epicurus to be ashamed, and shew the true praedictions which have beene in dreames. And as for the constitution of mans body, dreames are oftentimes good symptomes of it, and in that respect may be called, peculiare solatium naturalis oraculi, the peculiar comfort of a naturall Oracle. On the other side the Telmessenses, Clemens Alexandri. Stromat. l. 1. or as Clemens Alexandrinus calleth them the Telmisenses and who as hee saith invented the art of divining by dreames, they saith Tertullian, Nulla somnia evacuabant, made no dreames to be vaine. But these were as farre from the truth as Epicurus, and unlesse that men doe dreame in their understanding, they cannot but acknowledge that in the multitude of dreames there are many vanities. And so it is in the multitude of words. There may be some matter sometimes in some of them, but in the multitude of them there are many vanities. Let therefore the feare of Gods anger who is displeased at them, keepe thee from them. And indeed the feare of God is a most excellent meanes to doe it. For as Saint Chrysostome speaketh,Chrys. Hom. 15. ad populum. Nihil tam peccata consumit, virtutem verò facit crescere ac germinare, sicut timor, There is nothing that doth so destroy sinnes, and make vertue to encrease and grow, as the feare of Gods wrath doth. And therefore he addeth, Gehenna nihil gravius, sed ejus metu nihil utilius, There is nothing more grievous then hell, but nothing more profitable then the feare of it. When our Saviour Christ was pleased to shew his terrour in the Temple, he made all the buyers and sellers to flye out of the Temple. Yea the Priests fled also, and none remained in it, as Anacletus Bishop of Rome affirmeth: which thing Saint Hierome reckoneth among the chiefest of our Saviours miracles.Hieronym. uper cap. 21. Matth. And surely the terrour and feare of Gods wrath throughly apprehended are able to worke miracles in calling men out of their sinnes, and in stopping them from running into them.

epigraph.q: VER. 8. Jf thou seest the oppression of the poore, and violent perverting of Iudgement and Justice in a Province, marvell not at the matter: for hee that is higher then the highest regardeth, and there be higher then they.

div.p:
Verse 8. The Preachers last words were, feare thou God, and from thence passing to those who doe not feare God, hee saith, If thou seest others not to feare God, not to feare his anger, yet doe thou feare him, doe thou feare his wrath. If thou seest the wickednesse of those that are in authority, their oppressing the poore, there violent perverting of judgement and justice, and seest not the wrath of God upon them, mervaile not at the matter. For he that is high above the highest regardeth them, hee seeth them and their doings as well as thou dost. The Originall word here used is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
custodit; as Saint Hierome also rendreth it, he keepeth and preserveth. Hee keepeth the poore though they be oppressed by them: he keepeth judgement and justice, though it be by them violated and perverted. Perhaps thou dost mervaile that good and vertuous men should be so used, so wronged. But Seneca saith unto thee,Seneca de provid. l. 4.
Quid miraris bonos viros ut confirmentur concuti? Non est arbor solida nisi frequens ventus incursat, ipsa enim vexatione radices certius figit, fragiles sunt quae in aprica valle creverunt, Why dost thou mervaile that good men are shaken that they may bee setled? A tree is not firme in the ground unlesse the wind doe often beate upon it; the very shaking of it doth fasten the roote most surely: they are weake that doe grow in the warme vally. Perhaps thou dost mervaile that any should bee so cruell as to oppresse the poore oppressed with want and misery: that they who have their authority to doe justice and judgement, should pervert and destroy it. But is it any mervaile that heate driveth away cold, or that moysture destroyeth drynesse? They being contrary the one to the other, the stronger overcommeth the weaker. And therefore seeing the bad mind of the ruler is opposite to the good cause of the poore: and seeing the unrighteous heart of the Iudge, is opposite to the righteousnesse of judgement, no mervaile though he oppresseth the one, perverteth the other. Saint Iohn therefore saith,1 Ioh. 3.13. & 12. Doe not mervaile my brethren if the world hate you. The workes of Cain were evill, the workes of Abel good, therefore did Cain slay his brother. And therefore it is that they who are elder with Cain in place and authority being more wicked with him also, doe wrong the righteous and godly. Perhaps thou dost mervaile, why God whose power is high and great above all, and whose seate of judgement is higher then the highest, why hee doth
suffer it and permit it to be so.August. de Civit. Dei. l. 11. c. 8. But mervaile not, for as Saint Austin speaketh, Non ullum Deus non dico angelorum sed vel hominum creasset, quem malum futurum esse praescisset, nisi pariter nosset, quibus eos bonorum usibus commodaret, God would not have created any I say not of the Angels, but of men, whom he foresaw that they would bee wicked, unlesse he had foreknowne also to what good uses he would apply them. Wherefore as in the art of Rhetoricke there is a pretty elgancy from the opposition of sentences;Aug. Ibid. so saith the same father, Quadam non verborum sed rerum eloquentiâ, contrariorum oppositione saeculi pulchritudo componitur, By a kind of eloquence not of words, but of things, from the opposition of contraries the beauty of the world is made and set forth: Origen therefore affirmeth,Origenes super Numeros Dispositione divina sic omnia in hoc mundo esse disposita, ut prorsus nihil apud Deum sit otiosum, etiamsi malum illud sit, That so are all things ordered in this world by the divine dispensation, that nothing is to no purpose, although it be evill that is suffered to bee. Now the word marvaile in this verse may be referred to any of these, either to the bad will and delight of the wicked in authority; or to the patient will and sufferance of God though above them in authority; or to the greatnesse and foulenesse of the matter, and wickednesse. For the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used compriseth all. And there be higher then they: there be also others which being higher in the world and greater in strength, feare not, spare not to oppresse them, as they have oppressed weaker and lower then themselves.Chrysost. in Psalm. 3. For as St. Chrysostome noteth, the wicked in this world are like beasts in a theatre, and as the beast which hath killed one, is killed by another, so they Alios quidem invadunt, ab aliis vero interficiuntur, prevaile over some by their oppression, but are by others brought under and oppressed. God sometimes being pleased in this world to make his judgements to be seeme, in the perverting of judgement by the wicked. But howsoever God may see and say nothing now, he will at length let all see that the poore oppressed shall be relieved, that judgement and justice perverted shall bee rectified and established.

q.p: VER. 9. Moreover the profit of the earth is for all: the King himselfe is served by the field.
VER. 10. Hee that loveth silver, shall not bee satisfied with silver, nor hee that loveth abundance, with increase: this is also vanity.
VER. 11. When goods increase; they are increased that eate them: and what good is there to the owners thereof, saving the beholding of them with their eyes?
VER. 12. The sleepe of a labouring man is sweete, whether hee eate little or much: but the abundance of the rich, will not suffer him to sleepe.

div.p:
Verse 9. Saint Hierome reading this verse thus,Hieronym •• hunc vers. Et amplius terrae in omnibus est rex in agro culto, And moreover in all things of the earth a King in a tilled field, and applying it to God, who in the verse before is said to be above all, in these words understandeth him, to be in all things of the earth as a King in a tilled field: and that this world being unto him as a field of corne, hee doth not now alwayes punish the wicked although hee see their wickednesse, but leaving the tares and the corne to grow together, hee letteth them alone untill the day of judgement, at which time he will gather the corne into his barne, and burne the tares with fire. The most direct translation as I conceive, is that of Arias Montanus, Et praestantia terrae in omnibus rex agro fit servus, And the excellency of the earth is in all things; the King is made a servant to the field. For in the height of men it being the height of pride that maketh them to oppresse and wrong the poore, and those that are under them: the Preacher having shewed that there are higher then they by whom they are tamed, here hee addeth, that the earth it selfe is higher, and more than all, though all doe tread it under their feete: So that the King himselfe is servant, to the field. For doth he not receive his food and sustenance from the field as a servant from his master? Is not his body the livery of the earth which he weareth as a servant doth the livery of his master? Are not the workes of nature, the works of the earth,
and doth not a King doe them, as a servant doth the workes of his master? What are the revenues of his kingdome, but as it were wages which the field payeth him, as a master payeth wages to his servant? But generally that which is understood here by interpreters is the praise of husbandry, and that in Kings themselves. The Septuagint therefore read it, Et praestantia terrae in omnibus est rex agri culti; And the excellency of the earth in all, is a King of a tilled field. The Syriack reads it, Haereditas terrae in omnibus est rex qui agrum colit, The inheritance of the earth in all things is a King who tilleth the ground. Olympiodorus reads it, Super omnes rex est dominus agrielaborati, Above all is the King, who is the master of a dressed field. Others Abundantia terrae pro omnibus rex agri agricolati, The abundance of the earth for all is the King of a field husbanded. And it is to shew the excellency of tillage that our Translation reads it: Moreover the profit of the earth is for all: the King himselfe is served by the field. And indeed a great honour it is to Kings to have a care of tillage.Josephus Histor. l. 8. c. 2.
Iosephus speaking of the raigne of Solomon saith, Mirandum in modum per id tempus auctae sunt res Hebraeorum, & tribus Iudae, populo ad agrorum colendorum studia converso, wonderfully in that time was the estate of the Hebrewes encreased, and of the tribe of Iudah, the people being turned to the care of tilling the ground. Valerius Maximus shewing that Masanissa King of Numidia lived above ninety yeares, sheweth also the benefit of his long life to have beene this,Valer. Maxim. l. 8. c. 3.
Quod terram quam vastam & desertam acceperat perpetuo culturae studio frugiferam reliquit, That the ground which he found wast and barren,Nazianzene Epist. 194. by the perpetuall care of husbandry he left fruitfull. Nazianzene also speaking of Caudicenus the Governour, and setting forth the jollities of Countrie people when their harvest was ended, saith, Agriculturae nimirum haec festiva sacra sunt, tuo beneficio rursum ad homines reversae, These are the merry solemnities of husbandry by thy favour returned againe unto men. And here let me commend the husbandry of the earth of our bodyes, then which nothing is more excellent either for Prince or people: Let the plow of Gods Word subdue it, let the seeds of vertue bee sowne in it, and though our bodyes be earthy, let them bee made heavenly by the fruits of heavenly grace,Clem. Alex. Admonitio ad Gentes. For as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh, Terram in coelum mutat Dei agricola, The husband-man of God turneth earth into heaven. But yet being not satisfied in the meaning of this verse, let mee propose to consideration one meaning more. For the Preacher having noted in the verse before, how the wicked are suffered by God in their wicked doings, here taketh away the mervaile of it, because it is but here upon the earth that they have their desires, where all things are common unto all; and because that though they bee on high, yet it is but in the favours of the earth; for the King himselfe the highest of all, hath but the priviledge to bee in a field well dressed and husbanded, whereas others are in more barren soyles. But that the right which God will doe unto the poore oppressed, and to the righteous wronged, is reserved to bee in heaven: where they shall bee
Kings not as earthly Kings in a tilled field, but in a Kingdome of eternall glory. Some doe here take the earth for the people of the earth, the field for the inferiour sort, because they that dresse the field are of the inferiour sort, and then whereas in the former verse is shewed the evill of those that are in higher place oppressing those that are under them, they conceive, that here an argument is given, whereby to worke contentment in it. For seeing it is needfull for the generall profit of all that there should be some on high, some under them, therefore though they on high doe abuse their places, yet that it may bee borne with, in respect of the generall benefit that ariseth from inequality of persons, in which regard even the King serveth the meanest person as having need of him.

Verse 10. The Preacher shewing farther the commendation of husbandry, preferreth it before the other wealth of the world. First, because the profit of the earth satisfieth the appetite of nature feeding upon it, but silver doth not satisfie the appetite of him that loveth it. Secondly, because there is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 revenue, fruite from the earth, but he that loveth silver although he have much of it, yet hath he no fruit by it, hee enjoyeth no comfort from it. And therefore I should read the verse from the Originall thus. He that loveth silver shall not bee satisfied with silver, and he that loveth it in the multitude of it, shall not have fruit. But to consider the verse as it is in it selfe, here is a double love of mony set downe. First, a love in seeking of it before it is gotten. Secondly, a love of it when it is gotten. Hee that loveth silver, &c. It is the love of silver which is the mischiefe of it, and that is to bee removed from the heart of man. Wherefore when Saint Peter saith, Mat. 19.27. wee have forsaken all and followed thee: if we consider this All in it selfe, what could it be in such poore men, who were but fisher-men, and sustained themselves by their daily labour? But S. Greg. saith well,Greg. Hom. in Matth. In hac re affectum debemus potius pensare quam censum. Multum relinquit qui quantumlibet parum totum deseruit. Multum ergo Petrus & Andreas reliquerunt, quando uterque etiam desiderium habendi reliquit, In this thing we must consider rather their mind then their wealth. For he leaveth much, who leaveth all though never so little. And therefore Peter and Andrew did leave much because both did leave the desire and love of having. He that loveth silver shall not bee satisfied with silver: hee that out of love seeketh after it, shall love still to seeke it, and never rest satisfied. For as Saint Bernard compareth such a one,Bern. Tract. de diligendo Deum c. 3. he is like to one that being very hungry gapeth continually for wind, Quo inflari potest, satiari non potest, with which he may be puffed up, but cannot be filled; for so, such are swolne great in pride with their wealth, but are never satisfied wi h it. The true happinesse of man, saith Boetius; Boetius de consol. l. 3.
Non in eo sita est ut multa possideat, sed ut desideria sua bene adimpleat, Is not placed in this, that a man possesseth much, but that hee doe well satisfie and fill his desires. And Saint Austin saith, Beatus est qui habet quicquid vult, August. de Trin. l. 3.
& nihil malè vult, Hee is happy who hath whatsoever he will, and hath not his will
bent ill unto any thing. But how wretched then is he, whose will is never satisfied, and hath his will alwayes bent and set amisse? And he that loveth abundance: it is much easier to put off the love of wealth, before a man hath it, then when hee hath it: because that which a man hath not, is not so much cared for, as being a thing not belonging to him; but when a man hath it, then it being his owne, that sets his love upon it;Aquinas 2. 2. Quest. 86. Answ. 3. Aug. Epist. ad Paulin. and then as Aquinas saith, it is like the cutting off of a member from h m, for a man to part with it. Saint Austin therefore saith, Terrena diliguntur arctius adepta quam concupita, Earthly things are loved more eagerly being obtained then being desired and sought for. Then it is that he loveth it as his God, setting it up in his treasury as in a Temple, or in his chest as in a shrine, and not daring himselfe to touch it as a sacred thing. So that not satisfied with the encrease, he hath no fruit in the enjoying of it. The name onely and care of a rich man, is that which such a one hath, he hath no use of his riches. He may be said to have a rich purse, but a rich minde such a one cannot have, who will hardly spare himselfe that which hee standeth in need of. Wherefore Seneca saith,Seneca Epist. l. 9. ep. 109.
Desunt inopiae multa, avaritiae omnia: hinc avarus in nullum bonus est, in seipsum pessimus; tam enim ei deest quod habet quam quod non habet, to poverty many things are wanting, but to covetousnesse all things: hence it is that a covetous man who is good to none, is worst to himselfe; for he wanteth as well that which he hath, as that which he hath not. But especially he is said to have no fruit of his abundance, because it doth not bring forth the fruits of charity.Greg. Pastor. Cur. Par. 3. Adm. 21. For as Saint Gregory speaketh, Fructus ex eis caperetur, si eas bene spargere non amando voluisset. Qui vero eas diligendo retinet, hic uti{que} sine fructu relinquet. The fruit of benefit should bee gathered from riches, if hee that hath them by not loving of them would scatter them abroad. But hee that loving them doth keepe them shall leave them without fruit. And no marvell if silver and abundance of riches doe not satisfie the soule of man, for as Saint Austin speaking to God saith,Aug. Solil. c. 30.
Facta est anima rationalis capax Domine majestatis tuae, ut à te solo & nullo alio possit impleri, The reasonable soule is made capable, O Lord of thy Majesty, that by thee alone and nothing else it may be filled.Bern. Hom. super Mat. 19.27. And Saint Bernard therefore saith also well, Anima rationalis caeteris omnibus occupari potest, impleri non potest, The reasonable soule may be busied about other things, but it cannot be filled with them. The Preacher therefore concludeth, This is also vanity. This is not the good of man, for to that two things are required, first Vt sit bonum habenti, That it be good unto him that hath it; secondly, Vt terminet ejus appetitum, That it terminate and set an end unto his desire: but this riches doe not, being the care and torment of him that hath them, and without fruit of comfort, and leaving his desire unsatisfied,Lyra in hunc vers. as if hee had them not. But this is therefore vanity, and though it bee silver, although it be abundance of silver, it is a thing of nothing.

Verse 11. The Preacher having preferred the wealth of the field,
before the wealth of money; yet here sheweth the wealth of the field to be vaine also, because when the good fruits of the earth are encreased, they are encreased also that doe eate them. For more being needfull for the sowing, reaping, ordering of them, there are the more mouths to devoure them.Arabica versio. This sense the Arabick translation makes to be most proper, for that reads it, In multitudine panis, multi & qui comedunt eum, In the multitude of bread, many there are also that doe eate it. And to shew the vanitie of this, the Preacher addeth, What good is there to the owners thereof, saving the beholding of them with their eyes? What good doth that doe the owners, which is eaten by others? What nourishment have they by it, save onely the feeding of their eyes? He that is the Master may please his eyes in beholding many to be fed with his provision; but as St. Hierome speaketh,Hieronym. in hunc versum. Plus quam unius hominis cibum ipse capere non potest, More then the sustenance of one man himselfe cannot receive. Or else wee may consider that the Preacher having shewed the vanitie of riches in the covetous wretch that doth not use and enjoy them; here he speaketh of them as they are made use of. And then we may take his words either in a good or in a bad sense. First, in a bad sense: When goods encrease, and men have much to spend, they are encreased that eate them; they will have many about them, they will keepe a great retinue, and shew the greatnesse of their estates, by the great number that are fed by them. But what more vaine then this? For what good is there to the Masters of them? What are they for the most part, but as Lyra speaketh, Inutiles & ribaldi, uselesse, needlesse,Lyra in hunc versum. Nah. 3.17. and ribaldry fellows. Of whom wee may understand the Prophet Nahum to speake, when he sayth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Coronantur, crowned they are as Locusts, that is, those by whom they are crowned and compassed about are but as Locusts, and as Locusts doe onely devoure the fruits of the earth, so doe they onely devoure meate and drinke. What good is there therefore to the Masters of them, save the beholding of them with his eyes? The beholding of so many to be their servants, to waite upon them, and to follow after them.Olympiodor. in hunc vers. This sense the reading of Olympiodorus doth seeme to countenance, who hath it thus, Principatus enim est illi ut videat oculis suis, For it is a principalitie to his vaine minde, and he thinketh himselfe a little King to behold it with his eyes. Or else the Preachers words may be taken in a good sense thus. Although some be so base, that they will not spare a little out of their superfluitie to relieve others; yet they that are good, when their goods are encreased, will doe good with them, and they whom their charitie feedeth, shall be encreased also. But then the latter part of the verse must be read, either as the Syriack hath it, Et factum est, foelix possidentibus se, Syriaca versio. quoniam de capite meo vidioculis meis, And it becommeth a happinesse to them that enjoy themselves, because from mine head I have seene it with mine eyes. Or else as the Venetian translation hath it, Et quid gratius esse poteritidomino ejus, Veneta versio quàm videre hoc ipsum oculis suis, And what can be more acceptable to the owner of it, then to behold this very thing with his eyes? to behold
so many blessing God, and praying for him, by whom they are relieved. But the Originall word which I finde in the Hebrew being 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and which though translated by diverse, Quid prodest? What profit? yet properly signifieth rectum, that which is right, and so is used by the Preacher in the second Chapter, the one and twentieth verse; the meaning which I conceive of the Preachers words is this. When goods are encreased by the blessing of God, care and charge are encreased with them, and they are more that eate them, because there must be more to looke unto them, to mannage, and to order them. Of Iob wee reade that his substance was seven thousand sheepe, Iob 1.3. three thousand Camels, five thousand yoke of Oxen, five hundred she asses, and a very great household. His substance being shewed to be great, the great number of his household is shewed also, as being needfull for it. But besides, Quid rectum dominis suis, What is right to their Masters, then that with their eyes they behold and looke to their servants, and see that they governe themselves well, and that they be not idle. Abraham had so great a family, Gen. 18.6. & 7. that his owne servants made an army, wherewith at once he conquered diverse Kings: yet he had them all so employed, that when the three men came unto him, he ran to Sarah his wife to cause her to make ready three measures of fine meale, and himselfe ranne to the heard and fetcht a calfe tender and good. Now thus to looke to the well managing of a great estate, to the well governing of a great family, being no little toyle and vexation of spirit, well sheweth the vanitie of worldly goods, even in them that have abundance,Bernar. Ser. 7. in Psal. Qui habitat. and doe use it well. The former part of this verse St. Bernard applying in a spirituall sense, and comparing a religious man unto a fruitfull Vineyard, telleth us, Tali vineae nunquam infestationes, nunquam insidiae deerunt, nempe ubi multae opes, multi sunt & qui comedunt eas. Sapiens ergo solicitus servare vineam suam, non minus quam excolere, nec sinet eam vorari à vulpibus, To such a vineyard there are never wanting annoyances and snares, for where are much riches, there are many also that eate them. A wise man therefore being carefull to keepe his vineyard, no lesse then to dresse it, will not suffer it to be devoured by Foxes.

Verse 12. The Preacher here joyneth the covetous wretch, and the voluptuous rich man together, shewing a poore labourer to be in a better condition then both they are. For whether he eate little, as the covetous wretch doth: and though his povertie deny him that, which the others love of his riches will not grant himselfe, yet hath he little care, little trouble of minde, so that he enjoyeth his sleepe quietly, which is the wages that nature payeth him for his labour. Yea, it is a sweet sleepe unto him: his sleepe is to him as the sweet sound of still musick, all his senses being joyned in an unison of rest: his sleepe is to him a sweet moysture, which distilling from the hony-combe of labour, dulleth the appetite of watchfulnesse, and withall nourisheth his strength, to make him able to watch the better. Whereas the abundance
of the covetous wretch, will not suffer him to sleepe; Ambros. de Nabut. c. 6 but as St. Ambrose speaketh, Excitat eum cupiditas, torquet invidia, sterilitas proventuum infoecunda perturbat, solicitat abundantia, His covetousnesse rowseth him, his envie tormenteth him, the barren unfruitfulnesse of his revenues disquieteth him, his abundance vexeth him. Yea, as the same Father noteth, Ne ipse quidem Deus eum dormire permittit, even God himselfe will not suffer him to sleepe. For in the Gospel, God himselfe, Interpellat cogitantem, excitat dormientem, Interrupteth the rich wretch, while he is thinking, awakeneth him while he is sleeping, and sayth unto him, Thou foole, this night shall thy soule be taken from thee. Luke 12.20. And as God doth not suffer him to sleepe, so neither doth he suffer himselfe to sleepe, but being full of trouble, In ubertate fructus vocem gementis emittit, In the plentie of his fruit he sendeth forth the voyce of sorrow, saying, Quid saciam? What shall I doe? For is not this the voyce of a poore man, who hath not meanes to live? But the poore labourer who worketh hard to get his meanes of living, by his labour getteth sweet sleepe, whereby his life is by farre more happy and comfortable unto him. Or else whether the poore labourer eate much, as the voluptuous rich man, as having by his labour the better stomacke to eate, and not wanting to supply his stomackes desire, yet it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a plainnesse of nourishment, which being not heavy of digestion, doth not burthen the body, and from which health,Clem. Alexand. Paedag. l. 2. c. 1.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
& justae vires, and just strength ariseth, as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh; so that he enjoyeth his due and just sleepe, whereby he is sweetly refreshed, and made more able and fit for his labour. Whereas the abundance of the rich will not suffer him to sleepe; and that sayth Lyra, for two reasons.Lyra in hunc vers. Primo quia reformidat ire adlectum, donec per spatium temporis vigilaverit post cibum: secundo quia in lecto existens ex nimio cibo sentit dyscrasias somnum impedientes, First, because he feareth to goe to his bed, untill for a time he hath watched after the eating of his meate; secondly, because being in his bed, from too much meate he findeth many distempers which hinder his sleepe. So that as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh,Clem. Alexand. Paedag. l. 2. c. 9.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ventrum in arctum compressorum murmura & tumultus, The murmurings and tumults of his belly and straitned guts, make such a noise as that he cannot sleepe. His lazinesse also making his stomack to be dull, there is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
studium delitiarum an accurate study of delicates to entise his stomack to a full feeding: but this cannot entise sleepe to come unto him. And therefore although he doe invite it by his soft downy bed, which on either side of his body riseth up 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
aggeris instar, like an high banck, as if it would keepe in by force the pleasant streames of sleepe, yet he cannot entertaine it. Whereas the poore labourer, whose hard lodging is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , iners artificium quietis, the unartificiall art of rest, huggeth his rest most sweetly, and findeth no disturbance untill the time of rising awakeneth him. It is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
plena & perfecta dormitio, a full and perfect sleeping, which he enjoyeth: whereas though the other may have some
imperfect unquiet slumberings, yet his abundance of eating will not suffer him 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to sleepe soundly, which are the Originall words here used.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome applying this verse to a spirituall sense, sayth, Porro quia somnus, communis de hac vita exitus appellatur: melior erit requies ejus qui operatur in praesenti; & secundum vires suas in bonis operibus conversatur, quàm eorum divitum, de quibus scribitur, vae vobis divitibus, quia recepistis consolationem vestram, Moreover, because the common passage out of this life is called a sleepe, better shall be his rest who worketh in this present life, and according to his abilitie is conversant and busied in good works, then of those rich men of whom it is written, Woe unto you that are rich, Mat. 6.24. for you have received your consolation.

q.p: VER. 13. There is a sore evill which I have seene under the Sunne, namely, riches kept for the owners thereof to their hurt.
VER. 14. But those riches perish by evill travell; and he begetteth a Sonne, and there is nothing in his hand.
VER. 15. As he came forth of his Mothers wombe, naked shall he returne to goe as he came, and shall take nothing of his labour, which he may carry away in his hand.
VER. 16. And this also is a sore evill, that in all points as he came, so shall he goe: and what profit hath he that hath laboured for the winde?
VER. 17. All his dayes also he eateth in darknesse, and hee hath much sorrow and wrath with his sicknesse.

div.p:
Verse 13. There is, sayth the Preacher as pointing at it, and shewing it unto us, and as desirous that others should see it, and take notice of it, as well as himselfe had seene it and observed it. There is a sore evill: the Septuagint doe reade it, Infirmitas pessima, a sore disease; St. Hierome Languor pessimus, a sore weaknesse; Pagnine and Arias Montanus, Mala infirmitas, an evill disease; Tremellius, Malum afferens aegritudinem, an evill
bringing sicknesse. And surely, as St. Ambrose speaketh,Ambros. in Psal. 1.
Malus est languor qui bonam quietem mentis aufert, It is an evill weaknesse which taketh away the good quietnesse of the minde: it is an evill sicknesse which taketh away the sweet sleepe of the body, whereof the former verse speaketh. And what is this disease, but the dropsie of the soule? For distendunt divitiae, non implent, Riches doe but stuffe out the soule, they doe not fill it; even as in a dropsie, drinking swels the body, but doth not stay the thirst. What is this infirmitie, but the wolfe of the heart? For insatiabilis edacitas cupiditatis est, The devouring of covetousnesse is insatiable; even as the infirmitie of the wolfe devoureth continually. What is this sicknesse, but to use the words of St. Ambrose, Quaedam animarum pestilentia, quae corrupto salubrium cogitationum spiramine, gravi odore terrae illius ac flagitiosae voraginis contrahitur, lues aestuantium passionum miseranda grassatur, A kind of plague of the soule, which the spirits of wholesome thoughts being corrupted, is gotten from the ill sent of that earthly disposition, and pernicious gulfe, a woefull pestilence of the boyling affections which seiseth upon them. But this translation supposeth as I conceive the Originall word to be 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth sicknesse or infirmitie: whereas it is not that word which now wee finde, but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
dolorificum, an evill bringing sorrow, as Buxtorfius giveth the force of it. And surely, whatsoever the contentment of a covetous minde may be for the present, it will bring sorrow, or bring forth sorrow at the last. Yea, indeed it is an evill, which as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifieth, from whence the Originall word here used is derived, with sorrow bringeth forth sorrow, with the sorrow of care and wretchednesse, bringeth forth the sorrow of Gods wrath against it. Or else the radicall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying also permanere, residere, to remaine, to abide; the word here used, may signifie such a sore evill, as sticketh close, and is not easily removed. Which I have seene under the Sunne: that is, literally in this world, metaphorically it may be expounded, under the Sunne-shine of plentie and abundance, under the light of knowledge and understanding. Riches kept for the owners thereof unto their hurt: Saint Ambrose considering the words of the rich man in the Gospel, when he sayth to his soule, Thou hast much goods layd up for many yeares; first, he noteth, Nescit avarus bona, nisi ea quae quaestuosa sunt nominare, A covetous man knoweth not how to call any thing goods, save those things that are gainefull. But then permitting him to call them so, he sayth, Cur ergo de bonis facitis mala, quum de malis bona facere debeatis? Why then doe yee make good things to be evill, when yee ought to make evill things to be good? Ei qui uti scit, Ambros. l. de Nabut. c. 7.
multa bona sunt, ei qui nescit uti verè mala, To him that knoweth how to use them, they are much good, to him that knoweth not how to use them, they are truely hurt and evill. Give them to the poore, thy righteousnesse remaineth for ever, and what greater good can there be then this is? But whilest thou keepest them wretchedly, and as thou thinkest, dost keepe them for thy selfe, who art the owner of them, Saint Ambrose
telleth thee truely,Ambros. Ibid. Non tibi reservas, sed potius tibi ipsi adimis: magis enim servares tibi, si dispertires aliis, Thou doest not keepe them for thy selfe, but rather takest them away from thy selfe: for thou shouldest better keepe them for thy selfe, if thou diddest distribute them to others. The same Father marking the rich fooles words, when he sayth, I will pull downe my barnes, addeth, Rightly doth he say, I will pull downe my barnes, Destruit enim horrea, qui non novit sua frumenta dividere, sed claudere, He pulleth downe his barnes, who doth not send abroad his corne, but shutteth it up. Destruit sua dives, qui nescit aeterna, That rich man destroyeth his owne, his owne temporall things, who seeketh not eternall. Rectè destruit, qui sapienter aedificare non novit, He doth truely pull downe, who knoweth not how to build up wisely: he truly hurteth himselfe, who keeping his riches for himselfe, doth no good with them. But the words of the Text being, Kept for the owners thereof, or, Kept to the owners thereof, they may seeme to imply, as if they were kept and preserved by some other for them. And indeed God doth preserve their riches for these covetous wretches, expecting when they will bestow them to his glory, which he keepeth for their comfort: but they possessing them unprofitably, they are but kept for their hurt.Chald. Costi. Thus the Chaldee Paraphrase doth give the sense of the place, saying, Est autem perniciosum malum quod vidi sub sole, cui medicina non est: homo qui divitias congregat, ne{que} eas ad pietatem confert, parùm sane praevidens dierum finem. Haec enim substantia illi in perniciem venturo saeculo conservatur, There is a pernicious evill which I have seene under the Sunne, for which there is no remedy, a man who gathereth riches, and doth not bestow them upon the workes of devotion, little indeed foreseeing the end of his dayes. For this substance is kept unto him, for his hurt and mischiefe in the world to come.

Verse 14. From the perishing of the rich, the Preacher goeth on to the perishing of their riches:Salvianus contra avaritiam. l. 1. For so Salvianus also understandeth the former verse: who citing the verse thus; Pessimum ac feralissimum morbi genus divitiae conservatae in malum domini sui, A most grievous and a most lamentable kinde of sicknesse, are riches kept to the hurt of the owner; he addeth, Verum est: quid enim pejus aut quid miserius, quam si quis praesentia bona in mala futura convertat, & quae ad hoc à Deo data sunt ut pararetur ex iis vitae beatitudo perpetua, per hoc ipsa quaeratur mors & damnatio sempiterna. In quo & illud considerandum est, quod si servatae divitiae ad malum hominis conservantur, quanto utique ad majus malum coacervantur? It is true: for what is worse or more miserable, then if any one doe turne the present good things into future evill things, and those things which God hath given to this end, that from them may be gotten the eternall blessednesse of life, that thereby death it selfe should be sought, and everlasting damnation. In which this also is to be considered, that if riches being kept, are kept to the hurt of man, then how much greater is the hurt to which they are heaped up? But to passe to the riches themselves, which passe away so soone. The Preacher sayth,
But those riches perish: hee saith not they shall perish, but to shew how suddenly how certainely they vanish, in the present time hee saith, they perish. The Originall therefore may not amisse be rendred. And the riches themselves perish; our translation hath it, But those riches, that is, those which a covetous minde hath gotten and possesseth. Wherefore Baldvinus applying to this purpose, the Manna of the Israelites, Baldvinus in Alleg. Tilmanni. which kept unto the morning perished, saith of it, Hoc exemplo de manna damnatur malum avaritiae, qua pecunia male parta, possessori suo in vermem vertitur, By this example of the Manna the evill of covetousnesse is condemned, by which money ill gotten and kept perisheth and is turned into wormes to the possessour of it. By evill travell: by the evill travell of those who make a prey of them. For as Lyra speaketh, Per hoc raptores & cupidi insidiantur illi; By the meanes of his wealth ravenous Catch-poles doe lay snares for him. Or else it may be rendred, In evill travell: that is, even in the evill travell or his solicitous and vexing carefulnesse to preserve them.Clem. Alex. stromatum lib. 4. For as Clemens Alexandrinus citeth out of Antiphanes the Comoedian, Pluto is lame when he commeth unto men; but when he goeth away he hath wings. Or else in evill travell, that is in an evill vexation and breaking of his heart for the perishing of them: and then as Isidore relateth,Isidore Pelusiota lib. 2. Epist. 149. that anciently the manner was after a feast to take the harp and to sing unto it this song, O divitiae utinam nec in terra nec in mari videamini, O riches, I wish that ye might never be seene either by Land or Sea; so the same is the ditty of his pensive heart. And hee begetteth a sonne: the manner is of many, that to cover their covetousnesse they plead their care for their children, and their affection to them, Quasi vero quicunque patres sunt, nequaquam aut possint aut debeant omnino esse, nisi divites, & amare liberos suos sine opum multiplicatione non valeant, As if whosoever are parents, either cannot or ought not to bee so, unlesse they be rich; and that they could not love their children without abundance of wealth, as Salvianus speaketh.Salv. contra Avaritiam lib. 1. But therefore it is sometimes the justice of God to take away their riches, and to leave them nothing to leave unto their children, for whom as they pretended their covetous scraping was. The mention of begetting a sonne is here set downe after the perishing of his riches; as if the Preacher to shew Gods wrath against such covetous wretches would imply unto us, that while they have their wealth, God doth not give them a sonne, that they might not have the comfort and hope of leaving it unto him; but when their wealth is gone, then they have a sonne, that their misery may bee the greater by leaving him in misery. And there is nothing in his hand: because there was so much covetousnesse in the heart of the father, there is no support of sustenance in the hand of the son. There is nothing in his hand, no not so much as to labour; but as Lyra speaketh, Bonis paternis privatus, Lyra in hunc versum. ad laborandum pro victu acquirendo non est assuetus, Being deprived of his fathers goods, he is not used to labour, whereby to get his meate.

Verse 15. Poverty is the porter of mans life, that lets him in, that
lets him out: it lets him in naked as leaving him to himselfe, it lets him out naked as making him to leave all that he hath behind him. Some it lets in, and followes still through their whole life, even till it lets them out againe. And although some it leave for a time, yet oftentimes it meets with them againe. Yea even he doth sometimes fall upon it, who is most carefull to drive it away, and thinketh himselfe to bee farthest from it. The best way therefore is so to shunne it, as not to be afraid to meet it: not by a carelesse negligence to lye naked to the assaults of it, and yet not to bee disquieted with vexing impatiency, if it strip a man of all, and leave him naked, as he came forth of his mothers wombe. It is St. Chrysostomes question upon the like words of Iob. Sed cujus tandem uteri meminit? Iob 1.21. Chrysost. in Catena Gr. Nempe primi illius opificii, suae è terra coagmentationis, But what wombe is it, that is spoken of? Namely the wombe of the earth, from whence man was framed in that first working of God. And surely as there, so here, the returning that is added doth make it necessary so to be understod: for it is to the wombe of the earth that man returneth. Now from this wombe man came naked also, and then as Saint Chrysostome also speaketh,Chrys. Ibid. Nuditas donum fuit, munusque imperatorium, ut adhibito studio videret homo quemadmodum imbres declinaret, quemadmodum sapienter frigus arceret, quemadmodum ad depellendos ictus muniretur, &c. & aliam & aliam solertiam nuditas genuit, Nakednesse was a gift and a royall bounty, that by study and care man might find out, how to shelter himselfe from raine, how wisely to keepe away cold, how to fence himselfe for the resisting of blowes, &c. and thus man being brought forth naked, his nakednesse brought forth one invention after another. But that man returneth naked this is the punishment of God for sin. And well it were if he that returnes naked for sin, did returne naked without sinne.Origenes Hom. 1.
Origen speaking of Iob saith, Nudus peculio sed & peccato, nudus substantia sed & injustitia; nudus malis, bonis vero omnibus indutus, justitia vestitus, sanctitate circundatus, charitate ornatus, misericordia ac bonis operibus coronatus, Naked of Cattle, but naked also of sinne, naked of substance but naked also of wickednesse; naked of evils but having on all good things, clothed with righteousnesse, encompassed with holinesse, adorned with charity, crowned with mercy and good workes. But the covetous wretch, as he returneth naked of his wealth, so he returneth loaded with his sinnes, loaded with the cryes of the poore that have not beene relieved by him, loaded with the curses of those that have beene wronged by him. And whither doth he returne? Of Iob Cl. Alexandrinus saith, Revertitur ad locum ubi Deus est verus pater & mater nostra, Clem. Alex. Catena Gr. He returneth to the place where God is, who is our true Father and Mother both. But the covetous wretch returneth to the Devill, who as he was the father of sinne in man, so is the punisher of man for sinne; and as he bringeth forth wealth to many by the devises which he teacheth them, so doth he bring forth for them torments in hell. To goe as hee came: it is the manner to send away unwelcome guests as they came, and a covetous wretch being a most unwelcome guest to the world, as
doing no good in it, hee is also sent away as he came. Or as a bad servant is used, and turned away to goe as he came; so a covetous wretch, who is so bad a servant to God, neglecting his businesse for which hee made him rich, and committed his talent to him, is by God turned away with shame to goe as he came. So shall he goe, and when perhaps he hath stayd a good time and spent the time carefully, in his owne wayes, and by his cate hath done much and laboured hard in his worldly businesse; so shall he goe, as if he had done nothing, as if then he were to begin, and as when he first came, so shall he goe: this must needs be a sore evill: And shall take nothing of his labour; Nihil attulit natus, nihil hinc auferet sublatus, Hee brought nothing when he was borne and brought forth, and when he is taken away he shall take away nothing,Orig. in c. 1. Iobi. saith Origen. Nothing of his labour: although it was his labour that did get it, that is not a sufficient plea for the keeping of it. Hee that laboureth to get, must labour to get well, and having well gotten by well labouring, he must also use well that which he hath gotten, or else he may justly feare, least God in justice deprive him of it. Which hee may carry in his hand: that is, which hee may give away when he dyeth. For the hand being the instrument of giving, the Preacher useth this phrase to expresse a giving. Nothing therfore hath he to give nothing to his children, nothing to give to his frinds, or kindred, nothing to give to the poore, that though at last, yet by shewing mercy to the distressed he might find mercy with God. Charity is most acceptable to God, when it is shewed to the poore in the time of health and life; but I will not deny it acceptance with God even in death also. Howsoever let me say, as Salvianus doth, Licet offerat, Salvianus contra Avaritiam. l. 2.
oret Deum ut lenta sua placeat oblatio, plangens ad ipsum quod tarde offerat, plangens & poenitens quod non prius, Although a man doe give, let him beseech God, that his slow giving may be pleasing to him; lamenting this very thing that he giveth so late, bewayling and repenting that hee did not give sooner. But sometimes it is the justice of God that hee whose wretched covetousnesse in his life, would not give when he had it, shall at his death have nothing in his hand to give, that being taken away which he would not give.Fulgos.

Verse 16. When Constantine the Emperour had shewed the King of Persia, all the good and glorious things of Rome, then did the King shew him this sore evill whereof the Preacher speakes here; for thereupon he making answer said, Mira quidem haec, sed ut video, sicut in Persia, sic Romae homines moriuntur, These things are indeed wonderfull, but I see that as in Persia, so at Rome men die also: thereby implying that wheresoever any one is, whether at Rome or in Persia, or how great soever any one is, whether King of Persia or Emperour of Rome, when hee dyes, he must goe as he came. In all points as he came: What? In all points? He came a child, shall he goe away a child also? Yes,Chrys. Hom. 47. ad Popul. Antioch. if he be such a covetous wretch as here the Preacher speaketh of. For as Saint Chrysostome saith, Si nondum vilitatem rerum temporalium conspicimus, nondum viri facti sumus, scientes quod haec sunt puerilia, If we doe not discerne
the basenesse of temporall things, we are not yet become men, knowing that these are childish things. As he came so he goeth: hee came from nothing,Iob 6.8. Greg. in c. 6. Iobi. he goeth to nothing, so Iob speaking of such saith, Their paths of their wayes are turned aside, they goe to nothing and perish. And Saint Gregory expounding those words of Iob saith, In vacuum ambulant qui nihil secum de fructu sui laboris portant. Alius nam{que} adipiscendis honoribus desudat, alius multiplicandis facultatibus aestuat, alius promerendis laudibus anhelat, sed quia juncta haec quisque moriens deserit, labores in vacuum perdit, quia secum ante Iudicem nihil tulit, They goe to nothing, because they cary with them nothing of the fruit of their labour. One sweareth in getting of honours, another toyleth in multiplying riches, another is out of breath in hunting after pleasures: but because every one dying leaveth all these though joyned together, he looseth his labour for nothing, because hee bringeth nothing with him before the Iudge.Chrysost. in Euangelis. Hom. 15.
And what profit hath he? Let Saint Chrysostome answer for riches, who speaking of them saith, In vita cruciant, in morte deserunt, & in divino tribunali divites ipsos accusant, In his life they torment him, at his death they forsake him; and before the divine tribunall they are ready to accuse him. Now being things of no profit, what usage is fitter for them then to tread them under our feete? Doth not the Prophet David tell us, Psalm. 8.6. & 8. That God hath put all worldly things under our feete, all sheepe and Oxen, yea and the beasts of the field, the foules of the ayre, and the fishes of the Sea? Nos ergo bona temporalia in eo loco teneamus, in quo Deus ea constituit, Let us place temporall things in that manner as God hath set them,Eusebius Emissenus. Zach. 6.1. as Eusebius Emissenus speaketh. Let not our hearts bee set upon those things, which God hath set under our feete, and which for their profit deserve no better regard of us. For what profit hath he that laboureth for the wind? The vision of the foure Chariots which the Prophet Zachary saw, Zach. 6.3. & 4. is by the common opinion of all learned men both Iewes and Christians, as Saint Hierome and Saint Cyrill affirme, interpreted to bee understood of the foure Monarchs: but the Angell which talked with the Prophet being asked by him, what they were, hee answered, These are the foure winds of heaven. And indeed what is the greatest glory of this world, but a wind that passeth away, and commeth not again? Philo therefore speaking of the Kings of the earth concludeth rightly,Philo, in libro, quod Deus sit Jmmutab. Nihil in humanis rebus praeter umbram & levissimam auram, sine mora praetervolantem, That there is nothing in humane things besides a shadow and a very light ayre, which without staying flyeth away. And whereas Seneca saith, Crede mihi levia sunt, propter quae non leviter excandescimus, beleeve mee they are light things, for which wee are not lightly moved; let us at least beleeve the Preacher, who tels us they are wind.

Ver. 17. The life and death of a covetous wretch is here set forth unto us: his death in the next two verses before, his life in this ver. All his dayes: he keepeth no festivals, he observeth no daies of joy and gladnes, but all his dayes are alike to him. And though they bee dayes to him,
dayes of plenty and prosperity, dayes of a sunne-shining fortune, yet he maketh them nights to himselfe, he eateth in darknesse, ashamed justly that any one should see how coursely, how scantly he feedeth. He hath none that eareth with him; that would bee too much light to witnesse his basenesse. Hee loveth to eate in darknesse so much, that for want of meate his hand can scarce find the way to his mouth. Or else to take his eating whereby life is maintained to signifie his life, all the dayes of his life are spent in darkenesse, in a strange darkenesse of mind. And therefore Saint Cyprian saith, O detestabilis cacitas mentium, Cyprianus, Epist. 2.
& cupiditatis insanae profunda caligo, quum exonerare se possit & levare ponderibus, pergit magis fortunis augentibus incubare, pergit paenalibus cumulis pertinaciter adhaerere, O the detestable blindnesse of minds, and the deepe darknesse of mad covetousnesse, when that hee may unburthen himselfe, and ease his weights, hee goes on to hugge more closely his vexing riches, and cleaveth the faster to his tormenting heapes. All his days are spent in darknesse, he seeth not the wants and miseries of others: for though he sees them, he affordeth not help, as if he saw them not.Chrysostom. Homil. 14. in 1am ad Corinth. Wherefore S. Chryso. saith, Explica utrius{que} animam, & ejus qui despicit pecunias, & ejus qui non despicit: & videbis quod hic quidem est similis furentibus, nihil volens videre nec audire, ille vero est similis portui liberato à fluctibus, & est omnium amicus, Vnfold the mindes of both, of him that despiseth monies, and of him that despiseth them not; and thou shalt see that this man is like to them that are mad, and will see nothing, heare nothing; the other is like to a haven freed from tossing waves, and is a friend to all. All his dayes are spent in darkenesse, In obscurity and basenesse of life, being of no esteeme, no credit where he liveth: for so the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 may also signifie. And yet hee hath 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
indignationem indignation (which is the Originall word that followes and is translated sorrow) because he is no more regarded, no more reckoned of seeing his wealth is so great. But to follow the reading of our translation, wee may distinguish the latter words of the verse thus, Hee hath much sorrow, by strangers, much wrath by his owne household, much sicknesse by himselfe. First, much sorrow from strangers: for as Saint Chrysostome speaketh, Qui pecunias diligit, innumeros habet suspectos, Chrysost. ad Populum. & multos accusatores, invides, calumniantes & insidiantes, He that loveth riches, suspecteth numberlesse people, and hath many accusers, envying him, slandering him, and laying snares for him. Secondly, much wrath by his owne household: for, as it is said that Absalom did,Chrysostom. Homil. 13. in Epist. ad Romanos. hee weigheth the hayres of his head, Et jacturam si faciat, ut vel obolum perdat, gravissime omnium se affligit ac vitam amisisse arbitratur, And if he suffer any dammage, so that he lose a farthing or a halfe penny, he thinketh himselfe to be afflicted above all measure, and even to have lost his life, as Saint Chrysostome also speaketh. Thirdly, his owne much sicknesse is the vexing malady of his owne tormenting care,Chrys. Hom. 14. in 1am ad Corinth. and this is such a sicknesse, that Saint Chrysostome speaking of it saith, Fugiamus ergo hunc morbum, fugiamus hanc gehennam, est enim gehenna cupiditas
ista, Let us flye therefore from this disease, let us flye from this hell, for this covetous desire is a very hell. And it is said his sicknesse, because hee puts it on himselfe:Sen. Ep. 83. for as Seneca speaketh, Non habet ut putamus fortuna longas manus, neminem occupat nisi haerentem sibi, The misery of wealth, hath not as wee thinke long armes, it possesseth none but them, who by love doe sticke and adhere unto it. Or else to take all in reference to himselfe only. His sorrow wee may see growing in the field of the rich man in the Gospell,Amb. Serm. 81. of which Saint Ambrose sayth, Video quod non tam redditus largiores, quam gemitus attulit graviores, I see that it did not bring forth unto him, so much larger revenues as more grievous sorrowes. His wrath against himselfe is because hee never gets fast enough, for to him, Major acquisitio fit major accessio paupertatis, His greater gayning is but an encrease of his poverty. And when hee hath a hundred talents, hee is still the poorer because hee desireth a thousand, when hee hath a thousand he is still the poorer because he desireth tenne thousand,Chrys. Hom. 14. in 1am. ad Corinth. Bern. ep. 113. as Saint Chrysostome speaketh. Lastly, the feaver of his fretting carefulnesse is so continuall, that if hee have any respit of contentment, it is true as Saint Bernard speaketh, Praterit jocunditas non reditura, & manet anxietas non relictura, The contentment passeth away not to returne, the anxiety of his heart remaineth never to leave him. How well therefore doth such a one deserve the stile, which in the Gospell is given him?Basil. Hom. in ditescentes. And of which S. Basil speaking saith, Audi miser te dignam appellationem, quam tibi nullus hominum, sed ipse Dominus indidit, stulte hac nocte animam tuam à te repetent: superat aeternam paenam irrisio ista stultitiae, Heare O wretch the appellation worthy of thee, and which no man, but the Lord himselfe hath given thee, Thou foole this night shall thy soule be taken from thee, or required of thee: this scoff: of thy folly exceedeth thine eternall punishment.

q.p: VER. 18. Behold that which J have seene: it is good and comely for one to eate and drinke, and to enioy the good of all his labour that he taketh under the Sunne, all the dayes of his life which God giveth him: for it is his portion.
VER. 19. Every man also to whom God hath given riches and wealth, and hath given him power to eate thereof and to take his portion, and to reioyce in his labour, this is the gift of God
VER. 20. For he shall not much remember the dayes of his life, because God answereth him in the joy of his heart.

div.p:
Verse 18. This is the fourth time that the Preacher hath set downe this sentence, and seeing he repeateth it so often, wee have reason to regard it the more. Behold: That which the Preacher had beheld in the world, he bids us to behold in this verse: that which he had seene and looked into, and upon sight, in his judgement approoved to be true, that he proposeth to our sight, judgement, and approbation. Mark. 9.5. & 6. It is good: St. Peter sayd, It is good to be here, when he was with Christ upon the mountaine, but the Spirit of God noteth, that he wist not what he sayd. And Proclus speaking of the same thing,Proclus Ser. de Transfigura. thus setteth out St. Peter by occasion of it, Petrus more suo semper praceps, Peter after his manner alwayes hasty. It is good therefore for every one to consider what he sayth, and to see into it, as here the Preacher doth, before he say of it, It is good. It is good, good, but unto them that are good, because they will doe it in a good manner. And comely: So that a man doth not destroy his owne comelinesse by it, doth not by eating and drinking make himselfe a beast, doth not by rejoycing make himselfe a foole, and make the devill sport. Comely it is,Bernard. in Canti. Serm. 24. but as St. Bernard speaketh, Quid indecentius, quàm curvum recto corpore gerere animum? What more uncomely, then in an upright body to have a crooked minde, bowed and bended downe like a beast to these sensuall contentments onely? Comely it is, but as one well speaketh, Indecens quidem est avem alas habentem non in altum evolare. Habemus autem alas excellentiores illis, intellectum scilicet et voluntatem, quibus altius volare valemus, It is an uncomely thing for a bird that hath wings not to fly. But wee have wings more excellent then those, namely, our understanding and will, by which wee can fly higher. Wee must therefore make it our chiefest joy, to fly up to God, that so wee may be able to say with the Prophet David, Thou hast put gladnesse in my heart,
Psal. 4.7. more then in the time that their corne and wine encreased. For one to eate and drinke: if he be one that can doe no more, let him doe that, let him take with comfort, that which God sendeth him, and cheerefully eate and drinke that which he hath: if he be one to whom the hand of Gods blessing hath been more liberall, let him enjoy it with thankfulnesse to God, and with fitting delight to himselfe. It is not a token of Gods displeasure to enjoy the pleasures of this life, nor is it a thing displeasing to God, to rejoyce in them. Saint Gregory sayth very well,Greg. Mor l. 23. c. 4.
Scit redemptor ecclesiae et in hoc itinere solatia venienti tribuere, et pervenienti ad aeternam patriam superna praemia reservare, The Redeemer of the Church knoweth how to give comforts in this journey unto him that travaileth, and how to reserve heavenly rewards for him that resteth in his eternall Countrey.
And seeing the Preacher sayth, It is good, I know not why any one should say,Hieronym. in hunc vers. it is bad. The exposition of St. Hierome upon these words is this, that it is good, Ad comparationem ejus, qui opibus suis in curarum tenebris vescitur, In comparison of him, of whom the verse before speaketh, that feedeth on his riches in the darknesse of cares. And the reason which he addeth, is very proper, Hic enim voluptas parva est in fruendo, ibi vero solicitudinum tantummodo magnitudo, For here is some little pleasure in enjoying, but there is onely a greatnesse of cares. But to proove it also in it selfe to be good, the Preacher addeth, It is good to enjoy the good: now it cannot but be good to enjoy good. Then good it is, the good of this life, but not the good of man, not the good for which man was created. The good it is which man may enjoy, but not the good on which man must set his heart: the good it is which the earth affordeth, but which in comparison of heaven is rather evill than good. Of all his labour: if the good be, but the hire of hard labour, let a man enjoy that, that he may be the better enabled to labour: if the good be the benefit of more gainefull labour, let a man be the more free in enjoying of it. All labour is not the same, neither hath all labour the same successe, but what the successe is, that let a man enjoy. That he taketh under the Sunne: Let his life see the comfort of that, which under the Sunne he hath seene how to get; let others also in a carefull and wise manner, see how God hath blessed his labour under the Sunne: let him not eate in darknesse and solitary sorrowfulnesse, that which he hath laboured for under the Sunne. All the dayes of his life: the Originall is, the number of the dayes of his lifes. First, the number of his dayes, for mans life is but a number, and as in number, there is a perfect end every where, in two as well as in three, in three as well as in foure; so in mans life there may be a perfect end every where, this day as well as to morrow, and to morrow as well as next day: and in all, man is but a day-labourer under the Sunne. Secondly, it is sayd, of his lifes, (to make use of that though it be an Hebraisme:) for there is the life of youth, the life of manhood, the life of age, and to every life there belongeth a different manner of enjoying the good of his labour, as well as a different kinde of labour is proper unto each of them. Which God giveth him: it is God which maketh up the number of mans dayes for him; so long as he addeth his supportance, they continue; when he subtracteth the stay of his hand, they are ended presently. If he give bountifully, our dayes are many; if he be sparing to give, our dayes are few and quickly gone. For it is his portion: his portion in this earthly Canaan, which GOD hath set out for him: his portion which his labour hath gotten and possessed. But it is but a portion, but a small portion onely of that which is provided for him; and therefore let every one so enjoy this, as that he be carefull not to lose the other: let every one so husband this portion, as that he may finde the encrease of it in the Kingdome of glory in Heaven.

Verse 19. When God commanded Moyses to strike the rocke, Exod. 17.5. & 6. he sayth, Behold, I will stand before thee there: Moyses striketh, but God standeth there; and it is the note of Lippomannus, Lippomannus in Catena. Iubetur Moyses astante Deo percutere petram, ne gratia tanti beneficii homini & non Deo tribuatur, Moyses is commanded, God being present, to strike the rocke, least the favour of so great a benefit should be ascribed to man and not to God. And surely, God it is who maketh the streame of wealth and riches to abound to every one: though the diligence and care of man be imployed, yet it is God who standeth by, and maketh the waters to flow. The rich therefore in estate must be poore in spirit; for so Hilarius Hilarius. expoundeth the poore in spirit, Qui nihil quicquam suum esse, nihil proprium, sed cuncta dono parentis unius tribui agnoscunt, Who acknowledge nothing at all to be theirs, nothing to be proper to themselves, but all things to be given by one Father, even the Father of lights, Iames 1.17. from whom commeth every good and perfect gift, as St. Iames speaketh. This is that which the Preacher teacheth every man to whom God hath given riches and wealth, and hath given him power to eate thereof. He that hath meate in his mouth, hath not power to eate it, unlesse God doe give it unto him: without God wee are not able to doe any thing. The French translation doth reade this very well, Dont il le fait maistre pour en manger, whereof he is made Master to eate of it. For the covetous wretch is not master of his owne wealth;Ambros. de Nabut. c. 14. but as St. Ambrose speaketh, Non tam possessor est divitiarum quam ab eis possidetur, Is not so much a possessour of his riches, as rather is possessed by them. He therefore doth not eate of his riches, that is, doth not make use of them for his necessary occasions. And surely, this is not done, unlesse God doe give it, and give a power to doe it. For there be powers that doe resist men in it, even the powers of darknesse in their malice outwardly, and in the strong power of mans owne corruption inwardly. And to take his portion: that is, sayth Olympiodorus, Olympiodorus. Qui futurae foelicitatis partem hic aliquam fruitionemque accepit, Who here hath some part and fruition of his future happinesse. And indeed to them who serve God in their wealth, their riches are but the first part, and the least part of that blessednesse which afterwards God will bestow upon them. But to take his portion here, I understand to be, to take contentment in his portion, to be satisfied with it, and not with greedinesse of minde never to have enough. The Prophet Isaiah, speaking of the covetous Israelites, sayth, Their land is full of silver and gold: their land, their purses, not themselves.
