And so it is with many, to whom God doth not give a heart to take their portion with contentment. And to rejoyce in his labour. The Chaldee Paraphrase applyeth this joy unto heaven, where it is,Chald. Pard. that true joy is to be had: and accordingly giving the sense of the whole verse it selfe, Omnis quoque homo cui dedit Deus divitias & substantiam, & potestatem, dedit ei Deus ut comedat ex eo in hoc saeculo, & ut faciat ex eo eleemosynam, & ut recipiat mercedem perfectam patris sui in saeculo venturo et gaudeat in labore suo cum justis, Every man also to whom God hath
given riches and wealth, and God hath given him power that he may eate of it in this world, and that he may shew charitie by it, and that he may receive a perfect reward from his Father in the world to come, and may rejoyce in his labour with the righteous. But to understand the joy of this life, to rejoyce in his labour, is beyond the supplying of necessaries which nature requireth, even to delight himselfe, and to give himselfe a recompence of fitting pleasure for the paines of his labour.Lyra in hunc versum. This is the gift of God. Lyra tels us, that the gifts of God in this life, are of three degrees, Majora, media, minima, Greater, middle, lesser; the greater are the gifts of grace and vertue, the middle are the gifts of health and strength, and other bodily blessings; the least are riches and wealth. But seeing these are the gift of God to man, it must be mans care to give them to God againe.Salvianus contrae Avaritiam. l. 4. For as Salvianus speaketh; Hoc dignior est abs{que} dubio largitate nostra, quia nobis ipse ante largitus est: hoc justius ei officiis respondere tenemur quo beneficiis illius magis impares sumus, By so much is he doubtlesse more worthy of our bountie, by how much he hath been first bountifull to us: and therefore are wee the more justly bound to answere him in our offices of dutie, because wee are most unable to answere his favours. Many are ready to acknowledge their wealth to be Gods gift:Salvianus contra Avaritiam. l. 1. but the same Father tels us, Hoc est agnoscere munus Dei, ut datis suis illum honoremus, à quo data ipsa accepimus, This is to acknowledge the gift of God, to honour him with his gifts, of whom wee have received the gifts themselves.

Verse 20. It is the solicitous care of mans heart for the things of this life, that in a great measure maketh his life miserable unto him. The Preacher therefore speaking here of one that leadeth a comfortable life, sayth, He shall not much remember: not much, and yet something; for he must not be carelesse, not wholy negligent in looking to the affayres of his life.Gregor. Moral. l. 9. c. 40. Saint Gregory therefore noteth well, Quia solicitos nos esse veritas in crastinum prohibet, habere utcunque curam in praesentibus non negat, Because the truth forbiddeth us to take care for to morrow, he doth not deny but that wee may take care for the present. Not too little, as well as not much is the rule of Wisedome and Religion. He shall not much remember the dayes of his life: Sorrow shall not make him thinke the dayes of his life to be too many, nor calling to minde how bad they have beene which he hath past, to wish that they may be few which are to come, nor complaining as shee doth in the Poet; Cur mortis adempta est conditio? Possem tantos finire dolores, Why is the condition of death taken away from me? I might make an end of these so many griefes. But I rather take the meaning of the words to be this, He shall not much thinke, nor be troubled in his minde, how to provide for the dayes of his life, he shall not loose the comfort of the present dayes, by being solicitous for the dayes to come. The foole in the Gospel, who was much troubled with pulling downe and building up, Longos annorum ambitus, spei vanitate in horreis simul includebat, Did shut up all at once in his barnes, the long circuits of many
yeares, as Gregory Nyssene speaketh; but as the Father addeth,Gregor. Nyssen. de Oratione Domin. Annon una nox illam somniatam spem confutavit? Did not one night confute that dreamed hope? It is for this day, not for dayes, that our Saviour Christ doth teach us to pray. Doe not therefore much remember the dayes of thy life. Doe not take much care for many dayes: for as Gregory Nyssene speaketh; Qui diem tibi dat, etiam ea quae ad diem pertinent dabit, He that giveth the day, will also give thee those things which appertaine to the day: he that giveth thee many dayes, will also give thee that which shall be sufficient for many dayes. Who is it that maketh the Sunne to shine? Who is it that maketh the darknesse of the night to vanish away? Who is it that turneth and caryeth the heaven about, whereby he maketh day? Is it not God? Et qui haec tibi & alia tanta dat, nunquid tuo eget auxilio, ut praestet carni tuae id quod necessitas requirit? He that giveth these, and other great things unto thee, doth he need thy helpe, that he may provide for thy selfe that which necessitie requireth? Quae corvorum arva sunt? Quae aquilarum horrea? Annon una omnibus victum suppeditat divina voluntas? What plowed fields have the crowes? What barnes have the Eagles? Doth not one divine will of God supply food unto them all? So Gregory Nyssene. Because God answereth him in the joy of his heart. This translation supposeth a question to be made, and indeed it is a common question in solicitous worldly hearts, Quid faciam? What shall I doe? What shall I doe the next yeare? What shall I doe in mine old age? What shall I doe all the dayes of my life? The rich foole in the Gospel, making this question in the Gospel, Chrysologus would know who it is to whom he speaketh,Chrysologus, Serm. 104. and of whom he asketh it, and supposing it to be some one within him, he concludeth it to be the devill, who possesseth the hearts of such solicitous worldly people. But here God answereth, and that the question might not be asked, he answereth before hand, by giving a joyfulnesse and cheerefulnesse of heart, which relying upon Gods providence and goodnesse, is not troubled with such vexation of thoughts. Wherefore Chrysologus sayth, Noli homo inania providendo gemere, Chrysologus, Serm. 163.
noli caduca praeparando laborare, quia prandii tui semper & ubique Deus praeparator existit, et Creatoris ad prandium tota concurrit et advolat creatura, O man doe not sigh in providing vaine things, doe not labour in preparing fading things, because God is the preparer of thy dinner, at all times, and every where, and to the dinner of the Creatour, even all the creatures run and fly together. Cajetane readeth the latter part of the verse thus, Quia Deus testificatus est in laetitia cordis ejus, Because God hath testified in the joy of his heart: and this indeed is the most direct and proper signification of the Hebrew, as Tremellius also noteth. The meaning of the words, as Cajetane translateth them, himselfe giveth to be this,Cajetan. in hunc vers. Quia Deus dando in corde divitis jugem laetitiam, est tanquam praebens testimonium foelicitatis ejus, Because God giving in the heart of such a rich man a continuall cheerefulnesse, doth as it were give testimony and
witnesse of his happinesse. The Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used, may also be translated, Canens, singing, as if God himselfe did sing in the heart of such a one, and make musick unto him, to make him merry, and cheerefull, and joyfull. But from any translation, we may note that God is not onely in a strict, rigid, severe and sower looking heart, but in a merry and lightsome and free heart also. The Ruler did send for his guests from the open wayes to come to his feast, and they that live in an open and sociable freedome of life, may be as welcome to God, as they Whose cariage is composed of an austere severitie and gravitie. Vpon those words in the Canticles, Cant. 3.2. Gilbertus in Cantica. In the broad wayes I will seeke him whom my soule loveth, Gilbertus noteth, Non dedignatur etiam ab his qui foris sunt qui nulla arctioris vitae regula constringuntur mutuari virtutis insignia, reputans ferventiorem ibi frequenter affectum, ubi inferior fuerit ordinis gradus, Shee disdaineth not even from them who are without, and who are not bound with the rule of a strict life, to borrow the ornaments of vertue, reckoning that oftentimes there is more ardent affection, where there is a lower degree of orderly austeritie and strictnesse.

q.p: VER. 1. There is an evill which J have seene under the Sunne, and it is common amongst men.

VER. 2. A man to whom God hath given riches, wealth and honour, so that he wanteth nothing for his soule of all that he desireth; yet God giveth him not power to eate therof, but a stranger eateth it: This is vanity, and it is an evill disease.

VER. 3. If a man beget an hundred children, and live many yeares, so that the dayes of his yeeres bee many, and his soule be not filled with good, and also that he hath no buriall, J say that an untimely birth is better then hee.
VER. 4. For he commeth in with vanity, and departeth in darknesse, and his name shall bee covered with darknesse.
VER. 5. Moreover he hath not seene the Sunne, nor knowne any thing: this hath more rest then the other.

div.p:
Verse 1. IN this life which is filled with evils, in which respect Seneca saith, Nemo vitam eligeret si scienti daretur, No one would choose life, if it were proposed to one that did know it: easie it is to him that looketh any way, to say, there is an evill, and there is an evill, and therefore no marvell it is that the
Preacher doth so often say it: When our Saviour wept, Lazarus being dead,Hieronym. Saint Hierome saith, Doluit Lazarum non dormientum, sed potius resurgentum, & flebat quem cogebatur propter salvandos alios ad saeculum revocare, hanc vitam dans Dominus ingemiscebat, He lamented Lazarus not sleeping, but rather rising againe, and he wept for him, whom he was constrained for the salvation of others, to bring backe into the world, giving him this life he groaned.Concilium 4m. Toletanum. And so the fourth Councell of Toledo, Non ploravit Lazarum mortuum, sed ad hujus vitae aerumnas resuscitandum, He wept not for Lazarus being dead, but because he was to be raised to the miseries of this life againe. And surely, as it is easie to see the evils of this life, so it is not easie to keepe the eyes from teares in the seeing of them. Which I have seene: the Preacher was diligent in looking into the evils of mans life: and surely, it is good to see and consider them, that so wee may the more rightly judge of this life, and may bee the more willing to leave it, and to goe to a better. Wherefore Saint Hierome writing to Heliodorus saith,Hieronym. Ep. 3. quae est ad Heliodorum. O si possemus ascendere in sp •• ulam, de qua universam terram sub nostris pedibus cerneremus! jam tibi • stenderem orbis totius ruinas, gentes gentibus, & regnis regna collisa, alios tor •• eri, alios necari, alios absorberi fluctibus, alios ad servitutem trahi, O that, we could ascend some high watch Tower, from which we might behold the whole earth under our feete; I would even now shew thee nation against nation, kingdome against kingdome buckling together, some to bee tortured, others to be killed, some to be swallowed up in the Waves, others to be haled into bondage. It is one end for which God hath filled mans life with evils, that wee seeing them might not mistake our journey for our home. For travellers falling in their way upon some pleasant places, it is not seldome, Quod eorum gressus tardet pulchritudo itineris dum delectet, that the pleasure of their journey hindereth their going on, while that it doth delight them. And therefore while we are journying to heaven, it is needfull to see and observe the evils of the earth, Ne magis nos diu pergere quam citius pervenire delectet, Lest we be more delighted to be long in going,Greg. Mor. l. 2. c. 11. then quickly to come unto it, as Saint Gregory speaketh. Vnder the Sunne: it is under the Sunne that all the evill is, above the Sunne there is nothing but good. There be as Saint Ambrose speaketh,Ambrosius. Omnia bona in uno bono, All good things in one that is good. Quid enim ibi deesse potest, ubi Deus est, cui nihil deest? For what can there bee wanting, where God is to whom nothing is wanting? There it is as Saint Bernard speaketh,Bernardus. Vbi nihil sit quod nolis, & ubi totum sit quod velis, where there is nothing which thou wouldest not, and where there is every thing which thou wouldest. Ibi est quicquid expedit, quicquid delectat, omnes divitiae, omnis requies, omne solatium, There is whatsoever is needfull, whatsoever is delightfull, all rest, all comfort. There is Vita sine morte, juventus sine senectute, lux sine tenebris, gaudium sine tristitia, regnum sine commutatione, Augustin. Serm. 49. ad fratres in cremo. life without death, youth without old age, light without darknesse, joy without sorrow, a kingdome without changing, as Saint Austin speaketh. There the brightnesse of glory doth as farre
exceed the Sunne, as the brightnesse of the Sunne exceedeth all things that are under it. And it is common among men: to name man, is to name the subject of evill, and therefore St. Basil defineth man to be,Basilius Homil. 11. in Hexamer. Animal deciduum, ab ipsa mox effusione uteri materni ad extrema senectae lineam agmen secum trahens inexplicabilium malorum, veluti sentinam quandam exhaurit, A living creature subject to falling, which instantly from his shedding out from his mothers wombe even to the last line of his old age, drawing with him a troope of unexpressable evils doth as it were empty and draw out the sincke of them. Among men therefore who are the common subject of all evils, no marvell if one evill be common. One evill may be common among many, when many evils are so commonly upon one.

Verse 2. In my meditations upon this passage of the Preacher, the rich man in the Gospell hath often come into my mind: but here mee thinkes the two Preachers doe handle the same Text, and that which here the Preacher of Israel delivereth by way of doctrine, the Preacher of the Vniversall Church doth there exemplifie by a parable. The rich man there, is here a man to whom God hath given riches, wealth, and honour: which words Lyra doth thus distinguish,Lyra in hunc versum. by riches understanding artificiales divitas, aurum & argentum, artificiall riches, gold and silver, by wealth understanding naturales divitias, naturall riches, as corne and other fruits of the earth, by honour understanding, statum honorificum a great and glorious estate. But to take them altogether, it is God that giveth them. For as the Psalmist speaketh, Psal. 95.4. In his hand are all the deepe places of the earth, all the deepe mines of gold and silver are in his hand, and as Chrysologus speaketh, Quae in manu Dei sunt, Chrysologus Serm. 46.
sine Deo nequeunt obtineri, Those things which are in Gods hand cannot bee obtained without God. Our Saviour Christ speaketh also of the riches which the earth bringeth forth, and which in a more evident manner are the gift of God to man. So that he wanteth nothing for his soule: that is, animae concupiscenti his desiring soule, for so the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifieth. Of all that hee desireth: this is to bee understood in his owne thoughts and imagination, Luk. 12.19. according as the rich foole in the Gospell said to his soule, soule thou hast much goods layd up for many yeeres, take thine ease, eate, drinke, and be merry, Migraturae mox animae condita satis longa praeparaus, providing for his soule which was presently to be gone away things laid up for a long time. And wee may marke in both places, how both are for their owne souls, for their own desires: they who have so much for themselves have nothing for the poore soules of others. Others may begge and desire in their wants and necessities, but nothing is granted, to supply their wants, to satisfie their desires. Humanus agerinhumanum dominum sustinebat, A kind and liberall field in bringing forth fruit,Chrysologus Serm. 104. sustained an unkind and miserable master, saith Chrysologus of him in the Gospell: and here a gracious and bountifull God giveth riches, and wealth and honour, to an ungracious and wretched man, who will give nothing to others that stand in need
of his helpe. But therefore God doth not give him power to eate of it, that is, his life is cut off, the powers of darknesse doe take away his soule, according as in the Gospell it is said,Luk. 12.20. Chrysologus Ibid. Hac nocte repetunt animam tuam, This night they require thy soule of thee. Where Chrysologus noteth, Sanctorum animas Deus repetit, & reducit; tartarei ministri repetunt & pertrahunt animas impiorum, God requireth the soules of the righteous, and taketh them backe to himselfe who gave them; but the ministers of hell require the soules of the wicked and dragge them away. Thus the rich foole horreorum suorum seras negando aliis, sibi conclusit; by barring up his barnes, and denying reliefe to others did shut them up to himselfe, and had not power to eate thereof: thus he who wanted as he thought nothing for his soule that he could desire, wanted his soule, and that was taken from him, when so much wealth was given him. But a stranger eateth it: and whereas it is said in the Gospell, then whose shall these things bee,Lyra in hunc versum. which thou hast provided? that is saith Lyra, Quasi diceret, alieni habebunt, As if he should say, strangers shall have them. So that as Chrysologus speaketh, Est alienorum custos, qui esse suorom noluit prorogator, ingratus Deo, sibi nequam, He is but the keeper of the things of strangers, who will not be a charitable dispenser of his own, unthankfull to God, pernicious to himselfe. And is not this then a vanity and an evill disease? A vanity of the world, and an evill disease of humane nature. For though the man be dead, it is but an evill disease of the corrupted nature of man, to which it is subject, and whereof it is sicke. Many particular men are taken away by it: and they that are living, may therein see the infirme frailty of humane condition. When men have plenty and flourish in abundance, they promise to themselves long joy, much delight, even all that their soule desireth; but then doth God take away their lifes,Chrysologus Ibid. and as Chrysologus speaketh of him in the Gospell, Sic praeventus est, ut magis cogitata perderet, quam bona, Hee was so prevented, that he might rather loose his thoughts then his goods; in like manner then doth God cut off the lives of many, as well to shew them the vanity of their thoughts, as to shew them and others the vanity of mans estate on earth.Olympiodorus in hunc versum. Olympiodorus applying this verse in a morall sense, tels us, Saepe accidit, ut aliquis magnas sibi divitias in dicendi copia & in scientia Scripturarum comparavit, aliarum{que} rerum cognitione, sed quia deinde foeditas morum à verbis suis dissidet ac doctrina; hinc fit ut qui in libros illius traditiones{que} incidunt, magnam inde ipsi quidem utilitatem capiant, nihil vero ipse autor emolumenti perceperit, Oftentimes it commeth to passe, that some one hath gotten to himselfe a great fluency of speech, and a great abundance in the knowledge of the Scriptures and of other things; but because the lewdnesse of his manners departeth and disagreeth both from his words and doctrine, hence it is that they who meete with his books and instructions, doe gather from them much profit to themselves, but the author himselfe reapeth no benefit from them. One thing more let me note, which the earnestnesse of my thoughts passed by: and that is the difference betweene devouring or swallowing, and eating: for
none devoure or swallow more then covetous wretches; but God doth not give them power to eate it, so that it is not turned into the nourishment of any comfort to them. And what is that but a vanitie of feeding? What is that but an evill disease of an ill tempered and ordered stomacke?

Verse 3. But put case sayth the Preacher, that a stranger doth not eate of it, and that himselfe beget an hundred children, whereof it is likely, that some will outlive him, to have his estate and wealth after him: and put case that his life be not taken away, but that he liveth many yeares, even as many more as he begetteth children, and that the dayes of his yeares be exceeding many; yet if being filled with yeares, if being filled with children, his soule be not filled with good, with the good of contentment in that which he hath, with the good of comfort in expecting a reward for that which he hath done: and also that he have no buriall: to take these words to signifie no more, then the reproach of not being buryed, which the Prophet Ieremiah denounced against Iehojakim, saying, that he should be buryed with the buriall of an Asse, that is, Iere. 22.19. should be cast forth to rot above ground, is to bury the force and worth of the Preachers meaning. And yet how to lay it open well, is not a thing of easie worth. Saint Hierome giveth diverse interpretations of it; as, first,Hieronym. in hunc. vers. that he doth not thinke of his buriall, thinke of his death, but because he hath lived many yeares, and hath much layd up for many yeares more, therefore hath no buriall in his minde, hath no remembrance of his death to be ready for it. Or secondly, hath no buriall, that is, his covetous heart, which hath gathered so much in his life, will not allow any thing at his death to be spent upon his buriall, will not spare any thing to the building of a Sepulchre for himselfe. Or, thirdly, hath no buriall, because being assaulted and murdered for his wealth, his wealth is taken from him, and no buriall is given to him. Or lastly, which St. Hierome approoveth best, because he hath done no good nor worthy thing, whereby to preserve his memory among posteritie, and not to suffer his life to passe away in silence as a beast, whereas he had enough, and might have done enough, whereby it might have appeared, that he had lived. To these let me adde some other expositions which I have thought upon. As first, he hath no buriall, that is, there is no mourning nor lamentation for him, but as he did no good while he lived, so no one is sorry that he is dead. Or secondly, he hath no buriall, because although dead, yet he is as it were not dead,Salv. contrà Avaritiam lib. 2.
Et quum Deus jusserit viventem opibus renuntiare, ille eas cupit in liberis & cognatis suis etiam mortuus possidere, And when God commandeth the living to renounce his riches, he being dead desire still to possesse them in his children and kindred, leaving all to them, as Salvianus speaketh. But as the same Father also hath it,Salv. contra Avaritiam. l. 3.
Propinqua vobis vestra pignora esse & conjunctissima satis certum est; sed mihi credite, nemo vobis propinquior, nemo conjunctior, quam vos ipsi. Amate itaque, non obsistimus, amate filios vestros, sed secundo gradu à vobis; ita illos diligite, ne vos odisse videamini. Inconsultus
nam{que} & stultus amor est, alterius memor, & sui immemor, That your children are neere and deare unto you is a certaine thing, but beleeve me, there is none more neere and deare unto you then your selves: love therefore, we forbid you not, love your children, but in a second degree to your selves, doe you so love them, as that you be not seene to hate your selves. It is an unadvised and foolish love, which is mindfull of others,Nazianzene Orat. 2. in Pasch. but forgetfull of himselfe. Wherefore as Nazianzene speaketh, when yee goe out of Aegypt, take something with you, leave not all to them, who perhaps Scelerate quaesita sceleratius consument, will consume more wickedly those things which were wickedly gotten. Shew thy selfe to be dead, by giving something to pious uses, that so thou mayst bee buried. Or else he hath no buriall, because although men doe give him buriall, yet God doth not. God taketh care of the dead bodies of his servants, he taketh order for their buriall: and therefore hee saith to Iacob going downe to Aegypt, Gen. 46.4. Gen. 50.13. I will surely bring thee up againe: which he did when Iacob was dead, bringing up his dead body to be buryed in the Sepulcher of his fathers. But as for the wicked, God doth not bury them, he doth not lay them up in his Cabinet, untill hee shall bring them forth againe in the glorious Resurrection. The covetous wretch hath no buriall from God, for God is not left his heire, God is not left his executour, God is not made Overseer of his will: it belongeth to them to looke to that and to doe it, God was not remembred at all by him, God therefore looketh not after him. But what a wrong is this to God? Is not hee the true master of all mens estates? What are we all but possessores usufructuarii, possessours only of the use of that which we have?Salvianus contra Avaritiam. l. 1. Wherefore as Salv. speakes, tenuimus quoad licuit, tenuimus quoad permisit ille qui praestitit, quid rectius? quid honestius? quam ut ubi res ab eo discedit, qui usum habuit, revertatutr ad eum possessio, qui utendum concessit, we have had our estates as long as we could, we have had it, as long as he pleased who lent it unto us, what is more right? what more honest? then that whereas the estate goeth from him who had the use of it, the possession doe returne to him, who granted it to bee used. But as for him who thus dying hath no buryall, hath not God to bury him, the Preacher pronounceth of him, I say that an untimely birth is better than hee: I say, hee that gave his wise judgement of the two children the one living the other dead, doth here give his judgement of an untimely birth, and an untimely death. For death is alwaies untimely unto a covetous wretch, hee is alwayes unwilling to part with his riches, and hee is never ready and fit to depart out of the flesh: Now justly is the untimely birth preferred. For the one comming too soone into the world comes not at all; the other being not fit to goe out of the world, when he is gone is fit only for torments in hell. The one delivered from the miseries of this life, commeth not nere the sorrowes of the next; the other having made this miserable life more miserable to himselfe by his wretched covetousnesse, doth make hell even covetous and greedy to devoure him. Where his punishment shall never be filled up, as here
his heart was not with the things of this world.

Verse 4. Saint Bernard speaking unto man, sayth,Bernard. Ser. de primord. med. & noviss. Augustin. l. cui tit. Speculum peccato. Cogita unde veneris, & erubesce, ubi sis & ingemisce, quo vaedis & contremisce, Thinke from whence thou camest, and be ashamed, where thou art, and sigh for sorrow, whither thou goest, and tremble with anguish. Saint Austin also speaking unto man, sayth, Intelligar ergo in quantum sit ingressus tuus flebilis, progressus tuus debilis, et egressus tuus horribilis, Vnderstand therefore how lamentable thy comming is, how feeble thy going on is, how terrible thy going out is. It is the like manner of expressing himselfe, and of setting out mans misery and condition which here the Preacher useth. He commeth in with vanitie: with the vanitie of Originall corruption, and departeth in darknesse, in the darknesse of his actuall transgressions. For these are darknesse indeed, by which the light of Gods favour is darkened and kept from us, the light of knowledge is darkned and shut up in us, by which the darknesse of eternall misery is brought upon us. Saint Austin noteth, Non dicit Deus, Augustin. in Psal. 8.
fiant tenebrae, et factae sunt, et tamen tenebras ordinavit, et divisit à luce tenebras, God did not say, Let there be darknesse, and there was darknesse, but yet God ordered the darknesse, and divided the darknesse from the light: it is so with the transgressions of men, God never sayd, Let them be, but having their being from man, he ordereth them, and by his justice divideth them from the light of happinesse. But here is nothing sayd of the covetous wretches life; his vaine comming in, his darke going out mentioned; wee reade nothing of his wretched life, as if that were not worthy to be remembred. And indeed, it followes, His name shall be covered with darknesse. Whereby is not meant onely, that his name shall be forgotten, for then it had been enough to have sayd, his name shall be covered. But seeing it is added, that his name shall be covered with darknesse, it is meant that the foulenesse and blacknesse of his actions, shall make his name to be as a thing abhorred to be thought upon. And surely, when vanitie lets him in, and darknesse shuts him out, what could it be but wretchednesse that kept him company in the meane while? But it seemeth to me that the Originall here may not amisse be translated, He commeth into vanitie, and goeth into darknesse. First, he commeth into vanitie:Ambros. in Psal. 118. Octon. 5. Saint Ambrose shewing the vanitie of mans life, and that it is but a shadow, telleth us, that when the Sonne of God was borne of the Virgin, it is sayd, that the power of the highest overshadowed her, Quia in umbram descendit, ab umbra incipiens operari salutem hominis, et consummaturus claritate solis aeterni, Because he descended into a shadow, from a shadow beginning to worke the salvation of man, which he will finish in the brightnesse of the eternall Sunne.Ambros. Ibid. And the same Father considering the words of David, I will live and keepe thy words; thereupon noteth, Vivam ait, quasi nondum vivens; hic enim in umbra vivimus. Ergo vita ista in corpore, umbra est vitae, et imago, non veritas, He sayth, I will live, as not living yet, for here wee live in a shadow. This life therefore
in the body, is a shadow and an image of life, not the truth of it. Secondly, He goeth into darknesse: sed forte tales esse putet homo, quales patiuntur in carceribus inclusi. Vtinam tales essent, tamen in talibus nemo vult esse. In his autem carcerum tenebris possint includi & innocentes. In talibus enim tenebris sunt inclusi martyres, But perhaps some one may thinke this darknesse to be such, as they suffer who are shut up in prison. I wish that it were such, but yet in this darknesse no one would willingly be. But in the darknesse of prisons, innocents may be shut up: for in such darknesse Martyrs have beene imprisoned,Augustin. Homil. 40. as Saint Austin speaketh. This therefore is another darknesse, this is that outer darknesse of which the Scripture speaketh,Augustin. in Psal. 5. and into which he is cast, Qui extra Deum penitus est, quoniam dum tempus est corrigi noluerit, Who is without GOD wholy, because when there was time, he would not be corrected, as St. Austin speaketh.Ambros. l. 7. in Lucam. So doth St. Ambrose also expound the outer darknesse, saying, Quicunque extra sunt promissa coelestium mandatorum, in tenebris exterior • bus sunt: quia mandata Dei lumen sunt. Et quicunque sine Christo est, in tenebris est, quia lumen in tenebris est Christus, Whosoever are without the promises of the heavenly commandements, they are in outer darknesse, because the commandements of God are light. Whosoever is without Christ, he is darknesse, because Christ is a light in darknesse. And of this outer darknesse St. Austin sayth, Penitus autem esse extra Deum, quid est nisi esse in summa caecitate? But to be wholy without God, what is it but to be in extreame darknesse? Into this darknesse therefore it is that the soule of a covetous wretch goeth, when the life into which he came is vanished away. And When his soule thus lyeth in the darknesse of horrour, when his body lyeth in the darknesse of the grave, then is his name also covered, either with the darknesse of silence, abhorring to mention it, or if it be mentioned, with the darknesse of reproaches that are cast upon it.

Verse 5. The Preacher having shewed in the former verse the condition of the covetous wretch, here he sheweth the condition of the abortive childe, and from the sight of both confirmeth his sentence, that the abortive childe is in better condition. For as he hath not seene the Sunne, so neither hath he seen the miseries that are under the Sunne, neither hath the Sunne seene his sorrow and labour in the enduring of them. His eye hath not beheld the glory of the Sunne, and the Sunne which is the eye of the world, hath not beheld the wretchednesse of his life.Ambros. Hexam. l. 4. c. 1. It is true, that the Sunne is Iucunditas diei, coeli pulchritudo, naturae gratia, praestantia creaturae, The sweetnesse of the day, the beauty of heaven, the grace of nature, the excellency of the creature, as St. Ambrose speaketh: but yet as the same Father addeth, Non te tanto splendori Solis temere committas, Commit not thy selfe rashly to so great a brightnesse of the Sunne. I have read of some, who when the Sunne riseth, doe curse it alwayes, in respect of the scorching heate of it, and when it goeth downe,Ambros. Ibid. then they rejoyce. And St. Ambrose tels us, In mari positus illum nauta accusat, in montibus illum pastor declinat, The mariner on
the Sea accuseth the hot beames of it, the shepheard on the mountaines flyeth to the shadow from it. Wherefore the good of the Sunne hath evils also with it; and so many are the evils of mans life under it, that rather then to suffer the darknesse of them, it is better not to enjoy the light of the Sunne. But if he that shall see the Sunne of the heavens, shall not have his eye upon the Sunne of righteousnesse, to walke in his wayes: surely much better were it for him, not to have seene the Sunne at all. For as St. Ambrose speaketh,Ambrosius, Ibid. Si caeco damnum est hujus solis gratiam non videre, quantum peccatori damnum vero luminis munere defraudato, perpetuae noctis tenebras sustinere? If it be a losse to a blind man not to see the comfort of this Sunne, how great a losse is it to a sinner, being deprived of the favour of the true light, to suffer the darknesse of an eternall night? Nor knowne any thing: but as he hath not knowne any thing that is good, so hath he not knowne any thing that is evill; as he hath not knowne the world, so he hath not knowne the sorrowes of the world, neither hath the world knowne him turmoyled and distressed in them. It is true, as St. Ambrose speaketh; Scire bonum, melius est quam nescire, & ei qui bonum scit, pulchrum est etiam scire quod malum est; ut sciat pravum vitare, & ut prudens lubeat custodiae cautionem, It is better to know good, then not to know it, and to him that knoweth good, it is a gracefull thing to know also what is evill, that so he may know to shun the evill, and being wise may be cautelous to keepe himselfe from it.Ambros. de Paradiso. c. 7. But as the Father addeth; Ita debes scire utrumque ut profunde noveris, et quod noveris exequaris, actusque scientiae congruat. Alioquin tolerabiliorem scriptura judicat eum, qui utrumque nescit. Gravat enim scire, quod vel exequi vel vitare non velis: gravat scire quod vel exequi vel vitare non possis, Thou must so know both, as that thou know them soundly, and dost execute that which thou knowest, and that thine actions agree to thy knowledge. Otherwise the Scripture judgeth him more tolerable (which word Tremellius useth in this verse,) who knoweth not either. For it is a burden to know that, which thou wilt not either performe being good, or avoyd being evill: it is a burden to know that which thou canst not doe being good, or shun being evill. And therefore more tolerable is the condition of the abortive, then of the covetous wretch. That hath more rest then the other: What the rest of the other is,Greg. Mor. l. 16. c. 29. St. Gregory sheweth; Qui in hoc appetit mundo prosperari, caeteros excedere rebus, & honoribus tumere, huic n • mirum cura saecularis in delectatione est, & quies in labore, valdè enim fatigatur, si desit cura saeculi qua fatigatur, He that desireth to flourish in this world, to exceede others in substance, and to swell in honours, to him the care of the world is a delight, and his rest is in labour; For he is very weary, if that he want the care of the world which may make him weary. O what wretched rest is this! Surely, it is not in this world that rest is to be found.Ambrosius in Euangel. Lu. c. 9. Wherefore St. Ambrose noteth, Sex diebus mundus est factus, septimo requietum est die: ultra mundum ergo est quies, ultra mundum etiam fructus quietis, In six dayes the world was made, on the seventh day there was rest; it is beyond this
world therefore that rest is, and it is beyond this world that the fruit of rest is to be had. For what rest can there be here, Vbi multa cautela custoditur salus corporis, custodita etiam amittitur, amissa cum gravi labore reparatur, et tamen reparata in dubio semper est, Where the health of the body is preserved with much watchfulnesse, being preserved is also lost, being lost is recovered with much labour, and yet being recovered is alwayes in danger & doubtfulnesse,Greg. Mor. l. 11. c. 26. what will become of it, as St. Gregory speaks? What rest is there in this world, Vbi amamus amicos suspicati, ne offendi valeant, formidamus inimicos, atque securi non sumus de iis quos formidamus, ubi plerum{que} inimicis sic confidenter quasi amicis loquimur, et nonnunquam verba diligentium quasi verba suscipimus inimicorum, Where we love our friends, and yet are suspicious least they should be offended with us, where wee feare our enemies, and yet are not secure of those whom wee feare, where often we speake to our enemies so confidently as if we spake to our friends, and not seldome wee take the words of our friends, as if they were the words of our enemies? What rest is there in this world? Fixum enim statum hic habere non possumus ubi transituri venimus, atque hoc ipsum nostrum vivere transire est, For here wee cannot have a fixed estate, whither wee come to passe away, and where our very living is but a passing away, as St. Gregory speaketh. Now the abortive resteth, he goeth not this journey, as he hath no friends, so he hath no enemies; as he hath not health, so he hath not sicknesse. And that which maketh his rest to be the more; Vt non videt, sic non vadit, as he seeth not the Sunne, so he goeth not into darknesse; not into the darknesse of Gods wrath for sinne. The Originall word here is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and according to the naturall and proper forme of it, signifieth ferculum, a messe, or depositum, something committed to trust. Now although it be a short repast which the abortive hath, yet it is better then the gluttonus feeding of the covetous wretch: although it be very little which is committed to the abortive, yet it is the lesse that he hath to answer for, and that maketh his rest to be more, then the rest of the covetous wretch, who having received much, and done little good with it, hath a sad accompt, a sore reckoning to make for it.

q.p: VER. 6. Yea, though he live a thousand yeares twise told, yet hath he seene no good. Doe not all goe to one place?
VER. 7. All the labour of man is for his mouth; and yet the appetite is not filled.
VER. 8. For what hath the wise more then the foole? What hath the poore that knoweth to walke before the living?

div.p:
Verse 6. Iob in few words hath fully told us what man is, saying, Man is of few dayes and full of trouble: Et quod verum verbum hoc sit,
Job 14.1. non nos verba docuere sed verbera, And that this is a true saying, not words but stripes have taught us,Bernard. Serm. Feria 4. Hebdomadae poenosae. Greg. Mor. l. 11. c. 26. the stripes of many miseries sayth St. Bernard. And St. Gregory briefly upon the same words sayth, Augustatur ad vitam, dilatatur ad miseriam, Man is straitned in respect of his life, and enlarged in respect of his misery. But suppose the life of man should be long, Nihil proficit sibi, sed officit, it would profit him nothing but hurt him rather, as Lyra hath it. Yea though he should live a thousand yeares twise told: hyperbolice dicit, the Preacher speaketh hyperbolically sayth St. Hierome. For Adam lived not a thousand yeares, and thereupon a thousand yeares with God being but as one day, as God had sayd to Adam, In the day that thou eatest of the forbidden tree, thou shalt surely dye, so he dyed accordingly before he came unto a thousand yeares; that being the same day with God. But though he should live twise so long as Adam did, and outlive that also, yet hath he seene no good: Wherefore as St. Bernard speaketh, Quomodo bonum est nos hic esse? Bernard. Homil. 6. In Ascens. Domin. Immo vero molestum est, grave est, periculosum est. Nimirum ubi mali plurimum, sapientiae modicum, si tamen vel modicum invenitur. Vbi viscosa omnia, omnia lubrica, operta tenebris, obsessa laqueis. Vbi periclitantur animae, affliguntur spiritus, How is it good for us to be here? Nay, rather it is troublesome, it is grievous, it is dangerous. Namely, where there is much wickednesse, little wisedome, if there be a little found to be there. Where all things are catching like birdlime, all things are slippery, all things covered with darknesse, all things beset with snares. Where our soules are endangered, our spirits are disquieted. There be many gay-good things that appeare in the world;Bernard. de Consid. l. 2. prope finem. but as Saint Bernard writing to Eugenius, sayth, Cuncta haec veluti nubes quaesdam matutinales velociter transeuntes exsuffles à facie considerationis tuae, occurret tibi homo, dolens quod homo sit, erubescens quod nudus sit, plorans quod natus est, murmurans quod sit, If thou shalt blow away all these from the face of thy consideration, as a morning cloud, which soone vanisheth away, there will meete thee a man lamenting that he is a man, blushing that he is
naked, weeping that he is borne, repining that he is. He that should live a thousand yeares twise told, might seeke and looke long to finde some good, but where should he see it in mans life? Quid enim calamitate vacat, nascenti in peccato, fragili in corpore, & mente sterili? For where is misery wanting unto him, who is borne in sinne, fraile in body, barren in minde? as St. Bernard addeth in the same place. But as for the covetous wretch, Qui privatus interno lumine, tamen in hac vita diu vult perpeti caecitatem suam, Who being deprived of the inward light of naturall understanding, yet desireth to lye long under his blindnesse in this life, and with his owne hands addeth to the load of this miserable life, how is his life filled Multis & multiplicibus miseriis? With many and manifold miseries? Miseriis corporis, miseriis cordis, miseriis quum dormit, miseriis dum vigilat, miseriis quaqua versum se vertat, With miseries of body, with miseries of heart, with miseries while he sleepeth, with miseries when he is awake, with miseries which way soever he turneth himselfe. How is he Appetitus insidiis, interrogatus contumeliis, pulsatus injuriis, vexatus suppliciis, convitiis lacessitus, Assaulted with traps, accused by reproaches, beaten with injuries, vexed with mulcts and punishments,Bernard. Feria 4a Hebdomadae poenosae. provoked with scoffs? as St. Bernard elsewhere speaketh. And where then is any good for him to see? Doe not all goe unto one place? Doth not he that liveth two thousand yeares goe to the grave at last, as well as he that is an abortive? Nay, is not the rest of the abortive more then of the other, seeing he is at the place of their rest by two thousand yeares sooner, then the other? Indeed man who is driven out of Paradise, is delighted in this his banishment, and faigne would stay here;Gregorius. but as St. Gregory speaketh, Quamvis diu hic stare desiderat, ipso tamen cursu mortalis vitae impellitur ut egrediatur, ipsis suis incrementis ad detrimenta tendit, & inde semper deficit, unde se proficere in spatium vitae credit, Although he desire to stay long here, yet by the very course of this mortall life, he is driven on, and caryed to goe out; by the very encreasing of his life, he tendeth to decreasing, and thereby he alwayes decayeth, whereby he beleeveth that he proceedeth on in the space of his life. Vntill all come unto one place, the place which Adam provided for all his posteritie, and where himselfe being layd, all shall be brought unto him.Masius in ult. cap. Iosh. vers. 32.
Masius tels us, out of Iacob Edissenus Syrus, that when Noah went into the Arke, he tooke the bones of Adam with him, and that when he came out of the Arke, he divided them among his Sonnes, giving the head as the chiefest part unto his first borne; and therein as it were saying unto them, Let not this delivery from the flood make you secure, behold your first parent, and the beginning of mankind, you must all, and all that come from you, goe unto the dust to him.

Verse 7. The Preacher here passeth A bonis fortunae, ad bona naturae, from the goods of fortune, to the goods of nature, and having shewed the vanitie of them, here sheweth the vanitie of these. And indeede great is the vanitie and misery of mans life,Greg. Mor. l. 11. c. 26. even in these also. Wherefore Saint Gregory sayth, Si subtiliter consideretur, omne quod hic agitur,
poena & miseria est. Ipsi enim corruptioni carnis servire ad necessaria & concessa, miseria est; ut contra frigus vestimenta, contra famem alimenta, contra aestum frigora requirantur, If it be duely and exactly considered, every thing that is here done is a punishment and misery. For even to serve the frailty of the flesh in things lawfull and necessary, is a misery: as that garments may be provided against cold, that food against hunger, that cold things against heate. The Preacher here that hee might not speake of all, speaketh of the chiefest for necessity, All the labour of man is for the mouth: that is, though all the labour of man should bee for the mouth, yet the appetite is not filled. Tremellius reads it,Tremellius. Vt omnis labor hominis obveniatori, Although all the labour of man should meet his mouth: and he expoundeth it, that is, Velut sponte ingerat se in os, & laboranti commodissime succedat, ex sententia, Although it should even thrust it selfe into his mouth, and it should succeed to the labourer according to his desire, yet the appetite is not filled. For he that hath eaten is hungry again, and the food receaved being consumed there is more required, more needful to preserve life, and that death break not in through the weake wals. Zeno speaking of the sinne of our first Parents, saith,Zeno l. 1. Serm. 6.
Vbi Adam sacrae arboris pomum male dulce delibavit, lachrymas repperit, dolores & gemitus ultimò{que} sudore turbatus, posteris haereditatem indigestae mortis dereliquit, when Adam had tasted of the fruit of the forbidden tree, which was bitter sweet unto him, hee found teares, griefes, sighs, and lastly being troubled with sweate, he left to his posterity the inheritance of indigested death. Whatsoever food we take, it is spent in sweats, in teares, in the sorrowes of labour, and though our nourishment be digested, death remaineth still indigested and to withstand that the appetite is never filled. But by the ancient Fathers this verse is much applyed in a morall sense, and that diverse wayes.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome applyes it in a good sense, and he saith, Melius est hoc intelligi de viro Ecclesiastico, qui in Scripturis eruditus omnem laborem habet in ore suo, & anima ejus non impletur, dum semper cupit discere, It is best to understand this of an Ecclesiasticall man, who being learned in the Scriptures hath alwayes his labour in his mouth, and his soule is not filled, while he desireth alwayes to learne. So doth Salonius apply it, who saith,Salonius in hunc vers. How can it bee that all things which a man laboureth for should be in his mouth? A wise and learned Ecclesiasticall man hath all his labour in his mouth, because all things which he learneth in the Scriptures he daily considereth, preacheth, teacheth, and his soule is not filled: quia non sufficit sibi quod didicit, sed magis & magis semper discere cupit & studet, Because that which hee hath learned doth not suffice him, but hee desireth and studyeth still to know more and more.Greg. Hom. 40. Saint Gregory applies this verse morally in a bad sense, and he saith, All the labour of a man is in his mouth, but his soule is not filled, Quia quisquis hoc laborat solummodo, ut sciat quid loqui debeat, ab ipsa refectione scientiae suae mente vacua jejunat, Because whosoever doth labour for this only that he may know what to speake, himselfe fasteth with an hungry mind from the refection of his owne knowledge. And
using to this purpose the speech of the rich glutton who desired a drop of water to coole his tongue, he saith, Infidelis populus verba legis in ore tenuit, quae opere servare contempsit: ibi ergo amplius ardebit, ubi se ostendit scire quod facere noluit. The unfaithfull people had the words of the Law in their mouthes, which they despised to observe in their actions: there therefore shall they burne the more, where they shewed that they knew,Cassian Collat. 14. c. 9. that which they would not doe. In Cassian Abbot Nesteros applies it by way of advise, and speaking as it seemeth to Cassian himselfe hee saith, Observate inprimis, & tu maxime Ioannes, ut indicas summum ori tuo silentium, hic est enim primus actualis disciplinae ingressus. Omnis quippe labor hominis in ore ipsius est, & ut omnium seniorum instituta at{que} sententias intento corde & quasi muto ore suscipias, ac diligenter in pectore tuo condens ad perficienda ea potius, quam ad docenda festines, Observe yee chiefely, and you Iohn especially, that you injoyne great silence to thy mouth, for this is the first entrance of an actuall discipline. All the labout truly of a man is in his mouth, and that thou dost receive all the institutions and sentences of the elders, with an attentive heart, and as it were with a dumb mouth, and that laying them up diligently in thy heart, thou hasten rather to practise them, then to teach them.

Verse 8. What hath the wise more than the foole? Much every way, even in the feeding of nature. For a wise man doth not make the feeding of the body, to be his study and care, as knowing, Non nostrum esse manus nutritionem, sed esse nutritionem propter nostram hic mansionem, quam ad incorruptionem ratio instituit, that the nourishing of the body is not our businesse, but that the nourishing of the body, is for our continuance here,Clemens Alexander Paedag. lib. 2. cap. 1. which reason ordereth unto immortality, as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh. A wise man affecteth not delicacy and daintinesse of feeding, as knowing Deum parasse opificio suo, homini inquam, cibum & potum, ut conservetur, non ut voluptate afficiatur, That God hath provided for his workmanship, namely man, meate and drinke to preserve him, not to affect him with pleasure. A wise man is moderate in his feeding, as knowing, Quae sunt secundum naturam appetitiones circumscribi sufficientia, The appetites, which are according unto nature to bee bounded with sufficiency: Whereas he that is a foole in feeding, and made a foole by feeding, Habet constupratum gustum misera & infausta condiendi arte & inani in faciendis bellariis artificio, Hath his tast adulterated with a wretched and unlucky art of seasoning, and with a vaine skill in making of junckets,Clem. Alex. Ibid. as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh. Wherefore hee addeth, Mihi quidem morbi eorum misereri lubet; ipsos autem non pudet suas decantare delitias, I am moved to pitty their disease, although themselves bee not ashamed to extoll their delicates. A foole in feeding, Soli cibi devorationi blanditur, Doth only flatter his appetite with devouring of meate, and esteemeth more of one cooke then of diverse husbandmen. A foole in his feeding is ever immoderate, Intruso in ventrem nutrimento, tanquam ad viaticum non ad digestionem edulia reponat, Thrusting his meate into his stomacke, as if hee laid up provision for a journey,
did not eate his meate for digestion. But though a wise man excell a foole so farre, yet in the vanity of humane nature, which needeth still new supply of nourishment to preserve it, What hath the wise man more than the foole? When a wise man hath eaten, is he not againe hungry, as well as a foole? And must not his hunger againe be satisfied, or else hee cannot live as well as a fooles hunger? In this vanity of nature they agree, though not in the vanity of their feeding. What hath the poore that knoweth to walke before the living? It is the saying of Clemens Alexandrinus, Nemo ad res necessarias pauper, No one is poore in necessary things, and surely he that knoweth any thing may know how to live. He that will but walke in the labour of any course of life, may easily bee able to walke before the living. But what hath the poore more in preserving of his life by food, or what hath he lesse then any other? Hee may bee stronger in digesting of his meate, and the strength also of his body may be the greater by it, hee may be the healthier in his life, and his life also may continue the longer by it.Clem. Alex. Ibid. For as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh, Qui escis utuntur vilioribus robustiores sunt & saniores, They that use the coursest meats are the stronger and the healthier. He may have lesse to eate, and it may be, lesse variety to eate of, he may have nullas appendices coenae, No labels of dainties hanging to his lips, no banquets, or after services but in this vanity of humane nature, he is as weake as any, in this poverty of nature he is equall with any, and whatsoever his food bee, his hunger againe afterwards is the same that is in the rest of men. Now as it is in the bodily feeding of nature, so it is in the spirituall feeding of the soule by grace: when we have eaten, there must bee an appetite againe, and againe must the appetite be satisfied, or else a spirituall life will not bee preserved in us. It is a fault in any to say or thinke that they are good enough, and thereby to bee negligent in stirring up their appetite, and in seeking after more. To be filled with Religion is to bee empty of it. Our Saviour Christ saith, Matth. 6.6. Blessed are they that hunger and thirst after righteousnesse, for they shall bee filled: they shall bee filled in heaven, they should not be on earth.Hierom. in Matth. And Saint Hierome saith upon the words, Apertissime nos redemptor instituit, nunquam nos satis justos aestimare debere, sed quotidianum justitiae semper amare profectum, Our Redeemer doth evidently teach us, that we must never thinke our selves to be righteous enough, but alwayes to love a daily progresse in righteousnesse. And Abbot Theodorus in Cassian tels us truly,Cassian Collat. S. Abbot Theod. cap. 14.
In uno mens eodem{que} statu manere non praevalet, id est, ut nec augmentum virtutum capiat, nec detrimentum sustineat: non acquisisse enim minuise est, quia desinens proficiciendi appetitus non aberit a periculo recedendi, The mind of man cannot abide in one and the same state, that is, as neither to receave increase of vertues, nor to suffer losse of them: for not to gaine more, is to grow lesse, because the appetite of going on failing, a danger of going back, will not be wanting.Bern. Epist. 253. Ad Abba. G •• . • . Let therefore the saying of Saint Bernard bee remembred, Quid prodest Christum sequi, si non contingat consequi? Ibi tu Christiane fige cursus tui metam, ubi Christus posuit suam! What doth it
profit to goe after Christ, unlesse wee come unto him? Doe thou O Christian there set downe an end to thy course, where Christ did set downe an end unto his. Hee was obedient unto death, and let not thy obedience, and growth in obedience, untill then come to an end.

q.p: VER. 9. Better is the sight of the eyes, then the wandring of the desire: this is also vanity and vexation of spirit.
VER. 10. That which hath beene is named already, and it is knowne that it is man: neither may hee contend with him that is mightier then he.

div.p:
Verse 9. The Septuagint in reading of this verse doe give a good and plaine sense of it, and not dissenting from the force of Originall; they say, Melius est videre quod cupias, quam desiderare quod nescias, It is better to see that which thou desirest, then to desire that which thou knowest not. And although the saying bee true in respect of the object desired, Ignoti nulla cupido, of a thing unknowne there is no desire, yet in respect of the effects which follow the thing desired, there are many who desire that, of which they know not, how it will prove unto them, nor what will be the consequences of it. Wherefore it is wisdome so to rule the desire as that the eye of the understanding doe alwayes goe before it, to discover the way that it caryeth us, and to foresee to what it will bring us; lest our desire be placed on something, which at last is most undesired by us. But to take the sense of the words, as they follow the preceding argument of the Preacher; I should conceive their meaning thus. That in dainty and voluptuous varieties of meate, the sight of the eyes is better then the wandring of the appetite, and it is better to bee pleased with looking upon them, then to please the appetite with feeding on them.Clem. Alex. Paedag. lib. 2. cap. 1. For though as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh, Insipientis sit ea quae epulis apponuntur valde admirari ac stupere, It be the part of a foole, much to admire, and with amazement to behold, those things which at feasts are set upon the table: notwithstanding as hee addeth, Insipientius est hominem servire ferculis, adeo ut eorum, ut ita dicam, intemperantia una cum eis circumferatur à ministris, It is a more foolish thing for a man to be a servant to dishes, so that by intemperancy he bee as it were caryed by the servitors up and downe together with the dishes, and that his desire doe wander and walke after them, and as it were waite upon them, as they are set downe, or taken away, or else are removed from one place to another. For as the same Father speaketh, Vt in cibos regnum & dominium obtineamus, non ut his serviamus ordinati sumus, Wee
are ordained by God to have command and authority over our meate and drinke, not to be enthralled and subjected to them. If thou overlooke them therefore comming where dainties are, it is a thing more seemely and better for thee, then to overcharge thy stomacke by feeding upon them, and by suffering thine appetite to wander and walk too boldly and freely among them. For this is nothing else but as in Cl. Alex. it is called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
in ventrem vesania, a belly madnesse, Symmachus as Saint Hierome tels us did read the verse thus,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Melius est providere quam ambulare ut libet, It is better to provide, then to walke as it listeth: and surely it is better to provide for cleering of a mans way and for keeping of his way, then by walking and wandring as hee listeth to meete with those troubles, which may crosse his passage, and whereby himselfe may be lost in his way. It is better to provide for the end of our journey, and for the accompt which then we are to make, that so we may bee receaved into the rest of joy; then by walking now as we will, to suffer then what we will not: and when we come to our walke and to seeke rest, to finde the way of endlesse torments to be opened unto us; surely this will shew our walking to have beene vanity, and to have brought us to nothing but vexation of Spirit. But to apply the conclusion of the verse according to the sense, wherein I have understood the foregoing verses. What is the renewed hunger and appetite of man, though never so often satisfied, but a vanity of nature? What is it, but as St. Hier. tels us, that Aquila and Theodotio did render the words in this place, Pastio venti, a feeding on the wind? Seeing the satisfaction by feeding passeth away, and the appetite is as empty as if it had but fed on the wind. Cl. Al. tels us, Amygdalae dicuntur inanes, non in quibus nihil inest, Clem. Alex. stromatum lib. 7.
sed in quibus id quod inest est inutile, Almonds are said to be naught and empty, not in which there is nothing found, but in which that which is found is uselesse and unprofitable. In like manner the feeding of mans body is said to be a vanity, not because it doth nothing, for the appetite is satisfied for the present by it; but because to take away the continuall renuing of the appetite it is altogether unprofitable and of no use. Againe, what is the excesse of feeding and pampering the flesh with voluptuous dainties, but a vanity of sin? What is it but a vexation of Spirit by those paines and torments which from diseases it breedeth? For as such feeding 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dulleth and stupifieth the mind and understanding, so doth it quicken the sense to the greater misery and vexing of the spirit.

Verse 10. That which hath beene: That is, that which hath beene the subject of this discourse and whose vanities have beene shewed. For here the Preacher drawing to conclusion of this part of his treatise, repeateth briefly, what he hath said, and of what he hath spoken. Is named already, or his name is already proclaimed, even by this proclamation of the King of Israel: namely in the beginning of this book; Eccles. 1. v. 2. & 3. where having said, vanity of vanities, all is vanity, he addeth, What profit hath a man of all his labour which hee taketh under the Sunne? And it is knowne that it is man: knowne to every man particularly by that which
he feeleth in himselfe, knowne to every one generally by that which is easie to be seene and observed in the life of man. Now the whole creature is sometimes taken for man, Mar. 16.15. as when our Saviour Christ saith, Goe ye into all the world and preach the Gospell unto every creature. Vpon which words Saint Gregory noteth,Greg. Mor. l. 6. c. 8.
Omnem videlicet creaturam solum intelligi hominem voluit, cui commune aliquid cum omnibus creavit, By every creature he would have man only to be understood, whom he hath made to have somthing common with every creature. And though it be true that every creature is subject unto vanity, and the inferiour creatures especially, and that for mans sake; yet it is man of whom the Preacher speaks. Man, Ambros. de fide l. 5. c. 1. that is as St. Amb. speakes, Non una persona hominis, sed una caro, & una fragilitas generationis humanae, Not one person of a man, but one flesh, and one frailty of humane generation. Job 15.15. & 16. Eliphas comparing man with the heavens saith, that the heavens are not cleane in Gods sight, but how much more abominable and filthy is man, that drinketh iniquity as water? Abominable in his originall corruption, filthy in his actuall transgressions, and the more abominable, more filthy, in that he drinketh iniquity like water. In eating there is some stay made of the meate in the mouth, but in drinking that which is taken, is swallowed downe presently; so that thereby is noted the hast of man to commit wickednesse;Greg. Mor. l. 2. c. 15. and as St. Greg. speaketh, Quia illicita sine timore facit, quasi potum injustitiae sine obstaculo bibit, because he practiseth unlawfull things without feare, therefore is he said to swallow downe the drinke of iniquity without any stopping. This then being man, what mervaile is it that hee is the subject of so much vanity? What mervaile though in his body he be so many wayes distressed, so many wayes troubled and pained? For indeed as Saint Gregory speaketh, Ipsa haec nostri corporis quae salus vocatur, aegritudo est, & quot solatia ad vivendi usum quaerimus, quasi tot nostrae aegritudini medicamentis obviamus, This very estate of our body, which we call health, is but a sicknesse, and how many helpes wee seeke for the use of life, by so many medicines as it were doe we withstand our sicknesse. No mervaile also then though man in his minde suffer so many stormes and tempests of disquietnesse and sorrow. For as Saint Gregory also speaketh, Modò spe decipitur, modò pavore vexatur, modò dolore dejicitur, modò falsa hilaritate elevatur, Now is he deceived with hope, then vexed with feare, now dejected and cast downe with griefe, then lifted up and cheered with a false mirth; it is mans owne sinne that is the cause of all this. And therefore let him not aske why God hath made him so, neither may hee contend with him that is mightier then he. There is no entring of a suite against God, for his cause is alwayes right, and he is alwayes sure to prevaile in it. God created man in perfection and happinesse, and the first man depriving himselfe of it, in whom all were: hinc corporis corruptio, hinc animi ignorantia, hinc curae inutiles, Ambros. de voc. l. 1. c. 3.
illicitae cupiditates, timor vanus, amor noxius, injusta gaudia, poenitenda consilia & non minor miseriarum mu •• itudo quam criminum, Hence is the corruption of the body, hence the ignorance of the mind, hence
unprofitable cares, unlawfull desires, vaine feares, hurtfull love, undue rejoycings, counsels and resolutions to be repented of, and no lesse a multitude of miseries, then of sinnes and offences. Besides, God is alwayes mightier then man, much above him in his wayes, counsels, and judgements. Saint Gregory sayth very well,Greg. Mor. l. 27. c. 25.
Homo quum de Deo tacet, per rationem, in qua conditus est, esse aliquid videtur: sed si loqui de Deo coeperit, illico quam sit nihil ostenditur, Man when he is silent concerning God, seemeth to be something, by the reason in which he was created: but if he begin to speake of God, forthwith it appeareth how plainely he is nothing. It is therefore rightly concluded by Salvianus, Salvianus de Guber. Dei. l. 3.
Sicut plus est Deus quam omnis humana ratio, sic plus mihi debet esse, quam ratio, quod à Deo cuncta agi cognosco, As God is more then all humane reason, so it ought to be more with me then reason, that I know all things to be ordered by God. On his side there is might, not to oppresse, but to overcome any thing that can be pleaded against him: and it shewes the vanitie of mans weaknesse, that he would excuse his owne weaknesse by contending with God any way.

q.p: VER. 11. Seeing there be many things that increase vanitie, what is man the better?
VER. 12. For who knoweth what is good for man in this life, all the dayes of his vaine life, which he spendeth as a shadow? For who can tell a man what shall be after him vnder the Sunne?

div.p:
Verse 11. Much and manifold is the vanitie of humane things, so that it need not to be made more. But seeing there be also many things that doe encrease it, why should any man labour to encrease it to himselfe? Why should man by contending with God, and by seeking to cast upon him the blame of humane vanitie, thereby make himselfe to suffer the more in his discontented and troubled thoughts, and by provoking the anger of God, make him to heape the more vanities upon him, and then what is man the better? But among the many things that increase vanitie, there is one especially, to whom all other things are but serving instruments, and that is the devill. He was the authour of mans vanitie and misery, and he laboureth still to be the increaser of it. When the devill tempting our Saviour Christ sayd,Cyprianus Serm. de Jejunio & tentat. Christ. If thou be the Sonne of God, cast thy selfe downe: Saint Cyprian asketh, why he did not rather say, If thou be the Sonne of God, ascend into heaven, because that agreeth rather unto the Sonnes of God. The answere which the Father giveth is, Nec tentando vult ascensum persuadere coelestem, He will
not, no not in tempting perswade an heavenly ascending. All his endeavour is to cast men downe into earthly vanities.Origen. l. 1. in Job. Origen observeth that if the devill had smitten but one corner of the house, wherein the children of Iob were feasting, it had been enough to have throwne it downe; and thereupon asketh, what made him to smite the foure corners of the house? The answere which he giveth is, that he did it, Vt ostenderet ferociam, atque animum suum homicidialem, That he might shew his fiercenesse and his cruell minde to worke mans mischiefe and ruine. For leave and permission being granted from God, it seemeth sayth the Father, that all the devils made hast to assault the house on every side, striving as it were betweene themselves, who should be the first in causing the hurt. And surely, in smiting men with the winde of vanitie, most eager and violent is the devils malice, and to encrease that, they are encreased in their number, where the goodnesse of God doth not restraine and curbe them. Wee reade in St. Marke, what the devils sayd to our Saviour Christ, when he cast them out of the man that was in the Synagogue,Mark. 1.23. & 24. Theophylac. in Euang. Marci. Let us alone, what have wee to doe with thee thou Iesus of Nazareth? Art thou come to destroy us? What is this sayth Theophylact, to destroy us? The answere which he giveth is, Hoc est, auferre à nobis potestatem, quam in homines habemus, ad torquendum scilicet eos, This is, to take away from us the power, which wee have over men for the tormenting of them. So that such is the greatnesse of the devils desire to torment men, as that they accompt it their destruction not to be suffered to doe it. Wherefore also on the contrary, they accompt it their gaine, their pleasure and delight, to vex and disquiet men with the vanities of this life. Shall any then joyne hands with the devill, to encrease their owne vanitie? Shall any contend with God, and thereby be at peace with the devill, that he may the more easily encrease their misery and trouble? What can man be the better for this? Saint Hierome reads the first part of this verse thus, Quia sunt verba multa multiplicantia vanitatem, Because they are many words multiplying vanitie: the words that are used in contending with God, and in pleading against him, are but many words that doe multiply the vanitie and folly of sinne. Tremellius reads this verse thus; Quum adsunt res multae, multiplicat vanitatem; quid amplius isti homini est? When there is much wealth, that multiplyeth vanitie; what hath that man the more? And so also doth the French translation read it. Now the sense is good, and therefore let me consider it a little. One word whereby the Latines doe expresse riches and wealth, is Facultates, Abilities, and the reason is given, Quia inde oritur hominibus facultas, multa licentiosè agendi, Because from thence many have power and abilitie, of living licentiously: as, of voluptuous feeding, profuse drinking, wearing of gay and costly apparell, and other the like vanities, which thereby are multiplyed. Saint Austin therefore sayth, Aurum est materia laborum, periculum possidentium,Augustin. de verb. Domin. enervatio virtutum, dominus malus, servus proditor, Gold is the matter of labours, the danger of the possessours, the
weakning of vertues, a naughtie master, a treacherous servant. And indeed, many are the cares and troubles, many the dangers and difficulties, much the decay of goodnesse, cruell the commands, false the service, which proceed from wealth. Saint Bernard Bernard. tels us, that a Camel hath but one burden onely, but that a rich man hath two, Alterum terrenarum possessionum, alterum verò peccatorum, The one of his earthly possessions, the other of his sinfull vanities. The first he must lay downe at his death, whether he will or no; the last unlesse he doe lay downe before his death, he shall for ever cary and never be eased of it. But to shew, how much wealth multiplyeth vanities,Greg. Mor. l. 33. c. 1. St. Gregory noteth, that they who doe possesse it, Tanto familiarius diabolo serviunt, quanto hujus vitae successibus apud semetipsos altius intumescunt. His nam{que} cum gloria augetur elatio, cum elatione vero additur cura, huc illuc{que} animus tenditur, quia & desideria cum rebus crescunt, By so much the more friendly and readily doe they serve the devill, by how much within themselves they are swolne higher by the successes of this life. For by these with their glory, their pride is encreased, with their pride also their care, this way and that way is their minde distracted, because their vaine desires also are augmented with their wealth. And what then hath such a one more? Surely more troubles, more miseries, more sinnes. And that he might have lesse of these, it were farre better for him, if he had lesse of the other.

Verse 12. To contend, for I know not what, is a great shame, but to contend with God, for I know not what, what greater shame can there be? And who is there that knoweth what is good for man in this life? Who is there so well learned in the knowledge of himselfe? Who is so well studied in the knowledge of another? What art, what skill, what mystery is there, that can teach any one to know it? Many thinke, that this or that is good for themselves, or others. Many hope well, many are well perswaded of this thing or that thing, but who knoweth any thing? Saint Ambrose sayth, Leo aeger Simiam quarit ut devoret, quo possit sanari; Ambrosius Hexam. l. 6. c. 4.
caprea vulnerata dictamum petit, & de vulnere excludit Sagittas; ursus aeger formicas devorat, ergo ferae norunt expetere ea quae sibi prosint, tu ignoras O homo remedia tua, The Lyon being sicke seeketh an ape to devoure it, that thereby he may be healed; the goate being wounded seeketh for dittany, and so driveth out the arrow from the wound; the beare being sicke devoureth pismires: the beasts therefore doe know how to seeke those things which are profitable for them, but thou O man knowest not the remedies that are good for thee. Man desireth often that as good for himselfe, which is indeed evill; and often shunneth that as evill, which is indeed good for him. It is God onely that knoweth, as St. Austin speaketh, Quid nobis in hac vita expediat, Augustin. l. cui titul. expos. quarund. proposit. ex Epist. ad Roman. & quid post hanc vitam daturus est, Both what is good for us in this life, and what the good is which himselfe will give us after this life. Man judgeth the troubles and miseries of this life to be evill for him, but God knoweth them to be good; and though in themselves they be evill, God turneth them
for his servants into good unto them.Ambros. de fuga saeculi. c. 6.
Et non mirum si convertit in bonum, qui perfectae bonitatis est, And no mervaile if he turne them into good, who is himselfe perfect goodnesse, as St. Ambrose speaketh. It is a great ignorance therefore, that any are vexed for the miseries of this life, or that any doe imagine the servants of God to be miserable if that they suffer them: Quia quum flagella humiliter suscipiunt, post flagella ad requiem sublimiter suscipiuntur; Because while they receive these afflictions humbly, after these afflictions they are received into rest gloriously:Gregorius in Euang. Homil. 15.
Et tanto mundior pòst ad judicem venit, quanto nunc ejus rubiginem ignis tribulationis purgat, And afterwards he commeth by so much the purer to the Iudge, by how much now the more the fire of tribulation doth purge him, as St. Gregory speaketh. Who knoweth what is good for man in this life? In this life, not onely many are the evils that doe besiege man, but man knoweth not what is good, and how then can he seeke it, much lesse finde it? But in the next life, there is nothing but good to be knowne; and though the good cannot be knowne as it is, yet as it is knowne, it shall be the compleate and endlesse good of man. There evill shall be knowne as a thing not to be feared, and whatsoever contentment may arise from the knowledge that others doe suffer it, they that are in that life shall never know it by any feeling of any in themselves. O therefore that men who cannot know what is good for them in this life, would seeke for that good in the next life! All the dayes of his vaine life, which he spendeth as a shadow: When Adam had sinned, he went to the bushes and trees, to hide himselfe under their shadow; and from that time it is, that man spendeth all the dayes of his vaine life as a shadow. Then his life became vaine, because he was departed from the fountaine of life; then all his dayes became a shadow,Greg. Mor. l. 11. c. 26. and were turned into night: Quia amisso amore conditoris calorem cordis perdidit, & in solo iniquitatis suae frigore permansit, Because the love of his Maker being lost, he lost the heate of his heart, and remained onely in the cold of his iniquitie, as St. Gregory speaketh. But the shadow here is most directly the shadow of ignorance, wherein man spending all his dayes, seeth not, knoweth not what is good for him: but taking oftentimes shadows for substances, or beholding things as they are shadowed over by the subtiltie of Satan, by the vanitie of the world, by the blacknesse of his owne fond affections, is commonly mistaken in the truth of things. For who can tell a man, what shall be after him? What shall follow him, what shall overtake him: Who can tell him what is close behinde him, and may befall him the next day of his life? Wherefore though any one did know what were good for man, yet what were man the better? Seeing he could not tell him, whether he should enjoy it or no. The best way therefore for man, is to commit himselfe to him, who knoweth what is good for him, and what shall befall him: the best way is to submit himselfe to his pleasure, whose good pleasure can make all things to be good unto him: the best way is to get under the shadow of his wings, that there he may be preserved
while he spendeth his dayes as a shadow. What shall be after him under the Sunne: That is, briefly, in this world. Man was made under the Sunne, made to see and know the truth of things, ordained to see and know his owne good; but sinne comming as a cloud betweene the Sunne and him, and though he be under the Sunne, yet keeping the light thereof from him; hence it is that he spendeth all his dayes as a shadow, and in the darknesse of ignorance: hence it is that being deprived of the heate of Gods favour, Sub umbra interni frigoris absconditur, He is hid under the shadow of his inward coldnesse and vanitie. Wee say sometimes that the Sunne is under a cloud, but it is man, not the Sunne that is under the cloud: man who is under the Sunne, is under the cloud of his corrupted nature, and that makes him to lye under so many miseries, not knowing what to doe, what is good for him, what shall be after him.

q.p: VER. 1. A good name is better then precious oyntment: and the day of death, than the day of ones birth.
VER. 2. It is better to goe to the house of mourning, then to goe to the house of feasting: for that is the end of all men, and the living will lay it to his heart.
VER. 3. Sorrow is better then laughter: for by the sadnesse of the countenance the heart is made better.
VER. 4. The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning: but the heart of fooles is in the house of mirth.
VER. 5. It is better to heare the rebuke of the wise, then for a man to heare the song of fooles.
VER. 6. For as the crackling of thornes under a pot, so is the laughter of a foole: this is also vanitie.

div.p:
Verse 1. THE Preacher having manifested the vanity of a false humane happinesse in the former part of this Treatise, proceedeth now to shew what the true happinesse of man is. And the happinesse of man consisting as Lyra noteth,Lyra in hunc versum. Objective in Deo solo, formaliter in clara ejus visione & fruitione, dispositive vero in meritorio opere, For the object of it in God alone,
for the forme of it, in a cleere vision and fruition of God, and for a disposition unto it in the works of a godly life.
