It is of the happinesse of man in this last kinde considered that the Preacher speaketh, Et quae est inchoatio quaedam perfectae beatitudinis, sicut dispositio est quaedam introducendae formae inchoatio, And which is a kinde of beginning of perfect happinesse, even as a disposition to a forme, is a kinde of beginning of the forme, which is to be introduced. Now the works of a godly life being the actions of vertue and devotion; the Preacher beginneth with the actions of vertue. And first, with the actions of prudence, which as the Philosopher sheweth,Aristotel. Proprie sunt eligere ea quae sunt meliora, Properly are to choose those things that are better. Wherefore in this verse he tels us, that a good name is better then precious oyntment, the one being but a perfume of the nostrils, the other a perfume of the heart. It is not sayd, a great name, arising from the greatnesse of worldly honour, worldly wealth, worldly glory in any kinde: but a good name, arising from the goodnesse of a mans workes and actions.Chald. The Chaldee therefore doth thus reade this verse, Melius est nomen bonum quod comparabunt justi in hoc saeculo, quam unguentum unctionis, quod fuerit inunctum super capita regum & sacerdotum, Better is the good name which the just shall obtaine in this world, then the oyntment of anoynting which was powred upon the heads of the Kings and Priests. And Olympiodorus rightly sayth,Olympiodor. in hunc vers. that the praise belonging to a name is due to that name, Non quod linguae sicut pictae tabellae efformant, sed quod ex officiosis actionibus viri justi comparant, Not which the tongues of men as painted tables set forth, but which righteous men procure by their vertuous actions. Saint Chrysostome considering those words of the Psalmist, They call their lands after their owne names, thereupon sayth, Psal. 49.11. Chrysostom.
Ecce aliud genus amentiae, aedificiis, agris, balneis sua nomina inscribere. Ne nomen O homo aedificiis inscribas, sed trophaea recte factorum erigas, quae et in praesenti vita nomen tibi conservant, & infutura vita, immortalem tibi requiem comparent. Nihil enim facit nomen adeo immortale, ut natura virtutum, Behold another kinde of madnesse, to set their names upon houses, lands, baths. But O man, doe not ingrave thy name on houses, but erect trophees of thy good workes, which will preserve thy name in this life, and in the next life will procure thee immortall rest. There is nothing that doth make a name so immortall, as the nature of vertues. When Iacob asked to know the name of the Angel that had wrestled with him; the reply of the Angel is, Gen. 32.29. Wherefore is it that thou dost aske after my name? And he blessed him there. What is this? His name was desired, and he gave him a blessing. It was not sure so much that the Angel would have his name concealed, as rather to shew, that the true glory of a name doth not consist in letters and syllables, but shineth from the actions of goodnesse and vertue. And the day of death is better then the day of ones birth. It is soone after the day of any ones birth, that anciently in the Church of the Iewes, and still in the Church of Christians, his name was and is given to him. And it is the day of
death that maketh the name of any one to be good: for untill then what name hee will deserve, it cannot be said. Hence it is that the Preacher joyneth these together, and even thereby prooving that the day of death is better than the day of ones birth, because a good name is better than a name. It is true that in the day of death, peregrinamur à mundo, wee are absent from the world; but in the day of birth peregrinamur à Domino, we are absent from the Lord,2 Cor. 5.6. as the Apostle speaketh. It is true that the day of death depriveth us of the good things of this life, but it giveth us the better things of a better life, and is it not then better? It is true that the day of death taketh away the light of the Sunne from us, but it giveth us the light of God himselfe: it takes us away from the earth, but it brings us to heaven, and how much better is that? It is true that the day of birth enters man into many miseries, but the day of death sets an end to all. It is true that the day of birth brings forth a man unto many sinnes, but at the day of death the time of sinning dyeth. It is true that the day of our birth, is the beginning of our journey to our Country, but the day of death leads us into it. And is it not better to be in our Country then to bee travelling to it? Is it not better that sinne should dye in us, then we live to sinne? Is it not better to bee delivered from miseries then to be brought into them?Ambr. de fide Resurrect. Saint Ambrose therefore tels us, Fuisse quidam feruntur populi, qui ortus hominum lugerent, obitus{que} celebrarent. Nec imprudenter: eos enim qui in hoc vitae salum venissent, moerendos putabant; eos vero qui ex istius mundi procellis & fluctibus emersissent, non injusto gaudio prosequendos arbitrabantur, There are reported to have beene some, who lamented the births of men, celebrated their deaths. Nor unwisely: for they judged those to bee lamented who came into the salt Sea of this life; they accounted those happy and to bee honoured with joy, who were escaped from the waves and stormes of this world. Saint Bernard speaking of himselfe saith,Bern. de Inter. Dom. cap. 35.
Vivere erubesco, quia parum proficio: mori timeo, quia non sum paratus: malo tamen mori & misericordiae Dei me committere & commendare, quia benignus & misericors est; quam de mala mea conversatione alicui scandalum facere, I am ashamed to live because I am so little bettered; I feare to dye, because I am not ready: yet I had rather to dye; and to commit and commend my selfe to the mercy of God, who is gracious and mercifull, then to give a scandall to any one by my sinfull conversation.Cyprian. de Immortalit. Saint Cyprian relateth of a Bishop, who being neere to his death, and unwilling to dye, and praying unto God for a longer life, an Angell appeared unto him, and with an angry countenance in reprooving him said, Pati timetis, exire de vita non vultis, quid faciam vobis? Yee feare to suffer, yee will not goe out of this life, what shall I doe unto you? All which shewes the day of death to be better then the day of ones birth; but take it, as the Preacher sets it downe: it is when a good name is joyned with it, which is better then a precious oyntment.

Verse 2. The plague of sinne is that which alwayes raigneth; and therefore as in a time of the plague it is better to goe into a house not
infected, then into a house that is infected; so it is better to goe into the house of mourning which is not infected with the plague of sinne, then into the house of feasting, which is infected with it. The Originall word for feasting, is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying a drinking feast most properly, and there it is that the infection of sinne is most dangerous. What though in the house of mourning one being dead, all are sorrowfull, and in the house of feasting all bee merry and pleasant? yet it is better to bee with the sorrowfull, that the cause of sorrow for thy sinnes may be the lesse; then being merry for a fit to fall into some sinne, for which it will be needfull for thee to be long sorrowfull; Eccles. 2.4. & 5. The Preacher had built unto himselfe pleasant houses, Vineyards, Gardens, Orchards, and he it is that here preferreth the house of mourning before the houses of pleasure and delight. God saith unto the Prophet Ieremiah,
Ier. 18.2. Arise and goe downe into the Potters house, and there I will cause thee to heare my words. The Potters house is the house of mourning, wherein is the earthen vessell broken, the earthen vessell of mans body broken by death. And if wee shall goe downe thither, that will make us willing to heare the words of God, whereby to keepe our soules from the infection of sinne. The very temper of sadnesse is a friend to vertue; whereas the heart set upon a merry pinne, is like one standing on the top of a Pinnacle, and in great danger of falling. Saint Chrysostome therefore saith,Chrysostome Hom. 54. ad Popul. Sit aliquis gaudens & laetus, effusus{que}, quid turpius? Sit aliquis dolens & maestus, quid hoc est sapientius? Non enim stat anima firma sede, sed tanquam a quodam flumine tollitur, & elevatur à voluptate, nihil habens stabile, If any one be very joyfull and profuse in mirth, what is more unseemely? If any one be sad and sorrowfull, what is more wise? For the soule doth not stand upon a firme seate, but is caryed away as it were with a river, and is lifted up with pleasure having nothing setled in it. But in the house of mourning there is a speciall cordiall and Antidote against the pestilence of sinne, For that is the end of all: by going into that house is shewed to what we must all goe; there the end of one sheweth, what is the end of all: for all must dye. Saint Austin saith, Ex quo nascimur, necesse est ut moriamur: morbus hic necesse est ut ad mortem perducat, In that wee are borne, there is a necessity that wee must dye: this disease of necessily doth bring men to their death. The Physitian seeing one sicke of a dropsie, another of a feaver, saith, sure they will dye, and yet often they dye not: but hee that is sicke of this disease, is sure to dye without question: And of this doth the house of mourning put us in mind. An usuall name whereby we call a Sepulcher is a monument: and the reason of the name of a monument,Augustin. Serm. 1. in 1. Dom. Quadrag. is as Saint Austin giveth it mo • ens mentem, because it admonisheth the mind: and so indeed the Septuagint doe read it here, In illa enim finis cunctorum admonetur hominum, For therein the end of all men is admonished: the end of another doth admonish every one of his owne end. And how can it choose, but that this also should bee a meanes to restraine him from sinne? It was the first meanes which God used to keepe man from sinne to tell him of this
death, Genes. 2.17. saying, in the day that thou eatest of the forbidden fruit thou shalt surely dye: and it is still a most excellent meanes to keepe man from sinne to remember his death. Isocrates hath a saying; Si mortalis es, ut mortalis vive, If thou bee mortall, live as a mortall man; and seeing wee must all dye let us all so live, as they who at our death must give an accompt of what we have done.Greg. Mor. l. 13. c. 15. Saint Gregory saith, Qui considerat qualis erit in morte, semper fit timidus in operatione, & paene mortuum se putat, quia moriturum minime ignorat: perfecta enim vita est mortis imitatio, quam dum justi solicite peragunt, culparum laqueos evadunt, He that considereth what hee shall bee in death, is fearefull in the works of his life, and thinketh himselfe almost to be dead, because he is not ignorant that hee shall bee dead. For a perfect life is an imitation of death, which while the righteous are carefull to doe, they escape the snares of offences. Wherefore we have here lastly the applying of the cordiall to the hear. And the living will lay it to his heart: the living, he to whom God hath given life to see another dead that is living, and not dead in a careles course of wickednesse, he will lay it to his heart. Symmachus did read it, as S. Hier. tels us, Respiciet ad mentem, will look unto his mind, and consider with himselfe, whether he be ready for his death or no. Tren • ell. reads it, Inditurus est illud animo suo, He will put it on upon his mind; as if his body putting on a mourning garment for the death of his friend, his soule also should put on a mourning garment by the sad remembrance of his own death. Our English hath it very well according to the Originall, will lay it to heart, will bring it home to his own heart,Seneca epist. 102. telling his heart, how that also shall be strucken with death. Seneca observeth well of death, Quod non cogitatur nisi ut aliena, That it is not thought upon, but as belonging to another. We can say, such a one is dead, and such another is dead, and yet we doe not think of our death. But let him that liveth in Gods feare, and looketh to dye in his favour, lay it to his owne heart, to keepe him from the infection of sin, that so though his life may be somewhat the more sad, his death may be by much the more joyfull.

Verse 3. A gravity of behaviour is better than a light wantonnesse; and though it looke with the aspect of sorrow, yet hee that can but looke into the heart shall find that full of cheerefulnesse. Laughing and sporting are often by carelesnesse ensnared in the traps of trouble, whereas a sober sadnesse being more vigilant doth easily avoyd them, and give the heart more quietnesse. But the generall reading of the first part of this verse is, Ira melior risu, Anger is better than laughing. For though an affability of caryage,Cassian. Institut. lib. 8. cap. 5. or else as in Cassian it is stiled, placiditas, a plausibility of disposition and behaviour be a thing acceptable to others, and that which giveth much contentment unto him that hath it; yet it is not seldome that a more sterne countenance, a more sower behaviour, though distasted by others, and causing discontentment unto him that hath it, is rather required and better chosen. Wicked Marcion framing to himselfe one God,Ter. contra Marcion. l. 1. who was all mildnesse, all sweetnesse, and having no anger in him, Tertullian doth justly refute him saying,
Hinc sufficit perversissimum Deum ostendi in ipso praeconio solitariae bonitatis, From hence it sufficeth to shew the perversenesse of his God, even from the praise it selfe of his solitary goodnesse. The meekenesse of the Dove is indeed commendable, but yet sometimes the sting of the Serpent is more praiseworthy. Now this anger is chiefely to be preferred in two respects. First, when others would entise us to sinne: secondly, when by others we see sin practised. As for the first, how often hath an angry sadnesse of countenance, driven away the tempters and seducers unto wickednesse: whereas a courteous affability, a kind plausibility hath made them the bolder to give an assault, and hath made the assault stronger in the successe of it.Aristot. Ethico. lib. 4. cap. 6.
Aristotle therefore speaking of affability saith, Medium illud laudandum, quo quispiam ea quae oportet acceptabit similiter & agre feret, That meane is to be praised, whereby any one shall both accept kindly, and reject with discontentment those things which he ought. Saint Hierome reads it in the Proverbs,Prov. 6.6. Amb. Hexam. cap. 21.
Goe to the Bee, O sluggard, But why unto the Bee? Saint Ambrose giveth an answer, who telleth us, Inter mella fundunt apes venena, si fuerint lacessitae, Among hony the Bees doe send forth poyson if that they bee provoked: and let him remember this, who is so full of hony in his affability, all whose caryage is nothing but a sweetnesse of disposition; and let him learne how to cast out the venime of his anger against the enticers and seducers unto wickednesse. Secondly, anger also is preferred, when wickednesse is committed by others, for how often hath a gentlenesse of caryage encouraged in wickednesse, when a rough temper might easily have stopped it? This was the fault of Heli, Sed quo contra subditorum vitia tepuit, eo contra ipsum districtio aeterni Rectoris exarsit, But he being only mildly warme against their sins that were under him, it made the wrath of the eternall Governour to burne against him,Greg. Moral. l. 5. c. 30. as Saint Gregory speaketh. But here as the same Father speaketh, a double anger is to be considered, Nam alia est ira quam impatientia excitat, alia quam Zelus justitiae format. Illa ex vitio, haec ex virtute generatur, For there is one anger which impatiency stirreth up, another which the zeale of justice frameth. That proceedeth from vice, this from vertue. But even in this also a great care must be had, that immoderatenesse doe not transport it, and as Saint Gregory speaketh,Gregor. Ibid. Excitata ipso zelo rectitudinis longe a rectitudine aberret, Being stirred by a zeale of rightnesse, it wander farre and erre from rightnesse. It is needfull therefore as Isidore Pelusiot •
adviseth,Isido. Pelusiota lib. 2. Epist. that a man be angry even with his anger, Quia si fractum & dissolutum inveniat, nullo negotio superat, sui vigilantem ipsi irascentem, quam primum discedit, Because if it finde a man to bee remisse and slacke, it subdueth him without any difficulty, but if it find him vigilant and angry with it selfe, it quickly forsaketh him. The latter part of the verse by interpreters is read diversly. And if wee apply the anger against those who entise our selves to wickednesse, it may well bee read as Saint Hierome hath, Emendabitur cor, The heart will bee amended; or else as Saint Hierome tels us, that Symmachus did read it, Melior fiet animus, The
mind will bee made better: which is the translation that Tremellius also doth give it; because anger against such corrupters doth preserve and encrease goodnesse in the heart and mind. Or else if we apply the anger, against those by whom wickednesse is committed, it may well be read as the Septuagint have it, corrigitur animus delinquentis, The minde of him that offendeth is corrected. Or else as I conceive it may not amisse bee rendred, Benignum fit cor, The heart is made loving and kind; it being a testimony of a loving minde and heart towards him that is reproved, when an angry countenance reprooveth his faults.

Verse 4. The wise being in the house of mourning, the heart of them is there also: they are truly affected with it, they do indeed lament their deceased friend. Fooles being in the house of mirth, the heart of them is there also, they are wholly possessed, transported, ravished with it,Olympiodor. in hunc vers. and in their mirth are most serious. Olympiodorus therefore speaking of the former part of the verse saith, Vir sapiens funebri luctu secum animo deputans se natum de corruptibili carne brevi ex hac vita migraturum; mortales caeteros qui eadem sunt nati conditione affectu pio prosequitur, A wise man by occasion of funerall sorrow considering in his mind that himselfe also being borne of corruptible flesh, is shortly to depart this life, sheweth a pious affection of sorrow towards others that are mortall and borne of the same condition. Whereas fooles being in the house of sorrow, they are little moved with sorrow, but their heart is in the house of mirth, sporting at least within themselves, when the outward occasion presenteth matter of sorrow unto them. Otherwise was the carriage of Pammachius, Paulinus ad Pammach. Epist. 35. to whom Paulinus writing and commending him for his vertuous sorrow in the buryall of his wife saith, Quam non vacuam fletibus, nec vano pomparum inanium honore comitatus, debito ordine primum charo funeri justa persolvens, piis lachrymis, & largo charitatis rore perfusus religiosas exequias honorasti; Whom following without the vaine ostentation of empty pompe, but not without weeping, in a dew order first paying the duties to her deare funerals by religious teares, thou didest also honour her funerall solemnities with a large dew of charity wherewith thou wert endued. The same Father in the same Epistle speaking of sorrow for the dead, saith, Bonae lachrymae charitatis, in quibus Pater Abraham matrem repromissionis eluxit: bonae lachrymae pietatis quas Ioseph justus impendit patri. Sed quid Sanctorum mortalium praedicem fletus? Flevit & Iesus amicum, hanc etiam passionem de nostra infaelicitate dignatus, ut mortuo infunderet lachrymas, Good were the teares of affection, in which Father Abraham lamented the Mother of the promise: good were the teares of devout duty which righteous Ioseph bestowed on his father. But what doe I set forth the weeping of holy mortall men? Iesus also wept for his friend, and vouchsafing to take this passion also from our unhappinesse, he powred out teares for the dead. The councell therefore of the sonne of Syrack is,Ecclus. c. 38. v. 16. & 17.
My sonne, let teares fall downe over the dead, weepe bitterly and make great moane and use lamentation, as hee is worthy. But to looke againe upon the words of the verse:
The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning: his body, in which his heart is set, as it were in a house, being a house of mourning, as well in regard of the sober and sad demeanour of it, is in respect of the teares which he sheds, the sighs that he makes, both for his owne sinnes, and for the troubles of Gods Church, and the miseries of his people. But the heart of fooles is in a house of mirth; their body being full of the gesticulations of mirth, as well in respect of their light behaviour, as in regard of the vaine talking, ridiculous laughing, both of and at their owne sinnes, as also the distresse of Gods Church, the calamities of his people. Againe the heart of the wise is in the house of mourning: the heartie mourning of the wise is in the house, private, and unknowne; it is not in the streets open to the view and notice of the world: for so the command of our Saviour Christ is, When yee fast,
Mat 6.16. & 17. & 18. be not as the hypocrites of a sad countenance, for they disfigure their faces, that they may appeare to men to fast. Verely, I say unto you, they have their reward. But when thou fastest, anoynt thine head, and wash thy face, that thou appeare not unto men to fast, but unto thy Father, which is in secret; and thy Father which seeth in secret, shall reward thee openly. The heart of fooles is in the house of mirth: they have all their mirth to themselves, all is in the house, to the feeding, feasting, delighting of themselves, and their owne hearts. The heart of others is not made merry by them, either by the workes of charitie, or the good offices that they doe them. It is not abroad that their mirth is seene, within the dores of their owne house all is enjoyed. Saint Hierome understanding this verse with reference unto that which followeth, giveth this sense of it,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Cor sapientis vadat ad domum talis viri, qui se corripiat delinquentem, ut adducat ad lachrymas, & qui provocet propria lugere peccata; & non eat ad domum laetitiae, ubi doctor adulatur & decipit; ubi non conversionem audientium, sed applausus quaerit & laudem. Talis praeceptor plangitur, dives in sermone, non dives in opere, Let the heart of the wise goe to the house of such a one, who may reproove him when he offendeth, that so he may bring him to teares, and make him to lament his owne sinnes: and let him not goe to the house of mirth, where the teacher flattereth and deceiveth: where he doth not seeke the conversion of the hearers, but his owne applause and praise. Such a teacher is to be lamented, being rich in speech, but not in the worke of the ministery.

Verse 5. It is better: it may not be sweeter, it may not be so pleasing and delightfull, but sure it is better, and there is lesse hurt, more good that ariseth from it. There is in rebuke a jarring and harsh musick, because it opposeth the fault that is committed, it disagreeth with the minde of him that hath committed it: but yet it is a better musick then the melodious songs of flattering parasites, who leading on in wickednesse, doe bring on to destruction. It is storyed of Alexander the great, that having had a Philosopher a long time with him, at length sayd unto him, Recede à me prorsus, consortium tuum nolo, Be gone from mee, I desire not thy company. And being asked why, made answere, Quod
quum tanto tempore mecum degeris, nunquam me de vitio aliquo increpasti, Because having lived so long time with me, thou hast not reprooved any vice in mee. For either thou hast not observed me to erre, which is a great argument of ignorance, because being a man, I know my selfe to be exposed to many errours. Or else thou hast knowne me to erre, and hast held thy peace, which is a proofe of thine unfaithfulnesse. Surely, it was a great praise of that great Monarch thus to doe. But if he were put away, that did not reproove, then much more are fooles to be put away, who by their songs doe nourish men in their errours, and much better it is to heare the reproofe of the wise. Of the wise, who have wisedome to know what it is that they rebuke, who have wisedome to consider whom they doe rebuke, who have wisdome to understand how they doe rebuke, and that they doe it neither furiously nor proudly. First,Cassian. Institut. l. 8. c. 5. not furiously, and therefore Cassian sayth, Delinquentem fratrem si necesse est, ita curare festinet, ut dum medelam leviori forsitan febricula laboranti procurat inferret, non semetipsum iratus deteriori morbo caecitatis involvat, Let every one if it be needfull, so hasten to cure his offending brother, that while he seeketh to apply a remedy to one who is sicke perhaps of a light feaver, being angry he doe not cast himselfe into a worse disease of blindnesse.Augustinus Serm. 18. de verbis Dom. Secondly, not proudly, and therefore St. Austin sayth, Neque consentientes sitis malis, ut approbetis, neque negligentes ut non arguatis, neque superbientes ut insultantes arguatis, Neither be ye consenting unto evils, that ye should approove them, neither negligent that yee should not reproove them, neither proud that yee reproove them in an insulting manner. Then for a man to heare the song of fooles: a song made to the tune of fooles, who neither care what they sing, nor consider to whom they sing it; but onely intend by singing to please, though by pleasing they bring much hurt and mischiefe. Great is the power of sweet singing; and as Theodorick speaketh in Cassiodore, In humana voce varias animi affectiones gravidametra pepererunt, The fruitfull measures of the voice, have brought forth many affections of mans minde; and no lesse is the power of flattering lips in their strange working upon mans heart. So that as in the same place Theodorick speaketh of those who heard the Syrens singing; Eligebant suaviter decepti Scopulos incurrere, ne tantam paterentur dulcedinem praeterire, They did choose being sweetly deceived to runne upon the rockes, rather then to suffer themselves to passe by so great delight; in like manner, men doe rather suffer themselves to fall upon many evills, then not to content themselves with delightfull flatteries. But as there also it is sayd of Vlysses, Cogitavit foelicissimam surditatem, & quam vincere intelligendo non poterant, melius non advertendo superabant, He invented a most happie deafenesse, and that which his Mariners could not overcome by intending to it, he made them to overcome better by not perceiving of it; so to overcome the power of such deceitfull flatterers, the way is to neglect to heare their songs, and rather to listen to the more solemne musicke of a grave and wise reproofe, then to the light and wanton songs of these enticing
seducers. Gregorius Thaumaturgus noteth in this verse,Greg. Thaumat. that when the Preacher sayth, It is better to heare the rebuke of the wise, the word is there singular, speaking of one wise man, and him to be opposed unto the song of many fooles, for there the word is plurall. Whereupon he sayth, Multo magis optandum sapientis unius objurgationem excipere, quam totius chori improborum & miserorum hominum cantantium auditorem fieri: ille quidem prodest dum corripit, isti vero bellum inferunt dum laudant, It is much rather to be wished, to receive the reproofe of one wise man, then to be the hearer of the whole quire of wicked and miserable men singing: for he doth benefit us while that he doth rebuke us, but they make warre against us, while that they praise us.

Verse 6. Fooles themselves are but thornes, their laughing is but as the crackling of thornes under a pot. Themselves as thornes doe grow up to be burned; their laughing as the crackling of thornes under a pot, doth make a great noyse for the time, but it is quickly gone. Yea, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Cusuc, the sporting of fooles; and as the French translation hath it, La gaudisserie, the merriment of the wicked, all their pleasant delighting of themselves, is speedily vanished away, like the flashing of thornes. For as St. Ambrose speaketh, Spinae dum arde • t sonant, Ambros. de hortat. ad virginitatem. & cito exuruntur, ut nullus caloris sit effectus, Thornes when they burne make a noyse, and quickly are consumed, so that there is no effect of their heate; so likewise fooles, when they are in prosperitie make a noyse of it, but it is soone gone, and they have little fruit of any comfort by it. Besides, as the crackling of thornes is under the pot, so that though the flame doe lift it selfe up in an exulting bravery, yet it is kept downe and suppressed; in like manner, the laughing and merriment of the wicked is under the pot of manifold troubles and distresses of this life, by which it is suppressed, and whereby the gallantry of it is checked and cast downe.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome taketh the fooles laughing in this verse to be the fooles singing in the former verse, and accordingly applyeth unto the pleasing words of a flattering teacher; Vel ad curas saeculi, quae spinae interpretantur, auditores suos cohortantis, vel futuro eos incendio praeparantis, Either exhorting his hearers to the cares of the world, which the thornes are interpreted to be; or else preparing them for the burning which is to come: and whose words though never so sweet to his hearers, are in Gods eares but as Insuavis strepitus spinarum sub olla ardentium, the harsh unpleasant noyse of thornes under a pot.Lyra in hunc vers. Lyra also taking the two verses to be of a consort, applyeth this verse also unto flatterers, and that as thornes Faciunt magnum sonum et inutilem, imo ad sui consumptionem, ita stulti applausus in malo alterius: nocet enim utrique, scilicet adulatori, et ei cui adulatur, Doe make a great and unprofitable sound, and that to the consuming of themselves; so a fooles applauding of another in his wickednesse hath the like effect: for it hurteth both, as well the flatterer as him that is flattered. Saint Bernard sayth, Spina culpa est, spina poena est, spina falsus frater, spina vicinus est malus, Sinne is a thorne, punishment is a thorne, a false brother is a thorne,
a bad neighbour is a thorne, and this false brother, this bad neighbour is a flatterer, and therefore fitly here compared to a thorne. And of him it may be sayd, as St. Bernard also speaketh, Attende pessimum germen ejus cui maledictum est terrae nostrae: quum inquit colueris eam, spinas & tribulos germinabit tibi, Behold the worst fruite of that our earth to which the curse was given, When thou dressest it, it shall bring forth bryars and thornes. Saint Ambrose understandeth this verse of a fooles unseemely laughing, and that as the crackling of thornes under a pot, Sic est risus stultorum qui sine gratia sonat, et ollam sui corporis urit, So is the laughter of fooles which soundeth without comelinesse,Ambros. de horta. ad virginitatem. and burneth, disfigureth the pot of his body. The Father addeth, saying, Merità negabat Sarah quia riserat, ne videretur ridendo de effectu promissionum dubitasse coelestium; et tamen ille risus plenus gravitatis et pudoris erat, quem nemo alius testis nisi Deus solus cognosceret, quem occulta non fallunt, Iustly did Sarah denie that she laughed, that shee might not seeme by laughing to doubt of the efficacy of the heavenly promises; and yet that laughing was full of gravitie, full of modestie, which no other witnesse knew but God alone, to whom no hidden things are secret. But how much then is the immodest and unmeasurable laughing of fooles to be condemned? And who have as many witnesses of their shame as of their laughing. Their laughing is not secret, but maketh as great a noyse as the crackling of thornes under a pot: the pot of their mouths boyling with a froth and scum of their folly.Clemens Alexandr. Paedag. lib. 2. cap. 5. So that their laughing is as Clemens Alexandrinus speaketh, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Irridendus risus, A laughing to be laughed at. Let it therefore be the care of every one, so to use laughter, so to enjoy the merriment of this world; that it may not be the laughter, that it may not be the merriment of fooles, but of them that are wise; that so God at length may fill their mouth with laughter, and their lips 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
jubilatione, Iob 8 21. Greg. Mor. l. 8. c. 32. with shouting for joy, as Bildad speaketh in Iob. For as St. Gregory noteth upon the words, Os justorum tunc risu implebitur, quum eorum corda finitis peregrinationum fletibus aeterna laetitiae exultatione satiabuntur, The mouth of the righteous shall then be filled with laughter, when the teares of their pilgrimage being dryed up, their hearts shall be satisfied with exultation of joy. Non autem tunc erit risus corporis, sed cordis risus. Risus enim nunc corporis de lascivia dissolutionis, sed risus cordis tunc de laetitiae nascetur securitatis, But then it shall not be a laughing of the body, but a laughing of the heart. For now the laughing of the body commeth from a wantonnesse of loosenesse; but the laughing of the heart shall then arise from a joy of securitie. When the servants of God being filled with the joy of a manifest beholding of him, Quasi ad hilaritatem risus exilient in ore mentis, Shall as it were breake forth into a cheerefulnesse of laughing, in the mouth of their understanding. Then their laughter shall not be as the crackling of thornes under a pot, Iob 38.7. but as the singing together of the morning Starres, and as the shouting for joy of all the Sonnes of God. What weeping for our sinnes can be sufficient to come to this joy? As for the
other, what is it but vanitie? Vanitie in all, but in a foole what is it but notorious vanitie? And as for flattery, what is it but a silly vanitie in him that is pleased with it? What is it but a wicked vanitie in him that useth it?

epigraph.q: VER. 7. Surely, oppression maketh a wise man mad: and a gift destroyeth the heart.

div.p:
Verse 7. The French translation doth reade here instead of oppression, Ce qu' on est trompe, This that they are deceived; maketh a wise man mad; and so the sense of the verse may seeme to be referred unto flattery, whereof the former verses speake, and by which when a wise man perceiveth himselfe to have beene deluded, it maketh him even mad with anger against himselfe. Our translation of oppression may be referred unto the rebuke whereof before the Preacher speaketh; which as comming from the wise, and being just, is worthy to be heard, so being unjust, is enough to make even a wise man mad in vexing of himselfe. Or else wee may take the connexion thus, that the Preacher having shewed the infirmities of fooles, here he sheweth the infirmities of wise men: and first, shewing the weaknesse of a wise man oppressed; secondly, he sheweth the corruption of a wise man oppressing: and of both he sheweth that their understanding is destroyed. Surely, oppression maketh a wise man mad: a wound is there most grievous, where the sense of feeling is most perfect, and therefore a wise man being most apprehensive of the wrong that is done him, and best able to looke into it, and to judge of every circumstance of it, that makes him to be the more affected with it. But yet he that shall be so much moved with the wrong of another, as to loose his owne understanding, must needs be onely Sapiens in profectu positus, a wise man that is tending to wisedome, not one that hath attained to it, as St. Hierome well noteth,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Basilius Epist. 86. quae est ad Bosphorum Episcop. the wise man here to be. Saint Basil speaking of himselfe sayth, Quo putas animum meum dolore affecit fama calumniae illius, quam mihi offuderunt quidam; non metuentes judicem perditurum omnes loquentes mendacium? Tanto videlicet, ut prope totam noctem insomnem duxerim; ita ipsa cordis mei penetralia concepta moestitia occupavit. At necesse est ut omnia feramus, omnia patienter toleremus, ultionem ipsorum Domino committentes, qui non despiciet nos, With what griefe dost thou thinke did that calumny oppresse my minde, which some not fearing the Iudge, who shall destroy all them that speake lyes, did cast upon me? Even so much, that I slept not almost all the night, so had the apprehended sadnesse possessed the secrets of my heart. But it is necessary, that wee beare all, that wee suffer all patiently, committing the revenge of them to the Lord, who will not despise us. This was a wise man indeed, feeling the force of oppression in making his heart sorrowfull, but yet overcomming it by the force of grace. Saint Austin doth well compare a wise man wronged unto the ship wherein
our Saviour was asleepe: he heareth himselfe to be slandered, and therupon is much moved with anger, Convitium ventus est, iracundia fluctus, The slander is the winde, the anger is the wave, and by them being tossed, he is in some danger. But when he studyeth revenge, and the desire of that oppresseth his minde, I am navis propinquat naufragio, then is the ship neere to a shipwracke. And all is because Christ is asleepe in the ship; In corde enim hominis somnus Christi, oblivio fidei, For in the heart of man the sleepe of Christ is the forgetfulnesse of faith. Let the eye of faith be open,Augustin. l. 3. contra literas Petil. and that will tell us, as St. Austin speaketh, Non intuendum esse, quam sit amarum, sed quam falsum sit quod audio, That wee must not looke how bitter that is which wee heare, but how false it is. That will tell us, Quis quis volens detrahit famae meae, nolens addit mercedi meae, Whosoever he be, that willingly detracteth from my credit, he unwillingly addeth to my reward.Paulinus Epist. 14. ad Celantiam. Indeed, as Paulinus speaketh, Beatus qui tam sancte tamque graviter disposuit vitam suam, ut de eo sinistri aliquid ne fingi quidem possit; dum adversus obtrectatorum libidinem pugnat meriti magnitudo, Happie is he who ordereth his life so holily, so wisely, that no wrong can be fayned of him; whiles that the greatnesse of his worth, withstandeth the malice of his slanderers. Or if wee be not so happy, let us be carefull, Ne ex nobis scintilla procedat, per quam adversus nos sinistrae famae flamma confletur, That from our selves a sparkle doe not proceed, from whence the flame of a wrong report, may be kindled against us. Or if wee be not so carefull, Nos modo id agamus, ut male de nobis nemo loqui absque mendacio possit, Let us at least doe this, that no one may speake evill of us without a lye. And then if any will wrong us,Chrysostom. Homil. 26. in Acta Apostol. Rideamus, ploremus, Let us laugh, let us weepe, sayth Saint Chrysostome. Let us laugh, in comforting our selves in God; let us weepe, as lamenting our oppressours woefull estate. This is the part of a true wise man. To have wisedome to see the wrong that is done, and not to have wisdome to see how to beare it, will indeed soone make such a wise man mad. And a gift destroyeth the heart: Saint Hierome tels us, that the Septuagint, Aquila, Theodotio, did reade this verse, as himselfe also reads it, Perdit cor 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 fortitudinis sive vigoris ejus, Destroyeth the heart of his strength or vigour. Whereupon it seemeth to me, that they derived the Originall word here used from the roote 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 from whence is derived 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Cumbi, the loynes wherein the strength of man lyeth. Now this translation referreth this latter part of the verse to the former part, shewing how oppression maketh a wise man mad, by taking away and destroying the light of understanding, which is as it were the heart of it. But St. Hierome also tels us that Symmachus did reade it, as the latter translatours doe, And a gift destroyeth the heart: that is, corrupteth it, and maketh it blind, even in a wise man.Deut. 16.19. Cajetan. Ibid. So we reade in Deuteronomy, A gift doth blind the eyes of the wise, and perverteth the words of the righteous. Where Cajetane noteth, that Iudges are sayd to be wise, and to be righteous, whereof the one declareth the perfection of the understanding; the other of the will,
and yet that a gift is opposed unto both, as destroying both. Wherefore he saith, Perpende vim munerum contra utram{que} partem animi, intellectum scilicet & affectum, & quod amplius est intellectum, perfectum sapientia, affectum praeditum justitia, Consider the force of gifts against both parts of the soule, the understanding, and the will, and that which is more, the understanding perfected by wisdome, the will endued with righteousnesse. And indeed it is an excellent wisdome which is not taken with the shining countenance of a gift, and which knoweth how to take heed of gifts that are offered.Greg. Thaumat. Ser. 1.
Gregorius Thaumaturgus doth teach us this wisdome from a woman, but it is from the perfection of women, he blessed Virgin Mary, to whom when the Angell had brought the message, that she should conceive the Son of God, she asketh how shall this be? Ne{que} prius Sanctissima virgo donum admisit, quam quis illud mitteret, & quodnam donum esset, ac quis ferret addidicisset, Neither did the most holy Virgin admit of the gift, untill shee had first learned, who it was that sent it, what the gift was, who it was that brought it saying, as it were in her heart to the Angell, Vnde sic nobis benedictionem asportasti? Ex cujus thesauris verbi margarita emissa est? Vnde nobis promissum materiam paravit? From whence dost thou so bring a blessing unto us? Out of whose treasure is the pearle of this world sent us? What ground hath this promise that it should be made to us? And surely it is needfull that a wise man looke well into a gift, and examine it throughly, least that it destroy the heart of his wisdome.

q.p: VER. 8. Better is the end of a thing then the beginning thereof: and the patient in spirit, is better than the proud in spirit.
VER. 9. Bee not hasty in thy spirit to bee angry, for anger resteth in the bosome of fooles.

div.p:
Verse 8. Saint Hierome reading the first part of this verse,Hieronym. in hunc vers. as the Septuagint doe, Better is the end of a speech then the beginning of it, giveth diverse interpretations unto it; as first, Meliores sunt in dicendo epilogi quam exordium, in his enim dicentis solicitudo finitur, in illo incipit, Better is the conclusion of a speech then the entrance of it, because in that the care of the speaker is ended, in this it beginneth. Againe, because when a speech is ended, the hearer considereth, of that which hath beene said; but when we begin to speake, he hath not as yet gotten any benefit by it. Againe quia melius sit tacere quam loqui, Because it is better to hold our peace, then to speake. Lastly he saith, that it may bee also understood
thus, because while we are in this world; Quod scimus omne principium est, That which we know is all a beginning, but when that which is perfect is come, we shall in the end be made perfect. But to take it as our translation hath it; many reasons also may bee given of it. As first better is the end of a thing then the beginning: because the beginning is for the end, the end is not for the beginning: againe because the beginning of a thing is the imperfection of it, the end is the perfection: againe, because the end giveth knowledge of a thing, what it is, the beginning doth not: lastly because the end goeth beyond the beginning by many degrees. From whence is to bee learnt, not to judge of things according to the beginning of them, but according to the end. For that may be much better then the beginning, at least wise it will direct much better our judgement of it. And let us also learne not to stop or stay our owne good courses in the beginning of them, but to proceed in them unto the end, because to end well is much better then to begin well. And that we may practise these things which we learne, let us be slow or long in spirit, taking time to weigh and consider all things before wee judge, and not proud in spirit, as we know all things and could judge presently. Let us be patient in spirit, and contented to beare the burden of proceeding on, and not proud in spirit, as if in the beginning we were come to the top of perfection. But to consider the words, as they respect the foregoing passage. The Preacher having shewed the infirmity of wise men, when they are oppressed, here prescribeth a remedy against it, by wishing them rather to looke to the end, and to the right which in the end God will doe them; then to the beginning, and to the wrong which therein is done them. For there is an end to be made, when God will judge all in righteousnesse, and rewarding the patient, for the oppression they have suffered, will requite the oppressours according to their deserts. The vulgar Latin reading the first part of the verse thus, Melior est finis orationis quam principium, Better is the end of a speech, then the beginning,Lyra in hunc versum. Lyra conceiveth it as if it were thus to be rendred, Better is the end of prayer, then the beginning, and thereupon wishing the oppressed to goe to God for helpe, saith, that the end of prayer is better than the beginning of it, Quia incipit a tristitia propter illatam sibi calumniam, & terminatur in consolationem a Deo datam, Because it beginneth from sorrow for the wrong receaved, but is ended in consolation which is by God granted. And the patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit: the Originall is longus spiritu, long in spirit, and signifieth such a one who though he be long wronged, yet is still patient. And this is more than to bee slow in spirit. For some at the time when they are wronged, are quiet and patient, and being slow in spirit, doe passe it by commendably: but afterwards calling it to mind, and thinking much upon it, they inflame themselves with the fire of griefe, and studying for a meanes of revenge, Mansuetudinem quam tolerantes habuerunt, Greg. Pastor. cu. Par. 3. Adm. 9.
retractantes in malitiam vertunt, Checking the meeknesse, which in their suffering they had, they turne it into malice, as Saint Gregory
speaketh. For it is the cunning of Satan, that being overcome at first by the patient taking of wrong, he maketh his second assault, and often times, Tanto mentem moerore conturbat, ut vir patiens illa se aequanimite • tolerasse post victoriam captivus crubescat, Hee disquieteth the mind with so much sorrow, that a patient man captive after his victory is ashamed to have taken things so quietly, and is grieved that hee did not returne like for like, and seeketh if occasion may bee offered to returne worse. But what is this else, then as Saint Gregory speaketh,Greg. Ibid. Per fortitudinem in campo victorem esse, & per negligentiam post modum inter urbis claustra capi, In the field by courage to be victorious, and afterwards by negligence to be surprised within the fences of the City? But he that is longus spiritu, long in spirit, will not only at first be patient, but afterwards also, even so long, untill he have forgotten the wrong. It may be noted also, that it is the patient in spirit, that is here commended, inwardly patient, not only in outward appearance; for in vaine is rage, and clamour, and reviling suppressed, if within, malice the mother of wickednesse beare sway, In cassum foras nequitia ex ramis inciditur, si surrectura mul • iplicius intus in radice servatur, In vaine are the boughs of wickednesse cut off without, if within it be kept in the roote to spring up much more. This saith Saint Gregory, Tanto deterior fit culpa in conspectu Dei, Greg. Ibid. quanto sibi apud homines virtutis speciem vendicat, Is by so much the greater fault in the sight of God, by how much before men it challengeth to it selfe the shew of vertue. Is better than the proud in spirit: the Originall is, Elatus spiritu, lifted up in spirit, that is, then he, who is presently flying in his face that doth him wrong, and will not be beneath him in any thing. Our English also doth well expresse it proud in spirit: for indeed impatiency is nothing but a pride of heart, which maketh men disdaigne to beare with any thing. Besides it maketh men also proud in a vaine glorious boasting, Quia dum despici in mundo hoc quis{que} non patitur, bona si qua sibi occulta sunt ostentare conatur, & sic per impatientiam us{que} ad arrogantiam ducitur, Because while every one cannot endure to be despised in this world, if that there bee any good things hidden in him, hee striveth to make them knowne, and so by impatiency a man is brought to arrogancy, as Saint Gregory speaketh. Lastly, the patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit; Because as hee possesseth his soule in quietnesse and comfort, so hee delivereth his soule from many evils, and shall receave a good reward of glory. Whereas the proud in spirit being driven in his rage, whither his owne desire doth not cary him, Agit commotus velut nesciens, unde post doleat sciens, Being moved doth that as it were ignorantly, for which he grieves when that he knowes it. Or else being caryed headlong, Quaedam velut alienatus peragit, vix mala sua postquam fuerint perpetrata cognoscens, some things hee doth as it were a mad man,Greg. Ibid. scarcely knowing his owne evils after that hee hath done them; as Saint Gregory speaketh.

Verse 9. There is in anger a double rashnesse, hast, and posthaste. Posthaste is when men run into anger, before they have cause. Hast
is when they have cause to be angry, but they runne into it, before they have well considered of the cause, and before they have well ordered the passion of their anger. The first is extremity of folly, the second is folly also.Seneca de Clement. l. 2. cap. 4. And as Seneca saith, Illos crudeles vocabo, qui puniendi causam habent, modum non habent, I will call them cruell, who have cause of punishing, but not measure in punishing; so they may well bee called fooles, who though they have cause to be angry, yet are hasty in running into it.Ambros. de hortat. ad virginitatem And this it is, which Saint Ambrose understandeth here to be meant, who saith, Noli festinare in spiritu tuo irasci; hoc est, causa sit quae moveat indignationem, non sit festina vindicta, Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry: that is, although there be cause that moveth thine anger, yet let not thy revenge be hasty. Be not therefore hasty to be angry, but if thou bee angry bee hasty to put it away againe.Greg. Mor. l. 5. c. 30. For as Saint Gregory noteth, anger doth affect men foure wayes, Nonnullos ira citius accendit, facilius deserit; citiùs flammam faciunt, sed protinus in favilla frigescunt: nonnullos tardè quidem commovet, sed diutius tenet; accensionem tarde suscipiunt, sed accensi semel difficilius extinguuntur: alii citius iracundiae flammas accipiunt, & tardius deponunt: alii vero has & tarde suscipiunt, & citius amittunt; Some, anger doth quickly set on fire, and it leaveth them easily, they are soone in a flame, and forthwith cooled into embers. Others, it moveth slowly, but it holdeth them long, and they being hard to take fire are also hardly put out; Others doe flame in anger quickly, and are slow in foregoing of it: others are slow in taking it, and quicke in leaving it. In which foure kinds, Ad tranquillitaetis bonum ultimus plus quam primus appropinquat, & in malo secundum tertius superat, The last commeth neerer to the good of quietnesse then the first, and in evill the third exceedeth the second. It is the apprehension of the just cause of anger,August. in Epist. 149. which maketh men too often to be too hasty in it: but Saint Austin saith very well, Multo melius nec juste cuiquam irascimur, quam velut justè irascendo, in alicujus odium irae occulta facilitate dilabimur. In recipiendis enim hospitibus ignotis ista solemus dicere, multo melius esse malum hospitem perpeti, quam forsitan per ignorantiam bonum excludi, dum cavemus ne recipiatur malus. Sed in affectibus animi contra est, nam incomparabiliter salubrius est, etiam irae justae pu • santi non aperire penetrale cordis, quam admittere non facile recessuram, & perventuram de surculo ad trabem, audet quippe impudenter etiam crescere citius quam putatur, It is much better that we be not angry with any one justly, then that by being angry, as it were justly, we fall to the hatred of some one by the secret facility of anger. For in receaving of strangers we use to say thus, that it is better to suffer a bad guest, then that by ignorance, a good guest should bee excluded, while that we take heed that a bad one be not admitted. But in the affections of the mind it is quite contrary: for it is incomparably safer not to open the inward dores of our hearts when anger knocketh, then to receave that which will not easily depart, and which from a twigge will grow to a beame, for it dareth even impudently to encrease faster then is thought. Be not hasty to be angry: the Originall word here
used doth most properly signifie indignation: now indignation is, Qua is cui irascimur contemnitur & vilependitur, quasi indignus à qu • tale quid patiamur. Huic conjunctus est timor mentis quo irascens seipsum extollit, & alteri praefert, That, by which he with whom we are angry is sleighted and contemned, as being one unworthy, from whom we should suffer such a thing. And with this is joyned a swelling of mind whereby he that is angry lifteth up himselfe, and preferreth himselfe before the other. And thus are the two verses well joyned together. For the former verse endeth with the proud in Spirit.Arist. Rhetor. l. 1. c. 2. But to take the word as it signifieth anger generally. Let no one imagine anger to be only a heate of passion, for that is only in the sensitive part of the soule, whereas anger is in the will especially, and the definition of it is, Motus animi male volentis alteri ob injuriam acceptam, & doloris ultionem expetens, A motion of the mind ill willed towards another for a wrong receaved, and through griefe desiring revenge. In which respect the Philosopher calleth it, Libidinem ulciscendi, a lust of revenging. Wherefore when the Preacher saith; be not hasty to be angry, it is not so much, be not hasty to give way to the heate of passion, as be not hasty to give way to the desire of revenge. Neither doth he suppresse his anger, who suppresseth the violence of his passion, unlesse he also reject the seeking of revenge when anger resteth. The difference which S. Hier. maketh betweene fury and anger is this, Furor incipiens ira est, & fervescens in animo indignatio; Hieronym. ira autem quae furore restincto de siderat ultionem, & eum quem nocuisse putat, vult laedere, Fury is anger beginning, and a boyling indignation in the mind; anger is that, which when the fury is extinguished, desireth revenge, and seeketh to hurt him, by whom it thinketh hurt to have beene done. The Preacher therefore saith, anger resteth in the bosome of fooles: that is the bed wherein the watchfulnesse of it sleepeth, and therefore Cassian saith, that they who are transported with anger,Cassian. Instit. l. 8. c. 1.
Sapientiae participes fieri non possunt, tametsi sapientes omnium pronunciari opinione videantur, Cannot be partakers of wisdome, although they may seeme to be pronounced wise by the opinion of all. And Saint Gregory saith, Quum tranquillitatem mentis ira diverberat, Greg. Mor. l. 5. c. 30.
dilaniatam quodammodo scissam{que} perturbat, ut sibimet ipsi non congruat, ac vim intimae similitudinis amittat, When anger beateth the quietnesse of the mind, it doth so disturb it, as if it did teare and cut it, so that it doth not agree with it selfe, nor is like to it selfe. Let him therefore that will not be a foole, observe the Apostles direction, and let not the Sunne goe downe upon his wrath, Ephes. 4.20. let not the night of anger destroy the light of wisdome and reason in him. For as Saint Gregory expounding those words saith,Greg. Ibid. Quum menti iracundia confusionis tenebras incutit, huic Deus radium suae cognitionis abscondit, When anger casteth the darknesse of confusion upon the mind, God hideth the beame of his knowledge from it.

epigraph.q: VER. 10. Say not thou what is the cause that the former dayes were better than these, for thou dost not enquire wisely concerning this thing.

div.p:
Verse 10. The Preacher having shewed the impatiency of wise men and therein their infirmity for wrong receaved from particular persons: here hee sheweth and reformeth their impatiency against the generall times. For it is the manner and humour of too many, who would bee thought wise to condemne the times in an impatient discontentment against them, especially if themselves doe not thrive or be not favoured in the times as they desire or as they thinke they should be. To expresse the impatiency of such men, the Preacher maketh them to aske a question, saying: What is the cause that the former dayes were better? For it is the manner of impatiency to bee asking questions, as if no right nor good answer could bee given to them. But the answer which the Preacher giveth to this question, is to forbid them to aske it, because it being a question that commeth not from wisedome, it should not come from them, that would be accompted wise. And surely it cannot bee a thing that is wisely enquired after. For though the question supposeth that the former dayes were better, yet how dost thou know it? Hadst thou lived in the former dayes thou wouldest have said the same of them. And still thou wouldest have commended that most, which thou diddest least know.Matth. 26.64. Matth. 27.11. Hilarius in Matth. Can. 32. When our Saviour Christ was asked by the High Priest, whether he were the Christ the Sonne of God, he answered, thou hast said: when Pilate asked him whether he were the King of the Iewes, hee answered, thou sayest: whereupon Hilarius saith that answer was given to the High Priest in the tense of the time past, because out of the law he had alwayes said, that Christ was to come; but to Pilate who was ignorant of the law, Christ answered in the tense of the time present, Quia per fidem praesentis confessionis salus gentium est, because it is by the faith of the present confession, that salvation is to the Gentiles. But I note it for this, to observe how well sighted the Iewes were in the times past, and in the prophesies of Christ, and how blind they were in the present times, when Christ the Messiah was present among them. Not unlike to them are many malecontent and impatient spirits, who see the goodnesse of former times, and extoll them, but cannot see the goodnesse of God in the present times to praise him for it.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome expounding this verse saith, Nec vetus saeculum praesenti praeferas: quia unus utrius{que} conditor est Deus, virtutes bonos dies viventi faciunt, vitia malos, Neither doe thou preferre the old world before the present, because one God is the maker of them both; vertues doe make the times good to him that liveth in them, vices doe make them evill. And that it is not
wisely sayd to speake so, he sheweth in another place, saying, Stultum est referre ad tempora, quum in nostra sit potestate, Hieronym. in c. 6. Amos. vel bonum diem nobis vel malum facere. Non dies ullus malus est, sed unusquisque parat sibi malum, It is a foolish thing to referre it to the times, when as it is in our owne power to make the day either good or evill to our selves. For there is no day evill, but every one maketh the day evill to himselfe. Another exposition which Saint Hierome giveth of the words is this; Sic debes vivere, ut semper praesentes dies meliores tibi sint quam praeteriti, Thou must so live, that alwayes the present dayes may be better to thee, then the past were: least it be sayd to thee, as it was to the unwise Galatians, Having begun in the Spirit, Galat. 3.3. Iohn 12.35. are yee now made perfect in the flesh? The saying of our Saviour Christ is, Iohn 12.35. Walke while yee have the light, least darknesse come upon you: and it is the note of Saint Bernard upon it, Non ambulantem, Bernard. super Cantic. Serm. 49.
sed sedentem à mortis tenebris comprehendi periculum est, The danger is not of him that walketh, but of him that sitteth, least the darknesse of death come upon him. He that walketh on, and maketh the present dayes still to be better, he is safe: but he of whom it may be sayd, the former dayes were better, he it is that is in danger of comming to the evill day.Lyra in hunc versum. Lyra out of Bonaventure giveth this exposition of the words; The time wherein the Law was given, was better than the former times wherein men lived after Adams fall, because then many were the benefits which God bestowed on his Church. The time of grace also is much better than the time of the Law, and much greater are the benefits which therein God hath vouchsafed to his Church. And therefore he sayth, that to aske why the former dayes were better, is unwisely inquired; Quia talis quaestio supponit manifestè falsum, Because such a question doth suppose that which is manifestly false. But taking the sense of the question, which way any shall thinke good, Lyra conceiveth the folly of it to be,Lyra, Ibid. Quod illi sic quarentes, propriam malitiam, & suae inconstantiae defectum volebant retorquere in Deum qui est autor temporum, Because they who doe thus enquire, desire to turne off their owne wickednesse, and the defect of their inconstancy upon God, who is the authour of times: which being a blasphemy, the Preacher sayth, Say not &c.

q.p: VER. 11. Wisedome is good with an inheritance: and by it there is profit to them that see the Sunne.
VER. 12. For wisedome is a defence, and money is a defence: but the excellency of knowledge is that wisedome giveth life to them that have it.

div.p:
Verse 11. It is good that wisedome and wealth are joyned together, both in respect of wisedome, and in respect of wealth. In respect of wisedome it is good, because thereby that is enabled to doe the more good, and to performe the functions of wisedome with the more benefit: in respect of wealth it is good, because thereby that is the better ordered, and possessed the more happily. The first thing which the devill desireth against Iob,
Iob 1.11. is, that God would put forth his hand, and touch all that he had, and deprive him of it: the reason of it is given by St. Chrysostome, Chrysostom. Homil. 2. de Iacob. Diabolus quandoquidem eum ditescentem eisdem temporalibus divitiis vidit, atque ex eisdem aeternas sibi thesaurare divitias putavit, quoniam eo ditescente ditescebat justitia: tentat eum igitur pecuniis nudare, quod claris eum facinoribus nudet, The devill, for as much as he saw him both rich with the same temporall riches, and also thought him with the same to treasure up for himselfe eternall riches in heaven, because he being rich, righteousnesse was rich also: he therefore endeavoureth to spoyle him of his wealth, that also he might spoyle him of his worthy deeds, which his wisedome joyned to his wealth performed.Xenoph. de Cyro. c. 8.
Xenophon hath a good passage, who sayth, Non eos qui plurimas pecunias possident & custodiunt, foelices duco, nam hoc pacto qui muros custodiunt, foelicissimi forent, quippe qui omnia quae sunt in urbibus custodiunt; sed qui parare quam plurimas justè possunt, & eis praeclare uti, hunc foelicem arbitror, & pecunias ejus etiam faelices, I doe not accompt them to be happy, who possesse much wealth and keepe it, for then they that keepe the wals should be most happy, because they keepe the wealth of the whole Citie; but I judge him to be happy, who can get much wealth honestly, and having got it can use it worthily; and his wealth I thinke to be happy also. Now this is he, who hath wisedome and wealth joyned together, and in him it is that the good both of wisedome and wealth is joyned together. Wisedome where wealth doth not set it out, is often despised; wealth where wisedome doth not direct it, is often the cause of much mischiefe unto many. Fulgentius Fulgentius. speaking of Sodome, sayth, In saturitate cibi vivens Sodoma cibus ignis effici meruit, Sodome living in the fulnesse of food,
was made to be the food of the fire of Gods wrath, and many living in the plentie of wealth, doe but heape up unto themselves, a plenty of misery. It is hard for a rich man to enter into the kingdome of heaven: even as hard as for a Camel to goe through the eye of a needle, yet wisedome can make a passage for him. Wherefore Bonaventure sayth,Bonavent. Zacheus quum esset Camelus, intravit per foramen acus; & foramen dedit divitibus intrandi in coelum, Zacheus when he was a Camel, entred through the eye of a needle, and by his example made a hole for rich men to enter into heaven. Wisedome it was which opened the way for him, and which will open the way for any other. Gen. 31.27. When Laban had overtaken Iacob, being departed from him, he told him that he would have sent him away with mirth and with songs, with tabret and with harpe: but Saint Ambrose defending Iacob sayth,Ambrosius Epist. l. 1. Epist. 4.
Non equidem talibus deductoribus ad Ecclesiam Dei pervenitur, ad quem tendebat Iacob, It is not by such leaders of worldly contentment that we come to the Church of God, to which Iacob went. And yet even by such leaders wee may come to God, if that wisedome leade them. But then it must be a true wisedome, that is, an humble modest wisedome, not a selse-conceited wisedome; for rich men too often imagine themselves to be filled with wisedome, because their bags are full,1 Tim. 6.17. whereof Saint Paul speaking sayth, Charge them that are rich in this world, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , non sublime sapere, not to be wise above their capacitie. Let it be a true wisedome, and that will teach them not to set their heart upon their riches. And if their heart be not set upon them,Cassiodorus in Psal. 61.
Vt in ipsis singularis foelicitas judicetur, profecto necessariae divitiae sunt. Inde enim egentibus subvenitur, inde plures ad coelorum regna pervenerunt, so that a singular happinesse be not accompted to be in them, riches are indeed necessary. For thence much succour is given to the poore, and thence many have attained to the kingdome of heaven, sayth Cassiodore. Saint Bernard asking a reason, why the Sonne of God did give Saint Peter power to walke upon the sea, whereas he divided the sea, that the children of Israel might walke upon the ground, himselfe giveth this reason; because Saint Peter was light, being poore, and not burdened with the wealth of the world,Bernard. l. 2. de Consider. whereas the Israelites were loaded with gold and silver, and the wealth of the Aegyptians; and that therefore God gave them a stronger and firmer ground to support them. And surely, it is true indeed, the wealth of the world hath need of the solid ground of wisedome to walke upon, or else it maketh men to fall into many temptations; but if that support it, though it passe through a sea, the way is safe wherein it goeth. The Septuagint doe reade it in this place, Vtilior est sapientia cum divitiis, Wisedome is more profitable with riches, and thereunto our English translation accordeth in the following words, saying, and by it there is profit. Estius in hunc vers. Whereupon Estius noteth, Dicit utilior, non melior: nam sapientia per hoc quod cum divitiis conjuncta est, proprie neque utilior efficitur, neque deterior, neque major, neque minor, The text sayth, more profitable, not better: for wisedome
in that it is joyned with riches, is properly made neither the better nor the worse, neither the greater nor the lesse, although by occasion it may be made either lesse or more profitable. To them that see the Sunne: that is, to them that are living: for it is in this life onely that riches are profitable, in the next life they are of no use: here they are currant money, but there they goe for nothing. But though this be the plaine meaning of the words, yet it seemeth to mee that the Preacher should meane somewhat else in this phrase, That see the Sunne. Wherefore the Hebrew word being 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
& magis, And more to them that see the Sunne; I apprehend this meaning in the Preachers words, That as wisedome is good with riches, so it is yet more good to them that see the Sunne, that is, to them who enjoy the libertie of this life, as being neither restrained from it by sicknesse, or any other hinderance: which, though wisedome and wealth be joyned together, may much impayre the good of them. In a morall sense, the application which Saint Ambrose maketh of this verse,Ambros. in c. 2. Genes. ad Sabin. is this. Bona est sapientia cum haereditate, id est, cum fide, quoniam est haereditas credentium in Dominum, Good is wisedome with an inheritance, that is, with faith, for that is the inheritance of them that beleeve in the Lord.

Verse 12. That which is translated a defence, in the Originall is a shadow, but the meaning is a defence or protection, and therefore the Chaldee Paraphrast explaineth this verse thus;Chald. Quemadmodum homo praesidio & velut umbraculis sapientiae defenditur, sic et umbra pecuniarum incolumis degit, eo potissimum tempore quo illas ad justitiam confert. Et sanè dignitas cognitionis sapientiae legis ab ipso sepulchro ad futurum saeculum possessori vitam confert, As a man is defended by the succour and helpe of wisedome, as it were by a comfortable shadow, so doth a man live safely by the shadow of money, especially, when that he useth his money in the workes of righteousnesse. And indeed the excellency of the knowledge of the wisedome of the Law, even from the grave, doth give life to the possessour of it in the world to come. But this verse depending upon the verse going before, and that ending with these words, To them that see the Sunne, the shadow here giveth some light to the understanding of it. And therefore wee may take the seeing of the Sunne, to be the heate of the troubles and molestations of this life, against which money and wisedome are a shadow of shelter and defence. First, Wisedome is a shadow, Vbi tutum est fugientibus refugium, gratum fessis refrigerium, Where there is a safe refuge for them that flie unto it, and where there is an acceptable refreshing to them that are weary.Lyra in hunc vers. It is a defence, sayth Lyra, Contra hostes visibiles & etiam invisibiles, against visible enemies and also invisible. It is a shadow, Et ab aestu carnalium desideriorum, & à facie impiorum qui bonos affligunt, Both from the heate of carnall lusts and affections, and from the face of the wicked, who afflict the good. It was wisedome that defended Daniel from death, Dan. 2.13. when Nebuchadnezzars decree went forth that the wise men should be slaine. A false wisedome was not able
to defend the Magitians and Chaldaeans, but the true wisedome of Daniel defended himselfe and them. Wisedome therefore is a wall of defence, and money is a hedge. Mat. 13.22. The thornes in the Gospel which sprang up, and choaked the good seed, are by our Saviour expounded to be the deceitfulnesse of riches; but that is when the thornes doe grow among the corne, when the love of riches hath placed them in the heart, which is the field, where the seed of spirituall grace ought to grow. Let them be kept out of the heart, let them be esteemed of as they are, outward things, and let them be placed without our affections, then they are as it were a fence, an hedge unto a man, whereby he is preserved from hurt. So they were to Iob,
Iob 1.10. by Gods providence over them; of whom it is sayd, That God had made a hedge about him, and about his house, and about all that he had on every side: that God had blessed the workes of his hands, and had increased his substance in the land. Augustin. in Psal. 103. Conc. 4. Of which words Saint Austin speaking sayth, Repulsus est tentator, observatum est caput ejus, penetrare non potuit ad cor. Muratam civitatem forinsecus oppugnavit, sed non expugnavit, The tempter was repulsed, his head was observed, he could not pierce to the heart. He outwardly assaulted a walled Citie, but he could not enter it. Notwithstanding the Originall word here being a shadow,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome doth well note upon it, Omnis nostra in hac terra protectio instar umbrae est, sive sapientiae, sive argenti, All our protection upon this earth, is but as it were a shadow, whither it be, the protection of wisedome, or else of money; untill the day breake, and the shadows flie away,Bernard. in Cantic. Ser. 73. and when Omnia occupante luminis plenitudine, nulla pars superesse poterit tenebrarum, A fulnesse of light possessing all things, no part of darknesse shall be able to remaine, as S. Bernard speaketh. But the excellency of knowledge is, that wisedome giveth life unto them that have it: least that the joyning of wisedome with money, might seeme to be some disparagement unto it, the Preacher here setteth wisedome alone, and giveth it this excellency, that it giveth life, that is, both the life of grace and glory. It is wisedome that doth give it, not riches;Greg. Thaumat. in hunc vers. so sayth Gregorius Thaumaturgus, Vita hominis non ex caducarum & fragilium opum collectione, & possessione, verum ex sapientia provenit, The life of man doth proceed not from the gathering and possessing of fraile and fading riches, but it commeth from wisedome. Or at least, riches are no way able to give life, as wisedome is able, so sayth Lyra, Lyra in hunc versum. Sapientia enim sine divitiis tribuere, sed divitiae non possunt hoc tribuere sine sapientia, For wisedome doth give it without riches, but riches are not able to give this without wisedome. When God had cast man out of Paradise, that he might not eate of the tree of life, he placed at the entrance of it Cherubims, with a fiery sword, and therein not onely shewed his anger against man, but his mercy to him, as not onely keeping him out, but shewing him also how he might returne in. Wherefore Bachiarius sayth, Eousque de ligno vitae, idest, Christi participatione exules fimus, donec ad eum per romphaeam flammeam, id est, ignitam Martyrii passionem, aut per Cherubim
Domini, Bachiarius Epist. ad Januarium. qui interpretantur multitudo scientia remeamus, So long are wee made exiles from the tree of life, that is, from the partaking of Christ, untill wee returne to him by a flaming sword, that is, by the fiery suffering of martyrdome, or else by the Cherubims of the Lord, which are interpreted a multitude of knowledge. Doe but therefore labour for the knowledge of wisedome, and be not wearyed in the study of it; that will open paradise unto thee, that will bring thee to the tree of life, that giveth life unto him that hath it.

q.p: VER. 13. Consider the worke of God; for who can make that straight, which he hath made crooked?
VER. 14. In the day of prosperitie be joyfull, but in the day of adversitie, consider: God also hath set the one over against the other, to the end that man should finde nothing after him.

div.p:
Verse 13. The Preacher here farther exhorteth unto patience from the perfection of Gods worke: which therefore he wisheth us to consider, that the consideration of it may be a meanes to quiet our minds. The anger of a wiseman may be moved against the wrong that is done by man, his impatiency may be stirred up against the imperfections of humane proceedings, which either he seeth that he could amend, or else at leastwise thinketh that he could doe it. But can any one amend that which God doth? Can any one truely say, that God hath made such a thing crooked, and that himselfe will make it straight? Now it is by Gods providence that all things are disposed, it is under the government of God, that all things have their course, and therefore let his pleasure in all things make thee patient, who art displeased with that, which men doe. Men are often caryed in their wayes, either with love or hatred, but God is lead by neither. He is that good Iudge, who as Seneca speaketh,Seneca de Ira. c. 16.
Improbandos damnat, non odit, condemneth those which are to be blamed, but doth not hate them. Wee reade in Daniel of diverse thrones that were set or lifted up, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the Originall word there used signifieth, Dan. 7.9. but wee reade onely of one, the Ancient of dayes that did sit: and what may this signifie unto us, but that this Iudge is as much as all others are, in that he doth exceed all in equitie and righteousnesse.Psal. 45.7. Basilius Ibid. He is one that loveth righteousnesse, and hateth iniquitie, as the Psalmist speaketh. Where Basil tels us, by the Originall word there used, Non tam labore & exercitatione partam dilectionem, quam insitam à natura justitiae offectionem, Not so much to be signified an acquired love
by exercise and labour, as an affection to righteousnesse ingrafted naturally. He therefore that loveth righteousnesse will not himselfe wrong thee, nor see thee wronged by another without revenging of thee: wherefore in him rest quiet and contented. Doe not trouble thy selfe with any thought of mending that which hee ordereth, Deut. 32.4. but consider his worke, for his worke is perfect, as in the song of Moyses wee are taught. Bernard saith,Bern. Ser. 3. in die Pentecost. Tria in magno hujus mundi opere cogitare debemus, quid, & quomodo, & ad quid sit constitutus, There are three things which in the great worke of this world wee are to consider, what it is, how it is, and to what end it is. In the being of it is set forth Gods inestimable power, Quod tam multa tam magna tam magnifice tam multipliciter sunt creata, that so many, so great things, so variously, so gloriously are created: in the manner of their being his singular wisdom shineth forth, that these things are placed above, these below, these in the middle, all most comely and orderly: and if thou consider to what end it is made, occurrit tibi tam utilis benignitas, tam benigna utilitas, quae etiam ingratissimos quos{que} multitudine & magnitudine beneficiorum possit obruere, There meetes thy sight so profitable a bounty, so bountifull a profitablenesse, that it is able to overwhelme any though most unthankfull with the multitude and greatnesse of the benefits. Now who can consider so perfect power, so perfect wisdome, so perfect goodnesse in the worke of God, and yet trouble himselfe with impatient thinking that he can better order any thing, then it is by God ordered? We read that God having made his worke, and looking upon it, hee saw that all was good, for as Saint Chrysostome noteth, Quia humana natura imbecillis est, Gen. 1.31. Chrysost. in Gen. Hom. 5.
& opera Dei digna laudare non sufficit, divina Scriptura acceptam ab ipso opifice laudem nos docet, Because that humane nature is weake, and is not sufficient to praise the worthy works of God, therefore the divine Scripture teacheth us the praise that it had from the maker himselfe. Now shall any one thinke of correcting his works, or imagine himselfe able to doe it, whose worke hee is not able to praise? For as the same Father also speaketh, Talem sortitus est Dominum, qui talia facit, quae à nobis ne{que} laudari satis possunt, Thou hast such a Lord and master, who doth such things, as that by us they cannot be sufficiently extolled. It is true that wicked people doe pervert the works of God to their owne sinfull pleasures and desires, but therein they cease to be Gods Workes. For as Tertullian speaketh, Quid non Dei est, quod Deum offendit? Tertul. l. de. Spectac. c. 2.
Sed quum offondit, Dei esse desiit, & quum desiit, offendit, What is there that is not Gods, which doth offend God? But when it offendeth it ceaseth to bee Gods, and when it ceaseth to bee Gods, it offendeth. But that which wicked men thus make crooked, God will one day make straight.
