And as for God himselfe, hee can make nothing crooked, and therefore none can make that straight, which he hath made crooked. Men by their impatiency doe but make themselves more crooked, and make the straight rule of Gods justice the more to condemne them. The Septuagint, and accordingly the vulgar Latine doe read the latter part of this verse thus,
Quod nemo possit corrigere, quem ille despexerit, That no one can correct him whom God hath despised, that is, whom God for the hardnesse of his heart hath rejected.Lyra in hunc vers. And therefore saith Lyra, In tali casu cessandum à correctione, In such a case there must be a ceasing from correction. Not but that the publike Magistrate ought to correct such an one, Quia ejus correctio non solum ordinatur ad emendationem fratris, sed etiam ad bonum communitatis, Because his correcting is ordayned not onely for the amendment of a brother, but for the common good of the state. But as for the private correction where it is in vaine bestowed, it may be better spared.

Ver. 14. God hath made the dayes of mans life like the dayes of the yeare; some be faire, some fowle, some daies of adversity, some of prosperity. And as there is no true Almanacke but this one, that after faire weather comes fowle, after fowle comes faire; so it is in mans life, after prosperity comes adversity, after adversity followes prosperity. How in either of these dayes we are to behave our selves, the Preacher here sheweth. In the day of prosperity be joyfull: joyfull in thankfulnesse to God, and sing with the Spouse in the Canticles, Cant. 2.16. My beloved is mine, and I am his, Ille mihi quia benignus & misericors est, ego illi, quia non sum ingrata. Ille mihi gratiam ex gratia, ego illi gratiam pro gratia. Ille meae liberationi, ego illius honori. Ille meae saluti, ego illius voluntati; He is mine because bountifull and mercifull unto me, I am his, because not unthankfull unto him. He is mine, because he hath shewed me grace out of his grace, I am his because I have returned grace and thankes for his grace. He is mine in giving me freedome, I am his in giving him honour. He is mine in working my salvation,Bernard. in Cant. Serm. 68. I am his in serving his will, as Saint Bernard hath it. The Originall here is word for word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Esto in bono, Be thou in good, as Saint Hierome renders it, that is, saith the Glosse, In virtutibus & operibus, In vertues, and vertuous workes, and let them speake thy thankfulnesse.Greg. Nyss. de opific. hominis. For as Gregory Nyssene hath it, Manus datae sunt hominibus ut melius loquerentur, sunt enim hominis manus quae pro illo respondent, & rationem reddunt de illo; & dum bruta pedibus respondent calces impingendo benefactori suo, homo extollendo manus in sancta, Domino vere respondet, Hands are given unto men that they might speake the better; for they are the hands of man which answer for him, and give an accompt of him; and while bruit beasts answer with their heeles, by kicking at him, who hath beene good to them, man by lifting up his hands unto holy things, doth truly answer the Lord. This therefore let us doe in the day of prosperity, that it may not be said to us as it was to the Israelites by the Prophet Ieremiah, yee shall be ashamed of your revenues, because of the fierce anger of the Lord: Jer. 12.13. Theod. Ibid. that is saith Theodoret, Quae putatis illustrare vos verbi gratia, opes, potentiam, haec vos pudore perfundent, dum causam agetis apud Deum, Those things which you thinke doe make you glorious, namely your riches and your power, shall make you ashamed, when your cause shall be handled before God.Greg. Mor. l. 6. c. 7.
In the day of adversity consider. Consider, for as Saint Gregory speaketh, Qui accepta praditus sit ratione
considerat, quod sibi sit impossibile, ut haec peregrinationis suae tempora sine gemitu evadat, He that is endued with reason, considereth that it is impossible for him, that he should passe these times of his pilgrimage without sighing. Consider, Et si peccator, agnosce pro correctione tua esse quod caederis, si autem justus es ad gloriae tuae probationem intelligas evenire quod pateris, And if thou be a wicked man, acknowledge that it is for thy correction, that thou art beaten, if thou be a righteous man, thou wilt understand, that what thou sufferest commeth to passe for the proofe of thy glory, as Gaudentius hath it.Gaudentius praefat. ad Benevol. Iob was knowne to bee a righteous man in prosperity, but whether he would continue so in adversity was a thing not knowne. He was therefore touched, Vt qui notus erat Omnipotenti Deo, notus per flagella fieret & nobis & sibimetipsi, That hee who was knowne to Almighty God, by troubles might be knowne to us and to himselfe, as Gregory hath it.Greg. Hom. 19. in Ezek. Consider and behold the great wisdome of God in thine adversity: Vt quum defecerit homo, & subvenerit Deus, dum homo liberatur a Deo, Deus ab homine ut dignum est, honoretur, That when man faileth, and God helpeth; while man is delivered by God, God may be, as is most due, by man honoured. Consider and remember, that Christ hath left us an example, that we should follow his steps, as Saint Peter speaketh. Hee walked & in pulvere & in sanguine, 1 Pet. 2.21. both in dust, and in bloud, and we must follow him in the dust of painefull labour, in the bloud of affliction and misery. God also hath set the one over against the other: it is the saying of Nazianzene, Circulus quidem fratres, Naz. orat. 7. ad med. est in rebus humanis, Deus nos per contraria erudit, My brethren, there is a kind of circle in humane things, and God doth instruct us by contraries, sometimes by prosperity, sometimes by adversity, now by one, and then by the other. These two God hath set as it were the two opposite scales of the ballance, whereby to keepe us upright in a due measure. Prosperity doth easily make mans heart too light, and then God by adversity addeth weight unto it.Exod. 8.8. Origen. Ibid. Pharaoh in the prosperity of his kingdome did forget God easily, asking who is the Lord; but as Origene noteth, Ante verbera Dominum nescit, verberatus supplicari pro se Dominum rogat, Before he was smitten, he knew not the Lord, being smitten he desireth that the Lord may be intreated for him. Adversity doth some times make mens hearts too heavy, and then God doth ease it by sending comfort, and taking away the weight of it: thus when God had strucken the hardned and rocky hearts of the Israelites with extremity of thirst, then hee commanded Moyses to strike the rocke, and made that to yeeld water unto them: thus when God had delivered them into captivity being in the land of Canaan, yet he did it as Saint Austin speaketh,August. in Psal. 84.
Non ad interitum, sed ad disciplinam, non damnante Patre, sed flagellante, not to their destruction, but to their instruction, not as a rejecting, but as a correcting Father, and when they were oppressed with the weight, he sent them still deliverers. To the end that man should finde nothing after him: but should be forced to acknowledge that God had set all things before his eyes, which might be the meanes of his happinesse. Wherefore
Moses saith, see I have set before thee this day life and death, good and evill.Deut. 30.15. Chrys. Hom. Epist. ad Timoth. And Saint Chrysostome saith, Deus omnia facit, cuncta molitur, ut vota nostra at{que} desideria transferat ad coelestia, God doth all things, worketh all things, that he may transfer and remove our desires and affections unto heavenly things. The French here to make the sense more plaine read it thus; that man might find nothing a redire apres luy, to say after him, or to returne as a plea against him. To which sense the Septuagint and vulgar Latine doe also render it, Vt non inveniat homo contra cum justas querimonias, that man may not finde against him just complaints, which commeth in effect to the same sense which I have already given of it. Or else the meaning of the words is, to the end, that man should not know, what shall be afterwards unto him, as whether adversity or prosperity, thereby to make him to commit himselfe to God, and to depend upon his pleasure.

q.p: VER. 15. All things have I seene in the dayes of my vanitie: there is a just man that perisheth in his righteousnesse, and there is a wicked man that prolongeth his life in his wickednesse.
VER. 16. Bee not righteous over much, neither make thy selfe over wise: Why shouldest thou destroy thy selfe.
VER. 17. Bee not overmuch wicked: neither bee thou foolish: Why shouldest thou dye before thy time?
VER. 18. It is good, that thou shouldest take hold of this, yea also from this withdraw not thine hand: for hee that feareth God shall come forth of them all.
VER. 19. Wisedome strengtheneth the wise more than tenne mighty men which are in the City.
VER. 20. For there is not a iust man upon earth, that doth good and sinneth not.

div.p:
Verse 15. It was Salomon who saw more then all that were before him, and all that were to be after him, and therefore it is not much that he saith, I have seene all things. And though he had not seene all things in their particular existence, yet in the generall vanity of them hee had seene all things. But here it may bee proposed whether a Minister in teaching, as here Salomon doth, may alleage his own experience. Whereunto to give an answer, I conceive that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a talking of himselfe is by a Minister to bee carefully used, and not too frequently. And if he doe speake of his owne experience, let it be that whereof hee is well assured, and so that if need be he confirme by Scripture, seeing he is not inspired as Salomon was. In the dayes of my vanity, hee saith, not in the dayes of my life, but of my vanity, as acknowledging that though they were the dayes of so glorious a King, yet not worthy to be accompted a life. Origen considering those words spoken of Elizabeth, Luk. 1.57. Origen. in Luc. Hom. 9.
that when her full time came, that shee should be delivered, she brought forth a sonne, thereupon noteth, Vbicunque justus nascitur, ibi complentur dies. Ortus justi plenitudinem habet: peccatoris nativitas vanitatem atque inanitatem, Wheresoever a righteous man is borne there the dayes are fulfilled: the birth of the just hath a fulnesse, but the nativity of sinners a vacuity and vanity. But though the dayes of the wicked be more especially vanity, yet the dayes of mortall men, even of the righteous are no better then vanity also. Wherefore St. Austin saith, Dies qui hic sunt, August. in Psal. 89.
sunt dies qui non sunt. Illi autem anni & dies non deficiunt, in quibus nec nos deficiemus, sed sine defectu reficiemur, The dayes which are here, are dayes which are not. Those yeares and dayes doe not faile in which neither shall wee faile, but without any defect shall still bee supplyed. There is a just man that perisheth in his righteousnesse: there was one that did so, even assoone as there were but three in the world.Gen. 4.8. Philo. libro quod deterior insidietur potiori. Although it be true as Philo noteth, that it was not Abel so much that perished, as Cain himselfe. And therefore he rendreth the Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Et interfecit ipsum, and killed himselfe, adding upon it, Prima quidem specie Abelem occisum subindicat; sin autem diligentius rem expendas, ipsum Cain occisum à seipso. Proinde sic legendum, Insurrexit Cain & occidit sepisum & non alium, At first sight it seemeth to declare that Abel was slaine; but if thou consider the matter more diligently, it sheweth Cain himselfe to be slaine by himselfe. And therfore it is thus to be read. Cain arose and slew himselfe and not another. There was another that perished so, even as soone as the second Adam was made of a woman: and the Iewes putting Steven to death, Saint Austin saith of them,Aug. Serm. 92. de diversis. Quum ad lapides cucurrissent, duri ad duros, jactabant in illum pares suos, when they ranne for stones, hard went to hard, and they cast at him their owne peeres and aequals, being like to stones in their hard hearts. For indeed such is the malice of the wicked against the righteous, that there is more mercy in beasts and senslesse creatures then in men towards them. Saint Austin noteth it in the three children cast into the fiery furnace,Aug. Serm. 240. de Tempore. of whom he saith, Dum vindicat flamma, impii necantur, & justi salvantur,
when the flame punisheth, the wicked are slaine, the just are delivered. Nilus notes it in Daniel cast into the Lions denne, and shewing the injustice of men,Nilus in Ascetico. the justice of the beasts sayth, Hominis virtus apud homines invidiae & contentionis, apud feras venerationis & honoris occasio fuit. The vertue of man with men was an occasion of envy and strife, with the beasts of honour and reverence. There is a wicked man that prolongeth his life in his wickednesse: for though long life bee a blessing, yet as Eucherius Eucherius. speaking of the blessings of this life saith, Propterea id Deus largitur etiam malis, ne magnum bonum videatur bonis, Therefore doth God also sometimes grant it to the wicked, that it may not seeme to the good, to be a great good thing. But that which I rather note here, is this, that the Preacher saith, I have seene, as shewing it to be a thing which he saw with no great wonder or trouble of mind. For what though he saw the righteous to perish in his righteousnesse? he knew this world to the righteous to be like Aegypt to the Israelites, and as Eusebius Gallicanus speaketh,Eusebius Gallican. Dum incolitur afflixit, dum relinquitur locupletavit, while it is inhabited it afflicteth them, when it is forsaken it enricheth them. He knew the very perishing of the righteous to bee better than the flourishing long life of the wicked. According as Chrysologus noteth upon that passage in the Gospell,Chrysologus Serm. 121. that the Angels caryed away poore Lazarus, hell swallowed the rich glutton, saying, Ecce fratres, mors pauperis totam vitam divitis vicit, & elatio sola pauperis totam divitis pompam transcendit & gloriam, Behold brethren, the very death of the poore man excelleth the whole life of the wicked, and the carying away only of the poore man transcendeth all the pompe and glory of the rich man. What though he saw the life of the wicked prolonged in his wickednesse? Yet be knew that this length was but a little while, untill God would come to judge him for his wickednesse. According as the Prophet Zephaniah speaketh,Zepha. 1.14. Ruper. Ibid. The great day of the Lord, it is neere, it is neere and hasteth greatly. Where Rupertus noteth, Nec semel contentus dixisse juxta est dies Domini, repetivit juxta est & velox nimis, & vere secundum magnitudinem periculi, Not contented that he had said, it is neere, he repeated it, it is neere, and hasteth greatly, and so it is truly in respect of the greatnesse of the danger. Hee knew that though the wicked live and flourish,Minut. Faelix in Octavio suo. yet that as Minutius Faelix speaketh, Vt victimae ad supplicium saginantur, ut hostiae ad poenam coronantur, As sacrifices they are fatted for their punishment, as offerings they are crowned to their misery. The Poet saith,Ovidius. Gramine pasta Phalisco, victima Tarpeios inficit jcata focos, The sacrifice fed with the grasse of the mountaine Phascon, being strucke coloureth the Tarpeian fire, so the wicked being strucke at length by death, colour with their bloud the fire of hell. Now the Preacher seeing all this, he saw in it the vanity of this world. But though this bee the plaine and more evident sense of the verse; yet to the first part of it Saint Hierome, though not in his commentary upon this verse, yet elsewhere giveth another sense, there is saith he, a just man that perisheth in his righteousnesse, Non quo justus sit, sed quo sibi justus videatur, Not
that he is just, but that he seemeth to himselfe to be just, and therefore wee ought not to trust in our owne righteousnesse. Now according to this sense of the former part, wee may also understand the latter; There is a wicked man, prolongans in iniquitate sua, Hieronym, in c. 26. Isai. continuing in his iniquitie (for so the Originall is) not as if it were iniquitie, but as thinking it to be righteousnesse in his owne sight. Neither doth this sense unfitly agree with the following verses.

Verse 16. From the vertues of prudence and patience, the Preacher passeth unto justice; and first he removeth the excesse of it. Be not just overmuch: Saint Ambrose sayth,Ambros. de Poeniten. Cont. Novat. l. 1. c. 1.
Si virtutum finis ille est maximus, qui plurimorum spectat profectum, moderatio prope omnium pulcherrima est, If that end of vertues be the greatest, which respecteth the profit of most, then is a moderation of all things most commendable. For that it is which doth not offend even those whom it condemneth: that it is which the eares of men are willing to heare; that it is which their minds doe not abhorre; that it is which their hearts doe not feare. Certainly, he that desireth to redresse the vices or humane infirmitie, must as it were cary and beare the infirmitie it selfe upon his shoulders, and not cast it away in a rigid severitie. The good Shepheard in the Gospel is sayd to have caryed the wandring sheepe, not to have driven it; and it is not seldome that the cariage of a moderate reproofe, doth more good then the fierce driving of severe austeritie. For how should he commit himselfe unto thee to be cured, whom thou hast in disdaine, and who knoweth that he shall be despised and not pittied by thee? There is no vertue that doth not consist in a mediocritie, and onely the love of God cannot be too much. For as Bernard speaketh,Bernard. de diligēdo. Deo. Modus diligendi Deum est sine modo, the measure of loving God, is to love him without measure. And as Aquinas speaketh of praising the Lord,Aquinas. Quantum potes, tantum aude, quia major omnibus Deus, nec laudare sufficis, As much as thou canst, be bold to doe, for God is greater then all praise, and thou art not sufficient to praise him; so it is true of loving the Lord, as much as thou canst, thou mayest be bold to doe, for he is greater than all love, and thou art not sufficient to love him. But the love of God requireth of us, that we love our brethren also, and that our justice be not bitter against them. Saint Hierome sayth,Hieronim. in hunc versum. Si quem rigidum & trucem ad omnia fratrum peccata conspexeris, ut nec in sermone peccanti, nec propter naturalem interdum pigritiam moranti det veniam, hunc scito plus justum esse quam justum est, If thou beholdest any one rigid and fierce against all the offences of his brethren, so that he doth not pardon him that trippeth in his speech, or him who sometimes by reason of a naturall slownesse taryeth too long, know this man to be more just than it is just he should be. But as a man may be overmuch just towards another, so may he be overmuch just in himselfe also. He that will doe no more than the Law requireth of him, he that will goe no further than he is tyed and bound: he that will have all that the Law giveth him; he that will spare and remit nothing of that which is due unto

〈1 page duplicate〉
him, may well be sometimes more strict, mor just than he should be. Wherefore Isidore Pelusiota sayth,Isidorus Pelusiota Epist. l. 3. Epist. 320.
Noli jus tuum severe ac rigide persequi, verum per bonitatem id expura, Doe not exact thy right severely and punctually, but by thy goodnesse make it more cleere and manifest. Neither make thy selfe overwise: these two are commonly joyned together, and he that is overjust, is usually too well conceited of his owne wisedome; and he that makes himselfe overwise, is for the most part overmuch just, either in standing upon his own right, or else in condemning that which is not right in others.Cyprianus. Saint Cyprian readeth this verse thus; Noli esse multum justus, et noli argumentari plus quam oportet, Be not just overmuch, and doe not argue and dispute more than is meete. For that indeed is the manner of them that make themselves overwise. They will alwayes oppose others by reasoning and arguing, and never yeelding that themselves are in the wrong, they have never done talking and disputing.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome reads this part of the verse thus, Ne quaeras amplius, seeke not farther than is meete for thee. For that is also the fashion of them that make themselves overwise, they are prying into every thing, as if their wisedome were able to judge of it, or were able to redresse any thing that might be amisse. But to consider the words as wee reade them. Isaiah 57.10 The Prophet Isaiah fayth, Thou art wearied in the greatnesse of thy way; and surely, there are none more wearied, then they that walke in the selfe-conceit of their owne great wisedome. For there is nothing which they will not undertake, though it be a burden never too heavy for them. There is nothing which as they thinke they cannot goe through, though it be never so farre from the reach of their abilitie.Hieronym. in & 57. Isai. Saint Hierome tels us, Via regia temperata est nec plus in se habens nec minus: tunc plus sapimus quam oportet sapere, quando pro prudentia callidiatem diligimus, The Kings way is temperate way, neither having too much nor yet too litle: then are we wise more then wee should be wise, when that for wisedome wee doe love craftinesse. And indeed thus to make our selves overwise, is to make our selves as the Serpent was, more wise then any beast of the field. Why shouldest thou destroy thy selfe? One might thinke, that it were a more direct conclusion for the precedent words, Why shouldest thou deceive thy selfe, when thou thinkest to be just, in being just over-much, when thou thinkest to be wise in making thy selfe over-wise? But the Preacher sayth, Why shouldest thou destroy thy selfe? For indeed, overmuch justice doth as it were of it selfe call for justice to destroy it; and overmuch wisedome doth as it were shew it selfe to wisedome to be punished. Besides, the Preacher useth this conclusion, to give the more force unto his admonition. For as Salvianus speaketh, Nunquid postest cuilibet quicquam scipso proprius, nunquid charius inveniri? Can there be found any thing neerer unto any one than is himselfe? Can any thing be found dearer?Salvian. contra Avaritiam. l. 3. Wherefore the Preacher sayth, Why shouldest thou destroy thy selfe? And as Salvianus addeth, Nihil planè durius vobis, nihil inhumanius, nihil tam ferum, nihil tam impium dici potest, à quibus impetrari
omnino non potest, ut vos ipsos ametis, There is nothing more cruell, than you, nothing more inhumane, nothing so wilde, nothing so wicked, from whom it cannot bee obtained, that you would love your selves; So the force of the Preachers conclusion is; There is nothing more barbarous and hard hearted then thou art, if I cannot perswade thee not to destroy thy selfe. Thou who art so wise, tell me why dost thou doe it? Thou who art so just, tell me, why shouldest thou destroy thy selfe?

Verse 17. Be not wicked overmuch: if wee take the words to speake of wickednesse in generall, Saint Hieromes exposition is very good,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Noli peccatis addere peccata, semel peccasse sufficiat, debemus erigere post ruinam. Si enim juxta eos qui de Physicis disputant, novit hirundo pullos de succo oculare Chelidoniae, cur nos ignoramus medicinam poenitentiae propositam esse peccantibus? Doe not adde sinnes unto sinnes: let it suffice to have sinned once: when wee are fallen, wee ought to arise againe; when a building is ruinated, it ought to be repayred: for if, as they who write of naturall things relate, the swallow know how to give sight to her young ones with the juice of Salendine, why are we ignorant, that the medicine of repentance is proposed unto sinners? Or else wee may take the exposition of Cajetane, Be not wicked overmuch; that is,Cajetan. in hunc vers. be not carelesse to fall into any grosse sinne. He that sinneth least, sinneth overmuch; but yet the goodnesse of God, doth not thinke overmuch of it, unlesse our negligence or wilfulnesse cary us into some haynous offence. The words of Cajetane are, Ne mortale committas peccatum, commit not a mortall sinne. Now though all sinnes bee mortall in themselves, yet there be degrees in the measure of them, and in the measure of Gods displeasure against them. Lesse sinnes may stand together both with the state of grace, and with the hope of glory; greater sinnes cannot, and therefore to fall into them is to be wicked overmuch, seeing the losse by them is so overgreat. Or else if we take these words with reference unto the former verse, and as carying an opposition unto the sense thereof, then to be wicked overmuch, is to be too little just, or to be unjust, which is indeed a great wickednesse, and maketh much overmuch wicked. In the Proverbs Solomon tels us, Pro. 20.10. that diverse weights are alike abomination to the Lord, or else as the Hebrew is, a weight and a weight, a weight too little, as well as a weight too great, is abhorred by him. It is the just ballance and weights that he appooveth: it is justice in all things that he requireth. Neither be thou foolish: the words also may be taken either with reference to the words next before, and then they shew onely the folly of being overmuch wicked, which is indeed a greater folly by farre, then is in them who are the veriest fooles naturally. For they doe foolishly, because they see not how to doe better, but to see the greatnesse of a wickednesse now the great danger of it, and to be admonished to keepe our selves from it, and yet to runne into it, this is a folly of all follies. Or else the word may be taken in a reference and opposition to
those words in the former verse, Neither make thy selfe overwise; and then, neither be thou foolish, is, neither make thy selfe to have too little wit, in not being able to discerne either what is thine owne right, and due to thy selfe, or what is the right of others, that it may be given to them by thee. Why shouldest thou dye before thy time? Cajetane Cajetan. speaking of these words sayth, that it is mira sententia, a wonderfull sentence: and indeed, many are the expositions that may be given to it. The Hebrew is, Why shouldest thou dye in a time not thine; that is, before thine old age, for that is mans time of dying, when the time of living according to the course of mans nature is expired. And this is that curse which God denounced upon the house of Eli, 1 Sam. 2.32. That there should not be an old man in his house for ever. To this purpose let me have leave to relate a story out of Saint Bernard, who reporteth that in a Citie of Catalonia neere to Valentia, in his time a young man of eighteene yeares of age being disobedient to his parents, and as overmuch wicked and foolish falling into robberies, for which he came to be hanged: as he hung on the gallowes, on a sudden his beard grew out, and that together with the hayre of his head was changed to be white, and his face being turned to be full of wrincles, he appeared a man about ninetie yeares of age, the people that were present looking on and beholding this change.Bernard. Tom. 2. Quadrages. 2. Dominic. quadrages. Serm. 17. The meaning of it, the Bishop, as he sayth, received by divine inspiration, and taught the people, that the young man should have lived so long, if that he had lived in obedience to his parents. But to returne to the meaning of the words. The time for a man to die, is when he is ready for his death; even as when a Steward is ready for his accompt, then is the time for him to make his accompt; and therefore be not wicked overmuch, neither be thou foolish, least God take thee away in thy wickednesse, in thy folly, and thou be not ready to make thine accompt. Or else the time of mans dying and going hence is, when heaven is ready and open to receive him; till then he may well wish to tary here; and therefore take heed of wickednesse, least God at once call thee hence, and shut thee out from thence. Againe, Est tempus morientis, & tempus mortis, There is a time of him that dyeth, and a time of death, the time of death is, whensoever that commeth, the time of him that dyeth is, when that he hath time to consider of his death, to looke unto it, and to prepare himselfe for it: beware therefore least for thine overmuch wickednesse and folly, God take thee away suddenly in a time not thine, and give thee not time to thinke of thine end. Yet againe, that is a mans time in which he provideth, Sibi non suis, for himselfe and not for the things which he possesseth: now many there are who spend all their time in caring for the things of this world, and have little or no regard unto themselves; wherefore if they dye in this time, what doe they but dye in a time not theirs? Lastly, when the wicked is in the height of his flourishing, and the greatnesse of his bravery, then is his time that hee desireth most of all to live, then hee would not dye by any meanes, and yet then doth God many times deprive
him of his prosperitie, and of his life also. In Iob,
Job 18.10. Bildad speaking of the wicked sayth, A trap is layd for him in the way: where Catena Graeca Catena Graeca. noteth, Irruptiones solitudinibus & locis desertis fieri solent; verum impius non indeserta regione, sed in media via comprehenditur, hoc est, in summo fortunae splendore subitam subversionem cogitur subire, Assaults of robbers use to be made in solitary places and deserts, but a wicked man is set upon, not in a desert region, but in the midway, that is, in his greatest lustre and splendour, he is enforced to suffer a sudden overthrow. The question of the Preacher in this place, Why shouldest thou dye before thy time? caryeth this force: As for God who hath the command of thy life and death, he doth not desire thy death, much lesse doth he desire it before thy time; wherefore then by thine owne wilfulnesse shouldest thou thy selfe shorten thine owne time, and dying before thy time hasten thy misery?

Verse 18. It is good: Aquinas tels us, Aquin. 1.22. Q. 64. A. 1. Bonum cujuslibet regulati & mensurati consistit in hoc quod conformetur suae regulae, The good of every thing that is measured and regulated, consisteth in this, that it doe agree unto his rule: even as in artificiall things, the good of them is, that they are answerable to the rule of art: from whence it followeth, that the evill of them is, in that they differ from their rule. And that commeth to passe two wayes, either when they come short of their rule, or else doe goe beyond it. Now the rule of justice and wisedome, and all the wayes of man, is the Law of God, and therefore unto this they must be conformed, so that they doe neither exceed it, nor yet come short of it. Wherefore sayth the Preacher, It is good that thou shouldest take hold of this; that is, reach forth thy hand so farre untill thou come unto it, but not to over-reach it. It is good to put forth thy care so farre, as to take hold of justice, as to take hold of wisedome, but not to be overmuch just, not to make thy selfe overwise. It is good also not to withdraw thine hand, or to pull it in too much, but to let it out so farre, untill it come where it should be. It is good not to withdraw thy diligence in such manner, as that thou be too little just, which is to be overmuch wicked; or else, as that thou have too little wit, which is to be foolish. The worke of God is sayd to be perfect, and the Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 there used signifieth such a perfection of things, as that when two things are joyned together, the one doth not exceed the other. And therefore the worke of God is sayd to be perfect, Exod. 32.4. because therein neither his power doth exceed his justice, nor his justice his power, neither his patience his wrath, nor his wrath his patience. It must bee therefore the endeavour of men in their wayes to follow God, and neither to put forth their hand by any excesse, nor to pull it backe by any defect, but to make them equall to the rule of Gods law. The least erring from the rule, taketh away the goodnesse of the thing. Saint Ambrose speaking of Adam, sayth, In paradiso mandavit Deus Adae ut custodiret mandata, sed fortasse non mandaverat custodire minis, et ideo lapsus est, ideo deceptus à serpente, putans quod si in parte aliqua recederet à
mandato, Ambros. Serm. 1. in Psal. 67.
non penitus errarat; sed quia à semita mandatorum recess • t, totam viam deseruit, God commanded Adam in Paradise, that he should keepe his commandements, but perhaps he did not command him to keepe them exactly and diligently, and hence it was that he fell, hence it was that he was deceived by the serpent, thinking that if he did in some part goe aside from the commandement, he should not altogether erre; but because he departed from the path of the commandements, he left the whole way. The Hebrew here is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
apprehendas in hoc, as implying a thrusting of the hand into it; and from thence it is as I conceive,Chald. Costi. that the Chaldee giveth this exposition of it, Bonus est qui mundi hujus profundis et intimis implicatur, ut bona animo suo rependat, He is good, who entreth into the depth and bottome of the things of this world, and not deceived with the outward shew of them, discerneth what in truth they are, and from thence gathereth good unto his soule. Our manner of expressing and translating the Originall doth import a firmnesse in goodnesse, and not to leave it off or to goe backward in it. And indeed, we reade in the Psalmes, That the righteous shall flourish as a Palme tree; Hugo Victor. Miscellan. l. 1. ti. 95. that is, sayth Hugo Victorin. Iusti conversatio tanquam palma plus finiendo peragit quam inchoando propoint; The conversation of the righteous is like a palme tree, and in the end performeth more, than in the beginning it proposeth; the palme having but a lesse roote,Laurentius Iustinia. and a great top. For he that feareth God: Laurentius Iustinianus speaking of the feare of God, sayth, Corona sapientiae, timor Domini: magna enim salutisspes, & maxima in profectu virtutum causa est timor Domini; The feare of the Lord is the crowne of wisedome, the diademe of justice: it is the great hope of salvation, and the greatest cause in the proceeding of vertue is the feare of the Lord. Wherefore it followeth here, He that feareth the Lord shall come forth of them all of all those stops and impediments that would hinder his proceeding. Or else as the Hebrew word more directly is, Progredictur, egredteur ad omnia, Shall goe forward, or come forth unto all things, as St. Hierome reads it. The Septuagint, as Saint Hierome sets it downe, and accordingly the Vulgar Latin doe reade it, Qui timet Deum nihil negligit, He that feareth God neglecteth nothing; he neglecteth not his care in not reaching forth too farre, he negleceth not his diligence in not withdrawing his hand a little too much, he considereth a little carelesse erring to he the loosing of goodnesse.Augustin. in Psal. 29. Saint Austin sayth, Praecavisti magna, de minutis quid agis? Annon times minuta? Projecisti molem, vide ne arena obruaris, Thou hast been carefull of great things, what dost thou in little things? Dost thou not feare little things? Thou hast removed the great pile, take heed that thou be not overwhelmed with the sand.Chrysost. in Mat. Hom. 83. Saint Chrysostome sayth, Mirabile quid et inauditum dicere audeo: solet mihi nonnunquam non tanto studio magna videri esse peccata vitanda, quam parva & vilia. Illa enim ut aversemur, ipsa peccati natura efficit; haec autem hac ipsa re quia parva sunt, desides reddunt, & dum contemnuntur, non potest ad expulsionem eorum animus generose insurgere;
unde cito ex parvis maxima fiunt negligentia nostra, I am bold to delivera wonderfull and unheard of thing: it useth to seeme to mee oftentimes, that great sinnes are not to bee shunned with so much care as little and poore sins: for that we shunne them, the very nature of sinne causeth, but these even in that regard because they are little, doe make us lazy and carelesse, and while they are despised, the mind cannot lift it selfe up generously to the expelling of them; from whence quickly by our negligence, of a little they are made very great. And this is that which Saint Bernard Bernard. teacheth, A minimis incipiunt, qui in maxima proruunt, They begin with little things who breake out into great.

Verse 19. The meaning which our translation seemeth to give to this verse, is to shew the strength of wisdome, above the strength of might, and that one wise man is stronger then many mighty men, nay then tenne mighty men, that is very many, although they have also the strength of a City joyned unto them. Wisdome giveth strength unto a foole, and a wise man by his good counsell is able to support a fooles weakenesse, as that hee shall resist his enemies. But this excellency of strength whereof the verse speaketh is that which wisdome giveth to the wise, to him that is capable of the force of it, to him that knoweth how to use the strength of it, him it strengthneth more then else the greatest might is able.Ambros. in Psal. 104. Saint Ambrose therefore describing a wise man in the strength of wisdome saith, Insurgit sapiens quasi victor, debellatis & triumphatis, libidine, timore, ignavia, mastitudine, caeteris{que} vitiis, donec ea de possessione suae mentis eliminet & omnibus terminis finibus{que} suis propulset & arceat: quoniam dux cautior novit excursus cavere latrocinantium, & quaedam furta belli, quae iniquissimi animae nostrae adversarii ignitis saepe pertentant spiculis, A wise man lifteth himselfe up as it were a conquerour, lust and feare, and sloth, and pensivenesse, and the rest of vices being subdued and triumphed over by him, untill that he force them and drive them even from all his borders and bounds; because as a wary Captaine hee knoweth to looke unto the incursions of robbers, and to those stealths of Warre, which the most wicked enemies of our soule doe sometimes make with fiery darts. But the Originall word translated mighty men, being 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which properly signifieth Dominatores Governours, according as also generally the word is translated in this place by interpreters: it may seeme that here by Governours in a City are understood men of humane and worldly wisdome. For as S. Ambrose speaketh, Inconsultis populis sapientes qui{que} adhibentur rectores, Ambros. in Psalm. 104. Non longe ab initio. qui plebeiam insipientiam vigore propia regant, wise men commonly are set for Governours over inconsiderate people, that by their owne strength as it were, they may rule the plebeian folly. And then we may understand the meaning to be, that true godly wisdome is of more strength then the united force of that which is worldly, though in the kind of it very strong. Behold this in Saint Steven, of whom we reade, Acts 6.10. that they who disputed with him were not able to withstand the wisdome and the spirit whereby he spake. Gregory Nyssene setting downe the conflict doth
thus expresse it;Greg. Nys. Orat. de S. Stephen. Omnes quibus eruditionis & scientia non nihil in erat in sese convertebat, & ex his qui caeteris praestare eruditione videbantur conspiratione facta, veluti in phalangas quasdam constipati, sic impetum Stephani sustinere nitebantur. At ille omnibus pariter invictus erat, sive cum multis solus, sive cum paucis congrederetur, All in whom there was any learning and knowledge, he turned upon himselfe; and of them who seemed to excell the rest, there being as it were a fouresquare army set thicke together, so did they endeavour to sustaine the assault of Steven: but he was alike unconquerable to them all, whether he encountred alone with many or else with few. But there is yet another meaning, which the reference of this verse to the following verse doth seeme to approve; and that is to understand here a comparison betweene God and sinfull man; so that the Preacher sheweth, that a wise man relying by his wisdome upon God, hath farre more strength, then as Lyra here speaketh, Quaelibet potestas humana, any power of man is able to give him. This was the strength on which Sampson relyed when that hee pulled downe the house upon the Philistines. For though his hayre was growne againe in which his strength had lyen, yet as Cajetan Cajetan. noteth, Non confidebat in auctis capillis qui obsecrat supplex pro robore hac vice, Hee did not trust in his growne hayre, who humbly be sought the Lord to grant him strength this one time.Chrysost. in Genes. Hom. 25. Saint Chrysostome speaking of Noah in the Arke saith, Ego supra omnia admiror virtutem justi, quod potuerit versari in medio bestiarum, leonum dico & pardorum, & aliarum immitium ferarum, sed ob fidem in Deum omnia isti facilia videbantur, I above all things admire the courage of the righteous man, that he could be conversant in the middest of beasts, as Lions, and Leopards and other untamed wild beasts. But by reason of his confidence in God all things did seeme easie unto him.Greg. Mor. l. 31. c. 13. Saint Gregory considering those words in the Proverbs, The righteous is bold as a Lion, thereupon saith, Iusti viri securitas recte Leoni comparatur, quia contra se quum quoslibet insurgere conspicit, ad mentis suae confidentiam redit, & scit quod cunctos adversarios superat, The security of a righteous man is well compared to a Lion, bause when he beholdeth any to arise against him, hee goeth to the confidence of his mind, and from thence knoweth that hee is sure to overcome all his adversaries.Hieronym. in hunc vers. One exposition which Saint Hierome giveth of this verse, is by the tenne men here qui habent potestatem & in urbe consistunt, who have power, and stand in the City, to understand the Angels, Qui ad perfectum numerum pervene denarium, who are come to the perfect number of tenne, and doe succour mankind. But saith hee, if any one consider all the succours that are, the succour of wisdome is greater, that is, of our Lord Iesus Christ.

Verse 20. For there is not: The reason which maketh the wisdome of man to be weake is sinne; and therefore all men being sinners, there can bee no true wisdome in any of them, nor any sound strength from their wisdome.1 Mac. 1.21. We read in the Machabees, that when Antiochus went into the Sanctuary, he tooke away the light that was burning there; and
sin entring into mans soule the Sanctuary of God, that hath taken away the cleere light of wisdome that was burning in it.Salvianus de Provid. l. 5. Psal. 139.7, Chrys. Hom. 1. de poenitent. Ionae. Wherefore Salvianus saith, exue nequitiam si vis habere sapientiam, Put away wickednesse, if thou wilt have wisdome. And Saint Chrysostome speaking to Ionah, when he fled away from God, saith unto him, whither dost thou flye? Hast thou not heard another Prophet saying, whither shall I goe from thy spirit? Or whither shall I flye from thy presence? Who answering himselfe saith, Sed tale est peccatum, quod ad multam ignorantiam redigat animam, But such a thing is sinne, that it bringeth the soule to a great deale of ignorance. Not a just man: In Scripture a just man is taken two wayes, either in respect of God, not imputing his unrighteousnesse unto him, or else in respect of the righteousnesse that is inherent in him. By inherent righteousnesse there is no man perfectly just; by not having his unrighteousnesse imputed unto him every child is absolutely a just man. And therefore Saint Austin speaking of Christ saith,August. cont. Iulian. lib. 6. cap. 5.
Sanat vitiatum à reatu statim, ab infirmitate paulatim, Hee healeth him that is corrupted from his guiltinesse presently, from his weakenesse by little and little. Or else a just man is said to be so in respect of the righteousnesse unto which hee tendeth, not in respect of the righteousnesse to which he hath already attained. Wherefore Saint Austin considering the words of the Psalmist, Lead mee O Lord in thy righteousnesse, Psal. 5.8. Aug. Ibid. thereupon noteth, Satis hic declaravit in profectione se esse ad perfectionem, non in ipsa perfectione, quum ut deducatur exoptat, He declareth here sufficiently that he was in journying to perfection, not in perfection it selfe, seeing hee prayeth that hee may bee lead. Wherefore his exhortation is good, Curramus, intendamus, in via sumus, August. in Psalm. 38.
nec tam sis securus ex iis quae pertransisti, quam solicitus pro eis ad quae nondum pervenisti, Let us runne, let us be earnest, we are yet but in the way, neither let us bee secure by those things which wee have passed over, as rather carefull for those things to which we have not attained. Not a just man upon earth: S. Hier. noteth of the red heifer, whose ashes were an expiation for the sins of the people,Hieronym. in c. 3. Lamen. Ierem. Quod non aliter immolari & offerri ad altare possit, nisi quae terrena opera non fecerit, jugum non traxerit, That it might not be sacrificed and offered upon the Altar unto the Lord, unlesse it were such a one which had not done the workes of the earth, and upon which never yoake had come; which was to signifie that workes of the earth are sinfull, and that there is no man on the earth that sinneth not. While we are on the earth, we have still enemies, Et qui pugnat, & adhuc periclitatur, & aliquando percutitur, etiamsi non sternitur. Qui autem non habet adversarium, Aug. l. de Natura & gratia. plena pace laetatur, & ipse esse verissime sine peccato dicitur, And hee that fighteth is both yet in danger, and also sometimes strucken and wounded although he be not cast downe and overthrown. But he that hath not an enemy rejoyceth in full peace, and hee it is who most truly is said to be without sinne. It is in heaven therefore where full peace to enjoyed, that sin doth not annoy, it is not on the earth. That doth good and sinneth not: it is not a doing good that the Preacher here denyeth, but a doing
good and sinning not to be joyned with it. And yet doth not the Psalmist say, Psal. 53.3. there is none that doth good, no not one? How then doth here the Preacher speake of doing good?August. in Psal. 52. Saint Austin giveth the answer in Gods name, saying, Donavi hominibus bene facere, sed ex me inquit, non ex se, ex se enim mali sunt. Filii hominum sunt quando male faciunt, filii Dei quando bene, I have given unto men to doe good, but it is from my selfe, not from themselves; for of themselves they are evill. And they are the sonnes of men when they doe evill, the sons of God when they doe good. It is therefore of the sons of men that the Psalmist speaketh: for so he saith, God looked downe from heaven upon the sonnes of men, and saw that none did good. But it is of the sons of God that the Preacher speaketh, saying, There is not a just man, that doth good and sinneth not. That sinneth not, even when hee doth good, by the imperfection of his doing of it.August. ad Bonifac. l. 3. cap. 7. Wherefore Saint Austin saith, virtus quae nunc est in homine justo hactenus perfecta nominatur, ut ad ejus perfectionem pertineat, etaim ipsius imperfectionis, & in veritate agnitio, & in humilitate confessio, The vertue which is in a just man, is so farre said to be perfect, as that there appertained to the perfection of it, an acknowledgement in truth, and a confession in humility of the very imperfection of if. In which regard,Greg. Mor. l. 29. c. 2. Saint Gregory saith, Quid in hac vita omnes qui vertitatem sequimur, nisi aurora sumus? Aurora enim noctem praeterisse nunciat, nec tamen diet claritatem illa ostendit, sed dum illam pellit, & hanc suscipit, lucem tenebris permixtam tenet; sic nos & quaedam jam quae lucis sunt agimus, & tamen in quibusdam adhuc tenebrarum reliquiis non caremus, What in this life are we all who follow the truth, but as the morning? For the morning sheweth the night to be past, but yet it doth not shew the cleerenesse of the day; and whiles it driveth the one away, it receaveth the other, it possesseth a light mixed with darknesse; so wee now doe some things which are of the light, and yet wee doe not want in some things the reliques of darknesse. The Preacher doth not here say that a just man cannot but sinne, neither doth he say there cannot be a just man; but there is not a just man that sinneth not. It was the cavill wherewith the Pelagians troubled Saint Austin, August. de peccatorum meritis lib. 2. cap. 7. whether it were impossible that by the absolute power of God a just man might not live on earth without sinne. But what have we to doe with the absolute power of God? Saint Austin saith well, Si quaeratur utrum in hac vita aliquis sit sine peccato, esse non credo: magis enim credo Scripturae, ubi Sanctorum vox est, si dicimus, &c. If it be asked whether in this life any be without sin, I beleeve not: because I beleeve rather the sacred Scriptures, wherat is the voice of the Saints: If we say, that we have no sin, we deceive our selves, and there is no truth in us. The Originall word here used is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth to sin by erring and of ignorance, and therefore is fitly applyed to the just man who sinneth not presumptuously and stubbornly. And it is as fitly used to shew the imperfection of humane wisdome, for where there is an erring and ignorance, there must needs be a defect and weaknesse.

q.p: VER. 21. Also take no heed unto all words that are spoken, lest thou heare thy servant curse thee.
VER. 22. For oftentimes also thine owne heart knoweth, that thou thy selfe likewise hast cursed others.

div.p:
Verse 21 As there is not a just man that sinneth not, so there is none so just, none that sinneeth so little, but his righteousnesse by slanders is diminished, his sinnes by false reports are made more and greater than they are. Which partly ariset;h from the envy which is so generally in men, and partly from the nature of slandering, which being done in the absence of them whom it wrongeth, hath the lesse shame, and is the sooner entertained. For as Saint Bsail speaketh,Basilius Ep. 75.
Quis in accusndis vitiis nemine contradicente defecit? Quis deferendo mendacii convictus est, non coram constituto eo quem falso detulit? Who ever was confuted in accusing vices, when no one did contradict him? Who ever in reporting a lye was convicted, hee not being brought to answer if of whom it was falsly reported? It is against this therefore the the Precher here instructeth a just and wise man what to doe. Also take not heed: not to heare that which is spoken may not be in thy power: for the tongue of a slanderer though it be low in whispering at the first broching of a false report, yet it becommeth loud in spreading of it afterward; but though thou dost heare, take not heed unto it. And as Saint Chrysostome speaketh,Chrysost. in Acta Apost. Hom. 26.
Nobis ne sit curae, quid multi de nobis sentiant. Deo vivimus, non hominbus; in coelo cives sumus, non super terram: illic praemia nostrorum laborum jacent; illinc laudes expectemus; catenus curemus homines, ne illis offendiculo & damno simus. Si ego quidem facio quod decet, & alius blasphemat, nihil ad me, sed ad illum, Let us not be carefull what many thinke or say of us: we live to God, not to men; we are Citizens in heaven, not upon the erth: there are laid up the rewards of our labours, from thence we expect praises: so farre let us care for men, as that we doe not wrong them, nor trespasse against them. If I doe that which I ought, and another slander me, it is nothing to me, but much to him. To the same purpose Saint Austin saith, Non curo vanum calumniatorem, Aug. l. cont. Manichae. quia idoneum tene promissorem, I doe not regard a vaine slanderer, because I have an able promiser. And accordingly therefore when the Manichees reported of him, that he forsooke their sect either for feare or desire, as one that tooke no heed unto it, he saith, Quod de animo meo verum non sentis, facile contemno. Hoc enim sentis, quod etsi de me non agnosco, fieri tamen potest ut sit in homine. Ergo etiam si in me erras, non tamen ita erras, ut me de numero hominum eximat tua opinio, quia id de me credis, quod fieri
potest in animo humano, etiam si non sit sanctum in animo meo. Nec igitur opus est ut tibi hanc suspicionem magnopere coner auferre, That thou dost not think the truth of my mind I easily despise. For thou thinkest that, which though I doe acknowledge to be in me, yet it is a thing which may be in a man. Wherefore although thou errest in me, yet thou dost not so erre, as that thine opinion should exempt me from the number of men; because thou dost beleeve that of me, which may bee in the mind of man, although it be not good in my mind. And therefore it is not needfull that I should much labour to take away this suspicion from thee. Take not heed therefore unto such words: but though thou dost heare them, Psal. 38.13. yet be as David was, and as a deafe man that heareth not. Or if thou dost take heed unto them, as there may be just reason in many respects to doe so, yet then as the Originall here saith, Ne apponas cor tuum, set not thine heart upon them, let them not trouble and disquiet thine heart.Hieronym. Ep. ad Oceanum. For as Saint Hierome saith, Si aequo animo pensamus, id ipsum quod nobis quis detrahere videtur injuste, laudari nos potius, quam accusari probamur, If wee rightly weigh it, even this that any one seemeth unjustly to slander us, doth prove that we are praised rather than accused. Our Saviour Christ was said to have a Devill,August. in Psal. 99. and thereupon S. Austin saith, Non opus erat ut Iesu hoc audiret; sed te monuit adversus aspera verba; There was no need that Christ should have this spoken of him; but it was to admonish us, that when we are evill spoken of, we take it not to heart. It is not I confesse, an easie thing to doe it: the Prophet David was touched home with it, Psalm. 55.2. & 3. who saith, I mourne in my complaint and am sore vexed, because of the voice of the enemy. But let us know the Disciples not to be above the master, and let us prove our selves to bee the Disciples of Christ by following bis example. Vnto all words that are spoken: regard not all words that are spoken, but consider who speakes them. If they be the servants of God that speake not well of thee, then respect what they say.Greg. in c. 2. Ezek. Hom. 9. For as Saint Gregory speaketh, Debent haberi in metu ac reverentia judicia justorum, quia membra Dei omnipotentis sunt, & hoc ipsi in terra reprehendunt, quod Dominus redarguit è coelo, The judgements of the righteous ought to be had in an awfull reverence and esteeme, because they are members of Almighty God, and what they reproove on earth he condemneth in heaven. But if they be the words of the wicked, regard them not;Greg. Ibid. for as the same Father speaketh, Stultum est valde, si illis placere quaerimus, quos non placere Deo scimus, It is a very wicked thing, if we seeke to please them, whom we know not to please God. Least thou heare thy servant to curse thee: this wickednesse of slandering is not seldome in those who are neere unto a man, and if a servant doe it, perhaps others who are thought to be friends may be guilty of it. Wherefore because this would bee a great trouble to a man that such should wrong him, and because thereby he may also be caryed into many mischiefes, as of quarelling and breach of charity, therefore the Preacher adviseth,August. in Psalm. 99. not to hearken after what is said, nor to bee willing to heare such things when they are brought unto us. Saint Austin tels us, that when a
nett is spread for a bird, the manner is to throw stones at the hedge.Augusti. in Psal. 99. Now sayth he, those stones doe not hurt the bird, for who striketh the bird that casteth them? But the bird fearing this vaine sound fals into the nett. In like manner, sayth he, men that feare and regard the vaine sound of all words, what doe they but fall into the devils nett, whd thereby caryes them captive into much evill, many troubles, and inconveniences? Or else by servants here, wee may understand, any inferiour and base people, which are indeed too apt to slander and wrong in their speeches and reports their betters and superiours. But take no heed to all that is spoken, for such take little heed what they speake, and if such things trouble thee, thou mayest have trouble enough quickly.

Verse 22. For oftentimes also thine owe heart knoweth: thine owne heart is thine owne conscience; according to the saying, Conscientia est cordis scientia, Conscience is the knowledge of the heart. And indeed the Hebrew hath no other word to expresse the conscience, but onely 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which properly signifieth the heart. Thine owne conscience therefore knoweth, for that is as Bernard Bernard. speaketh, Vox virtutis, & radius lucis, a beame of light to discerne the truth, and a voyce of power to tell it plainly to thee. Thou needeest not any other to shew thee thine ill doing; there is one within, Qui secretam gannit in aurem, Who whispereth in thine eare what it is. Doe but turne thine hearing inward, doe but cast thine eyes upon thine owne breast; and from thence thou shalt be best informed of thy doings. There is no difficultie for thee there to know them. Indeed, as Saint Bernard Bernard. also speaketh, Labor est potius aures obturare, ne audias. Ipsa se offert, ipsa se ingerit, The labour rather is to stop thine eares, that thou doe not heare thy conscience. Shee offereth her selfe, shee thrusteth her selfe upon thee. Nay, shee will be heard, doe thou what thou canst, and make thee know thy sinnes. Nero after his much bloud-shed, may change his bed-chamber, but his fiends ever attend him, ever are with him, and are as parts of himselfe. If a wicked man could shift from himselfe, he might have some hope not to heare of his sinnes; but so long as he hath himselfe, he hath one that will tell him of his faults. Yea, what if a wicked mn in some sort doe runne from himselfe? His soule may flie from his body, but his conscience will not flie from his soule, nor his sinne from his conscience, there he shall still have it brought unto his knowledge. That thou thy selfe likewise hast cursed others: the force of this reason may be conceived three wayes. First thus, seeing that thou thy selfe, as thou knowest, hast cursed others, and wouldest not that they should have heard it, or from others heard of it; be contented therefore in like manner, neither to heare nor to heare of the cursings and evill speakings which others use of thee. So Lyra expoundeth it, saying,Lyra, & Glossa Ordin. in hunc versum. Sicut nolles maledicta tua investigari, sic nee debes aliorum investigare, As thou wouldest not that others should search out thine evill speakings, so the evill speakings of others ought not to be searched out by thee. Thus
also doth the Ordinary Glosse understand it, applying to this place that common saying, Quod tibi non vis, alteri ne feceris: patere legem quam ipse tuleris, That which thou wouldest not have done unto thy selfe, doe not unto another: suffer the Law which thou thy selfe hast made. Of which Saint Austin sayth,Augustin. that it is a sentence, whereupon all nations under heaven are agreed, and which if wee referre to the love of God, extinguisheth all haynous crimes; if wee referre unto the love of man, banisheth all grievous wrongs. Secondly, wee may conceive the force of the reason thus; seeing thou knowest thy selfe to have spoken evill of others, and to have cursed them, for which thou mayest justly feare the wrath of God upon thee; therefore take not heed to the words of others that speake evill of thee, but passe them by, and forgive them mildly and quietly, that God may mercifully and graciously forgive thee also:Hieronym. in hunc vers. thus Saint Hierome seemeth to understand it, saying, Quomodo novit conscientia tua, quod tu saepe aliis detraxisti, sic et aliis debes ignoscere detrahentibus, As thou knowest thy selfe often to have slandered others; Mat. 18.34. so thou must forgive others when they slander thee. He that in the Gospell was cast into prison by his fellow-servant, had not complained of it to his Master, there was no end of that, but instantly the Masters anger was incensed, and he that was so courteous before, was then most severe. And surely, there is nothing that doth more provoke the wrath of Almightie God, then when wee being ou rselves spared by him,Ambros. in Psalm. 118. Serm. 20. will not spare others for the same things. Saint Ambrose therefore sayth, Necesse est eam formam in te redire judicii quam in alium ipse decernendam putaveris, There is a necessitie that the same forme of judgement should returne upon thee, which thou thy selfe hast thought fit to be decreed against another. In the Lords prayer wee say, Forgive us our trespasses, as wee forgive them that trespasse against us: Where Chrysologus sayth,Chrys. Serm. 71.
Homo penes te est potestas veniae, in te est indulgentiae jus, tu tibi remissionis autor constitutus. Gratis petis veniam qui tibi in alio indulgere contemnis. Homo tu tibi factus es ipse misericoridae mensura, quantum quaris misericordie, fac tantum, Man the power of pardon is in thine owne power, the right of indulgency is in thy selfe, thou art made the authour of remission to thy selfe. In vaine dost thou seeke pardon, who despisest in another to give it to thy selfe. Man thou thy selfe are made the measure of mercy to thy selfe; as much mercy as thou seekest for thy selfe,Anselmus. so much shew to others. Anselme therefore speaketh well unto us, Debetis conservis non negare, quod à bono Domino gaudetis vos percepisse, Take heed, you must not deny unto your fellow-servants, that which you rejoyce to have received from a good Master. And a good Writer sayth also well, Cum hac obligatione Dei bona in te veniunt, ut à te in proximos proficiscantur, With this obligation doe the good things of God come unto thee, that from thee the like may proceed to others. Thirdly, as I understand, the force of the reason may be conceived thus: Seeing thine owne heart knoweth, that thou hast cursed others, and in thy speeches detracted from them, thou mayest be sure also that
others doe the same towards thee. For it is the justice of God, even in this world, to requite men in the same kinde that their wickednesse was committed. His law is, Thou shalt doe to them,
Deut. 19.19 & 21. as he had thought to have done to his brother, life for life, eye for eye, hand for hand. Although it were not done but intended onely by false accusations, the Lord would have the same to be done to him. Wherefore when thou by false reports wrongest another, thou mayest be assured that God suffereth the same to be done of thee. Saint Austin noteth of the Aegyptians,Augustin. de Temp. Serm. 89.
Percutitur Aegyptus primogeniti affectu, ut ex eo cognoscerent, quantus dolor sit filiorum, qui necaverunt filios Hebraeorum, Aegypt is smitten with the affection of their first borne, that from thence they might know the griefe for children destroyed, who had destroyed the children of the Israelites. Wherefore seeing thou who hast spoken ill of others, mayest be sure that others speake ill of thee, to avoyd the vexation of it, doe not harken after it, doe not looke into it. For as Tertullian speaketh, Nihil amarius quam id ipsum pati quod feceris, There is nothing more bitter than to suffer that which thou hast done to others.

q.p: VER. 23. All this have prooved by wisedome: J sayd, J will be wise, but it was farre from me.
VER 24. That which is farre off, and exceeding deepe, who can finde it out?

div.p:
Verse. 23. All this have I proved by wisedome: The Preacher had attained unto much wisedome, all this he had prooved by it, and all this was nothing neere the all which he had prooved by it. Wherefore this it was which made him to see the imperfection of his wisedome. For wise men as Saint Gregory speaketh, Dum proximi luci fiunt, Tertul. Cont. Marcia. l. 2. Greg. Mor. l. 32. c. 1.
quicquid eos in seipsis latebat inveniunt. Vnusquisque enim sibi dum tactu veri luminis illustratur, ostenditur, & unde agnoscit, quid est justitia, inde eruditur, ut videat quid sit culpa, While they are brought neere unto the light, doe find out whatsoever was in themselves hidden from themselves. For every one when he is enlightned with the touch of the true light is shewed unto himselfe, and from whence he perceiveth what is righteousnesse, from thence he is taught to see what is wickednesse; from whence he discerneth, what is wisedome, from thence he is shewed, what is folly. But they who have not attained to wisedome, Tanto se ei propinquos aestimant, quanto et ejus rectitudinis regulam ignorant, quia siti in tenebris mirari lucis claritatem necesiunt, quam nunquam viderunt, By so much doe thinke themselves neere unto it, by how much they doe not know the rule of the rightnesse of it, because being placed in darknesse, they know not how to admire the brightnesse of the light which thay have never
seene.Basilius tractatu de fide. Saint Basil therefore also speaking of these words, sayth, that wisedome is sayd to be far off, Non quidem quod revera illa fugeret, sed quod ii maxime intelligunt quod ea omnem cujusvis ad ipsam comprehendendam captum exuperet, qui Dei beneficio ampliorem ipsi quam caeteri cognitionem sunt consecuti, Not that wisedome it selfe doth flie away, but because they who by the favour of God have obtained a more ample knowledge of it than others, doe especially understand that it exceedeth the capacitie of any one to be able to comprehend it.Greg. Mor. l. 35. c. 2. Wherefore Saint Gregory againe speaking of wise men, sayth, Quanto magis contemplando proficiunt, tanto amplius despiciendo quod sunt, aut nihil aut prope, nihil se esse cognoscunt, By how much they profit in contemplation, by so much despising themselves in that which they are, they acknowledge themselves to be nothing, or neere unto nothing. He therefore that shall study wisedome, shall finde it to be true which Lyra noteth,Lyra in hunc vers. Frequenter contingit, quod homines studiosi circa divina credunt in principio acquisivisse demonstrationes, de quibus postea percipiunt quod sint magis topicae vel sophisticae rationes, Oftentimes it commeth to passe, that men studious about divine things, doe beleeve in the beginning that they have gotten demonstrations, which afterwards they perceive to be onely topicall or sophisticall arguments. And when they can say, all this I have prooved by wisedome, then they are ready to say, all this which I know, I perceive to be no wisedome. I sayd I will be wise: he sayth not, I am wise, but I will be wise; and as Saint Gregory speaketh,Greg. Mor. l. 35. c. 2.
Qui sapienter quidem locutus hominibus fuerat, sapientius se cognoscit, non esse sapientem, He that had spoken wisely unto men, more wisely doth know himselfe not to be wise. But yet he sayd, I will be wise, He had a desire to be, his minde was stirred up to seeke after it, and that resolutely and earnestly.Gregorius in c. 10. 1 Regum. For as Saint Gregory noteth, this is the difference betweene wisedome in this life, and wisedome in the next; Ista quidem cognitio lucis electorum desideria satiare non novit sed excitare, illa vero & satiare & excitare. Nam tam jucundares est, ut incessabiliter concupiscatur, & tam plena, ut qui jam semper hanc in magno desiderio viderunt, semper ineffabili plenitudine satientur, That knowledge of the light is able to stirre up the desires of the elect, but not able to satisfie them; but this will both satisfie them, and stirre them up also. For so pleasant a thing it is, that it may be uncessantly desired, and so full a thing, that they who alwayes see it in a great desire of it, are alwayes satisfied with an ineffable fulnesse of it. But it was farre from me: Wisedome flyeth, and it flyeth upon the wings of the winde, that is, that I may use Saint Gregories words,Greg. Mor. l. 17. c. 15.
Volat, quia longe in altum ab intellectu nostro se rapit: volat super pennas ventorum, quia transcendit scientiam animarum, It flyeth because it caryeth it selfe on high farre away from our understanding: it flyeth upon the wings of the winde, because it transcendeth the knowledge of humane soules. Man may say, I will be wise, and so seeke after wisedome, and that with the swiftest and greatest pursuit of his endeavours;Hieronym. in hunc vers. but as Saint Hierome speaketh, Quanto plus quaefierit, santo minus reperiet, sed se in mediam demersum caliginem, tenebrisque ignorantiae
circundatum agnoscet, By how much the more he shall seeke it, by so much the lesse he shall finde it, but shall acknowledge himselfe to be drowned in the midst of darknesse, and to be encompassed with blindnesse and ignorance. Quanto plus scire coeperit, tanto ei in his quotidie orietur major obscuritas, By how much he shall begin to know the more, by so much dayly in these things of wisedome shall the greater obscuritie arise unto him. The Preacher had sayd, I will be wise, he had sayd it secretly in his owne heart and minde by his resolute purpose of striving to attaine it, but he doth as it were cry out, It was farre from mee. For as Saint Gregory speaketh,Greg. Mor. l. 17. c. 2.
Exclamare mens humana in admiratione compellitur, dum altitudine considerationis in requisitionibus suis eo ipso quo latius extenditur, angustatur, The minde of man is forced in admiration to cry out, while that by the height of contemplation, it is even thereby the more straitned in its seeking and searching, by how much it is the more enlarged. The more the Preacher sought, the more he saw that he had to seeke, the farther he was gone, the farther he saw that he had to goe, the farther he went, the farther he saw that wisedome was from him. Wherefore Saint Gregory expounding these words, sayth, Quaesita sapientia longè recedere dicitur, Greg. Mor. l. 32. c. 1.
quia appropinquanti altior videtur, Wisedome being fought for, is sayd to be farre off; because by him that commeth neere it, it is seene to be higher still, then he did or could perceive it to be.

Verse 24. That which is farre off, even so farre off that he whose arme is able to breake even a bow of steele, is not able to reach it: even so farre off, that he who is able to make his nest with the Eagle, is not able to flie unto it: even so farre off, that he who could span from East to West, could not comprehend it. That which is exceeding deepe, even so exceeding deepe, that he who could follow the Leviathan, could not come unto it, that he who could set out the center of the earth, is not able to finde it out, and who then is able to attaine unto it? Wisedome it is that the Preacher speaketh of, and the remotenesse of it, the exceeding depth of it, sheweth it to be divine wisedome. For that is so farre off, that it is not knowne, from whence it commeth, nor where the place of it is; Iob. 28.20. according as Elihu sheweth in the booke of Iob, saying, Whence commeth wisedome, and where is the place of understanding? That is so deepe, that the depth sayth, it is not in me, and the sea sayth, it is not with mee. That is, so farre, that the weaknesse of mans understanding is overwearyed, before it can come unto it, that is, Iob 28.14. so exceeding deepe, that the eye of mans understanding is dazeled to looke into it, and mans wit is endangered much by ventring into it, that is, deepe and deepe, as the Originall expresseth it selfe; deepe to men, deepe to Angels, and exceeding the capacitie of both of them. Saint Austin asking the question, what God is? giveth it this answere,Augustin. de fide Cont. Arrian. c. 6.
Certè hic est, de quo et quum dicitur non potest dici, quum aestimatur, non potest aestimari, quum comparatur non potest comparari, quum definitur, ipse sua definitione crescit, Surely, it is he, who when he is spoken of, cannot be
spoken of, who when hee is considered of, cannot bee considered of, who when he is compared to any thing, cannot be compared, and when he is defined, groweth greater by defining of him. It was not the Lord which the Prophet Ezechiel saw, Ezek. 1.28. it was only a vision: in the vision it was not the glory of the LORD which hee saw, but the likenesse of it; nay it was not the likenesse of it, but the appearance of the likenesse of the glory of the LORD, that made him to fall on his face, as not being able to behold it. But if this did so astonish the Prophet, who can behold the LORD himselfe in his glory? In the Psalmes,Psal. 18.10. Greg. Mor. l. 7. c. 15.
the Lord is said to ride upon a Cherub: upon which words Saint Gregory saith, Cherub quippe plenitudo scientiae dicitur, proinde super plenitudinem scientiae ascendisse perhibetur, quia majestatis ejus plenitudinem scientia nulla comprehendit, A Cherub is so called as being a fulnesse of knowledge: and therefore is God said to ascend above the fulnesse of knowledge, because no knowledge comprehendeth the fulnesse of his Majesty. Isaiah 6.2. When we read in the Prophet Isaiah, of the Seraphims standing above the throne of the Lord, that each of them had six wings, and that with twaine the Cherub covered his face, with twaine he covered his feete, and with twaine he did flye, Origen Origen. saith, Duabus velabant faciem, non propriam sed Dei, duabus alis velabant pedes, non proprios sed Dei. Operiebant faciem Dei, exordium enim Dei ignotum est, sed & pedes: novissimum enim quod in Deo nostro est non comprehenditur: sola media videntur, ex iis quae sunt intelligo Deum, With twaine they covered his face, the face of God, not their owne, with two wings they covered his feete, not their owne feete, but the feete of God. They covered the face of God, for the beginning of God is unknowne; but so they did his feete also, for the last that is in our God is not comprehended: only the middle things are seene, and from those things which are, doe I understand God. Behold here the remotenesse and depth of divine wisedome whereof the Preacher here speaketh: his face is covered, his beginning is unknowne there is wisdome farre off: his feete are covered, the last that is in God is not comprehended, there is the exceeding depth of it. The Preacher here comprehendeth in two things, Eph. 3.18. that which Saint Paul setteth out in foure, the length, and bredth whereof S. Paul speaks, is but the remotenesse whereof the Preacher speaketh; the depth and height which S. Paul distinguisheth, is but the depth of the Preacher doubled. Now upon S. Pauls words S. Ambrose saith,Ambros. in Epist. ad Ephes. Quum dicit latitudo & longitudo & altitudo & profundum, hoc uti{que} significat, ut sicut in sphaera tanta longitudo est, quanta latitudo, & tanta altitudo quantum profundum, ita & in Deo omnia aequalia sunt immensitate infinitatis, when he saith, length & bredth, height and depth, this it is which he signifieth, that as in a spheare, the length is as great as the bredth, and the height as great as the depth, so in God all things are equall by the immensity of an infinity. And this it is which the Preacher signifieth, for shewing the extent of divine wisdome to be as great in the depth as it is in the widenesse, and both to be incomprehensible, he asketh, who can finde it out? Surely as S. Basil speaketh,
Etsi omnes omnium mentes unà ad investigandum coirent, item{que} ad enunciandum lingua concurrerent, tamen qui assequi possit nemo existeret, Basilius tractatu de fide. Although all the minds of all should joyne together to search after it, and also the tongues of all should joyne together to expresse it, there would bee none that could attaine unto it. But yet that wee be not discouraged from the seeking after it, S. Gregory tels us, Qui videri non potest per incircumscriptum lumen aeternitatis, videri potest per quasdam circumscriptas imagines, He that cannot be seene by the unlimited light of his eternity, yet can bee seene by some limited shadowes which hee casteth from himselfe. Wherefore when Elihu in Iob saith, that wisedome is hid from the eyes of all living; S. Gregory understandeth it, Nemo quippe eam videt,
Iob 28.21. qui adhuc carnaliter vivit, quia nemo potest Deum simul amplecti & saeculum, No one truly seeth it, who liveth carnally; because no one can at once embrace God and the world.1 Tim. 6.16. And when the Apostles saith of God, that hee dwelleth in a light, which no man can approch unto, whom no man hath seene nor can see, the same Father expounding it saith,Greg. Mor. l. 18. c. 28.
More suo homines vocat omnes humana sapientes; quia qui divina sapiunt videlicet supra homines sunt, According to his manner he calleth men, all them who savour the things of man, because they who savour divine things are above men. Let us therefore walke not after the flesh, but after the spirit, and though divine wisdome bee a farre off, yet wee shall come to some sight of it; let us by our heavenly conversation be above men, and though it be exceeding deepe, yet we shall come to some apprehension of it, and shall at length be brought to drinke of the fountaine it selfe, although we now but tast of some streames of it.

q.p: VER. 25. I apply mine heart to know, and to search and to seeke out wisdome, and the reason of things, and to know the wickednesse of folly, even of foolishnesse and madnesse.
VER. 26. And J finde more bitter than death, the woman whose heart is snares and nets, and her hands are bands: who so pleaseth God shall escape from her, but the sinner shall be taken by her.

div.p:
Verse 25. There is a threefold wisdome, Sapientia carnis quae inimica est Deo, sapientia mundi quae stultitia est apud Deum, sapientia vera quae est Dei, A wisdome of the flesh which is enmity to God, a wisdome of the world which is foolish with God, a true wisdome which
is the wisdome of God, as S. Bernard sets them downe. The Preacher therefore having shewed how true wisdome was too far from him,Bern. Serm. 9. inter parvos. too deepe for him, as well beyond his sight as his reach, hee sheweth how hee applyed and turned his minde unto the other two. The Hebrew is thus 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Circuivi ego & cor meum, I and my heart turned about or made a circle to know, &c. And surely it is well, when a man and his heart doe goe together. For too many goe to many places, whither their hearts goe not with them, to mind what they see, what they heare. Many goe to God, to the Church of God, but their hearts goe not with them, to consider and to apply to their heart, that which is said unto them. Many goe to the house of mourning, to the buryall of the dead, but their hearts doe not goe with them, to remember their owne mortality in that which they see. Many goe many wayes, but they take not their hearts with them to make use of those things which they meere with. But the Preacher tooke his heart with him, he and his heart turned about, he observed things, and his heart looking into them considered of them. I, in the Originall is expressed with an emphasy, as if it contained as much as I the King, and I the Preacher, and who both had but one heart, which sought the good of his people. Or else we may take the Originall word, as it signifieth to make a circle; for in seeking of knowledge there is a circle made, and as it proceedeth from the effect to the cause, so it returneth from the cause to the effect. Or else in the Preacher we may conceive the circle to be, the contemplation of his heart, how all things proceeded from the power of God as the efficient cause, and how all things returned to the glory of God as to the finall cause. To know and to search and to seeke out wisdome: in the placing of which words wee may either observe the order of the Preachers intention, or else of his proceeding.
