If wee looke to the order of his intention, then knowledge is first, and the other two follow, as being but the way to come to his intention. If we looke upon the order of his proceeding, then knowledge is placed first, as being that which lead him to search farther, to seeke for more. And here we may consider the Preacher to speake in Saint Bernards words,Bern. Serm. Beatus qui invenit sapientiam. Vehementer eam considerat anima mea, nec invenisse sufficit si contigerit invenire, My mind doth earnestly seeke and apply it, selfe unto it neither doth it suffice mee to have found it, even when I have found it. For even when he knoweth he seeketh and searcheth. Whereby also the Preacher teacheth us, that wisdome is not gotten without searching and seeking. Frustra quaerit qui in lectulo suo quaerit; non enim in terra suaviter viventium sapientia invenitur, He seeketh it in vaine, that seeketh it in his bed, for wisedome is not found in the land of them that live deliciously as Saint Bernard also speaketh. Wisdome is a field, Fodiamus in eo, thesaurus absconditus latet, effodiamus eum, Let us digge in it, the treasure lyeth hid, let us digge it out by searching and seeking. And the reason of things: for hee it is that knoweth a thing, that knoweth the reason of it; that is to know any thing cleerely, all knowledge else is darke
and obscure. The Originall word here is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
supputatio, ratiocinium, a numbring or reckoning, and it may be taken to signifie the Preachers care to get the perfect and exact knowledge of humane wisedome. For as Saint Austin speaketh;Ambros. in Domi. Quadrages. Nemo numerat nisi quod vult diligentius custodire, nemo nisi qui veretur ne fraudem absque numero patiatur, No one numbreth any thing but that which he will keepe very diligently, no one numbreth but that he feareth least he should be deceived, if that he doe not number. The Preacher therefore that he might not be deceived, that he might know things truely, did search and seeke and cast up supputationem, the accompt and reckoning of things. And to know the wickednesse of folly: As I conceive, wee may not amisse understand this of the sinfulnesse that is in that folly of man, which is accompted to bee the wisedome of man. For as there is no true wisedome, but the wisedome of GOD, so the very vertues of humane wisedome have a sinfulnesse of folly in them. Saint Bernard sayth,Bernard. Super. Cantic. Serm. 23.
Frustra hujus saeculi sapientes de quatuor virtutibus tam multa disputaverunt, quas tamen apprehendere omnino nequiverunt, quum illum nescierint qui factus est nobis à Deo sapientia docens prudentiam, & justitia delicta donans, & sanctificatio in exemplo temperantiae continenter vivens, & redemptio in exemplum patientiae fortiter moriens, In vaine have the wise men of this world disputed so much of foure principall vertues, which yet they could not apprehend, because they knew not him who is made unto us of God, Wisedome teaching us prudence, and justice pardoning our sinnes, and sanctification, living continently for an example of temperance, and redemption, dying patiently for an example to us of patience. What sayth he, have yee to doe with vertues, who are ignorant of Christ the power and vertue of God? Where is true wisedome, but in the doctrine of Christ? Where true justice, but in the mercy of Christ? Where the temperance, but in the life of Christ? Where true fortitude, but in the death of Christ? They onely who are endewed with his doctrine, are to be called prudent, they onely just, who from his mercy have obtained pardon of their sinnes, they onely temperate, who study to imitate his life, they onely valiant, who in adversitie doe hold fast the doctrine of his patience. In vaine doth any one labour in the getting of vertues, if he hope to have them any other way, then from the Lord of vertues, whose doctrine is the seminary of prudence, whose mercy is the worke of justice, whose life is the glasse of temperance, whose death is the ensigne of valour. Even of foolishnesse and madnesse: the Hebrew most directly is, and the foolishnesse of madnesse, whereby, as I conceive, wee may not amisse understand the mad folly of wicked people, who yet thinke themselves in pleasing themselves the wisest of all.Augustin. in Psal. 39. Saint Austin therefore speaking of the sinfull contentments of this life, sayth, Quae vides, bona putas, falleris, sanus
non es, nimia febre phreneticus factus es, Those things which thou seest, thou thinkest to be good things, thou art deceived, thou art not sound in thy wits, thou art made mad with a strong feaver. It is but a folly of madnesse, which such accompt wisedome. Saint Ambrose readeth this verse thus;Ambros. de bono mortis. c. 7.
Circuivit cor meum ut considerarem & quaererem sapientiam & numerum & ut scirem impii laetitiam, & molestiam & jactationem, et inveni eam amariorem morte, My heart went about, that I might consider and seeke wisedome and number, and that I might know the joy of the wicked, and their trouble, and their boasting, and I found it more bitter than death. Non quia amara sit mors, sed quia impio amara; et tamen amarior vita quam mors. Gravius est enim ad peccatum vivere, quam in peccato mori: quia impius quam diu vivit peccatum auget; moriatur, peccare desinit, Not that death is bitter, but because it is bitter to a wicked man; and yet life is more bitter than death. For it is more grievous, to live unto sinne, than to dye in sinne: because a wicked man while hee liveth encreaseth his sinnes, but let him dye, hee ceaseth to sinne.

Verse 26. And I finde: I here is I with a witnesse. Quod expertus est loquitur, Hieronym. in hunc vers. Lyra in hunc vers. he speaketh that which he had found by experience, sayth Saint Hierome. More bitter then death: because, sayth Lyra, Separat animam à suo creatore, mors autem à solo corpore. Prior autem separatio amarior est, quia separat à bono infinito, It separateth the soule from his Creatour, whereas death from the body onely. The first separation therefore is the more bitter, because it separateth from an infinite good. Another sayth well, Nulla quidem mors est, quae tot amaritudines propinet, tot dedecora inferat, quot infert et propinat una libido, There is indeed no death which reacheth to a man so many bitter draughts, which bringeth him to so many disgraces, as that one wickednesse of sinfull lust doth give and bring unto him. Or else wee may understand the words in a generall sense, as setting forth the greatnesse of the evill.Hieronym. in hunc vers. So Saint Hierome seemeth to understand it, who writing upon this verse, sayth, Nunc ait illud in sua se quaesisse sapientia, quod in rebus humanis malum universa antecedat mala, et quae res impietatis, stultitiae, erroris, vecordiae teneat principatum, Now he sayth that he sought in his wisedome, that which being evill in the affayres of men, exceedeth all evils else, and which thing hath the precedency, of all impietie, folly, errour, madnesse. The woman: it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Illa foemina, The woman, the shame of women, the lascivious woman: And therefore Saint Hierome sayth, Non putemus temere hanc Solomonem de omni genere mulierum protulisse sententiam, Let us not rashly thinke that Solomon did pronounce this sentence of all kinde of women. Whose heart is as snares: the Originall directly is, Quae ipsa decipulae, Who is her selfe snares: her selfe is but the snares of another. For indeed,
the Originall word is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Decipulae venantium, The snares of hunters, and therefore both the Septuagint and Saint Hierome doe reade it so, Quae laqueus venatorum est, Who is the snare of the hunters. And what are these hunters but the devils? So sayth Lyra, Laqueus venatorum, id est, daemonum qui venantur animas, & muliere quasi laqueo utuntur ad eas capiendas, The snare of the hunters, that is, of the devils, who hunt after soules, and doe use a woman as it were a snare to catch them. In the Proverbs, Solomon speaking of this woman, sayth, Remove thy way farre from her,
Proverbs 5.8. & 9. and come not neere the dore of her house: Least thou give thine honour unto others, and thy yeeres to the cruell: that is, sayth Rabbi Solomon, Ne des annos tuos, principi gehennae, Least thou give thine yeares to the Prince of hell. Theophylact also sayth,Theophyl. in c. 15. Luca. Qui adhaeret Domino unus spiritus fit cum illo, qui vero adhaeret scorto unum corpus fit cum natura daemonum, atque fit totus caro, He that is joyned to the Lord is made one Spirit with him, he that is joyned to an harlot, is made one body with the nature of the devils, and is indeed made even all flesh. Vpon this verse it is the note of him who is the Authour Catenae Graecae, Autor Catenae Graecae. Intellexit insuper malum illud quod hujusmodi omnia operaretur esse diabolum; He understood moreover that evill which wrought all these things to be the devill. And whose heart is nets: So is the Originall most directly: So that her selfe is a hunter also as well as a snare, and in her heart shee spreadeth her nets, for there it is that her cunning plots and devises are framed, whereby shee catcheth simple soules. It is not a net, but nets that her heart is, because shee is full of subtle projects, full of baytes to allure, and of ginnes to entrap. Lyra noteth that her heart is sayd to be nets,Lyra in hunc versum. Quia sicut sagana capiuntur pisces magni parvi et mediocres, sic mulier de quolibet statu hominum decipit plures, Because as in a nett are taken, great, little and middle fishes, so such a woman deceiveth many of every state and condition of men. All is good fish that commeth to her nett. And her hands are bands: Saint Hierome tels us,Hieronym. in Epist. ad Fabiolam. Duplicia sunt in Scripturis vincula, There are in the Scriptures two kindes of bands, the one are the bands of God, which are his commandements, the other are the bands of the devill, such as are the bands of this wicked woman. But upon this verse, Saint Hierome tels us, that Aquila did render these words, Vinctae sunt manus ejus, Her hands are bound: and thereupon Saint Hierome notes, Suadere potest, vim facere non potest, nec ad se nolentes compellere, Shee may perswade but shee cannot enforce, neither can shee compell unto her selfe those that are unwilling: Who so pleaseth God shall escape from her. The Originall is as Saint Hierome doth render it, Bonus coram Deo eruetur ab ea, Hieronym. in hunc vers. He that is good before God, that is, he that hath a good and honest heart, which is the thing that God lookes upon, he although hee may be in danger, yet shall be delivered from the nets of her heart.
Or else to take it as wee reade it, Who so pleaseth God, shall escape from her, Tremellius in hunc vers. that is, sayth Tremellius, as if he sayd, Abs qua nemo sine singulari ope gratiaque Dei integrum se servare possit, adeo vafra est lenociniorum malorum artifex, From whom no one without the singular helpe and grace of God, can preserve himselfe, so subtle is shee in framing of pleasant allurements, and mischiefes. But the sinner shall be taken by her: and to be taken by her, what is it but to be taken by the devill? What is it but to be lead in triumph as a slave to sinne?

q.p: VER. 27. Behold this have I found (sayth the Preacher) counting one by one to find out the account.
VER. 28. Which yet my soule seeketh, but J finde not: one man among a thousand have I found, but a woman among all those have J not found.
VER. 29. Loe this onely have J found, that God hath made man upright: but they have sought out many inventions.

div.p:
Hugo Ʋictorinus. Verse 27. It is the saying of Hugo de Sancto Victore in his annotations upon some part of this Booke; Sermones sapientium & anigmata eorum scrutari, et eam quae intrinsecus abscondita est, sapientiae dulcedinem ad gustum elicere, speciemque ejus in lucem proferre, quis potens est? Quid ergo facimus nos? Tantum ipsis sermonibus persequamur eam, & si forte intentio differatur, pascat interim nos inquisitio illius: Si inventam non possumus, tamen quaesitam doceamus; To search the words of the wise, and their darke sayings, to bring forth to the taste that sweetnesse which lyeth within hidden, and to shew forth in the light the beautie of it, who is able? What therefore doe wee? Let us onely follow after it with our words, and if the finding of it be not obtained, let the seeking of it content us: and if wee cannot shew it found, let us shew it sought for. This therefore in this place, as it is some satisfaction to my selfe, so let it be my excuse to others. For that the meaning of this verse is not unworthy to be sought for, me seemes the Preacher tels us, both because he sayth, Behold, as presenting it to the view to be lookt upon; and because he sayth, I have found, as being a thing which himselfe esteemed of, and lastly,
because he addeth, sayth the Preacher, as putting his name more especially unto it. Our translation seemeth to import no more than the diligence of the Preacher in his carefull seeking, and in his exact reckoning; and so doth Lyra expound it, saying, Id est, Lyra in hunc vers. diligenter investigavi singulis applicando intellectum meum. Per talem modum loquendi dicitur de diligenti investigatore circa multa, talis inquisivit haec & illa, That is, I have searched diligently by applying mine understanding unto every thing. According to this manner of speaking, wee say of a diligent searcher about many things, such a one hath sought these and these things. And surely, it is true,Ambros. Prooem. in Luc. as Saint Ambrose speaketh, Aperit sibi diligentia januam veritatis, It is diligence that doth open to it selfe the gate of truth. And therefore Qui suscipiet certamina veritatis, He that will take upon himselfe to strive for the victory in the exercise of truth, must be anoynted with the oyle of diligence, Pastor ut salvum gregem habeat eum, frequenter numerat, Ambros. in Dom. Quadrages. A shepheard that he may not loose any of his flocke doth often number them, saith the same Father; and he that in seeking will not loose the truth, must diligently count one by one to finde out the account. Saint Hierome giveth this good morall exposition of the verse,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Hoc inquit reperi universa diligenter eventilans, quod paulatim peccando, & ad unum delictum aliud apponendo, grandem nobis summam efficimus, This saith he, have I found sifting all things diligently, that by going on in sinning by degrees, and by adding one sinne to another, we make unto our selves a great summe of sinnes, even so great that we can make no accompt unto God for them, we cannot answer him one for a thousand. Now as Saint Austin saith, Quid interest ad naufragium, Aug. Epist. 108. ad Seleucia. utrum uno grandi fluctu navis obruatur & operiatur, an paulatim subrepente aqua in sentinam, & per negligentiam derelicta at{que} contempta impleat navem at{que} submergat? What difference is there in respect of the shipwracke, whether the ship be covered and overwhelmed with one great wave, or whether the water sinking by little and little into the bottome of the ship, and being there left by negligence as a thing despised doe come to fill it and drowne it? Take heed therefore of many littles, they make a great deale at last.Tremel. in hunc vers. Tremellius who reads the verse thus, Vide, hoc inveni inquit Ecclesiastes semel at{que} iterum quaerendo assequi ratiocinium, See this have I found, saith the Preacher, by seeking once and againe to finde out the accompt; referreth the thing found to that which the Preacher saith of a naughty woman in the former verse: and of the accompt hee saith, Est ratiocinium improbitatis quae est in impura ista muliere, It is the accompt of the wickednesse which is in that impure woman. But the difficulty of the sense lying as I conceive in the Originall words 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which our translation rendreth counting one by one, but are directly translated, as Saint Hierome rendreth them, Vnam ad unam, One to one, or as Arias Montanus readeth them, Vnam ad
alteram,
• ne to another; it seemeth to mee that the verse may have this sense. This have I found, saith the Preacher, that to find the accompt of things by wisdome, one thing leadeth to another, and as the Philosopher speaketh, Ex notioribus pervenitur ad ignotiora, From things that are more knowne, things unknowne are discerned. Or else the meaning of the verse may be taken thus, This have I found, saith the Preacher, that to finde out the accompt of things in wisedome, and knowledge, contraries opposed one to one, and compared one with the other doe open well the way, and bring a man the better on toward it. Is it not so even in the knowledge of vertue and wickednesse, whereof the Preacher here speaketh? He that hath lived in wickednesse, and by Gods grace is called to an amendment of his life doth much the better know the basenesse and danger of the one, the comfort and happines of the other, and thereupon hateth the one more earnestly, and embraceth the other more eagerly.Gregorius in Euang. Homil. 34. Saint Gregory therefore saith, Qui nullis se oppressos peccatorum molibus sciunt, stant quidem in via justitiae, sed tamen ad coelestem patriam anxiè non anhelant, tanto{que} sibi in rebus licitis usum praebent, quanto se perpetrasse nulla illicita meminerunt. Et plaerum{que} pigri remanent ad exercenda bona pracipua, quia valde sibi securi sunt, quod nulla commiserint mala graviora. At contra nonnunquam hi qui se aliqua illicita egisse meminerunt, ex ipso illo dolore compuncti inardescunt in amorem Dei, sese{que} in magnis virtutibus exercent, & quia se errasse à Deo considerant, damna praecedentia lucris sequentibus recompensant, They who know themselves to be oppressed with no weight of sinnes, doe stand indeed in the way of righteousnesse, but they doe not strive so carefully towards their heavenly Countrey; and by so much doe give themselves the more liberty in lawfull things, by how much they know themselves to have committed no unlawfull things: and oftentimes are indeed dull and slow to the exercise of the chiefest good things, because they are very secure in themselves, that they have committed no grievous sinnes. On the other side, oftentimes, they who know themselves to have done unlawfull things, being stirred up from their owne griefe doe burne the more in the love of God, and doe exercise themselves in great vertues, and because they consider themselves to have wandred from GOD, they recompence the former losses with following gaines.

Verse 28. Which yet my soule seeketh, &c. The Preacher though he had found the way to find out the accompt of things, yet he had not found out the accompt. Or though he had sought diligently, counting one by one, yet he was still to seeke. There is a place in Wiltshire called Stonage, for diverse great stones lying and standing there together: of which stones it is said, that though a man number them one by one never so carefully, yet that hee cannot finde the true number of them, but that every time he numbers them,
he findeth a different number, from that he found before. And this may well shew the erring of mans labour in seeking the accompt of wisedome and knowledge. For though his diligence be never so great in making the reckoning, he will be alwayes our, and not be able to finde it out. One man among a thousand have I found: the Preacher in seeking to finde wisedome, sheweth what helpe he found, it was but one of a thousand among the many thousands that were under him, among the thousands that attended upon him, it was but one of a thousand that he found faithfull in true wisedome to him. The rest either feared to displease him, or desired to humour him, or regarded not either what hee sought, or what hee found in it. Or else the man which the Preacher speaketh of is to bee taken generally for a good man, and hee it is who is, dignus viri nomine, Hierom. worthy the name of a man, he it is who being one of a thousand is worthy to be chiefe of the thousand. But though Solomon found but one, yet it may be that God found more: for when Eliah said, I, even I onely am left; God told him,1 King. 19.10. & 18. I have left seven thousand in Israel which have not bowed the knees unto Baal. Howsoever this is certaine, that the number of the good in respect of the bad, is very little, even as one to a thousand. When the Syrians came up against Israel in the time of Ahab, it is said,1 King. 20.27. that the children of Israel pitched before them like two little flocks of kids, but the Syrians filled the Country, and so indeed are the good, they are but like two little flockes of kids, but the wicked fill the world. The godly are but like the three hundred men of Gideon,
Iudg. 7. the wicked are as the Midianites, and are upon the earth like Grashoppers for multitude. But a woman among them all have I not found: among them hee had found none to helpe him in the finding of wisedome, Omnes enim me ad luxuriam & non ad virtutem deduxerunt, For all of them did draw me to wantonnesse and not to vertues, as Saint Hierome maketh him to expound his words. Or else more generally his meaning may bee taken thus, that having found out a very bad woman, he looked to finde a good woman also, but he could not finde any. Not that he did not simply finde any good, but that hee found not any so good as shee was bad. Or else he sayth, that he found none, because sayth Lyra, in respect of men, they were few:Lyra in hunc versum. or else in respect of themselves, they are sayd to be none, because they were so very few. For as the Philosopher speaketh,Aristot. 2. Physicorum. Illud quod modicum est, quasi nihil computatur, That which is little is esteemed as nothing. Indeed a woman is in herselfe the weaker vessel, and too often a strong instrument of the devill to entice men unto wickednesse. Wherefore Saint Chrysostome noteth,Chrysostom. Homil. 38. in Epistol. ad Corinth. that when the devill spoyled 〈◊〉 of his substance, and children, and health, yet he left his wife un • o him, Quia putavit multum eam sibi conferre ad Sanctum expugnandum, because he thought that shee would be a great furtherance unto him to conquer that Saint of God. The same Father is
elsewhere bitter in speaking of women,Chrysostom. Homil. 6. ex imperf. in Matth. as saying, Quid est aliud mulier, nisi ineffugabilis poena, necessarium malum, naturalis tentatio, desederabilis calamitas, domesticum periculum, delectabile detrimentum, boni colore dilecta? What is woman, but a punishment that cannot be driven away, a necessary evill, a naturall temptation, a desireable calamitie, a domesticke danger, one beloved for a colour of good? But he tels us also,Chrysostom. Homil. 15. ex variis in Matth. Sermo est de muliere mala, non de bona. Novi enim multas ad omne opus bonum promptas, My speech is of a bad woman, not of a good. For I have knowne many ready to every good worke. Wherefore he also tels us, that though Iezabel was so bad, that shee would have taken away the life of Eliah, when he had restored life to her and all Israel, by taking away the famine, yet that the poore widow of Zarephah was so good, as that shee was readie to give him food, when shee had no more left to feed her selfe and her childe. The Scripture is full of the examples of good women; and Saint Hierome having reckoned up diverse of them, writing to a Virgin,Hieronym. Epist. ad Principiam virg. he concludeth, Haec breviter perstrinxi, ut nec te poeniteat sexus, nec viros nomen suum erigeret, in quorum condemnationem foeminarum in Scripturis sanctis vita laudatur, These have I briefly passed over, that neither thou mightest repent of thy sex, neither might men be lifted up in regard of their sex, to whose condemnation the life of women is praised in the sacred Scriptures. Let it cause modestie in women, that shee was the first sinner, and who having cast man downe in Paradise, did cast him out of Paradise. Let her weaknesse make her the more carefull in looking to her selfe,Basilius de vera virgin. ad Letorum Episcopum. and the better to keepe her selfe from danger. Longissime arcere illecebras mali, & aurem quidem intus castissima cogitatione, oculos verò cautissima aversione munire, To drive away farre the allurements of evill, and to fence her eares with most chaste thoughts within, her eyes by a most wary turning away from it, as Saint Basil adviseth. But in a tropologicall application of this verse; as the Italian sayth, that words are women, and deeds are men; and therefore that they must be maryed together:Hieronym. in hunc vers. So Saint Hierome tels us, Possumus & cogitatus pro viris accipere, mulieres pro operibus, & dicere quod difficile cogitatio alicujus pura inveniri possit: opera vero quia per corpus exercentur, aliquo semper errore commixta sunt, Wee may here take our thoughts for men, women for our workes, and say that hardly can the thought of any one be found pure: as for our workes, because they are performed by the body, they are alwayes mixed with some errour.

Verse 29. The Preacher having spoken much of the vanitie that is in men and women, and of the badnesse of them, least hereupon any blame might seeme to accrew to God, who was the maker of them, here he wholy cleareth God. Loe this onely have I found: The Originall word here translated onely, and so generally by Interpreters
is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and most directly signifieth Seorsim, apart. So that it, seemeth to mee, that the Preachers meaning may be, that he severing in the consideration of man, the workes of God, and the works of man, he found the workes of God to be right all, and that it was man himselfe, who had made himselfe and his works to be perverse and crooked. And surely, who so ever will rightly judge of man and his wayes, he must consider them apart, as they proceed from God, and apart, as they proceed from himselfe, that so in all things God may be justified, and man himselfe may beare his owne condemnation. Or else to consider the words, as generally they are read. Loe this onely have I found: that is, this as a most manifest, most sure and undeniable truth. That God hath made man upright: Let a right line be extended never so farre, let it be extended infinitely, it will be right still; now God is rightnesse it selfe, and he being extended into his workes, they are right all. But of man who is the chiefest of his inferiour creatures, it is sayd, that God made him in his image, and after his likenesse. Now as Saint Bernard speaketh, Oportet id quod ad imaginem est, cum imagine convenire, It is necessary that he who hath an image, should agree with his image. And therefore it being sayd of God, Great is our Lord, and great is his power; Psal. 147.5. Psal. 92.15. Bern. Sup. Can. Serm. 80.
the Lord is upright, and there is no unrighteousnesse in him: Saint Bernard also addeth, Ab isto recto & magno Deo, habet imago ejus ut ipsa recta & magna sit; Eo magna est quo capax aeternorum, eo recta quo appetens supernorum, From that upright and great God, his image also hath it to be upright and great; great, in that it is capable of eternall things, right, in that it desireth heavenly things, and things that are above. Aquinas speaking of these words, that God made man upright,
Aquin. 1. Q. 95. Ar. 1. sayth, Erat rectitudo secundum hoc quod ratio subdebatur Deo, rationi vero inferiores vires, & animae corpus. Prima autem subjectio erat causa & secundae, et tertiae. Quamdiu enim ratio manebat Deo subjecta, inferiora ei subdebantur, The uprightnesse was in this respect, that reason was subjected unto God, the inferiour powers unto reason, and the body to the soule. The first subjection was the cause of the second and of the third. For so long as reason remained subjected unto God, the inferiour faculties were subject unto it. It is a question proposed by Aquinas, and it is generally handled by the Schoolmen, Vtrum primus homo fuerit creatus in gratia, Whether the first man was created in grace, that is, whether in the act of creation there was given unto him onely a rightnesse of nature, or else a rightnesse of grace also. That a rightnesse of grace was given to Adam before his fall, is a thing agreed upon, because by his fall he was deprived of it, but whether at the instant of the first creation it were given to man, that is their question. But if it were given to man afterwards before his fall, why not at first? And indeed what need of such questions? The reading of the latter part of this verse according to the Septuagint
and the Vulgar Latin, Et ipse se infinitis miscuit quaestionibus, and he intangled himselfe with numberlesse questions, should teach them to avoyde such fruitlesse speculations. From this distinction of man, in puris naturalibus, in his pure naturall condition, and in the state of grace, some of the Schoolmen have looked too farre after Pelagius. Let it suffice, as the Preacher sayth, that God made man upright; and Aquinas thinketh that this is sufficient to proove, that man even in the first instant of creation, was made in the state of grace. But the Originall word which the Preacher here useth in the end of the verse being the same which he hath used before in the five and twentieth, and seven and twentieth verses 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying computationes & ratiocinia, reckonings and accompts: let mee consider here God as a true and just accomptant, and making all things straight and right. When he made man he brought all things to a true accompt, he did cast up his body to a right temper, he did cast up his senses to a right obedience to reason, he did cast up his will to a right desire, he did cast up his minde to a right understanding; the generall summe of all, he rightly made to be the true happinesse of man. There was not the least errour in all his accompt. But they, that is, men have sought out many reckonings: which first must needs be wrong, because many, seeing the right in all things can be but one. And secondly, they are wrong because men have sought them out, who going out of the way in wrong paths, can there never finde the right way. They cast up many reckonings, and many are the things which every one according to his humour and phansie maketh reckoning of. In the body they reckon upon nothing but sensualitie, in the senses upon nothing but voluptuousnesse, in the will upon nothing but pleasing it selfe, in the understanding upon nothing but vanitie and folly. The generall summes, to which they reduce all their reckonings are three, either pleasure, or profit, or honour. And whereas the Psalmist sayth,Psal. 20.7. Augustin. in Psal. 19.
Some trust in horses, and some in Chariots, that is, sayth Saint Austin, Hi volubili successione temporalium bonorum, & hi superis praeferuntur honoribus, & in his exultant, Some are drawne with the voluble successe of worldly benefits, others are set above their fellowes in height of honours, and in them doe prance and rejoyce. But howsoever, men may now make their accompts, they shall in the end see the falshood of them, when they shall finde the fruit of them, no way to answer to the cost and paines and time, which they have layd out upon them. But to consider the words also as wee doe reade them. But they have sought out many inventions: mee seemes that men herein are like unto some busy heads and working minds, which being left in a good estate, and having well to live, by their inventions and devises are not quiet untill they have brought all to nothing, and cannot at last devise how to helpe themselves. For so man being by God made in a good estate, it was
the devils invention, to set him on worke to finde out good and evill, and ever since his minde being set upon inventions, the seeking of them bringeth him to misery. Wherefore Saint Bernard Bernard. readeth the latter part of this verse thus, Ipse autem se implicuit doloribus multis, but he hath involved himselfe into many troubles. Or else wee may take the inventions of men to be fictions, like the invention of Poets: for indeed, whatsoever men conceive of them, they are no better than imaginary fictions, having no realitie of truth and substance in them. And therefore Philo sayth well, Is qui fictus est homo, Philo. l. 1. Legis Allegoriarum. differt ab eo quem Deus fecit, That man which is fayned differeth from him which God made. Man is made of himselfe a fayned man, consisting in the fayned inventions of his owne wayes, but as he was made by God, he was made in the truth of uprightnesse.

epigraph.q: VER. 1. Who is as the wise man? And who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? A mans wisdome maketh his face to shine, and the boldnesse of his face shall bee changed.

div.p:
Verse 1. PHilo speaking of wisdome saith, Quis bonum istud indagans inveniat? Quae maria tranans? Quas penetrans insulas? Quas terrarum oras adiens? Quasnam apud gentes? Philo de nomini mutatione. Who by searching can find out that good? What seas must hee passe over? What Islands must he passe into? To what shoares must he go? With what nations is shee to be found? And this the Preacher having shewed in the latter part of the former Chapter, by setting forth the difficulty of attaining wisdome, the rarity of a wise man, hee beginneth this Chapter with the excellency of him, saying, Who is as the wise man? Who, though never so rich in estate, who though never so great in power, who though never so high in honor? Nay who is rich in estate, who is great in power, who is high in honor but a wise man onely? Philo therefore speaking of wise men saith, Qui soli veri reges, who alone are the true Kings. And in another place speaking of them hee saith,Philo de Agricul. Sunt aliqui quos Deus altius promovet, & evolantes suprà omnes species omniaque genera propè seipsum collocat sicut Mosi quoque dicit, tu verò hic sta mecum, There are some whom God promoteth highly, and these flying above all degrees and ranks, hee placeth nere unto himselfe,Exod. 34.5. Philo de Sacrific. Abelis & Caini. saying unto them as hee said to Moses, but doe thou stand here by mee. Wherefore hee noteth that when Moses was to dye, he did not dye as commonly others doe, but only left this world at the command of his word, by whose word the world was made,Phili de nomini mutatione. Ʋt discas quod sapientem illum eodem quo mundum honore Deus dignatus est, That thou mayest learne, that God did grace that wise man with the same honour that hee did the world. The same authour therefore gives this honour to a wise man, saying, Sapiens Dei comes est, A wise man is the companion of God. But to consider the manner of the Preachers words; they being set downe as a question do shew as it were, that he could onely admire
him, and could not judge of him; and is as if hee said, as Philo speaketh, De sapientia, quae non me tantum sed toto mundo est antiquior, non est fas quenquam judicare nisi Deum aut aliquem sincerum purum germanumque amatorem ipsius sapientiae, Philo de Charitate. To judge of wisdome, which is more old not onely then my selfe, but the whole world, it is not lawfull for any except God himselfe to judge, or else some sincere pure and very true lover of wisdome it selfe. S. Hierome tels us, that the Septuagint did read these words thus, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Quis novit sapientes? who hath knowen wise men? whereupon hee addeth, Et reverâ quum multi sint qui sapientiam repromittant, difficile invenitur, qui discernere queat sapientem, ab his qui videntur esse sapientes. Et quum sint plurimi qui scripturarum occulta dicuntur posse solvere, rarus qui veram inveniat solutionem. Hieronym. in hunc vers. And indeed seeing there are many, who doe promise wisdome, he is hardly found, who is able to discerne a true wise man from them who seeme to bee wise. And whereas there are many who are said to be able to resolve the hidden things of the Scriptures, hee is a rare man that findeth a true resolution. And who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? The French readeth it, Et qui scait que veulent dire les choses? And who knoweth what the things would say? For there is a speaking by things as well as by words, and it is by them as well as by his word that God speaketh to us, yea the things themselves, doe speak in their silent language; which he that is wise understandeth, and is able to give the interpretation of it. Wherefore when the Preacher saith; and who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? hee meaneth, who but a wise man, of whom the words before speake. The Septuagint and S. Hierome do read it, Quis novit solutionem verbi? Who knoweth the solution of a word, the answeare of a quaestion? And then it may bee noted, as S. Hierome hath it,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Quod oblique de se loquitur, quia nemo fuerit ita sapiens, & nullus sic fecerit problematum solutiones, That the Preacher indirectly speaketh of himselfe, because none was so wise as hee was, none did answeare and resolve problemes and hard quaestions as he did. Amans wisdome maketh his face to shine. That is, saith Tremellius ipsum gloriosum & illustrem reddit, Synecdochicè, doth make him glorious and famous, the face being taken Synecdochi cally for the whole man. But to consider the words as wee find them,Tremellius in hunc vers. in the face the wisdome of man is not a little discerned, and well may it bee said to make the face to shine; seeing as Philo speaketh Habent sapientes, Philo quod dater. potiori insidietur, purificatum visum, examinatum auditum, & sic caeteros sensus. Habent sermonem quoque immaculatum; Wisemen have their seing purified, there hearing cleansed, and so their other senses. They have also a spotlesse speach. And here also S. Hierome tels us that the Preacher doth obliquely speake of him selfe, whose wisdome, Non solum intrinsecus latebat, sed & in superficie corporis & speculo vultus elucebat, ultraque omnes homines prudentiam mentis in facie suâ pinxerat, Hieronym. in hunc versum. Not only did lye hid within, but shined also in the outside of his body, and in the glasse of his countenance, and above all men he had the wisdome of his mynd painted in his very face. Or, if it shall bee
thought good, wisdome may bee sayd to make a wise mans face to shine, because his very countenance though hee say nothing giveth light, and directeth men in a right way. Or else wisdome may bee said to make the face to shine, because from the face, and from the mouth placed in it, it casteth forth a light, which maketh the understanding of things to appeare. And the boldnesse of his face shall bee changed: interpreters here are troubled. The Originall word here used and translated boldnesse is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which properly signifyeth strength. S. Hierome reades it, Fortis faciem suam mutabit. The strong shall change his face. The vulgar Latin also Potentissimus faciem suam mutabit, Lyra in hunc vers. The most mighty shall change his face, and then Lyra expoundeth it, In resurrectione quando sibi dabit gloriosam faciem, In the resurrection, when God shall give unto him a glorious face shining as the Sunne in heaven. The French readeth it, Son regard farouche, His rough and wild aspect; the Septuagint as our English did take it for boldnesse, but then they read it as S. Hierome tels us, Et impudens vultu suo odietur, And an impudent man shall be hated by his countenance, as if the Preacher did shew the difference betweene the countenance of a wise man, and of an impudent man, declaring how pleasing the one was, how hatefull the other. And indeed as the countenance of a wise man is never impudent, so the countenance of an impudent man is hatefull to all that are wise. Or else to take boldnesse in a good sense, there is nothing that doth beter set the assure, and make confident the countenance of a man then wisdome doth. That giveth such boldnesse unto it, that oftentimes the very countenance of a wise man striketh terror into the wicked and foolish. But let mee have leave to give the words another meaning, and to referre the face here mentioned not to the face of a wise man, but to the face of the thing, whose interpretation a wise man findeth out. His wisdome therefore maketh the face of the thing to shine, and to shew it selfe. For as Philo speaketh Lumen animae solari similimum est scientia, Philo de congress. quaerend. erudition. gratia Knowledge the light of the mind is most like unto the solar light; and as that maketh things to appeare to the eye what they are, so doth the other make things appeare to the mind, and sheweth the interpretation of them. As the one taketh away the darke visage of things, so the other taketh away, and changeth the hard visage of questions and problemes, and prevailing over the strengh of them, maketh the meaning of things easie to be seen.

q.p: Ver. 2. I counsell thee to keepe the Kings commandement, and that in regard of the oath of God.
Ver. 3. Bee not hasty to go out of his sight, stand not in an evill thing, for hee doth whatsoever pleaseth him.
Ver. 4. Where the word of a King is, there is power, and who may say unto him, what dost thou?
Ver. 5. Who so keepeth the commandement, shall feele no evill thing and a wisemans hart discerneth, both tyme and judgment.

div.p:
Ver. 2. I counsell thee: the Originall sayth no more then I; and he that shall find out the meaning of the place need to bee such a one as the former verse speaketh off, and that knowes solutionem verbi, the resolution of a probleme, the interpretation of a thing. Let my boldnesse bee excused, and I will shew my thoughts. It seemeth to mee, that I standeth here, as it were an answere to the quaestions of the former verse, wherein the Preacher speaketh as it were softly and with a still voice, as if hee would not bee heard, saying no more then I. And hee speakes also in a darke obscure manner, as if his modestie did cast a veile over it. Neither doth hee speake it, untill that first asking the quaestions, the answere of all men did in there harts prevent him, and say that it was hee. Our translation to make up the sense followeth Pagnine, and as hee saith, Ego moneo te, I admonish thee; so that saith, I counsell thee: I who have obtained wisdome and am able to counsell thee, I counsell thee, I who require obedience from myne owne subjects, do counsell all subjects to give obedience to their Kings, I who am unwilling to punish thee for not keeping the Kings commandement, do counsell thee to keepe it. To keepe the Kings commandement: The Hebrew is, to observe the mouth of the King, which is but one and the same. For as Philo speaketh; Regis officium est jubere quae oportet fieri, & vetare a quibus abstinere decet: caeterum jussio faciendorum, & interdictio cavendorum propriè ad legem pertinet. Atque ita consequitur, ut Rex animata lex sit, lex vero sit rex justissimus. Philo de vita Moysis. The office of a King is to command those things which ought to bee done, and to forbid those things which ought to be avoyded. But the command of things to be done, and the forbidding of things not to bee done properly belongeth to the law. And so it foloweth, that a King is a living law, & the law is a most just King. Now keepe the Kings commandement, as thou wouldest the commandement of thy Father. For as Philo also speaketh Parentis locum obtinet ac vicissim, tanquam à germanis filiis reverentiam postulat. Sunt autē principes (ut verum fatear) publici parentes civitatum & gentium, quotquot boni sunt, nec cedunt pietati naturalium. For hee holdeth the place of a Father, and in a mutuall respect requireth reverence as from naturall children. For
Princes, (that I may confesse the truth) are the publike Fathers of Citties and people, as many as are good,Philo de creatione Principis. neither do they yeild in affection to naturall Fathers. And that in regard of the oath of God. Tremellins reades it, sed pro ratione juramenti Dei, but with regard unto the oath of God, as if the meaning were that the King is so to bee obeyed, as that God is not to bee disobeyed, and that the oath made to the King were so to be kept, as that the oath made to God bee not broken. For there is nothing more sure, then that God is rather to bee obeyed then man. But to consider our reading, by the oath of God, may bee understood the word of God: for as Philo speaketh, Ipsa Dei verba sunt juramenta, Philo l. 2. Legis Allegoriarum. legesque divinae & jura sacratissima; The very words of God are oaths and divine lawes, and most sacred statutes. And then the meaning would bee no other then this; that we are to keepe the commandements of the King, because God doth command it, and that wee are to do it not only for feare of wrath but also for conscience sake. Roma. 13.1. & 5 But the oath of God here more directly is the oath which is taken in the name of God, and whereof God is made to bee a witnesse. For so an oath properly taken is by Philo defined to bee that,Philo de Planta. Noe. Quod est fidei signum firmissimum conjunctum cum Dei testimonio, which is the most firme signe of faithfulnesse joyned with the testimony of God. As for the beginning of an oath S. Chrysostome seemeth to conceive that untill after the dayes of Abraham, there was not any used. For saith hee, Qui fuerunt tempore Abrahae multa faedera fecerunt, victimasque mactarunt, & obtulerunt sacrificia, Chrys. Homil. 26. ad populum. necdum erat juramentum, They who were in Abrahams tyme made many covenants, killed many sacrifices, sacrificed many offerings, and as yet there was not an oath. Indeed the first oath that wee read of was that betweene Abraham and Abimelech at Beersheba,
Genes. 22.31. from whence the place had its name. But as for the oath of subjects taken to their King, and which wee call the oath of alleagance, as far as I know, this is the first place that any mention is made of it. Among the heathens,Plin. in Panegy. ad Trajan. I find in Pliny that it was a thing done in Trajans time, who did sware unto his people, and had his people sworne unto him.Cassiod. var. l. 8. ver. 3. And in Cassiodore I find that Athalicus King of Italy did likewise take an oath unto his people and tooke an oath from them. But that which here is to be noted is the regard of an oath, and which is called the oath of God as due to him to bee performed, as well as unto him to whom it is made. According as our Saviour Christ saith Performe thyne oath unto the Lord.
Matth. 5.33. It is storyed of Alexander the great that being resolved to destroy Lampsacum, as hee was going about it, Anaximenes the Philosopher and his Master came to meete him, and to intreat him for the Citty, which being forseen by Alexander hee swore that hee would not doe, that which Anaximenes should aske him. Whereupon Anaximenes told him, that which I desire is that thou wouldest destroy Lampsacum. Now Alexander being so taken by his word, for the reverence of his oath did not destroy the place. Most Noble, it was in this King to keepe his oath, and most necessary it is to keepe thy oath that is made to the King. For
as Philo speaketh: Est jus-jurandum non exiguum negotium, tametsi contemnitur propter consuetudinem, Ph • lo de Decal. videlicet testimonium Dei de rebus dubiis Deum autem citare testem mendaci
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . An oath is not a light buisinesse, although it bee despised because men are accustomed here unto: namely being the testimony of God concerning doubtfull things. Now to cite God as a witnesse of a lye, is a foule wickednesse; would any one come unto his friend and say, I pray you do a wickednesse for mee, for my sake doe something that is against right and reason? would not his friend abhorre him that should doe it? would hee not suddenly breake off all friendship with him? Et quod non audes ab amico petere, ad id Deum vocas? And that which thou darest not to aske of a friend, dost thou call God unto it saith Philo? Dost thou say to him give false witnesse for me, be a partner with mee in my villany and treachery, Et quum sis Deus optimus servias scelesto homini, & when thou art God the perfection of goodnesse serve the turne of a wicked man. What can this be but horrible iniquity? The same authour therefore giving direction for an oath, saith, Juraturus debet omnes rei circumstantias diligenter perspicere, quanta sit, quam vera, quam benè à se percepta, tum seipsum considerare, num purus sit animâ, corpore, linguâ: nefas est enim per os quo profertur nomen illud sanctissimum, quicquam turpe progredi: quaeratur etiam tam loci quam temporis opportunitas. Hee that is to sweare ought diligently to looke into all the circumstances of the thing, how great it is, how true, how well perceaved by himselfe, then hee ought to consider himselfe, whether he be pure in mind, in body, in toung. For it is not well that any naughty thing should proceed from that mouth by which that most holy name is uttered: let also a fit opportunity of time and place bee sought for.

Ver. 3. The water here is not so cleare, that it is easy for the sight to peice into it. Be not hasty to go out of his sight. The Hebrew is, Nesis festinus, à facie ejus abibis, Bee not hasty, thou shalt goe away from his face. According to which reading let me propose what hath come into my mind. First then as I conceive the sense may bee taken thus. Bee not hasty, not hasty to come into the presence of the King, that may bee the way to have thy selfe put away quickly from it. 1 Sam. 18.1. Gregor. Thaumat. Oratione in Origen. Gregorius Thaumathurgus observeth, that it is not said that the soule of David was knit to the soule of Jonathan, but that the soule of Jonathan was knit to the soule of David. And surely it is better when the favour of a Prince doth call any one into his presence, then when the ambitious desire of any one doth hastely thrust himselfe into it. Stand not in an evill thing, if thou dost not goe away from the sight of the King, but standest before him, stand not in an evill way, that will at lengh be thy fall, when the sight of the King hath found it out. For hee doth whatsoever pleaseth him: the Originall saith onely whatsoever pleaseth, and seeing I conceive it to bee spoken of a good King, I understand the sense, as if it were supplyed with whatsoever pleaseth God. And therefore when a good King findeth thy wayes to displease God, they will displease him also, and thou shalt
not stand in his sight. Or secondly, the meaning of the verse may bee conceived thus. Bee not hasty in the sight of the King, neither in thy words or actions, for so thou mayest hasten thy selfe to bee gone out of his sight. But if thou hast beene hasty and run into some errour, do not stand nor persist in it. For as S. Bernard speaketh, Alioquin non erit humanum peccatum, sed obstinatio diabolica. Nam perseverare in malo diabolicum est, & digni sunt perire cum illo, quicunque in similitudinem ejus permanent in peccato, Otherwise it will not bee a humane sinne,Bernard. de Advent. Dom. Serm. 1. but a divelish obstinacy, and worthy are they to perish with him, who in a likenesse to him persist in any sin. For he doth whatsoever pleaseth him: It shall not bee as thou wilt, neither mayest thou doe, whatsoever thou pleasest, but it is he that is King, it is his pleasure that is done in all things. But to consider the reading of our translation. Be not hasty to goe out of his sight, if thou hast offended him, bee not hasty to bee gone from him, doe not presently forsake his service and attendance: such hast, may increase his displeasure against thee. But if thou dost stay, stand not in an evill thing, stand not to justify thy self if he will have it evill, thou must not think to make it good, For he doth whatsoever pleaseth him: whatsoever it bee which thou hast done, whether good or evil. He bestoweth his favours as his owne mind is, whatsoever thou pleadest for thy self. Or els bee not hasty to goe out of his sight, that is saith Tremellius, Ne ab obsequio illius te subducito animo perturbato, Tremel. in hunc vers. Do not withdrawe thy self from thine allegance to him in a discontented mind. Stand not in evil: that is perturbatione & rebellione quae tibi malum allatura est; In discontent and rebellion, which will bring evill to thee. For he doth whatsoever pleaseth him: God doth enable him to have his will upon such treacherous subjects in the destruction of them: when Zedekiah had rebelled against Nebuchadnezzar and broken his oath, the Babylonian Monarch comming with his army and burning Jerusalem, S. Chrisostome saith of it,Chrysostome Homil. 19. ad Populum. ubique ignis grassabatur barbaricus juramento ignem ducente, & flammam passim circum agente. The barbarian fire everywhere spoiled, the violated oath leading the fire; and carrying the flame about from place to place. And surely the fire of Gods wrath doth still pursue rebellion, wheresoever it be. It behooveth an honest heart so to reverence a crown, as not to dare to touch it in any undutifull respect.Damian. Ep. 12. The Amalekite who comming unto David told him that being desired by Saul he stood upon him and slew him, because he was sure that he could not live, and that he took the crowne that was upon his head, no sooner had ended his speach, then David commanded him to bee slaine, and ended his life also. But what was his offence? was it because he yeilded to the Kings request, and killed him who was already killed and could not live a very litle longer? Or was it because he took away the crowne? Damianus speaketh unto this purpose, saying Amalecites ille, qui gloriatur seperemisse Saulum, dum non se galeam, 2 Samuel. 7. sed diadema bellantis abstulisse confingit, gladio Davidis percussus occubuit, that Amalekite who gloried to have slaine Saul while he maketh a tale, that he
tooke from the head of the warriour not his helmet but his crowne, fell downe slaine by the sword of David. As if there could bee no excuse, no pretence, why any one should unpunished offer violence to the crowne, or do wrong to the dignity of a King. Lippomannus well observeth, although Moyses and Aaron had a commandement from God to deliver and free the Israelites from the tyranny of Phaaroh, and that although Phaaroh were of all Kings the most wicked, and condemned by the Lord in expresse words,Lyppomannus in Exodum. yet they did not arme the Israelites against the King the lawfull magistrate over Aegypt, they did not kill the tyrant with the sword sed continent sese, & obsecrant Phaaronem obedienter, but they conteine themselves and beeseech the King obediently. S. Hierome applying this verse unto the King of heaven and earth, from whose commandements wee must not hastely depart, and in the breach of whose law wee must not persist, expoundeth the last part of the verse thus,Hieronim. in hunc vers. Quod si perseveraveris, rex vitiorum & peccati diabolus operabitur perditionem in te, & faciet quodcunque voluerit, If thou shalt persevere, the King of vices and sin the Devill, will work perdition in thee, and he will do whatsoever he pleaseth. Lyra who expoundeth also this verse of the heavenly King, saith, Bee not hasty to go from his sight, transgrediendo praecepta affirmativa, by breaking his affirmative commandements: stand not in an evill thing, transgrediendo negativa, by transgressing his negative praecepts. For he doth whatsoever pleaseth him: that is, saith he Quia tantae authoritatis & potestatis est, Lyra in hunc vers. quod non potest ei resisti, because he is of so great power and authority that he cannot be resisted.

Vers. 4. Where the word of a King is, there is power: the Venetian translation expressing the sense, some what more forcebly reads it thus, Est in verbo regis potentia quaedam, There is in the word of a King a kind of power. Indeed it is most true of God, voluntas opus efficit, & praebet sermo virtutem, His will effecteth his work, and his word giveth power; and God having Kings his deputies, in some sort hath communicated the same unto them. The saying is, that the requests of Princes are commands, and one noting it upon that passage of our Saviour, when entring into Symons ship he prayed him to thrust a little from the land there tels us, Lu. 5.3. Quaelibet Jesu verba ex majestate personae in praecepta transibant, All the words of Jesus from the majestie of his person were made to bee commands. And surely it is from the majestie which God hath given Kings, that all their words haue so much power. Of David it is said when he was but elected to bee King,1 Sam. 14.7. Confregit David viros suos verbis David did break his men with his words, as Cajetane and Pagnine do translate the place: and therfore how powerfull are the words of those who hold the scepter, and sit upon the throne? The people of Israel acknowledging and promising their obedience to Joshua, do it in these words, Iosh. 1.18. as the Originall hath it, Qui rebella verit ori tuo moriatur, He that shall rebell against thy mouth, let him bee put to death, as if (saith one upon it) Tanta esset authoritas hominis, ut vel labiorum ejus motus habeatur ut praeceptum, cui contradici non potest sine supplicii metu, As if the
authority of the man were so great, that even the very motion of his lips should bee had for a command which might not bee opposed, without feare of punishment. But how carefull therefore ought Princes to bee of their words, and that by them they do not give power to any thing to which God doth not give his approbation. Let there words command that which Gods word commandeth, and then it is a happy power, which from God is given them. Yea therein to make their words most powerfull, let them adde their owne example also: For as Cassiodore speaketh, Non potest authoritatem habere sermo, qui non juvatur exemplo, Cassiod. Var. l. 11. Var. 8.
dum iniquum sit bona jubere & non eadem facere, Speaking cannot have so much authority, which is not strengthned by example: seeing it is a sinfull thing, to command good things, and not to do the same. And who may say unto him, what dost thou? The same it is which Elihu saith in Job, Is it fit to say to a King, thou art wicked,
Job. 34.18. and to Princes yee are ungodly? King Theodoric in Cassiodore speaking of himself, and in himself shewing the right of Kings saith, Hac sola ratione discreti, Cassiod. Var. l. 6. Var. 4.
quod alteri subdi non possumus, qui judices non habemus, In this respect are wee distinguished from others, that wee cannot bee subject to another, who have no judges over us. Kings have no judge upon earth over them, they have there owne judg God alone in heaven. Wherefore Eucherius saith, Quia rectores habent judicem suum, magna cautela subditorum est non temerè vitam judicare regentium, Because Governours have their owne Judg, it must bee the great care of subjects not to judg rashly the lifes of them that do govern them. Ne{que} enim frustra per semetipsum aes nummulariorum effudit, & cathedras vendentium columbas evertit; nimirum significans, quia per magistros quidem vita judicatur plebum, sed per semetipsum examinat facta magistrorum, Eucher. lib. 1. in lib. pag. For it was not without cause that the Lord by himselfe did cast out the mony of the mony changers and overthrew the tables of them that sold doves, namely signifying thereby, that by the governours is judged the life of the people, but by himself he examineth the doings of the governours. And indeed it was the fault of the Priests, of the governours of the Temple, which by this action our Saviour Christ reprooved, and condemned. S. Chrysostome gathereth the same from the Ark of God, which beeing shaken by the oxen that drew it, & Ʋzzah putting forth his hand to hold it, he was there smitten for his rashnesse, and dyed by the Arke of God, whereupon he noteth, videre licet quomodo subditum procul a sacerdotum correptione abesse oportet. Nam quum aliquando arca reduceretur, 2 Samuel 6.7. & subditorum aliqui ad lapsum inclinantem videntes erigerent, eo ipso loco paenam dederunt, It may bee considered how far it beehoveth a subject to bee from the reproofe of his superiours, For when sometime the Arke was brought back,Chrysostomus Homil. in locum ex. cap. 16. ad Rom. de colendi • sacerdot. and some of the subjects seeing it inclining as likely to fall did but set it up, they were punished in the same place. There is no doubt but that as the Ark was shaken & likely to fal, so Kings & governours are not only likely to fall, but do fall often. Notwithstanding it is not for them that are under them, to say unto them, what do yee? For as S. Chrysostome also
noteth Insurrexerunt adversus Aaron post vituli formatam effigiem, Core, Dathan, & Abiron, quid ergo? nonne illi periere? It was after that Aaron had sinned foolishly and hainously in making the calf, that Corah, Dathan and Abiron rebelled against him,Chrysost. Homil. 2. in Epist. 2. ad Timot. but what then, did not they perish? yes, they did, and that was to shew, that although the governour might bee wicked, it was not for them who were under him, to take upon them to correct him. Philo Philo. saith, Nihil molestius quam majores ab inferioribus & magistratus a subditis accusari, There is nothing more grievous then for superiours to bee accused by their inferiours and magistrats by them that are under them. God therfore is pleased to ease them of this grievance, and to forbid subjects to doe it. But let this therefore make Princes and governours to bee the more carefull of doing well, least God reproove them the more sharply, because hee will not suffer men to bee their reproovers. Let them heare God both in his word, and in their owne consciences saying unto them, what dost thou? Ambros. 2 Apolog. David c. 3. although they doe not heare it from their subjects. The ill cariage of them that have command doth too much herein shame themselves, and incense the wrath of God against them. And therefore S. Ambrose saith, Quem mihi in hujusmodi reperias virum, qui in potestate constitutus id quod per justitiam non licet, per potestatem non licere agnoscat? Ambros. 2. Apolog. David c. 3. What man canst thou find out among such, who being placed in authority, doth account that to bee unlawfull for him to doe by his power, which is unlawfull for him to doe by justice? And therefore how great cause have they to praise God, whose graciousnesse is pleased to set such over them, as doe set him in all their wayes before them? How great cause have they in all respects to honour them, who ruling them in goodnesse doe rule themselves by goodnesse? Long may such live and rule with glory and renowne.

Ver. 5. The Preacher having shewed that the pleasure of a King in his displeasure is not to be resisted, & that the faults of a King by his subjects are not to bee corrected, here in this verse gathering his discourse, as his manner is to a head and conclusion, he giveth comfort for the one, and direction for the other. His comfort is in these words, who so keepeth the commandement shall feele no evill: his direction in the other words. Who so keepeth the commandement, that is, is carefull to do that which he ought, for that is the commandement which serveth for all men, of what rank or quality soever, that is the commandement which respecteth all estates and conditions, that is the commandement which is to bee observed in all seasons and occasions, who so therefore keepeth the commandement and doth that which he ought, shall feele no evill thing. Perhaps he may not keepe the favour of the King, but if he keepe the favour of God, he hath lost nothing. The Hebrewes shall know no evil thing, and surely howsoever he may know what is the displeasure of a Prince, yet knowing the good pleasure of God to bee towards him, he need not to bee too much grieved for it. The Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
here used doth signifie a carefull knowledge, as when it is said the Lord knoweth the way of the righteous, that is, is carefull to keepe and preserve them in it, and certanily he that knoweth this, Psal. 1.6. though evill may come unto him, yet he shall not so know it, as too much to care for it. Our translation readeth it very well, he shall feele noe evill, for though he find it to bee evill, yet he shall not much feele the evill of it. Baronius reporteth of Constantine the great, that beeing spoken to by many to punish some who had throwen stones at his image, saying, that with the stones they had wounded all his face, he wiping his face with his hand & smiling with his countenance, gave them this answeare, Ego verò nusquam vulnus in fronte factum video, sed sanum quidem caput, Baron. Tom. 3. Anno Christi 324.
sana verò & facies tota, I doe not feele any where any hurt done mee or any wound made in my face, but my head is sound, and all my face is well, and whole likewise; plainly so it is with them that keepe the commandement, and the evill which is done them, is but like an evill done to their pictures, they feele it not. For how should they feele evill,
Rom. 8.28. to whom all things work together for their good? How should they feele evill to whom God is good: Sicut enim illo offenso nihil est quod nobis valeat suffragari, ita eodem propitio nulla nobis nocebit adversitas: For as he beeing offended, there is nothing that can favour us, so he being gracious unto us, there is no adversity that can hurt us, as Leo speaketh. The exposition which Lyra and the Glosse give of these words is this, They shall feele no evill, Leo Serm. 6.
in futuro in the time to come: and Lyra addeth, Minus dicit & plus significat, he saith little and meaneth much for though he saith he shall feele no evill,Lyra in hunc vers. he meaneth that he shall find much, good for the evill which he suffereth. For the evill, as it is an exercise of his patience, so it is the encrease of his glory. The Originall according to the words soundeth thus, Non cognoscet verbum malum, shall not know an evill word, or as S. Ambrose readeth it verbum nequam a naughty word:Ambros. Enarr. in Psal. 41. as if wee might take the meaning of the place to bee this, he that keepeth the commandement and feareth God, is so farre from rebelling against his Prince, so farr from taking upon him to correct him, that he knoweth not how to speake an evill word, either of him or against him. And a wise mans hart: the opinion of the Jewes was, whereunto accordeth the phrase of the sacred Scripture, that in the hart especially the soule did hold her residence and as it were her royall court, and that there, were principally exercised the noblest operations of the understanding, invention, judgment, and other the like excellencies of mans most glorious soule. But the more received opinion in the world hath been to place the working of these chiefest faculties in the head rather, and to leave unto the hart the passions only and affections, as griefe, joy, anger, love, wherwith mans soule aboundeth. In which diversity of opinions to make a reconciliation the matter is not difficult: for the Scripture speaketh not of those fruitlesse speculations which trouble and racke the braine with discourse or disputation only, and which as the
Philosopher speaketh may thrive in a wicked man as well as in a good, seeing the passions have no power upon them. But the Scripture respecteth the practicall actions of men, which testifie the goodnesse or badnesse of their lives, and which because God commandeth to bee lively, burning, harty, and likewise because in them the passions of the hart are of great force and strength, either by hindering or helping their vertue and efficacy (for experience daily teacheth, how much the moderation of our passions helpeth in good works, and how much the unrulinesse of them provoketh unto wickednesse, and stoppeth from goodnesse) hereupon the Scripture ascribeth to the hart also those practicall operations, seeing that by the passions of the hart they are either spoiled or bettered in man. Discerneth both time and judgment: It is not to bee conceived that Princes may not heare of their doing amisse, or that they may not bee told of their faults, but it must bee done by one that hath a wise hart, and which is able to discerne his tyme when to doe it, and who knoweth how to do it with judgement. Et dum apertâ invectione feriri nequeunt, Gregor. Moral. 13. c. 2.
quasi honore tegminis velare, and wheras they may not bee strucken at with open inveighing, as it were under the honour of a vaile to cover what he saith, as S. Gregory speaketh. That which our translation hath rightly according to the Originall, judgement, the French rendereth, Le moyen q'on doit tenir, the means and manner that ought to bee used and observed. For indeed these two things the time and the manner are principall things that ought to bee regarded in the office of reproving. And therefore a wise man as S. Gregory speaketh, Aliquando malis & quasi parcens non parcit, aliquando vero quasi non parcens parcit, Sometimes in evils as it were sparing he doth not spare them, and sometimes as it were not sparing he doth spare them. Sometimes he no sooner seeth evill done then he is ready to reprove it, and to reprove it sharply where he knoweth that he may be bold, and that his speaking shall bee welcome. And what doth he then but spare not sparing? Quia dum correptionis verbum non distulit, citius hunc à culpâ liberavit, Because while he deferred not the word of reprofe, hee did the sooner free him from his fault. Liberè enim arguens non pepercit, sed in eo quod correxit, pepercerat: For in that he repooved freely he did not spare, but in that he amended him, he did spare him. At other times a wise man heareth or seeth evill, and saith nothing, but seeketh and waiteth for a time, when he may best reprove it, as knowing Nisi sustineat, quando congruè proferre correptionem possit, auget in eo malum quod insequitur. That unlesse he tary for a time when he may best bring forth his reproofe, he doth encrease the evill in that he seeketh to suppresse it, as S. Gregory hath it. So likewise for the manner of reproving, a wise man discerneth, that sometimes it may bee done in a particular manner, but that sometimes it must bee done generally in a common speech of admonition, which he maketh for the good of all the hearers, and wherein he mentioneth those faults, which he knoweth him to have
committed who is present to heare them, though he may not bee pointed at or distinctly noted.Greg. Ibid. Et quum generaliter contra culpam invectio intenditur, correptionis verbum libenter ad mentem ducitur; quia potens pravus ignorat quod sibi hoc specialiter dicatur, And when the inveighing is directed generally against the fault, the word of reproofe is willingly admitted into the mind, because the great person offending doth not know that this was spoken specially against him. And is not this by sparing not to spare? Quum specialiter correptionis verba offendenti non intulit, ut tamen vulnus illius sub communi admonitione percussit, when as the reprover doth not cast his words particularly against him that hath sinned, and yet did strike his wound under a common admonition as S. Gregory also speaketh. The Originall word here used is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and most properly signifieth judgement, the judgement that is given by the judg, and if wee take it so, wee may give the words this sense. That he who walking in Gods commandements meeteth with evill, doth as it were not regard it as not feeling it: and if it come from him, who hath not a judge upon the earth, so that here he cannot looke for right, then as Lyra speaketh,Lyra in hunc vers. Attendit tempus judicii, ubi oportet de omnibus reddere rationem, A wise man expecteth the time of judgement, when God comming to judge, all must give an accompt of all that they have done.

q.p: Ver. 6. Because to every purpose there is time and judgement: therefore the misery of man is great upon him.
Ver. 7. For he knoweth not that which shall bee: for who can tell him when it shall bee.

Ver. 8. There is no man that hath power over the spirit, to retaine the spirit; neither hath power in the day of death: and there is no discharge in that war, neither shall wickednesse deliver those that are given to it.

div.p:
Ver. 6. Because there is: The reason why the heart of a wise man seeketh after time and judgment, is, because there is a time and judgement, that which is not, he seeketh not for. A time there is, which judgment must discerne, and a judgement must fit and further time, both must go together, to accomplish every purpose. To every purpose, to the purpose of God, to the purpose of the Devill, to the purpose of the good Angels,
to the purpose of men. God himselfe observeth time, who cannot bee without an exact and prefect judgement, wherefore God is said to bee adjutor in temporibus,
Psal. 9.9. a helper in times, a refuge in times of trouble. Where Theodoret tels us, that Aquila did render it, In tempus opportunum, Theodoret. Ibi. at a fit time; and that Symmachus did render it, opportunè, fitly, opportunely. And in deed it must needs be understood of a fit time. For as Philo Philo. speaketh, Quid aliud esse tempus potest, quam tempus rei bene gerendae? What else can time be, then the time of well doing any thing? Besides the Originall word is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifyeth an opportune time. Againe what are the times of troubles, but Gods fit times? For mans necessitie is Gods opportunity, and as Saint Austin speaketh, Ʋbi defecit humanum consilium, Augustin. Serm. 89. de Tempor. ibi intercedit divinum auxilium, where humane counsell faileth, there commeth in the divine helpe. When our Saviour Christ himselfe was apprehended, he spake for his disciples, that they might be let goe, John 18.8. v. 9. that the saying might be fulfilled, of them which thou gavest me, have I lost none. But what doth this meane? Had they been lost, if they had been taken? Were they not afterwards taken and put to cruel deaths?Philip. Abbas Epist. 114. An ancient writer answers it, Ex iis quos ad salvandum ei pater dederat quempiam non amisit, quia occidi eos tempore immaturo non permisit, Of those which his Father had given him, he did not loose any, because he did not suffer them to be slaine in a time that was not seasonable. When they had received the Holy Ghost, and by that heavenly fire were brought unto a ripenesse, then the time for it being ripe also, he feared not any death for them. Secondly to the purpose of the devill there is a time and judgement, and he hath his opportunities, his occasions to draw men unto wickednesse. And indeed great is the power of them upon men, and therefore it must be our care to shun and avoid them. When Eve had told the Serpent, the charge which God had given them, Gen. 3.3. shee delivers it thus, yee shall not eate of it, neither shall yee touch it, least that ye die, but in Gods charge set downe in the former chapter, wee doe not find these words, Gen. 2.17. Ye shall not touch it; wherefore Lyra saith, that she did adde these words out of a dislike which she had of the precept,Lyra. Ibid. because he who disliketh a precept, in relating of it, doth easily add unto it, to make it seem more grievous. But it may be well, as others conceive, that God also did use those words, and that to this end, that the occasion of sinning might be avoided: for being once touched, it was not far to bring it to the mouth. Luke 9.59. When our Saviour Christ said to one,Aug. de verb. Dom. Serm. 6.
follow me, and he said, Suffer me first to goe and bury my father. Saint Austin asketh, why our Sauiour Christ would not suffer him to do it; the businesse being so good? The answere which by some is given, is, that our Saviour did it to keep him from the occasions of being drawne away from him, because going to his friends, they might have perswaded him to follow still the world. Matth. 13.30. Thirdly to every purpose of the good Angels there is a time and judgement: in the Gospel we read, that the servants are not forbidden to sever the tares from the good corne, but they are commanded to expect the time of harvest. Whereupon one
saith well, Ʋbi seges matura sit ad messem, nullum ibi malum timetur, licet tunc accedat asperitas falcis, sola immatura asperitas nociva est, quae autem tempore opportuno exhibetur semper salutaris, For where the corne is ripe for harvest, there no hurt is feared, although the sharpnesse of the sickle be used, it is only an immature sharpnesse that is hurtfull, that which in due time is used, at all times is found profitable. Lastly, Levitic. 16.21. to every purpose of men there is a time and judgement: the Scape-goat which was to be let goe into the wildernesse, was to be sent away by the hand of a fit man, as we read in the law. The Venetian translation reads it, Opportuni hominis; of an opportune man: the Tigurine translation reads it, Tempestivi hominis, of a seasonable man, and it is such a man that rightly ordereth his affaires in this life. Rom. 12.11. In the Epistle to the Romanes where wee haue it, bee fervent in spirit serving the Lord; diverse do read it, Ferventes spiritu, servientes tempori, Fervent in spirit observing the time, and S. Ambrose reading it in that manner giveth this note upon it,Ambr. in Epist. ad Roman. Quoniam dixerat spiritu ferventes, ne hoc sic acciperent, ut passim & importunè verba religionis ingererent tempore inimico, per quod forsan scandalum excitarent, statim subjecit tempori servientes, ut modestè & cum honestate & locis & personis, & apto tempore religionis fidem loqueretur, Because he had said fervent in Spirit, least they should take this so, that they should importunely thrust the words of religion upon any in a contrary season, whereby perhaps they might raise a scandall, he added forthwith, serving the time, that modestly, and with due regard they should speak the faith of Religion, in fit places, to fit persons, and in fit time. Therefore the misery of man is great upon him: Hieronym. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome tells us that the Septuagint and Theodotio did read it, Because the knowledge of man is great upon him; and he conceiveth the difference to arise from the likenesse of the two Hebrew words 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the one signifying misery, the other knowledge, especially seeing ו and ר which are the onely different letters in these two words, are so very like also in the form of them. The reading of the Septuagint applyeth the words unto the wise man, who observing time and judgement in things, sheweth his knowledge to be great. The reading, which we have, applyeth the words unto a foolish man, who not observing time and judgment, which every purpose hath, thereupon doth bring much misery upon himselfe. For as Philo saith, Sicut corporibus nostris interitum morbus, Philo de Temulentia. incolumitatem affert sanitas; itidem animas prudentia servat, quum sit ipsa mentis sanitas, imprudentia vero interimit, quum sit morbus earum insanabilis, As sicknesse bringeth unto the body destruction, health safety; in like manner, wisdome preserveth the soul, seeing that is the health of the soule, but folly destroyeth the soule, being an uncurable disease of it.

Vers. 7. Although I conceive this verse to have reference to the former, yet I doe not take the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here to be causall, but as it were copulative only. For he knoweth not that which shall bee. Great is the misery of man in that he knoweth not the things that are to
come upon him. For as the Poet speaketh, Nescia mens hominum fati sortisque futurae, Ignorant is the mind of man of that which shall befall him, and of that condition which shall come unto him.
