And as Saint Hierome addeth, Aliud sperat, aliudque evenit, de altero loco expectat hostem, Hieronym. in hunc vers. & alterius jaculo vulneratur, He hopeth for one thing, and another commeth to passe, he expecteth an enemie in one place, and he is wounded with the dart of another. The Prophet David therefore, praysing God saith, For thy words sake, and according to thine own heart hast thou done all these things, 2. Samu. 7.21. to make thy servant to know them: where Cajetane noteth,Cajetan. Ibid. Prius gratias egit de beneficio affirmato, modo gratias agit denotificatione tanti beneficii, Before he gave thanks for the benefit established unto him, now he thanketh God for making knowne unto him so great a benefit. And surely it was a great blessing to the people of Israel, that God did send Prophets among them, who did foretell things to come. The want of this blessing the Psalmist lamenteth, when he saith, we see no signes,
Psal. 7.4.9. there is no more any Prophet, that is, saith the Chaldee Paraphrase, Non est Propheta Domini qui sciat quod futurum est in homine, There is not a Prophet of the Lord who knoweth, what is to come in man.1. Kings. 18. It was the carefull goodnesse of Obediah, that when Jezebel persecuted the Prophets of the Lord, he hid a hundred of them by fifty and fifty in a cave, feeding them with bread and water: and Theodoret speaking of it, saith, Prophetis sufficientem cibum offerebat Abdias, illorum salutem propriae saluti praeferens, & vitam quae sine illis transigenda esset mortis loco duceus; Obediah ministred to the Prophets sufficient nourishment,Theodor. Ser. 18 de Provident. preferring their welfare before his owne safety, and accounting that life which should be spent without them, to be but as it were death. Whereby he seemeth to signifie, that Obediah did so esteem of the knowledge of things to come, which by the Prophets was enjoyed, that he thought it better not to live, then to live without it. Indeed wise men may, and doe, think and consider of things that are to come; David telleth Nabuchadnezzar, As for thee, O King, thoughts came into thy mind upon thy bed, Theod. in Danielem. what should come to passe hereafter, and as Theodoret expounding it addeth, Cogitabas an esses victurus semper, an vero humanae naturae lege moriturus, Thou diddest think whether thou shouldest live alwayes, or whether according to the law of humane nature thou wert to die also. Notwithstanding, though wise men may, and doe think and consider of things that are to come, it is not the wisest that knoweth that which shall be, and who can tell him when it shall be? But this verse may be referred either to a foole, or else to a wise man. First to a foole, who hath no purpose to looke unto the time and judgement that is for every purpose: but as the misery of man is great, that he knoweth not, what is to come, so he maketh his misery much the greater, by not endeavouring to know it in some kind as he can, by thinking, forecasting and considering of it. Wherefore Tremellius expounding these words. And who can tell him when it shall be? saith Quis ex insipiente facere possit sapientem? Who of a foole can make a wise man? It was the scandall that the
devill would have put upon our Saviour Ghrist, to whom they said, Matt. 8.29. Art thou come to torment us before our time? But it was themselves in truth who were doing before their time; for as Chrysologus very well noteth, Sepelit vivos crudelitas immatura, & de tempore, queritur, quasi antè tempus habere debuerit, Chrysolog. Serm. 16. Overhasty cruelty buryeth among the graves of the dead them that were alive, and yet complaineth of time, as if it ought to have them before the time. This untimely proceeding is also in all sinfull fooles. They are before time in making the vaine pleasures of this life to be the happinesse of man, and in placing their rest and contentment in them. They are after-times, as not thinking of the things that are to come afterwards, but as passing them over, as never to be, are so gone beyond in them, in their little regard of them. When Goliah said to David, Am I a dogge, that thou commest to me with staves? 1. Sam. 17.43. Saint Chrysostome shewing him to be worse then a dogge, saith, Si canis fuisses, nunquam dimicantem contrâ te Dominum provocasses sed ut canis interitum futurum, & dignum supplicium metuisses. Pejores cane, qui nec virgam metuis, nec lapidem quo moriturus es, If thou hadst been a dogge, thou wouldest never have provoked the Lord fighting against thee, but as a dogge thou wouldst have feared thy destruction, that was at hand to come, and thy deserved punishment. Thou art worse then a dogge,Chrysost. Homil. de David & Gol. who neither fearest the staffe, nor yet art afraid of the stone by which thou art to die. And surely sinfull fooles are worse then the very beasts, for they have some presage divers times of that which is to come. Secondly this may be applyed unto a wise man, who lamenting the misery of man in not knowing the things that are to come unto him, and finding no where any one that is able to tell him, is thereby stirred up to look the more carefully into it, and by the circumspection of his judgement so to consider things, and the fit time of things, that as much as may be he may prevent the uncertainty of them. For as Saint Ambrose speaketh, Illud ingenii, si quis potest vigore mentis praevidere quae futura sunt, & tanquam ante oculos locare quid possit accidere; & quid agere debeat si ita acciderit definire, interdum duo, & tria simul volvere animo, quae conjiciat, Ambros. de Offic. l. 1. c. 38.
aut singula conjuncta accidere posse, & aut singulis aut conjunctis disponere actus quos intelligat profuturos, That is wisdome, if any one can by the strength of his mind foresee the things that are to come, and as it were set before his eyes that which may happen to come to passe, and can define what he ought to doe, if that it happen so to come to passe. Sometimes turning over two or three things in his mind together, of which conjecturing that either all may come to passe joyntly, or this or that severally, or whether they fall out joyntly or severally, can by his understanding so order his actions, as that they shall be profitable to him. Moreover a wise man considereth, that although divers things come to passe, and that he cannot know what is to come to him, notwithstanding that all things are by God made and done for the good of men, and that they are not disposed without his Providence. For as Philo speaketh, Semper autor curam gerit operis sui, communi necessariaque lege naturae;
quemadmodum & parentes curant suam progeniem, Philo de mundi Opificio, fine libri. Alwayes the author of any thing taketh care of his owne work by the common and necessary law of nature, even as parents take care for their children. Now because the Providence of God disposeth all things with judgement in their fit times; therefore doth a wise man by labouring to judg rightly of all things, and by endeavouring to find out the fit times of them in some sort ease the misery of mans condition, by getting some kind of knowledge of what is to come, and by being able in some measure to tell when it shall bee.

Vers. 8. The Preacher having shewed the power of a King, here he sheweth his weaknesse also to him; thereby to make him the more carefull in using of his power, thereby to make them the more patient that shall be wronged by it. There is no one that hath power over the Spirit. Aquinas applies these words unto the Holy Spirit of God, Aquin. 2. 2. Q. 189. A. 1. to shew his power in man; and thereupon citeth Saint Gregory, who speaking of the Holy Spirit, saith, Implet citharaedum puerum & Psalmistam facit, implet pastorem armentarium, & prophetam facit, implet abstinentem puerum, Greg. in Evang. Homil.. 30.
& judicem senum facit, &c. O qualis est artisex iste Spiritus, nullâ ad discendum morâ agitur in omne quod voluerit; He filleth a young man being a Harper, and maketh him a Psalmist, he filleth a heardman and maketh him a Prophet, he filleth an abstinent child, and maketh him a Judge of old men, &c. O what a workman is this Spirit! there is no delay in teaching any thing which he will have learned. But it is the Spirit of man, the Spirit of life in man, whereof the Preacher speaketh, shewing that he who hath power over many that are under him, hath not power over his owne spirit, over his owne life. That is a thing which though he doe possesse, yet he is not master of it. Homo vitae commodatus est non donatus, Man is but lent to his life, not given unto it, and the greatest King being but a man, must resigne his possession when the spirit leaveth him. It is the property of the law of nature, that it is common unto all; cold striketh all, heat troubleth all, griefe assaulteth all, a power over the Spirit is denyed all. To retaine the Spirit, it was a fable among the auncients in former time, that God appointing unto every thing his office and function, he appointed unto death, to take away the lives of men, and that death refused that imployment, because it should be by every one accused; but yet at length it did undertake it, because God did promise that it should be by all excused. For so indeed it is: of one wee say that he dyed because he was an old man, of another, because he was intemperate in his diet, of a third, because he was carelesse of his health, and so seeking in all to excuse death, wee do as it were closely make shew that we are able to preserve from death, to retaine the Spirit. But as Saint Hierome speaketh, Nihil prodest ora concludere, & vitam retinere fugientem, It is to no purpose to shut our mouth to keep in our breath, and to stay life flying away from us. When the spirit is to be gone, no hands can hold it, no force can stay it, no perswasion can prevaile to make it to tarry, no command can retaine it.
He that can forbid things by laws in his kingdome, cannot forbid the Spirit to depart by any law hee can make. Neither hath he power in the day of death: it is storyed of Alexander, that having heard of Paradise, and that it was upon the earth, he was very eager in seeking of it out, and to that end comming into the East part of the earth, an old man meeting with some of his souldiers, bid them to tell Alexander, that he sought Paradise in vaine, for the way to Paradise was the way of humility, which he did not take. But saith he, take this stone, and carry it to Alexander, and tell him, that from this stone, he shall perceive what himselfe is. Now the stone was a pretious stone, and of such a quality, that whatsoever thing was weighed with it, that was still the heavier, only if it were covered with dust, then it was as light as a straw. The meaning of the thing did easily appeare, as shewing Alexander and all Princes, that though in their lives they overweigh others, by the greatnesse of their power, yet that in death their power is nothing, and that then they weigh as light as any other. And there is no discharge in that warre. The Originall word here translated discharge, signifyeth nothing else but a sending, and therefore in this place, which speaketh of warre, it may imply either a sending out of forces to withstand death, or else a sending forth of Ambassadours to make peace with death. But all is bootlesse in this warre. He that can send out never so great forces to withstand his enemies, hath no forces that will resist this enemie. The word which this warriour beares upon his shield, is, Nemini parco, I spare none. Poverty spareth the rich, paine spareth the healthy, shame spareth the honourable, death spareth none, for no means that can be used against it. And therefore there is also no peace to be made with it. The Prophet Isaiah speaketh of some, who said, Isaiah. 28.15. vers. 1. they had made a covenant with death: but in the beginning of the chapter, he sheweth who they are, namely the drunkards of Ephraim. For what is it but the voice of a drunken man, a foole, or a mad man; so to speake? And therefore Saint Hierome saith, Quum interitus inimicus vitae nostrae advenerit, Hieronym. in hunc vers. inducias accipere non possumus, When destruction, the enemy of our life commeth, there is then no truce to be had. Neither shall wickednesse deliver those that are given to it: wee read in the Psalmes; of violence and wickednesse that are in the citie, and that day and night they doe goe about it, upon the walles thereof. Where Saint Austin expoundeth it, Super muros ejus, id est super munimenta, super nobiles ejus,
Psal. 55.9. v. 10. upon the walls thereof, that is, upon the fortresses thereof, upon the nobles thereof: and it is not seldome seene, that such doe make wickednesse to be their wall, whereby to defend themselves. But what defence soever this may be in their life, it shall be none unto them at their death, it shall not then deliver them. Lyra expoundeth these words, of those wicked, Qui aliquando mortē differre per artem magicam vel aliquâ superstitione credunt, who hope to put off death by Magick art, or else by some other superstitious way. But that which is rendred wickednesse, according to the Originall, may also be rendred inquietudo, unquietnesse. For generally
none are more unquiet then fierce and swaggering Princes are. What are they but tumbling seas, whose boyling, swelling, overflowing waves bring terrour and trouble to all that are neere them? But God hath said unto them all, Hither shall ye come, and no further, and here shall your proud waves be staid, Job 31.11. here death doth arrest you. It is related of Alexander the Great, that as he went to his conquest, comming neere some wise men, he called them unto him, and upon asking them some questions, finding them to be wise men indeed, he bid them to aske some gifts of him, and they should have them. Whereupon the Philosophers said, Wee desire certaine immortality of thee: at which Alexander laughing, said, I accounted you to be wise men, but now I perceive you to be ignorant, I cannot give that to my selfe, and how then can I grant it unto you? Are you mortal, then say they unto him? I am said he. Then replied they, Why then dost thou disturbe the whole world, seeking the dominion of it, as if thou wert immortall. Lastly, wee may take the unquietnesse here spoken of, to be nothing else but the unwillingnesse of people to die, especially of great persons, and their much striving with death, and the great adoe they make against it, all which is not able to deliver them from it.

q.p: Ver. 9. All this have I seene, and applyed my heart unto every worke that is done under the Sunne there is a time wherein one man ruleth over another to his owne hurt.
Ver. 10. And so I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the place of the Holy, and they were forgotten in the citie, where they had so done: this is also vanity.
Ver. 11. Because sentence against an evil worke is not executed speedily: therefore the hearts of the sonnes of men are fully set in them to do evill.
Ver. 12. Though a sinner do evill an hundred times, and his dayes be prolonged; yet surely I know that it shall be well with them that fear God, which fear before him.
Ver. 13. But it shall not be well with the wicked, neither shall he prolong his dayes which are as a shadow; because he feareth not before God.

div.p:
Ver. 9. As in the creation of the world wee often read, that God saw what he had done, and made; so in the consideration of things which are done by men in the world, the Preacher often saith, I saw. But that which God saw was alwayes good. For as Saint Ambrose speaketh,Ambros. Hexa. l. 2. c. 5.
Facit filius quod vult pater, laudat pater, quod facit filius, The Sonne doth that, which the Father will have done, the Father praiseth that which the Sonne hath done: whereas that which the Preacher saw was always vaine and naught. And as God is said to see the goodnesse of his works to set it forth the more; for as Saint Ambrose also speaketh,Ambros. Ibid. l. 1. c. 9.
Plus est quod probetur aspectu, quam quod sermone laudetur: suodeni{que} utitur testimonio, non alieno suffragio, It is more that a thing is approved by sight, then that it is praised by speech; because it useth its owne testimony, not the suffrage of another; so it setteth forth more the badnesse of worldly humane things, that the Preacher saith he saw them, as shewing that upon sight and consideration they manifested themselves to be vain and naught unto him. He had applyed his heart unto them, to look neerly on them, that he might the better see and judge of them as they were. It is also to set out the badnesse of them, that he saith, every work which is done under the sun: for Philo speaking of the Sunne, saith, Opino quod Sol & Luna perpetuo lumen ministrat: semel jussi in rerum primordio, & divinum mandatum indesinenter faciunt, non aliam ob causam, Philo de mundi Opificio. quam quia malitia procul terminis caeli exulat, I thinke that the Sunne and Moone doe alwayes give their light. and being once commanded in the beginning of the world, uncessantly do keep the divine commandement, for no other reason, than because wickednesse is farre bannished from the bounds of heaven. And for the same reason the Preacher here being to speake of wickednesse, saith, that he saw it under the Sun. There is a time wherein one man ruleth over another to his owne hurt: and when is this time? namely when being set in the place of a ruler, he is not carefull for to rule well. For as Saint Gregory speaketh,Gregor. in Evang. Hom. 17.
Ad paenam nostram ut video episcopi vocamur, qui honoris nomen, non virtutis tenemus, It is to our
punishment I see that wee Bishops are called, when wee hold the name of the honour, but observe not the duety. When is this time? namely, when he that is above another in command, is beneath him in goodnesse.Greg. Regist. Epist. For as Saint Gregory also speaketh, Quum elevatur, dejicitur, qui honoribus proficit, & moribus cadit, He is cast downe, that is lifted up, who riseth in honours, and falleth in manners. But as I conceive, the meaning of the Preacher doth most directly ayme at the ruling of Kings. And surely there is a time when they doe rule to their owne hurt, namely when by the wickednesse of their gouerment they provoke the wrath of God against themselves. Josephus notes it in the Kings of Israel, of whom he saith, that for their iniquity and injustice, Alter super alterum irruentes multi parvo tempore perierunt,
1. King. 15. Joseph. Antiq. l. 8. c. 12.
& eorum genus exterminatum est, One rushing upon another, many in a short time perished, and their race was rooted out: whereas Asa for his goodnesse and godlinesse lived to a long and happy old age, and when he had reigned one and Forty yeeres, died a good death. When it is said of Elijah, the charet of Israel and the horsemen thereof,2. King. 2.12. Lyra noteth, Currus qui ducitur ponitur primo & auriga qui ducit secundo, ad ostendendum quod ille bene ducit regendo, qui primò fuit ductilis in obediendo; Lyra. Ibid. The charret which is drawn is set downe first, and the horseman that drives it, is set downe afterwards, to shew that he doth well lead in ruling, who hath been first ready and willing to be lead in obeying. And surely he it is that doth rule for his owne good, as well as for the good of those that are under him, who is ready to be ruled by obedience unto Gods law. Wherefore Saint Bernard saith, Praesunt principatus & regunt, Bernard de considerat. l. 5.
sed reguntur & ipsi; ita ut regere non norunt, ubi regi desierint, They who are in authority are set above others, and do rule over them; but so as that themselves are ruled also; and doe not then know what it is to rule, when that they cease to bee ruled. They may rule still, but it is to their owne hurt, to the increasing of their punishment, which he will inflict, who ruleth all things. S. Hierome readeth the latter part of the vers thus, Dominatus est homo homini, ut affligeret eum, Man ruleth over man, that he might afflict him: and the reading is well enough admitted by the Originall; but though there be such among inferiour rulers, yet it is farre from the name of a King that he should be such a one.Psal. 47.2. Chrysost. Ibid. The Psalmist having said, The Lord most high, is terrible, why doth he adde, Hee is a great King over all the earth? Saint Chrysostome answereth, Sic Propheta dicit orbis salutem, So the Prophet speaketh, shewing the salvation of the world, and as it were mitigating the terrour of the Lord with the name of a King. Prosper speaking of Queene Hester, Prosper. Par. 2. de Promissi. c. 38 saith, Sic se pro suis opponit periculis, sic datis in mortem suis laboribus vitam conferendo ministrat, utpote regina, So doth she oppose her selfe to dangers for her people, so doth she minister to them, who were appointed to die, by her labours giving life unto them, because a Queene. It was emphatically spoken by the thiefe on the crosse, remember me when thou commest into thy kingdome; which Cyrillus Hierosolomytanus thus expresseth, Non dico ut aliter mei memineris,
quam quum veneris in regnum. Quae te virtus illuminavit ô latro? Cyril. Hierosolo. Cap. 13.
Ideo & juste audit confide, non quod opera tua digna sint confidentiâ; sed quia rex adest qui gratiam confert; I say no otherwise that thou remember mee, then when thou commest into thy kingdome. O thiefe, what vertue hath inlightened thee? Wherefore he justly heareth, be of good cheare, not that thine owne works are worthy to cheare thee, but because a King is present, who sheweth grace and favour. The speech of King Theodorus, as it is worthy of a King, so it sheweth what belongeth to a King, Among the glorious cares of the common wealth, which by the assistance of God, our thoughts continually doe meditate upon,Cassiodrr. var. 3. var. 30.
Cordi nostro est levamen humilium; the relieving of the afflicted goes unto our hearts, that wee may set up the obstacle of goodnesse against the power of the proud, and that there may bee nothing done out of presumption upon us, whose resolution is to beat downe proud things.

Ver. 10. They are the words of Hugo de sancto victore cōmenting upon the beginning of this booke of the Preacher,Hugo de Sancto vict. in Eccles. Hom. 3. and may be much more mine, Nos quid sumus tenebrae ad lucem, ut comprehendere cogitemus, quae abscondit Deus ab oculis hominum? What are we darknesse to light, that wee should thinke to conceive those things which God hath hid from the eyes of men? But shall I not therefore meditate upon Gods word? Shall I not indeavour to find the meaning of it? When man meditateth, God inlightneth, and it is to mans endeavours, that God giveth his blessing. Much obscurity there is in this verse, and much variety in the translating of it. But first to consider to whom to apply it, by reason of these words, from the place of the holy ones, Saint Hierome applyes it to Spirituall Magistrates, Qui quum viverent putabantur digni esse ecclesiae principes & templo Dei, Hieronym. in hunc vers. Who when they lived were accounted worthy to be Princes of the Church, and worthy of the temple of God. Tremellius applyes the verse to the temporall Magistrate, and to the throne of Judgement, Quae functio & sedes Dei est, Tremellius in hunc vers. which is the function and seat of God: Lyra applyes it unto both, saying, Sicut sacerdotes & principes mali qui tenent in terris locum Dei, isti in spiri tualibus, Lyra in hunc vers. & illi in temporalibus, As evill Priests and Princes, who on earth doe hold the place of God, the one in Spirituall things, the other in temporall things. Now for the translation of it, the Septuagint, and accordingly the Uulgar Latine, read it thus, Vidi impios sepultos, qui etiam quum adhuc viverent in loco sancto erant, laudabantur in civitate quasi homines justorum operum, I saw the wicked buryed, who when they were yet alive, were in the holy place, and were praised in the citie, as men of righteous works. Upon which reading S. Gregory saith,Gregor. Moral. l. 25. c. 30.
Multis enim peste propriae pravitatis obsessos sub nomine Christiano ipsae tranquilitas Ecclesiasticae pacis abscondit, quos tamen si levi persecutionis aurâ pulsaverit, mox extra aream velut paleas tollit, for many who are encompassed with the pestilence of their own wickednesse, the tranquillity of the peace of the Church hideth under the name of Christians, upon whom if a small ayre of persecution beat, it driveth them like chaffe out of the floore. Multi sunt
qui rem virtutis intimae ad decorem sumunt visionis externae; Many there are who take the matter of vertue, which is a most inward thing, only for the beauty of an outward shew. Saint Hierome reads it thus, Et tunc vidi impios sepultos, Hieronym. in hunc versum. & venerunt, & de loco sancto egressi sunt, & laudati sunt in civitate quia sic fecerunt. And then I saw the wicked buried, and they came and went forth from the holy place, and they were praised in the citie, because they had done so: which himselfe expoundeth thus, I have seen the wicked dead, and so buried, with such an opinion of them, as that they were esteemed holy on the earth. And these often after death are praised in the Church; and publickly are commended, either by their successours, or by the people as blessed in those things, which in probability they have not done. Or else wee may take the meaning which Lyra giveth, who saith, That when they were dead, then they were called wicked, but when they were living, were praised either in flattery, or else for fear. Both these translations doe seeme to have read in the Originall 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth to praise, whereas the Originall word which now is read,Tremel. in hunc vers. is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth oblivisci, to forget. Wherefore Tremellius reads it thus, For I observed those that had so ruled, being wicked, to be buryed after that they were departed, and they departed from the place of the holy, and to be forgotten in the citie in which they did so, As if the Preacher shewed, that though they were on high while they lived on the earth, yet that being dead, they were laid under the earth, and that as if the place of their authority had been but a place of memory, to keep them in mind for the time, when they were gone from them, their memory was gone also in the citie. The french Translation hath it thus, And then I saw the wicked buryed, and afterwards returned; and them who were gone and come from the place of the holy, who had well done to be forgotten in the City; as if the Preacher did compare together the wicked, and the righteous after death, as shewing how the one though dead, yet did return and live as it were again in the memory that was retained of them, but that the other though they had lived holily, and done vertuously, yet that they were forgotten quite and dead, in the memoryes of men, as well as in respect of their own lives. Our translation hath it, as you have it set down before; As if the Preacher did set forth hypocrites in religion, who came to, and went from the Church of God with a great shew of holinesse: but that being dead they were forgotten, having left no workes of goodnesse behind them whereby to be remembred. But to take the Originall as it self speaketh directly thus, & then I saw the wicked buried, & they came & they went from the holy place, and they were forgotten in the citie that they had done so; which is Saint Hieroms translation, only that he saith Praised, where the Hebrew saith now, forgotten. The sence which I gather from the foregoing, and following verses, is this, that as the Preacher had seen the lives of wicked rulers and governers, so he had seen and considered their deaths, and that though they had judged others with violence and opression, yet that themselves were then judged rightly, that
they bcfore whom others came to be judged, came then themselves before God to be judged, and that he being a Judge, Cui tacendo quisque se non potest celare, quem negando non potest fallere, From whom no one by holding his peace can conceale himselfe, whom no one by denying can deceive, as Saint Gregory speaketh, by him being condemned for their wicked lives, they went away from the holy place, from the glory of heaven,Gregor. in Evangel. Hom. 17 from that blessed Sanctuary, into which no unclean thing can enter. This followed them with God after their death; with men after their death, that which followed them, was, that they were forgotten in the city, and that they whose power and greatnesse made them before to be talked of, and feared by all, were then remembred by none. The Chaldee paraphrase speaking of the Preacher, as if he spake of himselfe, saith, Ecquis quaeso vel in sententiâ legis vigilantior, vel circa summiillius judicis venturi diem solicitus magis quam ego, Chald. in 2. Ecclesiatis. Is there any I pray you more vigilantin the sentence of the Law, or more solicitous concerning the day of that highest judge that is to come, then I am? And surely if Princes and Governours, would be watchfull in these two things, it would make them to doe better in all things that belong unto them. If they would consider, Quanta illud edictum sequentur lamenta, Cyprian. Serm. de Ascens. quomodo in proprio adipo frixae libidines ebullient: How great lamentations will follow that decree, how the lusts of men fried in their owne fat shall then boile, they would not rule by opression, they would take heed how they did rule to their own hurt. This is also vanity this, to make the inward substance of vertue ashadow of outward beauty. This, to have an opinion of holinesse, and to be praised for it, but not to deserve it. This, to be flattered or feared alive, to bee hated being dead. This, beeing present to bee remembred, being absent to be forgotten. This, that to be forgotten which should be remembed, that to be remembered which should be forgotten. This, to bee Church Christians, the guests of hell in life and conversation. This, for a while to rule in pride and oppression, and for ever to be slaves to misery and torments.

Ver. 11. Because sentence against an evill worke is not executed speedily: Indeed the patience of Almighty God is exceding great, and the reason of it by Rupertus is set downe to be twofold, Ʋt omnis paenitens, Ruper. l. in Naum. id quod saluatur debere se sciat expectantis patientiae, & nullus impaenitens in damnatione suâ derogare ei valeat quasi festinantis impatientiae. That every penitent,Hierony in hunc vers. might know that he owes it to Gods patience that he is saved, that no impenitent in his damnation might derogate from him as if he were of an hasty impatiency. But the cheife end of Gods patience is to invite and draw men to repentance. And therefore S. Hierome saith, Differt paenam dum expectat paenitentiam, he differeth the punishment while he expecteth repentance. Should God strike as soone as wickednesse is committed, who should go to heaven? Romans. 2.4. Wherefore by the Apostle God is stiled to be rich in forbearing, that is (as we may say) his riches, because indeed it is that which doth gaine soules,
it is that which doth make him rich in soules, which is the riches that God desireth, that God laboureth for. Tertullian saith, Erroneam ovem patientia pastoris inquirit & invenit: Tertullian l. de patientia. nam impatientia unam facile contemneret, It is the patience of the shepheard that seeketh the wandered sheepe, and by which it is found: for impatiency would easily contemne one. But patience undertaketh the labour of seeking, and moreover as a patient bearer, he layes it on his shoulder, and so brings home that which was lost. Illum quoque prodigum filium patientia patris & recipit & vestit & pascit, & apud impatientem fratrem excusat: That prodigall Sonne also the patience of the Father, receiveth, cloatheth, feasteth, and doth also excuse him to his impatient brother, as Tertullian also addeth. But let it bee marked in these words, that it is the execution only that is deferred: the sentence against every evill worke is already given, and it is a sentence of condemnation. Neither is it a secret sentence which though given is concealed, but it is as the Originall here speaketh 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
enarrata sententia a published and declared sentence: So that it is only a repreive of mercy which a wicked man hath. But though the sentence of condemnation bee fully knowne, and though it bee only the patience of God that spareth the execution, and that to this end that repentance may wholy prevent it, notwithstanding the heart of the Sonnes of men, that is saith Lyra, Illorum qui sunt nutriti in carnalitate & sunt filii hominum, non Dei, of them who are nourished in carnall sensuallity, and are the Sonnes of men, not of God, the heart of such turneth all to an encrease of wickednesse. Chrysologus observing the plea of the Devils, who say why art thou come to torment us before our times? thereupon noteth Agnoscit Deum, judicem profitetur, clamat judicium esse debere, & de tempore praescribit, He acknowledgeth God, he confesseth the Judge, he cryeth out that judgment is due, but he prescribeth concerning the time.Lyra in hunc vers. And so it is with wicked men, who acknowledging the judge, and the sentence to be given, yet because the execution of sentence is so long delayd, from thence do plead as it were a prescription of impunity, and perswading themselves in a manner,Chrisalog. Serm. 16. that the execution which is so long put off, will never be laid on them, from thence are emboldened and made worse in their sinfull courses, and therefore their heart is fully set to do evill, there full strength is set unto the doing of it. The Originall is their heart is full to do evil, full of evill purposes, full of evill desires imaginations, devises for the bringing forth of evill workes. Their heart is so full, that there is no roome for the feare of Gods wrath, no roome for the consideration of their own danger no roome for the apprehension of the foolishnesse of wickednesse, whereby to retaine them in any measure, but they runne with a full streame into the workes of iniquity. The Catena Greca giveth this exposition of the words,Catona Graeca. Quoniam Dei providentia propter immensam intolerandis malis clementiam non statim in improbos grassatur, nec paenas scelerum expetit, ideirco vir nequam quasi impune laturus peccandi sibi licentiam diutius persuadet, Because the providence of God
through infinite clemency in bearing with evils, doth not forthwith fall upon the wicked, nor presently punish their wickednesse, therefore a wicked man, as if he should go without punishment perswadeth himselfe that he shall be longer licenced in sinning. As for the execution of justice which is to come they behold it as a thing that is afar off, & that makes it to seem a little thing unto them. For as the stars though in themselves very great, yet being seene afarre off, seeme to bee little; so wicked people considering of the day of judgment as a time to come long hence, they are little moved by it. Ezek. 12.22. Thus it was with the Isralites concerning their temporall destruction, their proverb was, the dayes are prolonged, and the same is the thought of wicked people, it is a long time to the last day, and thereupon they spend their dayes in wickednesse. But if God be so patient, how then is God said, Psal. 7.11. to be angry with the wicked every day, as the Psalmist speaketh? St. Hierome answereth, Pulchre ait infrendens omni die qui enim propter patientiam suam ita delicta non punit, quasi iratus & comminatus diem ultionnis expectat, wisely doth he say that God is angry every day;Hieronym. for he who through his patience doth so not punish offences, doth as it were threatning and angry expect a day of revenge. And therefore as St. Gregory hath it, Quos diu ut convertantur tolerat, non conversos durius damnat, Gregor. Hom. 13 Those whom he suffereth long that they may be converted, being not converted, he condemneth the more severely. And yet sometimes also God punisheth the wicked forthwith, that thereby others might feare least he should do so alwayes. Levit. 10.12. The two Sonnes of Aaron offered strange fire before the Lord, and there went out a fire from the Lord and devoured them; in quibus non judicium tantum sed praesens judicium, Deus ostendere voluit, nec prius peractum est facinus peccantium, quam ulciscitur paena peccatum, upon whom God was pleased to shew not only judgment, but present judgment, neither was the sinne of the offenders sooner commited, then punishment revenged the sinne,Salvianus de Guber. Dei. l. 1. as Salvianus speaketh. And why may not the same just and angry God, as soone punish any wicked dooers as he did them? St. Heirome reads the first part of the verse thus, Quia non est contradictio facientibus malum citò, Because there is not forthwith contradiction to them that do evill:Cassian. Coll. 2. C. 11. and Cassian also reading it in the same manner; Abbot Thuon giveth this exposition of it, because wickednesse is not forthwith checked, blamed, and opposed in them that do evill, either by themselves or others, therefore is the heart of the Sonnes of men filled in them, that they do evils.

Ver. 12. The Preacher having in the verse before shewed the patience of God not to be hasty here he shewes it to be very slow, so that although a sinner do evill an hundred times, that is, very much; yea although he do the same evill over a hundred times, yet he forbeareth him, and in the lengh of his patience prolongeth his dayes,
Exod. 34.9. it may be to an hundreth yeares. When Moses saith unto God, O Lord let my Lord I pray thee go among us, for it is a stifnecked people, the exposition which some give of
it is this, such is the perversnesse and stubbonrnesse of this people, that thy patience, thy mercy, thy goodnesse is needfull to go among them, and a long with them. For though Moses himself were a most meeke man, as the Scripture testifieth, yet he acknowledgeth his owne patience not to bee sufficient, but it is Gods patience which he confesseth to be most fit for them, which in the daily sufferance of grievous sinners is continually manifested. But to give the meaning of the whole verse, that which our translation as I conceive importeh, is this, that though the wicked who abound in sinnes, are not punished for them, but live at ease, and in prosperity, whereas they who feare the Lord and shunne iniquity are full of troubles and sorrows; notwithstanding that it is not the wicked but the Godly who have cause of comfort and joy. Indeed the foole that looketh on the wicked thinketh him to bee happy, Prov. 17.24. because as a foole he hath his eyes in the ends of the earth, as in the Proverbs the Preacher speaketh, his sight reacheth not beyond the earth, to those things which shall bee after death. A foole looketh upon a godly man under trouble and sorrow, and thinketh him to bee unhappy,Aug. in Psal. 91 because as a foole, Attendit quid patitur, & non attendit quid illi servetur, He attendeth what he suffereth, and doth not attend what is reserved for him as S. Austin speaketh. Wherfore the same Father sayth, Noli gaudere ad piscem, qui in esca sua exultat, nondum traxit hamum piscator, Do not rejoyce at the fish, which rejoyceth at his bayte, the fisher hath not yet pulled his hook: boni laborant quia flagellantur ut filii, mali exultant quia damnantur ut alieni, The good are troubled, because they are chastised as Sonnes, the wicked rejoice because they are condemned as aliens and strangers. The prayer therfore of Origen is,Orig. Hom. 8. in c. 20. Exod. Oro te, flagella me quoque, & nolime reservare cum his qui non flagellantur: I intreat thee O Lord, chastice mee also, and do not reserve mee with them which are not chastised. For as he also sayth, Hoc est terrible, hoc extremum quum jam non corripimur pro peccatis, This is terrible, this is extreame, when wee are not now corrected for our sinnes. Saint Hierome readeth this verse thus, Quia peccator facit malum centies, & elongat ei Deus, ex hoc cognosco ego, quod erit bonum timentibus Deum, qui timent a facie ejus, Because a sinner doth evil an hundreth times, & God doth lengthen his dayes unto him, from hence I know that it shall be well with them that feare God, which feare before his face. And himselfe giveth the meaning of it to be this; from hence that God giveth to him space of repentance who sinneth very much (for that doth an hundreth times signifie) and doth not forthwith punnish him in his wikednesse, but taryeth that he may be turned from his wickednesse; I understand how mercifull and gracious God will be towards them, who have a feare of him, and tremble at his word. The same Father in the same place tels us that Symmachus did read the former part of the verse thus. Peccans enim malus mortuus est, longa aetate concessa ei, Hieronym. in hunc versum. An evill man sinning is dead, a long age being granted to him, which as he saith was expounded thus, That he who doth evil & sinneth
is dead, dead in sin, although his dayes be prolonged, and that he live to old age. And it seemeth by Saint Hierome, that not onely Symmachus, but Aquila and Theodotio also did translate the Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
mortuus dead, as if it came from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signiffies to dye, wheras other translations which render it centies a hundredfold do take it as if it came from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifies centum. But according to the reading of Symmachus, I conceive the meaning to be, that though a wicked man be spared long, yet at lengh he is dead, and at last is brought to judgement; and then he findeth, that his sparing so long was not his good, but the cause of his greater evil, that it was not the favour of God, but his anger against him. Wherefore S. Austin saith, vis nosse, nulla paena, quanta sit paena? wilt thou know, how great a punnishment no punnishment is, consider a wicked man not punished, for it is the greatnesse of Gods anger against him, that he doth not punish him: magna est ira ejus, Aug. de verb. Dom. Serm. 37.
parcendo saevit, & juste saevit, Great is the wrath of God, in sparing he is cruell, and justly is he cruell. His sparing is in the life, but after death cruell are the torments, which his justice inflicteth. On the contrary, he that feareth God, in this life suffereth griefe and cares, but it is he that shall be comforted after death, it is he that shall be full of comfort, at the last judgement, then it shall be well with him. When our Saviour Christ ascended into heaven, and his Discipes amazed with sorrow stood gazing after him, the Angels say unto them, Acts. 1.11. why stand yee gazing up into heaven? This same Jesus, which is taken up from you into heaven, shall so come in like manner, as yee have see him go into heaven: but is this the comfort which they gave to the Orphan Disciples? Is this the consolation which they have for his absence, that he shall come again to judgement? shall not his comming to judgement be full of terrour and horrour? yes to the wicked. But to them that feare God,
Matt. 25.34. to them that feare before his face, it shall be a day of gladnesse, and joy, a day of lifting up their heads. For then they shall see him face to face, before whose face they have feared, then they shall heare the joyfull sentence of, Come yee blessed of my Father, inherit the Kingdome prepared for you from before the foundation of the world. Of this time Job speaking, and of his reedemers comming at this time, saith, Whom I shall see for my selfe and myne eyes shall behold him; for my selfe,
Job. 19.27. that is saith Vatablus bono meo for my good, as shewing the meaning to be, that he should see him for him selfe, and not against him selfe, for himselfe to his unspeakable joy and comfort, not against himselfe to his condemnation. Oh how well will it then be with him that feareth God? The doubling of the words in the end of the verse, With them that feare God, which feare before him; I conceive to signifie a double feare, the first signifying that feare, Qui timet iram Dei, which feareth the wrath of God, the other that feare, qui timet offensam Dei, which feareth the offending of God: the one feareth him, the other feareth before him, as being before him in the wayes of godlinesse, and fearing to depart from them. The Hebrew is, feareth before his face, that is, enjoying the gracious look of his favor
and countenance feareth to loose it, and to be deprived of it. And though it be not so well with the other, as it is with him that thus feareth, yet it shall be well with him also, when by a servile feare he is brought from it into a filiall feare.

Vers. 13. Saint Hierome, and the Uulgar Latine begin the verse thus, Et bonum non sit impio, And let not good be unto the wicked: which Saint Hierome expoundeth to be an imprecation against them, who have not the feare of God, and that the Preacher wisheth that they may not be delayed long in their punishment, but that being forthwith taken away by death,Hieronym. in hunc vers. they may receive the torments which they have deserved. And whereas Saint Hierome addeth, Quae quomodo clementer dicta sint requirendum est, which things, how they be mercifully spoken, is to be looked after;Lyra. in hunc vers. Lyra sheweth, that the hastning of their punishment is a lesning of it, because thereby their sinnes are the fewer, which by the delay of their punishment would be multiplied, and so would multiply the greatnesse thereof. Wherefore the mercy of the words is, that he desireth a lesse measure of torments for them. And to view the words so rendred, Let not good, that is, not the good of this life (saith the Ordinary Glosse) because it is no other good that they seek for, Let not good be to the wicked, because he doth abuse it, saith Lyra. But to follow rather our reading, which is according to the Originall, as also according to the Septuagint, It shall not be well with the wicked: how well soever either themselves or others may imagine it to be now with them, it shall not be well with them. Among those things which Almightie God shewed to the Prophet Ezekiel in the Temple, Ezek. 41.18. c. 19. wee read, and it was made with Cherubims and Palme trees, so that a Palme tree was between a Cherub and a Cherub, and every Cherub had two faces, so that the face of a man was towards the Palme tree on the one side, and the face of a young lyon towards the Palme tree on the other side, Now what doth a Cherub import, but a fulnes of knowledge? And is it not Christ, in whom are all the treasures of wisdome and knowledge? Colos. 2.3. Is not he the very wisdome of God? He it is therefore, who hath two faces, the one like the face of a man, courteteous and mild; the other of a lyon, fierce and terrible, with both it is said,Hesychius sup. c. 23. Levitici. That he beheld a Palme tree. Now a Palme tree in the Scriptures, as Hesychius tells us, useth to signifie justice. Wherefore Christ beholdeth justice, both with a mans face, and with a lyons face: with a mans face in this life, which is a time of mercy, and wherein he spareth the wicked, expecting their amendment. But when the fulnesse of the time of this life is come, and that the wicked are called to judgement, then he looketh upon justice with the face of a lyon, with the fiercenesse of his wrath, and then it shall not be well with the wicked. Then as the Prophet Esaiah speaketh, Isai. 30.27. his lips shall be full of indignation, and his tongue as a devouring fire, sending the wicked by his sentence into that fire, of which Saint Austin speaking,Augustin. saith, Ignis iste noster licet qualis fornacis Babyloniae sit, igni illi inferni comparatus, est velut ignis depictus, This fire of ours, although it be such as was in the furnace of Babylon, being
compared with the fire of hell, is but a painted fire. Neither shall he prolong his dayes: Saint Hierome expounding these words, saith,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Non enim hi qui multo tempore vivunt, prolongant dies suos, sed qui grandes eos faciunt honorum operum magnitudine, For they who live a great while, doe not prolong their dayes, but they who make them to be great by the greatnesse of their good works. Wherefore, saith he, Gene. 47.9. Jacob confessing his sinnes, saith, Few and evill have been my dayes. But the Preacher speaking of the time to come, meaneth, as I conceive, That though the dayes of the wicked may be long in this life, whereof in the verse before he speaketh, yet that in respect of the next life, which shall be endlesse, Psal. 102.11. they shall be very short. Wherefore when the Prophet David complayneth, I am withered like grasse, Saint Hierome expoundeth it,Hieronym. in hunc vers. Non quod longam vitam quaesierit in presenti, sed quod de futuro timeat, ne longitudo vitae ipsius, ubi vera est vita brevietur, Not that he desired a long life in this present world, but because he feared of that which is to come, least there the length of his life should be short, where true life is. Saint Austin therefore speaking to one who is troubled at the prosperity of the wicked in this life, saith, Attendis ad dies tuos paucos, & diebus tuis paucis vis impleri omnia. Quae omnia? ut damnentur omnes impii, & coronenter omnes justi. Istis diebus tuis vis haec omnia impleri? Implet ea Deus in tempore suo. Quod tibi videtur longum, breve est, omnia ista cito transeunt, & qui florent ad tempus intereunt in aeternum, Thou dost attend unto thy few dayes, and in thy few dayes thou wouldst have all things to be fulfilled. What all things? That all the wicked be condemned, and all the godly be crowned. Wouldest thou that all these things should be fulfilled in thy dayes, they shall be fulfilled by God in his time. That which seemeth long to thee, is but a little while: all those things quickly passe away, and they who flourish for a time,Augustin. in Psal. 91. do perish for ever. Which are as a shadow: the Hebrew is no more then, as a shadow, and so the words may be referred either to that which goeth before thus, Neither shall he prolong his dayes, as a shadow: for a shadow is prolonged when the Sunne is going downe, and then is longest when the Sunne is lowest, and neerest to a setting; but so shall not the dayes of the wicked be prolonged. For when their Sunne commeth to set, their temporal life to end, then the length of their eternall life shall quite be cut off; and not a day of comfort for ever shall be afforded to them. Or else these words, as a shadow, may be referred unto that which followeth, and so Cajetane doth referre them,Cajetanus in hunc vers. who expounding these words saith, He compareth a man that doth not feare in the sight of God, unto a shadow, because as a shadow is not his true body, whose shadow it is, but only some representation of it, Ita non timens conspectum divinum non est homo sed hominis umbra, So he that feareth not the divine looke, is not a man, but the shadow of a man. He is not I say a man according to the use of understanding, but a shadow of a man: for the use of mans mind dependeth upon the feare of the divine sight, as it were upon the first rule. And indeed the Original seemeth to favour this exposition,
which saith, Qui non ipse timens a faciebus Dei, as if the sence were, who being not himselfe, feareth not before God, and that the negation did denie as well himselfe as his feare. Saint Gregory therefore speaking also of the wicked, saith, Ideò peccasse se nesciunt, quia homines se non attendunt: nam si considerarent se homines, citius agnoscerent, Gregor. Moral. l. 24. c. 6.
quantò infrà homines peccando cecidissent, Therefore doe they not know themselves to have sinned, because they doe not marke themselves to be men: for if they did consider themselves to be men, they would acknowledg how far by sinning they had fallen below men. Because he feareth not before God: that is, because he feareth not to come before God at the judgement day. But because he feareth so little now, when the time commeth, he shall feare and tremble beyond all imagination. Matth. 24.29. Our Saviour in some sort describing that time, saith, that then the powers of heaven shall be shaken: and Saint Austin expounding it saith, De angelis hoc dicit, timor en. illos apprehendet, magnus timor; He speaketh this of the Angels, for trembling and great feare shall surprise them.Augustin Serm. in Fer. 6. Paras. But if the Angels shall tremble at the horrour of that day, who being guilty of no sinne, shall not then be judged, how shall the wicked tremble, whose judgement and condemnation shall then be pronounced. Holcot Holcot. telleth a story of two souldiers, that comming to the valley Jehosaphat, in Judaea; and one saying to the other here shall be the generall judgment, wherefore I will now take up my place, where I will then sit, and so taking up a stone he sate downe upon it, as taking possession before hand. But being sate, and looking up to heaven, such a quaking and trembling fell upon him, that falling to the earth, he remembred the day of judgement with trembling ever after. This feare may give some remonstrance of that which then shall be felt; but the feeling of it will be greater then can be apprehended now.

q.p: Ver. 14. There is a vanitie which is done upon the earth, that there be just men unto whom it happeneth, according to the worke of the wicked; again there be wicked men, to whom it happeneth according to the work of the righteous: I said that this also is vanity.

Ver. 15. Then I commended mirth, because a man hath no better thing under the Sunne, then to eate, and drinke, and to be merry: for that shall abide with him of his labour the dayes of his life, which God giveth him under the Sunne.

div.p:
Ver. 14. This verse speaketh of two things which fall out in the world, the misery of the just; the prosperity of the wicked, and unto each the Preacher addeth a severall vanity, to make it the better noted. This is sayth he a vanity which is done upon the earth: for it is while the just are upon the earth, that this vanity cleaveth unto them, and that they have sinnes and corruptions in them, which by the evils of affliction are prevented and pared a way, that so they may not diminish their glory in heaven.Chald. Poraph. The Chalde Paraphase therefore writing upon these words expoundeth them thus, Vidi in Spiritu sancto quòd malum accidit justis in hoc saeculo ad removendam ex eis culpam levem ut, sit merces eorum integra in saeculo venturo, I have seen by the holy Spirit that evill happeneth to the just in this world, to remove from them lesse faults, that so their reward may be whole and perfect in the world to come. Saint Austin considering that answer of the Spouse, when her beloved called her, I have put off my coate, how shall I put it on?
Cant. 5.3. I have washed my feet, how shall I defile them? thereupon saith, O grande misterium! ergone timet inquinare pedes remeando ad eum, qui discipulorum pedes lavit? Timet certe per quia terram venit, O great mystery!Augustm. tract. 57. in Johann. what doth shee feare the fouling of her feete by going unto him, who washed his disciples feet? Shee feared indeed, because shee goeth upon the earth. For while the righteous go upon the earth, though with great earnestnesse and speed they even runne to God, yet such is the vanity of this life, that their feet are defiled, and affliction is needfull to wash the durt away. Saint Bernard saith, Nobis fratres semper putationis est tempus, sicut est semper est opus: Scrutemur vias nostras & studia nostra, & eo se judicet quisque profecisse, non quum non invenerit quod reprehendat, sed quum quod invenerit, reprehenderit, Bernard. Ser. 58. in Cant. Brethren there is to us alway a time of pruning as it is alwayes needfull: let us search our wayes and our endeavours, and herein let every one judge himselfe to have profited, not when he cannot find that which he may reprehend, but when he reprehendeth that which he findeth. The other vanity in this world whereof the Preacher speaketh, is the prosperity of the wicked, and whereof the Preacher sayth, I sayd this also is vanity. A vanity it is the world, and maketh oftentimes even the righteous vaine in their imaginations, when they think upon it. So that as Saint Austin speaketh, some one in his troubled mind is even ready to say, Deus, puto
mali tibi placent, & bonos odisti; amas eos qui faciunt iniquitatem, O God I thinke that the wicked please thee, and that thou hatest the good, thou lovest those that work iniquity. Another as the same Father speaketh, considering himselfe to be cast into prison, and there to be carefull to do the workes of righteousnesse, while he that did cast him into prison, though living in wickednesse, rejoyceth and aboundeth in the pleasures of the earth, from hence his disquieted heart is even ready to say,Augustin. psal. 91.
Deus quare tibi servio, quare obedio verbis tuis? O God why do I serve thee, why do I obey thy words? Now indeede whereas the Psalmist saith, O Lord how great are thy workes? And thy thoughts are very deep, it is Saint Austins note upon it, Nullum mare est tam profundum quam est ista cogitatio Dei, ut mali floreant, & boni laborent, Augustin. Ibid. There is no sea so deepe as is this thought of God, that the wicked do flourish, and the good are troubled. And in this very place Saint Hierom tels us, that whereas we read it, There is a vanity which is done, Hieronym. in hunc vers. Symmachus did read it thus, est difficile cognitu quod sit super terram, It is hard to be understood that which is done upon the earth. Hard it was to Solomon who therefore confesseth, I sayd that this is also vanity. Hard it is even to those who living justly, and knowing God to be just, do thinke with themselves, Decet eum meliora dare melioribus, It behooveth him to give the better things to them that are better. But let me say to every such one, as Saint Austin doth. Esto tranquillus & intelliges: Augustin. in psalm. 91.
nam perturbaris & in cubiculo tuo obscuras tibi lucem. Radiare tibi vult Deus Aeternus, noli tibi facere nubilum de perturbatione esto tranquillus in te, & vide quid tibi dicit, Bee pacified and thou shalt understand, for thou art troubled, and dost darken the light to thy selfe in thine own chamber. The aeternall God is willing to shine in unto thee, do not make thy selfe a cloud from thine own perturbation: be quiet in thy self, and see what he saith unto thee: Quia Deus aeternus est modo parcit malis adducens eos ad paenitentiam,
Psal. 92.132. flagellat bonos erudiens illos ad regnum coelorum, Because God is aeternall, he spareth the wicked leading them unto repentance, he chastiseth the good bringing them up and instructing them to the kingdome of Heaven. It is good therfore in all things to praise the Lord, and to give thanks unto him, to shew forth his loving kindnesse in the morning, and his faithfulnesse every night as the Psalmist speaketh. Now as Saint Austin hath it, the morning is, when it is well with us, when we have comfort:Augustin. in psal. 91.
the night is, when we are in heavinesse and sorrow: what therefore is it that wee are briefely taught? But in our prosperity to praise the mercy of God, in our adversity to praise the righteousnesse of God, who layeth no more upon any, then while they are upon the earth, their sinnes do deserve though they be just and godly. For he praiseth the righteousnes of God, Qui non accusat Deum, quia patitur aliquid mali, sed tribuit illud peccatis suis, & emendationi ipsius, who doth not accuse God because he suffereth any evill, but ascribeth it unto his owne sinnes, and to God amending of him. As for the flourishing
of the wicked, the same Father speaketh also very well, Nolite seduci prosperitate impiorum, nolite attendere florem faeni, nolite attendere ad tempus beatos, in aeternum miseros, Suffer not your selves to be seduced with the felicity of the wicked, regard not the flower of the grasse; regard not them who are happy for a time, and eternally miserable.

Ver. 15. It is a common received opinion, that in this booke the Preacher often speaketh under the person of others. And that he doth so, Saint Gregory proveth, because in the end of the book he saith, Finem loquendi omnes pariter audiamus, let us all heare together the conclusion, or as wee read it, let us heare the conclusion of the whole matter. Gregor. Dialog. l. 4. c. 4. For saith he si in libro eodem per locutionem suam personas multorum non susceperat, cur ad audiendum loquendi finem secum pariter omnes admonebat, If in the same booke, by the manner of his speach he had not taken upon him the persons of many, why doth he admonish all together with himself to heare the end of the speach. Wherefore going on he saith, there are are somethings in that booke which are moved by way of enquiry: other things which give a reason by way of satisfaction Alia quae ex tentati profert animo, & adhuc hujus mundi delectationibus dediti: alia in quibus ea quae sunt rationis affert, atque animum à delectatione compescit, Other things which he produceth from the minde of one that is tempted, and as yet is given to the delights of the world: other things in which he discourseth according unto reason, and withdraweth the mind from delight. Gregory Nyssene speaketh doubtfully of this point and sayth, Anne autem dicat, quasi ea reverà fecisset, an fingens propter utilitatem nostram, ut consequenter ad scopum ducat orationem suam, Gregory Nyssen in Eccles. Homil. 3.
non possum asserere: liceat volenti quam velit ea de re facere conjecturam, Whether he speaketh, as having done these things indeed, or else as framing his speach in this manner for our profit, that he might the better bring it to his proposed scope, I cannot affirme: let it be lawfull for him that will, to conjecture of it as he will. The reason of this opinion is, because that there are diverse passages of this booke, Quae qui virtutem sibi proponit non libenter adsciverit, which he that proposeth vertue to himselfe would not willingly allow of as Gregory Nyssene speaketh. But that is as things are understood. In this verse, when some do read it, Forte convivia meditantur, calices praeparant, tempus rosarum expectant, They meditate of feasts, they prepare cups,Augustin in Ps. 99. they expect the time of roses, as Saint Austins words are upon the like occasion. And then the Preacher must be concieved to speake in the person of a carnall man, who mindeth onely the things of this life. But let it be free for me, to take the Preacher here as speaking from himselfe, and so to speak of a chearfulnesse of heart, which is a thing not only pleasing unto God, but gracefull in man. For the Preacher having spoken of the oppression of the wicked, and of the troubles of the righteous, here he sheweth a good remedy against them, and an excellent carriage in them. Then I commended mirth; when he had considered the troubles of mans
life, then he commended cheerefulnesse, he commended it as a thing worthy of praise in it selfe, he commended it unto men, as a thing bringing much good unto them. And this it is which the Prophet David commendeth, Psal. 100.2. saying, Serve the Lord with gladnesse, come before his presence with singing. Although it be a service of misery and labour, in which thou art, yet passe through it with a merry and glad hart: doe not murmure at it, doe not fret, chafe, vex thy selfe for it. Non id agunt murmura tua ut non servias, Augustin. in Psal. 99.
sed ut malus sis servus, Thy murmurings doe not make thee not to serve still, but onely to be a bad servant in it, as S. Austin speaketh. But mark also, what the Prophet addeth, Come before his presence with cheerefulnesse; for it is no great matter to be cheerefull outwardly, but doe thou bee cheerefull in the presence of God, Non valdè lingua exultet, sed conscientia exultet, Let not thy toung be very merry, but let thy conscience be cheerefull: be glad and merry in the sight of the Lord, because a man hath no better thing under the Sunne. But above the Sunne there is farre better, there is such mirth as here can not be conceived, Ibi totum negotium nostrum erit non nisi laudare Deum & frui Deo: Augustin. in Psal. 86.
hoc uno beati erimus otioso negotio, There all our businesse wil be nothing, but to praise God, and to enjoy God: by this one quiet businesse we shall be blessed, as Saint Austin speaketh. While we are here there is nothing better then to be cheerefull, which maketh comforts to be much more comfortable, and maketh troubles to be much lesse trouble some. Then to eate and to drink and to be merry: although it be the bread of sorrow that thou eatest, although it be the cup of affliction that thou drinkest, eate it, and drinke it merrily. Because oppression eats thee, doe not thou forbeare to eate thy meate; because afflictions swallowes thee up, doe not thou forbeare to swallow downe thy drinke, but doe both merrily, which will make thy meate and drinke to doe thee the more good. Or else we may take these words as an expression of inward cheerefulnesse, by the outward manner of the world. Thus saith S. Austin was holy Crispina cheerefull,Augustin. in Psal. 137.
Gaudebat quum tenebatur, quum ad judicem ducebatur, quum in carcerem mittebatur, quum ligata producebatur, quum in catastâ levebatur, quum audiebatur, quum damnabatur. In his omnibus gaudebat, & eam miseri miseram putabant, quae coram Angelis gaudebat, She was merry when she was apprehended, when she was led to the Judge, when she was sent into prison, when being bound she was brought forth, when she was lifted up in the cage, when she was heard, when she was condemned. In all these things she rejoyced, and they who were miserable thought her to be miserable, who rejoyced before the Angels. Of this cheerefulnesse Gilbertus speaking saith, Quis dabit hortulo meo hanc aquam? Quis dabit, ut tota hortuli mei facies irigua sit laetitia, & lucis rivulis nihil in eo aut sterile sit, aut quadam indevotione triste? vicina sterilitati videtur operatio tristis, & spiritualis gaudii carens irrigatione, Who will give into my little garden this water? who will cause that the whole face or plot of my garden may be watered with cheerefulnesse, so that by the rivers of light somnesse,
there may be nothing in it either barren, or else sad by a kind of indevotion. For a sad working,Gilbert. Serm. 34. in Cantu. and wanting the watering of a spirituall cheerefulnesse, seemeth to be nere unto barrenesse. For that shall a bide with him of his labour: and make him to abide and continue though troubles assault him never so much. Hoc comitabitur eum in labore, this shall a bide with him, keepe him company in his labour, saith Arrias Montanus, and make him able to a bide his labour: Saint Hierome addes, Et ipsum egredietur cum eo de labore suo, And that shall go with him out of his labour, as leading him also the sooner and the better out of it. The dayes of his life. The Hebrew is the dayes of his lifes, and though it be an Hebraisme yet we may take it, as speaking of the two kinds of mans life, either in trouble or in comfort, and of his dayes in both. When the Prophet David saith▪ Every day will I blesse thee,
Psal. 145.2. Saint Austin noteth upon it, Non mirum est si laeto die tuo benedicis Deum tuum, August. in Psal. 144. It is no mervaile if in thy cheerefull day thou dost blesse thy God with cheerefulnesse: but if a sad day come, if troubles fall upon thee, and then thou beare them with a cheerefull hart, then thou be cheerefull in praising the Lord, this is that which David saith that he would doe, this is that which the Sonne of David here would have thee to doe. Which God giveth him under the Sunne: The dayes of man being under the Sunne, their course is like unto the Sunne, and as the Sunne sometimes shineth, sometimes is clouded, so the dayes of man are sometimes cleare, sometimes dark. Ʋnder the Sunne they are, but yet given by God who is above the Sunne: from his providence come both good and bad dayes unto us. There were three dayes before the Sunne was made, and that was to shew, that God is the Authour, and not the Sunne, of the day unto us. And surely he it that is the Author of the goodnesse or badnesse of our dayes unto us. And therefore let us still be cheerefull, as thankfull for his favour, as resting in his providence, as contented in his will, as obedient to his pleasure.

q.p: Ver. 16. When I applyed mine heart to know wisdome, and to see the businesse that is done upon the earth (for also there is that neither day nor night seeth sleepe with his eyes.)

Ver. 17. Then I beheld all the worke of God, that a man cannot find out the worke that is done under the Sunne; because though a man labour to seeke it out, yea further though a wise man thinke to know it, yet shall he not he be able to find it.

div.p:
Psal. 1.2. Ver. 16. The Prophet David speaking of a blessed man saith, his delight is in the law of the Lord, and in his law doth he meditate day and night: where there is first a delight, there followeth such an earnest meditation, as that it ceaseth not day nor night. And so here where the hart to is applyed to know wisdome, there is such a seeking of it, as that neither day nor night he seeth sleep with his eyes. But as Saint Ambrose noteth, that he meditateth day and night, In quo non tàm continua legendi postulatur intentio, quàm servandae legis affectus. Ille enim plenè meditatur, qui sibi ipsi lex, Ambros. in Ps. 1
scriptum in corde suo opus legis intendens, In whom there is not required so much a continuall eagernesse of reading, as an earnest affection to the keeping of the law. For he meditateth fully, who is a law to himselfe intending the work of the law written in his hart. In like manner, the study of wisdome night and day is not so much to beate and break the braynes in the apprehension of it, as rather to make a right use of it, by the application of the hart unto it. Meditetur ergo legem vita nostra; meditetur conversatio, meditetur actus, Let our life therefore saith S. Ambrose meditate the law, let our conversation meditate it, let our actions meditate it; & so let me say, let the governement of our wayes study wisdom, let the framing of our works study it, for that is to apply the hart to know wisdome. But what is the wisdome which the Preacher is so earnest to know? To see the businesse that is done upon the earth, that is to see the wisdom of Gods providence in ruling and ordering the affaires of the earth. And indeed as the glorious wisdome of God doth therein shine unto us, so it is needfull to observe it, and to looke into it. Seneca observeth it with wonder in the use of the winds, which suffer not the ayre to wax muddy, sed continuâ vexatione utilem reddunt vitalemque tracturis, But by a continuall vexation tossing and taring of it, doe make it to be usefull and vitall unto them that draw it in; which, that the fruits may be gathered, blow away those superflous things which are mixed with them, Et latentem fructum, ruptis velamentis suis (quae folliculos agricolae vocant) adaperit, Seneca l. 5. Qu. Naturall c. 18. & openeth the hidden fruit by breaking the coverings of it, which husband-men call the husck or hose of the corne,
which nourish plants and trees, and by shaking of them serve to ripen those things which they beare, drawing up the nourishment unto the top, which else might stay and be stopped: and which lastly give commerce to people devided far a sunder, and make man to know those things, whereof his owne countty would have left him ignorant. Seneca doth againe observe it, in the miseries of some, the ease and quietnesse of others. For saith he a fresh Souldier feareth the suspicion of a wound, but he that hath been long in the warres, boldly looketh on his blood, as knowing that often he hath won the victory, when he hath lost his blood; Hos ita{que} quos Deus amat, probat, indurat, recognoscit exercet, Sene: l. de Divina Provident. eos autem quibus indulgere videtur molles ventuis malis servat, Those therefore whom he loveth, he proveth, he hardeneth, he knoweth, he trieth, but those whom he seemeth to spare, he keepeth them tender, for evils to come. It is needfull also to looke into the wisdome of Gods providence, thereby to be the better able to answer fooles who make objections against it. Some of them are proposed by Saint Austin, as Qualis inquiunt providentia, Getulia sitit, & mare compluitur? Et quare aliquando percutiunt montem fulmina, & non percutiuut latronem? What a providence say they is this, Getulia is dry and thirsty, and the sea is rayned upon? And why sometimes doe the lightenings shrike the mountaines, and not strike the robbers which are upon them? As for the sea, the Father answereth, that there are creatures living in it, which have need of of fresh waters, and which therefore doe often come into the fresh rivers for them. And whereas the objection going further saith, Quare pisci pluit & mihi non pluit aliquando? Why doth it raine for the fish and not for me sometimes? The Father answereth; Ʋt cogites te in regione esse deserti, & ut amarescat tibi vita praesens, futuramque desideres, That thou mayest consider thy selfe to be in a desert region, and that this life being bitter to thee, thou mayest desire that which is to come. As for Getulia he answereth, that in other places where corne can not be kept long, but is quickly corrupted,Augustin. in Psal. 148. there it raineth every yeare, and every yeare corne groweth: ibi quia raro, & multum datur, & diu servatur, There where it raineth more seldome, much corne is given at once, and it will also be kept a long time. Lastly as for the lightnings he saith, Majores majora noverint, & det vobis Deus plus sapere quam dico, They who are more learned know more, and God grant that you may understand more then I say: but let me say what I consider, Ideo aliquando percutitur mons, qui non timet, ut mutetur homo, qui timet, & tu quum das disciplinam, terram feris, ut infans expavescat, Therefore sometimes is the mountaine strucken, who can not feare, that man who feareth may be changed by it: thou thy selfe also, when thou reprovest thy child, dost sometimes strike the ground that the child may feare. To conclude this meditation, it is needfull to looke into the providence of God, that seeing his infinite majestie, goodnesse, love, power, wisdome, we may know him the better, and be stirred up to love him the more. For as Saint Austin speaketh in his
meditations, Quisquis Domine cognoscit te, diligit te, obliviscitur se, Aug. in meditationibus. & amat te plùs quàm se, relinquit se, & venit ad te, ut gaudeat de te, whosoever, O Lord, knoweth thee, he loveth thee, hee forgetteth himselfe, and he respecteth thee more then himselfe; he forsaketh himselfe, he commeth to thee, that he may rejoyce in thee.

Vers. 17. Then I beheld all the work of God: he beheld all to be the worke of God, all the world to have been made by him, all things in the world to be ordered by him. For as Saint Austin speaketh, Quicquid hic accidat contrà voluntatem nostram, Aug. in Psal. 148.
noveris non accidere nisi de voluntate Dei, de providentiâ ipsius, de ordine ipsius, de nutu ipsius, de legibus ipsius, Whatsoever here commeth to passe, against thy will, know that it doth not come to passe but from the will of God, from his Providence, from his disposing, from his pleasure, from his laws. That a man cannot find out the work that is done under the Sunne: where, to find out the worke, is to find out the reason of the worke, and the manner of it. For the work it selfe is offered to the sight, but the reason, the manner of it, is that which cannot be discovered by man. Wherefore Saint Chrysostome considering those words of Saint Paul, When I was a child, &c. saith,1. Cor. 13.11. Quamvis puer, plura videat, audiat, & loquatur, & sapiat quidem, nihil tamen integrè; Chrysost. Hom l. de Incompreh. Dei natura. ità more pueri ego quoque & scio complura, modum tamen eorum ignoro, Although a child see, heare, and speak many things, and be wise also, yet it is not perfectly; so like a child, I know many things, but I am ignorant of the manner of them. For it is most true,Cyprian de Card • n. operibus Christi. as Saint Cyprian speaketh; Non patitur ad liquidum se videri divinitas, quam uti{que} investigatio fidelis aliquo modo adorat vel sentit, The Divinity doth not suffer it self to be discerned plainly, which yet a faithfull searching in some measure adoreth, or perceiveth. A faithfull searching perceiveth so much, as to adore God for that which man cannot perceive, and dareth not in any thing to blame that which is done by him. He that commeth into a workmans shop, and seeth many tooles there, Si non habeat peritiam artificis, & habeat saltem considerationem hominis, quid sibi dicit? If he have not the skill of the artificer, yet if he have at least the consideration of a man in him, what doth he say to himselfe? Surely these things doe not without cause lie here: the workman knoweth why, though I know not. In officinâ non audet vituperare fabrum, & audet in mundo reprehendere Deum, In the shop he dareth not to reprehend a workman, and shall any one dare in the world to reprehend God,Aug. in Psal. 148. saith Saint Austin. But if a man know not the worke that is done under the Sunne, much more doth he not know that, which is done above the Sunne. The counsels of God are much more hidden from him, if that which the Sunne shews him yet be concealed from him. Because though a man labour to seek it out: the labour of man by seeking findeth much, but this it cannot find; in this saith Saint Hierome, Nihil aliud proficit, nisi in suâ tantùm quaestione torqueri, & disputationem pro tormento habere, nec tamen invenire quod quaerit, It profiteth nothing
else but to be tortured in its owne rack, to be tormented with its owne disputation, and yet not to find that which it seeketh. Chrysost. Dei Incomp. Dei Nat. Hom. 3. The Uulgar Latine reads it; Et quanto plus laboraverit ad quaerendum, tanto minus inveniet, And by how much the more it shall be labour to seek, by so much the lesse it shall find it. For as Lyra noteth, ex tali curiosa inquisitione, frequenter aliquis in errorem incidit, From such a curious seeking oftentimes a man falleth into errour. Yea, indeed the wayes of God are such, that not onely being sought they cannot be found, but that they cannot be sought also. Wherefore when Saint Paul saith; that God dwelleth in light, which no man can approach unto, Saint Chrysostom noteth, Diligentiae Pauli attende, non dicit lucem incomprehensibilem, sed lucem inaccessibilem, quod longe amplius est. Quod en: inquisitum & investigatum comprehendi non potest, id dicimus incomprehensibile esse, quod autem neque investigandi ullo modo operam patitur, & ad quod nemo proprius accedere potest, id inaccessibile est, Observe the diligence of Paul, he doth not say a light incomprehensible, but a light inaccessible, which is much more. For that which being sought and searched for, cannot he comprehended, we say is incomprehensible, but that which suffereth not by any means the labour of searching after, and which no one can come neere that is inaccessible. Yea, further, though a wise man think to know it, yet he shall not be able to find it out: a wise man thinketh with himselfe, that he can know much, and he resolveth with himselfe that he will know much, but let him think of himselfe what he can, let him resolve with himselfe what he will, his thoughts in his kind are vaine, his resolution fruitlesse, he cannot find out the wayes of Gods Providence.
