q.p: Ver. 11. I returned and saw under the Sunne, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battel to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of skill, but time and chance happeneth to them all.

Ver. 12. For man also knoweth not his time, as the fishes that are taken in an evill net, and as the birds that are caught in a snare; so are the sonnes of men snared in an evill time, when it falleth suddenly upon them.

div.p:
Vers. 11. The Preacher keeping himself unto his maine argument, which is to shew the vanity of the things of this world, saith,Lyra in hunc vers. I returned and saw under the Sun, that is saith Lyra in habitatione hominum, in the dwellings of men. For God is said to have placed his tabernacle in the Sun, but men have their tabernacles under the Sun. That the race is not to the swift. Which in a fuller and plainer manner is well set
downe by Olympiodorus, who saith, Aliud contemplatus sum, quod vincere in cursu, non sit cujusque levis & expediti adcurrendum, neque omnium qui potentes sunt egregios ac invictos se praestare in praelio, neque ad prudentes sapientesque viros atque industrios divitiis devolvi, sed nec eos qui multa noverint, Olympiodor. in hunc vers. gratiam consequi, I considered another thing that to overcome in running is not the glory of every one, who is light and nimble in running, neither is it the triumph of all, who are mighty to make themselves victorious and conquerours in war, neither is it the happinesse of prudent wise and diligent men that riches are cast upon them, neither is it also the successe of those who know many things to find grace and favour. The drift of the Preacher is to shew that all the providence of man is uncertaine, and that after all care taken, much watching used, and all things made ready, yet when it comes to the point, even he that is most mighty, he that is most circumspect findeth that he hath not some thing that is necessary. And it is as if the Preacher had said, gather into one even all the gifts of humane nature, whether speed, or valour, or wisdome, or industry, together with ability of all the arts and sciences, all these will faile when there is occasion of them, all these will confesse that they have not that which they are. And when it should appeare, what they are, the most swift shall not have the race, the most valiant shall not have valour, neither shall art science or diligence have their use and benefit. Surely he is a foole, who in the providence of man doth not see even those things which are most certaine and most ready to misse of their mark. And indeed from hence especially is shewed the providence of God, and that it is that alone which hath at hand all things necessary, and which therefore never faileth in the proposed end. When wee read of the Samaritane, who travelling by the way, and falling upon a wounded man, beeing moved with compassion bound up his wounds, and powred wine and oyle into them. Doth it not seeme much that beeing but a traveller and passing on the way he should have wine and oyle in readinesse with him? Luc. 10. Suppose that he might cary wine with him, yet whence should he have oyle? Or suppose he might also carry oyle with him, because wee read that Jacob travelling by the way, and erecting a pillar powred oyle upon it: yet where had he things needfull for ligatures to bind up the wounds? Surely this Samaritane was not man but God, and that is plaine even from this alone that he had all things needfull for the cure prepared and in readinesse: whereas in the pinch of time either all things or many things would have been wanting unto humane Providence.Origen. Homil. 34. in Luc. Atleastwise as Origene speaketh, Ʋt scias quod secundum providentiam Dei Samaritus iste descendit ut curraret eum qui inciderat in latrones, manifestè doceberis ex eo, quod secum habebat alligaturas, secum oleum, secum vinum, that thou mayest know that it was by Gods providence, that the Samaritane came downe for the curing of him who fell among theeves, thou shalt be taught it manifestly from hence because he had in readinesse by him bindings, in readinesse oyle, in
readinesse wine. But time and chance happeneth to them all: that is saith Olympiodorus, incerti rerum eventus, nihilque est hominibus tanquam satis, nihil undique perfectum, nihil aequale, omniaque fere dissimili sine terminantur, the events of things are uncertaine,Olympiod in hunc vers. and there is nothing unto men that is as it were sufficient, there is nothing every way perfect, nothing that goeth on in an equall and like course, but all things almost in the issue have an end unanswerable to the beginnings & proceedings. But here Aquinas noteth two things, first that this is not so spoken, quod omnia quae in eis fiunt sint casualia, sed quia in quolibet eorum aliquid casuale inveniri potest, not that all things which are done in them doe happen by chance, but because in every one of them there is somthing of chance which may bee found. Secondly he noteth, Aquinas 1. Qu. 103. Ar. 5. quod ad ostendendum casualia secundum ordinem alicujus superioris causae provenire non dicit simplicit er quod vidit casum in omnibus esse, sed dicit tempus & casum quia scilicet secundum aliquem ordinem temporis casuales defectus inveniuntur in rebus, that to declare casuall things to come to passe according to the ordering of some superiour cause, he doth not simply say, that he saw chance in all things but he saith time and chance, namely because it is according to some ordering of time, that casuall events are found to bee in things. And the reason also why casuall events are found in things is well given by Saint Hierome who saith, Haec autem fiunt quia incerto statu feruntur omnia, Hieronym. in hunc vers. & non est in praesenti retributio meritorum, sed in futuro, but these things are done, because all things are carryed on with an uncertaine condition, and because it is not in this world, but in that which is to come, that there shall be a reward of worth and desert. So that by chance the Preacher intendeth nothing else but the disposing of things by God, wherein man is uncertaine altogether and ignorant what they will be in a more hidden sense which Saint Hierome calleth, secundum 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 according to the anagogall meaning, the same Father explaineth the verse thus; he that is bound with chaines of iron, and loaded with weights of lead (for iniquity is a talent of lead) is not fit for the race of which the Apostle speaketh, I have finished my course.
Zach. 5.7. 2 Tim. 4.7. I have keept the faith. But he that is light, and whose soule is not burdened, notwithstanding he is not able without God his helper to attain to the goal. And whereas there is a battle to be fought against opposing powers, even he that is strong shall not be able to overcome by his owne strēgth. He also that is perfect and wise among the Sons of men,Hieronym. in hunc vers. yet cannot have the heavenly bread of life, unles it be by wisdome exhorting and calling him, come eate of my bread.
Proverb. 9.5. And because there be not riches wanting, of which the Apostle saith, be rich in good works;
Tim. 6.8. and els where, ye are rich in all uterance, and in all knowledge, it must be known that a wise man cannot get these riches, unlesse he receive them from the Lord, whose riches they are. Favour also unlesse it be accompanyed with knowledge and granted by God, although he be a learned man, he shall not be able to find it. Lastly it is a thing unknown
to man, when the time shall come, in which the various event and end of all things shall be.

Vers. 12. For man also knoweth not his time: the septuagint and the vulgar latin read it thus, Et quidem nescit homo finem suum, and truely man knoweth not his end. Now that is a time indeed on which the welfare of man doth principally depend, and for which he ought carefully to be alwayes ready, seeing he doth not know the time when it shall be. Wherefore Saint Bernand saith, Miser quare omni hora te non disponis? Bernard. Serm. 26. in Cantic. Cogita te mortuum, quum scis de necessitate te moriturum, O miserable man, wherefore dost thou not dispose thy self every houre for thine end? Think thy self to be dead, who knowest that of necessity thou must dye. And to stirre up the same care in us Saint Gregory saith,Gregorius. nemo in hujus vitae itinere torpeat; ne in patria locum perdat. Quod eum adhuc hodie licet bene agere scimus, utrum cras liceat ignoramus, let no one be negligent in the journy of this life, least he loose his place of abode in his country. For we know that we may doe good, while it is yet to day, but we know not whither we shall be able to morrow. But to consider the reading of our translation, which is according to the Originall. The ignorance of man in not knowing his time is more then of beasts. Jeremy. 8.7. For the Prophet Jeremy saith, the stork in the heaven knoweth his appointed times, and the turtle and the crane and the swallow observe there comming. In Cassiodore King Theodoric shewing the same saith, Mergi quibus nomen est ex facto, cohabitatores piscium, aquatiles volucres futuras tempestates naturaliter praevidentes sicca petunt, stagna derelinquunt, The Mergi, (we take them for the Cormorant) who have their name from their deed, the cohabitants of fishes and water fowles; for seeing naturally tempests that are to come, leave the lakes and get to drye places.Cassiodorus Var. l. 3. Var. 48. He speaketh also of the Echini: a kind of fish, who are as he describeth them, mella carnalia, constatilis teneritudo, croceae delitiae divitis maris, dum futuras tempestates agnoverint loca mutare cupientes, quia illis prae levitate corporis nandi nulla fiducia est, lapillos quibus pares esse possint complexi, quadam anchorarum ponderatione librati; scopulos petunt, quos fluctibus vexandos esse non credunt, a fleshy hony, a firm softnesse, the saffron delights of the rich sea, when they perceive tempests to be comming, desiring to chang their places, because they trust not to their owne swimming in regard of the lightnesse of their body, they take unto them little stones, such as they may be able to rule and master, and being poised by them as it were by the weight of anchors, they get unto the rocks, which they beleive the waves will not be able to disquiet. Thus these creatures herein may seeme to excell man, who is a creature far more excellent then they. But the reason why man knoweth not his time, is, that he may acknowledge God to be the ruler of his time, and may depend rather upon his providence then upon his owne strengh and circumspection. Psal. 31.14.15. Wherefore the Prophet David saith, I trusted in thee O Lord, I said thou art my God. My times are in thy hands. Which is as if he said, it is not in my carefulnesse,
not in myne inventions, not in the projects of the discourse of my mynd, that the event of myne affaires, my good and happinesse are placed: but in thy hands O Lord, thy will, thy judgement for these are the hands of the Lord, by which he worketh. As the fishes that are taken in an evill net: first the net is said to be evill, because evill for them, as the French translation addeth to make the sense plainer. And so doth Tremellius expound it saying, Damnoso sibi & calamitoso, a net evill and hurtfull and dangerous to themselves: But it may be also called an evill net, as being a net of deceipt and prey, and as shewing those things to be evill in men. Secondly by their speach the Preacher hath reference to what he had said before in the former vers: for fishes are swift in their course of swimming, but meeting with a net are stopped in their way, so that the slow paced worme doth often out goe them, even as he that is swift in running meeting with some accident that he knew not of, leaveth the race to him that in swiftnesse came behind him. And as the birds that are caught in the snare: this also hath reference unto the former verse. For as birds whose wings are ready to carry them on high meeting with a snare are kept below and hindred in their flight, so that the butterfly gets up higher then they; even so men of skill are forward by their skill to fly into favour, but meeting with some event not thought upon by them they are kept below and out of favour, when some others of lesse skill have more favour then then they. So are the sons of men snared in an evill time: Philo shews it in them who are strong and win not the battel saying, athletae robore freti & bona corporis habitudine, dum certam sibi pollicentur victoriam, vel exclusi sunt è certamine, vel victi ab adversariis: alii ne secundam quidem palmam sperantes primam coronam reportaverunt praemium wrestlers furnished with strength and enjoying a good disposition of body, while they promise themselves a certaine victory, are either excluded from the game or conquered by there adversaries:Philo de Joseph. others who did not so much as hope for the second garland, have carried away the first crowne as their reward. He shews also that riches are not to men of understanding, quidam negotiatores certa lucra sibi proponunt, securi de periculis; alii de damno soliciti magnum fecerunt operae pretium, Some merchandising dealers propose unto themselves by their understanding certaine gaines, and are secure of dangers, which yet they fall into: others are much troubled with feare of their losses, who come to great gaines. When it falleth suddenly upon them: that is unlookt for, unthought of, unknowne altogether. For as Philo speaketh, qui vigilant, quantum ad incertam perceptionem attinet nihil a dorminentibus differunt, seipsos fallendo, dum seputant rerum naturas clare perspicere, they who are watchfull, for as much as pertaineth to an uncertaine apprehension, doe not differ any thing from them that are asleepe, by deceiving themselves,Philo. Ibid. while they think themselves to perceive certainly the nature of things. Againe he saith, proinde tanquam altum dormientes erramus, non valentes quicquam ratiocinatione vel penetrare vel certo
comprehendere, quando cuncta umbris spectrisque sunt similia, wee are therefore like those that are a sleepe, not being able by reasoning to peirce into any thing, or certainely to comprehend it, when all things are like to shadows and phantasies. But this ignorance of man in not knowing his time, and this uncertanity of humane events, must make him in wisedome to provide even for those things which he doth not feae nor look for.Cassiodor. l. 3. var. 48. Wherefore King Theodoric in Cassiodore saith, providentiae est cavere, etiam quae non putantur emergere. Munitio tractanda est semper in otio. Quia tunc male quaeritur quando necesse indicitur, It is the part of providence to take heed of those things which are not thought to come to passe. Fortifying is to be done in quietnesse. Because it is then ill sought for, when it is commanded as necessary. And this it is also which Seneca adviseth.Senec. l. 2. Epist. Epist. 18.
In ipsâ securitate animus ad difficilia se preparet, & contra injurias fortunae inter beneficia firmetur, In security it selfe let the mind prepare it selfe for troubles, and against the injuries of fortune let it be stengthned even in the middest of favours.

q.p: Ver. 13. This wisdome have I seene also under the Sun, and it seemed great unto me.
Ver. 14. There was a little City, and few men within it, and there came a great King against it, and beseiged it, and built great bulwarkes against it.
Ver. 15. Now there was found in it a poore wise man, and he by his wisdome delivered the City, yet no man remembred that same poore man.
Ver. 16. Then said I, wisdome is better then strength; never the lesse, the poore mans wisdome was despised, and his words not heard.
Ver. 17. The words of wise men are heard in quiet, more then the crye of him that ruleth over fooles.
Ver. 18. Wisdome is better then weapons of warre: but one sinner distroyeth much good.

div.p:
Ver. 13. The Preacher having shewed the insufficiency of humane wisdome, that thereby the providence of God might be the more glorified, & thereby man might be made the more carefully to seeke unto him, the more faithfully to trust in him. Least hereupon there might be some disesteeme of the worth of wisdome, or some neglect in the painfull getting of it: the Preacher here also sheweth, the excellent use and the glorious benefit of it, and with all the remarkable Providence of God in blessing of it. This wisdome have I seen also: he doth at once both shew it to others, and look himselfe upon it. He shewes it to others as commending it to them, he lookes upon it himselfe, as being a thing which he sees with admiration. He both shewes it and lookes upon it as being a rare thing in the world. Ecclesiastes 1. For as the vulgar Latin hath it before in this booke, stultorum infinitus est numerus, of fooles there is an infinite number. How many notorious fooles are there, who spend all their time care paines in getting of riches, and neglect that one thing which is necessary, the salvation of their soules? How many shamefull fooles are there, who having great riches, and might with a litle of them laid out in charity purchase the glory of heaven, doe by their wickednesse spend their means to sell themselves to destruction? How many silly fooles are there, who thinke a little crying, God pardon me, to be repentance enough, and that they can make their peace with God, when and how they will, as if the Father had left times and seasons in their power and not in his owne? Indeed who can number the follies of men, and the fooles that are among men? One saith, si ad mores hominum respicias, mundum universum stultorum domum judicabis, if thou beholdest the manners of men, thou wilt judge the whole world to be a house of fooles. But to find a wise man, to see wisdome is a rare thing and that maketh the Preacher to looke upon it. But what is wisdome? Philo tels us vulgus prudentem exstimat eum, Philo legis Alleg. lib. 1.
qui mores ophistarum inventione & locutione pollet plurimum, The most part think him to be a wise man, who after the manner of Sophisters is, able to find out devises, and with fluency of words to set out, what he would say. But himselfe tels us, that wisdome non est verbis sapere sed opere spectatum esse actionibusque ad virtutem compositis, is not to be wise in words, but to be approved in deeds and in actions composed to the rule of vertue. The wisdome whereof the Preacher here speaketh, is that which S. Ambrose describeth, vivacitate ingenii, mentis vigore atque autoritate posse praesentia solvere pericula, prospicere futura, denuntiare imminentia, argumenta expedire, remedium ferre in tempore, by a lively quicknesse of wit,Ambros. de Offic. lib. 2. c. 8. by a strength and command of understanding, to be able dispell present dangers, to foresee them when they are to come, to declare them when they are at hand, to dispatch businesses, and in time to bring help. Have
I seen under the Sun: wisdome under the Sun, but it is from above the Sun, James 1.5. that it is gotten. Saint James therefore saith, if any of you lack wisdome, let him aske of God that giveth to all men liberally and upbraydeth not, and it shall be given him. And Cassiodore saith well, sapientia à Domino Deo est, & cum ipso fuit semper & permanet in aeternum: qua propter toto nisu, toto labore, totis desideriis exquiramus, ut ad tale tantumque munus Domino largiente parvenire mereamur, Cassiod. Divin. lection. c. 28. wisdome is from the Lord God, it hath been with him alwayes, and remaynes with him for ever: wherefore with all our endeavour, with all our labour, with all our desires let us strive and seeke, that the Lord bestowing it upon us, wee may be thought worthy to obtaine such and so great a gift. Ʋnder the Sun the Preacher saw this wisdome, and it was as another Sun on earth, under the Sun of heaven. For as the Sun excelleth among the planets and starres of heaven, and is as it were the eye of the world; so wisdome excelleth among all the gifts of the soule, and is as it were the inward eye of the little world man. For as Philo speaketh visus mentis nihil aliud est quam prudentia, Philo lib. de Abrahamo. the sight of the mind is nothing else but wisdome. And it seemed great unto mee: the vulgar Latin saith, maxima very great, even so great is the beauty of it upon the earth, as the glory of the Sun in heaven. For as Philo speaketh, Pretiosa prudentia, Philo legis Alleg. lib. 1.
& inter opes divinas citra controversiam pulcherrima, pretious is wisdome and among the divine riches, without controversie the most beautifull. Most beautifull it is among the divine riches, most needfull it is among humane blessings. For as the same writer speaketh, sicut nostris corporibus interitum morbus, incolumitatem affert sanitas; it idem animas prudentia servat, quum ipsa sit mentis sanitas; imprudentia vero interimit quum sit morbus eorum insanabilis, as sickenesse bringeth destruction to our bodyes,Philo de Temulentia. health safety; in like manner wisdome preserveth our soules, seeing that is the health of the mind, but folly destroyeth them, seeing it is the incurable disease of them. Moyses speaking to the Israelites concerning their going into the land of Canaan, and saying when yee shall come into the, land and shall have planted all manner of trees for food, Levitic. 19.23. thereupon Philo noteth, that while they staid without that land, they were not able to plant such trees. And he according to his manner fetching out a mysticall sense from it addeth upō it, donec enim in sapientiae viā mens intrat non progreditur, sed errabunda vagatur, sylvestres tantum modo curat arbores, quae vel in totum steriles sunt, vel fructum ferunt ad cibos incommodum. Sed quando ingressae viam sapientiae, per decreta ejus ascendit, & incepit in his omnibus decurrere; tum mites & mitium fructuum colit feraces pro illis sylvestribus, tranquillitatem pro perturbationibus pro ignorantia scientiam, pro malis bona, Philo de plantatione Noe. for untill the mind entreth into the way of wisdome, it doth not go forward, but gadding wandreth up and downe, planteth only wild trees, which either are barren, or else bring forth that fruit which is not good to eate. But when it is come into the way of wisdome it ascendeth up by the rules thereof, and beginneth to run a course
according to all these rules, then it planteth better trees, and such as bring forth better fruit, instead of those wild trees, quietnesse instead of perturbations, knowledg insteed of ignorance, good things instead of evill. Lastly the Preacher saith, unto mee it seemed great: for it is the wisdome of another that the Preacher speaketh of, it is not his owne. Gregory saith Omnis cui sapientia recta est, plurima non est, Gregor. Morab. lib. 17. c. 11. every one whose wisdome is right, doth never thinke it to be great being his owne, if it be right, it never seemeth to be great unto him; but the wisdome of another he seeth to be great. Ʋnto mee saith the Preacher it seemed to be great; and as it seemed to him, so it seemeth to every one that hath wisdome and understanding, though perhaps others may sleight it, a foole may despise it.

Vers. 14. Rabbi Solomon saith Lyra expoundeth this verse, tanquam sic fuerit ad literam, as if there had been some such City on the earth,Lyra in hunc vers. and that it was so besieged, so delivered, as here it is set downe; but he sheweth not either how the City was named or how the King was called. It matters not for the scope of the Preacher, whether it were so or no, there being Cities on the earth great and little, and enemies that doe beseige them with great forces, this is sufficient ground for that which is said. But when we speake of Cities and of citizens, it is not amisse to remember, that this is only according to the speach of man, and in respect of them, of whom as they are compared one with another, some are said to be of one City, some of another, some are said to be citizens, some are not: whereas in truth as Philo speaketh, Solus Dominus Deus civis est, omnis autē creatura inquilinus & advena; Philo lib. de Cherub. qui vero dicuntur cives per abusum nominis magis quam verè sic appellantur, the Lord God alone is a citizen, every creature is a foreigner and stranger, they that are called citizens are so tearmed, rather by an abuse of the name, then properly and truly. For indeed the whole world and all things therein, as they are the works of God, so they are his possessions, which he lendeth unto men, because himselfe hath not need of them. But he that doth use them, doth not possesse them, because there is one owner and master of all, who rightly saith the whole earth is myne, and yee are strangers and sojourners in it. And this is not onely most true, but most usefull for comfort. For because men doe think the things of the earth to be their owne, therefore are they full of sorrow, when they are taken from them: whereas did they thinke themselves to be strangers to them, the losse of them would be the lighter to them. But to consider the City here spoken of. This verse sheweth the great ods, that is betweene the defendants and the assailants; for that is the basenesse of oppression, that it alwayes worketh upon great inequality. There was a little City, Et ideo poterat de facili obsideri, Lyra in hunc vers. and therefore it might be besieged easily: and few men in it, & ideo male poterat defendi, and therefore it could be hardly defended saith Lyra; yea the few men that were in it, were but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 weak sickly men as the Originall is. For the word is derived from the roote 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signifieth aegrum esse to be
sick and diseased. And there came a great King against it, not only a King, but a great King, great in his dominions, and being a King of many countreys, he came against one, and that one a little citie. And besieged it, besieged a few men with a great armie, with very many men, and encompassed them round, that at least they might perish by famine. And built great bulwarks against it: bulwarks as great as the little citie, and even little cities in themselves, being built as habitations for the souldiers to dwell in: These were the uneven tearms upon which the war was made, and what greater disadvantage could a poore little citie have. But taking the Preacher to speak metaphorically, the application which the Jews make of it, is by the little citie, here to understand man as Saint Hierome saith,Hieronym. in hunc vers. to understand the body of man, as Lyra saith, By the few men in the citie, to understand, as Saint Hierome saith, membra de quibus ipse homo contexitur, Lyra in hunc vers. the parts of which man is composed; to understand the members of the body, as Lyra saith. By the great King that came against it, to understand, as Lyra saith, Ipsum fomitem ad malum inclinantem, qui rex magnus dicitur, eo quod multi obediunt ei, the corruption of man which inclineth him to evill, which is said to be a great King, because many doe obey it. I have noted this difference betweene Saint Hierome and Lyra, in relating the exposition of the Jews, because thereby is perceieved how Lyra would draw the Jews to maintaine the doctrine of the auncient School-men, who placed originall corruption principally in the depravation of the sensitive part which is seated in the body.Philo de sacrif. Abel. & Cain. But that Saint Hierome relateth the opinion of the Jews, more truly appeareth from Philo, from whose ground, it may be that the exposition is taken; for hee saith, in uniuscujusque nostrum civitate quae constat ex animo & corpore, pro firmissimo propugnaculo sunt cogitationes amicae prudentiae, in the citie of every one of us, which consisteth of a soule and a body, a most firme and strong tower are those thoughts, which are the friends of wisdome. The application, which Christian writers make of the passage of Scripture metaphorically taken, Luk. 12.32. is, by this little citie here to understand the Church of Christ, which our Saviour himselfe calleth a little flock. For as Saint Bernard noteth, in the Scripture a citie, a spouse, and sheepe doe signifie one and the same thing: and that the Church is said to be civitas propter collectionem, sponsa propter dilectionem, oves propter mansuetudinem, a citie in regard of their unitie and gathering together, a Spouse in respect of the love of Christ towards her, and sheepe in regard of meeknesse and mildnesse.Bernard. Sup. Cant. Ser. 76. And wouldst thou know, saith Saint Bernard, a city and a spouse to be the same thing? Behold what Saint John saith, Revel. 21.26. and I saw the holy citie, the new Jerusalem comming downe from God out of heaven, prepared as a bride adorned for her husband. The Church then is the citie of God,Aug. de Civit. Dei. l. 11. princ. Cujus cives esse concupiscimus illo amore quem nobis illius conditor inspiravit, Whose citizens we desire to be by that love which the builder of it hath inspired into us, as Saint Austin speaketh. According to this exposition, by the few men in it, are understood
the faithfull members of Christ, which in respect of unbeleevers are indeed a very few. By the great King comming against it, and which besieged it, is understood the devill and his warfare against the Church of Christ. Who is said to be great, non quod magnus sit, Hierony. in hunc vrrs. sed quod magnum se esse jactitet, Not because he is great, but because he boasteth himselfe to be great, as Saint Hierome speaketh. But perhaps more agreeably to the Preachers meaning in this place, we may apply this citie unto vertue, which though of great worth, yet is of litle command. This citie it is, which as Saint Austin speaketh, doth not glory in it selfe, but glorieth in the Lord: this citie it is, which doth not seek her owne glory, but whose glory is God in the testimony of a good conscience; this citie it is, which doth not in glory lift up her owne head;Aug. de Civit. Dei. l. 15. but saith unto God, Thou art my glory, and the lifter up of my head, this is that citie, quem non fecit amor sui usque ad contemptum Dei, sed quem fecit amor Dei usque ad contemptum sui, Which is not built by a love of a mans self, even to the contempt of God, but by a love of God, even to a contempt of mans selfe. The few within this citie, are the few lovers, and followers of vertue. The great King which commeth against it, is vice, the greatnes of whose dominion is extended far and wide, and which besiegeth vertue, with the bulworks of affronts & tēptations, which it raiseth up against it.

Vers. 15. Now there was found in it a poore wise man: Saint Hierome reads it, and so the Hebrew is, et invenit in ea, and he found in it, as if it were to be referred to the great King, and did upbrayd him, that when he came with so great an army against so litle a citie, he found one man in it to be able to withstand him, and to defend the citie against him. The Originall word here used for a poore man, is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and signifieth him, who of his owne is so unable to helpe others, that he needeth help from others: which is here elegantly used, as shewing, that he who was not able to helpe others with his riches, yet was able to helpe them with his wisdome, and as implying, that though he needed the help of others for his reliefe, yet that they needed his helpe for their deliverance. For though he were a poore man, yet he was a wise man. Philo shewing the judgement of the world, saith,Philo de Nominum mutatione. Stultus omnis existimat pecuniis abundantem, externisque facultatibus affluentem, statim conspectum & prudentem esse; atque ut summatim dicam, prudentiam in re fortuita collocat, quum contra fortuitum in prudentia statuendum esset. Aequum est enim ut quod instabile est a stabili regatur, Every fool thinketh him who hath store of money, and aboundeth in outward estate, to be forthwith a prudent and a wise man: and that I may speak briefly, placeth wisedome in that, which is a thing of chance, whereas things of chance ought to be placed in wisedome. For it is just that that which is uncertaine, should be ruled by that which is setled. But indeed, there is none that can be a wise man, unlesse he be a vertuous man: for all the vertues being linked together, and wisedome being the bond in which they are tied, a wise man and a vertuous man cannot but be joyned also, wherefore that which Saint Ambrose saith of the just man, is true of the
wise man,Ambros. de Abel & Cain. l. 2. c. 3.
quam beata civitas quae plurimos justos habet, quam celebrabilis ore omnium, quomodo benedicetur tota de parte, & beatus atque perpetuus ejus status existimatur? How blessed is that citie which hath many righteous people in it, how famous is it in the mouthes of all, how is the whole blessed from a part, and how happy and established is the state of it accounted to bee? One such righteous man, one such wise man, is able in danger to deliver a City, for so it followeth. And he by his wisedome delivered the citie: In Plautus, Seragastio, a servant asking another, ut munitum tibi visum est oppidum? Plautus ex Persa. How doth the towne seeme to thee to be fortified: The answere which is given, is, si incolae bene sint morati pulchrè munitum arbitror, if the inhabitants be well governed and good, I thinke it to be well fortified: and then reckoning up many vices, hee concludeth, haec nisi inde aberunt, centuplex murus parum est servandis rebus, unlesse these things be absent, a hundred walls are but little for the preservation of it. And this it is which Saint Austin saith, who speaking of the evills of mans mind, the evils of his life, the evills of his manners, addeth,Aug. de Civita. Dei. l. 2. c. 3.
Quae ita magna sunt, ut his doctissimi eorum viri etiam stantibus urbibus respublicas perire confirment, Which are so great mischiefs, that by them the most learned among the heathen doe prove common-wealths to be ruinated, even while the cities are standing. Saint Ambrose also saith, Periturae urbis, aut malorum iminentum, vel futurae labis hoc primum indicium, Ambros. de Abel & Cain. l. 2. c. 3.
si decedant viri consultores, the first signe of a citie ready to perish, or else of evils that doe hang over it, or of destruction comming to it, is this, if wise men, who are able to give direction and counsell doe leave it, and by death depart from it. But one wise man, though a poore man, remaining in it, is able by his wisdome to deliver it; Yet no man remembred that same poore wise man: one would have thought that all should have rewarded him, yet such was their ingratitude, that there was no man that remembred him. No man that remembred the necessities of his want and povertie, who in their necessity had delivered the whole citie: no man that afforded him reliefe and succour out of that which he had, who by his wisedome had preserved unto all, all that they had: no man that honoured him, and gave unto him his due respect for it. Now what could be more unworthily done? What could shew people more shamefully wicked? For as Saint Ambrose speaketh, Nemo debet invidere alteri laudem, Ambros. Ibid. quae sibi prosit; utque improbus quisque redemptorem suum dum suspicit frequenter imitatur: certe veneratur, plerumque diligit, No one ought to envie anothers praise, which is his owne profit, and every wicked person, while he respecteth his deliverer, often imitateth him; at leastwise honoureth him, and oftentimes loveth him. But some as being more then wicked, are so puft up in pride with the conceit of their owne wealth, that even their safety bestowed upon them, by a poore man is not regarded; and such also is the hard condition of poverty, that the good, which a poore man doth, is not respected, not remembred. To apply now the applications, which were made of the former verse, unto this verse also. They who expound
the city to be the body of man, expound this poore man to be synderesin & dictamen rationis, Lyra in hunc vers. the prescript and rule of reason inclining unto goodnesse, as Lyra setteth it downe, and which saith he is said to be poore, quia pauca obediunt ei, because they are few that doe obey it. They who expound the city to be the whole man, expound this poore man to be the inward man, who is indeed poore in spirit. And he it is that is not remembred by the outward man,Hieronym. in hunc vers. nec subdit se consiliis ejus, sed rursum fruitur sua libera voluntate, neither doth subject himselfe unto his counsels, but taketh againe liberty to doe, as he will. They who expound the city to be the Church of Christ, understand the poore man to be Christ himself who for our sakes was made poore, and is not only wise but wisedome it self. He it is who delivereth his city his Church by his wisedome. How often saith Saint Hierome have we seen the Lyon with the forces of the world comming against the Church, and strongly besieging it, pauperis istius sapientia corruisse, Hieronym. in hunc vers. by the wisedome of that poore man to have failed in his enterprises, and to have been lost in them? But as the Father goeth on, when this poore man hath so prevailed, and peace hath been restored to the city, vix aliquis ejus meminit, vix aliquis illius mandata considerat, there is scarcely any one that doth remember him, scarcely any one that considereth his commandements, but giving themselves to pleasures and luxury seek after riches, which help not in the time of need, and in danger doe not deliver. Lastly if we expound the city to be vertue, we may expound also, the poore wise man to be wisedome it self, which is indeed the preserver of the vertues, and which is said to be poore because of the humility of it, whereby it seemes to it self alwayes to be litle. This poore man among the vertues themselves is many times forgotten when many, pleasing themselves with the good thing that is done, are not carefull to doe it wisely, whereby the goodnesse of it is lost and overthrowne.

Ver. 16. Then said I: he that hath prooved any thing may be bold to affirme it, and therefore in the verse before, the Preacher having shewed wisedome to be better then strength, here he is free to say it. But the Hebrew word (J) being set downe with an emphasis it implyeth that whatsoever others may or doe say, or whatsoever their opinion and judgement may be, I said, wisedome is better then strength. The Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 translated strenght, may be taken either for courage as it is a vertue of the mynd, or els for the outward force of the body, and other outward might and power. In both acceptions it is true that wisedome is better. For wisedome is the chiefe of all the morall vertues, and whereas it is commonly said, that there are foure Cardinall or principall vertues Aquinas saith, Aquin. 1.2. quod prudentia sit simpliciter principali omnibus, sed aliae ponuntur principales, unaquaeque in suo genere, that wisedome is absolutely the more principall then all the rest; and that the rest are set downe as principall in their kinds every one. The reason of it also is set downe by him: for seeing the good that is in humane actions consisteth in this, that they are regulated and ordered by
the due rule, it is therefore necessary that humane vertue, which is the spring of good actions be placed in a drawing neere unto the rule of humane actions: Now the rule of humane actions is twofold, God and humane reason. God is the first rule, and by him humane reason is also to be regulated. Hence therefore it is that the divine vertues, which consist in attaining unto that first rule, because God himselfe is the object of them, are more excellent then either morall or intellectuall vertues which consist in attaining to the second rule of humane reason. Hence it is also that among the divine vertues, faith, hope, charity, the chiefe of these is charity because that doth respect God in a neerer manner then the other doe. For faith and hope doe respect God, secundum quod ex illo provenit nobis vel cognitio veri vel adeptio boni, as from him proceedeth unto us either a knowledge of some truth, or else the obtaining of some good: but charity respecteth God, ut in ipso sistat, non ut ex eo aliquid nobis proveniat, that it may rest in God himselfe, not as from him is derived any thing to us. Hence therefore it is also that wisedome which respecteth humane reason, as in it self it is, is better then the rest of the morall vertues, which respect reason as from thence is taken, that which is the meane in humane actions and affections. As for fortitude in particular, as Saint Ambrose saith of it, quod fortitudo sine justitia est iniquitatis materia, quo enim validior eo promptiorest, ut inferiorem opprimat, Ambros. de Offic. c. 1. c. 35. that fortitude without justice is but the matter of iniquity, because the stronger it is, the more ready it is to oppresse inferiors; so it may be said that fortitude without wisedome, is but the matter of folly; because the stronger it is the more apt it is by folly to run into mischiefe. But in this place I conceive to be understood rather an outward force and might, then which, a vertuous wisedome is by far better, and not seldome prevaileth over it. That which is said to Rebecca concerning the twins that were in her wombe, Genes. 25.23. according to the Originall may be taken that the greater should serve the lesse, and Saint Austin taking it so,Augustin. affirmeth it to be true in the case of vertue. For though vertue appeare to be lesse, more vile, and despicable, at length it shall triumph over the most mighty, and subdue them under her command. How litle was David in power, when he fled from Hierusalem? How great was the might of Absalom? What therefore was it that made Cushi rather to joyne himselfe with David then with Absalom? Saint Chrysostome saith, that having considered both sides in his mind, he found Davids side although litle yet to be stronger, because justice was with it. Absaloms side though great, yet to be weaker because it was unjust.Chrysostm. in Psal. 7. And that therefore standing, non ubi multitudo hominum, sed ubi virtutis praesidium, opem Dei ad se traxit, not where there was a multitude of men, but where was the defence of vertue, he drew unto himselfe the assistance of God. The admonition of the Father is, that we would doe the same, and alwayes stand with them with whom standeth right, although they be never so many that doe withstand it. For as he concludeth, vitium etsi secum habeat
universum orbem terrarum est omnium maxime imbecillum, virtus autem etsi sola sit est omnium potentissima, vice although it have the whole world with it, is of all things most weak; vertue though it be alone is of all things the strongest. Neverthelesse the poore mans wisedome is despised, and his words are not heard: Saint Hierome reads it according to the Originall most directly thus, & sapientia pauperis quae despecta est, & verba ejus quae non sunt audita, and the wisedome of the poore man which is despised, and his words which are not heard. According to which reading the sense is; wisedome is better then strength, yea even the despised wisedome of the poore man, and his words which no man vouchsafeth to heare. The septuagint and the Vulgar Latin read it, Quomodo ergo sapientia pauperis contempta est, & verba ejus non audita? How therefore is the wisedome of the poore man despised, and his words not heard? As making a wonder and a strang thing of it. The French translation readeth the latter part of the verse thus, The wisedome of the poore man is despised and there is nothing heard spoken of his deeds: which as the Hebrew admitteth, so it answereth to the conclusion of the former verse, where it is said, and no man remembred that same poore man. To consider our translation; it seemeth to me to of a poore Prophet or minister, for poverty is commonly the companion of such. And too often it is that his counsel is despised, although it be taken from Gods word, which is of such excellency, that as Saint Chrysostome speaketh,Chrysost. Homil. 2. ad populum. Multis saepe unum verbum sufficit hinc excerpsisse ut totius vitae principium habeant, oftentimes it sufficeth to many to have taken one word from thence, that they might have a beginning for the ordering of their whole life. Too often it is, that his words are not heard? or if they be heard, it is only for the delight of them. Whereas Sainth Chrysostome saith,Chrysost. Homil. 2. ad populum. non est theatrum ecclesia ut ad delectationem audiamus, auditores hinc recedere oportet lucratos amplius, the Church is not a theater that we should heare for delight, the hearers must goe hence as having gained something.

Vers. 17. Saint Hierome most directly according to the Originall readeth the verse thus, Verba sapientium inquiete audiuntur, plusquam clamor potestatem habentis in stultis, The words of the wise in quietnesse are heard rather, then the cry of one that hath power among fooles. And as for the meaning of them, I conceive the Preacher to go on still in shewing wisdome to be better then strength or power, and as before he shewed it in the deeds of wisdome, so here he shewes it in the words of wisdome. For he saith, that the words of wise men in quiet, that is beeing delivered in softnesse and quietnesse of voice, and comming from a quietnesse and meeknesse of Spirit, which is not disturbed either with pride or fury, yea though they proceed from them, who live in the privatenesse and quietnesse of a low and meane condition, yet are heard sooner, and being heard prevaile more, then in fooles words that are. uttered with a lowd crye of the voice, with a strong passion of fury in the heart, with a domineering insolency of speach, yea though they
come from one, who for his place hath command and authority over them to whom he speaketh. The words of wise men are like the river Indus, of which Minutius Foelix speaking saith, Indus fluvius & serere Orientem dicitur & rigare, the river Judus is said both to sow the East and to water it; for so it may be said of the words of the wise that they are both semina & flumina, both seeds and rivers, seeds because they sow goodnesse in their hearers;Minutus Foelix in Octavio. rivers because they water that which is sowen and make it to grow in them. But the cry of fools is like a violent torrent, which washeth away that which it soweth, and doth not suffer it to continue in the ground. Saint Gregory speaking of a perverse Preacher saith, fortitudo ejus est elata scientia locutionis, qua inflatus caeteros despicit, atque in contemptu omnium quasi singulariter apud se peritus intumescit, his strength is a lifted up knowledge of speaking,Gregor. Moral. lib. 17. c. 3. by which being exalted he despiseth others, and swelleth in a contempt of all, as if in himself he were singularly learned. And what is the cry of fooles being in authority? What is the greatnesse and power of their words, but the same vain glorious pride, and which is despised by the hearers, as much as they despise them to whom they speak? By application wee may consider the truth of this in the Preachers of the Church whereof some, like wise men, deliver their words in quietnesse, in the quietnesse of a well composed speach and mind, and graced with the quietnesse of a well ordered life. Now these are they whose words are heard, for what is their voice but as Gillebertus speaketh, vox Domini, Gillebertus in Canti. Ser. 14.
vox intimae inspirationis mentis auribus suaviter illata, the voice of the Lord, a voice of most inward inspiration sweetly sliding into the ears of the mind? Of these Paulinus speaking saith, Ʋbique ancupemur verbum Dei, de omnium fidelium ore pendeamus, quia in omnem fidelem Spiritus Dei spirat, & necesse est à minimo Dei servo velguttam caelestis sapientiae distillare, quae ariditatem mei cordis irroret, & mihi supra omnium saeculi sapientum flumina, ad portum utilitatis exuberet, Let us seek every where after the word of God,Paulin. Epist. 4. let us hang upon the mouths of all his faithfull ministers, because the Spirit of God breatheth on every one that is faithfull, and it cannot be but that from the least servant of God, some drop of heavenly wisdome should distill to bedew the drynesse of my heart and to abound unto me into the haven of my profit, above all the rivers of the wise men of the world. Others there are,Hieronym. in hunc ver. who as Saint Hierome speaketh, in clamore vocis suae & populi acclamantis, in the cry of their owne voice, and of the people applauding them, doe please themselves, and are pleasing to the ears of others, but are not heard in their hearts, doe not work upon their consciences. For though their voice cry aloud, yet it is the cry of fooles, their lives being dumbe and themselves not practising that which they teach. Whereas Saint Chrysostome saith, habeat vita tua claram vocem, & licet os tuum obstruxeris, vel tuba clarius personabis, let thy life have a cleare voice,Chrysost. in Psal. 49. and then though thou stop thy mouth, thou shalt sound more clearly then a trumpet. And to the same effect
Saint Gregory saith, praedicator quisque plus actibus quam vocibus insonet, & bene vivendi vestigia sequentibus imprimat, ut potius agendo quam loquendo quo gradiatur offendat. Let every Preacher sound aloud rather by his actions then by his words,Gregor. Pastor. Curae p. 3. c. 6. and by his well living let him imprint steps for others to follow him: So that he shew them rather by his living, then by his speaking, whither they must go. The Septuagint and the vulgar Latin read the verse thus, Verba Sapientium audiuntur in silentio, plusquam clamor principis interstultos, the words of the wise are heard in silence, more then the crye of a Prince among fooles, where Lyra noteth, that it is said in the plurall number, the words of the wise or of wisemen, as shewing those words to be spoken of, quae procedentia ab ore sapientis proposita sunt sapientibus, Lyra in hunc vers. which comming frō the mouth of a wise man are delivered to wise hearers. For by them saith he they are heard in silence that is, attente, attentively and carefully. Or else their words are said to be heard in silence, because saith the Glosse, in silentio audientium, in the silence of the hearers, which is the same in effect. So that according to this reading the meaning of the Preacher is: that the words of wise men have more command over wise hearers then the proclamations of Princes have over fooles. Wherein is shewed as well the folly of not obeying the command of governours, as the power of wisdone in commanding wise hearers. And this seemeth to be the meaning of our translation.Tremedus in hunc vers. Tremellius read's the verse thus, verba Sapientium submissorum audienda esse potius quam clamorem dominantis cum stolidis suis, the words of wise submisse men are to be heard rather, then the crye of a foolish ruler, as he expoundeth himself. The French translation reads it thus, the words of the wise ought to be heard more quietly, or as the margent varyeth it, the words of the wise who keep themselves ought to be heard rather, then the crye of him that ruleth among fooles. The first reading suposeth the meaning to be, that the words of the wise ought to cause more attention, then the crye of him who for his crying beareth rule among fooles. The latter reading supposeth the meaning to be, that wise men, who keepe themselves quiet from tumult sedition and faction, are rather to be heard, then they, who by their factions and tumultuous crying and shrieking have great authority and power among fooles, whom they lead after them.

Vers. 18. Wisdome is better then weapons of war: the Preacher here seemeth to mee to answere an objection. For though it would be granted, that wisdome in war is better then strength, in respect of fore seeing dangers, and in regard of providing against them, and of preventing of them, yet it might be questioned, whether, when it came to the push, when it came to the joying of the battle or combate, strength then were not more to be prefered. For though in the disposing and ordering of things wisdome might have the precedency, yet it might seeme that in the acting and executing of them strength should have the upper hand. To take away therefore this objection, the
Preacher saith that wisdome is better then the instruments of war, which serve for the acting and executing of it. And indeed the Originall word here used to signify war is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which properly signifieth congressum & conflictum, the joyning and conflict of a battel of fight: So that the Preacher shewed even in this also wisdome to be better then strength.Amhros. de offic. lib. 1. c. 35.
Saint Ambrose noting of King David that in his war and fighting prudentiam fortitudinis comitem habuit, he had wisdome the companion of his valour, sheweth it in this, that when he was to fight with Goliah in single combat, he refused the armour and weapons of war with which he was burdened: virtus enim suis lacertis magis quam alienis integumentis nititur, for vertue relyeth more upon his owne-strength then upon outward defence. Indeed Goliah as the same Father els were speaketh, sub munitionibus undique circumseptus fuit, under the fortifications of his armour was every where walled in;Ambros. Serm. pro Comm. martyam. but David, nec operitur galea, nec praecingitur gladio, nec lancea utitur, & fortissimum illum armatum inermis occidit, is neither covered with an helmet, nor girded with a sword, nor useth a Speare, and beeing unarmed slayeth that mighty armed man: because by his wisdome which is better then weapons of war, he trusted in God who is the Lord of hoasts, what was it but a stratagem of wisdome which Gideon used against the Midianites? They were not weapons of warre wherewith he armed his souldiers, but a trumpet was in every mans hand, with empty pitchers and lamps within the pitchers, by which means, in trecentis viris de ingenti populo & acerbo hoste revexit triumphum, Ambros. de Offic. lib. 1. c. 40. even with three hundred men only he triumphed over a mighty people & a cruell enemy, as S. Ambrose also speaketh, But one sinner destroyeth much good: which S. Hierome expoundeth with reference to the former part of the verse thus, quod si unus insipiens fuerit, quamvis parvus aut nihil sit, crebro tamen per illius stultitiam opes magnas divitiasque subuerti, if there be one unwise man although he be meane and of little accompt yet often by his folly great wealth and riches be overthrowen. The vulgar Latin reads it as the Septuagint, Qui in uno peccaverit multa bona perdet; he that sinneth in one thing shall loose many good things: according to which sense Saint Hierome also saith that the Hebrew may be rendred. But then I conceine this one thing to be wisdome, for he that transgresseth in wisdome overthroweth what good soever there is else in him.August. pe lib. arbit. lib. 1. c. 13. Saint Austin defineth wisdome thus, est appetendarum & vitandarum rerum scientia, it is the knowledge of things that are to be embraced, and that are to be shunned: for indeed nothing can be embraced, nothing shunned as it ought to be unlesse that wisdome give direction in it. Wherefore the tenet of the schooles is, that there can be no vertue in man without wisdome, and hereupon it is that wisdome is most necessary in the life of man. Aquinas sheweth it thus, Bene vivere est bene operari, to live well saith he is to doe well: now that any one may doe well, it is not only required that he doe what he should, but that he doe it as he should, which is to doe it out of a good consideration,
and not of passion only. The consideration then of choice is in those things, which do respect the end, and therefore the rightnesse of this consideration requireth two things. The first is a due end, the second is that which is conveniently ordered for the due end. Now to the due end man is fitly disposed by vertue, whose object is a good end: but for that whereby a man is rightly disposed towards the due end, this is done by the right ordering of reason, because to consider and to choose are the actions of reason. Aquin. 1.2. Qu. 57. A. 5. Wherefore it is needfull that in reason there must be some intellectuall vertue by which reason may be perfected in this regard, and this vertue is wisdome, which is therefore most needfull for to live well. In a more generall acception of the latter part of this verse, it may betaken to shew the same unto us, James 2.10. which Saint James doth, who saith, whosoever shall keepe the whole law, and yet offend in one point he is guilty of all: that is saith Aquinas, Aquinas. factus est omnium reus, quia pro uno ac si pro omnibus peribit, he is made guilty of all, because he shall as well perish for one, as if he perished for all. For though he shall suffer greater punishment, that comnitteth more and greater sins, yet as for the loosing of the glory of heaven, and as for being cast into the torments of hell, he that breaketh one commandement shall find this to be his portion, as well as he that breaketh all. This was shewed in the law by a leper, Levit. 1.3. for as he that had the spot of leprosie in any one part of his body was accounted a leper, although all the rest of his body were sound and whole; so he who hath the spot of the leprosy of sin in any one thing, therby is deprived of the society of the Saints and of Gods people, though otherwise he may not be uncleane. The same was also shewed by the sacrifices: for that which was to be sacrificed to God, was to be without any blemish; because the blemish of any one commandement broken, taketh away the acceptance of all the rest that is done, and maketh it to be unpleasing to God, unprofitable to man. Saint Chrysostome Chrysostom. shewes it in a harp thus: as in a harp to make the musick good and harmonious, it is not enough that all the strings be rightly tuned except one: so, that the harmony of our life may be good musick in the eares of God, it is not sufficient, that nine of the strings of the Psaltery of Gods law be sound and well, if that one string of obedience be wanting. The command therefore of our Saviour Christ is, take my yoak upon you;
Math. 11.29. it is not sayd take it in your hands, or take it upon your shoulders, or else upon your head, but take it upon you, upon all of you, all over you. The words of this verse, Aquinas expoundeth thus, be that sinneth in one looseth many good things, that is,Aquinas. he that hath not charity which is the perfection of all vertues and graces, looseth them all, because they are inseparably united unto it. Wherefore Saint Hierome saith, Ʋbi est charitas quid est quod possit abesse? ubi non est charitas quid est quod possit prodesse? Hieronym. Where there is charity, what is there that can be wanting? where there is not charity what is there that shall not want the profit of it?

epigraph.q: Ver. 1. Dead flyes cause the oyntment of the Apothecary to send forth a savour; so doth a little folly him that is in reputation for wisdome and honour.

div.p:
Ver. 1. THe Originall admitteth diverse translations, and accordingly diverse senses: that which our translation expresseth, as it is agreeable to the Hebrew text, so it is pithy in it selfe. Lyra giveth the same meaning to it, but he fetcheth it about another way: and telling us that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the Originall word here used, and commonly signifying pretiosum pretious, doth sometimes signifie ponderosum heavy, he reads the latter part of the verse thus,Lyra in hunc vers. ponderosior est quam sapientia & gloria, stultitia parva, a little folly is more weighty then wisdome and glory. And he explaineth it, that a small defect in manners, which is here sayd to be a little folly, is more weighty then wisdome and glory: quia frequenter facit eam vilescere in persona aliqua notabili, because oftentimes it maketh that to be despised in some person of note. But whether it be a defect in manners, or otherwise, the truth is the same. Wherefore the shunning of this hath been the cause of much mischiefe in the world. For hence hath risen the Popes infallibility, the impeccancy of his judgement in matters of faith. For the Church of Rome being famous in the world and worthily glorious for those blessed lights of the Christian Church which anciently had been Bishops in it, to prevent the blemish, or at least to maintaine the credit of it against any occasion that might arise, this invention was set up, that a Bishop of Rome by erring could not be blemished. Hence it is also that many learned men have defended their owne errours, and that their followers have justified their masters in them. For that a small folly might not diminish the greatnesse of their fame, they have laboured to make even folly to be wisdome. Whereas this it is indeed which hath been
the dead fly that hath made the oyntment of their renowne to send forth a stinking Savour. For as saint Gregory saith, musca nimis insolens & inquietum est animal: in qua quid aliud quam insolentes curae desideriorum carnalium designantur? A fly is a very insolent and troublesome creature,Gregor. Moral. lib. 18. cap. 28: in which what else is signified then the insolent affections of carnall desires. Let a fly be driven away many times he still comes againe, and will not be kept away, he returneth to the oyntment untill he be drowned in it, and then makes it to give a stinking savour; even so it is with the affections of men, which although their understanding see them to be placed amisse, and doth as it were drive them away, yet they pressing upon them, untill they sink into them and fasten in them, doe then make the credit even of learned and famous men to be defiled and blemished. Wherefore the Chaldee Chald. expounding this verse saith, appetitus malus qui moratur ad portas cordis sicut musca, adducit mortem in saeculo, eo quod faetere facit sapientem in eo tempore quo peccat, & disperdit nomen bonum, quod simile erat oleo unctionis, quod confectum est aromatibus, an evill lust,Chald. which abideth as it were at the gates of the heart like unto a fly, bringeth death in this world, because it maketh a wise man even to stinck in that time wherein he sinneth, and destroyeth his good name which was like unto the anoynting oyle that was made of spices. But why should any man be ashamed to acknowledge his errours, to confesse his imperfections, seeing there is no man without errours, without imperfections?Hieronym. advers. Pelag. l. 2. Saint Hierome expoundeth the last part of this verse unto this sense, saying, muscae mortuae demoliuntur atque corrumpunt suavitatem olei; quis mortalium aliquo errore non capitur? Dead flyes destroy and corrupt the sweetnesse of the oyle; what mortall man is there that is not taken with some errour? Isa. 7.18. And in his comment upon this verse saith, muscae quae secundum Isaiam principantur in parte fluminis Aegypti perdunt olei suavitatem; in unoquoque credentium relinquentes immunditiae suae adorem & vestigia, the flyes which according to the Prophet Isaiah abound in some part of the river of Aegypt destroy the sweetnesse of the oyle leaving in every beleever the sent and footsteps of their uncleanesse. Another exposition which he giveth of the first part of this verse is this;Hieronym. in hunc vers. quod sic malus commmixtus bonis contaminet plurimos, quomodo muscae si morantur in unguento perdant odorem illius & saporem, that a wicked man mixed among good defileth many, even as flyes, if they dye in oyntment, destroy the sweetnesse and the savour of it. The last part of this verse Saint Hierome a greably also to the Hebrew readeth thus, pretiosa est super sapientiam & gloriam stultitia parva, a little folly is more pretious then wisdome and glory; and he giveth it this meaning, that because oftentimes wisdome is joyned with craftinesse, and prudence hath naughtinesse in it, he exhorteth therefore that we seeke after simple wisdome, which is joyned with the innocency of doves: let us be wise to that, which is good, and simple to that which is evill. Or else the meaning may be expressed thus, that a simple and downe right wisdome being no way crafty and
vaine glorious, which generally in this world is accounted for foolishnesse, is more pretious then wisedome and glory, that is then a vaine-glorious and ambitious wisedome, which is the wisedome of this world, being impatient of injuries under pretence of credit and honour, and given to ambition under a shew of vertue and of doing good. The Chaldee also reading this last part of this verse in the same manner, thus delivereth the sense of it, quam gloriosus & decorus est magis quam sapientia sapientium, Chald. & divitiae divitum, vir cujus insipientia est parva & modica? how glorious and beautifull is that man above the wisedome of the wise, and the riches of the rich, whose folly is little and small? that is, as I conceive, the wisedome of the wise in this world, being indeed no wisedome, though in their owne apprehension it may seeme never so great; and the glory of the rich being indeed no glory though in their owne eyes it seeme very bright, and dazle the sight of others: it is he who knowing that he cannot attaine unto true wisedome laboreth to make his folly as little as he can, that excelleth them both. Saint Bernard reading the first part of the verse as Saint Hierome doth, muscae moriturae exterminant suavitatem olei, dying flyes drive away the sweetnesse of the oyntment, or which is indeed rather a mixture of the translation of Saint Hierome and of the vulgar Latin, by allusion he applyeth it unto the oyle of Christs blood,Bernard. Serm. Feriae 4. Hebd. panosae. saying, absit quod mucsae moriturae exterminent suavitatem unguenti; quod de corpore tuo fluit, God forbid that dying flyes should drive out the sweetnesse of the oyntment, which floweth from thy body; because in thy blood is mercy, and there is plenteous redemption. Dying flyes are the blasphemies, dying flyes are the insulting mocks, which a wicked and provoking generation did cast upon thee: but thou diddest pray for them, saying, Father forgive them.

q.p: Ver. 2. A wise mans heart is at his right hand: but a fooles heart at is his left.
Ver. 3. Yea also when he that is a foole walketh by the way, his wisedome faileth him, and he saith to every one that he is a foole.

div.p:
Ver. 2. A wise mans heart is at his right hand: that is, in him things are placed and ordered contrary to the course of depraved nature, he doth not make that, his guide to lead him in his wayes, he doth not follow the courses of it; his wisedome sheweth the corruption of it. A fooles heart is at his left hand: that is, as nature inclineth him so is he carryed, he doth not strive against the corruption of it, that is his leader, after which he goes, and as a foole thinketh his way to be right because he followes that. Or els thus, a wise mans heart is as his right
hand, and he doth that in his actions, which his heart thinketh, his works and his heart are neere together: but a fools heart is at his left hand, he thinketh this and that, but he doth it not, or if he doe it, it is with the left hand very untowardly. Or els thus, a wise mans heart is at his right hand, that is, carried rightly unto the right object of it; for though the heart be placed at the left hand, yet in respect of the object which standeth as it were opposite and contrary unto it, it may be said to be at the right hand. But a fooles heart is at his left; the object at which he loooketh is not placed right before him, and he looketh as it were aside and awry in his desire, by which he is carried to it. To this purpose Lyra expoundeth it, who saith, the heart of the wise is at his right hand, quia dirigitur ad bonum moris per dextram designatum, Lyra in hunc vers. because it is directed to that which is good in manners signified by the right hand: and the heart of a foole is at his left hand, because he tendeth always to evill, which is signified by the left hand. Or els thus, the heart of a wise man is at his right hand, that is, he worketh nothing but that which is right, his actions as they come from his heart, so they come from a right heart intending good by them, and they are done in a right manner, a right heart being carefull so to order them and to performe them. But a fooles heart is at his left hand, and though his action may be good in it self, his heart is not good from which it commeth; or though his heart, his meaning may be good, yet that which he doth is spoiled and overthrowen in the handling and doing of it: or else his heart being naught, his hand, his works and actions are naught also. For according to the pattern in the heart, so is the work of the hand made. To this purpose doth Tremellius expound it, saying, Sapientem nihil nisi cogitate agere, & cum animo suo prius expendere quàm dextram adopus admoveat, a wise man doth not doe any thing without premeditation, but first he considereth it in his mynd, before he putteth his hand unto any thing. But a foole is carried on without consideration, & rationem & sapientiam a se depellere, Tremell. in hunc vers. ut quae aversantur homines fere sinistra depelluntur, and doth put away reason and wisedome from himselfe, as for the most part those things which men dislike are put away with the left hand. For so the manner is of fencers, who with the right hand assault there adversaries, and with the left hand defend themselves, and keepe off those things which would hurt them. Saint Hierome expoundeth it that the heart of a wise man is said to be at his right hand, because he hath no left. For saith he justus sinistram non habet in se, sed totum in eo dextrum est,
Matt. 5.39. a righteous man hath nothing in himselfe that is left; but all in him is the right. And to confirme this he alleadgeth the speach of our saviour in the Gospel who saith, resist not evill, but whosoever shall smite thee on the right cheek turn to him the other also. Where Saint Hierome noteth, non jubemur sinistram genam praebere percutienti, sed alteram dextram, we are not commanded to yeeld to him that smiteth the left cheek, but the other right cheek. Or els Saint Hierome expoundeth it, that a wise mans heart is said to be at his
right hand &c. because he that is wise doth alwayes think of the world to come,Hieron. in hunc vers. and which leadeth to the right hand, for there the sheep shall be placed: whereas the foole myndeth the present world, which is placed on the left hand for there the goats shall stand. To this purpose the Father alleadgeth the verse of the Poet, dextera, quae magni Duis sub maenia ducit, hac iter Elysium nobis: at laeva malorum exercet poenas & ad impia tartara mittit, there is the right hand which leadeth under the wals of great Pluto, this way we goe to the Elysian feilds: but the left hand bringeth to the torments of the wicked, and sendeth them into cruell hell. But to make use of the Originall, which may be translated the right side as well as the right hand, then if we read it A wise mans heart is at his right side &c, in respect that the side of a man is that whereon he resteth, we may give it this sense, that the heart of a wise man resteth on those things, which are at the right side that is on better things, in them taketh delight, in them placeth his confidence: but that the heart of a foole restest on those things, which are at the left side, that is, on worser things, upon them setteth his affections, in them placeth his affiance. Or lastly we may conceive that a wise mans heart is said to be at his right side, because it is joyned in affection to things that are vertuous, to heavenly and spirituall things, but the heart of a foole is said to be at his left side, because it is joyned in affection to things of pleasure, profit, honour and the earthly contentments of this life. But how few such wise men are there?Hiero. ad Demetriad. Vig. Ep. 1. how many such fooles? Saint Hierome complaineth, In omnibus mundi studiis profectu non satiantur homines, in virtute tantum caepisse sufficiet ferventissimi in terrenis, frigdissimi in caelestibus sumus, & summam in rebus parvis exhibemus alacritatem, ad majora torpescimus, in all the labours of the world men are never satisfyed with going on, in vertue it shall suffice to have begunne only: we are most fervent in earthly things, most cold in heavenly, and in the prosecution of small matters we shew great alacrity, but unto greater things, and things of importance we are quite dull. Saint Austin also complayneth of the same, saying, piger es ad faciendum ante te opus bonum, & strenuus es ad transeundum mare: quia avaritia imperat, servis, quia Deus jubet, Augustin. in Psal. 128.
odisti; thou art slow to doe a good work which lyeth before thee, so that thou mayest reach forth thine hand unto it, but thou art valiant to passe over the sea, for thy profit: because covetousnesse commandeth, thou dost serve it, because God commandeth thou dost disslike it. The reason of it is, because the heart of men is not at their right side, as the heart of wise men is; but at their left side, as the heart of fooles is. For so Saint Austin telleth us vis desideriorum facit tolerantiam laborum & dolorum, & nemo nisi pro eo quod delectat, sponte suscipit ferre quod cruciat, Augustin. l. de patientia. it is the force of desires that breedeth a quiet suffering of labours and paines, and no man doth willingly endure that, which tormenteth, unlesse it be for that which delighteth. But if we be such who have turned our heart to the right side, and are going on the way that leadeth to the right hand of glory, then as Saint Bernard
saith, Pudeat nunc negligentius in vitam, quam prius in mortē ire, & minori studio salutis acquirere quam perditionis augmentum, nam ut omnino simus in excusabiles in via vitae, quo citius eo facilius curritur, & leve salvatoris onus quo crescit amplius eo portabilius est, Bern. Epist. 341 let us be ashamed to goe on more negligently towards life, then before we went on towards death, and with lesse care to seek the increase of salvation, then of perdition; for that we might be altogether in excusable in the way of life, the faster it is run, the more easely it is gone, and the light burden of our saviour by how much greater it grows, by so much it is carried the more lightly, and is the lesse troublesome. Thus the words being metaphoricall, they may be taken and expounded divers wayes.

Vers. 3. The fooles heart in the verse before is said to be at his left hand, either because it is not carryed unto the right object, or else because it proceedeth not from a right beginning of due consideration: and in both these respects it is, that when he walketh by the way, his wisdome faileth him. For first when he is carryed to the wrong objects of this world, to the honors, profits, pleasures thereof, either he doth not attaine them, and so his wisdome faileth him; or els if he doe attaine them, he doth not find that good, that contentment in them, which he proposed and promised to himself, and so his wisdome failing him he shewed himself to all to be a foole. Secondly when his heart doth not proceed from the beginning of a due consideration, then also when he walketh by the way, when he is going on, his wisdome faileth him, he is not able to bring to an end that which he hath begunne, he is not able to performe that which he hath taken upon him, and so saith to every one that he is a foole. This is that folly which our Saviour speaketh of, saying, which of you intending to build a tower, sitteth not downe first,
Luk. 14.28, 29. and counteth the cost, whether he have sufficient to finish it. Least happily, after he hath laid the foundation, and is not able to finish it, all that behold it, begin to mock him saying, this man began to build, and was not able to make an end. Another way we may take the meaning of the verse thus: that a foole hath not so much wit, as to conceale his folly, and seeing he cannot shew his understanding, to hide the want of it; but even when hee walketh by the way, when he is in publike, his wisedome faileth him, and doth not keep him company, and he saith to every one that he is a foole: He saith it, and speaks plainly, although he say nothing, by that which he doth. And though he sayes it to every one, yet to himselfe he sayes it not, but thinketh himselfe to be very wise, and much wiser then they are, who see him to be a foole. Tremellius expoundeth the verse thus,Tremell. in hunc vers. that walking by the way, he is said to say to every one that he is a foole, Quia ipso vultu, gressu, & signis omnibus clamat stoliditatem suam, because by his very countenanc, gate, and all signes hee proclaimeth his stoliditie. But all these expositions referre He unto the foole himselfe, when wee read, and he saith to every one that he is a foole. Whereas according to the Originall, the word He may be referred also to every one. So doth Saint Hierome referre it, and therefore saith, that this is the meaning of
it, Stultus ut ipse peccat, sperat omnes peccare similiter, atque ex suo ingenio universos judiea, Hieronym. in hunc vers. A foole, as he sinneth himselfe, so he hopeth that all others doe sinne likewise, and he judgeth of every one according to his owne disposition. And the father shewes us; that Symachus did so translate the verse, as that he made this to be the meaning plainly. Hee therefore reads the verse thus,Aristot. Polit. l. 3. c. 6.
Sed & in via stultus quum ambulat, ipse insipiens suspicatur de omnibus, quod stulti sunt; but also a foole when he walketh in the way, being himselfe unwise, thinketh of all others that they are fooles. For as the Philosopher saith, qualis quisque est, tales existimat alios, Aug. in Psal. 118. Conc. 12. such as every one is, the same he thinketh others to be; the lascivious man, thinketh others to be lascivious, the covetous person, thinketh others to be couetous, the foole thinketh others to be fooles. According as Saint Austin also saith, hoc proclivius suspicatur homo in alio quod sentit in seipso, that doth a man readily suspect of another, which he findeth in himselfe: Exod. 32.17. & 18. When Moses and Joshua were comming downe from the mountaine, and heard a noyse in the campe, Joshua said there is a noyse of warre, but Moses said, The noyse of them that sing do I heare. Here was great difference in their judgement: but the reason was, That Joshua being a warre-like man, and addicted to armes, hee therefore judgeth the noyse to be a noyse of warre; but Moses being a man of peace, and given to peace, he judgeth the noyse to be a noyse of peace,2 Cor. 10.12. Aug. in Psal. 118. Conc. 12. each judgeth according to his owne disposition. To this purpose Saint Austin also alleadgeth that place of Saint Paul, when he saith, But they measuring themselves by themselves and comparing themselves among themselves are not wise. As if the meaning were, That they thinking others to be as themselves, and so measuring themselves by them, and comparing themselves with them, did therein shew themselves to be fooles both in their judgement of themselves and others. Neither is this the manner of fooles only, but sometimes of wise men also. Joshua being himselfe a simple honest man; true in his words and deeds, hee thought the same of others, and so was deceived by the Gibeonites. When the brethren of Joseph,
