Genes. 37.32. having sold him to the Ishmaelites, brought his garment to their Father, stayned with the blood of a kid; although Jacob knew the great hatred which his brethren did beare him, yet he never suspected what they had done unto him: for being himselfe a vertuous godly man, he could not suppose that any such villany should be committed by them. But that any one may not suspect evill of another, which is the too common fashion of people, it is good to observe the rule which Saint Austin giveth,Aug. in Psal. 118. Conc. 12. and that is, non videre quod latet, non invidere quod eminet, not to take upon us to see that which is hid, not to see that with an envious eye, which by the eminencie of it appeareth plainly. But as the word He in the last part of the verse is referred to every one, so Lyra giveth another meaning of it: when a foole, saith he, walketh by the way, that is in wickednesse and sinne, for that is his way, his wisedome faileth him, being therein, in truth, a very foole. He saith to every one, that goeth not in his way, that followeth not his courses,
that he is a foole, quia non sequuntur delectabilia hujus mundi, quae sola reputat bona, because they doe not follow the delightfull things of this world, which alone he esteemeth to be good things. And this is indeed the judgement which carelesse sinners have of them, that are religious and godly, they esteem them no better then fooles, thinking it strange that they run not with them into the same excesse of folly, speaking evill of them. 1. Pet. 4.4. And indeed this exposition agreeth well to the Originall, which speaketh of the way 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
secundum quod stultus ambulat, according to which, or wherein a foole walketh, as shewing that he gave his judgement in respect of the way. But it is in the way only that a foole hath this judgement, when he commeth to his journeys end, he will then be of another mind, and then he will confesse himselfe, and all that follow him to be fooles, and them only, to be wise, whom he accounted fooles. For the end shall teach even fooles wisedome, and then they shall wish that they had been wiser, who when they might have been, despised to imbrace it.

epigraph.q: Ver. 4. If the Spirit of the Ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place, for yeelding pacifieth great offences.

div.p:
Vers. 4. The Preacher having declared the nature of wisedome and folly, he delivereth next the effects of wisedome, and that in most important and necessary things. If the spirit of the ruler rise against thee: if the ruler be offended with thee, if angry at thee, if the flame of his wrath rise up high, as being great against thee, leave not thy place, that is, saith Tremellius, modeste te in statione tua teneto, nec rebellato, keepe thy selfe modestly in thy station, and doe not rebell against him. Or else as I conceive, the Originall words 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 may be rendred, doe not persist in thy place, doe not stand to make good, and to justifie that wherein thou hast offended him: and unto this, the following word of yeilding agreeth very well. Wee read of Jacob, how he went into another country, when his brother was angry with him, which Saint Ambrose setteth downe thus, Jacob fratri indignanti pie cessit, Ambros. de Offi. l. 1. c. 21.
& Rebecca id est patientiae instructus consilio abesse maluit & peregrinari quam excitare fratris indignationem, & tunc redire quum fratrem mitigatum putaret; Jacob religiously gave way unto his brother, being angry, and instructed by the counsell of Rebecca, that is of patience, had rather be absent, and in a strange country, then to provoke his brothers wrath, and then to returne when he thought his brother to be pacified. And surely it is wisedome in such a case not to stand to affront anger, but to goe aside a litle out of sight, or at leastwise by yeelding to give place unto it. Saint Ambrose reading the words as our translation hath them, and as they are read generally, ne relinquas locum tuum, leave not thy place, thereupon
saith, Locus tuus patientia est, locus tuus sapientia est, locus tuus ratio est, locus tuus sedatio indignationis est, Ambros. Ibid. thy place is patience, thy place is wisdome, thy place is reason, thy place is the pacifying of anger; leave not therefore these, in which thy welfare is placed. For yeelding pacifieth great offences, concerning the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which is rendred yeelding in our translation, Saint Hierome tells us, that generally in Greek it was translated 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
curatio aut sanitas, curing or healing, and so indeed it signifieth most properly, himselfe also therefore doth so translate it. But he tells us that Symmachus did translate it, quia pudicitia comprimit peccata multa, because modesty appeaseth many offences. The French translation reads it la douceur, meeknesse and mildnesse. But the word properly signifying healing or curing: I conceive that here it is used as importing a desire to make amends, a care to redresse what hath been ill taken, or ill done, an indeavour to recover the favour that is lost. And this is said to pacifie, or to make to cease great offences, both in respect of him who is angry, and in respect of him with whom he is angry,Tremel. in hunc vers. as Tremellius noteth. First in respect of the Ruler that is angry, because it stayeth his anger from running into the sinne of revenge, or some other the like, according as we read, that the wise carriage of Abigail stayed David, 1. Sam. 25.18. when he was highly angry with Nabal. Secondly in respect of him with whom he is angry, because it maketh his offences though great, to be pardoned, and freeth him from the hurt that hee feareth by them. But the ancient Fathers generally expound this verse in a spirituall sense. And the beginning of the verse being read thus by them, Si spiritus potestatem habentis, if the spirit of him that hath power, they understand this Spirit to be the devill, wherefore Saint Hierome saith, the Scripture here signifieth the Prince of this world, and the ruler of this darknesse, the spirit that now worketh in the children of disobedience, Ephes. 2.2. as Saint Paul speaketh of him. If he therefore ascend into our heart, and that our mind have received the wound of an evill thought,Hieronym. in hunc vers. wee must not willingly give place, but wee must fight against this evill thought, and strive to be freed from this sinne, so that the thought doe not proceed into action. And in another place, the same Father speaking of this verse, saith, Quasi in procinctu, & acie stamus semper ad pugnam, Hieron. ad Demetr. Epist. 8.
vult nos loco movere hostis & de gradu recedere: sed solidanda sunt vestigia & dicendum, statuit supra petram pedes meos, We are as it were ready, and stand alwayes marshalled in battell aray, the enemie would have us to leave our place, Psal. 40.2. and to remove from our station, but our steps must be setled, and wee must say unro him, He hath set my feet upon a rocke, and established my goings. Thus Saint Gregory speaking also of this verse, it is, saith he, ac si aperte dicat, si tentatoris spiritum contra te in aliquo praevalere consideras, humilitatem paenitentiae non derelinquas. Qui quod locum nostrum humilitatem paenitentiae dixerit, verbis sequentibus ostendit dicens, quia curatio faciet cessare peccata maxima. Quid est enim humilitas lamenti, nisi medicina peccati? as if he plainly said, if thou perceivest the Spirit of the tempter to prevaile in somthing against
thee, leave not the humility of repentance. For that he meaneth the humility of repentance to be our place, he sheweth by the following words saying, that healing maketh great sins to cease.Gregor. Moral. l. b. 3. c. 13. For what else is the humility of lamenting, but the remedy of sinning? Wherefore in generall he saith, malorum locus est superbia, sicut est contra humilitas locus bonorum, the place of sinners and evill men is pride, as on the the contrary the place of penitents and good men is humility. Beda also having cited this verse addeth, quod est aperte dicere, si principis mundi id est diaboli tentatio tibi forte institerit, caveto solcitus, ne à bona operatione cui insudabas, Beda in cap. 27. Proverbiorum. desistas if the temtation of the Prince of this world that is the devill shall presse upon thee, be diligently carefull that thou desist not from that good working wherein thou diddest painfully labour. Lyra saith that the verse may be understood of the devill, but himselfe applyeth it fomiti peccati, to the Originall corruption of humane nature, saying if the spirit, that is impulsus the strong inclination potestatem habentis, of that which hath power, Lyra in hunc vers. that is of naturall corruption, which is sayd to have power, because many do obey it as having power over them, shall rise up against thee, by pressing thee to sin leave not thy place, leave not thy stedfastnesse in vertue, in which a man ought to remaine as in a firme place. The reason followes, because healing will make great sins to cease, for though by resisting naturall corruption it be not wholy taken away in this present life, yet by such a resistance the power of it is diminished, & vertue both setled & increased, which is said to be a kind of health to the soule, and therefore by consequence a curing from infirnity. And this maketh sinne to cease, into which our naturall corruption would carry us, unlesse there were this healing or curing. He that is the Author of the Commentary on the Epistle of Saint Paul to the Epesians, which is found amongst Saint Hieromes works, folowing the generall exposition of this verse, doth thus expresse the meaning of it, Ille superbus & temerarius vult ascendere, sed etiamsi te oppressum putaverit, & se extulerit, ne tu dederis locum, potestas enim diaboli non in temeritate illius atque jactantia, sed in tua est voluntate, he, that proud and bold spirit, will rise up against thee,In c. 6. Epist. Ephes. but though he thinke thee to be overcome, and doe lift up himselfe, doe not thou give place, for the power of the devill is not in his boldnesse and bragging, but in thy will. Another exposition which I meete with of this verse is this, Si dominandi cupiditas animum tuum invaserit, locum prioremne facile deserueris, qui enim compescit in hujusmodi cupiditatibus animum suum multa vitabit & gravia peccata, if the desire of having power and ruling,Chald. Paraphr. that is the spirit of ambition shall assault thy mind, be not hasty in leaving thy former place and condition. For he that subdueth his mind in these desires shall shun many and great offences. For indeed they are many sins into which this desire carryeth men, and it is not an easy matter to overcome it, when it riseth up.Ambros. lib. 4. in Lucam. Wherefore Saint Ambrose saith, oftentimes those, whom no vices lead aside, those whom lust cannot move, whom covetousnesse cannot
overthrow, facit ambitio criminosos ambition maketh to be great offenders.

q.p: Ver. 5. There is an evill which I have seene under the Sun, as an error, which proceedeth from the ruler.
Ver. 6. Folly is set in great dignity, and the rich sit in low place.
Ver. 7. I have seene servants upon horses, and Princes walking as servants upon the earth.

div.p:
Vers. 5. There is an evill which I have seen under the Sun: it is still in hoc mundo subsolano in this world under the Sun that the Preacher seeth evill,Ambros. in Psal. 37. it is where fraile man ruleth, it is not as Saint Ambrose speaketh, Supra solem ubi sanctitas caelestium potestatum, above the Sun where is the holinesse of the heavenly powers. As an errour: Saint Hierome reads it quasi ignorantia as it were ignorance, and he tels us that the Septuagint, Aquila, and Theodotio did read it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
quasi non spontaneum as a thing unwillingly done. Which proceedeth from the ruler: the ruler here some doe understand to be God,Lyra in hunc vers. who as Lyra saith in truth can no way erre, but yet according to the judgement of foolish men he is supposed to erre: for they from the promotion of wicked men to dignities and honours doe not seldome say that God is a sleepe, or is deceived for want of judgement: whereas it is according to the dispensation of his wisdome and justice concealed from us why he sometimes suffereth the wicked to be exalted, the good to be cast downe: & ideo non hic dicitur per errorem principis absolutè sed quasi per errorem, and therefore it is not here said by the error of the Prince absolutely: but as it were by the error of the Prince because it seemeth so to fooles and simple ones. Others here understand the ruler to be the devill, who ruleth under the Sun, and thereupon they inferre this admonition as Saint Hierome sets it downe, ne simus itaque tristes si in hoc saeculo humiles videamur, scientes a facie diaboli stultos sublevari, & divites dejici, servos insignia habere dominorum & principes servorum ingredi vilitate, let us not therefore be sad,Hieronym. in hunc vers. if in this world we seeme to be in low degree, as knowing that it is from the favour and countenance of the devill, that fooles are exalted, and they who are rich in wisdome are cast downe, that servants doe enjoy the priviledges of masters, and Princes for worth doe walke in the basenesse of servants. Lastly others by the ruler understand them, who rule by autority and command in earthly government, and who have power and means to advance others to rule and command.
Now if such a one doe erre being a man, what mervaile can it be? Moyses therefore being neere unto his end, and praying unto God, let the Lord the God of the spirits of all flesh set a man over the congregation, Philo noteth upon it, Numb. 27.16. that Moyses himselfe durst not to commit the government to another, least perhaps he should be deceived in his judgement, and therefore not relying upon humane judgement and so not trusting to himselfe,Philo l. de Charita▪ he prayed unto God that he would choose a fit governour for his people. And it may be farther noted how he prayeth, Let the God of the spirits of all flesh &c. As if he had said, thou O Lord who peircest every man into the inwards of the spirit, and who seest not as man seeth, looking only upon the outward appearance doe thou choose a man. But although the ruler as beeing a man be a subject to errour as well as other men, yet it must be his care to erre as little as possible he can. Saint Cyrill observeth that in the law, whereas if others did sin God appointed a sacrifice and remedy for them, whether they sinned through ignorance or else with knowledge, in the sin of the high Priest there is not appointed any sacrifice for him if that he sinned by ignorance,Cyrill. l. 2. in Levit. quasi nullo modo in praelatis sit admittenda ignorantia aut defectus sapientiae ad suum munus requisitae, as if by no means there were to be admitted in them that doe rule, ignorance or defect of wisedome required to their place. Besides there had need to be a great care in the ruler, that shall choose others to rule and command, because it is a hard thing to discharg it. Nazianzene saith, difficile est homini imperare, difficillimum homines instruere & docere. Nazianz. Orat. 1. Apolog. Ars quidem artium & scientia scientiarum mihi esse videtur, hominem regere animal omnium maxime varium & multiplex, it is a hard thing for a man to rule, a most hard thing to instruct and teach men. It seemeth to me to be an art of arts, a science of sciences to rule man who is of all creatures most various and changeable. To the same purpose Saint Chrysostome saith,Chrysost. Homil. 15. in 2. ad Corint. imperium tenere non dignitas tantum est, sed ars etiam, & quidem artium omnium praestantissima, to have rule and government is not only a dignity but an art also, and of all arts the highest and most excellent. But that this care of not erring, by the ruler is not alwayes observed Nazianzene also sheweth, who complayning saith, Ʋno die sanctos fingimus, Nazianz. Oratione. 10.
eosque eruditos & sapientes esse jubemus, qui nihil didicerunt & qui ad sacerdotium nihil prius tulerunt quam velle, in one day we make men holy, and command them to be wise and learned, who have learned nothing, and who bring nothing before hand with them to the Priest hood, but a will only. And surely it would be a great help to the ruler for not erring, if they who are unworthy would not ambitiously seek for authority and command, and by a violent importunity even thrust themselves into it. Cicero saith well, Suum quisque noscat ingenium & exactum se judicem honorum & vitiorum praebeat, ne scenici plus quam nos videantur habere prudentiae, hic enim accommodatissimas sibi eligunt fabulas, Cicer. Offi. let every one know his owne ability and faculties, let him make himself a strict judge of honours and defects, of the honours that he seeks, of the defects
that he hath, least that stage players appeare to have more wisedome then we, for they doe choose unto themselves the fittest parts for themselves.

Ver. 6. Folly is set in great dignity: he saith not that a foole, but that folly is set in great dignity; either as shewing how exceeding foolish they are, who sometimes are advanced in worldly honour, even as foolish as folly can make them; or else as shewing, that when a foole is advanced, it is not so much himself as his folly that is set on high. For then his folly shews it self, himself as a foole is despised still. Saint Bernard complayning of this promotion of fooles in the Church, saith, scholares pueri & impuberes adolescentuli promoventur ad Ecclesiasticas dignitates, & de sub ferula transferuntur ad principandum praesbiteris, laetiores interim quod flagella evaserint, quam quod meruerint principatum, nec tam illis blanditur adeptum quam ademptum magisterium, Bern. Epist. 42. Schoole boyes, beardlesse youths are advanced to Ecclesiasticall dignities, and from being under the rod they are translated to be over the clergy, in the mean while being more glad in themselves that they have escaped the whip, then that they are come to honour, and the mastership that is taken from over them doth more please them then that which is gotten by them. Saint Basil complaineth of the same in the common wealth, saying, non item eum eligunt, qui est dignus, sed domesticum ac familiarem; neque ille eligitur qui salutaris esse possit reipublicae, sed qui in sua gente ac familia vi facultatum praepollet, Basilius in c. 3. Isaiae. they doe not also choose him that is worthy but some one that is domestick to them, or familiar with them: neither is he chosen who may be for the good of the common-wealth, but he who in his kindred and family aboundeth in possessions. And to this purpose he applyeth the words of the Prophet Isaiah, who saith, Isai. 3.6. a man shall take of his brother of the house of his Father, saying, thou hast clothing be thou ruler over us. And the rich sit in low places: the rich in this place expositours generally understand to be those, qui divites sunt sermone & sapientia, divites etiam operibus bonis, who are rich in utterance and wisedome rich also in good works as Saint Hierome declareth them.Hieronym. in hunc vers. And indeed these are they who are truly rich. Saint Austin. marking those words of Saint Paul, 1 Timot. 6.9. they that will be rich fall into temptation and a snare, and into many foolish lusts which drowne them in destruction and perdition, thereupon noteth, qui volunt divites fieri, qui volunt non qui sunt, nam qui sunt, divites sunt in bonis operibus, they that will be rich,Augustin. Serm. 205. de Tempore they that will be, not they that are, for they that are, are rich in good works. Saint Bernard therefore saith, filii Adam genus avarum & ambitiosum audite, quid vobis cum terrenis divitiis & gloria temporali, quae nec verae nec vestrae sunt. Si enim vestra sunt haec tollite vobiscum. Vere ergo divitiae non opes sunt sed virtutes, quas secum conscientia portat ut in perpetuum dives sit, Bernard. Ser. 4. adventus. yee Sons of Adam a covetous and ambitious generation heare this, what have ye to doe with earthly riches and temporall glory, which are neither true riches, nor your riches? For if they be your riches, take them with you when ye
goe hence. Riches therefore truly, are not wealth but vertues, which the conscience caryes with it, that it may be rich for ever.Chrysost. Homil. 11. in 1. ad Tundli. Saint Chrysostome speaking in the same manner, saith, quid parva ista miraris? quid ad ista quae abjectissima sunt inhias? quamdiu inops eris? quamdiu pauper esse persistes? in caelum animum intende coelestesque divitias animo versa, aurum irride, why dost thou stand amazed at those small things? why dost thou look so earnestly after those most base things? how long wilt thou be a beggar? how long wilt thou continue to be poore? fasten thine eyes upon heaven, and let thy mynd be busied about heavenly riches, despise gold. The spirit of God here calleth them rich, who abound with these riches. And Saint Ambrose saith,Ambros. l. 3. Epist. 10. ad Simplic. solum illum Deus divitem novit, qui sit dives aeternitati, qui non opum sed virtutum fructus recondat, it is he only that God acknowledgeth for a rich man, who is rich unto eternity, and who layeth up the reveneus of vertues not of wealth. But to give some reason why the Preacher in this place expresseth the worthy in wisedome and vertue by this name rich, I conceive it to be, as shewing that God did honour them, and esteeme of them, though in the world they were not honoured nor esteemed, and that he had advanced them in glorious riches, though in the world they did sit in low places. Saint Basil saith,Basil. Se leuc. Oratione 15.
placet sibi Deus abstrusum in despecto corpore margaritum conspicatus, God pleaseth himself beholding a hidden pearle in a despised and disrespected body. Or els the Preacher useth here this word, as shewing, that although they did not receive from others honour and dignity, yet by their owne paines they had gotten to themselves wisdome and worth, and that although the other were kept from them; yet that this could not be taken from them. The French translation doth read this word rich, ceu qui out de quoi they that have wherewith: as if the meaning were that fooles are set in high places, in dignities and honours, who have not wherewith, and are not of ability either to order their places, or to order themselves in their places: whereas they who have wherewith, who have wisedome and knowledge, as well to honour high places and dignities by their well discharging of them, as they should be honoured in them, are left to continue in a low ranke, Saint Bernard speaking of the Knight Templers saith, persona inter eos non accipitur, defertur honor meliori, Bernard. ad milites Templi c. 4. among them there is no accepting of persons, honour is given to him that is most worthy of it. And where it is so, in the temple and state, that time is come againe, of which Seneca saith, aureum saeculum erat, in quo honores melioribus dabantur, the golden age was,Seneca Epist. 91 in which honours were bestowed on them, that best deserved them. When a foole is set in dignity, it is as when an handfull of hay is set up to give light, which with smoake and smell offendeth all that are nere it. When as the worthy sit in low place, it is as when a goodly candle, that on a table would give a comfortable and comely light, is put under a bushell.

Vers. 7. I have seen: and with what looke doe we imagine that the Preacher beheld it? how angry was his eye? how ashamed his countenance?
would it not be a strange thing to see some beast ruling a man with a bridle, and at his pleasure to turne him and guide him which way he would? Surely no lesse strange sight it is, to see servants as Princes upon horses, and to see Princes as servants walking upon the earth. The meaning of the verse, Saint Gregory delivereth thus, Equi nomine dignitas temporalis accipitur, & quum omnis qui peccat, servus est pecati; servi in equis sunt, Gregor. Moral. lib. 31. cap. 10.
quum peccatores praesentis vitae dignitatibus efferuntur. Principes vero quasi servi ambulant, quum multos dignitate virtutum plenos nullus honor eriget, sed summa hic adversitas velut indignos deorsum premet, by the name of a horse, is understood temporall dignity, and seeing every one that sinneth is the servant of sinne, servants are upon horses, when sinners are advanced in the dignities of this present life. But Princes walke as servants, when no honour exalteth many who are full of the worth of vertues, but that great adversity doth presse them downe, as if they were unworthy men. S. Hierome expresseth the meaning of it thus,Hieronym. in hunc vers. quod hi qui servi sunt vitiorum atque peccati, sive tam humiles ut servi ab hominibus computentur, subita a diabolo dignitate perflati vias publicas mannis terant, & nobilis quisque vel prudens paupertate oppressus gradiatur itinere officioque servorum, that they who are servants to vices, and sinne, or else are so base, that by men they are accounted of as servants, being blowne up by the devill, with some sudden dignity, doe weare out the streets, and high wayes with their nags, & he that is noble or wise, oppressed with poverty, goeth along the way afoote, and waiteth as a servant. So that the difference not only is, that the one rideth, the other is afoot upon the earth; but also that the one sitteth at his ease, the other walketh with paine and labour. But though the foolish, the wicked be upon horses, they are servants still: and though the vertuous and the wise walke upon the earth, they are Princes still. Yea, how many servants are there more free then their masters,Ambros. de Jos. Parariarcha. c: 4
si in servitute positi a servilibus putent operibus abstinendum. Servile est omne peccatum, libera est innocentia, if being placed in servitude, they be carefull to abstaine from servile works. Every sinne is servile, righteousnesse is free, as Saint Ambrose speaketh. Psal. 105.22. Joseph was sold into Aegypt for a servant; but how was he a servant, who did binde Princes at their pleasure, and did teach Senators wisedome? How was he a servant, who bought the whole land of Aegypt, and made all the Aegyptians servants unto Pharoah? Even when he was the servant of Potyphar, he disdained not obsequium sedulitatis, the obedient readinesse of diligence, but he kept still the height of vertue, he preserved still the fredome of righteousnesse, the authority of innocencie. The selling of him could not take away this from him. Money is no prejudice unto this, which oftentimes hath bought masters unto them, who have been the disturbers of it: nihil tabulae auctionales, the deeds of bargaine and sale doe no wayes hinder this, by which many times the buyer hath been condemned unto bondage. There have been many who have bought faire damosells, to whom by a lustfull affection, they have been subjected in a shamefull thraldome. Wherefore
as Saint Ambrose speaketh, non ille solum liber qui dominum licitatorem non pertulit aut tollentem digitum non vidit, sed ille magis liber qui intra se liber est, It is not he only that is free, who hath not a master to set a price upon him, whose eye feareth not the finger that is lifted up against him, but he is rather free, that is free within himselfe.Aug. in Psal. 104.
Non ista est libertas quam manumissus accipit, & palma lictoris donatus acquirit, that is not a liberty which he receiveth, upon whose head, his master putting his hand, and therewith putting him away from him, hath said unto him, Liber esto, be thou free: that is not a freedome which he hath obtained, to whom the Sargeant hath given a branch of the Palme tree; but that is freedome which vertue, which wisedome bestoweth. He that is a foole, he that is wicked, though a Prince, is but a servant, he that is vertuous, he that is wise, though a servant, is a Prince. Saint Ambrose sheweth them both, who speaking of the first, saith, Stulto & imperare servitus est, & quod pejus est, quum paucioribus praesit, pluribus dominis & gravioribus servit, Ambros. Ibid. to a fool, even to reign is a bondage, and that which is worse, whereas he reigneth over a few, he serveth many and most grievous masters. For he serveth his passions, he serveth his lusts, whose dominion over him he is not able to shun, neither night nor day: for he hath his masters with him, and within himself suffereth this unsufferable servitude. Of the other, he saith, he that wil be free, let him be a servant of the Lord, ea enim parte qua participamur servitute, participamur & regno, for so far as we are interested in this service, so far we are interested in a kingdome: yea it is the Kingdome of heaven, which is within us, as our Saviour speaketh. Luk. 17.21. There is no little servitude in the Princes of the earth, even as they are Princes, and therefore Philo noteth, that it is well said of Joseph, that he was sold into Egypt, because he that ascendeth into a place of dignity, of a free man, is made a servant,Philo de Joseph. propter honores quos videtur accipere innumeris se dominis subjiciens, for the honours which he seemeth to receive subjecting himselfe unto numberlesse masters. For it is not one that is master of them, who rule in the government, but even the multitude of the people. But if unto this servitude, the servitude of wickednesse be joyned also, how grievous is it made? Now it were well, if they who condemne the evill of the world, when servants be upon horses, and Princes walke upon the earth, would be but carefull not to suffer the same in themselves. For when the flesh ruleth over the spirit, is not then a servant on horse-back? and lifted up in honour? Is not then a Prince subjected, and made to goe on foot? Saint Austin expresseth this perverted course by a fit similitude, saying, qualis est in oculis hominum, Aug. Serm. 5. ad fratres in Eremo. qui inversis pedibus & capite deorsum ambulare videtur, talis est in oculis Angelorum cui propria caro dominatur, such a one as he is in the eyes of men, who is seen to walke with his feet turned upward, and his head downward, the same is he in the sight of the Angels, whose owne flesh beareth rule in him. Who therefore should not be ashamed of it?Seneca Epist. 65. And if Seneca perceiving the shame of it, said of himselfe, major sum & ad majora genitus, quam ut
mancipium sim mei corporis, I am of more worth, and borne to better things, then that I should be the slave of my body, how much more should a Christian be moved with the shame • f it? How much more would his resolution be the same, and how carefull should he be to performe it?

q.p: Ver. 8. He that diggeth a pit, shall fall into it; and whoso breaketh an hedge, a serpent shall bite him.
Ver. 9. Whoso removeth stones, shall be hurt therewith: and he that cleaveth wood, shall be endangered thereby.

div.p:
Ver. 8. The consideration of the former verses, wherein the Preacher speaketh of the advancement of the unworthy, the low estate of them that are worthy, induceth me to understand this verse of him, who that he may exalt his owne unworthines, diggeth a pit by plots and devises, and secret suggestions, whereby to keep others down, and of him whose ambitious desire, that he may get up on high, careth not to break down hedges, to leap over ditches, and where his owne worth findeth not a way open for him, to make a way by the force of importunitie, and other sinister courses. And commonly where this violent desire is, it is a signe of little worth that there is to be found.Abusensis in 2. Reg. c. 15. v. 5. For so Abulensis delivereth his judgement, saying, Qui honorem desiderat, non est dignus honore, & qui desiderat statum excellentem non potest eum convenienter sustinere, hee that desireth honor, is not worthy of honor, he that desireth a high place, is not a man able fitly to discharge it. But to him that diggeth this pit for others, the Preacher saith, that he shall fall into it: for many times himselfe falleth from the height of his ambitious hope, who seeketh to keep downe others from rising. The Princesse of Babylon had digged a pit for Daniel, as low as the Lyons den, that by his fall themselves might be advanced in the Kings favour: but Daniel being preserved in it, and taken out of it, themselves were cast into it, and there were consumed, and perished. To him that breaketh so an hedge, the Preacher saith that a serpent shall bite him: and indeed, what is ambition it selfe,Bernard. l. 3. de considerat. but a biting serpent? Saint Bernard saith of it, O ambitio ambientium! crux quomodo omnes torquens omnibus places? nihil acrius cruciat, nihil molestius inquietat, nihil tamen apud miseros mortales celebrius negotiis ejus: O the ambition of the ambitious! Being a crosse which tormenteth all, how dost thou please all? there is nothing that vexeth more bitterly, nothing that disquieteth more grievously, and yet there is nothing more famous with miserable men, then the businesses of it.Augustinus. Saint Austin speaking of our first parents Adam and Eve, saith, Rapere voluerunt divinitatem, & perdiderunt faelicitatem, they would needs get
unto themselves divinity, and lost their felicity. They break through the hedge of Gods commandement, to come to the forbidden tree, and how grievously, how deadly did the serpent bite them? And surely oftentimes when ambitious heads breake through hedges, to get to high places, there is a serpent lurking secretly, which bites them by the heele, and either stops them from going on, or else bringeth by it some great mischiefe upon them. Or else the serpent that biteth these ambitious subtile workers, is some other more subtile then they, by whom they are undermined in their plots. Indeed when ambition is set upon it, no hedge, no wall is able to hold it, but it breaks through, it leaps over all. What hedges did Athaliah break, killing all the royall Progeny,2. King. 11. that her selfe might reigne? What hedges did Abimelech break, Judg. 9. killing seventy of his brethren, that himselfe might rule? What hedges did Absalom break, that he might be King in Israel? But did not the serpent bite them all?2. King. 15. Was not to all of them, their greatnesse their confusions? Saint Chrysostome speaking of Absalom, saith, Where fathers and Parents ought to finde comfort, there they find death; and whereas bruit beasts observe the lawes of piety toward them that breed them; whereas it is wickednesse to destroy the innocent, great wickednesse to destroy a father; ambitio docet id quod natura non novit, quod pietas ipsa horescit, Chrysost. Homil. de Absolom. audet perficere quod Deus novo supplicio cogatur vindicare, ambition teacheth that which nature knoweth not, which naturall affection abhorreth, and dareth to enterprise that, which God is compelled to punish with a strange and new judgement. Or else if the serpent bite not so hard, it is not seldome seen, that when the tree is ready to beare, it biteth off the bud, and when ambition seeketh for the fruit of a long sought-for greatnesse, it findeth none in it. When the Lord saith unto the Prophet Zachary,
Zachar. 11.15. take unto thee the instruments of a foolish sheepheard: the instruments of a sheepheard, being a bagge and a staffe, Rabbi David Rabbi David. and Vatablus say, that the bag of a foolish sheepheard is pera pertusa, a bag that is broken thorow, and which holdeth nothing; according whereunto wee may say, that the staffe of a foolish sheepheard is a broken staffe, not able to support him. And plainly it is so with many in the folly of ambition, they have broken through a hedge to come to greatnesse, and thereby have broken the bagge of their greatnesse, that it affordeth small benefit unto them: they haue leapt over a wall to get into honour, but the leap hath broken their staffe, so that they have little comfort to support them. A serpent hath bitten them, and the poyson thereof cannot be gotten out. Another exposition which Lyra giveth of this verse,Lyra in hunc vers. is to understand here the hurt that commeth by the occasion of sinne, so that he that doth not shun the occasion of it, doth even fall into it, and he that being bold, doth runne into the occasion of sinne, doth even dig a pit, in which he is taken. To the same purpose he expoundeth the latter part of the verse, understanding the hedge to be the restraint of discipline and government, which whosoever breaketh,Ephes. 4.27. Anselm. Ibid. giving himselfe more carelesse libertie in his courses, is easily bitten by the serpent, the devill. Anselm
considering the words of Saint Paul, Give no place to the devill, thereupon saith, that if the dore be not shut, or being shut, if it be not shut carefully, the devill, who is alwayes at the dore, will find some way of entrance into it. And he further tells us, that this dore hath two leafes, desire and feare, so that if we open either leafe, whether it be a desire after some worldly thing, or a feare of some earthly thing, the devill is ready to get in; and that therefore to be safe, wee must keepe both fast shut against him. When the holy things belonging to the Sanctuary were to be removed, all things were to be covered, least in the journey, Numb. 4. dust should be a soyling to them. In like manner therefore seeing they who are Gods children, are vessells of mercy, belonging to his Sanctuary, it must be their care, while they are in the way of this life, that they be covered all over with a diligent watchfulnesse, because otherwise the dust of sinne, or the pollution of some uncleanesse will easily fasten upon them. In the law, the Nazarite was not only commanded to abstaine from wine and strong drink, Numb. 6.3. v. 4. but also he might not eate grapes, whether moyst or drie, nor any thing that is made of the Vine tree, from the kernels, even to the huske. But why not these small things, in which there could be no danger of drunkennesse? Surely least by the contentment of these, he might be drawne to desire the wine, and so be carryed on to sinne. This remote occasion was forbidden, to shew how carefull every one should be in shunning the occasion of wickednesse.Seneca Epist. 117. And indeed, as Seneca saith, Quantum possumus a lubrico recedamus insicco etiam parum fortiter stamus, as much as we can let us keep our selves from slippery places, for even on dry ground it is not very strongly that we stand. The prayer therefore of the Prophet David, is, Remove from me the way of lying, by the way, meaning the occasion of sinning. For as the way leadeth unto the journeys end, so doth occasion lead unto sinne, which is the end of it. Let him therefore keep out of the way, that will not be carried on by it, let him not digge the pit, that will not fall into it, Psal. 119.29. let him not break the hedge, that will not have the serpent to bite him. Or else, we may conceive the Preacher, who hath before shewed the benefit and excellency of true wisedome, here to shew the hurt & reproach of crafty and subtill deceitfulnesse, which seeking to doe harme to others, bringeth it upon the seekers of it.

Vers. 9. The Preacher joyning this verse unto the former, I shall consider it in the same manner; and first to speak of the unworthy, ambitiously seeking to be on high, and placed in greatnesse; here the Preacher sheweth, that as he who taketh upon him to remove a stone, which is too heavy for him, shall be hurt with it; so he that taketh upon himself some weighty place of dignity, which he is not able to discharge shall be oppressed by it. As he that heweth wood which is too hard for him, is much endangered by it; so he that putteth himself into a place of greatnes which is too hard for him to performe, putteth himself into great danger also.Seneca Epist. 14.
Seneca saith of trees planted in valleys, ubi ab inclementia temporum protecti sunt, where they are sheltred from the unmercifulnesse
of seasons oftentimes are shaken and perish with the force of winds and raines and lightnings, what may wee think of them who are placed on the top of the mountaines without any shelter?Bernard. Sehm. de convers. ad Cler. c. 31. And surely if wise men who sit in a low place are not free from troubles and dangers, then certainly fooles being in great dignity cannot but be distressed by them. But it is the nature of ambition, not to regard dangers, and therefore Saint Bernard saith, paratos ambitiosos videas universa pericula subire, scandala suscitare, sustinere odia, opprobria dissimulare, negligere maledicta, thou mayest see ambitious persons ready to undergo all dangers, to raise up scandals, to sustaine hatreds, to dissemble reproaches, to neglect cursings. And surely being so ready to undergo them, no mervaile if they fal into them, no mervaile if they perish by them. Secondly to understand the verse as speaking of the occasions of sin: the Preacher in the verse before having spoken of occasions generally, and of lesser occasions, here he speaketh of great occasions, shewing, that as he who thinketh to remove great stones lying in his way, shall hurt himself and not be able to doe it, so he that thinketh to go on in a right course, and thrusteth himself upon strong occasions of beeing misled, presuming not to be hurt by them, shall find himself to be deceived, when his hurt will be manifest. For as Saint Bernard speaketh,Bernard. in Cant. Serm. 65.
majus est miraculum inter vehementes occasiones non cadere, quam mortuos suscitare, it is a greater miracle not to fall being among strong occasions, then it is to raise up the dead. And as he who thinketh to make his axe go thorow very hard wood, is oftentimes not a little endangered by the rebound which is given to it, so he who thinketh to make the edge of his care, to passe thorow strong occasions of sinning to which he applyes himself, shall find his great care to be not a little endangered. The Son of Syrach hath a true saying, Ecclesiast. 3.26. he that loveth danger shall perish therein: he that will not decline danger shall not be able to decline destruction by it. And therefore indeed what doth he but even love his owne perishing, that loveth to be in danger? What doth he but shew a willingnesse to sin, who is willing to run into strong occasions of it? If wee take the verse by it self, it may admit this sense and meaning of it: that seeing the removing of stones, which is so poore a thing hath labour and trouble and paine with it, for so the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used properly signifyeth beeing by interpreters diversly rendred, and which the Syriack rendreth cruciabitur shall be tormented: Seeing also that even cleaving of wood which is so meane a thing hath also danger with it, why should not any one be contented to take paines, to suffer trouble, to undergo danger for vertuous and heavenly things, which are worthy of paines, trouble, danger, and which will yeild a good reward for it. He that brought back his talent to his Lord without any profit brougth it back 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
in Sudario in a napkin saith our English, Luc. 19.20. but the word signifyeth such a linnen cloth, a is used to wipe away swet, as shewing that he had not bin idle, nor without labour and paine, though he
had been idle in respect of the true use of it, and in respect of his Lords benefit. Luc. 19.20. Wherefore Eusebius Gallicanus speaking of that passage saith, in sudario talentum reponit qui gratiam sibi traditam, Euseb. Gallic. in Homil. c. 1. in natali unius confessores. in hac carne laboribus & fatigationibus impensam torpescere sinit, he layeth up his talent in a napkin, who imploying the graces which he hath receaveth in the wearyings and labours of the flesh, doth suffer it to rust for any true good, which he getteth by it. Saint Basil therefore considering the words of the rich foole in the Gospell saying, I will pull downe my barnes and build greater, Basilius. asketh him, & si haec impleveris, nunquid destrues illa? Quid stultius quam in infinitum laborare? But if thou shalt have filled these also, wilt thou pull them downe likewise? What is there more foolish then to labour without end? And indeed what is there more foolish then to labour and suffer paines trouble and danger for the base things of this world, for chips of wood, for great stones? If wee will doe so, let us doe it for those things that shall bring us to heaven, and to eternall glory. Saint Cyprian readeth the latter part of the verse thus, Scindens ligna, periclitabitur in eo si exciderit ferrum; Cyprianus. Test. ad Quirinium. l. 3. he that cutteth wood shall be endangered thereby if that the iron fall off: and the meaning to which he applyeth it is this, Schisma non est faciendum, si in una fide & in eadem traditione permaneat, qui recedit, Hierony in hunc vers. a schisme is not to be made, if he that goeth away remaine in one faith, and in the same doctrine. Saint Hierome turning the words to a more hidden sence, by the stones which are simply mentioned, he understandeth the godly or the wicked. First applying them to the godly, Zachary. 9.16. which by the Prophet Zachary are said to be stones of a crowne lifted up, he giveth this meaning, that they who doe remove them by persecution, shall be hurt therewith. Aquila and Symmachus did translate the place dilacerabuntur, shall be torn in torments for it. Secondly applying the stones to the wicked who are like leaprous stones in the wall of an house, Levitic. 14. he giveth this sense, that when the Minister according to the commandement doth put them out of the church, himself is hurt with sorrow thereby, for so Saint Hierome doth read the place; dolebit in eis, he shall be sorry for them. In the latter part of the verse by wood he understandeth hereticks as beeing unfruifull wood in the church of God, and unfit for the building of it: and thereupon saith, quamvis sit prudens & doctus vir qui gladio sermonis sui haec ligna conscindat, periclitabitur in eis nisi diligenter attenderit, although he be a wise a learned man, who with the sword of his discourse cutteth this wood, he will be endangered by it, unlesse he attend didiligently unto it.

Vers. 10. Saint Gregory writing upon a passage of Job saith, Per ferrum virtus, per aes autem perseverantia exprimitur. Per ferrum homo enim: mala adversantia penetrat, Gregor. Moral. c. 34. c. 8.
per aes bona quae proposuit longanimiter servat. Aes enim rubigine nulla consumitur, by iron vertue, by brasse perseverance is expressed. For by iron a man breaketh thorow evils that doe oppose him, by brasse he preserveth long the good things
which himself hath proposed: for brasse is consumed almost by no rust. By iron therefore here we may conceive to be meant understanding the vertue of the mind, for that it is which peirceth into things. And the meaning, which our translation yeildeth from the words, is this, that if the understanding be blunt and dull, and that the edge of it be not whetted with knowledge and learning, that then a man must put to more strength, must use the more paines and industry. And indeed great is the benefit, great is the help of a painfull industry. Saint Bernard speaking of it saith, Ʋt quid dormiet industria? Grande profecto in vobis donum naturae ipsa est, Bernardus super Cant. Serm. 84.
quae si minus suas exequatur partes, nonne quod reliquum habet natura in vobis totum turbabitur? Why should industry be suffered to sleep? Truly even that is a great gift of nature in you, which if it be wanting to performe its part, is not all the rest which nature hath in you disordered and troubled? which if other things be wanting in it, doth make a good supply for them. But wisdome is profitable to direct: that is whether the iron be blunt or sharp. whether the edge be whetted or not whetted, whether more strength be put to, or not put to, whether sharpening, whetting, adding of more strength be needfull or not needfull wisdome serveth to direct in all. But the direct speaking of the Originall is this, If the iron be blunt, and he doe not whet the edge, and he put to more strength, but the benefit of rectifying is wisdome. Now to consider the verse with reference to the former, it seemeth to mee to give a reason, why he that cleaveth wood shall be endangered thereby. For if the iron which he useth be blunt, and he doe not amend it by whetting, but thinketh by the greater strength to make it to enter, he may easily not onely loose his labour, but get some hurt by it. And then to apply it also to ambition, and to the occasion of sinning, as I have done the verses before, first the bluntnesse of the iron signifieth the unworthinesse of him that seeketh or enjoyeth greatnesse, Contic. 1.6. the not whetting of the edge signifieth want of care and diligence to make himself worthy, the putting to more more strength signifieth the violence and boldnesse, that notwithstanding is used in thrusting into it, and in possessing of it. And this it is which doth the hurt. In the Canticles the spouse complaineth my mothers children are angry with mee, the vulgar Latin reads it pugnaverunt contra me, they have fought against mee, they made mee keeper of the vineyards, but myne owne vineyard have I not kept. Why was this a signe of anger or displeasure? was this any matter of hurt unto her, that shee was advanced to be keeper of the vineyards? Yes this it was, seeing thereby shee had not kept her owne vineyard. And surely not little is the hurt, which many receive by an unworthy greatnesse. Not seldome is it that they loose their credit, their good name, when they have gotten that,Plutarch. l. de doctr. principum if they get not worse hurt. He that having made a little statue, doth set it upon a great base, thereby maketh the littlenesse of it, the more to appeare, and when unworthinesse is set on high, then it is the more fully discovered. If the vessell be empty thou canst not tell whether it
be found, but fill it with liquour, and it will so be seen. Many times the unworthinesse of men is not found while they are in low condition, but let them be advanced then it shew's it self, then it flyes out into some shame or other. Wherefore Plutarch saith well, non in habendis sed in utendis magnitudo sita est, that it is not in having but in using, that greatnesse consisteth. But the benefit of rectifying is wisdome, either wisdome in him that is unworthy to consider his unworthinesse, and so not to seek for that for which he is not fit, or else in him that perceiveth the unworthinesse, and so doth not bring him to it. Secondly to apply the verse unto occasion of sinning. The bluntnesse of the iron is a dull carelesnesse in the wayes of a mans life, the not whetting of the edge is a want of admonition which should quicken the carelesnesse, the putting to of more strength is the adding of force to the occasion, which thereby indeed is made the stronger, and doth both the sooner and the more dangerously pull into mischiefe. But the benefit of rectifying is wisdome. Wisdome to see how the hurt is increased, wisdome to see how the occasion is strengthned, wisdome to see the fault of the dull carelesnesse. Or else wee may understand the verse as shewing severall remedies, how a defect may be supplyed and succoured. As first if the iron be blunt, one way to help it, is to whet the edge of it, and to redresse what is amisse. Or if that be not done, another way of helping, is to put to more strength, and so to make use of some other thing which may be insteed of it. But for a generall help, there is none like wisdome. That is an help upon all occasions, that findeth help many wayes, and alwayes doth it in the best manner. Saint Hierome readeth the verse thus, Si retusum fuerit ferrum, & hoc non ut prius; sed conturbatum fuerit, virtutibus corroborabitur, & reliquum fortitudinis sapientia est, Hieronym in. hunc vers. if the iron be blunted, and it be not as it was before, but that it be troubled, it shall be strengthned by vertues, and the remainder of strength is wisdome. And the meaning, which he giveth of it is; if any one doe see that by negligence he hath lost the knowledge of the Scriptures, so that beeing dull, he continueth not to be as he began. For oftentimes it commeth to passe, that when some one hath gotten a smack of knowledge, being lifted up by pride, he leaveth off to learne, and so by little, because nothing is added there grows a diminution, and the mind remaineth void of knowledge, the iron is dulled, for sloth and idlenesse are as it were a rust of wisdome. If it be therefore so with any one let him not be out of heart, let him go to his teacher, and let him againe be instructed by him, and after labour and industry and much sweate, for this it is, which in the Hebrew is delivered significantly, fortitudinibus corroborabitur, by forces he shall be strengthned, that is by labour and industry and sweat and dayly reading, he shall obtaine wisdome and his strength shall have this end that he shall get wisdome. The Septuagint and the Vulgar Latin read the verse thus, Si retusum fuerit ferrum, & hoc non ut prius, sed hebetatum fuerit, multo labore exacuetur, & post industriam sequitur sapientia, if
the iron be blunted, so that it be not as it was, but that it be dulled, by much labour it may be sharpned, and after industry followeth wisdome. And the meaning which Lyra giveth it is this, that the Preacher removeth a false persuasion which men have, who think that it is an easy matter to returne from wickednesse to vertue,Lyra in hunc vers. and therefore care not to seek after the occasions of sinning. But this the Preacher sheweth not to be so by the example of iron which is sharp. For if it smite upon a sharp stone the edge of it is lost, neither is it recovered but with much whetting. And so it is with him that declineth unto sin, for it is not easy for him, but a great difficulty to return into the right way, as experience confirmeth, and the Philosopher sheweth to be true. Or else as the Preacher before shewed the hurt of crafty deceit, so we may conceive him here to shew the hurt of open violence, and force.Aristot. 1. Ethit. For when craft cannot prevaile, the way of many is to seeke their ends by strength of violence wherein themselves often times doe receive the mischiefe of it. Wisdome therefore it is which the Preacher prefereth before both.

q.p: Ver. 11. Surely the serpent will bite without enchantment, and a babler is no better.
Ver. 12. The words of a wise mans mouth are gracious: but the lips of a foole will swallow up himselfe.
Ver. 13. The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishnesse: and the end of his talke is mischievous madnesse.
Ver. 14. A foole also is full of words; and a man cannot tell what shall be; and what shall be after him, who can tell him?
Ver. 15. The labour of the foolish wearieth every one of them; because he knoweth not how to goe to the citie.

div.p:
Vers. 11. There are two or three words in the Hebrew, which doe cause this verse to be diversly rendred, the one is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which Saint Hierome and the Vulgar Latine render in silentio in silence; the Septuagint render non in sibilo, not in a hissing, or not in a noyse which the Serpent
makes. And these two readings in effect are the same. Our translation, the French, and Tremellius do read it, without enchantment, for that also the Hebrew word doth signifie. The other words are 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which S Hierome rendreth habens linguam, he that hath a tongue, Tremellius, tenens verba ejus, holding his words, and understandeth it of the enchanter, holding the biting of the serpent. So that his meaning maketh his reading to be the same with the Septuagint, who render it incantans, he that enchanteth. The french saith le languard, a long-tongued prating companion, and as our English hath it, a babler, wherein they differ not in meaning from the Vulgar Latin. For the sense is, that as the serpent will bite without enchantment, so a babler, a a fellow of many words, if he be not looked unto, is commonly a slanderer, and being no better then a serpent, will by his detraction, even bite also. Saint Hierome applyeth his reading both to the sense of the Vulgar Latine, and to the sense of the Septuagint. As he applieth his reading to the sense of the Vulgar Latine,Hieronym. in hunc vers. he thus expoundeth it, Serpens & detractor sunt aequales: quomodo enim ille secretò mordens venenum inserit, sic ille clam detrahens, virus pectoris sui infundit in fratrem, a serpent and a slanderer are equall: for as the serpent secretly getteth in his poyson; so he detracting closely, infuseth the venome of his brest into his brother. But further we may note, the likenesse between a slanderer and a serpent, in divers things. First, as all doe hate a serpent, and flie from the sight of it, so all doe hate a slanderer, and flie from his company. Secondly, a serpent, as S. Austin saith, carrieth his poyson in his mouth, ready to be cast out, and with one biting poysoneth the whole body; so the slanderer hath his poyson in his mouth, ready to be vented, and with one word, as it were, with one biting, doth easily wound the name, credit, soule, the life of his brother. Thirdly as there is no other creature to which the devill is likened so much as a serpent, for though he be called a Lyon, a Wolfe, a Fox, yet most commonly he is called the old Serpent; so there is no other sinner so like the devill, as a slanderer is, he being as the devill is an accuser of his brethren. Lastly as a Serpent feedeth upon nothing but upon the earth, so that if a Partridg be set before him, he careth not for it; in the like manner a slanderer feedeth upon the hurt of others, as for that which is good in them he speaketh not of it. As S. Hierome applyeth his reading to the sense of the Septuagint he expoundeth it thus, if the Serpent the devill bite any one secretly and destroy him with the poyson of sinne, no other knowing of it; if he that is bitten hold his peace and do not betake himselfe unto repentance, neither is willing to confesse his wound unto his brother and teacher; his teacher who hath a toung for the curing of it cannot easily be profitable unto him.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Si enim erubescat aegrotus vuluus medico confiteri, quod ignorat medicina non curat, for if he that is sick be ashamed to confesse his wound to the Physitian, that which he knoweth not,Cassian. Collat. 1.2. c. 11. his Physick cureth not. Cassian who translateth the Septuagint thus, Si momorderit serpens non in sibilo, non est abundantia incantatori,
if the Serpent bite without hissing, there is no abundance in the enchanter, giveth the meaning of it to the same effect. The Preacher sheweth, saith he, the biting of a silent Serpent to be pernicious, that is, if the suggestion of the devill and his temptation be not made knowne unto some enchanter, unto some spirituall person, who by the charms of the Sriptures useth for to heale the wound, and to draw out from the heart the poison of the Serpent, he will not be able to bring succour to him that is endangered and ready to perish. In the same kind Olympiodorus expoundeth the verse,Olympiodor. in hunc vers. if saith he the Serpent of sinne doe bite in silence, that is, so that the sinner will not confesse his offence committed, he that by holy enchantment hath taken upon him to be his helper, cannot be able to give any health unto him, untill he shall be willing to confesse his sinnes. And lastly unto this agreeth Gregorius Neocaesariensis, who thus openeth the meaning of the verse,Gregor. Neocaes. in sua Metaphr. the hidden bitings of the Serpent the enchanters are not able to cure. For the hidden biting of the Serpent is sinne concealed by a sinner, which biting cannot be cured by the enchanters though never so wise, that is, by spirituall men and ministers, untill by confession it come to be maninifested. Tremellius readeth the verse thus, Si momorderit serpens non adhibita incantatione, tum nullum est emolumentum incantationis tenenti verba ejus, Tremell. in hunc vers. if the Serpent bite when the enchantment is not yet applied, there is no benefit in the enchanting of him, who hath the words of enchanting: as if the meaning were, though himselfe doe not so expresse it, that it is vaine to use a remedy for the preventing of hurt, when the hurt is already received. But seeing the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 properly signifyeth mussitationem & submissam orationem, a muttering, a soft and still speaking, so that the words directly are to be rendred, si Serpens momorderit non in mussitatione, if the Serpent shall bite not in muttering, that is, not secretly, but openly and in view, let me propose it only, whether the verse may not admit this sense: if open detraction be practised and permitted, he then that holdeth his toung to doe it in secret hath no benefit by it: as shewing the impudency of such a wickednesse so committed, which commonly as guilty to it selfe of its owne foulnesse, hideth it selfe for shame: or else as shewing the badnesse of those, who give way to it, themselves knowing it to be detraction and falshood, seeing the benefit which a detractor seeketh, is to doe it where it is not knowne to be false, that so it may be receeved.

Ver. 12. The words of a wise mans mouth are gracious: S. Hierome reads it verba oris sapientis gratia, the words of the mouth of a wise man are, grace for so the originall is: and to expresse the force of it, the French translation reads it, ne sont que grace; the words of a wise mans mouth are nothing but grace, being such,Lyra in hunc v. that as Lyra expoundeth it reddunt eum gratiosum coram Deo & hominibus, they make him gracious both with God and man. When the dove which Noah sent forth returned to the Ark, it brought an olive leafe in the mouth of it; which

passage of scripture Saint Ambrose considering saith, in ore quoque non frustra ramulus oleae videtur esse delatus,
Genes. 8.11. eo quod virtus & sapientia in ore justi habeant claritatem, it is also not without cause that a little olive branch was brought in the mouth of the dove, because vertue and wisedome in the mouth of a righteous man have brightnesse and clearnesse,Noe & Arca c. 19. whereby as they give grace and beauty to the speaker, so they give light comfort and delight unto the hearers of them. Saint Basil therefore also speaking of a wise righteous man saith, lingua justi spiritu sancto eam movente cordibus credentium verba inscribit vitae aeternae tincta quidem non atramento sed spiritu Dei viventis, Basil. in Ps. 44. Ambros. l. de the toung of the righteous being moved by the Holy Spirit writeth in the hearts of them that believe the words of eternall life, Numb. 10.10. not dyed with ink, but with the spirit of the living God. The mouth of a wise man, is like unto the silver trumpets which sounded to the Jews in the day of their gladnesse, and in their solemne dayes. Tuba est quae laetitiam sonat, non lites, it is a trumpet which sounded joy not jarring. But the lips of a foole will swallow up himself: the Hebrew is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
deglutiet eum will swallow up him, that is, as our English translation and Tremellius read it himself, For indeed the lips of a foole are but like a quagmire full of lightnesse and inconstancy moving and stirring upon any occasion, and into which himselfe sinking is swallowed up by it. The lips of a foole which make no end of talking are like a bottomlesse gulf, in which himselfe is drowned and perisheth. The Prophet David speaking of the foolish and wicked saith, Psal. 5.9. their throate is an open sepulchre: open it is and ready even to devoure themselves. Wherefore Saint Chrysostome saith upon the place, Ne sit ergo os tuum sepulchrum, sed thesaurus, let therefore thy mouth not be a sepulchre, but a treasury, and as a treasury is shut not open,Chrysost. so let thy mouth be, for so the mourh of the wise is, then only opening when it issueth forth some matter of moment worthy to be received. The mouth of a wise man is not like a devouring gulf, but like a pleasant fountaine, ubi in modum naturalis antri absidis fabricata concavitate, inde latex tanta quiete defluit, tanta quasi stabilitate decurrit, ut eum non putes crescere, nisi quia inde aliquid rauco murmure sentis exire, Cassiod. var. l. 2. var. 39. l. 8. var. 33. where the hollownesse of the circled inside, being framed in the manner of a naturall cave, from thence the water floweth out with so great quietnesse, and runneth as it were with so great staidnesse, that one would not think it to increase, but that he perceaveth some thing to goe out with a whistling noyse, as Cassiodore describeth a fountaine. Of Moyses holy Ephraim Ephraim. considereth that though he were famous for many miracles, Numb. 20. yet that offending a little with his toung at the waters of Meribah, thereby he lost his entrance into the Land of Canaan. Magnum & horrendum mare ei viam praecludere non potuit, sed verbum unicum inique ab eo prolatum, velut murus aliquis ipsi obstitit, ne ulterius progedi possit, the great and horrid sea was not able to shut up his way, but one word ill spoken by him stood up as it were a wall against him, that he could not goe on farther, Now if one word ill spoken did so much
prejudice him, how much mischiefe doe the lips of a foole bring unto him, how doe they swallow him up? When our saviour Christ cured the man that was deafe and dumbe, the Evangelist saith that looking up to heaven he sighed and said Ephata be opened. Mar. 7.34. But why did our saviour Christ sigh? Was he unwilling to relieve the distressed? Or was he loath to shew the man this favour! Either this miracle was a thing expedient to be done, or else it was not expedient to be done. If not expedient to be done, why did our saviour doe it? If it were expedient to be done, why did he sigh? Perhaps this sigh at this time was like that groane, which our saviour gave when he raised up Lazarus from the dead. And as there some give the reason of his groaning, because he was to call back Lazarus into this miserable life, wherein he was to under goe many dangers; so here our saviour sighed, because he was to restore speaking to the dumbe, and hearing to the deafe by which he should be subject to many evils and dangers, seeing that the toung is a dangerous thing, so that many have perished by it, and as the Preacher here speaketh the lips of a foole will swallow him up. But Saint Hierome doth not understand the mischiefe here spoken of to be referred to the foole himselfe: he reading the last part of the verse thus, Labia insipientis praecipitabunt eum, the lips of a foole will overthrow him, referreth the word him unto the wise man spoken of in the first part of the verse, saying, stultitia si sua esset rusticitate contenta minus aliquid haberet mali, if folly would be contented with its owne rudenesse it would have the lesse evill: but now it maketh war against wisedome, and whatsoever wisedome it seeth in a learned man, being provoked by envy it doth not approove it. For a wise man speaketh the words of knowledge,Hieronym. in hunc vers. the words of grace, which are able to bring profit to the hearers, but the ears of a foole doe not so receive the things that are said as they are spoken, but on the contrary endeavoureth to supplant a wise man, and to make him like unto himselfe. Et revera praecipitatur sapiens quando in aurem loquitur imprudentis, & verba ejus in profundo ut ita dicam gurgite pereunt, and indeed a wise man is as it were tumbled downe, when he speaketh in the eare of a foole, and his words doe perish, as I may so say, in a deepe gulf. Wherefore happy is he that speaketh in the ears of the wise. The Chaldee Paraphrase seemeth to referre the word him neither to the foole himselfe, nor to the wise man spoken of in the first part of the verse but unto man generally, which thus expresseth the sense of the last part of the verse, labia hominis stulti increpationem invehunt atque adeo universo orbi interitum, the lips of a foolish man bring on threatnings, and so destruction to the whole world, as if the meaning were, that as the grace which is in the words of a wise mans mouth bringeth good to many, and preserveth the world by the common benefit of it, even so the lips of a foole bring mischiefe unto many, and as it were by a generall infection doe cause the destruction of the world. It is the same meaning also, which another reading of the Chaldee Paraphrase Chald. Paraph. giveth unto it, where it is thus expressed, labia stulti viri plena sunt increpationibus,
propterea consumitur omne saeculum, the lips of a foolish man are full of threatnings, therefore is the whole world consumed: as shewing the great mischiefe which every where and alwayes they doe in the world.

Ver. 13. We have here the Serpent, the babler spoken of in the eleventh verse wreathed into a circle, his two ends, head and taile meeting together. And as at the one end he is a Serpent having his sting in his head, so at the other end he is a Scorpion having his sting in his taile. Foolishnesse in the beginning, mischievous madnesse in the end. The Prophet Isaiah saith, Isa. 32.5. the vile person will speak villany, where the vulgar Latin reads it, and so the Hebrew may be rendred, stultus loquetur fatua, a foole will speak foolish things or folly: whether he beginne or whether he make an end, it is folly still. When Jacob went into Mesopatamia the Lord appeared to him in the vision of the Ladder, Genes. 28.13. Genes. 35.9. and when Jacob came out of Mesopotamia God appeared againe unto him. Not only when he began his journy, but when he ended it, did he find the favour and blessing of God upon him. He was the same in his care to serve to God, and the same was the goodnesse of God towards him. But here we have a foole beginning his journy, and he begins it with folly; here we have him ending his journy, and he ends it in mischievous madnesse. The same that he was at first, the same he is at last, save only that his going on makes him to be worse. And surely it is most needfull to take heed of the beginning of wickednesse and folly. For commonly a beginning leads on farther, and that which is once began is not fortwith ended. Most safe it is to deny entrance unto folly, but if it be entred, thrust it out quickly. The Aegyptians had endured many plagues and were still hardened, but when they saw their first born to be slain, then they gave the Israelites leave to depart. Whereupon Nicetas Nicetas. in Nazianzene meditating saith, as the Aegyptians could not endure that plague but then permitted the Israelites to be gone, eodem modo daemonibus quoque animarum nostrarum persecutoribus gravissima haec paena videtur, quando in animo primogenita peccati, hoc est prima vitii origo, & principium extinguitur; in like manner unto the devils who are the persecutours of our soules this punishment seemeth to be most grievous, when in the mynd the first born of sin, that is the first entring of vice, and the beginning of it is extinguished. But it is not the care of a foole to doe this, his foolishnesse begins assoon as the words of his mouth begin,Ambros. in Psal. 119. Octon. 17. Saint Ambrose speaking of the Hebrew letter Phe saith of it, Phe litera decima septima latine signisicat erravi, sive os aperui, the letter Phe which is the seventeenth, in Latin signifieth, I have erred, or else I have opened my mouth, as if it were but one and the same thing to open the mouth, and to run into errour. Plainely it is so with a foole, the very opening of his mouth to speak, openeth the way at which his folly commeth forth. It is not said that the beginning of the words of his mouth is the beginning of foolishnesse, but in the beginning of his words he shews himselfe an absolute foole, and although then he should leave off
to speak, he hath said enough to speak out his folly. But he goes on and the end of his talke is mischievous madnesse. To begin to speak foolishly may be the fault of a wise man, but he when he sees it, or hath it shewed unto him, he will not persist in it, or if he have spoken foolishly once, he will lay his hand upon his mouth, and will not doe so againe. But a foole having began to speak foolishly, he goes on in the same pace to the end, having once spoken like a foole, he will speak so againe and againe. The Prophet Hosea saying Ephraim is an heifer, that is taught and loveth to tread out the corn, Saint Gregory considering the words, saith, vitula triturae laboribus assueta relaxata plaerumque ad eundem laboris usum etiam non compulsa revertitur,
Hos. 10.11. the heifer being used to the labour of treading out the corne, oftentimes being set free, returneth againe even not compelled to the same work and labour.Gregor. Moral. l. 20. c. 16. And so the mynd of wicked men being addicted unto such servitude, and accustomed to the wearyings of temporall things, although it may be freed from them, yet hasteneth to be oppressed with earthly cares and troubles. Surely such a heifer, such a calfe is a foole, and though he have shamed himselfe by his foolish talking, yet he will doe it more, extending his folly to the end of his talking which is mischievous madnesse. Saint Ambrose saith,Ambros. de Noe & arca c. 23.
Ʋbi principium est, finis quaeritur, where there is a beginning an end is looked for; and if we look to the end of a fooles speaking, it is not only like the beginning but far worse. It is true, which Saint Gregory sheweth, quod intra principium & finem clauditur breve est, that which is shut up within a beginning and ending is short. but that in so short a time, as betweene the beginning and end of a fooles words, the naughtinesse of them should be so much encreased, might seeme very strang, were it not known that folly and wickednesse grow apace. He that began with foolishnesse only, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ut qui stultitiae merum magnumque hauserit calicém, as he that hath drunk out the simple and great cup of foolishnesse as Philo speaketh,Philo de temulentia. he proceedeth to end with mischievous madnesse. Saint Ambrose reading the place in the fourtieth Psalme at the fourth verse, beatus est vir qui non respexit in vanitates & insanias falsas, blessed is the man who hath not regarded vanities, and false madnesse: thereupon saith, sunt ergo verae insaniae, & forfitan prophetarum, qui in excessu mentis positi prophetabant repleti Dei spiritu, ut quibusdam insani viderentur, quum propriae salutis immemores nudi plaerumque & excalceati, sicut Esaias Sanctus per populos currerent, vociferantes non quae ipsi vellent, sed quae a Domino juberentur, Ambros. in Psal. 39. there is therefore true madnesse, and perhaps such was that of the Prophets, who prophesied in an extasy of mynd being filled with the spirit of God; so that they might seeme to some to be mad, when unmyndfull of their owne health, they did run naked oftentimes among the people and unshod, as the holy Prophet Isaiah did. But though the Hebrew in that place of the Psalmes be not so, yet in this verse here the Hebrew is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
insania mala and evill madnesse, and so may seeme to inferre a good madnesse, perhaps such as that was in the ancient Prophets which
seemed some times to the people to be a madnesse. But to consider the words as our translation hath them mischievous madnesse. There is nothing so mischievous as a foolish and wicked toung is; wherefore Valerianus saith, quid mihi aliquis in comparatione malitiosae linguae artificium veneficii increpet, & noxias poculorum compositiones accuset? Excessit illa res omne genus veneni, quae non potest nisi morte compesci, what should any one inveigh to me against the art of poysoning,Valentianus homil. 5. de oris insolentia. or accuse the composition of pernicious cups in comparison of a wicked, foolish & malitious toung? This thing exceedeth all kind of poyson, which cannot be pacified but by death only.

Ver. 14. The originall is not so plaine but that it requireth the understanding to search into it. The meaning which I apprehend is this. A foole is full of words, as if he were full of matter, and multiplyeth still his words, as if he wanted words to expresse that which the abundance of his knowledge hath to say: notwithstanding a man that heareth him, cannot tell what it is at which he aymeth, what it is that he would have, to what his words will come, cannot tell what to make of them. And that which shall be after him, that which shall be said when he hath done, either to answere his words, or to reforme his errours, or to instruct himselfe, who can declare unto him? who can teach and tell him? For being possessed with a strong persuasion of his owne knowledge, thinking that to be as great as his words have been many, he disdaineth that any should be able to correct him. Or else the meaning may be conceived thus. A foole is so full of words as if he knew all things, and could tell any thing; but a wise man cannot tell what shall be, much lesse a foole: there is none that can doe it, and what shall be after him, who can tell? Lyra in huuc vers. As implying saith Lyra, that God alone is able to doe it. Sed stultus talis non est hac revelatione dignus, but such a foole is not worthy to receive this revelation from him. Or thirdly we may take the verse in this meaning. The Preacher having shewed in the end of the verse before, the end of a fooles talking to be mischievous madnesse, here he giveth the reason of it: for as Lyra also speaketh, qui multiplicat verba fatua finaliter venit ad verba pessima, he that multiplyeth foolish words, in the end commeth to very naughty words. And because all evil proceedeth from ignorance according as the Philosopher saith, ignorat omnis malus, Aristoteles. every evill body is ignorant, therefore he addeth that a man knoweth not, that is, such a foolish man knoweth not, that is considereth not, doth not forecast, what is likely to ensue, what may follow though it be not likely: neither will he heare or regard any one that shall endeavour to tell him and to let him see it. The Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
quid quod erit, a man knoweth not what that which shall be, and Saint Hierome taking the future tense there to signify the time past reads the verse thus, Et stultus verba multiplicat; Ignorat homo quid sit, quod factum est, & quod futurum est post eum, quis annunciabit ei? A foole also multiplieth words. Man knoweth not what that is which hath been, and that which shall be after him, who shall
declare unto him? And the meaning which he giveth of the verse is this: quum stulius nec praeteritorum meminerit, nec futura agnoscat, & ignorantiae tenebris volutetur, falsam sibi scientiam repromittens, in eo doctum se putat & sapientem, si verba multiplicat, Hieronym. in hunc vers. when a foole neither remembreth the things that are past, nor knoweth the things that are to come, but tumbleth and stumbleth in the darknesse of ignorance, yet doth he promise himselfe a false knowledge, and therein thinketh himself to be learned and wise, because he multiplyeth words. The Septuagint also and the vulgar Latin read it, ignorat homo quod ante se fuerit, man knoweth not that which hath been before him, as if a foole were noted in that he neglected to consider the sayings and doings of wise men that had gone before him, and which are good directions for man in his wayes. Another-meaning of the verse, which I meete with is this, that he who knoweth much and is able fully and elegantly to expresse himself yet hereby is not freed from the reputation of a foole: it is not all his wisdome, all his eloquence that is able to take this off from him.
