For this one thing that he knoweth not what shall be, and that none can tell him, what shall be after him maketh him to be a foole still. To this purpose, Thuanus Thuanus. speaketh very well, Stultus voces usque deque effutit inanes, atque audire licet talia, blaterantem, laeti vivamus, quando humanum caligo futuri damnat genus; A foole talketh of this thing and that thing, and many wayes turneth his idle discourse, and one may heare him babling such like things as these, let us live merrily, seeing that an ignorance of that which is to come blindeth the knowledge of man, and shutteth his eyes that he cannot see it. But indeed seeing a darknesse in respect of that which shall be, oppresseth man, how should he lead a merry life? How can he freely enjoy his pleasures? Suppose him to be in honour, how can he rejoice in his obtained dignity, not knowing whether in his honour there doe not lye hid his future disgrace, and in his pleasure his torment? There is no present good, which the ignorance of what is to come doth not destroy. Samuel telleth Saul, 1 Sam. 10.5. when thou art come thither to the city, thou shalt meete a company of Prophets comming downe from the high place, with a psaltery, and a tabret, and a harp: and a pipe before them, and they shall prophesy. And surely the instruments of mirth could be found no where so fitly as among the Prophets, and among them who did fore know things to come, and being evill might be able to prevent them; being good might with comfort expect them. Wherefore could a wise man tell what was to be, he might safely be merry in that which he had: but no man knowing this, he is but a foole that is transported with the present joy of any earthly thing. This ignorance is the misery of man, and this misery maketh the wisest man a foole. Saint Hierome writing to Eustochium telleth her, the troubles of marriage, and the uncertainties of wedlock thou hast learned by a domestick example; when thy sister Blesilla aetate major, Hieronym. ad Eustochium. proposito minor, above thee in yeares, but beneath thee in resolution of mind, after
she had marryed a husband, the seventh moneth was made a widow. O infaelix humana conditio & futuri nescia! O unhappy condition of mankind and ignorant of that which shall be! She lost both the crowne of virginity and contentment of marriage. If we mark the Scriptures, wee shall find few just and righteous men mentioned that were not Prophets.Philo. l. quis rerum divinarum sit haeres. Philo saith, Omnibus probis viris sacra Scriptura prophetiam tribuit. Proinde quotquot inter justos censentur, inducuntur prophetae pleni caelesti numine, unto all vertuous men the Scripture ascribeth, the gift of prophesy. And therefore as many as are reckoned among the righteous, are brought in prophets filled with the heavenly Spirit. And as in religion the knowledge of that which shall be in heaven, to them that feare God, doth very much sweeten the comfort of it, and stir them up the more earnestly to walke in the paths of Gods commandements; so in this life the ignorance of what shall be after death, doth much diminish the comfort of that which is enjoyed, & maketh the wifest man in humane understanding a foole, because although he can say never so much, yet he can say nothing of that.

Vers. 15. A fool may take pains, & many times taketh more pains then he deserveth thanks. For his talking wearyeth both himself, & every one that heareth him. Perhaps they may sit still, & yet are more wearied then if they had gone a great journy, and himself having gone a great journey, is no with the farther on his way. Because he knoweth not how to go to the city: he would go some whither, but he knows not how to come unto it: he talketh of a place whither he should go, but he cannot find the way thither. It is some great matter that he would say, it is some great place, a city that he would go unto, but he knoweth not how to doe it. He turneth this way, & that way, he talketh of this thing & that thing, but it is still frō the matter it is still from the city to which he should go. The point that he would speak of, is some point that many learned men have handled, as in a city many doe dwell that are men of worth, & he also would shew himselfe to be a man of worth, he also would shew his learning, but he is lost in the way, he is still out of it. Tremellius understandeth the last part of the verse, as shewing the wonderfull simplicity of a foole, so that he is not able vel movere pedem recte & urbis suae viam agnoscere, Tremellus in hunc vers. quametiam caeci addiscunt, even to move forward one foote aright, and to know the way of his owne city which even blind men doe learne. Cassian understandeth here, the labour of the foolish, to be the labour of carelesse sinners, which doth indeed weary every one of them in their sinfull courses. For as he saith well, ipsae nobis tormento sunt, quibus utimur voluptates, the very pleasures which wee use are a torment unto us, and the very delights and contentments of the flesh, become to be executioners of punnishment upon the authours and inventors of them. By the city also he understandeth that heavenly Hierusalem which is the mother of us all, and speaking of the wicked saith, ab itinere regio deviantes, ad illam metropolim civitatem, ubi noster cursus indeclinabiliter debet esse directus non
poterunt pervenire, that wandring from the high way of the King of heaven, they shall never be able to get to that metropolitan city, whither our course without declining ought still to be directed. And indeed in the booke of wisdome the wicked themselves confesse, wee wearied our selves in the way of wickednesse and destruction, Wisdome 5.7. yea wee have gone thorow desarts, where there lay no way, but as for the way of the Lord, wee have not knowne it. The way of the Lord which leadeth to the city of which the Prophet Ezekiel speaketh, Ezek. 48.34. the name of the city shall be The Lord is there, that they have not knowne and so they know not how to go to the city. Saint Hierome understandeth here the labour of the foolish to be, the study of the heathen Philosophers, the city to be wisdome. And therefore he saith, lege Platonem, Hieronym. in hunc vers. Aristotelis revolve versutias, Zenonem & Carneadem diligentius intuere, & probabis verum esse quod dicitur labor stultorum affligit eos, read Plato, turn over the subtleties of Aristotle, looke diligently upon Zeno and Carneades, and thou wilt prove it to be true which is said, Psal. 46.4. the labour of the foolish afflicteth and wearieth them. They indeed sought for the truth with all care and industry, but because they had not a guide, because the word of God was not a lampe to their feete and a light to their paths, they thinking by humane understanding to be able to comprehend wisdome, they came not to the city of which the Psalmist saith, the streams of the ryver make glad the city of our God.
Psal. 107.4. Or else S. Hierome understandeth the labour of the foolish to be the labour and study of hereticks, the city to be truth; for they labour and busy themselves in the study of the Scriptures, by which they onely tire and weary their minds, but cannot find the city, because they walke in a desart. To whom the Father applyeth that passage of the Psalmes, they wandred in the wildernesse, in a solitary way, they found no city to dwell in. Or else we may take the labour of the foolish to be the labour of them who seek after high & hard & hiddē matters: whereas they know not the may into the city that is ordinary and common things, such as are knowne to all men, and much more needfull and usefull for themselves. The Chaldee Paraphrase giving the exposition of the verse doth set it downe thus, labor quo in stultitia sua excruciatur stolidus, tantopere illum conficit & fatigat, ut non sit edoctus plane ad eam civitatem receptum habere, Chald. Paraph. in qua sapientes habitant, a quibus doctrinam sciscitetur, the labour by which a foole is tortured in his foolishnesse doth so much spend him and weary him, that plainly he is not informed to have recourse unto the city in which the wise doe dwell, from whom he may seeke learning. And surely he will fall into pernicions folly, who thinking himselfe excellent in divine gifts despiseth the learning of other men. Saint Gregory shewes it, when he saith, inde fiet, ut dum unusquisque se sancto Spiritu impletum praesumat, discipulus hominis esse renuat, & magister erroris fiat, from hence it will come to passe,Gregor. Dialog. l. 1. c. 1. that while every one thinketh himselfe filled with the Holy Spirit, refusing to be the disciple of man, he is made to be the master of errour.
When our Saviour Christ had appeared to Saint Paul going to Damascus,
Acts. 9.6. he saith unto him, a rise and goe into the city, and it shall be told thee there what thou must doe. Whereupon Saint Bernard saith, O sapientia suaviter verè universa disponens! Bernard. Ser. in ea. Eum cui tu loqueris erudiendum de voluntate tua mittis ad hominem, O wisdome truly disposing all things sweetly! Him to whom thou thy selfe speakest, thou sendest unto man to be instructed in thy will. Saint Paul is sent into the city and is appointed by man to be taught, that even the gifts of God might be seen not to be bestowed without mans ministery. And surely let him goe to the city of the wise, to the Universities of learning and knowledge, let him seeke the help and benefit of men, whosoever will preserve the gifts of God safe in himselfe. Which although they may be great, use to vanish in him, and to make his labour the wearying of a foole, by whom the furtherance of other men is despised. In generall the labour of the foolish we may understand to be vaine and bootelesse toyling: for so fooles toyle themselves grievously and reape no profit, no benefit by it. To whom the Prophet Isaiah saith, Isai 52.2. Wherefore doe yee spend mony for that which is not bread, and your labour for that which satisfieth not? Such a one may beate his wings much as if he would fly farre and high, but as Hugo de Sancto Victore speaketh, Non volat in summis, sed ambulat in imis, imò non ambulat, sed stat. Non autem jacet, sed slat, ut nunquam requiescat. Assidue ergo stat, qui sine intermissione laborat. Pedes sine incessu fatigat, sine fructu laborat, he doth not fly on high, but walketh below, yea he doth not walke but standeth still. Stand he doth, not lye,Hugo de Sanc. vict. lib. 3. de Erud. Homil. p. 1. c. 7. so that he never resteth. Continually therefore doth he stand, who laboureth without ceasing. He wearieth his feete without going, he laboureth without benefit. For how can he know, how to goe into the city that standeth and goeth not?

q.p: Ver. 16. Woe to thee O Land, when thy King is a Child, and thy Princes eate in the morning.
Ver. 17. Blessed art thou O Land, when thy King is the Son of Nobles, and thy Princes eate in due season, for strength and not for drunkennesse.

div.p:
Ver. 16. The Originall word which is rendred woe is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and signifieth not only vae woe, but regionem & provinciam, a region and province, as if not only woe were to the Land, but the Land it selfe were woe, or woe it selfe the Land, when the King is a Child &c. But the Preacher
speaking to the Land saith, woe to thee o Land, as condoling with it, and groaning together with it, under the burden of the misery. And surely a publick calamity though belonging to a forreigne country ought to work a compassionate sorrow, and make them to feele it in a commiseration, who doe not feele it in the affliction. When thy King is a Child: a Child may be taken here three wayes, either in years and age, or else in wisdome and government, or lastly in a newnesse and Childhood as it were of royall blood. If we understand a Child in years, it is true that such a King is often a woe to a Land, but it is not alwayes so.Hieronym. in c. 3. Isa. Solomon himselfe who as Saint Hierome affirmeth, began to reigne at twelve yeers of age, though others make a question of it, was a great blessing to his Kingdome. But if Solomon did not begin, to reigne so soon,2 Chron. 34.1. Josiah began to reign sooner, even at eight yeers of age, and he also was a great happinesse to his Kingdome. The meaning therefore of the Preacher in this acception of the word is, that ordinarily the Child-hood of a King is the maturity of misery to his Kingdome, though extraordinarily by the goodnesse of God it may be otherwise. Secondly if we understand a Child in wisdome, so he may be that is ancient in yeers, and being so, he cannot but be a woe to to his Kingdome. The want of wisdome in a Child by age is often supplyed, by the wisdome of his counsellers: the want of this in a man hath commonly a wilfulnesse joyned with it that will not be supplyed. The hand of a little Child may hold the stern of a great ship, when a greater strength may guide it. But if he that hath strength to guide it, have not skill to doe it, but yet will doe it, because it is in his hand, it cannot but be dangerous sayling. This therefore is the judgement which God threatneth, Isa. 3.1. v. 4. that he would bring upon Iudah saying, I will give them Children to be their Princes and babes shall rule over them. The stay and the staf, the whole stay of bread, and the whole stay of water, the whole stay of knowledge, the whole stay of wisdome, which is in a wise King he would take from them, and make children in wisedom to be their Princes. Thirdly a King may be sayd to be a child, when his descent is not from Kings; but being 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as the Originall word here is, excussus one wrung out from inferiour condition is lept into a throne. The next verse which saith, blessed art thou O Land, when thy King is the Son of nobles may seeme to approve this understanding of the words here. And according to this meaning doth the Chaldee Paraphrase bring examples, for the illustrating of it, saying,Chald. Paraph. Vae tibi terra Israel in tempore quo regnaver it super te Ieroboam impius. Beata erit terra in tempore, quo negnaverit super te Ezechias filius Achas qui erit de genere domus Davidis, Woe be to thee O Land of Israel, when wicked Ieroboam shall reigne over thee. Blessed shall the Land be in that time, when Hezekiah the Son of Ahas, and who shall be of the house of David shall be thy King. The Spaniards use to call him that is not descended from Christian parents novum Christianum, a new Christian, as anciently the Romans called a noble man not descended from noble progenitours novum hominem a new man: and so this exposition understandeth the Preacher, by a King that is a Child
to meane him, qui est novus in regno, who is newly born in a Kingdome. And no doubt such a one in many respects may be a woe to a Land. Wherefore Thuanus Thuanus. saith, happy is that country, in qua deducta numerans a stirpe vetustos jactat avos princeps, in which a Prince with glory numbreth his ancestrous in a long continued race. And thy Princes eate in the morning which words may be taken thus, that the Princes are like unto the King, and that as he is a Child, so they are children also: for it is the property of children to eate as so on as they are awakened from sleepe, it is the condition of children to look after nothing so much as after rheir food. Or else the words may be taken as speaking of such Princes as are greedy of prey, and like ravenous wolfs devoure in the morning: as often it commeth to passe, where the King is a Child. But most directly the words seeme to speech of those, who make their owne benefit, for that the word eating noteth, to be the chiefe thing that they look after, and in their waies doe preferre that before the publicke good. Or else the words speake of them, who make pleasure to be the first thing that they seeke, and in a second place the affaires of the Kingdome and estate. Or lastly the words way be understood to speake of those, who by early intemperancy make themselves unfit for publick affaires and imployments. Saint Hierome saith, Daniel. 7.9. verum mihi sacratius quid latere videtur in litera, but to me there seemeth somewhat more holy to lye hid in the letter. He therefore by the King who is a Child understandeth the devill, a Child indeed in respect of God who is the ancient of dayes as in Daniel he is described; and surely as Saint Hierome speaketh, Vaeterrae cujus est diabolus rex, qui semper novarum rerum cupidus, Hieronym. in hunc vers. etiam in Absalon adversus parentem rebellat, Woe to the Land whose King is the devill, who being alwayes desirous of new things, rebelleth in Absalon against his Father. And as the devill is the Prince of this world, so by the Princes which feed in the morning, he understandeth them, who feed on the delights of this world and nourish themselves in them. Wherefore he saith also, Woe to the Land, quae judices & principes eos habet, qui amant hujus seculi voluptates, which hath those for judges and Princes, who love the pleasures of this world, who before the day of death commeth, say, let us eate and drinke for to morrow we shall dye. So doth Saint Austin also expound the last part of the verse, saying, Principes mane manducantes, idest, ante horam congruam, quia non expectant opportunam quae in futuro est faelicitatem, festinanter beari hujus saeculi faelicitate cupientes, Augustin. de Civitate Dei l. 17. c. 20. Princes eating in the morning, that is, before the due season, because they doe not expect that seasonable happinesse which shall be in the world to come, desiring hastely to be blessed with the happinesse that is in this world. So likewise doth Saint Gregory give the meaning of it, who saith, againe by the morning is signified the prosperity of the present life, as when Solomon saith, Woe to thee O Land, when thy King is a Child, and thy Princes eate in the morning, quia enim mane primum diei tempus est, & vespera extremum, nequaquam reficiendi sumus de hujus vitae prosperitate quae praevenit, Gregor. Moral. lib. 16. c. 25.
sed de his, quae in fine diei, id est, in mundi termino sequuntur. Mane ergo comedunt, qui de mundi hujus prosperitatibus
extolluntur, & dum presentia vehementer curant, futura non cogitant, for because the morning is the first time of the day, and the evening the last, we are in no sort to be refreshed with the prosperity of this world which goeth before, but with the things which are in the end of the day, that is, doe follow in the end of the world. They therefore doe eate in the morning who are lifted up with the prosperity of this world, and while they earnestly seek after present things, they doe not think of those which are to come. And surely seeing as Saint Paul saith, Rom. 8.22. the creature doth groane under the captivity of this world, then as Saint Chrysostome speaketh, ne tu deterior creatura efficiare, nec tu praesentibus rebus acquiescas, non enim illas solum non amplecti oportet, sed ingemiscere ob retardationum nostrae ab hoc orbe profectionis, be not thou made worse then the creature,Chrysost. ibi. neither doe thou set up thy rest upon things present. For not only ought we not to embrace them, but even to sigh and groane by reason of the delay of our going from this world.

Ver. 17. Blessed art thou O Land: the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
beatitudines tuae O terra, thy blessednesse O Land, as wondering at the multitude and greatnesse of them. And therefore the French translation doth well exppresse the force of it, O que tu es bien-hereuse O terre, O how happy art thou O Land, or, O that thou art happy O Land. When thy King is the Son of Nobles: the Septuagint and Saint Hierome read it, filius ingenuorum, the Son of them that were free born. Vatablus candidorum, the Son of them that have been fortunate, as deriving the Originall word from the roote 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
albescere to be white. Tremellius reads it natus clar ssimis, born of them that have been most famous. The Venetian translation reads it, as our English doth, filium nobilius, the Son of Nobles,Hieronym. in vers. and by the derivation of the Originall word from the roote 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth exustus burnt, it setteth forth such a one in whom the drosse of basenesse is burnt out and purified, not only by the descent of Noble blood; but also by the care of vertuous education. Saint Hierome therefore expoundeth it, Princeps bonis moribus, & liberaliter institutus, a Prince endued with vertues, and nobly trained up. Or else as Tremellius explaneth it, bene institutus & informatus in administratione regni, Tremell. in hunc vers. well instructed and taught in the governing of a Kingdome. So that in himselfe he maketh good the nobility of his progenitors, this being the perfection of a glorious King. For as King Athalaricus in Cassiodore speaketh,Cassiodor. var. l. 9. var. 23.
nullum melius potest esse compendium, quam laudibus successisse majorum, there cannot be more said in few words to the honour of a King, then that his fame succeedeth to the fame of his ancestors. But that which the words most plainly and most directly doe import, is to note such a King, whose byrth is from the descent of nobles. And surely this is a great blessing to a Kingdome. For as Aquinas noteth out of Aristotle, De vili loco assumpti ad principatum, ut pluries laedunt politiam, & laeserunt aliquando Calcedoniam, juxta illud poetae asperius nihil est humile quum surgit in altum, Aquin. de reg. Princip. l. 4. c. 19 they that are taken from vile degree unto principality, doe oftentimes hurt the government, and sometimes they did hurt the state of Calcedon, according
to that of the Poet, there is nothing more sharp and hard then a base person lifted up on high. In respect of a King, it is true which Chrysologus hath, Major est innata gloria, quam quaesita, praecedit quod venit ab origine, Crysostom. quod sequitur ex labore: gloriam beatius est habere, quam quaerere, that is a greater glory which is born with a King, then that which is gotten by him, that which commeth from descent goeth before that which followeth from industry: it is more happy to have glory then to seeke it. When Moyses was put into the water, it was most likely that some fisherman or some one dealing in the waters should have found him; but Gods providence brought thither the Kings daughter that by her he might be taken up. For as Macarius noteth, quum Deus Moysem praenosset & praeordinasset futurum ducem & redemptorem populi, Macar. Homil. 9
effecit ut adoptaretur à filia Pharaonis, when God had foreknowne and foreordayned Moyses to be the Captaine and deliverer of his people, he brought it about that he should be adopted by Pharaohs daughter. As if God himselfe would not that he should come to the Scepter of government, who was not first ennobled. The same may be observed of David, whom God having annointed to be King of Israel, before he placed him on the throne he ennobled him in being the Kings Son in law. When Abimelech had made himselfe King, and Jotham the only Son of Gideon, which had escaped from the slaughter of his brethren, standing upon the top of mount Gerizim spake unto the men of Sichem,
Judg. 9.18. that which chiefly he objected against Abimelech was, that being the Son of a hand mayd he was made King. For though Abimelech were a most cruell bloody man, and a foule murtherer of his brethren, yet this he omitterh, and speaketh only of his base birth, as if that were enough to prove, that he could not be a good King over them. And thy Princes eate in due season for strength, and not for drunkennesse: as before it was the misery of a Kingdome, that the Princes were like to the King in want of wisdome and goodnesse; so here it is the happinesse of a Kingdome, that the Princes are like unto the King in vertue and carefull government. And surely as it is the blessednesse of a Land to have them to be so, so it is the great glory of a Noble King to make them to be so. The eating here also as I shewed in the former verse may be taken for a civill consuming, as being such a one as consumeth in the strength and power of justice, which alwayes observeth due season, and not in the drunkennesse of passion, and corruption of lustfull desires. For so the Hebrew is in strength, in drunkennesse. Or else we may take the Preacher to set forth those Princes, who as Saint Hiorome expoundeth him, nequaquam voluptatem negotiis rivium praeferunt, Hieronym. in hunc vers. sed post multum laborem & administrationem reipublicae cibum capere quasi necessitate cogantur, no sort preferreth pleasure before the busines of the people, but after much labour and care in publicke affaires are as it were constrained by necessity to receive nourishment. But that which most plainly and most directly the words doe declare, is the commendation of temperate feeding in Princes, and a shunning of the excesse of a riotous and voluptuos gluttony: is a taking of sustenance in due season for peserving of nature, not for corrupting
of it; For as God is said to give all their meate in due season, so all must take it in due season, and to a due end, in a due manner. To which purpose Tully hath a very good passage in his Oration for King Delotarus. Did ever any one see Deiotarus dancing or drunken? Psalm. 145.15. There are in him all Kingly vertues, which I think not to be unknowne unto thee O Caesar; but especially a singular and wonderfull frugality; although I know that a King useth not to be commended by this word. To be said to be a frugall man, hath not much praise in a King: to be valiant,Cicero Orat. pro rege Deitaro to be just, to be strict, to be grave, to be magnanimous; to be bountifull, to be beneficiall, to be liberall, these are Kingly praises; that is private praise. But let every one take it as he will, notwithstanding I judge frugality that is modestie and temperance to be a principall vertue. This it is therefore which Sidonius commendeth in Theodorie a King of Italy, of whom speaking he saith, Si in convivium petitur, non ibi impolitam congeriem argenti mensis cedentibus suspiriosus minister imponit. Maximum tunc pondus in verbis est, quippe quum illic aut nulla narrantur, aut seria, cibi arte placent non pretio, farcula nitore non pondere, Scyphorum raras oblationes facilius est ut accuset sitis, quam recuset ebrietas. Quid multis? Sidomeus Apoll. l. 1. Epist. 1.
videas ibi elegantiam Graecam, abundantiam Gallicanam, celeritatem Italam, publicam pompam, diligentiam, privatam, regiam disciplinam, When he is invited to a feast, there the blowing short winded servant doth not put a pile of unpolished silver upon the yeilding tables. The greatest weight is then in words, for there either nothing is said, or that which is serious. The meate doth please for the good dressing of it, not for the costlinesse, the dishes, for their cleanlinesse, not for their greatnesse. The presenting of cups is not frequent, so that thirst doth rather blame the rarity of it, then drunkennesse refuse it. What should I say much? There thou mayest see the elegancy of Greece, the abundance of France the ready diligence of Italy, publick pompe, private diligence, royall discipline. Lastly not to omit the exposition which Saint Hierome most approveth. The King here who is the Son of Nobles, he understandeth to be our Saviour Christ, the Son of Abraham Isaac and Iacob descended from the race of Prophets and holy men, in whom sin not reigning, in that respect they were ingenui, truly free and noble. By the Princes he understandeth thr Apostles, and all the Godly, who have for their King this Sonne of Nobles, and who doe not eate in the morning nor hastily, who doe not seeke pleasure in this world: but in due season shall eate when the time of retribution commeth; and then they shall eate in strength, Hieronym. in hunc vers. and not in confusion as he readeth it. Omne bonum praesentis saeculi confusio est futuri vero prepetua fortitudo, for every good thing of the present world is confusion, but the good of that which is to come is perpetuall strength.

epigraph.q: Ver. 18. By much slothfulnesse the building decayeth; and through idlenesse of the hands, the house droppeth through.

div.p:
Ver. 18. By much slothfulnesse: the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 being a word of the duall number, and therefore may well be translated, pigritia duplici by a double slothfulnesse as Buxtorfius renders it. Tremellius reads it pigritia ambarum, by the slothfulnesse of both. S. Hierome renders it, pigritiis, as if it did import no more then our English expresseth by much slothfulnesse. But I conceive the duall number to have reference not to the two hands of man, in which slothfulnesse appeareth, but to those two of which the former verses speake before, namely the King and Princes of a land. For here the Preacher by the similitude of an house and decay thereof, sheweth the decay of a Kingdome and state. And indeed a King in his palace may see a pattern and model of his Kingdome. For what are his out houses, but as it were his commons, or his people? What is his Guard-chamber, but his Souldiers and men of warre? What is his Presence-chamber, but his officers and magistrates in whom his authority is alwayes present? What is his Privy-chamber, but his councellers? What is his closet, but his nobles? who are admitted in more retirednesse unto him, and who are commonly close about him? What is his Chappel, but his clergy? What is his cabinet, wherein his jewels are kept, but his children? What is his Bed-chamber, but his Queene? What are the severall roomes and parts of his house, but the severall countryes of his kingdome? And in the decay of his Palace he may see the decay of his kingdome and state. For as slothfulnesse not looking to the building, the raine makes it to decay, so by carelesnesse and negligence in a King and his Princes, the Kingdome decayeth, groweth rotten and weake. If the King be a child, there cannot be but carelesnesse in him, for that is proper unto children; if the Princes be given to pleasure, to eate in a morning, there will be carelesnesse in them, for that a desire of pleasure alwayes bringeth. And where carelesnesse is, a decay is sure to be. The Preacher also sheweth, where the decay beginneth. It is first 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
contignatio the roofe of the house that decayeth, first the King decayeth in his honour and reverence, then the Princes decay in their estate and respect, lastly it breaks through and comes to the people, and they suffer decay many wayes by it. For through idlenesse of the hands, the house droppeth through: the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
dimissione manuum, by the hanging downe and letting fall of the hands. And therefore we may so take the words, as to conceive the Preacher here to speake of a double kind of idlenesse and carelesnesse, the one in neglect of humane help, the other of divine help by not lifting up the hands in prayer unto God. For it is he that must keepe the kingdome from decaying, or else the watchman
watcheth but in vaine. Saint Hierome applyeth this verse two wayes. In a publick reference unto the Church,Hieronym. in hunc vers. quod per negligentiam Principum omnis ejus corruat altitudo: & ibi illecebrae vit • orum sunt, ubi tegmen putabatur esse virtutum, because by the negligence of Princes all the height of it is ruinated, and the entisements of vices are there, where was thought to be the covering of vertues. In a particular reference he applies it unto that house which is erected in the state of every man, and to that dwelling, which we have in heaven. For if we shall be slothfull, and slowe to good works, that will decay and fall, & omnis contignatio quae debet culmen portare in sublime ad terram corruens habitatorem suum opprimit, and all rafrering or rearing up which ought to have a top on high, falling to the earth oppresseth him, who is the dweller in it. When the labour of the hands, the succour of the vertues is grown idle, tempests that come from above, and the showres of raine doe breake in upon us. Gregory Nyssene also in a particular reference understandeth the house to be the building of vertue in every particular man: for as, saith he, if the tymber which keepes the house together be weake and unsound, and he that dwels in it be slothfull in taking care of it, and looking unto it, the covering will be for no benefit, because the raine will pierce in through it. For the roofe must needs decays being open to the water, and the roofe being weakened it will not be able to beate the weight that is upon it;Gregor. Nyssen. in Cant. Homil. 4 so that all in time will goe to ruine. Ita nobis in aenigmate parabolae praecipit, so he exhorteth us in the darkenesse of the parable, that by he strength and firmnesse of vertues, we yeild not to the flowings of temptations, lest being decayed by the invasions of the passions of our mind, Ejusmodi aquarum extrinsecus in cor influentium influxum admittamus intra penetralia, per quas nobis pereant, quae sunt r • posita, lest by the influence of such waters, which come from without into the heart, we receive within the secreet closets of our houses those things by which the treasures that are laid up are lost unto us. Cassian noteth here the manner of the decay of this building; for as he saith, Non subitaneo ad ruinam procumbit domus impulsa, sed longa inhabitantium desidia, Cassian. Coll. lib. c. 17.
stillicidiis primum parvissimis penetrantibus corrupta sensim sunt munimenta tectorum, quibus per vetustam negligentiam in majorem modum pate factis & collapsis, ubertim post haec influit plaviarum maxima tempestas, it is not by any sudden violence that the house is tumbled downe, but by the long slothfulnesse of the inhabitants, first of all very little drops by little and little getting in, the strength of the roofe by degrees is perished, which by long continued negligence being more and more opened and ruinated at length the tempests of raine and stormes breake in every where. And so it is both in the publick condition of any kingdome and Church, and in the private condition of every particular man. The mischiefe of carelesnesse doth not forthwith appeare in a kingdome, that is not like the invasion of a mighty enemy, but yet in time the hurt, which it bringeth is as great, & as S. Gregory speaketh,Gregor. Past. Cu. p. 3. Adm. 34
hoc agit sentina latenter excrescens, quod patenter procella saeviens, a sinke secreetly encreasing doth the same, which a tempest doth openly raging. A particular person doth not suddenly
fall into extreame wickednesse, but as Cassian speaketh, per longam mentis incuriam, Cassian. Ibid. paulatim virtute animi decidente, & per hoc sensim vitiis increscentibus casu miserabili concidit, by a long continued carelesnesse of mind, virtue decaying by little and little, and hence vices accordingly increasing falleth miserably quite away from goodnesse. And therefore it is good to looke to little matters, to be wary of smaller slips into sin, for as Saint Gregory speaketh, often there is more hurt in a little then in a greater fault. Major enim quò citius quod sit culpa agnoscitu, eo etiam celerius emendatur: minor vero dum quasi nulla creditur, eo pejus quo & securius inusu retinetur, for a great offence by how much the sooner it is acknowledged to be a fault,Gregor. Ibid. by so much the sooner it is amended, a lesse fault while that it is thought to be none, is thereupon the more, and the more securely practised. From whence it commeth to passe, that the mind accustomed to lesse offences is not troubled for great sinnes, and being nourished and trayned up in sinning, ad quandum authoritatem nequitiae pervenit, proceedeth to a boldnesse and to a kind of authority and lawfulnesse of wickednesse, & tanto in majoribus contemnit pertimescere, quanto in minimis didicit non timendo peccare, and by so much contemneth in greater sins to feare, by how much in lesse sinnes it hath learned to sin by not being afraid.

epigraph.q: Ver. 19. A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh merrie but mony answereth all things.

div.p:
Vers. 19. The Preacher having shewed the hurt which commeth to a land, whose King is a Child, and whose Princes eate in the morning: here he sheweth the good which ariseth to a land, whose King is the Son of nobles, and whose Princes doe eate in due season. So Cajetane joyneth this verse to the former, who saith, those things belong to that blessed land spoken of before, namely abundance of bread wine and mony. For it is meete that a good King and temperate Princes doe govern the city or kingdome in abundance of bread wine and silver, & abundantia panis describitur perfacere panem risui, Cajetauus in hunc vers. by making bread for laughter, for the Originall word, which is translated feast in the first place signifieth bread. Or else to referre this verse to that which goeth immediately before it, as there the Preacher sheweth the mischiefe of lazinesse and sloth; so here we may understand him to shew the benefit of labour and paines, from whence commeth plenty noted by feasting and wine, pleasure and delight noted by laughter, wealth and greatnes of estate noted by mony, which answereth to all things. The last part of the verse, the Septuagint doe render, argento humilitatione obediunt omnia, all things by subjection doe obey mony. And if it be referred unto those Kings, who are the Sons of Nobles, the words shew, how they by their humanity, alacrity liberality, doe bind their subjects to them. Egesippus writing of Antipater saith that by nation
he was an Idumaean, among his owne descended from nobles, non tenuis pecuniae, & ideo praevalidae potentiae, arte mira factus ad contemnendam pecuniam propter conciliandam gratiam, not of small wealth and therefore of great power,Egesippus l. 1. Excid. Hieroso. c. 14. being a man composed by a wonderfull art to contemne mony for the getting of love. Tremellius refers this verse to that which goes before, but he referreth the words to them, who voluptuosly eate in the morning, whose building by slothfulnesse decayeth, and whose house droppeth through by idlenesse, quum omnia in luxum profusa sint, Tremellius in hunc vers. seeing all is spent in luxurious living: and then he readeth the last part of the verse thus, quorum pecunia facit, ut ista omnia respondeant, whose mony maketh that all those things answere unto their lustfull desires. Lyra also referreth the words in the same manner unto the same persons, and then expressing their feasting jollity he saith according to Saint Hierome and the vulgar Latin, in risu facient panem & vinum, in laughter they make bread and wine: in laughter, that is in foolish idle mirth,Lyra in hunc vers. they make bread and wine, that is disponunt mensam, they furnish and make ready their table. For he tels us that the Hebrew word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used and which signifieth facere to doe or make, is sometimes used to signifie disponere to order and dispose: as when it is commanded of the captive woman whom an Israelite would have to be his wife, that she shall shave her head and pare her nailes, the Hebrew is faciet ungues, she shall make her nayles, that is, Deuter. 21.12. order them by paring of them, and so saith he the word is here used. Now because where there is larg feasting and a plentifull table, there needeth much mony, therefore saith he it follwoes according to Saint Hierome and the Vulgar Latine pecunia obediunt omnia, all things obey money, that is, to get money they are ready to do any thing, & subvertunt judicium propter divitum munera, and they overthrow judgment for the gifts of the rich. Our translation sets downe the verse as if it were a sentence by it selfe, and as shewing that whereas a feast is made for laughter only, and wine is drunk to make merry only, that money serveth for all things. The Preacher expresseth the force of money by a Prosopopeia, and supposing the things to be endowed with speech and understanding, affirmeth money to give a satisfactory answer to whatsoever is asked, desired, commanded. Let that which speaketh be a great way off, yet money heareth, and answereth unto it.Seneca de Ira. l. 3. c. 32.
Seneca saith circa pecuniam multum vociferationis est, that about mony there is much noise great crying, but though never so much, never so great, money answereth all. To make the sense more plaine Pagnine reads it, Pecunia obtinet omnia, mony obtaineth all things Symachus did read it, argentum utile est ad omnia, Tulli l. 3. in veraem. money is profitable for all thing. And this was the judgment of Verres, as Tully sets it downe omnia pecunia effici posse, that all things can be done by mony. The same it is, which the Poet delivereth, & genus et formam regina pecunia donat, Queene mony giveth nobility of birth,Horati. and beauty of body. Wherefore the Prophet David that he might shew his great esteeme of God, & his great affection towards him, compareth him
with mony and riches, saying I have rejoyced in the wayes of thy commandements as much as in all riches.
Psal. 119.14. Riches being that which is so much regarded, so much loved, he sheweth his regard, his love of God to be much above it. But by whom is it that so much it is honoured? with whom is it so powerfull? Aquinas answeareth, Omnia corporalia obediunt pecuniae quantum ad multitudinem stultorum, qui sola corporalia bona agnoscunt quae pecunia acquiri possunt judicium autem de bonis humanis non debet sumi a stultis, sed a sapientibus, all bodily things doe obey mony, Aquin. 1.2. E. 2. A. 1. according to the course of things among the multitude of fooles, who know only bodily good things which by mony may begotten; but the judgement of the good things of man is not to be taken from fooles but from wise men. They are but fooles therefore over whom mony hath so great command, they are but fooles, who are so affected with it, that as Gregory Thaumaturgus expoundeth this part of the verse, argento quovis trahuntur, vili pretio nihil non humile & vile parati facere, by mony they are drawn any where,Gregor. Thaumat. in hunc vers. being ready for a base price to doe any vile and base thing. But in the last place not to omit Saint Hierome, who thinketh this verse to depend upon the former, and understanding the verse before of the slothfulnesse and carelesnesse of those, who rule in the Church, here he conceiveth the Preacher to speak of the same, and to condemne them, because they teach and preach those things, which may delight the people, which may nourish sinners in their sinful courses, and raise up unto themselves an applause among their hearers. Nonne quando in Ecclesia lascivit orator, & beatitudinem & regnum caelorum multitudini pollicetur, Hieronym. in hunc vers. videtur tibi in risu facere panem, & vinum ad laetitiam miscere viventium, when the Preacher playeth the wanton oratour in the Church, and promiseth to the multitude blessednesse and the kingdome of heaven, doth he not seem unto thee to make bread in laughter, and to mingle wine to the joy of the living? For so he readeth the text. The last part of the verse, that to mony all things obey, he applyeth two wayes. Either that such teachers, being grown rich by their flattery and plausibility, regnum in populos exercent doe even reigne over the people. Or else because silver in Scripture is often taken for speech, he conceiveth the Preacher to meane, quod eloquentiae & orationi, quae verborum sit fronde composita, facile vulgus cedat ignobile, that the ignoble common sort of people, doe easily yeild to eloquence and speech which is composed of the leaves of words.

epigraph.q: Ver. 20. Curse not the King, no not in thy thought: and curse not the rich in thy Bed-chamber: for a bird of the ayre shall carrie the voice, and that which hath wings shall tell the matter.

div.p:
Ver. 20. The Preacher having shewed the evill government of a King and his Princes, and the hurt which from thence the land suffereth, least hereupon any might be emboldned being moved by anger or fury to curse the King or the Princes he giveth direction here whereby to take heed of it: because it commeth to passe even beyond thought, that though it be done even in thought only or never so secretly, yet it is made knowne to them who are cursed, and danger is incurred by it. Curse not the King: the originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used signifieth any disrespect or disesteeme of the King. For indeed great is the honour and reverence that is due unto them, and great regard and care there must be had not to diminish it in the least manner.1 Sam. 6.19. We read that God smote the men of Bethshemesh because they looked into the Ark, a signe of authority: for when in the wildernesse the Ark moved, then the people went on their journey, when the Ark stood still then they rested, and it was the Ark that lead them into the land of Canaan. The note which Eucherius hath upon the place is this, ob hoc a Domino percussi sunt,
Numb. 10.33. quia non solum appropinquaverunt ad arcam, sed etiam ut alia translatio habet, despexerunt, for this were they smitten by the Lord not only because they came neere unto the Ark, but also as I take the meaning despised it, as another translation hath it.Eucherius. For because the Ark had been taken captive, therefore it may be that they did with contempt look into it; but God is so displeased, when authority is contemned, that he smote fifty thousand for it. Saint Cyprian therefore observing our saviours caryage, when being stroken by the officer, it was said unto him, answerest thou the High Priest so? Iohn. 8.22.23. noteth that our saviour custodiens & docens sacerdotalem honorem servari oportere, contra pontificem nihil dixit, sed innocentiam suam tantum modo purgavit, teaching and by his practise shewing that the honour of the High Priest was to be perserved, he spake nothing against the High Priest, but only defended his owne innocency, saying if I have done evill bare witnesse of the evill, if well why smitest thou mee? No, not in thy thought: Cypria. Epist. 69 the originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
non in scientia tua not in thy knowledge, that is, though thou mayest know the King to doe evill and the land to suffer evill by it, yea though thou mayest know it by thine owne suffering of evill, yet let not thine heart curse him. But to take the reading as generally the word is rendred, not in thy thought. The thought of man is the bed-chamber of his soule, there he is most secret, there most retired. But trust not to this secrecy: for as Lyra noteth, illa quae in cogitatione revolvuntur, Lyra in hunc vers. de facili verbo proferuntur etiam praeter intentionem proferentis, the things which are turned up and downe in the thought, are easily uttered in word, yea even beyond the intention of him that doth utter them. And indeed the earth is not a place of secrecy, it is not almost in the power of earthly frailty to keepe any thing secret and concealed. Wherefore Saint Paul was taken up into the third heaven,2 Corint. 12.2. when he heard things that might not be uttered: according as Saint Ambrose noteth upon it, who saith Paulus audivit aliqua secreta sapientiae, quae
prohibitus est aliis intimare, at ideo raptus est in paradisum, raptus est usque ad tertium coelum, Ambros. de Intepel. l 1. c. 9.
ut ea audiret, Paul heard some secrets of wisdom, which he was forbidden to make knowne to others, and therefore he was taken up into paradise, he was taken up into the third heaven, that he might heare them. And curse not the rich in thy bed-chamber: sleep desireth privatnesse and quietnesse,Ovidius. according as the Poet describeth the house of sleep to be in a cave, into which a long entry leadeth to give remotenesse to it, and that it hath no dore least the stirring therof should make any noyse, neither any watchfull bird or beast is suffered to be nere it. Wherefore it is also the manner to make choice of that roome for a bed-chamber which is most private; and hence it is that the Preacher here speaketh of a bed-chamber, as noting the greatest privatenesse that may be, and where that which is said may be heard by no one. But trust not unto that: for as the Poet sheweth the deceipt of this confidence, O Coridon, Coridon, secretum divitis ullum esse putas? servi ut taceant, jumenta loquentur, & canis & postes & marmora, claude fenestras, vela tegant rimas, junge ostia, tollite lumen è medio, clament omnes, prope nemo recumbat, quod tamen ad cantum galli facit ille secundum proximus ante dienc caupo sciet, O Coridon, Coridon, thinkest thou that any secret of a rich man can be kept secret, let the servants be silent, the beasts will speak it,Iuvenalis Saty 9 the dog, the postes, the marble: shut too the windowes, let curtaines cover the chinks, make fast the dores, take away the light, let all cry, let no one lye nere; notwithstanding that which he doth at the second crow of the cock, the next alehouse shall know before day; In like manner this it is which the Preacher here addeth, for a bird of the ayre shall cary the voice, and that which hath wings shall tell the matter, Hieronym. in hunc vers. it shall be quickly known. For so Saint Hierome saith, hyperbolice intelligendum, it is to be understood by way of an hyperbole, as when we say, the very wals which are witnesses of what were speak will not conceale it. So likewise Tremellius saith, ratio hyperbolica pro eo quod est, principes & potentiores sunt auritissimi, an hyperbolicall manner of speaking, as if he should have said, Princes and great men are very quick of hearing, so that hardly any thing is done or said which commeth not to their knowledge. They have some birds that flye up and downe, Daniel. 4.10. & 12. they have some that have wings which quickly bring to their ears that which is thought to be most secret. Nebuchadnezzar in the visions of his head saw himself to be a great tree, and the foules of heaven to dwell in the branches thereof: where Lyra saith, per volucres intelliguntur garruli & mendaces ad alta tendentes quia tales solent esse principibus laterales, Lyra Ibid. by the foules are understood prating and lying fellows, seeking to climbe on high, because such use to be neere about Princes. And here in this place he saith, that the birds of the ayre are relatores verborum talebearers, which are here said to be birds of the ayre, as in the parable of the sower, Luc. 8.5. & 12. the devils are said to be birds of the ayre. For such indeed chatter more them birds, and are alwayes flying thither from whence they may bring something, which they may reveale. Take
heed therefore that thou curse not either King or Princes, secrecy cannot hide it, the voice will be carried, the matter will be told:Lyra in hunc vers. for as Lyra noteth est repetitio ejusdem sententiae ad majorem confirmationē, the sentence is repeated for the stronger confirmation of it. But Saint Hierome desiring to make the words more profitable for us, he applyeth them unto Christ the King of his Church,Hieronym. in hunc vers. and telleth us that we are forbidden to speak rashly against him even in the secret of our heart, although by manifold afflictions his hand may be upon us. And that not only we must not speak ill against Christ, but not against his servants neither, and that an evill toung must not wrong them whom we see to be enriched with wisedome and knowledge and heavenly vertues; because the Angels which goe up and downe the earth will carry it to God. And if we take the Angels to be the wicked Angels, then Hugo Hugo. noteth unto us the difference that is betwixt the good Angels and the bad; Rev. 8.3. that the good Angels are said to offer up the prayers of the Saints unto God, but the wicked Angels are said to carry the offences of men unto God.

q.p: VER. 1 Cast thy bread upon the waters: for thou shalt find it after many dayes.
Ver. 2. Give a portion to seven, and also to eight: for thou knowest not what evill shall be upon the earth.
Ver. 3. If the clouds be full of raine, they empty themselves upon the earth: & if the tree fall toward the South, or toward the North, in the place, where the tree falleth there it shall be.
Ver. 4. He that observeth the wind shall not sow: and he that regardeth the clouds shall not reape.
Ver. 5. As thou knowest not what is the way of the Spirit nor how the bones doe grow in the wombe of her that is with child: even so thou knowest not the workes of God who maketh all.
Ver. 6. In the morning sow thy seed, and in the evening with hold not thine hand: for thou knowest not whether shall prosper, either this or that, or whether they both shall be alike good.

div.p:
Ver. 1. THe Preacher having before exhorted generally unto the works of vertue, here he persuadeth specially unto the works of charity, because they in an especiall manner do advance man to his eternall good in heaven. According as our Saviour speaking to the charitable saith, come ye blessed of my father inhreit the Kingdome prepared for you from the foundation of world. And the whole chapter is devided into three parts. Matt. 25.34. First he exhorteth unto the works of charity, unto the sixth verse. Secondly unto a speedinesse in these works, from the sixth verse unto the ninth, and there lastly he inferreth the conclusion of his purpose in the two last verses. The first part is subdivided into two parts, and first he exhorteth to the exercise of charity in the three first verses.Lyra in hoc cap. Secondly he removeth the impediment which might stop the speed unto it in the fourth, and fifth verses: thus Lyra giveth the division of the chapter. Cast thy bread upon the waters, &c. Saint Hierome directly according to the Originall reads it, mitte panem tuum super faciem aquae, Tremell. in hunc vers. quia in multitudine dierum invenies illum, Send thy bread upon the surface of the water, and in the multitude of dayes thou shalt find it. And so most literally the words seeme to say, that as that which is carried by the water is at length found in the ocean, where the multitude of waters is gathered together; so that which is given to the poore is carried into heaven, and there shall be found in the endlesse multitude of dayes, wherein shall be gathered together the multitude of all good things. Cast thy bread, that is saith Tremellius, thy seed, the seed of thy good works,Hieronym. in hunc vers. the bread which is made of the seed by a Synecdoche being used for the seed. But though he who soweth his land doth sow seed, yet as Saint Hierome saith, qui largitur egentibus
non granum seminis, sed ipsum panem serit, he that giveth to the poore soweth bread and not the grains of seed. Wherefore we may well enough take the word without a figure. Cast thy bread upon the waters: that is saith Saint Hierome ad eleemosynam cohortatur, Tremel. in hun • vers. quod omni petenti sit dandum, he exhorteth so unto works of charity, as that wee should give to every one that asketh. The French translation reads it, cast thy bread aval l'eau along as the waters go, and as occasion is offered unto thee so be still casting thy bread, be still shewing thy charity. And to this sense as I conceive doth the vulgar Latin read it, cast thy bread super transeuntes aquas upon the waters passing along, and as still any occasion passeth by the, let it not passe without thy bread cast upon it, thy charity shewed some way or other. Tremellius reads it, cast they bread secundum aquam by the waters, and giveth it this meaning, that as they who sow their seed upon fertile ground, which is neere unto waters, by which it is watered, do expect a plentifull crop from it; so the Preacher would have us to sow the works of charity, from whence we may expect a plentifull reward. And indeed God being alwayes full, so that his bounty cannot be exhausted, he loveth those that doe so carry themselves, and so dispose their wayes, as that their works may still expect a great reward from him. He is not liked by God, that spendeth his time so, and so consumeth his means, as that he cannot look to reape any fruit by it. He is approoved by God that maketh every bit of bread to bring great gaine unto him. Wherefore Saint Bernard saith, nunquam quum veniat Dominus, inveniat imparatos, sed semper vultus suspensos expausosque sinus habentes, Bernard. Ser. 17 in Canti. ad largam Domini benedictionem, let the Lord when he commeth never find us unready, but alwayes with our faces looking up towards him, alwayes having our bosomes open, our laps spread abroad as looking to receive a large blessing from him. For God desireth that we should be like unto them, who waite for their Lord when he will returne from the wedding, quod utique ab illis supernae mensae copiosis deliciis vacua nunquam revertitur manu, because from the abundant danities of the heavenly table he never returneth with an empty hand.Catena Graeca. Or else we are here bid to cast our bread upon the waters, as teaching us that when we give our almes, to the poore, we should also have a fellow feeling of their misery, and that as misery wringeth teares from the poore, so compassion should wring the same from us. So doth the Catena Graeca expound these words saying, Cum Sympathia & lachrymis fac eleemosynam tuam omni transeunti; with teares and Sympathy of griefe bestow thine almes on every one that passeth by. Cassiodore writing of some mountaynes called Lactari montes the milky montaynes, on which the beasts that feed doe give such norishing milke, that mens bodyes pined and consumed away doe thereby not onely receive strength and health but fatnesse also, whereas the beasts themselves are exceeding leane, so that as Cassiodore expresseth it, mero modo herbis animalia non proficiunt, unde hominum membra pinguescunt, exiles per dumeta excurrunt
montium, tenues videntur, & instar ejus cui medentur sustinent passiones, after a wonderfull manner the beasts doe not profit by that grasse, by which the bodyes of men grow fat: they go up and downe neer the thickets of the mountaines leane and thin,Cassidor. var. l. ver. 10. and as it were sustayning the condition of those, who are healed by them. Like to these beasts should charity make us, and as we comfort the poore with the milke that we give them, so we should as it were sustaine their distresse by a fellow feeling sorrow with them. Or lastly we are bid to cast our bread upon the waters, to teach us that our charity should be free and liberall and alwayes flowing as the waters are. For thou shalt find it after many dayes: that is although the waters may seeme to carry thy bread away, and thou mayest seeme to be no whit the better for it; yet it shall not be so, but thou shalt find it againe, and find it to thy great comfort and benefit.Gregor. Thamat in hunc vers. Thus doth Gregorius Thaumaturgus expound the words saying, quamvis id statim perdidisse videas quemadmodum si panem in aquam conjecisses, tamen progressu temporis nequaquam infrugifera apparebit beneficentia, although thy charity may seeme to some to be forthwith lost, as if thou hadst cast thy bread into the water, yet in processe of time thy bounty shall appeare not to be unfruitfull unto thee Or else, thou shalt find it after many dayes, that is although thou doe not find it presently, yet be not impatient, distrust not a reward, for though it be long before thou see the comfort of thy charity requited yet be sure of it, for it shall come at last, and make a large recompence for the delay of it. Let me therefore say unto thee as one doth, mitte panem tuum super aquas, & in verbo Domini promitto tibi, quod post multa tempora invenies, cast thy bread upon the waters, and cast thy care upon mee, for in the word of the Lord I promise the, that after many dayes thou shalt finde it. Yea let it be but a piece of bread that thou castest, and thou shalt find it to be a tree of of life unto thee. For as Saint Bernard noteth, this is the difference betweene God and the devill,Bernard de gradib. superb. gradu. 1.
ille obtulit pomum & abstulit paradisum, Deus offert paradisum & postulat pomum, He offered an apple, and took away paradise, God offereth paradise, and requireth but an apple.

Vers. 2. Give a portion: Saint Ambrose speaking of these words saith, primum quaerendum nobis est, quid sit unde partes facere praecipimur. Est namque quoddam bonum, & ipsum est summum bonum, charitas videlicet, quae nisi partiatur perfectum bonum non est. Partitur enim in dilectione Dei, & in dilectione proximi, the first thing that wee are to seeke for is, what that is of which wee are commanded to make a portion. For there is a certaine good, and it is the chiefest good, namely charity, which unlesse it be devided is not a perfect good. It is devided therefore into the love of God, and into the love of our neighbour.Ambros. m. c. 2. Apocal. The charitable love of our neighbour is devided into as many parts, as are there persons that stand in need of it. This therefore it is that the Preacher here saith, give thy portion to seven and also unto eight. That
is saith Lyra da abundanter, give abundantly:Tremell. in hunc vers. that is saith Tremellius distribue quam plurimis potes, give to as many as thou canst. Cajetane telleth us that the old Jewes in honour of the seven first dayes did give their almes unto seven persons as contented with that number.Cajetan. in haec verba. And that therefore the Spirit of God doth here admonish them to give a portion unto seven and unto eight also, as if it were said, doe not set those bounds unto thy charity,Nazianz. Orat. 16. so that if need be thou be not ready to go beyond them. But it seemeth by Nazianzene that the Jews did take their custome of giving unto seven from this passage of Scripture, as if they were commanded to give to seven only, and that eight was added as a thing left unto their own pleasure; he therefore speaking of Porreus a Bishop saith, pauperum inopiam quantum poterat sublevans, partemque dans non septem duntaxat, velut Solomonis lex praescribit, verum si octavus accederet, libentius sua profunderet, quam alii acquirunt; relieving the wants of the poore, as much as he could, and giving a portion not only to seven, as the law of Solomon prescribeth, but if an eight did come, bestowing that which he had as willingly, as others doe get that which they have not. And indeed it is the glory of charitie, to disperse it selfe to many, not only to those, that are of our kindred, but to those also that are not, not only to those that we know, but to those also that we know not, not only to those of the same place with us, but to Strangers also, not only to those that are of the same religion with us, but to them also that differ therein from us. The manner of the ancient Christians, being to doe so, and Julian the Apostate envying them for it, he gave order to his Officers to build hospitalls for travellers, Xenodochia, in which they should receive all, even Christians also, who were hatefull to him without any difference, saying that by that bountifull means, the Disciples of Jesus had won the hearts of all. Saint Bernard considering that passage of the women, Mark. 16.1. who had bought spices, that they might embalme Jesus, thereupon, saith, non ad ungendum tantum aliquam corporis partem, videlicet pedes aut caput, sed ut venientes ungerent Jesum, quod est totius corporis complexio. Bernard. Tu quoque si te induas viscera misericordiae, liberalem benignumque te exhibeas erga omnes, it was not to anoynt some one part of his body, namely his head or his feet, but that comming, they might anoynt Jesus, Galat. 2.9. V. 10 which comprehendeth the whole body of him. And doe thou also,Tertull. advers. Hermogen. if thou dost put on the bowels of mercy, shew thy selfe liberall, and bountifull towards all. When Saint Paul came to Jerusalem, Peter, James and John gave him the right hand of fellowship, and Tertullian saith of it, de officii distributione pepigerunt, they made a covenant with him concerning the distribution of the ministery, that he and Barnabas should goe to the heathen, and they unto the circumcision, only they would that they should remember the poore. That was a thing to be done every where, that was to be done among the heathen, as well as among the circumcision, that was to be done to eight, the Gentiles, as well as to seven the Jewes. For thou knowest not what shall be upon the earth, that
is, thou knowest not what misery, what calamity shall come, wherein the charity which thou hast shewed, may be a means to move God to preserve and to deliver thee. For godlinesse hath not only the promise of the life to come, 1. Tim. 4.8. but of this life also. Or else, as Lyra speaketh, forte eveniet mortalitas hominum per pestilentiam aut gladium, in qua toleris de vita praesenti; Lyra in hunc vers. & tunc opera pietatis valebunt tibi, quia sola pietas est comes defunctorum ut dicet Augustinus, perhaps a mortality of men shall come either by the Pestilence, or else by the Sword, in which thou shalt be taken away from this present life, and then thy works of godlinesse will be profitable unto thee: for godlinesse onely is the companion of the dead, as Saint Austin speaketh. Saint Gregory expounding this verse, It is, saith he, ac si aperte diceretur, sic dispensa temporalia, ut appetere non obliviscaris aeterna. Oportet namque ut in posterum bene agendo provideas, qui de venturo judicio quanta tribulatio sequatur ignoras. Hinc est quod quindecim gradibus templi ascenditur, ut ex ipsa ejus ascensione discatur, quatenus per septem & octo temporalis solicite dispensetur actio, & provide mansio aeterna requiratur, as if it were plainly said, so dispose of temporall things, that thou forget not to seeke after eternall things. For it behoveth thee that by doing well, thou provide for the time to come, who knows not what calamity may follow in the judgement that is to come.Gregor. Moral. l. 35. c. 7. Hence it is that the temple ascended up by fifteene steps, that by the very ascending of it might be learned, how by seven and eight both our temporall actions might be ordered carefully, and our eternall mansion might be sought for providently. The ancient fathers are very much in finding out some mystery in the first part of this verse, and in the numbers seven and eight. Saint Ambrose saith, Sancti itaque Dei partes septem dant amoris sui, Ambros. in c. 2. Apocalyp. quam in exercitiis vitae activae occupantur, videlicet quum curam proximo non solum carnalem sed & spiritualem impendunt. Dant etiam partes octo quum eos amor Dei ad contemplationem ejus revocant, the Saints of God therefore doe give to seven, portions of their love, when they are busied in the works of an active life, namely when they bestow not only a carnall, but a spirituall care upon their neighbour. They give also portions to eight, when the love of God calleth them back againe to a contemplation of him. Saint Hierome findeth out here the mysterie of the two parts of the Scriptures, and in the number seven, the Old Testament, because of the Sabbath of the Jewes, in the number eight the New Testament, because of the resurrection. And shewing that the Jewes did give their faith only to the Old Testament, to the number seven, that Marcion, the Manichees, and other hereticks did give their faith only to the number eight, to the new Testament rejecting the old, he concludeth, nos utrique credamus instrumento. Non enim possumus dignos cruciatus dignamque paenam jam nunc mente comprehendere, quae reposita est his qui versantur in terra Judaeis atque haereticis e duobus alterum denegantibus, Hieronym. in hunc vers. let us therefore beleeve both instruments. For we cannot now comprehend in our minds, the deserved torments, the deserved punishment, which is laid up for those that
are upon the earth, Jewes and haereticks, that doe denie either of them.

Ver. 3. S. Chrysost. shewing how in the condition of this life, we all stand in need one of the other; & that not only he that receiveth alms,Chrysost. Homil. 17. in 2. ad Corinth. standeth in need of him that giveth it, but he that giveth it also standeth in need of him that receiveth it: giveth this reason of it, nisi enim pauperes essent, salus nostra magna ex parte profligata esset, ubi enim pecunias serere possemus, non haberemus, because unlesse that there were poore, our salvation would be in a great part hindred, because we should not have where to sow our money. Now with this metaphor, the Preacher having begun this chapter,Tremell. in hunc vers. Tremellius conceiveth him to continue the same in this verse, and that here he sheweth, that as God blesseth the seed that is sowen, and by the raine of the full clouds, maketh it to be fruitfull; so he blesseth also the works of charity, and maketh them fruitfull in much comfort and happinesse. Wherefore taking also the Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here used to signifie plantam, a plant, for so himselfe translateth it, hee giveth this meaning of the latter part of the verse, that as wheresoever the plant falls, there the owner of it is sure to find it, and to receive fruit of it, so he that doth the works of charity, shall be sure to find and receive the fruit and reward of them. Now this meaning is both religious, and most true. When Alexander set forward unto his great exploits, before he went from Macedonia, he devided to his captains and friends all that he possessed. For which, when one of his friends reproved him, saying that he was prodigall, because he had reserved nothing for himselfe: the answere which Alexander gave, was this, that he had reserved much unto himselfe: namely, hope of the Monarchy of the world, which by his valour, and helpe of those his captaines, and nobles he hoped to attaine. And surely, though to some, he that giveth unto the poore, may seem to be prodigall, yet in respect of the hope, which he hath of profit, he is frugally wise. Neither is his hope such as Alexanders was, which depended on the uncertainty of warre, but it is grounded upon the certainty of Gods word. But as those excellent and most learned men doe many times fetch their translation afarre off, so it is not seldome that they goe far to bring home the sense and meaning of it. It seemeth to me, that wee may reach the Preachers meaning neerer hand. For having first exhorted unto charity, in the first verse, secondly having commended to our charity, many persons in the second verse, here he proceedeth to the measure of our charity, and would have it to be full. The Psalmist speaking of a good man, saith, he hath dispersed, he hath given to the poore,
Psal. 112.9. his righteousnesse endureth forever, his horne shall be exalted. And here the Preacher having exhorted us to disperse our charity to many; next he exhorteth us to give to them freely. For as the clouds being full of raine, doe readily empty themselves upon the earth, which is under them; so he would have them, who are full of abundance, freely to give to the poore, and to satisfie the want of them, who by the meanesse of their estate, are in a low condition.
And this he would have them to doe, while they have time of doing good, and when now in their lives they may provide how it shall be with them after death, because as the tree falleth, either toward the North, or toward the South, there it shall be. But there is also somthing more to be noted in the words. For they may be rendred out of the Originall thus, if the clouds be full, they empty the raine upon the earth, for so Pagnine, Arias Montanus, and the French translation doe reade the words. Now the Originall word here used for raine is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth a great and strong raine, as Rabbi Kimchi affirmeth: so that wee are taught, that as the clouds, being full, doe give great store of raine, so they who are full of the blessings of this life, should not be scant in affording reliefe unto them that want it. If thou be an Olive tree, a fat tree, be also a greene Olive tree, as the Prophet saith that he was, and bring forth much fruit in thy works of charity. For how canst thou pray as the Prophet David doth, Have mercy upon me, O Lord, according to thy loving kindnesse,
Psal. 52.8. according to the multitude of thy tender mercies blot out my transgressions; If there be not in thee a loving kindnesse toward the poore? Psal. 51.1. If there be not in thee tender mercies towards them, if it be a scantnesse, not a multitude of mercies that is in thee? Malachi. 1.14. Doth not the Prophet Malachy tell us, cursed is the deceiver, which hath in his flocke a male, and sacrificeth to the Lord a corrupt thing? Where he is called a deceiver, because having wherewith to doe better, by his offering he maketh himselfe, as it were, not able. But yet how many such are there in the world,Chrysost. Homil. 17. ad populum. and whereas Saint Chrysostome speaketh, they ride on horses with golden chains, and lie on silver beds, and use much more pompe, yet when they come to give to the poore, pauperrimis redduntur pauperiores, they are made more poore then the poorest. Alexander Quintus, Pope of Rome said of himselfe, That when he was a Bishop, he was rich, when he was a Cardinall, hee was poore, and when he was Pope, hee was a beggar; and plainly so it is with many, who the richer they are, still are the poorer, in respect of their giving to the poore. Now if we read the former part of the verse so, and take it in this sense, then we may understand the latter part of the verse thus, that as the tree falling towards the South, lyeth there, so when a worke of charity is done with a warme devotion, accordingly it is by God accepted: and as when a tree falleth towards the North, it lyeth there, so when a worke of charity is done with a cold devotion, it is accordingly by God esteemed. But generally the ancient Fathers, and latter expositors doe understand, or at least apply the latter part of the verse with reference unto death. Saint Gregory saith, Where the tree falls whether toward the North, or towards the South, there it shall bee, in diem enim mortis suae justus ad austrum cadit peccator ad aquilonem, Gregor. Moral. l. 12. c. 4.
quia & justus per fervorem spiritus ad gaudia ducitur, & peccator cum apostata angelo, qui dixit sedebo in lateribus aquilonis, in frigido suo corde reprobatur,
Isa. 14.13. for the righteous, in the day of death falleth towards the South, and by the fervour of the spirit, is carryed unto joyes; the sinner with
the apostate angel, who said, I will sit on the sides of the north,
Isa. 14.13. in his cold heart is rejected. Saint Bernard saith, Man is a tree, which by death is cut downe, and wheresoever he falleth, there hee shall be, because there God judgeth him, where death findeth him, and there he shall be without any change. Videat ergo quo casura sit, antequam cadat, quia postquam ceciderit, non adjiciet ut resurgat, sed ut nec se vertat, Bern. Serm. 49. ex parvis. let him therefore see where he falleth, before he falleth, because when he is fallen, he shall not helpe himselfe to rise, no, not so much as to turne himselfe. Now which way he shall fall, if any one will know, let him marke his boughs, for where the boughs are most and greatest, on that side there is no doubt that his fall will be. Our boughs then are our love and our desires, and from them our actions, by which we are extended towards the South, if that we love spirituall things chiefly: if carnall things be more weightie with us, then are wee extended towards the North, and accordingly, when we die will these make us to fall, make us to lie.

Vers. 4. For the understanding of this verse, wee may take a good light from Columella; whose words are these, Ʋbi paleis immixta sunt frumenta vento separentur. Ad eam rem favonius habetur eximius, quem tamen operiri lenti est agricolae, qui dum expectatur saeva nos hyems opprimit. Itaque in area detrita frumenta sic sunt aggerenda ut omni statim occasione possint excerni. Ac si pluribus diebu undique silebit aura vannis expurgentur, ne post nimiam ventorum segnitiem, Columel. l. 2. c. 21
vasta tempestas irritum faciat totius anni laborem, when the grains of corne are mixed with chaffe, let them be severed by wind. A west wind is accounted excellent for this businesse: but yet to stay for it, is a signe of a lazy husband-man, because while it is expected, the hard winter overtaketh us. Wherefore the threshed corne is so to be laid together in the barnefloore, that upon every occasion it may be winnowed. And if for many dayes, the wind be still and quiet every way, let it be cleansed with fannes, least after too much dulnesse and slacknesse of the winds, a grievous tempest overflow the labour of the whole yeere: To apply it to the verse. He that delayeth the works of his charity, expecting, as he saith, the fittest occasion, as if the husband-man should stay his winnowing, expecting a westerne favorian wind, sheweth his charity to be cold in him: and perhaps some tempest, some affliction shall arise, which may deprive him of his means, and make him unable to sow, unable to exercise his charity. In generall, the meaning of the verse is, that as he who scrupulously observeth the wind, regardeth the clouds, oftentimes overpasseth his sowing, looseth his reaping; so he that sheweth not his charity, but in a curious observing, how, when, and to whom he doth it, looseth the sowing of much seed, looseth the reaping of much fruite. To consider the thing more particularly. And first, as for him that curiously considereth unto whom he giveth, Saint Hierome saith,Hieronym. in hunc vers. qui considerat cui tribuit, saepe praeterit eum qui meretur accipere, he that considereth on whom he bestoweth his almes, oftentimes passeth him
by, who is worthy to receive them. The precept of our Saviour Christ is, Luc. 6.30. give to every man that asketh of thee: if his necessitie make him to aske, let thy charity make thee to give. What though he be an ill liver?Chrysost. Conc. 2. de Lazaro. Saint Chrysostome tells us non moribus demus sed homini, nec illius ob suam virtutem nos misereatur, sed ob calamitatem, let us not give to the manners of the man, but to the man, neither let us have pitty of him in regard of his vertue, but of his misery. The same Father tells us,Chrysost. Ibid. Portus in necessitate constitutorum homo misericors, a mercifull man is the haven of them that are in distresse. Wherefore as in a tempest the haven receiveth all that flye unto it, whether good or bad, so a mercifull man bestoweth his charity upon all, and though he rather helpeth them, that live well, yet all that be in want shall have his reliefe. Secondly as for him that observeth when he will give, and as the scrupulous husbandman observeth the wind, regardeth the clouds, so he stayeth untill the poore body sue unto him, or untill some friend whose favour he respecteth, doe speak for him, what doth he but loose the sowing of his charity? what doth he but loose much comfort which he might reape? For as Saint Austin speaketh,August. l. Hom. 50. Homil. 39.
perfecta est misericordia, ut ante occurrat esurienti cibus, quam roget mendicus, quae precibus extorquetur non est perfecta, perfect mercifulnesse, is that the food doe meete the hungry, before that the beggar aske for it, that which is extorted by begging is not perfect. Doth not saith he the raine fal before thou askest for it? Doth not the sun arise while thou art in thy bed? Doe not the fruits spring while thou thinkest not of them? And dost thou ô man sell a little bread for much asking? Magnum opus est eleemosynae, ut faciat homo, quod facit Deus, the great work of charity is that man doe as God doth.
