Thirdly as for him that curiously observeth how he giveth, and as he that observeth the wind soweth not least the wind should blow away his seed, as he that regardeth the clouds reapeth not fearing the frounes of the skye, so he feareth to shew his charity in any great manner, least himselfe should come to want; let him heare, what David saith he never saw, saying, I have been young,
Psal. 36.25. & 26. and now am old, yet have I not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging their bread. Perhaps it will be objected, that there have been many righteous men poore: but the place speaketh of a righteous charitable man, for so the following verse sheweth, which saith, he is ever mercifull and lendeth, and his seed is blessed. And who hath seen such a one or his seed to be brought to such poverty, as to beg his bread? When our Saviour Christ had fed foure thousand with seven loaves and a five fishes,Augustin. all being filled, seven baskets full of fragments were gathered up: and it is Saint Austins note upon it, crescit dum impenditur victus, sic eleemosyna si indigentibus erogetur, the victuals in spending were augmented, and so is the almes which is given to the poore. By allusion Saint Hierome applyeth this verse unto them,Hieronym. in hunc vers. who preach the word of God in that time only when the people are willing to heare: whereas saith he, oportunè importunè suo tenore Dei sermo est praedicandus, nec fidei tempore adversariarum nubium consideranda tempestas, the
word of God is to be preached in season, out of Season, in its owne tenour, neither in a time of saith, is the tempest of opposing clouds to be regarded. Saint Gregory maketh another allusion, and he saith, what is signified by wind but the tempting of the wicked spirits?Gregor. Past. Cu. p. 3. Adm. 16 What by the clouds which are moved by the wind but the opposition of wicked men? For as the clouds are driven by the wind, so wicked men are driven by the breath of the uncleane Spirits. He therefore that observeth, the wind, soweth not, and he that regardeth the clouds never reapeth, quia quisquis tentationem malignorum Spirituum, quisquis persecutionem malignorum hominum metuit, neque nunc grana boni operis seminat, neque tunc manipulos sanctae retributionis secat, because whosoever feareth the temptations of the wicked spirits, whosoever feareth the persecution of evill men, shall neither sow now the seed of good works, nor hereafter reape the handfuls of a holy retribution.

Ver. 5. The Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 some doe translate ventum the wind, taking their direction as it seemeth from the former verse, where the wind is spoken of. Others doe translate it Spiritum the spirit, being guided as it seemes by the latter part of this verse, which speaketh of the forming of man in the wombe of his Mother. Thus our translation readeth it, and therefore so to consider it. I am first of all moved to consider why the Preacher should joyne this with the argument of charity, and it maketh me to thinke that the works of charity doe make God in a more especiall manner to blesse the fruite of the wombe,2 Kings 14.8. and to give to them children, who doe give to his children in their distresse and want. I am sure that it was so with the Shunamite, and she having provided a chamber and furnished it for the Prophet Elisha, God provided a chamber for her child, and furnished her with fruit of her wombe. Saint Ambrose noting the same and speaking of it, saith, Sunamitis illa magna mulier in superioribus hospitium paravit, & ibi concipiendae sobolis meruit praerogativam, ibidemque resuscitati pignoris vidit miraculum, that great woman the Shunamite prepared an upper lodging for the Prophet, and there it was that she obtained the prerogative of conceiving a child, there she saw the miracle of her son restored unto life. But to consider the verse, what is more divine, what more admirable, what more secret then the forming of man in the wombe? Philosophers and Physitians may study much about it, as which part first liveth, which is first formed, and whether all be formed together, but Galen Galen. said well, the question is so difficult and hard to be resolved, as that it is known to none, but to God and nature. There may be much said of a formatiue faculty, and diverse opinions may dispute it diversly, at what time the formation is perfected, to which Hypocrates Hypocrat. prescribeth in male children thirty dayes as the longest time, in females two and forty: but let us say with the Psalmist, I will praise thee O Lord, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made,
Psal. 139.14. & 15. mervailous are they workes: my substance was not hid from thee, when I was made in secret, and curiously wrought in the lowest parts of the earth. As for the bones of man which the Preacher here more particularity mentioneth,
they are they, which as Hypocrates saith doe give 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to the body uprightnesse shape, stablenesse: because they doe as it were defend it, against the force that assaulteth it, and because they uphold the body, as the foundation, wals and timber uphold the house: uprightnesse, because unlesse the creatures had bones, they would creepe upon the ground as wormes doe: shape and figure because from them the stature and growth are limited and bounded. Moreover not one but many are the bones of mans body, and man being made to be apprehensive in understanding, stirring in action, capable of the representation of sensitive things, and accordingly to follow diverse objects to which his desire should carry him, therefore motion was bestowed upon him: whereas if he had consisted but of one bone, how could he either have bowed any way, or any way reached out his body to any thing, either by going to it or taking of it? Almighty God therefore for the use of mans life, and for the exercise of the severall motions of the body, hath strangly composed the body of a pack or set of bones, of diverse sortes and manifold shapes. Now this variety is likewise very usefull, that when one bone receiveth any hurt, thereby the others might not be hindred in their offices. And yet though many be the bones of mans body, such is the connexion of them, and so wonderfully are they fitted together, that all are as it were but one by that contiguity which is betweene them. The totall compage and set of the bones is called a Syntaxe and the fabrick of the bones so fitted together is called a sceleton. Of which how they are made, how joyned together, how fitted so, who can tell but he that maketh all? But to apply now the verse unto the Preachers argument in this place, I conceive thus of it. The Preacher here, in our charity would have us to imitate God in this great worke of his: for thou knowest not the way of God when he formeth the bodyes of children, and giveth soules unto them of whom he fore knoweth that they will be wicked, and that they will imploy both unto his dishonour: thou knowest not the way of God, when he giveth substance and life to children of adultery and fornication, as well as he doth to them who are born in wedlock, and of whom he foreknoweth that they will serve him and feare him. Notwithstanding this God doth, and doe thou so likewise in thy workes of charity, although thy poore foreknowledge may think, that what thou givest will be spent in naughtinesse. Againe he that is in the wombe knoweth not what is done for him, knoweth not who it is that doth it; he doth not aske it, he doth not desire it, God himself alone seeth, what is needfull, and he doth all for him. And doe thou so likewise, doe thou bestow thine almes on him that knowes thee not, on him that asketh not of thee, and cannot tell from whence it commeth to him. To this Saint Ambrose exhorting thee, saith, videndus est ille, qui te non videt, requirendus est ille qui erubescit videri: ille etiam clausus in carcere occurrat tibi, ille affectus aegritudine mentem tuam personet, qui aures non potest, he is to be seen by thee, who doth not see thee, he is to be sought out who is
ashamed to be seen by thee, let him meete thee who is shut up in prison, and let his voice who lyeth sick a bed sound in thy mynd, which cannot sound in thine eares. Againe that which God worketh in the wombe is all done in secret, and is hidden from the eyes of all: let thy workes of charity be done so likewise, let them be done in secrecy, not in ostentation, and let not thy left hand know, what thy right hand doth. Lastly thou knowest not how the Spirit comes into the child, how the bones are set up and strengthned, yet thou findest it to be done: wherefore give unto the poore and spare not, and though thou knowest not how it commeth to passe, yet thou shalt find thine estate to be strengthned thy substance to be encreased, the blessings of God to be upon thee and multiplied towards thee. It were a vaine thing to feare, when a child is conceived least the Spirit should not find the way into it, or least the bones should not grow in him, and no lesse vaine is their feare, who are troubled least by giving to the poore, their estate should decay, and that either themselves or theirs should be brought to misery. Leo therefore saith, non timeatur in his expensis defectio facultatum quoniam ipsa benignitas magna substantia est, nec potest charitati deesse materies, Leo. Serm. 10. de Quadrag. ubi Christus pascit, & pascitur. In omni hoc opere illa intervenit manus, quae panem frangendo auget, & erogando multiplicat; in these expences let not a failing of means be feared, because bounty it self is great wealth, neither can the matter of bounty be wanting, where Christ himselfe feedeth, and is fed. In every such worke that hand is a fellow worker, which encreaseth bread by breaking it, and by giving multiplyeth. And surely as God doth wonderfully by building up the house of mans body in his mothers wombe, so doth he oftentimes wonderfully build up their houses, who are free in the workes of charity. Wherefore Saint Chrysostome saith, in haec aedificia studeamus evacuare pecunias nostras, nec fabris nec structoribus nec operariis opus habebimus: manus namque pauperum tales domos aedificant & non mireris, Chrysost. in Epistol. ad Heb. Homil. 15.
elemosyna quippe artifex magna, & auxiliatrix eorum, qui illam faciunt, upon these buildings let us study to lay out our monyes, wee shall not need either carpenters, or masons, or labourers: the hands of the poore doe build such houses, and mervaile not at it, for charity is an artificer that doth great things, and is a great helper of them that use it.

Vers. 6. Great is the worke of God in framing of man, and it cannot but be a great admiration to man, to consider, how as Saint Hierome speaketh,Hieron. in hoc caput. ex vili elemento corpus hominis in diversas effigies artusque variatur, & de eodem semine aliud mollescat in carnibus, aliud durescat in ossibus, aliud in venis palpitet, aliud in nervis ligetur, from one vile matter and beginning, the body of man is divetsefied into diverse shapes and limbs, and of the same seed, some is mollified into flesh, some is hardened into bones, some beateth in the veines, some is bound up in the nerves and sinewes. And surely wonderfull also is the worke of God to him that shall consider it, how from one small graine, and that rotten in the earth, the blade springeth up, the blossome flourisheth,
and many graines are brought forth and ripened. To this the Preacher here returneth, and goeth on by the similitude of sowing to exhort us to the workes of charity and godlinesse. Now good works are like unto seed, because as from one graine of seed many seeds are gathered, not at the time of sowing, but at the end of the yeere; so from one good worke we shall gather a great harvest not forthwith perhaps when we do it, but at the end of our lives. But if thou sowest, let it be thy seed, let it be thine owne, let it be of thine owne that which thou dost, sow not with the seed of another man, for then thou sinnest, thou sowest not. And indeed thou mayest possesse much lawfully and justly, yet it is that only which thou sowest, that is truly thine. The rest of the good things of this life which thou hast, are not so much thine as the worlds. And when thou leavest thy great estate, which by much labour thou hast gotten to thine heires, to thy friends, it is their seed which thou sowest not thine owne, for they reape the harvest of thy paines and care. They are thy good works only, which the world shall not keepe from thee, they are thy workes of charity, which thou shalt not leave to thine heires and freinds, but shalt carry with thee into heaven, and there thou thy selfe shalt reape the endles and unconceivable comfort of them. Sow therefore thy seed, and sow in the morning, and in the evening withhold not thine hand, begin betimes, and when thou hast begun make not an end at any time.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Matutinam justitiam vespertina inveniat, & vesperi misericordiam solis ortus accumulet, let the evening find thy morning righteousnes, & let the morning adde unto the evenings mercifulnesse, as Saint Hierome speaketh. And here note, that there is here no mention made of the night, no sowing then is to be used, that being the time of death: wherin none can work. But while life continueth, sow in the morning and in the beginning of it, sow in the evening & the end of it, let no time be omitted. Againe note that the morning & the evening make the whole life of mā: it is but a day. To our understanding it seemeth in some to be very long, if that it exceed an hundred years: but so doth a groate seeme a great deale of mony to him that is very poore, whereas by a rich man it is accompted as nothing. And let this shortnesse of our life make us to be the more diligent in sowing. If a great King should bring us to a great heape of gold, and should bid us for one day to take out of it as much as we could, would we not then be sure to begin early in the morning, and in the evening would we withold our hand? Now thus God dealeth with us, he giveth to us one day to gather and to get as much as we can, not of fading earthly treasure, but of immortall heavenly glory, and shall we then loose any time? The reason which the Preacher further addeth to presse us to a plentifull and diligent sowing, is this, because thou knowest not whether shall prosper this or that or both: the word translated prosper in the Originall as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and most directly signifieth to be right, as being directed a right to the marke of thy comfort and happinesse. Saint Hierome readeth it, nescis quid placeat, thou knowest not what may please. The vulgar Latin according to
the Septuagint nescis quod magis oriatur, thou knowest not which shall rather spring up. The French translation hath it; lequel escherra mieux, which shall fall out better whether that which is done at one time, or that which is done at another. In generall that which the reason sheweth, is this, that for sowing, for doing good, every time may be as good as any time. Indeed for reaping there is a set time, and that time must be tarryed for and observed, which is the good time which God seeth upon the earth, and the glorious time which he hath appointed in heaven; but for sowing for doing well every time serveth, and who knoweth which shall doe best in the acceptance of God, and in the advancing of our blessednesse. Be therefore diligent and sow continually. It is not in sowing as it is in buying and selling, in those, things are done by weight and by measure, but in sowing, there is a scattering abroad in a free and full manner. Wherefore when it is said of the righteous man, he hath dispersed, he hath given to the poore, Theodoret noteth upon it, Imitatur serentes large semina & dissipantes ab manipulorum spem, Psal. 112.9. Theodoret. Ibi. he imitateth those that sow their seed abundantly, scattering it about in hope of filling there hands againe. Such a one it seemeth was Agnes the Empresse, of whom Damianus speaking saith, O beata superbia, O beata mentis elatio, Damian. l. 7. Epist. 5.
omnibus digna praeconiis: Nullis parcitur rebus, & hoc solum indigentibus & ecclesiis non datur, quod extra tui juris peculium reperitur, O blessed pride, O happy loftinesse of mind! worthy of all commendation! Nothing is spared, and that only is not given the poore and to the Church, which is not thine to give. Such a one was King Theodoric, of whom Cassiodore saith, haec sunt regia dona quod semina sparsa in segetem coalescunt, Cassiod. var. l. 3. var. 29.
in unum coacta depereunt. Optamus ergo munera multis collata dividere, ut possint ubique nostra beneficia pullulare, royall gifts are the same with seeds, being scattered they grow into feilds of corne, being kept together they perish and are lost. We desire therefore to disperse our gifts, and to bestow them upon many, that so the works of our bounty may every where spring up.

q.p: Ver. 7. Truly the light is sweete, and a pleasant thing it is for the eyes to behold the Sun.
Ver. 8. But if a man live many yeeres, and rejoyce in them all, yet let him remember the dayes of darkenesse, for they shall be many. All that commeth is vanitie.

div.p:
Vers. 7. This verse may be considered either as having reference to that which goes before, or else as beginning some new matter. As it hath reference to that which goes before, so it may also be considered
diversly. Saint Hierome taking it to have reference unto the former verse understandeth it, as shewing the happinesse, which shall be to them, who are diligent to sow their seed in the morning, and constant in sowing untill the evening.Hieronym. in hunc vers. And therefore he saith, Si semper benefeceris, & omni aetate aequalem cursum habueris, videbis Deum Patrem dulcissimum lumen, videbis Christum solem justitiae, if thou shalt be carefull alwayes to doe well, and in every age of thy life shalt hold an equall course of Godlinesse, thou shalt see God the Father, who is a most sweete light, thou shalt see Christ who is the Sun of righteousnesse. And applying the evening and the morning in the former verse by allusion unto the old and new Testament, he thereupon exhorteth us so to seek spirituall understanding in the old Testament, as that we doe not thinke that which we read to be contained in the Evangelists and Apostles only: ignoramus enim nos in quo magis scientia nobis à Deo tribuatur & gratia, faelicemque eum esse qui utrumque in commune sociaverit, & quasi unum corpus effecerit: quod qui fuerit consecutus videbit lucem, videbit Christum solem justitiae, because we know not in which rather knowledge and grace from the Lord may be given to us. So that he is happy who shall have joyned both of them together, and shall have made one body of them: which he that hath obtained, shall see light, shall see Christ the Sun of righteousnesse. But as the verse is referred to the former, and to the generall argument of charity, whereof the preceeding part of the chapter speaketh, it may be also taken and understood as containing an impediment in the works of charity which the Preacher removeth, as Lyra conceiveth it: or as containing an objection against the works of charity, which the Preacher answereth as Tremellius apprehendeth it. The objection conceived to be made may be thus expressed, why should I spend my means upon others, which I have gotten for my selfe? Why should others have the fruit of my labours? I will my selfe enjoy the sweete delight of it, I will my selfe take pleasure in it, and while I have the light I will cheare mine owne heart, while mine eyes behold the Sun, I will please mine eyes with the objects of contentment. Or if I doe help others, I will first serve my selfe, I will first sweeten mine owne life in the sweete light, I will first shine in the pleasures of mine owne wayes, while the Sun shines upon mee. Wherefore Saint Chrysostome saith well,Chrysost. Homil. de misericordia & duabus viduis. Tria sunt quae in misericordiae opere optanda sunt Christiano, ut possit facere, ut velit, ut compleat, there are three things which in the work of charity a Christian ought to desire, that he may be able to doe it, that he may be willing to doe it, and that he may accomplish his will and doe it. That he may be able, and that the means of doing may not be wanting, that he may be willing and that a mind of doing may accompany the means, that he may doe it, and that he may without delay accomplish that which he can, and to which he is willing. For there are saith he, which can and will not, which will but cannot, which can and will but doe not by delaying of it. Wherefore he concludeth, Qui potest facere, oret ut velit, & qui vult
oret ut possit, & qui utrique paratus est det operam ut misericordiam instanter efficiat, ne quod vult & potest differendo non compleat, Iet him therefore that can doe it, pray that he may be willing, Let him that is willing to doe it pray that he may be able, let him that is ready in both, be carefull that he doe it quickly and diligently, least by deferring he doe not performe that which he is both able and willing to doe. Or else as the verse containeth an impediment to the works of charity it may be thus expressed, the light of this life is a pleasant thing, and it is a delightfull thing to behold the Sun in this world, let us therefore use that which we have for our comfort and delightfull contentment here. Why should we give away our means in hope of happinesse and joy which is to be had hereafter? Ova in praesenti sunt meliora pullis cras, egs for the present are better then chickens too morrow, let us rather reape now the pleasures of the earth by spending our means upon our selves, then sow in expectation of blessednesse by giving unto others. And I wish that this impediment could be removed out of the hearts of many, which is not so much an impediment of the poores reliefe as of their owne salvation. But to consider the verse also as the beginning of a new matter, and as our translatours have set downe. The first thing that ever was commended is the light, and as Saint Ambrose speaketh, jure prima laudatur, Ambr. Hexam. l. 1. c. 6.
quoniam ipsa fecit ut etiam caetera mundi membra digna sint laudibus, justly is that first praised because that made all the other parts of the world to be worthy of praise. He that goes about to build an house, before he lay the foundation considereth with himselfe, where he shall make windowes in it, that so it may have light, that being the chiefest grace of the house, and without which the house hath neither comfort nor comelinesse. By this therefore the Preacher here expresseth the comfort of this life. And when he addeth, it is a pleasant thing for the eyes to behold the Sun, he doth not meane the direct fastning of the eyes upon the Sun, for that paineth the eyes and taketh away the sight of them: but he speaketh of beholding the brightnesse of the Sun shining upon us. And fitly doth he speake of beholding this brightnesse. For as Saint Ambrose also noteth,Ambr. Hexam. l. 4. c. 4.
Lucis natura hujusmode est ut non in mensura, non in pondere ut alia, sed omnis ejus in aspectu gratia est, for such is the nature of light, that not in number, not in measure, not in weight as other things, but in beholding consisteth all the grace of it. And therefore also fitly doth he expresse the prosperity of this world by it, which is all in shew and in apperance to the eye, not in substance and worth. But if it be so pleasant to behold the Sun of this world, how pleasant is it to behold the Sun of righteousnesse. If this Sun be so swift that by his speedy course he vieweth over all things in one day & night, how great is he who is alwayes present every where? and who by his majestie filleth all things? If the Sun be wonderfull, who is commanded to run his race, how wonderfull is he who speaketh to the Sun and it stirreth not? If this Sun be so great which by the chang of time every day approacheth unto places, and goeth away from them
againe, how great is he, who when he imptyed himselfe that we might behold him, was that true light which enlightneth every one that commeth into the world? If this Sun be so glorious, which by the interposition of the earth is darkned, Hagg. 2.6. how great is his majestie, who shaketh the heavens and the earth, the sea and the dry land.

Ver. 8. The Preacher here removeth the impediment, answeareth the objection, and to him that esteemeth so much of this present life he saith, suppose that thou shouldest live many years; to him that desireth to delight himself he saith, suppose that thou shouldest rejoice in them all; yet there are dayes to follow, dayes as long as now thy yeares are, dayes of darknesse, wherein the light of life shall be quite put out, wherein the comfort of pleasure shall be quite lost. And they shall be many indeed, not many as thine years of life were, that is thy small accompt, but so many as that they cannot be numbred, of which it can be said only that they are many, but it cannot be said how many they are. In the yeares of thy life therefore remember these dayes, in thy dayes of delight remember these dayes of trouble and let the remembrance of them make thee to provide against them, by well ordering thy life, by well governing thy delight, by sparing something out of it to comfort those who are in misery. When Josephs brethren making a relation unto him of their condition and family told him, thy servants are twelve brethren, Genes. 42.13. the Sons of one man in the Land of Canaan, and behold the youngest is this day with our Father and one is not, Philo notes upon it,Philo. haec de seipso loquentes audiens tanquam de mortuo, quid animi mali habere potuit? hearing them to speak these things of himselfe as of one dead, what revengfull and evill mind could he have against them? For indeed the remembrance that wee must once be dead, cannot but strike into us a care how we live. When Samuel had anoynted Saul to be King, to confirme unto him the truth of the joy, and withall to teach him how to be carefull in governing his joy, he gave him this signe, when thou art departed from me to day, thou shalt find two men by Rachels sepulchre.1 Sam. 10.2. For he that findeth in his mind a remembrance of his grave and sepulchre, will not easily be found exorbitant in his delights and joy. But though, as our translation maketh the verse to belong unto a new argument (for so the contents of the chapter sheweth) we may conceive it in this generall consideration, the summe whereof Eusebius gives us saying, per salutiferas gradimur vias, quando anima damnatis voluptatibus cogitat quando sepositura sit tabernaculum hujus corporis, Euseb. Gallic. Homil. 1. de Epiphan. then doe we go on the wayes of safety, when the soule rejecting pleasures doth rather thinke of that time, when it must lay aside the tabernacle of this body. Notwithstanding in regard of referring this verse unto the matter, whereof the Preacher before in this chapter speaketh, we are to conceive his meaning, that he would have the remembrance of death to stirre up men unto the works of charity. And what can doe it more forcibly? For that being a time when we are to be brought unto the judgement seate, that then we may find
the judge to be mercifull, the way is to shew our selves mercifull unto the poore.Chrysost. Homil. 5. de Paeniten. Wherefore Saint Chrysostome speaking of pacifying the judge saith, non pecunia, imo si verum dicere oportet pecunia placabimus per inopes accepta, da pauperi, & judicem mitigabis, it is not by mony to be done; or rather to speake the truth, by mony receaved by the poore we shall appease him, give to the poore and thou shalt pacifie the judge. That is a time when we would have Christ to acknowledge us, and when we are ready to acknowledge him: but is was by breaking of bread that our Saviour was made knowne unto those men that went to Emaus: and thereupon Saint Austin saith, Luk. 24.30. & 31. discite ubi Dominum quaeratis, discite ubi habeatis, discite ubi agnoscatis; panem frangimus & Dominum agnoscimus, learne where ye may seek the Lord, learne where ye may have him,Augustin. ser. 144. learne where ye may acknowledge him, we break bread to the poore, and we know the Lord. That is a time, when we desire to be delivered from the torments of hell, and how ready is charity to keepe us from them? Wherefore S. Austin saith, ante fores gehennae stat misericordia, Austin. Homil. 39. Homil. 50.
& nullum miserecordem permittit in carcerem illum mitti, mercifulnesse standeth before the gates of hell, and suffereth no mercifull man to be cast into that prison, so that as the flaming sword doth keepe us out of paradise, in like manner mercifulnesse doth keepe us out of hell. But if the remembrance of death cannot make us to be charitable, at leastwise let the neere approaching of death bee able to doe it. And as Saint Chrysostome speaketh, Si vivens non pavisti, saltem migrans, quum jam non es Dominus ultra, da tuorum bonorum partem, Chrysost. Hom. 25. ad populum. if living thou hast not fed the poore doe it when thou art dying, and when thou canst no longer keepe thy goods, give some part to the poore. Then make him in part an heire together with thy frinds, who to make thee an heire of heaven was contented to lay downe his life for thee. It is best to doe the works of charity in thy life, but if thou hast not done them before, thou maiest at the last moment of thy life make God to be gracious unto thee by them. The last part of the verse, all that commeth is vanity, is nothing else but a confirmation of that which goeth before, and being thus to be conceived, all that commeth into this world, goeth away againe, and as a vanity vanisheth, sheweth that men, who come into this life, must go out againe; that the things enjoyed in this life shall againe be lost; and therefore that how sweete soever the joy may be that by any is taken in them, it shall at lenght passe away and be shut up in darknesse. For as Saint Bernard speaketh,Bernard. Ser. 4. in octava Epipha. quum de transitoriis quis laetitiam quaerit, non poterit non transire transeuntibus his, de quibus erit, when any one seeketh joy in transitory things, it cannot but passe away, when the things passe away in which it is. Wherefore seeing the world passeth away, and the lust thereof, it cannot be, but that all wordly joy doth so likewise.

q.p: Ver. 9. Rejoyce o young man in thy youth, and let thy heart cheare thee in the dayes of thy youth, and walke in the wayes of thine heart and in the sight of thine eyes: but know thou, that for all these things God will bring thee into judgment.
Ver. 10. Therefore remove sorrow from thine heart, and put away evill from thy flesh; for childhood and youth are vanitie.

div.p:
Ver. 9. Saint Gregory observing that here the Preacher saith, rejoice ô young man in thy youth, and that in the next verse he saith, childhood and youth are vanity, or as he reads it adolescentia & voluptas vana sunt, youth and pleasure are vaine, thereupon saith, quid est hoc, quod vel prius reprehendenda praecipit, vel post praecepta reprehendit? nisi quod ipsis literae verbis innuit, ut qui difficultatem exterius patitur, veritatis intelligentiam consideret, quam sequatur? Quae nimirum veritatis intelligentia quum per cordis humilitatem quaeritur, assiduitate legendi invenitur, what is this that either the Preacher doth first command those things, which are to be reprooved, or that afterwards he doth reproove those things, which he hath commanded? unlesse it be that by the very words of the letter he doth imply unto us, that he who findeth difficulty without, should consider the understanding of the truth, which he may follow. And surely the understanding of the truth, when it is sought for by humility is found by the earnest diligence of reading. To consider therefore the understanding of this verse, Saint Ambrose because it seemeth that it is delivered by way of command understandeth it in a religious sense, and thus expoundeth it, rejoyce ô young man in thy youth, non unius tibi dicit tempus aetatis, est quasi quidam flos vitae bonorúmque aetas operum, de qua scriptum est, renovabitur sicut aquilae juventus tua. Et oblectet inquit te cor tuum in diebus adolescentiae tuae, & ambula in via cordis tui sine macula & in aspectu oculorum tuorum, & non in audacia oculorum tuorum. In aspectu utique spirituali, non audacia saeculari. Et scito quod super haec omnia adducet te Deus in judicium, he doth not speak unto thee of one time of thine age, it is as it were a certaine flower of life, and an age of good works,Ambros. de hort. ad virginitat. Psal. 103.5. of which it is written, thine youth shall be renewed as the youth of an eagle. And he saith, let thine heart delight thee in the dayes of thy youth, and walke in the wayes of thine heart, without spot, and in the sight of thine eyes, not in the boldnesse of thine eyes, namely in
a spirituall sight non in wordly boldnesse. And know that for all these things God will bring thee to judgment. Or els if wee understand the verse as a precept, wee may also conceive it in a literall sense thus; rejoyce o young man, and let thine heart cheare thee, and walke in the wayes of thine heart, and in the sight of thine eyes, but doe it so, as that thou know and consider; that for all these things God shall bring thee into judgement. For as an ancient writer saith, ita praesentis temporis est agenda laetitia ut nunquam amaritudo & timor sequentis judicii recedat a memoria, So is the rejoycing of this present time to be used by us, as that the bitternesse and feare of judgement to come be never forgotten by us. But as he that seeth evill will be done, may bid it to be done, when as he would forbid it much rather, if thereby he could stop the doing of it, so it is here with the Preacher. He saw that youth would be unruly, and that loving pleasure it would walke in the wayes of sinfull contentment and in the vanity of the sight of the eyes: wherefore he bids them to doe it by way of an irony, as the Jews say, but yet shewing also his meaning to be, that he would not have it to be done and that it ought not to be, he addeth, know thou that for all these things, the Lord will bring thee into judgement. Wherefore to view the words more particularly. Rejoyce o young man in thy youth & let thy heart cheere thee in the dayes of thy youth, that is, doe thou cheere thine heart, and let thine heart cheere thee, by taking contentment in them, and by giving unto thee a lightnesse of spirits and of jolity from them. In the second place where youth is mentioned againe the Hebrew word is not the same that it is in the first place: there it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which Arias Montanus translateth in diebus electionum tuarum in the dayes of thy choosings, that is when thou followest the choice of thine owne desires, and dost what thou wilt. John. 21.11. According as our saviour Christ speaking to Saint Peter saith, when thou wast young, thou girdedst thy self, and walkedst whither thou wouldest. And walk in the way of thine heart, and in the sight of thine eyes: that is, let thine heart choose the way, and let thine eyes guide thy heart in the choice of them: follow the conduct and leading of thy senses. Let not religion, let not reason direct thee, but as thy sense adviseth thee, so walk in the wayes of thine heart, and in the lust thereof. But know, for let mee teach thee this as a Preacher: know it, and let me tell thee of it, before thou find it to be so, know that thou who rejoycest, and givest thy self to pleasures, and by them and in them art most ready not to know this, at leastwise not to know it, as to consider it, know thou and in thy rejoycing think upon it, that for all these things the Lord will bring thee into judgement. The bringing into judgement is a thing which is known by reason, and is cleare by the light of nature. Wherefore in Austria one of the nobles dying, who had lived fourscore and thirteene years, and who had spent all his life in pleasures and delight,Aeneas Sylvius never being troubled with any infirmity, and this being told to Frederic the Emperour, from hence saith he, we may conclude the soules immortality, for if there bee a God who ruleth this world, as Divines and Philosophers
doe teach and that he is just no one denyeth, surely there are other places, to which the soules after death doe goe, and doe receive for their deeds, either reward or punishment for here we see that neither rewards are given to the good, nor punishments to the evill. Plutarch also saith, Ʋnus quidem est rex, & princeps est Deus, principium medium & finem universi tenens, Plutarchus. l. de exilio. qui via recta peragit, quem justitia sequitur omnium ultrix, qui divinam legem deseruerint, there is one King, and that King is God, who possesseth the beginning middle, and end of all things, who goeth on in a right way, and whom justice followeth revenging all that have forsaken the divine Law. But yet how few are there that doe know this?Bernard. Ser. 3. in Vigilia Natalis Domini. Wherefore Saint Bernard saith, illuminemus nobis lumen scientiae priusquam de mundi hujus tenebris exeamus, ne de tenebris transeamus ad tenebras, & tenebras sempiternas, Let us light unto our selves the light of knowledge before that we passe from the darknesse of this world, least that we passe from darknesse to darknesse and that eternall darknesse. But what knowledge saith he is this? surely to know that God will come, although we cannot know when he will come. But thou wilt say, that is the knowledge of all: for who knoweth not that hath but the name of a Christian, that the Lord will come, who is to come and to judge the quick and the dead, and to render to every one according to his works? My brethren this is not the knowledge of all, neither of many, but of few only, because they are but a few only, that shall be saved. Doe they who rejoyce when they have done evill, and take pleasure in the worst things, doe they either know or consider, that the Lord will come to judgement? Zephan. 1.12. If they say so, doe not beleeve them: for if they did either know it or feare it, they would watch, & non sinerent tam graviter conscientias suas perfodi, and would not suffer their consciences to be digged thorow so grievously. For all these things: for God is a searcher, that searcheth with candles, and as when we search for a thing diligently and warily, we set up many candles, so God will search with candles, that is, exactly find out all that thou hast done. These things: when we read in Genesis, that God created the heaven and the earth, the Hebrew word there used is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifyeth a judge, and Josephus Josephus. speaking of that place saith, therefore doth Moyses in the creation give unto God the name of a judge, that it might be known to all, that he who mercifully made the heaven and the earth, and all things therein for our benefit and comfort, will as a just judge require an accompt of us, whether we have rightly or perversly used all these things. God will bring thee into judgement: he that walketh freely and merrily in the wayes of his heart, shall be brought and haled against his heart and with much bitternesse of soule into judgement. And as for the judgement, what it shall be God himselfe shewes it, saying, judgement will I lay to the line, and righteousnesse to the plummet, and the haile shall sweepe away the refuge of lyes,
Isa. 28.17. and the waters shall overflow the hiding place. Where what is the haile, but the multitude of accusations which shall sweepe away the vaine hope that men have, that the infinite mercy of
God will save them, howsoever they live? And what is the hiding place, but the multitude of excuses, which men are ready to make for themselves, and which the waters of Gods justice, shall quite destroy and overflow?

Vers. 10. Therefore remove sorrow from thine heart, &c. The consideration of the former verse would make one to thinke, that the Preacher should rather have said, therefore remove joy from thy heart,Cassiador. var. l. 4. var. 4. especially, seeing as Theodoric speaketh in Cassiodore, gaudia semper animos inquietant. Modus enim raro laetis rebus imponitur, qui magis in tristibus invenitur, joyes doe alwayes disquiet the mind. For moderation is seldome observed upon joyfull occasions, which in sad accidents more easily is found. But seeing our English translation, and the French doe render the originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 used in this place, sorrow, I suppose that it is so to be referred to the last part of the verse before, as to speake of the sorrow which shall be to carelesse sinners, when God shall bring them into judgement for all their doings. But then the evill also which followeth in these words, and put away evill from thy flesh, is not to be understood not of the evill of sinne, but of the evill of punishment. So that the Preacher here may seeme to set forth, the punishment of hell; by the torments of the foule, in the sorrow of the heart, by the torments of the body, in the evill of the flesh. And surely that distresse is indeed sorrow, that misery is evill indeed. Our Saviour Christ speaking of the judgement, saith, Matt. 24.30. They shall see the Sonne of man comming in the clouds of heaven, with power. And would you know, what this power is, and what the greatnesse of it is? The man of God, Psal. 90.11. Moses sheweth both, saying, who knoweth the power of thine anger? It is the power of his anger, and so great, that none knoweth it.August. Cassiodor. Psal. 76.7. The Prophet David speaking of the last judgement, as Saint Austin and Cassiodore expound him, and speaking unto God, he saith, thou, even thou art to be feared, and who may stand in thy sight, when once thou art angry? God hath been angry often, and that hath made him to be feared, but when this once he shall be angry, who shall stand in his sight? The Originall, as Saint Hierome reads it, is, ex tunc ira tua, Hieronim. from that time shall thy wrath bee, that is, after that there is nothing in thee, but wrath against the damned, and thy wrath being then begun, it shall never be ended. When those things were revealed to Saint John, which concerned the end of the world, it is said, Revel. 10.3. V. 4 that he heard seven thunders uttering their voices; and when he was about to write, he was commanded to seale up those things, which the thunders had uttered, and not to write them: where the terribelnesse of that time is set forth, not only by the voice of thunder, not only by the voices of seven thunders, but also because it is commanded to be concealed, as shewing the terrour of that time to be so great, as that the very hearing of it were not to be endured. There is a story of one, who being risen from the dead, and being asked in what condition he was, he made answere, no man doth beleeve, no man doth beleeve, no man doth beleeve. And that being
further asked what he meant by that repititiō, he answered, no man doth beleeve how exactly God examineth, how strictly God judgeth, how severely he punisheth. But let the story goe to seek for truth, the thing is true, and no man beleeveth the sorrow, no man beleeveth the evill, which then shall be. The Originall word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Tremellius translateth indignationem, indignation, and by a metaphor expoundeth it of removing sinne from the heart, whereby the indignation of God is provoked.Hieron. in hunc vers. Saint Hierome reads it repelle iram à corde tuo, drive away anger from thy heart, and understanding the evill in the next words to be the evill of sinne, which therefore he rendreth malitiam wickednesse, he giveth the meaning of it, in ira omnes perturbationes animi comprehendit: in carnis malitia universas significat corporis voluptates. Sic ergo inquit bonis saeculi hujus fruere, ne aut desiderio aut carne delinquas, in anger he comprehendeth all the passions of the mind, by the wickednesse of the flesh, he signifieth all the pleasures of the body. So, therefore saith the Preacher, enjoy the good things of this world, that thou sinne not either in thy desire, or in thy flesh. The Septuagint, and the Vulgar Latine doe also read it, aufer iram a corde tuo, take away anger from thy heart,Lyra in hunc vers. and the exposition which Lyra giveth of it, is, by anger to understand revenge, quam solent juvenes magis quaerere quum senes propter caliditatem naturae, of which yong men are more desirous then old, by reason of the heate of their nature. By evill in the following words, he understandeth luxury. But if wee read it indignation, as the Hebrew word most properly doth signifie, I conceive that it may be understood of the angry fretting and chasing of the heart against the day of judgment, whereby sinners are checked in their pleasures, and forced sometimes to sadnesse, when they would be merry. So that we may understand the Preachers meaning to bee; be not angry in thy mind against the judgement of God, for thou shalt not be able to avoid it; but put away evill from thee, and so thou shalt escape the evill of it. Or else the anger may be understood of that anger which is in young men, when they are reprooved and blamed for their faults, which the Preacher would have them to remove from their hart, that good instruction might be the better received. And then by the evill of the flesh, wee may understand the corruption of nature, which the Preacher would have to be put away in youth, that by the growth of years, it grow not unto too much perversnesse. For childhood and youth are vanity: the originall is, youth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
et ortus aurorae, and the rising of the morning, which Saint Hierome pephaps understanding to be infancy, and knowing that to be meere folly, therefore he rendreth it, adolescentia & stultitia, youth and folly are vanity. Tremellius reads it, juventus & ortus ipse, youth, and the very beginning of it. But the rising of the morning being very delightfull and pleasant, I should conceive the Preacher to meane that youth and delight are vanity. And so doth the Septuagint and the Vulgar Latine read it, saying, adolescentia & voluptas sunt vana, youth and pleasure are vaine things. Vaine they are in the vanitie of sinne, and vaine
they are in the vanity of nature. Saint Chrysostome speaking of youth,Chrysost. Homil. 1. ad populum. stiles it, difficilem, jactabilem, fallibilem, vehementissimisque egentem fraemis, hard to be ruled, easy to be drawne away, apt to be deceived, and standing in need of very violent raines. In the parable of the householder, who hired labourers for his vineyard, it is said of those whom he hired about the third, sixt, and ninth houre, that he only bid them to goe into his Vineyard, but of those whom he hired early in the morning, whereby are understood those that are of younger yeers, it is said that he sent them, and that he agreed with them for a peny, as shewing it to be a hard thing to bring the vanity of youth unto the labour and care of goodnesse and vertue. Lastly there is in youth, and in the pleasure thereof, a vanity of nature, because, as Lyra speaketh,Lyra in hunc vers. Cito pertranseunt, & ad malum finem perducunt, they soone passe away, and bring to a bad end.

q.p: Ver. 1. Remember now thy Creatour in the dayes of youth, while the evill dayes come not, nor the yeers draw nigh, when thou shalt say, I have no pleasure in them.
Ver. 2. While the sunne, or the light, or the Moone, or the starres be not darkned, nor the clouds returne after the raine.

Ver. 3. In the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble, and the strong men shall bow themselves, and the grinders cease, because they are few, and those that looke out at the windows be darkned.
Ver. 4. And the doores shall be shut in the streets, when the sound of the grinding is low, and hee shall rise up at the voice of the bird, and all the daughters of musicke shall be brought low.

div.p:
Vers. 1. SAint Austin beginneth one of his Sermons thus,August. de Tempore Serm. 246.
Ad vos mihi sermo, ô juvenes, flos aetatis, periculum mentis, To you is my speech O young men, the flower of age, the danger of the mind. And to them it is that the Preacher here directeth his speech, it is to keep them from danger, it is to preserve them in the flower of Gods favour, that he saith, Remember thy creatour, &c. The memory of man is indeed a most excellent faculty, being that thing whereby we preserve those things which time hath spent and wasted, whereby the things that are absent, are still present, and the things that are gone from us, doe abide with us. Indeed it is that without which the life of man would be most wretched and miserable. Seneca Seneca. therefore saith well, He that keeps not in memory the things that are past, hath little better then lost his life given him in this world. Now if our memory be so excellent a faculty, how great reason have wee to remember our Creatour, by whom it hath been bestowed upon us? should not God remember us in his Providence and protection over us? should not he remember us in troubles and distresses, and when we have cast our selves away in our sinnes; what would become of us? But though God be most graciously mindfull of us, how little mind have we of him? Wee say of one that he hath a good memory, because he keepeth firmly, and a long time, that which he hath received: we say of another, that he hath an excellent memory, because he can repeate many things assoone as they are proposed unto him. But he hath a good memory indeed, that remembreth good things carefully, he hath an excellent memory, that remembreth God, who is good above all things. In the dayes of thy youth: a chiefe reason that makes young people, not to remember God their creatour, is this, because they thinke that they have a long time to live in the world, and though they forget him now, yet they will remember him hereafter. But to remove this, the Preacher saith, not in the time, but in the dayes of thy youth, to shew both to young and old, that our life is but for a few dayes. And Seneca saith well, that though death be before the old mans face, yet he may be as neere to the young mans back, let him therefore, while he hath day, remember his Creatour in the dayes of his youth. Indeed the Creatour must alwayes be remembred, not only in youth, but in old age, not only in the dayes of
youth, but all the dayes of our life. For as Zachary saith, That he redeemed us, that we might serve him in righteousnesse and holinesse,
Luk. 1.75. all the dayes of our life; so he hath created us, that we might remember him all the dayes of our life. It was the fault of Solomon who gave this good rule, and did himselfe in his younger yeeres observe it, that in his old age he forgot the Lord, who is alwayes to be remembred. But yet especially in youth, because then it is most acceptable to God, then most needfull in respect of man. God should not have the worst, but the best of our dayes, and when it is the worst of mans danger, then should he be most carefull to looke unto himselfe, by having his Creatour in his mind. Aristotle shewing the pronesse of youth unto vice,Aristot. Polit. giveth these particulars of it, that he is eager in desire, that he is bold in enterprises, that he is changeable in mind, that he is confident in hope, that he is presuming upon his knowledge, that he is prone to anger, that he is ready to make knowne whatsoever is in his heart. But if youth shall remember his creatour, he will remember to moderate his desires according to his creatours law; to feare the displeasing of him, and therefore not to be bold in enterprises; to be setled in a good course, which he approveth, and then not to change it; to put his trust in his Creatours goodnesse, and in his blessing upon him, and not in his owne vaine hopes; to know that he knoweth nothing as he ought, and not to presume upon his owne knowledge; to be slow to anger, that he sinne not in his anger, and make his Creatour to be angry with him; lastly to keepe his tongue with watch and ward, that his Creatour may keepe him safe from his enemies. While the evill dayes come not: the evill dayes are the dayes of old age, because many are the evills that old age bringeth, according as the Poet speaketh,Horatius. Multa senem circumveniunt incommoda, many are the inconveniences that doe encompasse an old man. Genes. 15.15. And therefore when God promiseth Abraham, that he should die in a good old age, Philo saith, ne promissum intelligamus de senectute quae apparet in corpore plena probrosis faeditatibus sed deprudentia constantiaque animi dictum accipiendo; honestatem praedicemus de senectute, Phil. l. quis rerum divinarum haeres. aqua seniores nominantur honoris gratia, let us not understand the promise of that old age, which appeareth in the body, full of reproachfull deformities, but by taking it to be spoken of wisedome and constancy of mind, let us affirme honesty to be old age, from whence it is that we call them elders in an honour to them. But here we may also conceive the dayes to be called evill, because when the dayes of youth are not well spent, the dayes of old age are hardly brought to goodnesse. Wherefore Saint Ambrose speaking of old age, saith, Stimulant eum peccata sua, Ambrosius. exagitat conscientiam consuetudo peccandi & usus erroris instabilem facit. Luctandum est hujusmodi ut abolefaciat inveterata atque diuturna, his sinnes doe spurre him on to sinne; the custome of sinning molesteth his conscience, and the use of going astray maketh him unsetled. Such a man must struggle very hard, that he may abolish things that are inveterate and of long continuance. Hilary also considering the words of the
Prophet Ieremiah,
Lament. 3.27. it is good for a man to bare the in yoke his youth, therupon saith, non expectat frigescentes senectutis annos, nec emortuam jam per aetatem vitiorum consuetudinem. Onus istud maturi ad obediendum anni aegre ferunt: caeterum aetas tenera gravis oneris molestiam per virtutis incrementa non sentit, Hilar. in Ps. 119 Sub lit. Beih. that yoake doth not expect the cold yeeres of old age, nor the custome of vice which is become even dead by age. That burden of obedience yeeres that are ripe doe hardly bare: but tender yeeres doe not feele the trouble of heavy weight, by the increase of vertue which is growing in them. Nor the yeeres draw nigh when thou shalt say I have no pleasure in them: he spake before of the dayes of old age, as speaking of the beginning of it, when the evils being lesse and fewer they are but dayes of evill: here he speaketh of the yeeres of old age, as speaking of the latter time of it, when the many and great evils of it, doe make a man to say, that he hath no pleasure at all in them. This time Saint Cyprian describing saith, Capilli fluunt, facies in pallorem mutatur, dentes lapsi numero minuuntur, cutis arescit, flatus non suaviter olet, pectus suffocatur, tussis cachinnat, talos & pedes tumor inflat, etiam interior homo qui non senescit, his omnibus adgravatur, the hayre fals away,Cyprian. de abusionib. saecul. the face is turned into palenesse, the teeth shedding are lesned in their number, the skin is dryed up, the breath smelleth not sweetly, the brest is stopped, the cough makes a great noise and laugheth as if were at mans infirmities, swelling pufs up the legs, ankles and feete, and the inward man, which cannot grow old, is oppressed with all these. Plutarch relateth that it was the saying of Cato the elder, that whereas with old age many reproches are joyned, and seeing that it is affected with many evils, the reproch of the evill of wickednesis not to be added to it:Plutarch. in Apothegm. Rom. solet enim senectus esse deformis, infirma, obliviosa, edentula, lucrosa, indocilis, & molesta, for old age useth to be deformed, weake, forgetfull, toothlesse, covetous, unteachable, unquiet. Wherefore if vice come also, which being in all shamefull, is most shamefull in an old man, what then will old age be? Surely such, as that man having no pleasure in it, God shall have no pleasure in him.

Vers. 2. As the Preacher having first exhorted unto vertue generally, doth more particularly exhort unto the vertue of charity in the chapter before; so having first shewed the vanity of mans life generaly he doth here more particularly shew the vanity and misery of old age: which he having began to doe in the end of the former verse he proceedeth in it. Now the manner of his speaking being metaphoricall, it may be taken diverse wayes: and first, as Tremellius doth, by the Sun, light, Moone and Stars, we may understand comfort, by the darkening of them sorrow, it being the usuall manner of Sripture by light and darkenesse to expresse consolation and misery. And then we may farther note that the Sun and the light doe signifie the comfort of the day, the Moone and the stars the comfort of the night:Tremell. in hunc vers. so that the Preacher sheweth, that old age hath comfort neither night, nor day: but when it is day it saith, when will the night come, and when it is night it saith, when
will the day appeare? And old age speaketh as blessed Job doth, Job. 20.26. & 27. the dayes of affliction have taken hold upon me, my bones are peirced in me in the night season, and my sinewes take no rest. And againe it hath the same language, I am made to possesse months of vanity, and wearisome nights are appointed to me, when I lye downe, I say, when shall I arise, and the night begone? I am full of tossings to and fro to the dawning of the day. And this continuall misery it is; which the Preacher farther expresseth, when he saith nor the clouds returne after the raine: that is saith Tremellius, neque calamitates subinde succedunt aliae aliis, ut in senectute fit, neither doe calamities follow one upon the neck of another, as in old age it commeth to passe. Or else by these last words, we may understand the great molestation of rheume and fleame wherewith old age is troubled; the defluxion of the rheume and fleame being as it were the raine, the gathering of new matter, which continually distilleth being as it were the returning of the clouds after the raine. From this misery of old age, saith Saint Ambrose, are they reprooved, who thinke this alone to be life, which is led in this world. Non intelligitis senectutem hanc miseriarum esse veteranam, processionemque aetatis aerumnarum stipendia, & Scyllaeo quodam usu, circumsonari nos quotidianis naufragiis, tundi fluctibus, & in scopulosishabitaculis degere, Ambros. de Abel & Cain l. 2. c. 10.
sicut illud non tam aeternum animal quam immortale malum? Doe ye not understand this old age to be as it where an old Souldier in the war of miseries, and the continuance of yeeres to be the reward of troubles: and that then, after the manner of Scylla as it were, on every side we heare the sound of dayly ship wracks, that then we are beaten with waves, and have our abiding in rocky dwellings, as it were that living crearure which is not so much eternall as an immortall evill. Wherefore saith he, behold, just, innocent, Godly Abel, and for the favour of his devotion incurring his brothers hatred immaturus adhuc aevi sublatus est parricidio, unripe as yet in time and age is taken away by parricide: naughty, wicked, ungodly Cain and polluted also with his brothers murder, long aevam duxit aetatem, liveth to be an old man. Lyra understanding the verse more plainly taketh it to expresse the decay of the sight in old age. Which is not able to see either by day the brightnesse of the Sun when it shineth, or the light of it, when it is clouded, nor by night either the weaker light of the Moone, or the lesse light of the Stars. Lyra in hunc vers. And the returning of the clouds after the rayn, he expoundeth esse tribulationem mortis super tribulationem senectutis, to be the tribulation of death following the tribulation of old age. But because this verse seemeth to have a more necessary reference unto the beginning of the former verse, where the remembrance of the creatour is called for, we may understand the words thus. Let him be remembred, while the Sun is not darkened, that is, while youth continueth, or if not so, while the light of the Sun is not gone, that is, while thy manhood lasteth, or if not so, while the Moone is not darkened, that is, while thine elders yeeres are not spent, or if not so, while the Stars are not shut up, while the worst of old age hath not seised
upon thee.Philo de mundi opificio. For so Philo distinguisheth betweene elder yeeres and old age, telling us, vir usque ad quinquagesimum, senior usque ad sextum supra quinquagesimum, quicquid vero deinceps sequitur ad senium pertinet, manhood continueth unto fifty yeeres, from thence unto fifty six we are said to be elders, whatsoever followes after that belongeth unto old age. To this care of early remembring the creatour betimes, Saint Ambrose applyeth those words of our Saviour, woe to them that are with child, and to them that give suck in those dayes, and thereupon saith,Ambros. de Abel & Cain l. 2. c. 1.
maturius igitur absolvatur hic partus, ut cogitationes nostrae bonorum processionibus explicentur, ut nihil imperfectum finis noster inveniat, nihil tanquam in incude positum usus nostri operis relinquat, let therefore this birth be perfected more speedily, let our purposes of good workes be manifested by the proceedings of them, let our end find nothing imperfect, let the practise of our weldoing leave nothing upon the anvil as it were unfinished. Woe be to them that are with child of goodnesse in their old age, or that then doe only give sucke. And then we may understand the last words thus, nor the clouds returne after the rayne, that is a difficulty of doing well doe not follow the neglect of it. Or else by the Sun we may understand divine grace, by the light humane underhanding, by the Moone the Church, by the Stars the teachers in the Church. For sometimes such is the naughtinesse of old age, that the checks of grace, the light of understanding, the authority of the Church, the instruction of teachers are things darkened unregarded, unperceived by it. When, as Saint Austin speaketh; sometime it is so buryed in a delight of drinking, quasi ad hoc arida viscera & succo exhausta curventur, ad vigorem pristinum reparandum ebrietatis inundatione riganda sint, as if the dry entrailes and exhausted of moysture were to this end bowed and weakened,August. de Tempore Serm. that they might he watered with the overflowing of drunkenesse for the recovery of their former vigour. Or else when sometimes the gulf of covetousnesse is so unsatiable, that as the same Father speaketh tanto ad acquirendum ferventius inardescit, quanto citius relictura est quod acquiritur, mirabili, insania it burneth by so much the more fervently after getting, by how much the sooner it is to loose that which is gotten, by a wonderfull madnesse. And then we may understand the returning of the clouds after the raine, to be the adding of one sin to another. Or lastly by the Sun we may understand reason, by the light knowledge, by the Moone imagination, by the Stars the senses, and so we may conceive the Preacher to speake of the time, when death is at hand, and when all these commonly doe faile, so that it is nere too late to remember the creatour. And then by returning of the clouds after the rayne, we may understand the returning of the body to the earth after the dissolution of it from the soule.

Ver. 3. In the day: it is to encrease the misery, that the Preacher calleth it a day, as noting a continuance of life, when death is more desireable. When the keepers of the house shall tremble: Saint Hierome tels us, that they who did refer this passage of Scripture unto the body
of man, did thinke that by the keepers here were understood the ribs,Hieronym. in hunc vers. quod ab ipsis intestina vallentur, & tota ventris mollitudo servetur; because by them the entrailes are walled, and the whole softnesse of the belly is preserved.Lyra in hunc vers. Lyra here by the keepers understandeth the senses which as he saith, praecavent corpori a noxiis, watch to keepe the body from those things that would be hurtfull to it. But seing the word tremble doth not well agree unto either of these expositions, as I conceive, by the keepers here we may best understand the hands. For though man arrive into this world as from a shipwrack, destitute and naked, yet God hath furnished him with two excellent helps, which no other living cteatures doe enjoy, reason and the hand. The hands therefore are said to be the keepers, because they doe keepe of hurt from man, who by them is able to preserve and safeguard himselfe from all other creatures. And all other creatures, which enter into the world armed at point, challenging as it were the injuries of the earth to assault them, how great soever their strength and feircenesse may be, how able soever they may be to endure any thing, yet are they not able to defend themselves against the hands of man. The teeth of the Lion, the pawes of the Beare, the sting of the Serpent, the hornes of the Bull, yea whatsoever else nature hath made strong for her selfe acknowledge a weaknesse under mans hand, and yeeld the homage of subjection unto it. And to shew further how fitly the hands are said to be keepers, a chiefe property of keepers is faithfulnesse; now Numa Pompilius consecrated the hands to faith, and the gnerall course of the world is to make and establish all bargains and covenants by the joyning of hand. And it is the use of some other countryes, that the oath of alleagiance is taken from the chiefe nobility in the hands of the Prince or his delegate. To say also something what is meant by the hands, the ancients doe understand all that which is from the shoulder to the fingers ends to be the hands. This part of the body Hypocrates and Galenus subdivide into three parts, brachium, cubitum, & extremam manum, the arme, the cubit, and the outmost hand. The name of arme we have from Festus, who calleth it armus, and it is extended from the top of the shoulder to the next joynt, where is the bowing of the cubit, and which therefore in English is called the bow, all being but one bone, and next unto the thigh bone the greatest in the whole body according to Galens measure. The next part tearmed the cubit, is that which from the arme goeth a long unto the wrest, being made of two bones, whereof the one lyeth upon the other. The lower of those is the bigger, and is tearmed ulna the ell, the upper is the shorter and is called in Latin radius a rod, a wand. The last part which indeed properly and peculiarly is the hand, containeth three parts in it, the wrest the afterwrest and the fingers. But to leave these things to Anatomists. That the hands might be the better keepers, God hath endued the hand with power to move it selfe five wayes, forward toward the brest, backward toward the back, upward toward the neck and head, downeward
toward the side of the chest, and lastly to turne it selfe into a circle and compasse. But to these motions old age addeth one more motum trepidationis the motion of trembling, which spoileth and maketh uselesse all the rest. And the strong men shall bow themselves: that which our Translation reads shall bow themselves, Saint Hierome reads peribunt shall perish, the vulgar Latin according to the septuagint nutabunt shall nod or stagger: Aquila as Saint Hierome saith did read it errabunt shall wander, and as the word most directly signifieth, the place as I conceive may be rendred, shall overthrow themselves. Now by these strong men are meant the feete, and the ancients doe meane by the foote all that which goeth from the hip joint to the farthest end, and extremity of the toes. But yet they make a distinction, and the foote properly so called they call the little foote, the other the great foote. The parts of the great foote are three, as the parts of the hand were, the thigh in Latin femur a ferendo because it beareth and holdeth up the creature, and is that which goeth from the hip to the knee, the leg which goeth from the knee to the heele, the little foote which is a foote indeed as being the base the ground and pedistall which sustaineth the whole building of the body. This is the true organ and instrument of going and walking and consisteth as the hand did of three parts, the wrest, the afterwrest, the toes. The strength of these parts which is the thing the Preacher here speaketh of especially consisteth in the bones which are numbred by Anatomists to be two and forty. But to touch only some of the principall: the longest bone in the whole body of man is the thigh bone, which in the length of it declineth some thing from an exact straitnesse, because at the knee it boweth inward, thereby to give the more stability and firmnesse unto the running, walking and standing of man. And therefore such men as are tearmed vary, having their thighes more straight then nature hath prescribed, are indeed 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
in eundo troubled in their going. The top of this bone is of a great largnesse, and is fastned into a deepe hollow of the hip bone, thereby to give it the stronger articulation, because of the very great burden which lyeth and resteth upon it. This strength is also encreased by a very strong ligament, which arising out of the bowing of the hip and placed under the top of this bone fastneth and bindeth the two bones together. The leg is made of two bones, the one called the shin bone, in latin tibia a flute or pipe, either that being called so because it is like a flute, or else a flute being called so, because at first it was made of that bone taken from the leg of a hart. This bone is the inner and thicker. The other thinner bone is called the brace bone, resembling the braces of building, and joyning the muscles of the leg together, as they hold the beames of an house together. But the distinction which commonly is made, is to call the one the shanke, the other the shin-bone. Now that two bones were fitter to make up the leg then one, is by Galen prooved, for as much as the greatnesse and heavinesse of one would have been an impediment to the ready moving of it. But though the strength of these strong men
bee so great, and that so well ordered, yet in old age it is enfeebled, when they bow under their burden, and are ready to overthrow themselves and the whole body. And the grinders cease because they are few: the Preacher here speaketh of the teeth, which both in Greek and Latin have their name from eating, being called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
quasi
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and so dentes quasi edentes neither is our English word unlikely to be taken from thence. Now the teeth are the hardest of the bones, if that they be bones, for Aristotle doth only account them to be bony, and to have some likenesse with bones, at least he is doubfull whether he should reckon them to be bones or noe. And the truth is that there are no other bones so solid and so hard as they are,Aristotel. neither doe they come much short of the hardnesse of stones, if they doe not equall stones in the edges of them. To shew that they are not bones, this evidence is brought, because the stone Sarcophagus so called, because it will consume flesh, and which within the space of forty dayes consumeth the whole body of man, yet doth not meddle with the teeth, whereas if they were bones they would be consumed as well as the other bones. The teeth also alone doe continue to grow as long as mans life continueth: because otherwise being worne out with dayly use of them, they would soon become unfit for use. And therefore they doe only grow so much after they are come to their full growth as they are worne away. This maketh Faloplus to affirme, that the formative faculty liveth in the teeth as long as man himselfe liveth: as if thereby God would shew that he hath not made man to dye, having provided that by nourishment he should be still preserved. The seate of the teeth are the jaws, where they have their severall sockets into which they are mortised. The comely order of them in their places Galen tearmeth the seemly dance of nature. They are divided into three kinds, the foreteeth which serve for cutting of the meate, the sharp teeth, which serve for the breaking of that which the foreteeth cannot cut; and the grinders or cheeke teeth, which serve for the chewing of the meate. These being the greatest, the hardest, the chiefest are here alone mentioned by the Preacher, and they are called grinders, because in the unequall roughnesse and broad hardnesse of them, they are like the grinding stones of a mill, whereby as milstones, so they, are fitter for comminution: for which cause it is, that millers when their stones by continuall use are growne smooth, by picking doe make them rough againe. To set downe the number of these in man, is a thing uncertaine, because some have five, others foure, others three, but these are very few, in each side of their jawes. The two hindmost grinders being both bred and placed after the rest, Hypocrates tearmeth dentes sapientiae the teeth of wisedome, because they are bred about the twenty eight yeare of mans age, by which time men are supposed to have learned wisedome for the ordering of their lives and wayes. But in old age these grinders also faile, and having been often repayred, they are at length decayed: their mortising is loosened, their sockes cast them out, and though there be most of them, they also at last are few or none
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
And those that looke out at the windowes bee darkned: they are the eyes which here the Preacher shadoweth, and the eye in Greek is called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the bed of the sight, in Latin oculus ab occulendo, either because it hath a secret and hidden light in it, or else because it is covered and hid with the eyelid. The use of the eyes, is to be as Galen saith, as it where spies, whereby to discover before hand those things that would annoy us, that they may be shunned, and to make way for us unto those things which being good are desired by us. And here the Originall word which the Preacher useth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
efenestris out of the windows is taken from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth insidiari to lye in waite as a spie. The windows here spoken of are the eyelids, which are areas it were falling dores and shutting leafes to windowes. For the reception of the formes of things into the eyes requiring a softnesse and a tendernesse in the temper of them, and this softnesse and tendernesse making them obnoxious many wayes to offence and hurt: therefore God hath sheilded them most watchfully, the eyelids ever and anon thrusting themselves between danger and them. To which purpose God hath given to the upper eyelid a very nimble motion: and though it be doubted whether the under eyelid doe move at all, yet something it stirreth,Arist. de partib. Anim. l. 2. c. 13. although the stirring of it be hardly discerned. But Aristotle noteth, that in birds it is the lower eyelid which most of all is moved, and that in them the higher stirreth little. These eyelids have haires set in them, being set there by God, before we come into the world, and that in such an exquisite order, with such an exact equality, for number and for magnitude, that by the addition or diminution of any thing their use as Gallen saith is marred and spoiled, and the eye not so well fenced nor sheltered. But though the dores be shut so carefully, the watch set so diligently, all things ordered so punctually yet in old age darknesse getteth in and dimmeth the sight, which is at last extinguished and put out. Now let this admonish us, that while we have the use of these parts we be carefull to use them well, that when we want the use of them it may be a comfort to us to remember how well they have been used by us. As when we cannot use our hands, let it be our comfort, in what good labour they have been imployed, when we cannot goe, let it be our comfort, how diligent we have been in going to Gods house, when we cannot see, let it be our comfort, how frequently our eyes have read the word of God, and other good bookes. Againe let this admonish us to live in Gods feare, while we enjoy the use of these parts, that when we doe not enjoy them, God may be our arme, God may be our staff, and that then by the eye of faith, we may behold him looking in mercy upon us.

Vers. 4. And the doores shall be shut in the streets: some take this to signifie no more then the weaknesse of old men, in not being able to goe abroad, or the dulnesse of them, in not caring to goe abroad. Saint Hierome speaking of the first, saith, clausas in plateis portas infirmos senis gressus accipi volunt, quod semper sedeat & ambulare non possit, by the
doores shut in the streets, they will have to be understood, the weak going of an old man, because he alwayes sitteth and cannot walke.Hieronym. in hunc vers. Of the second Tremellius understandeth the words, saying that they are so set downe, pro eo quod est à foro abstinere & à frequentia, Tremell. in hunc vers. ubi delectationem inventus percipit, for that which is plainly thus expressed, to abstaine from the market place, and from the entercourse of people,Lyra in hunc vers. where youth findeth delight. Lyra by the doores in the streets, understandeth the lippes, which are seated in the plaine of the face, and which saith he, are said to be shut, because an old man cannot speak well. But the Preacher speaking here of the decay of the senses of man in old age, I conceive him in these words, to signifie the sense of smelling, by the streets importing the nostrils, by the dores those holes in the spungie bone, into which the odours are received. Now for a little fuller opening of the meaning of the words thus taken. The nose, which is the instrument of smelling, is either inward or outward: the outward nose, which consisteth of the nostrils, addeth both beautie and majestie unto the face, and among the Aegyptians, it was an Hieroglyphick of a wise man; from whence it is also that nasutus is sometimes used to expresse one that is witty, because witty men are able to smell out the cunning devices of others. The reason of the Latine name for nostrills, which is nares, some give to be this, because the odoriferous spirits which are in the ayre doe in nare, swim as it were continually up and downe in them. The inward nose is made of the spongie bone and mamillary processes. The spongie bone hath its name, from the crooked and oblique holes of it, being therein for the most part like unto the crooked pores that are in a sponge. The mamillary processes have their name from the nipples of a dug, which in some sort they doe resemble, and which issuing from the lower part of the braine, are seated in the upper part of the spongie bone. Now the nostrils lead the ayre, as if it were through streets, informed with the forms of odors, through the dores and holes of this spongie bone, to the mamillary processes, where the faculty of smelling principally resideth, and from whence the braine is refreshed by them. But in old age the spirits being decayed, so that the mamillary processes are not so well furnished with them, though the streets and doores be open still, yet are they shut in respect of smelling, that being either altogether, or well neere lost. When the sound of the grinding is low: these words speak of that time, when in old age the jaw bone is growne in some measure sharpe, and the jaw in such sort is hardened, that it supplyeth in some manner the want of teeth, for the chewing of meate.
