But then, as the Preacher here speaketh, the sound of the grinding is low, the softnesse of the grinders maketh their noyse not heard, and yet they speak aloud to men, that their end is at hand. And he shall rise up at the voice of the bird: the Preacher here passeth unto the sense of hearing, and first shewing it to be quick in old age, afterwards sheweth the great dulnesse of it. First, so quick it is, that at the voice of a bird it is awakened: but this indeed is not the quicknesse of the hearing,
but in truth the badnesse of the sleeping. For as Saint Hierome speaketh,Hieronim. in hunc vers. frigescente jam sanguine, & humore siccato quibus materiis sopor alitur, ad levem sonitum evigilat, notisque medio quum gallus cecinerit exurgit, nequaquam valens strato saepius membra convertere, the blood now growing cold, and the moysture being dryed up, by which matters sleepe is nourished, it awakeneth with a little sound, and at midnight, when the cock croweth, it riseth speedily, being not able often to turne its members in the bed. Tully saith, that in sleeping, the sense of hearing is requisite,Tull. de Natu. Deor. l. 2. and serveth as an usefull means to awaken us: but that which youth needeth, old age needeth not, that wanteth sleepe, it wanteth not means to awaken it. And all the daughters of musick shall be brought low: the daughters of musick, are the many instruments of hearing, which being joyned, and married as it were to the sounds of the ayre, doe bring forth the delightfull hearing of musick, and other the like things. A good writer, comming to speake of the organs of hearing, addresseth himselfe thus unto it; But here the difficulty of the taske which I am to undergoe, putteth mee to seek, and so I doe, the assistance of Almighty God, that he would set a edge upon my wit, to be able to pierce,Rauhinus. and to discover the wonders of his creation, the dignitie of his wisedome, and his infinite goodnesse, wherewith he hath invironed us. And that he would furnish me with abilitie cleerely to set forth and manifest to your apprehensions all those things which so variously and artificially are folded up, that it is hard for the eye to observe and follow the traine of them. The organ of hearing, in Latin is called auris, and as Lactantius Lactant. will have it, ab hauriendis vocibus, from drawing the voices and sounds unto it. But the parts of the eare being many, they have also divers uses and offices: some being made as necessary to receive the sound, others as fit both to receive it, and to apprehend it, others as conducing both to the better receiving and perceiving of it, others as serving for the preservation and safety of all the rest. Generally the eare is divided into the outward and inward eare. The outward eare, which is spread abroad like unto a net, principally serveth to catch as it were the formes of sounds wandring through the ayre per vocalem undam, by a vocall wave, as Avicen speaketh, that so being there caught, they may from thence passe into the hole of the eare, as the fishes doe into the narrow end of the net. The principall parts of the inward eare, are the drum, whose head is covered with a membrance, as a piece of vellome covereth the head of a drum, and which hath also a cord that runs through the middest of it, like the cord of a drum, the hammer, the anvil, the stirop, not like the stirrops now used, but like the old fashion of stirrops, which resembled the Greek letter Δ, the ovall window, the labyrinth, the snaile shell, the stony bone, the inplanted ayre, which is cleare, thin, without motion, without sound, of a good quantity, and not conjoyned to the outward ayre. But to leave these things to those to whom they doe belong, and which indeed, as they cannot be found out exactly, so should not be sought after too curiously. For it is fit
that in Gods works, somthing should be the admiration of our silence, especially when our uncertaines conjecture do rather testifie a vaine desire of satisfying our audacious phantasies, then yeeld any matter of importance and profit. As for the generall use of hearing, Aristotle hath observed it well, that by hearing, the things of others are made known to our selves, as by our voice and tongue wee are able to make known our own things to another. But when old age commeth, the glory of this most excellent worke is humbled, and brought low, the anvil is worne, the hammer is weake, the drum is unbraced, the pure ayre is growne thick, the musicke is marred, the dolefull toll of the passing-bell being ready to sound, and to ring out. Let this admonish us to have God in our company when we cannot goe abroad to the company of others, to make our selves a sweet savor in the nostrills of God, when our nostrils cannot perceive the sweetnesse of savours, to be watchfull in the wayes of God, that when we cannot sleepe, yet wee may rest in him, to attend carefully in hearing of Gods Word, that when we cannot heare outwardly, yet may inwardly heare him speaking peace unto our hearts and consciences.

q.p: Ver. 5. Also when they shall be afraid of that which is on high, and fears shall be in the way, and the Almond tree shall flourish, and the grashopper shallbe a burden, and desire shall faile, because man goeth to his long home, and the mourners goe about the streets.
Ver. 6. Or ever the silver coard be loosed, or the golden bowle be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountaine, or the wheele broken at the cisterne.
Ver. 7. Then shall the dust returne to the earth as it was, and the spirit shall returne unto God who gave it.

div.p:
Vers. 5. Also when they shall be afraid of that which is on high: that is, saith Saint Hierome, ardua ingredi non valebunt, they shall not be able to goe up any high place: that is, saith Tremellius, incedentes metuent ne in lapillum exuberantem offendant, as they goe, they shall be afraid, least that they stumble at a little stone standing up. And feares shall be in their way, that is saith Saint Hierome lassis politibus & trement vestigio,
etiam in plano itinere fluctuantes offensam gressuum formidabunt, their knees being wearied, and their steps trembling, and being unstedy even in plaine ground they shall feare the stumbling of their going. And to the same purpose Tremellius saith, nullum erit tam aequabile solum, ubi, non metuant ab offensione & attritu pedis, there is no ground so levell and even, where they may not feare the hurting and bruising of their foote. The originall word here here used is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifying attriti contriti, worn, wasted, as noting the weaknesse of old age, not only to be unable to goe up any ascent, but also to be quickly spent and wearied in going a little upon the plaine ground. But the meaning also of the word may be taken another way, and the Originall sounding thus, ab alto timebunt, they shall feare from on high, Lyra apprehendeth it thus, that that shall be afraid, which is on high in man, and accordingly expounding it, he saith; id est, superior pars animae, quia omnes naturaliter timent mortem propinquantem, Lyra in hunc vers. etiam secundum partem superiorem corpori compatientem, that is, the superiour part of the soule, because all naturally doe feare death approching, even in the superiour part, which hath a fellow-feeling of the bodies corruption. Or else to follow our translation, the words may well guide us unto this meaning, that men are then afraid of that which is on high, that is, of God, as being speedily to give an account to him of their lives, who will be a strict examiner of them, and a severe punisher of all that is amisse. This which should be the feare of all our lives, cannot but be the feare of old age. And then accordingly to expound the following words, and feares shall be in the way, that is, saith Lyra, quia timent exire viam vitae praesentis, because they feare to goe out of the way of this present life. Or else we may take it thus, feares shall be in the way, that is, when they lie upon their death bed, where they are gasping for breath, and even going away, they shall be full of fears, whither they shall goe, what shall become of them. And the Almond tree shall flourish, that is, as the common exposition conceiveth it, and white haires shall flourish. And the reason, as I conceive, why by the flourishing of the Almond tree the white haires of old age are supposed to be understood, is because the Almond tree doth flourish, and is full of blossomes in the old age and winter of the yeare:Plin. l. 16. c. 25. for as Pliny relateth, the Almond tree doth blossome in the moneth of January. But the originall word, which is translated flourish, is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which commeth from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 & signifyeth to despise or reject: as it signifieth to flourish, it must be derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and have the letter א added unto it. Wherefore as I conceive, the word may here be taken, as signifying a refusing or contemning, and I take the Preacher to shew the decay of the sence of tasting in old age, as before he hath shewed it in the other senses. First then he sheweth it, in that the fruit of the Almond tree, which no doubt is much esteemed where it groweth,Plin. Ibid. as being the first that is ripe. For Pliny also relateth that it is ripe in the moneth of March, yet by old age is refused and neglected. The most delicious fruite, and that which is most gratefull to
the pallate, is not regarded by it. Secondly he shews it, in that the grashopper shall be a burden: for though it may be taken, as shewing the weaknesse of old age, not being able to carry a very small burden, as it were no more then a grashopper: yet I conceive it rather to shew the weaknesse of digestion in old age, so that the pestle of a larke, or as the Preacher speaketh, no greater quantitie then a grashopper is a burden to it. And I the rather follow this meaning, because the originall word signifieth a locust, and it may bee, the same light and thin meate, which the Baptist did eate in the wildernesse, who is said to have eaten locusts and wild honey. Tremellius reads it, Matth. 3.4. pinguefacientem se locustam, the locust making himselfe fat, and he taketh this passage and the former, as setting forth the spring-time,Tremell. in hunc vers. wherein the trees flourish, the living creatures rejoyce, which yet affecteth old age with no joy, no contentment. Saint Hierome, and the Vulgar Latine according to the Septuagint, doe read it, impinguabitur locusta, the locust shall be made fat, and Saint Hierome Hieronim. expoundeth it to shew, senum crura tumentia, & podagrae tumoribus pregravata, the swelling legs of old men, oppressed with the swellings of the goute. Lyra Lyra. expoundeth it to signifie ventrem tumescentem humoribus indigestis, the belly swelling with humours indigested. Thirdly, I conceive the Preacher to shew the decay of the sence of tasting, in shewing the appetite to be lost and gone, when he saith, and desire shall faile. The originall rendred desire, is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which some render concupiscentia, lust or concupiscence, others aviditas greedinesse, others voluptas pleasure, others superbia pride, others appetius appetite. Saint Hierome and the Vulgar Latine according to the Septuagint do reade it capparis, the fruite of capers, which Lyra expoundeth the concupiscence of the flesh, and saith that it is so called here, eo quod capparis est herba, quo luxuria excitatur, because Capparis is a plant by which lust is stirred up. And indeed the Jewes doe understand the desire here spoken of to be the lust of the flesh. But saith Estius, Non decet castitatem Scripturae sacrae hoc referre pro incommodo senectutis, quod multi boni & castitatis studiosi etiam in juventute exoptant, it doth not beseeme the chastity of sacred Scriptures, to reckon that for an inconvenience of old age, which many that are vertuous and lovers of chastitie,Estius in hunc vers. doe in their youth wish for. To which purpose he alleadgeth Cicero, who among the commodities and benefits of old age, reckons up this, quod hominem a libidinis aestu veluti a tyranno quodam liberet, that it freeth man from the fire of lust, as it were from a certaine tyrant. Wherefore saith he, that interpretation doth rather please, which understandeth it of the failing of the appetite of feeeding, which capers doe provoke. And concerning the decay of the sense of tasting in old age, Barzillai shews it, when he saith to David, I am this day fourescore yeares old, and can I discerne betweene good and evill? Can thy servant taste, what I eate, or what I drinke? Because man goeth to his long home: the originall is in domum
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
temporis sui absconditi, into the
house of his hidden time, as being understood of the grave, in which man lieth hid.2. Sam. 19.35. Saint Hierome and the Vulgar Latine, according to the Septuagint render it, in domum aeternitatis suae, into the house of his eternity, because saith Lyra, nunquam revertetur in vitam praesentem, he shall never return into this present life. Pagnine, Arias Montanus, and Tremell. read it,Lyra in hunc vers. in domum saeculi sui, into the house of his generation, the grave being the house wherein all they doe meet together, who lived together. Cajetane reads it in domum mundi sui, into the house of his world,Cajetan. the grave being to the dead, as much as the whole world. And whereas nature provideth for man the house of the wombe, the world provideth for him the house of the grave. And the mourners goe about the streets that is, saith Saint Hierome, sepulchrum exequiis quaerat celebratis, Hieron. in hunc vers. plangentiumque funus turba praecedat, in the performance of funerall obsequies, he seeketh for his sepulchre, the company of mourners leading the way in the streets. Let this then teach us, so to walke in Gods feare, that when in old age wee walke with feare, God may be our safety; let this make us to have our hearts on high, that when wee come to die, wee may not feare him who is on high, let our desire be after the best things, which shall be then desireable, when our desire of other things shall cease, let us flourish in good works, that when the Almond tree shall flourish, wee may expect with comfort the reward of them, let us so live, that dying wee may goe to happinesse, and thereby ease the griefe of them that mourne for us.

Hieronim. in hunc vers. Vers. 6. Or ever: The Preacher here, as Saint Hierome observeth, returneth unto his former speech, of remembring the Creatour in the dayes of youth, et post grande hyperbaton interjectum nunc caeptam sententiam simili fine concludit, after a great transposing of his words above the plaine and Grammaticall order of them concludeth his matter began by him, with the like end. The silver coard be loosed: Saint Hierome understandeth the silver coard to be nothing else but the thred of life, candidam hanc vitam & spiramen, quod nobis de caelo tribuitur, this white life and breathing, which from heaven is granted to us. Lyra by silver cord understandeth the harmony of the elements, in which they are tempered,Lyra in hunc vers. and mixed together in the body, and which by death is dissolved. But as I conceive, the Preacher having done with the head of man, he descendeth here unto the lower parts, and first, by the silver cord, I apprehend him to understand the spine bone, which from the neck is extended downe through the length of the back, in the middle of it, like a wreathed cord, and being hollow all along, hath treasured in it that marrow, from whence the sinews for the most part are derived: and the better to preserve so great a treasure, it is exasperated with many processes, which are as it were the flancks of the bulwarke to keepe it from hurt. This cord is made of divers small bones, as it were of divers wreaths, and in a generall division, containeth foure parts; the necke, the backe, the loynes, the holy bone. The racks (for so the small bones are called) of the neck are seven, of
the back twelve, of the loines five. The uppermost rack bone of the neck is called Atlas, because as he was faigned to beare heavē on his shoulders, so this beareth up the head, the heaven of the little world of mans body. The rack bones of the back are the same in number with the ribs doubled, every rack bone having two ribs, of each side one, joyned unto it: & though commonly the rackes of the back be twelve, yet sometimes they are but eleven, and sometimes they are thirteene, though that be not so often. The rack bones of the loynes are greater and thicker then any of the others. The holy bone hath its name, not for any holy mystery that is in it, which is the fond conceite of some, but as Homer Homer. calleth great fishes pisces sacros holy fishes, the reason whereof may be, because the greatest beasts were used to be offered in sacrifices; so this is called the holy bone from the greatnesse of it, as being greater then any other of the bones of the spine. Or else, it may be, as the Apostle speaketh,1 Corinth. 12.13. those members of the body, which we thinke to be lesse honorable, upon those we bestow more abundant honour. This silver coard is in a manner stretched out directly & straightly, that it is bowed now inward, then outward. First the upper part called the neck is bowed inward, that the gullet might rest the better upon it. The second part of it, which is called the back, boweth outward, that so the organs of respiration might have the more roome. The third part of it which are the loines, turn & bend againe inward, that the trunke of the hollow veine & the great artery might be the better upheld by it. But when old age commeth, this cord is loosned, which maketh the head to hang downe, the back to bow, the whole body to bend to the earth, whether it is going. Or the golden bowle be broken: by the golden bowle or cup, I conceive the Preacher to signifie the heart, the figure thereof being pyramidall with the base of it upward, and the cone or pointe of it downeward not unlike unto a bowle cup, and having also two ears, one of each side of it, not unlike the ears of a cup, which are called the deafe ears of the heart, as not having any hearing vertue, but serving to this end, that the hast of ayre and blood pressing to come to the heart might by them be stayd, and by degrees admitted to have accesse. Or else we may take the bowle to bee the cover of the heart, which being also formed like the heart, is hollow like a bowle, and which containeth a pretious liquor and water in it, by which the heate of the heart is danitily and sweetly cooled and refreshed. For the heart being so hot of it self, that the left ventricle of it will even scald a mans finger put into it, and the continuall motion of it being a means to encrease the heate, this water serveth for the tempering and moderating of it. It was this water, which at our saviours passion, the percing sword made to issue with blood out of his side. But to take the bowle for the heart it self, it is said to be a golden bowle in regard of the substance of the heart, which is a solid, red, and a golden flesh, the thickest part of the blood being the matter of it. It is a paler red then that which is in the flesh of the Muscles, but more compact and firme, that the spirits and native heate which are in the heart, and from thence are powred out of the
bowle into all the parts of the body, might be there preserved, and that it might not be crackt or broken by the forcible moving of it, and as being continually either delated or drawen in. This flesh is indeed a golden matter, as having the vegetative facultie seated in it, and giving chiefly vertue to the heart to performe the offices of it, which depend principally upon the vitall • pirits and blood, and the making of them. But how well soever this flesh is compacted together, in old age the bowle getteth cracks, and at length by death is broken: at length the heart becommeth uselesse, as a broken bowle or cup. Or the pitcher be broken at the fountaine: next to the heart in man is the liver, and from hence it hath in Latin the name of jecur quasi juxta cor, as it were placed neere unto the heart. Wherefore in these words I conceive the liver to be meant, that being the shop of sanguification or bloodmaking, as one speaketh, or rather as the Preacher here speaketh, that being the fountaine of blood, from whence by the channels of the veines, it is carried over the severall provinces of mans body. For here arise those two great and long veines, the port or gate veine, and the hollow veine, and which are multiplied into very many branches. The pitcher here is the body of the liver, which is not altogether unlike a pitcher, first being of severall formes as pitchers are, because the use of it needeth rather a convenient bignesse, then any proper figure: and then having two sides, wherof the outward is convex and turned round, the inward is hollow fit to receive something into it. The largenesse of it in man is greater then in any other creature of his proportion, and in the greatest men greatest: for the operations of mans soule being many, and in them many spirits being wasted and spent, and blood being the matter whereof the spirits are made, the liver therefore of necessity was to be the greater, that so the more blood might be supplyed, the whole body also from thence being to be furnished with it. But yet at length in old age the pitcher is broken, and as a broken pitcher holdeth little or no water, so that containeth little blood, from whence the veins being empty, way is made for death to enter in. Or the wheele bee broken at the cisterne: by these words I conceive the Preacher to signify the bladder, of which a good Anatomist speaking saith, that it is a large cistern or vessell. The Preacher here doth call it a wheele or orbe in respect of the roundnesse of it, from whence some have likened it unto a sphere. And the wheele or orbe is here said to be broken, for as much as the weakenesse of this part in old men maketh them unable to hold and keepe their water. These two latter passages the breaking of the pitcher,Hieron. in hunc vers. the breaking of the wheele, Saint Hierome understandeth to be nothing else, but aenigmata mortis dark expressions of death, because as when these are broken there is noe longer drawing of water, so when death commeth there is no longer drawing of breath. Tremellius by all these understandeth nothing else, but the temporall goods of this world, as the chaines, the jewels, the household-stuff, which in this life are enjoyed and by death are taken away. For so he expoundeth,
the silver cord, the golden bowle, the pitcher, the wheele; Lastly to apply the Preachers words unto a more spirituall use: remember thy creator, remember his justice to feare, his mercy to hope, his bounty to be thankfull, his greatnesse to reverence him, his goodnesse to love him, his sweetnesse to hunger and thirst after him. And remember him, while thou art drawen with the silver cord of the doctrine of faith, while thou hast the remembrance of him in the goldē cup filled with his blood, which he shed for thy sins. Run unto God, hastē to the fountaine of wisedome, be diligent to fil thy pitcher, & to drink of it being filled, lest the pitcher while it is empty be brokē at the foūtaine, & not the water but thy self be lost for evermore.

Ver. 7. When God made man, the originall, word for word speaks not as commonly it is translated, and the Lord God formed man of the dust of the earth: but thus is saith, the Lord God formed man dust of the earth.
Genes. 2.7. So that man is but earth in respect of his body, although changed curiously by the working of Gods hand, and although made of a different kind from the common earth. Wherefore the Preacher also here plainly cals it dust, saying, then shall the dust. And to consider this, saith Saint Basil, Basil. Homil. 11.
salutare quoddam emolumentum est adversus quodcunque peccatum, is a profitable help against every sin. But as for pride especially, what need of more to quell it, then to looke upon the earth from whence man was taken? surely as Saint Chrysostome speaketh, etiamsi sexcenties supercilia▪ surrigamus, ea reprimemus, Chrysost. Homil. 12. in Genes. although six hundred times we lift up our eye-browes, we cannot but cast them downe, by considering the condition of our first beginning. Wherefore Saint Basil saith very well, quid aspernabilius esse possit quam nos ipsi? Quid nobis occurrat dignius, quam ut nos humili dilectione exinaniamus? What can be more unworthy then we our selves are? What is more worthy in us, then that we disesteeme ourselves by a humble dejection? It had been nothing unto God to have made us of a finer and more excellent matter but as Saint Chrysostome speaketh, materiae vilitas magis demonstrat artis copiam the vilenesse of the matter doth the more set forth the abundance of his art, who to earth and dust hath given so much beauty, and with such variety of senses and feeling hath adorned it. Besides God hath made our body earthy, that we might make it heavenly. For as he hath made the heaven and the earth, so he hath vouchsafed us this honour, that we may make the earth to be heaven. Wherefore Saint Chrysostome saith, Corpus nobis finxit Deus ex terra, Chrysost. Homil. 15. m. 1. ad Tim. ut ipsum quoque subvehamus in caelum; non ut per ipsum animam detrahamus in terram, God hath formed us a body out of the earth that we might carry it to heaven, not that by it we should pull downe the house unto the earth. Return to the earth: and let not the journy of it thither,Hieron. contra vigilant. the lodging of it there be disturbed and disquieted. Saint Hierome arguing against Vigilantius sheweth that God himselfe did honour the body of Moses, dum illud propriis manibus sepelivit, while that he buried him with his own hands.Calcin. Comm. in c. 8. Actor. Calein also sheweth sepulturam honorem esse debitum corporibus sanctorum, that buriall is an honour due to the bodyes of the Saints. Bellarmine shewing
the benefits, which from buriall arise unto the dead, setteth this downe for one, quod consulitur honori eorum adhuc in hominum memoriis viventium: non enim caret ignominia quadam, quod faeditas nostri corporis aliorum conspectibus pateat, that thereby is provided for the honour of them,Bellar. de Purg. l. 2. c. ult. as yet living in the memories of men: for it is not without some reproach, that the loathsomnesse of our body lye open to the sight of others. But why then doe the Papists take the bones of the Saints out of their graves? Why doe they keepe them in boxes to be shewed to the people, to be handled by the clergy, to be carryed about in procession, to be set upon the Altars? Erasmus speaking of his travels, and relating the passages of it, of one place he saith, dictumirum, quantum ossium illic prolatum sit, it is wonderfull to tell how many bones were brought forth there, sculs, chins, teeth, hands, fingers, whole armes all which we adored and kissed;In colloq. pereg. relig. ergo. nec erat futurus finis, neither would there have been end, unlesse the companion of my travels, when their was brought unto him an arme, which had yet bloody flesh on it, had been moved at it, and his countenance had manifested a kind of loathing of it. The Church of Rome may accompt this an honour done to the Saints, because their bones are laid up in boxes of gold or silver, but to make the best of it, what is it but insepulta sepultura, an unburied buriall,Cicero Phil. 1. which Cicero esteemed for a disgrace. Neither is it any such honour as in the Scriptures we find to have been given to the Saint. Suppose the bones of some dead Saint to have wrought a miracle, which is a thing, the Papists talke much of, and which seemeth in this point to have been the ground of their superstition: the bones of the Prophet Elisha we are sure wrought a great miracle,2 Reg. 13.21. notwithstanding we doe not find that his bones were taken out of his sepulchre. But rather as Josiah commanded concerning the bones of another Prophet,2 Kings 13.18. let him alone, let no one move his bones, so may we well thinke Elishaes bones were left at rest. Wherefore that Wiclevian no doubt was in the right,Waldens. tom. 3. tit. 14. c. 128. who as Waldensis reporteth, judicialiter confessus est, confessed openly at his tryall, that the flesh and bones of dead men ought not to be worshipped by the people, nor to be taken out of their unsavory monuments, nor to be layd up in golden or silver boxes. And the spirit shall returne to God: the spirit dyes not, and therefore that returneth to God the fountaine of life. Hence the auncient Church did call the dayes on which the Saints of God dyed, natalia ipsorum, the dayes of their birth, because then they entred into that better life, which is indeed true life, because then they go into that heavenly country, which is truly called the land of the living. And though in common speach we say of the Saints departed, that they are dead, that is only to put a difference betweene them, and the Saints which are not yet departed from the earth. For though the Church of Rome dispute, that the Godly in this life are not called Saints, Rom. 17. v. 8.28 yet it is plaine that the Spirit of God calleth them so, and their canonization and Saint making, is but a trick of their Church-merchandising. Every Spirit of man departing
from his body, returneth unto God, but the Spirits of the wicked returne unto him to be sent from him by his just judgement into eternall torments, the Spirits of the righteous returne unto him to abide with him in endlesse joy and happinesse. They returne to God, but they doe not returne to be made God, to be prayed unto, to have vows made unto them, to have trust and confidence reposed in them. This is more then they looke for being in heaven, and much more then should be given them by us, being on earth. Who gave it: Saint Hierome speaking of these words saith, ex quo satis ridendi sunt, Hieronym. in hunc vers. qui putant animas cum corpore seri & non Deo sed à corporum parentibus generari, from whence they are worthy to be laughed at, who think the soules to be sowed and generated of the seed together with the bodyes, and to be brought forth not by God, but by the parents of the bodyes. For seeing it is said, that God gave the Spirit, he thinks it to be manifest that God is the Father of the soules and not men. And indeed Saint Austin writing of this argument, confesseth inter caetera testimonia, hoc esse praecipuum, among other testimonies for the proofe of it, this to be the chiefe. But yet Saint Austin in himselfe being doubtfull in this point, thinketh that the Preachers meaning may be, that as God made the first man out of the earth in respect of his body, which afterward by generation was to be brought forth; so that God himselfe made the first soule, which afterward was from man to be propagated. The good Father is most modest in writing of it, and whereas Saint Hierome had sent some unto him to be instructed in it, he tels us that he wrote back unto him, consulens & petens, ut prius ipsum doceret, Augustin. ad Opat. de Origi. animarum. & tunc ad illum mitteret quos doceat, advising and desiring that first he would teach himselfe, and then send unto him those that might be taught by him.

epigraph.q: Ver. 8. Vanity of vanityes (saith the Preacher) all is vanity.

div.p:
Ver. 8. Suppose a wise & learned man to be travelling over the world for increasing of his knowledg, and hearing of a great University to take his way unto it: but when he commeth thither, to find in one Schoole taught the manner and skill of playing at cards, in another Schoole of playing at tables, in another of playing at bowles, and so the severall kinds of idle games and pastimes, how would he crye out folly of follyes all is folly; in like manner the Preacher having by his wisdom and knowledge travelled in his thoughts over the whole world, and having viewed in the things that are without man, the mutability, uncertainity, insufficiency of them to content mans heart; having beheld in man the blindnesse, of his mind, the perversnesse of his affections, the fading decay and corruption of his body, he cryeth out likewise vanity of vanities all is vanity: that is all is nothing. Now as Saint Bernard speaketh,
mirandum, sed magis dolendum quam mirandum, quod id quod nihil est amari potest, it is to be wondred at, but more to be lamented then wondred at, that that can be loved which is nothing. But as he addeth, hinc plane sentimus, unde, quo venimus, quid perdidimus, quid invenimus, Bernardus Epist. 18. hence we perceive plainly, whence, and whither we are come, what we have lost, what we have found. Him we have lost, in whom all things are contained: that we have found, in which all things that are contained are nothing: from him we are come, who alone truly is, thither we are come, where every thing that is, by vanity is not. And yet this we love him we despise. For as Saint Bernard also speaketh, appetitus vanitatis, est contemptus veritatis, the liking of vanity is the dislike of uerity. But as he likewise addeth, quid vanius quam diligere vanitatem? Quid iniquius quam contemnere veritatem? What more vaine, then to love vanity? What more wicked, then to despise verity? Neither let the worldling thinke it to be strang, that thus the Preacher maketh the things of this life, to be so meerly vanity, to be so plainly nothing. Fos as Clemens Alexandrinus noteth,Clemens Alex. Stromat. l. 7.
quemadmodum amygdalae dicuntur inanes, non in quibus nihil est, sed in quibus id quod inest est inutile, almonds are said to be empty, not because there is nothing in them, but because that which is in them is unprofitable and to no use; so likewise the things of this world are said to be vanity, are said to be nothing, because how great soever they may be in their earthly magnitude, how glorious soever in their temporary bravery, yet they are of no use for the procuring of true good unto man, no way profitable for the establishing of mans happinesse. But who is it that thus speaketh, vanity of vanities all is vanity? It is not man that saith it, for in him a love of this world makes him to thinke too highly of the things of the world. It is not the King that saith it, for in Kings the glory of the world maketh them unable to see the vanity of the things of the world. It is not Salomon that saith it, for he was deceived by the things of the world, and could not discerne the vanity of them. It is the Preacher that saith it, he that by study and care had looked into the truth of things he that had unmasked the outside of shewes and apparences, and had searched out, what the things of this life are, he saw, and he saith, that all is vanity, and what he saith, truth it selfe saith. Great is the authority, which here is given unto Preachers. The Prophets to give authority unto their words, use to say; Thus saith the Lord; but the Lord himselfe, the Holy Spirit of God to give authority to his Preachers words, here saith, Thus saith the Preacher. David was a great King in Israel, and he was a Prophet: but Salomon was a greater King, and he was a Preacher. He chose for his text this argument of the vanity of humane things, and saying here, saith the Preacher, seemeth to mee, to have set it downe, as one generall and principall argument for Preachers to insist upon. As for this Preacher himselfe Saint Austin tels us, in hac vanitate intimandum totum hunc librum vir sapientissimus deputavit, non utique ob aliud nisi ut
eam vitam desideremus quae vanitatem non habet sub hoc sole, Augustin. de Civit. Dei l. 20. c. 3.
sed veritatem sub illo, qui fecit hunc solem, in setting forth this vanity the most wise man hath imployed this whole booke, and that for no other end: but that we might desire that life which hath not vanity under this Sun, but truth under him who made this Sun. But if we shall consider this verse not so much as a summary repetition of the whole book, as rather in a particular reference to that which goeth before it, then we may conceive the Preachers meaning thus, that seeing all the labour and care of man at length is brought to this,Hieronym. in hunc vers. that the dust returneth to the earth as it was, and the Spirit unto God that gave it, therefore it must needs be as Saint Hierome, speaketh, magnae vanitatis in hoc saeculo laborare, & nihil profutura conquirere, a signe of great vanity to labour in this world, & to seeke after those things which cannot profit us. It is S. Austins speach,Augustin. de Temp. Ser. 50.
si tibi diceret architectus ruituram domum tuam, nonne prius migrares quam murmurares, if a skilfull builder should say unto hee, that thy house would fall downe, wouldest thou not rather make hast out of it then stay in it to murmure against him? Now he that is the skilfull builder of the world, he that hath builded the house of thy body, he tels thee that thy house will fall, that thy strong supporters will bow, that thy safe keepers will faile, that thy firme cords will be broken, that thine honour will be layd in the dust; he tels thee that the world will fall, and dost thou not beleeve him? Surely if thou dost, thou must needs acknowledge, quam verum dixerat veritas, quam inaniter conturbatur vanitas, how truly truth hath said, how vanily vainty is disquieted, as Saint Austin speaketh: how truly the Preacher saith vanity of vanities all is vanity.

q.p: Ver. 9. And more over because the Preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge, yea, he gave good heed, and sought out, and set in order many Proverbs.
Ver. 10. The Preacher sought to find out acceptable words, and that which was written, was upright, even words of truth.
Ver. 11. The words of the wise are as goades, and as nailes fastened by the Masters of assemblies, which are given from one shepheard.
Ver. 12. And further by these my sonne be admonished: of making many bookes there is no end, and much study is a wearinesse of the flesh.

div.p:
Vers. 9. Moreover because the Preacher was wise he still taught, &c. Wherein our translation followeth the reading of Saint Hierome, and though Arias Montanus also use the same as being most literall, yet as I conceive the force of the Originall is more kindly expressed by the French translation which readeth it thus, and by how much the Preacher was wise, by so much the more he taught the people. In both, the sense is very little different, and as I conceive, the Preacher here by his owne example sheweth the duety and office of a Preacher. By these words he teacheth them that are to teach others two things. First that himselfe must be wise that shall take upon him to teach others wisdome. This Saint Hierome observing upon that passage of Ezekiel who saith, and it came to passe,
Ezek. 3.16. & 17 at the end of seven dayes that the word of the Lord came unto mee saying, Son of man I have made thee a watchman unto the house of Israel, thereupon noteth, qui speculator futurus est, & Dei verba populo narraturus, multo tempore debet quiescere, ut scilicet à Deo accipiat & discat, Hieronim. Ibi. quae postea distribuere possit, he that is to be a watchman, and to declare the words of God unto his people, must be still and quiet a long time, that so he may receave and learne from God those things which he may disperse abroad. There is no art that is presumed to be taught before that it be learned, and shall any presume to teach in this great art, who are not first well learned? Saint Gregory speaking of Preachers saith, oculi sunt qui in ipsa honoris summi facie positi providendi itineris officium suscipiunt, they are eyes which are placed in the very face of the highest honour and take upon them the office of foreseeing the way,Gregor. Past. Cu. p. 1. c. 1. and shall any thrust themselves into this place this office, which have not the cleare sight of knowledge in them? Secondly the Preacher teacheth here that the abilities of teaching ought to cause every one to teach, and that the more ability he hath, the more paines he is to take in it. But as Saint Gregory noteth, there are not a few, who being enriched with great gifts, dum solis contemplationis studiis inardescunt, parere utilitati proximorum predicatione refuguunt, while they burne in the studies of contemplation, only, doe shun to yeild in Preaching to the profit of their neighbours. Of whom he giveth this judgement, ex tantis proculdubo reisunt, quantis venientes ad populum prodesse potuerunt, Gregor. Pasti. Cu. p. 1. c. 5. they are guilty no doubt of so much evill, as by comming forth from their retirednesse into the world they might have done good. And is it not sometimes the judgement of God upon them, as the same Father noteth, dum sua & non aliorum lucra cogitant, ipsi se quae privata habere appetunt, that they bonis privant, deprive themselves of those
good things which they desire to have private to themselves. Yea he gave good heed: Saint Hieorme reads it, & audire eos fecit, and he made them to heare. Pagnine and Arias Montanus, & auscultare fecit, and he made them to hearken, as shewing his desire to be the profit of the hearers: and let every one who desireth to please God in this calling make this his chiefe desire. But to consider the words as our translation hath them. He gave good heed, that is, he was carefull so to teach,2 Tim. 4.2. as to take his fittest opportunity for it. Indeed Saint Paul saith, Preach the word, be instant in season, out of season: but as Saint Gregory noteth dicturus importunè praemisit opportune, quia scilicet apud auditoris mentem ipse sua se utilitate destruit, si habere importunitas opportunitatem nescit, being about to say out of season, he first saith in season, because importunity if it know not how to use opportunity doth often destroy it self by its owne profit. Yea not only is the vertue lost of that which is said when by an indiscreet unseasonablenesse of loquacity, it is disesteemed in the hearts of the hearers: but as the same Father speaketh,Gregor. past. cu. par. 2. c. 4.
autorem suum haec eadem loquacitas inquinat quae servire auditoribus ad usum profectus ignorat, the same loquacity disgraceth the authour of it, when that it knoweth not to how to be serviceable for the profit of the hearers. And sought out: the Originall word is in Pihel
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and as I suppose may be translated, as that before is translated by Saint Hierome fecit investigare he made them to seek out, or to search into, as shewing that the Preacher so taught as that he made the people to understand what he taught, and to see into the truth of it. And surely it must be the care of a Preacher to apply his matter and speach to the capacity of the hearers, that so there attention may be able to seek into it, and so search it out. In the law of the Jews he that hath digged a pit was to cover it, least an oxe or an asse should fall therein; Exod. 21.33. and it must be the care of him who by paines of study strength of understanding hath searched into the secrets of religion not to utter them heedlesly, least that an oxe or asse some unlearned and simple hearer fall into errour and hurt by it. The pit therefore is to be covered, and high knowledge before plaine heares is to be concealed, least while the doctrine of the teacher is lifted up on high, the weaknesse of the hearers should stumble and dash its foote below. In the Scripture it is ordinary by the clouds to signify Preachers, and Saint Gregory considering those words of Job, he bindeth up his waters in the thick clouds, there upon he saith, Job. 26.8. ut auditores rudes non inundatione scientiae obruantur, sed moderata praedicationis distillatione foveantur, ligat Deus aquas in nubibus: quia doctorum praedicationem temperat, ut auditorum infirmitas doctorum rore nutrita convalescat, that plaine hearers may not be overwhelmed with an inundation of knowledge, but that they may be cherished with a moderate distillation, he bindeth the waters in the clouds;Gregor. Moral. l. 17. c. 14. for he tempereth the preaching of the teachers, that the weaknesse of the hearers being nourished by their dew may grow strong by it. Wherefore it is a good rule which the same Father giveth, dignum est ut qui praedicet audientis modum
consideret, quatenus sua praedicatio cum auditoris sui incrementis crescat, it is meete that the Preacher consider the condition of his hearers, that so he may teach higher matters as his hearers are riper in understanding. But to understand the words, of the Preacher himselfe alone, and as our translation hath it, and sought out, they shew his study and diligence to find out that, which he might teach the people. For a Preacher must as well labour, and by meditation seek what to teach, as reach, and deliver that which he hath found, he must as well draw out of the fountaine, as powre out that which he hath drawn. Saint Gregory therefore saith, perfectus doctor Dei est docibilis & dum pascere cibo alios nititur, ipse multiformium delitiarum spiritualium dulcedine satiatur, he that is one of Gods carefull teachers,Gregor. m. 1. is himselfe teachable, and whiles he endeavoureth to nourish others with food,Sam. c. 4. he is diligent to fill himselfe with the sweetnesse of manifold spiritual delights. The staves whereby the Ark was to be born were alwayes to be in the Ark, they were not to be taken out from it: Exod. 25.15. and what are Preachers but as it were the staves of the Ark, whereby the Church of God is born up? wherefore as the staves were alwayes in the Ark, so saith Saint Gregory it behooveth teachers semper in suis cordibus eloquia sacra meditari, ut si quicquid necesse sit testamenti arcam sine mora elevent, Gregor. Past. Cit. p. 2. c. 11.
protinus doceant, alwayes in their hearts to meditate upon the sacred scriptures, that if need doe require, they may without delay take up the Ark of the testament, they may fortwith teach. And set in order many proverbs: to set things well in order doth set them out well, and in teaching it is therefore very needfull, because it is very helpfull. It was a ladder which Jacob saw reaching from earth to heaven, wherein by degrees the steps do follow in order, one after the other. And surely a good order in teaching doth best serve to bring downe the graces of Gods spirit from heaven, doth best serve to lead up the lives of men, to have there conversation in heaven. And for the order of teaching, let me note one thing from Jacobs ladder, Genes. 28.12. of which it is said, he saw the Angels, of God ascending & descending on it. The Angels of God being in heaven, one would think that it should have been first said descending and then ascending: but seeing it is first said ascend and then descend, let the Preachers of God who are his Angels sent unto his people learn this order, that first they ascend by prayer unto God to beg his blessing upon their labour, before that they descend by teaching to instruct the people.

Ver. 10. The Preacher sought: this repetition of the Preachers seeking induceth me the rather to conceive the seeking in the verse before of the peoples seeking, to which the Preacher exhorted them. The originall word here also used for seeking is not the same, that in the verse before it is. Here it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which signifieth to seek by suing and praying, to seek by asking direction and counsel of them who are able to give it. And surely thus must a Preacher seek, he must not be ashamed to aske counsel, where he standeth in need of it, and especially he must sue and seek to God for his assistance and blessing. For as Saint Gregory saith
well, necesse est ut si vere intendimus illuminata cernere, studeamus mentis oculos ad ipsum illuminans lumen aperire, it is necessary if we verily desire to behold those things, which are illuminated,Gregor. Moral. l. 23. c. 1. that we endeavor to lift up the eyes & mind of our to open them unto the light it self by which they are illuminated. Sought to find out: there is still somthing to be sought out by a Preacher, and still must a Preacher be seeking to find. For that I may deliver the common sentence of the Philosopher in Saint Gregoryes words, in hoc mundo dum vivimus, tunc perfectè quae scienda sunt scimus, quum proficientes per intelligentiam nihil nos perfectè scire cognoscimus, while we live in this world, then doe we know perfectly those things, which are to be known, when as profiting in understanding, we know that we know nothing perfectly. Acceptable words: Saint Austins direction is, agat vir eloquens, ut intelligenter, August. de doct. Christ. l. 4. c. 14.
ut obedienter audiatur, let it be the endeavour of an eloquent man, that he may be heard with understanding, with willingnesse, with obedience. And to this end it is that a Preacher is to find out acceptable words, such words as may procure an understanding, willing, obedient attention. The originall is as Saint Hierome reads it verba voluntatis, words of the will,1 Sam: 2.26. that is such words as are agreable unto the will of God, and are of power to work upon the will of men for their good and benefit. Of Samuel it is sayd that he was in favour both with the Lord and with men; and such must be the words of a Preacher, as that they be acceptable to God and to men. Unworthy is it a Preachers pains to seek to please men only: and what is it but as Saint Gregory speaketh,Gregor. in Ezek. l. 2. Homil. 21.
rem magnam vili pretio venundare to sell a pretious thing for a vile price? He is worthy of that name who as the same Father speaketh, ea quae dicit ideo placere hominibus appetit ut dum placet, quod dicitur, per eadem dicta non ipse sed Dominus ametur, Gregor. in Evang. Hom. 17 desireth that those things which he speaketh may be acceptable to men to this end, that while that is pleasing which is spoken, not himselfe but the Lord may be loved by the speeches. And that which was written, was upright. Our translation and the French also understand this part of the verse, as speaking of that which is written here in this book, but the Originall speaks no more, then the writing of uprightnesse, and sheweth the Preachers care and diligence not only by speaking but by writing also to instruct the people- And indeed speaking is but like a burning coale, which giveth heate and some light neere at hand, but writing is like a shining lampe, which giveth light far off. But that which the Preacher principally intendeth, is that Preachers must be carefull both in speaking and writing to deliver the words of uprightnesse the words of truth. The words of uprightnesse in shewing the right way to God, in discovering the wrong wayes of sin. The words of truth, in setting forth the truth of God, in refuting and rejecting the errours of men. First the words of uprightnesse, they must not spare to shew men their dueties, to tell men there faults. Wherefore the Preacher having mentioned acceptable words, he addeth words of uprightnesse as shewing that they must be so acceptable, as withall not
neglecting to presse unto uprightnesse of life, and to blame what is a misse therein. Saint Hierome therefore writing to Nepotian saith, docente te in Ecclesia non clamor populi, sed gemitus suscitetur, lachrymae auditorum laudes tuae sint, Hieronym. ad Nepotian. when thou teachest in the Church, let not the applause of the people, but their sighing be stirred up by thee, let their tears be thy prayses. Hosea. 4.8. The Prophet Hosea speaking of bad teachers saith, they eate of the sin of my people, which Saint Hierome expoundeth vivunt ex peccatis populi, Hieronym. in Hoseam. they live by the sins of the people, they make the means of their living to be the greater by suffering the people to live in their sins without reproose. Saint Gregory expoundeth it, peccata delinquentium fovent, Gregor. in Evang. Hom. 17 they nourish the sins of offenders, and as themselves are nourished by the meate which they eate, so by their carelesnesse, they nourish the people in there wickednesse, which should be destroyed by them.2 Reg. 13.17. In which respect the words of Preachers should be arrows, peircing the soule of sinners, and wounding them with griefe unto the heart, so that it may be sayd of them, as Elisha said of the arrow of Ioash, the arrow of the Lords deliverance. And surely it were good, if hearers would even open their breast,Origen. Homil. 2. in Cantic. and as Origen speaketh transfigendum praeberent hujusmodi jaculis, would even offer it to be periced with these arrows. The wounds which these arrows make, are as Gregory Nyssen calleth them, praeclara vulnera, excellent wounds: and indeed what are they but even sweete wounds by which not death but life enters into their secret parts.Gregor. Nyssen. Homil. 4. in Can. But in shooting these arrows let it be the ayme of Preachers to shoote only at the vices of men, not at the men themselves. The history is of Alcon the Cretian, that when a dragon hath taken away his son, he killed the Dragon with his arrow, but did not hurt his Son and it was his naturall affection that put his art into him, of whom it is well said, ars erat esse patrem, it was his skill that he was a father. And let Preachers shew themselves to be fathers in their great love, killing the brood of the Dragon, sin in the hearers, but not hurting them by any ill affection toward them. Words of truth: secondly the Preacher here sheweth that it must be the care of Preachers to instruct the people in the words of truth, and that their words must be so acceptable, as that being true likewise, they may make the hearers to understand, what is the truth of religion. Lactantius noteth that the doctrine of Epicurus was chiefly followed,Lactant. Divin. Institut. l. 3. c. 16
non quia veri aliquid afferebat, sed quia multos ad populare nomen voluptatis invitabat, not because it afforded any truth, but because it invited many to the popular name of pleasure: and so it is with some Pteachers, who are much followed, not because they deliver that which is truth, but because that pleaseth the hearers which is delivered by them. Such a one Saint Gregory describing saith, qui magna de se sentiens sed vera de Domino ignorans, Gregor. Moral. l. 17. c. 3.
longe a fidei cognitione disjungitur, & tamen videri fidei praedicator conatur, who thinking great things of himself, but not knowing the true things of the Lord, is far devided from the knowledge of faith, and yet desireth to seeme a Preacher of the faith. But it must be the
care of good Preachers to withstand such, to shun their practise, to oppose their falshood, and to teach nothing but the words of truth. Lastly it may be noted here that the words of uprightnesse, and the words of truth must be joyned together: there must be a diligence as well to illighten the understanding in the knowledge of truth, as to direct the will a right in the wayes of vertue. The Lord saith in Jeremiah,
Jerem. 23.29. is not my word as fire? whereupon Origen noteth that the words of Preachers must be as fire: and as fire hath two properties to burn and to illighten, so saith he must the words of Preachers have. If thou dost only reproove the vices of men, and labour to bring them to uprightnesse of life,Origen. in Exod. Homil. 13. but dost not explaine unto them, that which is obscure in religion, thy fire burneth, but it doth not illighten. If thou expound the mysteries of religion unto them, but dost not strive to reforme their ill lives, thy fire illightneth, but it doth not burn. His words are the words of the Lord, who is carefull to observe both.

Vers. 11. The words of the wise are as goades: that is, to admonish and tell them of their errours, that goe out of the way; to quicken and stirre up those that are slow and dull in the way. And as if these things were a marke shewing, which are the words of the wise, Saint Hierome saith, Si cujus ergo sermo non pungit, sed oblectationem, Hieronym. in hunc vers. facit audientibus, iste non est sermo sapientis: verba quippe sapientum pungunt, ut stimuli, if therefore the speech of any one doe not prick, but cause delight unto the hearers, that is not the speech of one that is wise: for the words of the wise doe pricke as goads. Saint Cyprian therefore saith, accipe non diserta sed fortia, Cyprian. Epist. ad Donatum. take not those things which are eloquent, and serve to delight the ears, but those that are strong and powerfull, to work upon the heart, to wound and gall the conscience, to rouse a carnall security. Such goads were the words of Saint Peter, when they that heard them, were pricked in their hearts, and cryed out to Peter, and the rest of the Apostles, Men and brethren,
Acts. 2.37. what shall we doe? Of these goads, that is true, which from heaven was spoken to Saul, It is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.
Acts. 9.5. And as nailes fastned by the masters of the assemblies: the words of the wise being driven into the heart, are there fastned by the force of them. Saint Gregory therefore speaking of these words, saith, Matt. 3.7. an Joannis verba clavi non erant? were not the words of John the Baptist nailes, when he saith, Acts. 7.51. O generation of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come? Were not the words of Stephen nailes, when he saith, Yee doe alwayes resist the Holy Ghost? Were not the words of Paul nailes, when he saith, O yee foolish Galatians, who hath bewitched you?
Galat. 3.1. But nayles are used not only to pierce, but to adorne also, and this our translation may seem to imply, which addeth, by the masters of assemblies. The Originall also doth imply the same, where the word which is translated, fastned, properly signifieth, plantati, planted, there being in planting an adorning the ground, and that which setteth forth the art of them that are masters in their worke. Now indeed, what doth more adorne then the
words of the wise?August. ex Hom. 50. Homil. 26. Wherefore Saint Austin saith, quomodo terrenis ornamentis caro luxuriosa parvo tempore ornatur, sic anima sancta divinis sermonibus tanquam spiritualibus & aeternis bonorum operum margaritis componitur, as with earthly ornaments, the wanton flesh is adorned for a little time, so the holy soule is beautified by divine speeches, as it were with spirituall and eternall jewels of good works. The words of the wise are a treasure, out of which all kinds of ornaments may be taken. Acts. 15.32. Wherefore when it is said of Judas and Silas, that they exhorted the brethren with many words, and confirmed them, the Syriack reads it not verbo plurimo, with many words, but verbo divite, with rich words, as if it would expresse the rich ornaments that were in the treasure of their words. But to consider the word, as here our translation readeth it, fastned, it sheweth, that as the words of the wise, being goads, doe bring wanderers into the way, and hasten dullards in the way, so they doe settle them also in the right way, that they doe not easily loose the way againe. But these words whieh are rendred here, by the masters of the assemblies, in the originall doe afford divers translations. The Venetian translation reads it thus, and like nayles firmly fastned, sustinentibus collectam supellectilem, holding up the furniture that is gathered together, to adorne the house, taking the sense of the words from the metaphor of the nailes which the Preacher useth. The French translation reads it thus, les maistres qui ont fait des recueils, the masters who have made the gatherings, are as mailes fastned, as shewing the sense to be, that the words of the wise having gathered and recalled men from wandring, and being themselves as nailes fastened and established in the right way of vertue, doe also by their example strengthen and confirm others in it. Tremellius reads it lectissima most choice words, as shewing that the words of the wise are gathered out and chosen and fitted for the occasion, for the matters, for the persons, when, whereof, to whom they are delivered. But as I conceive there are two things here not unworthy to be considered of: first that the originall word here used is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 from the roote 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which is distinguished from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a word like unto it in signification, in that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth signify the gathering of those things, which are dispersed: but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the gathering of those things, which are not dispersed: wherefore it may seeme here to import rather the gathering of men back from their sinfull courses, by the words of the wise as goads pricking them, as nayles peircing them, and fastning upon them. The other thing to be considered is, that these words in the originall may be as well joyned with that which followeth after, as with that which goeth before. Arias Montanus pins them to the end of the verse, Hebr. 13.20. and reads it thus auctores collectionum dati sunt a pastore uno, the authours of the gatherings are givē from one shepheard, as shewing that it is from that great shepheard of the sheepe, the Lord Jesus Christ, that all inferiour shepheards are given to his Church & people. But other translations refer all to the beginning of the verse and give us to understand, that the words of the wise are given from one shepheard. Our translation
leaves it at liberty, either to refer the end of the verse to the words of the wise, or to the masters of the assemblyes. John. 10.16. If it be referred to the words of the wise, most true it is, that there is one fold and one shepheard, and that from this one shepheard, who is the wisedome of his father, and wisedome it self; all the words of the wise are given. Or else we may understand this one shepheard to be the sacred word of God, which though consisting of severall parts, yet is but one book, and from which as from the foundation of them, as from the rule that measureth them, all the words of the wise are given.Hieron. in Esaiam. c. 29. Thus doth Saint Hierome expound these words. Or else if we desire to apply the words unto inferiour shepheards, it commeth sometimes to passe, that where there are many teachers, the one opposeth the other, and what the one liketh the other disapprooveth? so that the words of the wise take not that good effect which otherwise they might. And therefore the Preacher may seeme to commend those words, which being delivered by one wise shepheard, are not disturbed by any other. Oecumenius considering the vision that happened to Saint Paul at his conversion,Acts. 9.3. Oecumen. ibi •
noteth that it was not done in the city, but on the way, ne aliis liceret alio modo narrare quod circa ipsum contigisset, sed ipse fide dignus esset ad referendum qui vidisset, that so diverse might not relate diversly that which had befallen him, but that himselfe might be worthy of credit in relating it, who had seen it. And doth it not sometimes come to passe that the words of wisedome have more happy successe when they are given under the credit of one faithfull shepheard, then when divers shepheards each seeking his owne credit, diminish the vertue of that which they utter.

Vers. 12. And further by these: by these heavenly and spirituall instructions, according as our Reinolds citing these words, expoundeth them, saying, Sapienter nos adhortaiur, ut studia salutaria, Reinold. de Rom. Eccles. idolola. praefatione. precepta faciliora, fructu perennia iis anteponamus, quorum infinita est investigatio, nec alius demum exitus quam labor & aerumna, the Preacher doth wisely exhort us, that we preferre saving studies, which are easily perceived, everlasting in their benefit, before those the search whereof is infinite, and the end whereof at last is no other then wearinesse and misery. By these, these contained within this booke;Tremell. in hunc vers. so Tremellius, saying, hisce documentis meis instruitor potius, quam incumbas cognoscendae & explorandae vanitati, quae inest aliis studiis omnibus, by these my instructions be admonished rather, then bend thy paines to know and search out vanity, which is in all studies else. By these, these few words, this short booke be admonished, qui quantum dilatatur in sensibus; tantum constringitur in sermonihus, which by how much it is enlarged in the deep and copious sense and meaning of it, by so much it is straitned in the fewnesse of the words, and brevity of the speech,Hieron. in hunc vers. as teaching, saith Saint Hierome, brevitati studendum, & sensum magis sectandum esse quam verba, that brevitie is rather to be studied, and that sense and matter are rather to be sought for, then many words; because
otherwise there will be no end of books, no end of writing. By these, that is by these bookes of the Sacred Scriptures, saith Rabbi Salomon, Rabbi Salomon. which doe containe the sweete instructions and admonitions of happinesse and glory. But yet as Lyra well addeth, per hoc non excluduntur libri alii ad intellectum sacrae scripturae necessarii, sed illi qui non sunt ad salutem necessarii, by this are not excluded other bookes, which are necessary for the understanding of the scriptures, but those, which are not necessary unto salvation, & in making whereof there is no end, new difficulties arising continually.Lyra in hunc vers. By these, that is by these words, which are givē from one shepheard, and which being referred to him, though delivered in many bookes, yet make but one booke. For saith Saint Hierome, it is the manner of Scripture to cal many bookes one volume, if that they do not disagree the one from the other, and that they be written of the same thing. Yea, saith he, whatsoever thou shalt say, if it be referred unto him, who in the beginning was with God,
John. 1.1. and the word was God, it is one volume, and numberlesse bookes are called one law, one Gospel. But if thou shalt discourse of divers and disagreeing things, and by too much curiosity shalt be carried hither and thither in thy mind, etiam in uno libro multi libri sunt, Hieronym. in hunc vers. even in one booke there are many bookes. Of such bookes therefore there is no end. Bonum enim omne & veritas certo fine concluditur, malitia autem atque mendacium sine fine sunt, for all good and truth is contained within a certaine end, but wickednesse and untruth are without end, and by how much the more they are sought after, by so much the more they are to seeke. In this matter therefore saith Saint Hierome, study and meditation, labor est carnis, is a labour of the flesh. Of the flesh, saith he, not of the Spirit. For the spirit hath his labour also,1 Corinth. 15.10. according to that which the Apostle saith, I have laboured more then them all, yet not I, but the grace of God in me. This exposition Saint Hierome for his owne part preferreth before others. But let me note also,1 Timot. 1.2. how the Preacher here speaketh, saying, My Sonne: so that when Saint Paul calleth Timothy his Sonne, and when he saith of the Corinthians, 1 Corinth. 4.15. In Christ Jesus have I begotten you, through the Gospel, it is no new manner of speech. Clemens Alexandrinus noteth, apud barbaros quoque Philosophos per auditum instruere & illuminare dicitur regenerare, among the heathenish Philosophers, by hearing to instruct and to illuminate,Clemens. Alex. stromat. l. 5. is said to regenerate. To which purpose he citeth Socrates, who saith, Omnibus quidem esse immixtum naturalem amorem generandi simile, & hominibus quidem solum homines, viro autem bono similem sibi that there is infused into all a naturall love of begetting their like, into men of begetting men only, into a good man of begetting the like unto himselfe, by instructing of those that doe come unto him. But the phrase of speaking so is more ancient then Socrates, we have it here in Salomon, who making himselfe a Preacher, stileth those whom he instructeth his Sons. And let Preachers from hence learn, to carry themselves as Fathers towards their hearers, and let their words proceed from the sweetnes of a Fatherly affection towards them.
Saint Chrysostome observing that Moyses intending to reproove the people of Israel delivered a song unto them, and asking the reason, cur crimina objicit sub cantici nomine, Chrysost. in Esa. c. 1. Why he objecteth their faults unto them under the name of a song? he sheweth it to be the care of his spirituall wisdome, that so the musicke of the song might steale away the dislike of the reprehension. And indeed reproofe being harsh to humane nature, a harsh and fierce manner of using it doth often much hinder the good successe of it. Wherefore Saint Hierome saith, talis loquela non illuminat, non sanat, sed magis occidit, Hieronym. in Thren. c. 4.
atque in desperationem periclitantem mittit, such speaking doth not illighten, doth not heale, but killeth rather, and casteth into despaire him that is in danger. It is written of Domitian, that a boy holding for a mark a farre off his hand spread a broad, with the fingers severed, he shot his arrows so artificially that every arrow did hit on the empty spaces betweene the fingers, and that not one finger received any hurt by them. It must be the care of a Preacher to shoot his arrows, his words in the same manner, so that the empty spaces of sin, and which by sin are made empty of goodnesse may be hit and wounded, but that he leave the hand and fingers, that is, the mind and desire of working and doing well not wronged nor impaired.

q.p: Ver. 13. Let us heare the conclusion of the whole matter, feare God and keepe his commandements for this is the whole duety of man.
Ver. 14. For God shall bring every worke into judgement, and every secret thing, whether it be good, or whether it be evill.

div.p:
Ver. 13. The Jewes say as Saint Hierome relateth, that whereas among other bookes of Solomon which are lost and antiquated, this booke also should have been put away, because it affirmed the creatures of God to be vaine, and made all to be as it were nothing and preferred meate and drinke and fading delights before all things else,Hieronym. in hunc vers. yet from this one verse it obtained authority to be placed in the number of divine bookes because the Preacher shuts up his whole disputation and all his discours, with this summary conclusion, that the end of all speaking is this, to feare God and to keep his commandements. Let us heare the conclusion of the whol matter: the Originall word by word goeth thus, the end of the whol matter is heard: wherefore S. Hierome to expresse the force of it reads it thus, auditu perfacilis est, is easy to be heard. And indeed it seemeth to imply, that he would say was very short and that it would quickly
be heard, even so quickly as if it were already heard before that it were spoken. So that the words may seeme to carry this sense, you have heard me thus far, while that I have with many words spoken unto you, I will now ease your hearing, and end my speaking, if I may but say one word more. Feare God: there are many kinds of feare, a wordly feare, when a man rather then to forsake his owne contentment and ease, cares not to forsake God by forsaking his commandements: against which our Saviour Christ exhorteth saying, feare not them which kill the body,
Mat. 10.28. but are not able to kill the soule: but rather feare him who is able to destroy both body and soule in hell. A naturall feare, which Saint Basil Basil. saith, is the gift of God, the ornament of nature, by which we are warned and in some sort armed for the avoyding of evill, that may befall us.August. A servile feare, which Saint Austin defineth to be that, whereby goodnesse is not loved, but punnishment is only feared: and yet this is a good feare also. Wherefore Saint Ambrose Ambros. saith that the gloriours martyrs by this feare, the feare of hell torments where stengthned against the torments invented by man:Tertull. and this feare saith Tertullian is the instrument of repentance, the bridle of lust. An initiall feare, Prover. 1.7. to which we may apply those words in the Proverbs, the feare of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge: and which St. Basil Basil. cals an introductory feare, to lead us on to the more religious serving of God, so that it is composed partly of a servile partly of a filiall feare. Lastly there is a feare filial, a fear of God, as he is our Father, & wherby we are solicitous not to loose his favour, not to be deprived of his blessing. This by some is called reventialis timor, a reverencing feare, by others a chast feare, because it is like the feare of a chast wife, who feareth to loose her husbands love:Hieronym. in hunc vers. or else a chast and pure feare, as not mixed with a worldly and carnall feare. Now of this feare which Saint Hierome cals consummatum in virtutibus metum, a feare perfected in vertues, doth he understand this place, because the Preacher saith, that it is omnis homo the whole man. Or else he seemeth to understand the place of a servile feare, because it is said that this is omnis homo, that this is every man, this feare of God being inbred in every man. Feare God and keepe his commandements: man consisteth of two parts, his body and his soule, these two make up a whole man in nature, and here are two parts that make up a whole man in grace. The feare of God is as it were the body, the keeping of his commandements is as it were the soule. Lyra doth distinguish them thus,Lyra in hunc vers. the feare of God saith he, is to depart from evill, the keeping of his commandements is to be exercised in doing good, and these two parts of righteousnesse doe make up a perfect man in vertue. Or else we may distinguish them thus, to feare God, is in our hearts to serve him and honour him, to keepe his commandements is the outward demonstration of this inward devotion,Ludolphus de vita Christi. in the conversation and actions of our lifes to shew our selves his servants. For this is the whole duety of man: the Originall is no more then this, hoc est omnis homo this is every man. Some make up the sense thus, hoc, id est ad hoc this, that is to this,
to this end was every man made, doth every one live. Others make it up thus, hoc, id est per hoc, this, that is by this is every man, as conceiving the Preacher to shew, that this makes man to be, which is the proper glory of God. Quia quod Deus est per essentiam hoc etiam est obediens per participationem, because that which God is by his essence,Rupertus. he that is obedient is also made by participation and grace, by which we are made partakers of the divine nature. And as by obedience every man is, so the disobedient is one that is not. According as the Prophet Jeremy sheweth, who speaking of the disobedient saith, Jerem. 4.25. I looked and loe there was no man. Our translation maketh up the sense thus, this is the whole duety of man: and seeing the scope and drift of the Preacher in this booke is to shew the happinesse and chiefe good of man, perhaps it may not amisse be made up thus, this is the whole happinesse of man. But to take the words simply as the Originall hath set them downe, hoc est omnis homo, this is all man, that is saith Lyra, hoc est totus sive perfectus homo this is the whole or perfect man. For as the Philosopher speaketh,Lyra in hunc vers. totum & perfectum sunt idem, the whole and a thing perfect are one and the same thing. Wherefore saith Lyra, the tearme of that which is universally whole, is used here for that which is integrally whole, there being but one word in the Hebrew toung,Arist. Metaph. 5 which is used to signifie both of them. Or else if we will take it as yet more literally, and take the Hebrew 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for omnis as it signifieth all universally, so that we conceive the Preacher to import, that this is the very nature and essence of man; even in this manner also it may be not improperly construed. For what is the nature of man, but to be animal rationale, a reasonable living creature? And what is more reasonable then that God should be feared, and his commandements kept by man? what can be more unreasonable, then that the creature should deny this reverence & obededience to God his creatour?

Ver. 14. For God: judgement belongeth unto God, man must take heed how he meddle with it. Wherefore Saint Paul, saith judge nothing before the time, Corinth. 4.5. untill the Lord come who will bring to light the hidden things of darkenesse, and will make manifest the counsels of the hearts, and then shall every man have praise of God. For as Saint Ambrose saith very well, upon those words, injuria judicis est si ante cognitionem ejus, à servo procedat judicium, it is a wrong to the judge,Ambros. if before he heare and know the cause, judgement be given by a servant. And being a wrong to the judge, it cannot but be a mischiefe to him that shall doe it. Wherefore good is the counsell of Paschasius, declinemus ad praesens sententiam, subtrahamus judicium, dicamus totum Deo, Paschas. l. 2. Matthae. ne dum temere gestimus definire sententiam, nobis paremus ex discrimine alieno ruinam, for the present let us shun to give sentence, let us forbear to judge, let us say, let God doe all, lest while we rashly desire to give sentence, we bring upon our selves ruine from anothers danger. God shall bring: loath is guilty man to come into judgement, and therefore he cryeth to the hils to cover him to the mountaines to fall upon him: but mountaines
and hils and all shall forsake him and God shall bring him to it. The best way therefore is, of our selves before hand to goe unto his judgement, and in our owne hearts to arraigne our selves before God for that it is which will make his judgement to be comfortable to us. The Psalmist speaking of some saith, they looked unto him and were lightned, and their faces were not ashamed. And surely they who looke unto God, Psal. 34.5. and doe now behold him sitting upon his judgement seate, and consider themselves as standing before him to give an accompt of their lives unto him, they are they who when God shall bring them to judgement shall be illigthned with joy, and shall not have their faces confounded. For as Saint Bernard speaketh, diligit Deus animam quae in conspectu ejus, sine intermissione considerat, & sine dissimulatione dijudicat seipsam, God loveth that soule, which in his sight as well without intermission considereth, as without dissimulation judgeth it selfe. God shall bring every work: not only the bad works of the wicked, but the good works of the righteous, as from the last words of the verse may also be gathered. In the seventy fifth Psalme the second verse we read it, when I shall receive the congregation, I will judge rightly, but the Originall is rectitudines judicabo, Bernard. Serm. 3. in Advent. I will judge the rightnesse of things, and the vulgar Latin reads it justitias judicabo, I will judg the righteousnesse of things. Whereupon Hugo Cardinalis saith, terribile verbum, quod non tantum peccata sed & justitias judicabit, bona scilicet opera examinabit, it is a terrible word, Psal. 75.2. that he will not only judge sins, but the righteousnesse of things, and will examine the good works of men. Every work of every man will he bring to judgement, even those which now seeme to be little, and not worthy the taking notice of. Wherefore the Prophet David saith, O Lord thou hast searched me and knowne me, thou knowest my downe sitting and mine uprising.
